<H>A
<>DICTIONARY,
<>SANSKRIT AND ENGLISH,
<>EXTENDED AND IMPROVED FROM THE SECOND EDITION OF THE DICTIONARY
<>OF
<>PROFESSOR H. H. WILSON,
<>WITH HIS SANCTION AND CONCURRENCE,
<>TOGETHER WITH
<>A SUPPLEMENT, GRAMMATICAL APPENDICES AND AN INDEX,
<>SERVING AS
<>AN ENGLISH-SANSKRIT VOCABULARY.
<>BY
<>THEODOR GOLDSTÜCKER,
<>PH. D., PROFESSOR OF THE SANSKRIT LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE IN
<>UNIVERSITY COLLEGE, LONDON.
<>BERLIN:
<>A. ASHER AND CO.,
<>(ALBERT COHN AND DANIEL COLLIN)
<>LONDON:
<>DAVID NUTT.
<>MDCCCLVI.
[Pagetitle-ii+ 18]
;
; DEDICATION
;
<>TO
<>HORACE HAYMAN WILSON, ESQ., M. A., F. R. S.,
<>PRESIDENT OF THE ROYAL ASIATIC SOCIETY, HONORARY MEMBER OF THE ASIATIC SOCIETIES OF CALCUTTA AND PARIS AND OF THE ORIENTAL
<>SOCIETY OF GERMANY, FOREIGN MEMBER OF THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FRANCE, MEMBER OF THE IMPERIAL ACADEMIES OF
<>PETERSBURGH AND VIENNA, AND OF THE ROYAL ACADEMIES OF MUNICH AND BERLIN, PH. D. BRESLAU,
<>M. D. MARBURG &C. &C. AND BODEN PROFESSOR OF SANSKRIT IN THE UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD:
<>THE ILLUSTRIOUS SCHOLAR
<>WHO HAS LAID THE FOUNDATIONS OF SANSKRIT LEXICOGRAPHY
<>AND WHO, DURING HALF A CENTURY OF UNTIRING ACTIVITY,
<>BY DEVOTING THE GREAT RESOURCES OF HIS GENIUS, LEARNING AND INFLUENCE
<>TO THE ADVANCEMENT OF SANSKRIT PHILOLOGY.
<>HAS ENTITLED HIMSELF TO THE GRATITUDE OF ALL WHO TAKE AN INTEREST
<>IN THE RELIGION AND LITERATURE OF ANCIENT INDIA.
<>THIS WORK
<>IS INSCRIBED
<>AS A MARK OF PROFOUND RESPECT AND A TESTIMONY OF SINCERE AFFECTION
<>BY
<>THE AUTHOR.
[Pagetitle-iii+ 45]
;
; PREFACE
;
<H>PRELIMINARY REMARKS.
<P>In 1850 Professor WILSON authorized the late Mr. ASHER, of Berlin, to publish a new edition of his Sanskrit
<>and English Dictionary, the second edition having been out of print for many years. As the illustrious author, how-
<>ever, was prevented by his various duties from devoting the requisite time to preparing this edition, I was invited
<>to carry out the intended plan.
<P>According to this plan, the second edition of the Dictionary was to be reprinted in its original form, while I was
<>to superintend the impression, and make such corrections, alterations and additions as might seem advisable. But as
<>a leading object with the publisher was to supply the work within the shortest possible time, it was urged that the ad-
<>ditions, in order not to cause any great delay, were not to exceed the materials I might happen already to possess
<>or which might present themselves incidentally during the progress of the work.
<P>Had this plan been adhered to on my part, it might, no doubt, long since have been easily accomplished. Yet
<>when I resolved on a protracted residence in London, and thus found it in my power to turn to account printed and
<>unprinted books which could not be had on the continent, I thought it incumbent on me to improve the opportunity and
<>to advise the publisher to forego considerations of speed for what I believed to be a more lasting service to the student
<>of Sanskrit literature and philology. I proposed therefore not merely to embody in the intended work the materials I
<>possessed and which, having been collected for different purposes, would not always suffice for the requirements of
<>lexicography, but to extend them, to enlarge the substance of the second edition within its own sphere, and also to
<>introduce into it matter from those portions of Sanskrit literature which Professor WILSON had not deemed it necessary
<>to resort to at the time he published his work. I was informed, it is true, that causes over which I had no control,
<>would not allow me to go beyond certain limits of space or to alter the character of the previous Dictionary by making
<>references to the original authorities from which the information was derived, and therefore that I could not incorporate
<>in the results of my labour more complete indices of special works than were absolutely requisite; still I believed that
<>in spite of these limitations, it might be possible to adapt the intended work to the more pressing actual wants of the
<>Sanskrit philologer.
<P>That these alterations were sanctioned by Professor WILSON himself, it is almost needless to say. But I owe
<>it to the memory of the late Mr. ASHER to state that he readily waived the advantages derivable from a more expe-
<>ditious publication for the literary considerations which I had suggested.
<P>Circumstances, however, intervened which caused a still greater delay than I had anticipated. It was obvious
<>that to correct in the second edition such errors as could not but be expected in a work of this magnitude, and to do
<>so on my own responsibility, no other course was open to me than to examine the Dictionary word for word and meaning
<>for meaning, in other terms, to trace its entire contents as far as possible to the sources from which they were taken.
<>Unfortunately the Indices prepared in India by Professor WILSON were, with few exceptions, no longer available; I was
<>obliged therefore to give additional time to collecting the materials required for a proper discharge of my duty in this
<>respect. Another circumstance must be adverted to. In the existing editions of his Dictionary Professor WILSON has
<>excluded, on principle, words relating to the Vaidik literature, more especially to those works which bear the technical
<>name of Vedas. Notwithstanding the extension I proposed to give to his work, I still approved of this principle also
<>for the new Dictionary; I may add that the first pages of my MS. were written in accordance with it. Subsequent
<>experience, however, of the treatment which this portion of the literature has undergone in other quarters, has im-
<>posed upon me the moral obligation of allotting even to words of the Vaidik period a large share in the present work
<>and, as a consequence, to increase materials I possessed, but on which it was not originally intended to bestow special
<>labour and time. I now propose, in the Dictionary and {%its Supplement,%} to provide the student with the interpretation of
<>the principal Vaidik words that may be desired for the perusal of the Vaidik hymns and the chief works of the oldest
<>literature. Those alone will remain excluded the meaning of which could not be given on safe grounds as, in general,
<>it did not seem expedient to me, to admit into a Dictionary devoid of quotations, words the sense of which could not
<>be ascertained satisfactorily.
[Pagetitle-iv+ 48]
<P>A detailed account of the materials used in the present work must necessarily be deferred to a later date. I
<>embrace, however, the opportunity now offered me, to express my obligation to Dr. TH. AUFRECHT for the kindness
<>with which he allowed me the use of his Indices of the Hārāvalī, Trikāṇḍaśeṣa, Bṛhad-and Chhāndogya-Upanishads
<>and of the Vājasaneyisamhitā, as well as to Mr. CH. CASSAL for the assistance I have derived from an elaborate Index
<>he has made of Hemachandra's Anekārtha and which, according to a recent advertisement of Mr. S. AUSTIN'S at Hertford,
<>is now in course of publication together with the Anekārtha themselves, an Index and improvements of former editions
<>of the Abhidhānachintāmaṇi.
<P>The reasons which have induced me to base the etymological and generally the grammatical portion of the work
<>on the native authorities, to retain the technical terms of Pāṇini's school, to accompany the crude forms of the com-
<>pounds with their grammatical names, and to adopt a technical method of marking certain Upapada-compounds, not to
<>accentuate the words in the Dictionary,--these and other topics relating to its interior economy will have to be explained
<>in the Preface, although some of them may be gathered indirectly from a critical pamphlet the first part of which will
<>soon appear.
<P>The comparatively short time placed at my disposal for the preparatory labour and the considerations I had to
<>yield to when I allowed the printing to being, have forced upon me the necessity of adding to the Dictionary a Supple-
<>ment which to judge from the increase of matter since the first sheets were struck off will become a rather extensive one.
<>Having to choose between suppressing the additional matter which will accrue during the progress of the work, and
<>claiming the indulgence of the reader for the inconvenience of a Supplement, I could not hesitate in deciding on the
<>latter alternative. The Supplement will enable me, too, to supply omissions made inadvertently and to avoid the con-
<>sequence of excluding altogether those words or meanings which I might not feel justified in giving at the time being
<>on the score of doubtful authorities and which I preferred therefore to reserve till I could apply to them the result of more
<>extended research. Subjoined to the Supplement will be Appendices containing an explanation of the technical terms used
<>in the Dictionary, etymological essays, a treatise on the accentuation &c., and lastly an Index of English words referring
<>to the Sanskrit word the meaning of which they represent with the number of the page, column and line.
<P>These brief remarks will indicate my plan so far as it is necessary here; they will not, however, convey an
<>impression of the assistance I have derived from and the obligation which I owe to the previous editions of Professor
<>WILSON'S Dictionary. It would be unbecoming, on my part, in my present relation to these works, to speak of the
<>care, the conscientiousness and the scholarship which they so eminently combine; but, on the other hand I should be
<>wanting in justice were I to conceal the conviction I entertain that they have been the safest guide I could have found
<>when entering upon the present task, or were I not to mention that the changes I have introduced are owing, not to
<>the objection I make against the principle on which they are framed, but either to personal views or to the claims of
<>the actual condition of Sanskrit philology. But still less will these remarks be able to testify the gratitude which I
<>feel to the illustrious and venerable scholar himself. I have not only enjoyed, at all times, the benefit of his great literary
<>experience and of his invaluable advice, but he has manifested his active interest and concurrence in the present work
<>in taking upon himself the labour of correcting the printed proofs; above all, his spirit of genuine kindness and his rare
<>liberality have left on my mind impressions so lasting and profound that it will always give me the most heartfelt satis-
<>faction to look upon whatever good may arise from this book as virtually produced by him.
<P>I must also record the sense I entertain of the services of my present publishers. After a premature death had
<>closed the active career of Mr. ASHER, they have not merely taken up his plan but entered into it with the same zeal
<>and intelligence. I cannot forego the pleasure of mentioning the handsome manner in which they have allowed all the
<>literary considerations I have suggested to prevail over personal interest, and their ready acquiescence in the long and
<>unexpected delay; for no one can feel more convinced than I am, that without this friendly and scientific disposition
<>on their part--and I may add, too, without the creditable manner in which the printer acquits himself of his portion
<>of the duty--the irksome mechanical toil which is so abundantly inflicted upon the author of a lexicographical work would
<>probably not have failed to leave its unpleasant traces in the labour itself still more than, I fear, may actually be the case.
<>University College, London,
<>June, the 30th, 1856.
<HS>TH. GOLDSTÜCKER.
[Page001-a+ 41]
<H>A
<>DICTIONARY,
<>SANSKRIT AND ENGLISH.
<H>{#a#}

<L>1<pc>001-a<k1>a<k2>a
{#a#}¦ I. The letter {%ă,%} the first of the alphabet and the short
<div n="lb">vowel inherent in every consonant. See {#akAra#}.
<div n="P">II. The pronominal theme which occurs in the declension of
<div n="lb">{#idam#} and is considered as a substitute for {#idam#} and {#etat#} qq. vv.
<div n="P">III. ind. ({#nipAta#}) A particle, a shorter form of {#na#} (see also
<div n="lb">{#ana#} and {#anA#}); it is used <sup>1</sup> In composition with nouns, when
<div n="lb">it implies <sup>a.</sup> Negation. <sup>b.</sup> Privation or prohibition. <sup>c.</sup> Diminu-
<div n="lb">tion (i. e. a little). <sup>d.</sup> Deterioration. <sup>e.</sup> Similarity or comparison;
<div n="lb">in a few instances it has apparently become an expletive; cf.
<div n="lb">e. g. {#kupya#} and {#akupya, udAra#} and {#anudAra, eqamUka#} and {#aneqamUka#}.
<div n="lb">If the noun begins with a vowel, it assumes the form of {#an,#}
<div n="lb">as {#a#} and {#anta#} form {#ananta;#} this rule is neglected sometimes,
<div n="lb">if the vowel following the {#a#} happen to be a {#f;#} e. g. {#a#} and
<div n="lb">{#fRin#} form {#anfRin#} and sometimes {#afRin#}. <sup>2</sup> In con-
<div n="lb">junction with an inflected verb, when it implies blame or re-
<div n="lb">proach; e. g. {#a karozi vE tvaM jAlma#} ‘how badly thou dost
<div n="lb">(it), fool’. Accord. to an artificial E. from {#at,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}.
<div n="P">IV. ind. ({#nipAta#}) An interjection of pity.
<div n="P">V. 1. m. ({#aH#}) <sup>1</sup> Vaiśvānara (in an Upan.). <sup>2</sup> Brahman (m.).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Viṣṇu. <sup>4</sup> Siva. 2. n. ({#am#}) A name of the (neuter) Brahman.
<LEND>

<L>2<pc>001-a<k1>afRin<k2>afRin
{#afRin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-RI-RinI-Ri#}) Free from debt
<div n="lb">or obligation; also {#anfRin#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#fRin#}.
<LEND>

<L>3<pc>001-a<k1>aMS<k2>aMS (aMSa-curAdi-parasmEpadin)
{#aMS (aMSa-curAdi-parasmEpadin)#}¦ r. 10th cl. par. ({#aMSayati#} or
<div n="lb">{#aMSApayati-#} p. p. {#aMSita#}) To divide, to distribute.
<LEND>

<L>4<pc>001-a<k1>aMSa<k2>aMSa
{#aMSa#}¦ I. m. ({#-SaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Dividing, distributing. <sup>2</sup> A part. <sup>3</sup> A share
<div n="lb">or portion. <sup>4</sup> A fraction. <sup>5</sup> The numerator of a fraction.
<div n="lb"><sup>6</sup> A degree (of latitude or longitude, &c.). <sup>7</sup> The name of an
<div n="lb">Āditya. <sup>8</sup> (In music.) See {#aMSasvara#}. Also confounded with
<div n="lb">{#aMsa#} q. v. E. {#aMS,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY,#} or perhaps more correctly,
<div n="lb">{#am,#} uṇ(?) aff. {#Sa#}.
<div n="P">II. m. n. ({#-SaH-Sam#}) The shoulder, the shoulder blade.
<div n="lb">(In this sense the word is more correctly written {#aMsa#} q. v.)
<LEND>

<L>5<pc>001-a<k1>aMSaka<k2>aMSaka
{#aMSaka#}¦ I. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A part. <sup>2</sup> An heir, a kinsman, a relation.
<div n="lb">E. {#aMSa,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-kam#}) A day. E. {#aMS,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>6<pc>001-a<k1>aMSakaraRa<k2>aMSakaraRa
{#aMSakaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) The dividing into shares. E. {#aMSa#}
<div n="lb">and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>
[Page001-b+ 37]

<L>7<pc>001-b<k1>aMSaBAj<k2>aMSaBAj
{#aMSaBAj#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#BAk#}) An heir, a coheir, one who has
<div n="lb">a share or portion. E. {#aMS#} and {#BAj#}.
<LEND>

<L>8<pc>001-b<k1>aMSala<k2>aMSala

<L>9<pc>001-b<k1>aMSavat<k2>aMSavat

<L>10<pc>001-b<k1>aMSasavarRana<k2>aMSasavarRana
{#aMSasavarRana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Assimilation of fractions, ren-
<div n="lb">dering fractions homogeneous, reduction of them to uni-
<div n="lb">formity. E. {#aMSa#} and {#savarRana#}.
<LEND>

<L>11<pc>001-b<k1>aMSasvara<k2>aMSasvara
{#aMSasvara#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-raH#}) (In music.) The tonic or modal
<div n="lb">note. It is defined as ‘the note which displays the pecu-
<div n="lb">liar melody and to which all the others are subordinate’.
<div n="lb">Also written {#aMsasvara#}. E. {#aMSa#} and {#svara#}.
<LEND>

<L>12<pc>001-b<k1>aMSahara<k2>aMSahara
{#aMSahara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) A sharer, a divider, a coheir. E.
<div n="lb">{#aMSa#} and {#hara#}.
<LEND>

<L>13<pc>001-b<k1>aMSahArin<k2>aMSahArin

<div n="lb">{#hArin#}.

<L>16<pc>001-b<k1>aMSu<k2>aMSu
{#aMSu#}¦ m. ({#-SuH#}) <sup>1</sup> A ray of light, a sun- or moon-beam. <sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb">sun. <sup>3</sup> Light, splendour, effulgence. <sup>4</sup> Any thing minute or
<div n="lb">pointed (as a sun-beam). <sup>5</sup> A small end of thread, a small
<div n="lb">filament &c. <sup>6</sup> Dress, decoration. <sup>7</sup> The name of one of the
<div n="lb">Grahas (q. v.) which serve for making libations with the
<div n="lb">juice of the Soma plant. <sup>8</sup> The name of a Rishi. <sup>9</sup> The name
<div n="lb">of a prince, son of Puruhotra. E. {#aMS,#} uṇ. aff. {#ku,#} or {#am,#}
<div n="lb">uṇ. aff. {#ku,#} āgama {#Suk#}.
<LEND>

<L>17<pc>001-b<k1>aMSuka<k2>aMSuka
{#aMSuka#}¦ n. ({#-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Fine cloth, muslin. <sup>2</sup> Cloth in general. <sup>3</sup> A
<div n="lb">mantle, a wrapper, a linen garment worn round the upper
<div n="lb">part of the body. <sup>4</sup> White cloth. <sup>5</sup> The leaf of the Laurus
<div n="lb">Cassia. E. {#aMSu,#} taddh. aff. {#ka#}. Acc. to another E. a Tatpur.
<div n="lb">composed of {#aMSu#} and {#ka#} ({#kAS,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}).
<LEND>

<L>31<pc>002-a<k1>aMsa<k2>aMsa
{#aMsa#}¦ I. m. n. ({#-saH-sam#}) 1. The shoulder, the scapula; it is mentioned
<div n="lb">in medic. amongst those {#marman#} (q. v.) the wounding of which
<div n="lb">produces lameness or palsy. 2. (m.) One of the angles of the
<div n="lb">{#vedi#} (q. v.), compared to a shoulder. E. {#am,#} uṇ. aff. {#san#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-saH#}) 1. A part, a portion &c. See {#aMSa#}. (In this mean-
<div n="lb">ing the word is more correctly written {#aMSa#}.) 2. The name
<div n="lb">of a king, acc. to some, a son of Anu. E.(?).
<LEND>

<L>32<pc>002-a<k1>aMsakUwa<k2>aMsakUwa
{#aMsakUwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-waH#}) A bull's hump, the protuberance
<div n="lb">between the shoulders of the Indian ox. E. {#aMsa#} and {#kUwa#}.

<L>33<pc>002-a<k1>aMsatra<k2>aMsatra

<div n="lb">{#aMsa#} and {#tra;#} also derived, though without probability, from
<div n="lb">{#aMhas#} (changed to {#aMsa#}) and {#tra,#} as preserving from evil.

<L>34<pc>002-a<k1>aMsaPalaka<k2>aMsaPalaka
{#aMsaPalaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) (In medic.) The upper part of the spinal
<div n="lb">column; it is mentioned amongst those {#marman#} (q. v.) the wound-
<div n="lb">ing of which produces lameness or palsy. E. {#aMsa#} and {#Palaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>35<pc>002-a<k1>aMsaBAra<k2>aMsaBAra

<div n="lb">bliss. E. {#a#} neg. and {#karmaBoga#}.

<L>171<pc>005-b<k1>akz<k2>akz (akzU-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)

<div n="lb">{#--akzitvA#} or {#azwvA#}.--p. p. {#azwa#}.--Caus. {#akzayati-#}

<div n="lb">obtain. <sup>2</sup> To pervade. <sup>3</sup> To accumulate. With {#sam#}. To
<div n="lb">pervade.

<L>172<pc>005-b<k1>akza<k2>akza
{#akza#}¦ I. m. ({#-kzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A die, cubic or oblong, for playing with.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Beleric myrobalan (Terminalia belerica), a tree bearing
<div n="lb">a medicinal fruit, which is used also as a die. <sup>3</sup> A plant
<div n="lb">(Elaeocarpus Ganitrus). <sup>4</sup> The seed of this plant of which
<div n="lb">rosaries are made. In this sense it mostly occurs in com-
<div n="lb">position, as Rudrākṣa, Indrākṣa qq. vv. <sup>5</sup> The name of
<div n="lb">a weight, a Karsha or sixteen māṣas.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-kzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A wheel. <sup>2</sup> The axle of a wheel. <sup>3</sup> A car.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> A snake. <sup>5</sup> A name of Garuḍa. <sup>6</sup> A proper name, be-
<div n="lb">longing to several persons, as to the son of Rāvaṇa, to a
<div n="lb">prince, son of Nara &c. <sup>7</sup> Terrestrial latitude. <sup>8</sup> The string
<div n="lb">that supports the two shafts of the handle of a balance in
<div n="lb">which the axis of the beam is lodged. <sup>9</sup> The lower part
<div n="lb">of the temples.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-kzam#}) <sup>1</sup> An eye. <sup>2</sup> An organ of sense. <sup>3</sup> Any
<div n="lb">thing perceptible by the senses. <sup>4</sup> Sochal salt. <sup>5</sup> Blue vitriol.
<div n="P">IV. Tatpur. m. ({#-kzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The soul. <sup>2</sup> Knowledge, especially
<div n="lb">sacred knowledge. <sup>3</sup> Law suit, legal procedings.
<div n="P">V. m. ({#-kzaH#}) A person born blind.
<div n="P">VI. (In <sup>1</sup> Bahuvrīhi and <sup>2</sup> Avyayībhāva compositions as a
<div n="lb">substitute for {#akzi,#} samāsta aff. <sup>1</sup> {#zac#} and <sup>2</sup> {#wac#}) An eye.
<div n="P">E. {#akza#} ‘die’ is stated to be derived from {#aS,#} uṇ. aff. {#sa#}.
<div n="lb">For the etymology of this word see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>173<pc>005-b<k1>akzaka<k2>akzaka

<div n="lb">that plant; or the termination being a pleonastic affix, the
<div n="lb">word may have all the senses of the preceding. Also read
<div n="lb">{#akzika#}.

<L>212<pc>006-b<k1>akzara<k2>akzara

<div n="lb">alphabet. <sup>7</sup> A syallable. <sup>8</sup> The syllable om. <sup>9</sup> A vowel. <sup>10</sup> A

<div n="lb"><sup>12</sup> Water (see {#akzita#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#kzara#}. (The gramm.
<div n="lb">author. derive this word from {#aS (aSU),#} uṇ. aff. {#sara#} or

[Page007-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">which has not been obtained artificially. See {#kzAra#} and
<div n="lb">{#lavaRa#}. E. {#akzAra#} (which is explained as {#a#} neg. and {#kzAra#}
<div n="lb">artificial(?) and {#lavaRa,#} or better: {#a#} neg. and {#kzAralavaRa#}
<div n="lb">(Dvandva): neither {#kzAra#} nor {#lavaRa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Such food as may be eaten during a season
<div n="lb">considered impure or improper for the performance of re-
<div n="lb">ligious duties, as a season of mourning &c. (See {#aSOca#}.)
<div n="lb">It is said to consist of cows milk, ghee, rice, kidney-beans,
<div n="lb">barley, sesamum, and sea or river salt. The word occurs
<div n="lb">also written {#akzArAlavaRa#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#kzAralavaRa#} (Dvan-
<div n="lb">dva), sc. {#anna#}.
<LEND>

<L>319<pc>009-a<k1>agasti<k2>agasti
{#agasti#}¦ m. ({#-stiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a saint and reputed author
<div n="lb">of several hymns of the Rigveda, celebrated in Hindu my-
<div n="lb">thology, more usually entitled Agastya, and considered as
<div n="lb">the son of both Mitra and Varuṇa, by Urvaśī; hence his
<div n="lb">names Maitrāvaruṇi and Aurvaśīya. He is represented of
<div n="lb">short stature, and is said by some to have been born in a
<div n="lb">water jar; hence his names Kumbhasambhava, Ghaṭod-
<div n="lb">bhava &c. He is famed for having swallowed the ocean,
<div n="lb">when it had given him offence, wherefore he is called Pī-
<div n="lb">tābdhi. At his command the Vindhya range of mountains
<div n="lb">prostrated itself, and so remains; hence his present appel-
<div n="lb">lation. He is also mentioned as one of the oldest medical
<div n="lb">authors, considered as the civilisor of the South and as
<div n="lb">the regent of the star Canopus. <sup>2</sup> The name of a tree
<div n="lb">(Sesbana grandiflora). <sup>3</sup> m. plur. {#agastayaH#} are the descendants
<div n="lb">of Agasti. See {#Agastya#}. E. {#aga#} (mountain) and {#as#} (to
<div n="lb">throw), uṇ. aff. {#ti--:#} Agastya having ordered the Vindhya
<div n="lb">mountain to prostrate itself before him; or according to
<div n="lb">others, a Tatpur. composed of {#aga#} (water jar) and {#stya#}
<div n="lb">(from {#styE#} to condense): from his being kept and born in a wa-
<div n="lb">ter jar. (Both etymologies are apparently artificial and with-
<div n="lb">out any grammatical evidence.) See also {#agastya#} and {#agastI#}.
<LEND>

<L>320<pc>009-a<k1>agastidru<k2>agastidru
{#agastidru#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-druH#}) A tree (Sesbana grandiflora). See
<div n="lb">{#agasti#}. E. {#agasti#} and {#dru#}.
<LEND>
[Page009-b+ 56]

<L>349<pc>010-a<k1>agnAyI<k2>agnAyI

<LEND>

<L>350<pc>010-a<k1>agnAvizRu<k2>agnAvizRu
{#agnAvizRu#}¦ Dvandva. m. du. ({#-zRU#}) Agni and Viṣṇu qq. vv. E.
<div n="lb">{#agni#} (changed to {#agnA#}) and {#vizRu#}.
<LEND>

<L>351<pc>010-a<k1>agni<k2>agni
{#agni#}¦ m. ({#-gniH#}) <sup>1</sup> Fire; the fire for common use (or {#lOkika#})
<div n="lb">as well as the fire for sacrificial purposes (or {#vEdika#}) of
<div n="lb">which there are three kinds: the Gārhapatya, the Āhava-
<div n="lb">nīya and the Dakṣiṇāgni (qq. vv.). <sup>2</sup> The deity of fire, one
<div n="lb">of the most ancient and most sacred objects of Hindu wor-
<div n="lb">ship. As such Agni is considered as the mediator between
<div n="lb">men and gods, as protector of mankind and their home,
<div n="lb">and as witness of their actions; hence his invocation at all
<div n="lb">solemn occasions, at the nuptial ceremony &c. He is one
<div n="lb">of the eight Lokapālas or guardians of the world and especi-
<div n="lb">ally the Lord of the south-east quarter. He appears in the
<div n="lb">progress of mythological personification as a son of Angiras,
<div n="lb">as a king of the Pitṛs or Manes, as a Marut, as a grand-
<div n="lb">son of Śanḍila, as one of the seven Sages or Ṛṣis during
<div n="lb">the reign of Tāmasa or the fourth Manu, as a star and as
<div n="lb">a Ṛṣi or inspired author of several vaidic hymns. <sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb">fire of the stomach, the digestive faculty. <sup>4</sup> Bile. <sup>5</sup> Gold. <sup>6</sup> A
<div n="lb">plant of which the fruit has escharotic properties (Seme-
<div n="lb">carpus anacardium). See {#BallAtaka#}. <sup>7</sup> Another plant (Plum-
<div n="lb">bago zeylanica). See {#citraka#}. <sup>8</sup> Another plant (Plumbago
<div n="lb">rosea). <sup>9</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes used as) a denomination
<div n="lb">of the numeral three (because there are three sacred fires;
<div n="lb">see above). E. {#aNg,#} uṇ. aff. {#ni,#} the nasal of the root being
<div n="lb">dropped.
<LEND>

<L>352<pc>010-a<k1>agnika<k2>agnika
{#agnika#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) An insect of a scarlet color, the lady-bird.
<div n="lb">E. {#agni,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#} (resembling fire).
<LEND>

<L>353<pc>010-a<k1>agnikaRa<k2>agnikaRa
{#agnikaRa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-RaH#}) A spark. E. {#agni#} and {#kaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>354<pc>010-a<k1>agnikarman<k2>agnikarman
{#agnikarman#}¦ Tatpur. ({#-rma#}) <sup>1</sup> The action of Agni or fire. <sup>2</sup> (In
<div n="lb">medicine.) Application of fire for cure, cauterization. E.
<div n="lb">{#agni#} and {#karman#}.
<LEND>
[Page010-b+ 56]

<L>355<pc>010-b<k1>agnikArikA<k2>agnikArikA
{#agnikArikA#}¦ Tatpur. ({#-kA#}) Kindling or exciting the sacri-
<div n="lb">ficial fire, by throwing clarified butter &c. into it. E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#kArikA#}.
<LEND>

<L>366<pc>010-b<k1>agnicayana<k2>agnicayana
{#agnicayana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Arranging the fire-place, a sa-
<div n="lb">crificial ceremony, viz. arranging on a piece of ground of
<div n="lb">merely a fathom's length, which must have been previously
<div n="lb">ploughed, consecrated bricks (see {#izwakA#}), so as to make
<div n="lb">them to imitate the shape of a bird. There are five or in
<div n="lb">some case, six such chitis (q. v.) required for receiving the
<div n="lb">sacrificial fire. E. {#agni#} (in the sense of the dat.) and {#cayana#}.

<L>401<pc>011-b<k1>agnipraRayana<k2>agnipraRayana
{#agnipraRayana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Carrying forth the sacrificial
<div n="lb">fire, a ceremony occurring in several sacrifices, as in the
<div n="lb">Jyotiṣṭoma, the Darśapūrṇamāsa, the Chāturmāsya. It
<div n="lb">consists in taking the fire from the Prāchīnavanśa (q. v.)
<div n="lb">Manḍapa, a building erected in the centre of the Dārśikī
<div n="lb">Vedi (q. v.) and carrying it to the Āgnīdhra (q. v.) Man-
<div n="lb">ḍapa, which stands in the Saumikī Vedi (q. v.). E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#praRayana#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">band. E. {#agni#} and {#praveSa#}. Also {#agnipraveSana#} n. ({#-nam#}).

<L>407<pc>011-b<k1>agniBU<k2>agniBU
{#agniBU#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-BUH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Skanda, the Hindu
<div n="lb">deity of war. See {#kArttikeya, skanda, agnijanman#}. (Śiva hav-
<div n="lb">ing cast his seed into flame, for the purpose of generating
<div n="lb">a warrior, able to subdue Tāraka, a demon, Skanda was
<div n="lb">produced.) <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes used to denote) the
<div n="lb">numeral six (Skanda having six faces).
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-Bu#}) Water (rain being generated, according to
<div n="lb">the Hindu belief from the clouds which are produced by
<div n="lb">the smoke of fire). E. {#agni#} and {#BU#} (generating from).
<LEND>

<L>408<pc>011-b<k1>agniBUti<k2>agniBUti
{#agniBUti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-tiH#}) A proper name, viz. one of the
<div n="lb">pupils of the last Tīrthakara, belonging to the family of
<div n="lb">Gotama and being one of the eleven chiefs of the gaṇas or
<div n="lb">companies of the Jaina Ṛṣis. E. {#agni#} and {#BUti#} (super-
<div n="lb">human power): equal to Agni.
<LEND>

<L>409<pc>011-b<k1>agnimaRi<k2>agnimaRi

<L>410<pc>011-b<k1>agnimat<k2>agnimat

<L>416<pc>012-a<k1>agnimAruti<k2>agnimAruti
{#agnimAruti#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-tiH#}) A name of the saint Agastya.
<div n="lb">E. {#agni#} fire, i. e. the fire of the stomach, the digestive fa-
<div n="lb">culty, and {#mAruti#} a name of Hanumat; because the saint
<div n="lb">could digest as well as the monkey: the epithet alludes to
<div n="lb">a story of his devouring and digesting Vātāpi, a demon,
<div n="lb">who had assumed the form of a sheep.
<LEND>

<L>419<pc>012-a<k1>agnimuKa<k2>agnimuKa

<L>421<pc>012-a<k1>agniyojana<k2>agniyojana

<LEND>

<L>422<pc>012-a<k1>agnirakzaRa<k2>agnirakzaRa

<L>448<pc>012-b<k1>agnizwuB<k2>agnizwuB
{#agnizwuB#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zwup#}) A proper name, the son of the
<div n="lb">sixth Manu, Chākṣuṣa, by Naḍvalā, also called Agni-
<div n="lb">ṣṭoma. E. {#agni#} and {#stuB#}.
<LEND>

<L>449<pc>012-b<k1>agnizwoma<k2>agnizwoma
{#agnizwoma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a sacrifice or rather
<div n="lb">a series of offerings to fire for five days, to be celebrated
<div n="lb">in the spring. It is the first and principal part of the Jyo-
<div n="lb">tiṣṭoma, one of the great sacrifices in which especially the
<div n="lb">juice of the Soma plant is offered for the purpose of ob-
[Page013-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">taining Swarga or heaven. It is nitya or obligatory for
<div n="lb">the complete performance of the Jyotiṣṭoma and so far
<div n="lb">considered sometimes identical with it, while the other
<div n="lb">six parts or Somasansthās of this sacrifice are considered
<div n="lb">as kāmya and anitya, voluntary and supererogatory. (See
<div n="lb">{#atyagnizwoma, ukTya, zoqaSin, atirAtra, aptoryAma#} and
<div n="lb">{#vAjapeya#}.) The Agniṣṭoma consists of three distinct parts
<div n="lb">or savanas, the prātaḥsavana with five, the mādhyandina-
<div n="lb">savana with five and the tṛtīya-savana with two stotras.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The name of the Sāman or Sāmaveda verse called Yajnā-
<div n="lb">yajnīya (which begins with the words {#yajYAyajYA vo agnaye#} &c.
<div n="lb">see Sāmaveda I. 1. 4. 1.), because it closes the ceremonies
<div n="lb">of the Agniṣṭoma in the tṛtīya-savana. <sup>3</sup> The name of the
<div n="lb">first day in the Sattra Pañchadaśarātra. <sup>5</sup> A proper name,
<div n="lb">the son of the sixth Manu, Chākṣuṣa, by Naḍvalā, also
<div n="lb">Agniṣṭubh. <sup>6</sup> A species of the Soma plant. E. {#agni#} and
<div n="lb">{#stoma#}.
<LEND>

<L>450<pc>013-a<k1>agnizwomayAjin<k2>agnizwomayAjin
{#agnizwomayAjin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jI#}) One who has performed
<div n="lb">the Agniṣṭoma sacrifice. E. {#agnizwoma#} and {#yAjin#}.
<LEND>

<L>451<pc>013-a<k1>agnizWa<k2>agnizWa
{#agnizWa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-zWaH-zWA-zWam#}) Placed in, on or by
<div n="lb">the fire.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-zWaH#}) <sup>1</sup> An iron frying pan. <sup>2</sup> The eleventh yūpa
<div n="lb">or sacrificial post of the 21 posts in the Aśvamedha sacri-
<div n="lb">fice, that post to which the seventeen animals are tied.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-zWA#}) That corner of the eight corners of the yūpa
<div n="lb">or sacrificial post which is near the fire. E. {#agni#} and {#sTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>452<pc>013-a<k1>agnizvAtta<k2>agnizvAtta
{#agnizvAtta#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-ttAH#}) Demigods or manes to whom
<div n="lb">funeral oblations are presented; a sort of manes who when
<div n="lb">alive did not maintain their domestic fires nor offer burnt
<div n="lb">sacrifices. According to some they live in the Somaloka
<div n="lb">and are sons of Marīchi and progenitors especially of the
<div n="lb">gods; according to others they are residents of the Virāja-
<div n="lb">loka, sons of Pulastya, the manes of the demigods and
<div n="lb">demons, and parents of Pīvarī. Also written {#agnisvAtta#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#agnisva#} ({#agni#} and {#sva#}) and {#Atta#} (who are obtained by
<div n="lb">what belongs or is given to Agni) or {#agnizu#} (in or by obla-
<div n="lb">tions to fire) and {#Atta#} (obtained viz. invoked).
<LEND>

<L>453<pc>013-a<k1>agnisaMskAra<k2>agnisaMskAra
{#agnisaMskAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Consecration of fire, making
<div n="lb">the three fires (see {#agni#}) fit for sacrificial purposes by the
<div n="lb">Agnyādhāna, the Pavamāneṣṭi (q. v.) and other prepara-
<div n="lb">tory rites which, themselves, are performed with non-con-
<div n="lb">secrated fire. <sup>2</sup> The completion of any essential rite by
<div n="lb">worship with fire, especially the burning of the dead body
<div n="lb">as an essential rite of the Hindu religion. E. {#agni#} and
<div n="lb">{#saMskAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>466<pc>013-b<k1>agnihotf<k2>agnihotf

<L>467<pc>013-b<k1>agnihotra<k2>agnihotra
{#agnihotra#}¦ I. Bahuvr. n. ({#-tram#}) <sup>1</sup> A sacrificial ceremony which
<div n="lb">consists in making oblations to fire, of milk (payas), curds
<div n="lb">(dadhi), sour gruel (yavāgū), clarified butter (ghṛta), boiled
<div n="lb">rice (odana), grain (tanḍula), the juice of the Soma plant,
<div n="lb">flesh, sesamum oil (taila) and kidney beans (māṣa), or as
<div n="lb">is practised at present, merely of milk, sesamum oil and
<div n="lb">sour gruel. There are two kinds, 1. the nitya, perpetual,
<div n="lb">‘during the whole life’ or that Agnihotra which is addressed
<div n="lb">to Agni every evening at sunset and to Sūrya every morning
<div n="lb">at sunrise; and 2. the kāmya, voluntary or the Agnihotra
<div n="lb">which occurs only occasionally and which is performed for
<div n="lb">the attainment of some specific object, as the Mṛtāgnihotra
<div n="lb">or the Māsāgnihotra in the beginning of the Sattra Kun-
<div n="lb">ḍapāyināmayana. <sup>2</sup> The same as {#agnyADAna#} q. v. E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#hotra,#} sc. {#karman#} ‘an act in which oblations are made
<div n="lb">to Agni’.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. ({#-traH#}) <sup>1</sup> Fire. <sup>2</sup> Havis or clarified butter.
<div n="lb">E. {#agni#} and {#hotra#}.
<LEND>

<L>468<pc>013-b<k1>agnihotrahavaRI<k2>agnihotrahavaRI
{#agnihotrahavaRI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-RI#}) A wooden vessel used in sa-
<div n="lb">crifices for making libations with clarified butter. E. {#agni-#}
<div n="lb">{#hotra#} (clarified butter) and {#havanI#}.
<LEND>

<L>469<pc>013-b<k1>agnihotrin<k2>agnihotrin
{#agnihotrin#}¦ m. ({#-trI#}) <sup>1</sup> One who has performed the Agni-
<div n="lb">hotra q. v. <sup>2</sup> The same as {#agnyAhita#}. <sup>3</sup> The same as {#agni-#}
<div n="lb">{#cit#}. <sup>4</sup> One who possesses or keeps a sacrificial fire. Some-
<div n="lb">times read {#agnihotf#}. E. {#agnihotra,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>470<pc>013-b<k1>agnID<k2>agnID
{#agnID#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gnIt#}) The priest who kindles the fire;
<div n="lb">he is one of the three priests who are subordinate to the
<div n="lb">Brahman or the Ṛtvij performing the ceremonial of the
<div n="lb">Ṛg-, Yajur- and Sāmaveda, (see {#brahman, brAhmaRAcCaMsin#}
<div n="lb">and {#potf#}) and one of the four priests who receive the third
<div n="lb">division of the Dakṣiṇā. (See {#nezwf, pratihartf#} and {#acCA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAka#}.) E. {#agni#} and {#iD#} (instead of {#inD#}).
<LEND>

<L>471<pc>013-b<k1>agnIDra<k2>agnIDra
{#agnIDra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-DraH#}) <sup>1</sup> A proper name: the son of
<div n="lb">Priyavrata and Kāmyā, a king of Jambudvīpa; one of the
<div n="lb">ten sons of the first Manu, Svāyambhuva. <sup>2</sup> The same as
<div n="lb">{#agnID#} q. v. In this meaning the word seems to be a
<div n="lb">misspelling of {#AgnIDra#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-DrI#}) Kindling or exciting the sacrificial fire by
[Page014-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">throwing clarified butter &c. into it. See {#AgnIDrI#} which
<div n="lb">seems to be the more correct form of this word. E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#iDra#} (from {#inD,#} uṇ. aff. {#kran#}).
<LEND>

<L>472<pc>014-a<k1>agnInDana<k2>agnInDana
{#agnInDana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Kindling or exciting a sacrificial
<div n="lb">fire. E. {#agni#} and {#inDana#}. See {#agnikArikA#}.
<LEND>

<L>473<pc>014-a<k1>agnIya<k2>agnIya
{#agnIya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Fiery, relating to Agni (in
<div n="lb">the different meanings of this word). E. {#agni,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>474<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzoma<k2>agnIzoma
{#agnIzoma#}¦ Dvandva. m. du. ({#-mO#}) Agni and Soma. E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#soma#}.
<LEND>

<L>475<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomapraRayana<k2>agnIzomapraRayana
{#agnIzomapraRayana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Carrying forth the fire and
<div n="lb">the Soma; a ceremony in the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice which
<div n="lb">takes place after the Vaisarjana homa (q. v.) and consists
<div n="lb">in taking the fire from the Prāchīnavaṇśa (q. v.) Manḍapa
<div n="lb">and carrying it to the Āgnīdhra (q. v.) Manḍapa, and in
<div n="lb">the same time taking the Soma from the Prāchīnavaṇśa
<div n="lb">and carrying it to the Havirdhāna Manḍapa, a building
<div n="lb">erected in the Saumikī Vedi (q. v.). See also {#agnipraRayana#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#agnIzoma#} and {#praRayana#}.
<LEND>

<L>476<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIya<k2>agnIzomIya
{#agnIzomIya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Belonging or sacred to
<div n="lb">Agni and Soma. E. {#agnIzoma,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>477<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyanirvApa<k2>agnIzomIyanirvApa
{#agnIzomIyanirvApa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) A ceremony in the Dar-
<div n="lb">śapūrṇamāsa sacrifice which is performed on the day of
<div n="lb">the full moon and consists in making libations with the
<div n="lb">Puroḍāśa (q. v.) or cake sacred to Agni and Soma and
<div n="lb">previously fried in eleven kapālas or bowls. See {#agnI-#}
<div n="lb">{#zomIyEkAdaSakapAla#}. E. {#agnIzomIya#} and {#nirvApa#}.
<LEND>

<L>478<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyapaSu<k2>agnIzomIyapaSu
{#agnIzomIyapaSu#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-SuH#}) One of the three prin-
<div n="lb">cipal paśus or sacrificial animals in the Jyotiṣṭoma sacri-
<div n="lb">fice. (See also {#savanIyapaSu#} and {#anubanDyapaSu#}.) It is a goat
<div n="lb">or according to one school, a sheep, sacred to Agni and
<div n="lb">Soma, the procedings with which take place on the day
<div n="lb">called Aupavasathya or the fourth of the Agniṣṭoma (q. v.).
<div n="lb">E. {#agnIzomIya#} and {#paSu#}.
<LEND>

<L>479<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyapaSvanuzWAna<k2>agnIzomIyapaSvanuzWAna
{#agnIzomIyapaSvanuzWAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The procedings with
<div n="lb">the Agnīṣomīyapaśu. See {#agnIzomIyapaSu#}. E. {#agnIzomI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yapaSu#} and {#anuzWAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>480<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyapuroqASa<k2>agnIzomIyapuroqASa
{#agnIzomIyapuroqASa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-SaH#}) The Puroḍāśa (q. v.)
<div n="lb">with which libations are made during the Agnīṣomīyayāga
<div n="lb">(q. v.) after having been baked in eleven kapālas or bowls.
<div n="lb">E. {#agnIzomIya#} and {#puroqASa#}.
<LEND>

<L>481<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyayAga<k2>agnIzomIyayAga
{#agnIzomIyayAga#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-gaH#}) One of the three yāgas
<div n="lb">or sacrificial acts of which consists the Pūrṇamāsa or the
<div n="lb">latter part of the Darśapūrṇamāsa sacrifice. (See also
<div n="lb">{#AgneyayAga#} and {#upAMSuyAjayAga#}.)
<LEND>

<L>482<pc>014-a<k1>agnIzomIyEkAdaSakapAla<k2>agnIzomIyEkAdaSakapAla
{#agnIzomIyEkAdaSakapAla#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-laH#}) The Puroḍāśa
<div n="lb">(q. v.) or cake which is offered to Agni and Soma in the
<div n="lb">Darśapūrṇamāsa sacrifice after having been baked in eleven
<div n="lb">kapālas or bowls. See also {#agnIzomIyapuroqASa#}. E. {#agnI-#}
<div n="lb">{#zomIya#} and {#ekAdaSakapAla#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">E. {#agnIzoma,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>484<pc>014-a<k1>agnyaBAva<k2>agnyaBAva
{#agnyaBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Loss or extinction of the sa-
<div n="lb">cred fire. <sup>2</sup> Loss of appetite. E. {#agni#} and {#aBAva#}.

<L>485<pc>014-a<k1>agnyastra<k2>agnyastra
{#agnyastra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-stram#}) Fire-arms; in poetry, it is usually
<div n="lb">applied to a superhuman power over the element of fire, but
<div n="lb">occasionally indicates, apparently, a rocket. E. {#agni#} and {#astra#}.
<LEND>
[Page014-b+ 56]

<L>486<pc>014-b<k1>agnyAgAra<k2>agnyAgAra
{#agnyAgAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) A fire-temple; a chamber or build-
<div n="lb">ing where the sacred fire is kept. E. {#agni#} and {#AgAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>487<pc>014-b<k1>agnyADAna<k2>agnyADAna
{#agnyADAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The placing of the fire on the
<div n="lb">ground previously prepared for it (see {#agnicayana#}); a cere-
<div n="lb">mony which is necessary to make the Āhavanīya and the
<div n="lb">other sacred fires (see {#agni#}) fit for sacrificial use and is fol-
<div n="lb">lowed by the Pavamāneṣtis (q. v.). See {#agnisaMskAra#}. The
<div n="lb">act takes place in the spring, if the person belongs to the
<div n="lb">cast of the Brāhmaṇas, in the hot season or grīṣma if he
<div n="lb">is a Kshatriya, in the autumn or śarad if he is a Vaiśya
<div n="lb">and is performed once for all, to serve all future purposes.
<div n="lb">E. {#agni#} and {#ADAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>488<pc>014-b<k1>agnyADeya<k2>agnyADeya
{#agnyADeya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) The same as {#agnyADAna#} q. v.
<div n="lb">E. {#agni#} and {#ADeya#}.
<LEND>

<L>489<pc>014-b<k1>agnyAlaya<k2>agnyAlaya
{#agnyAlaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A place in which consecrated
<div n="lb">fire is kept. <sup>2</sup> A hole, with compartments of prescribed di-
<div n="lb">mensions and shape, for the several sacred fires. E. {#agni#}
<div n="lb">and {#Alaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>490<pc>014-b<k1>agnyAhita<k2>agnyAhita

<L>495<pc>014-b<k1>agra<k2>agra
{#agra#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-graH-grA-gram#}) <sup>1</sup> Chief, principal. <sup>2</sup> Prior,
<div n="lb">first. <sup>3</sup> Excessive, more, much.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-gram#}) <sup>1</sup> Top, summit, point, upper part. <sup>2</sup> Front,
<div n="lb">fore part. <sup>3</sup> The beginning, first part. <sup>4</sup> The best, excellent.
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> Goal, resting place. <sup>6</sup> Assemblage, multitude. <sup>7</sup> A weight
<div n="lb">equal to one Pala. <sup>8</sup> A kind of alms give to Brahmans,
<div n="lb">four mouthfuls or according to others, food given in alms,
<div n="lb">48 times the quantity of the alms called {#BikzA#}. <sup>9</sup> (In astro-
<div n="lb">nomy) the sun's amplitude. E. {#aNg,#} uṇ. aff. {#ran,#} the nasal
<div n="lb">of the radical being dropped.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a ray of light; the focal point. E. {#agra#} and {#kara#}.

<L>532<pc>015-b<k1>agrahAyaRa<k2>agrahAyaRa
{#agrahAyaRa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-RaH#}) A name given to the solar month
<div n="lb">Mārgaśiras or Mārgaśirṣa (q. v.) when the latter was made
<div n="lb">to commence the year; the eighth month of the lunar year
<div n="lb">of the Hindus, when the moon is full near the head of
<div n="lb">Orion, or about November-December. Also written {#Agra-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAyaRa#}. (The fem. {#agrahAyaRI#} is a false reading for {#Agra-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAyaRI#} q. v.) E. {#agra#} and {#hAyaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>533<pc>015-b<k1>agrahAra<k2>agrahAra
{#agrahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> An endowment of land or vil-
<div n="lb">lages conferred upon Brahmans. <sup>2</sup> A village, or a part of
<div n="lb">one, occupied by Brahmans and held either rent-free under
<div n="lb">special grants or at a reduced rate of assessment. The pre-
<div n="lb">cise nature of the tenure is usually denoted by a term pre-
<div n="lb">fixed, as Sarvāgrahāra, free from all (sarva) tax &c. E.
<div n="lb">{#agra#} (alms) and {#hAra#}.

<L>540<pc>015-b<k1>agrAhya<k2>agrAhya

<div n="lb">to be accepted. <sup>2</sup> Not to be attained. <sup>3</sup> Not to be trusted
<div n="lb">or consented to. E. {#a#} neg. and {#grAhya#}.
<LEND>

<L>541<pc>015-b<k1>agrima<k2>agrima
{#agrima#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) <sup>1</sup> Chief, principal, best.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Prior, precedent. <sup>3</sup> Elder, elder born.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-mA#}) The name of a fruit (Annona reticulata).
<div n="lb">See {#lavaRI#}. E. {#agra,#} taddh. aff. {#qimac#}.
<LEND>

<L>559<pc>016-a<k1>aGa<k2>aGa
{#aGa#}¦ I. n. ({#-Gam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sin. <sup>2</sup> Pain, suffering. <sup>3</sup> Passion, as love,
<div n="lb">hatred. <sup>4</sup> Impurity (see {#aSOca#}). E. {#han#} with {#A,#} krit aff. {#qa,#}
<div n="lb">the preposition being made short (or better {#aMh#} or {#aNG,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#ac#}.) See {#aMhas, aNGas#} and {#aNGa#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-GaH-GA-Gam#}) One afflicted with sin, pain,
<div n="lb">passion, impurity (see the preceding).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-GaH#}) Name of a demon, the general of Kansa.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-GA#}) <sup>1</sup> The goddess of Sin. <sup>2</sup> pl. f. ({#-GAH#}) The
<div n="lb">constellation, more usually known under the name of {#maGAH#}
<div n="lb">q. v. E. {#aGa#} (sin &c.), taddh. aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>564<pc>016-a<k1>aGamarzaRa<k2>aGamarzaRa

<div n="lb">prayer: reciting mentally a particular passage from the Ve-
<div n="lb">das, while a little water, in the palm of the right hand, is
<div n="lb">held to the nose; this forms a part of the daily ceremonies
<div n="lb">of the Brahmans.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-RaH#}) The son of Madhuchhandas and author of the
<div n="lb">passage recited upon the above occasion. E. {#aGa#} and {#marzaRa#}.

<L>580<pc>016-b<k1>aGoza<k2>aGoza
{#aGoza#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-zaH#}) (In grammar.) The absence of
<div n="lb">soft articulation, hard articulation; such as characterises the
<div n="lb">pronunciation of the letters {#ka Ka ca Ca wa Wa ta Ta pa Pa Sa za sa#}
<div n="lb">and of Visarga. See {#vAhyaprayatna#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Goza#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-zaH-zA-zam#}) <sup>1</sup> Without a soft sound-
<div n="lb">ing, sounding hard (as a letter). <sup>2</sup> Without a cowherd (as a
<div n="lb">country). E. {#a#} priv. and {#Goza#}.
<LEND>

<L>584<pc>016-b<k1>aNka<k2>aNka

<div n="lb">above the hips where women place young children in car-
<div n="lb">rying them. <sup>3</sup> The body. <sup>4</sup> Proximity. <sup>5</sup> Place, ground. <sup>6</sup> A
<div n="lb">hooked instrument. E. {#aYc,#} kṛt or uṇ. aff. {#ac#}. See {#aNkas#}.

<div n="lb">arithmetical sign, a number or coefficient. <sup>3</sup> (Used some-
<div n="lb">times to denote) the numeral 9. <sup>4</sup> A line, a stroke. <sup>5</sup> Fault,
<div n="lb">offence. <sup>6</sup> Ornament, decoration. <sup>7</sup> The act of a play. <sup>8</sup> A
[Page017-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">species of dramatic entertainment. <sup>9</sup> Mimic war or conflict.
<div n="lb">E. {#aYc,#} kṛt or uṇ. aff. {#ac#} or {#aNk,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.

<L>620<pc>017-b<k1>aNg<k2>aNg
{#aNg#}¦ I. ({#agi-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 1st cl. par. ({#aNgati-#}
<div n="lb">{#AnaNga#}) To go. With {#pari#} (or {#pali#}) To go round.--{#vi#}
<div n="lb">and {#pari#} (or {#pali-vipali#}) To go round; caus. To surround.
<div n="P">II. ({#aNga-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. par. ({#aNgayati#})
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> To mark. <sup>2</sup> To go. See {#aNk#}.
<LEND>

<L>621<pc>017-b<k1>aNga<k2>aNga
{#aNga#}¦ I. Ind. (see {#nipAta#}.) <sup>1</sup> A vocative particle implying
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> solicitation, equivalent to the English ‘do’, in phrases as
<div n="lb">‘do give’ &c. <sup>b.</sup> abuse, <sup>c.</sup> joy. <sup>2</sup> A particle implying con-
<div n="lb">firmation, as ‘indeed, certainly’, or putting stress on the
<div n="lb">word with which it is connected. <sup>3</sup> Again, further, the
<div n="lb">rather. <sup>4</sup> Quick. <sup>5</sup> A particle of assent used in composition
<div n="lb">with {#kf#} and its derivatives, {#I#} being substituted for the ter-
<div n="lb">minating vowel as in {#aNgIkaraRa#} &c. (See {#gati#}.)
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-Ngam#}) <sup>1</sup> A limb or member. <sup>2</sup> The body. <sup>3</sup> A part
<div n="lb">or division of a whole. <sup>4</sup> A division of Hindu learning, com-
<div n="lb">prehending especially such science as is considered depend-
<div n="lb">ant upon the Vedas, hence also called Vedāṅga; works
<div n="lb">on six subjects come under this description, viz. {#SikzA#} or
<div n="lb">pronunciation, {#vyAkaraRa#} or grammar, {#Candas#} or prosody,
<div n="lb">{#nirukta#} or explanation of obscure terms, {#kalpa#} or description
<div n="lb">of religious rites and {#jyotiza#} or astronomy. Also the Jainas
<div n="lb">call the twelve divisions of their holy work Gaṇipiṭaka,
<div n="lb">Angas. <sup>5</sup> An inferior or secondary part of a whole. <sup>6</sup> (In
<div n="lb">rhetoric.) An incidental passion or figure, illustrative of,
<div n="lb">but subordinate to the main subject of the description. <sup>7</sup> All
<div n="lb">the dramatis personae of a play, except the hero and he-
<div n="lb">roine, the body of the characters. <sup>8</sup> (In grammar.) The
<div n="lb">theme or that part of a word in general, to which the affix
[Page018-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">is attached, whether the affix be one of inflexion or deri-
<div n="lb">vation. <sup>9</sup> An expedient, a means of success. <sup>10</sup> Mind, un-
<div n="lb">derstanding. <sup>11</sup> A denomination of the numeral six (this
<div n="lb">being the number of the Vedāṅgas). E. {#aNg,#} kṛt aff.
<div n="lb">{#ac#}.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A country, Bengal proper, including
<div n="lb">Bhāgalpur, and its inhabitants. (In this sense the word is
<div n="lb">mostly used as a plural.) <sup>2</sup> A proper name: the son of Ūru
<div n="lb">by Āgneyī and grandson to Chākṣuṣa or the sixth Manu,
<div n="lb">a descendant of Atri; the eldest son of the king Bali. E. {#aNg,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">IV. m. f. n. ({#-NgaH-NgA-Ngam#}) <sup>1</sup> Having limbs, a body &c.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Near, proximate. E. {#aNga#} (see II.), taddh. aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<div n="P">II. f. ({#-NgikA#}) A bodice or jacket. E. {#aNga,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.

<div n="lb">Darśapūrṇamāsa sacrifice; or the Dīkṣaṇīyā, Prāyaṇīyā
<div n="lb">&c. with respect to the Jyotiṣṭoma &c. E. {#aNga#} and {#karman#}.

<L>699<pc>019-b<k1>aNgira<k2>aNgira
{#aNgira#}¦ m. ({#-raH#}) A proper name. See the following, of which
<div n="lb">it appears to be an abbreviated form.
<LEND>

<L>700<pc>019-b<k1>aNgiras<k2>aNgiras
{#aNgiras#}¦ I. m. sing. ({#-rAH#}) The proper name of a Maharshi,
<div n="lb">a great Ṛṣi or saint who is the reputed author of many
<div n="lb">vaidik hymns, but who is mentioned also in a subse-
[Page020-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">quent period as one of the inspired legislators of India
<div n="lb">and as the author of an astronomical work. The various
<div n="lb">legends connected with his life seem to have been occasioned
<div n="lb">by the word {#aNgiras#} coming from the same radical as,
<div n="lb">and its sound recalling that of, {#agni,#} fire (q. v.). Hence
<div n="lb">we find Angiras sometimes either as an epithet or as the
<div n="lb">father of Agni, and the Saint himself connected chiefly with
<div n="lb">such hymns as are addressed to Agni, to Indra or to dei-
<div n="lb">ties of a kindred description: a portion of the fourth Veda,
<div n="lb">the Atharvan, reports him also as an expounder of the
<div n="lb">Brahmavidyā (q. v.) or the sacred knowledge, that had been
<div n="lb">imparted to him by Satyavāha, a descendant of Bharadvāja.
<div n="lb">(See {#aNgir#}.) Though Angiras, as may be concluded from his
<div n="lb">name being connected with the authorship of a great por-
<div n="lb">tion of the sacred Hindu literature, appears to have been
<div n="lb">one of the oldest civilizers of India, no historical date is
<div n="lb">to be obtained from the epic or pauranik literature where
<div n="lb">the vaidik legends of his life are merely amplified; there
<div n="lb">he is named as one of the Prajāpatis or progenitors of
<div n="lb">mankind engendered, according to some by Manu, accord-
<div n="lb">ing to others by Brahmā himself, either with the female
<div n="lb">half of his body or from his mouth or from the space
<div n="lb">between his eye-brows. As such he is considered also as
<div n="lb">one of the seven Ṛṣis who preside over the reign of the
<div n="lb">first Manu or Svāyambhuva. He is called, besides, the priest
<div n="lb">of the Gods, the Lord of the sacrifice &c. Sometimes he
<div n="lb">is considered as a son of Uru by Āgneyī, the daughter of
<div n="lb">Agni. His daughters are the Ṛchas (or vaidik hymns) and
<div n="lb">also, Śaśvatī, Sinīvālī, Kuhū, Rākā, Anumati; his sons
<div n="lb">are Samvarta, the manes called Havishmats, Utathya,
<div n="lb">Bṛhaspati, Mārkanḍeya; his wives, Smṛti (traditional
<div n="lb">science), two daughters of Daksha, Svadhā and Satī, and
<div n="lb">Śraddhā, the daughter of the sage Kardama. As an astro-
<div n="lb">nomical personification he is Bṛhaspati himself or the regent
<div n="lb">of the planet Jupiter and presides over the sixth year of
<div n="lb">the cycle of sixty years. See also {#aTarvan#}.
<div n="P">II. m. pl. ({#-rasaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The descendants of the former. In this
<div n="lb">capacity they share also in the nature of the legends attri-
<div n="lb">buted to Angiras. Angiras being the father of Agni, they
<div n="lb">are considered as descendants of Agni himself, who is also
<div n="lb">called the first of the Angirasas. Like Angiras, they occur
<div n="lb">in hymns addressed to the luminous deities and, at a later
<div n="lb">period, they become for the most part personifications of
<div n="lb">light, of luminous bodies, of divisions of time, of celestial
<div n="lb">phenomena and fires adapted to peculiar occasions as the
<div n="lb">full and change of the moon, or to particular rites as the
<div n="lb">Aśvamedha, Rājasūya, the Pākayajnas or sacrifices with
<div n="lb">food, obsequial and funeral fires, expiatory fires, and the
<div n="lb">like. Most of the authors of the hymns of the Rigveda are
<div n="lb">connected with them and in the Purāṇas mention is made of
<div n="lb">two tribes of the Angirasas which were Brāhmaṇas as well
<div n="lb">as Kshatriyas. <sup>2</sup> The hymns of the Atharvaveda. See also
<div n="lb">{#aTarvan#} pl. and {#aTarvANgiras#} pl. E. {#aNg,#} uṇ. aff. {#asi#} with
<div n="lb">āgama {#iruw,#} or, according to another authority, a Tatpur.
<div n="lb">composed of {#an#} (meaning {#anna#} food, from {#an#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#})
<div n="lb">and {#giras#} (from {#gF#} to swallow) ‘devouring food’. The latter
[Page020-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">etymology, apparently without any grammatical authority,
<div n="lb">would refer especially to {#aNgiras#} as epithet of Agni. See
<div n="lb">also {#aNgirastama#}. The plural {#aNgirasaH#} is considered, though
<div n="lb">without any etymological necessity, as the plural of the
<div n="lb">deriv. form {#ANgirasa#} with luk or elision of the affix.
<LEND>

<L>701<pc>020-b<k1>aNgirasa<k2>aNgirasa
{#aNgirasa#}¦ m. ({#-saH#}) A proper name: an enemy of Viṣṇu in

<L>715<pc>020-b<k1>aNgula<k2>aNgula
{#aNgula#}¦ I. m. (and according to one authority also n.) ({#-laH#}
<div n="lb">{#-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> A finger. <sup>2</sup> The thumb. <sup>3</sup> A finger's breadth, as a
<div n="lb">linear measure, viz. a measure of eight barley corns joined
<div n="lb">side by side in breadth or of three grains of rice in length.
<div n="lb">Twelve angulas make a vitasti or span, and twenty-four
<div n="lb">a hasta or cubit. <sup>4</sup> (In astronomy.) A digit or one twelfth
<div n="lb">part of any dimension, subdivided into sixty vyangulas.
<div n="lb">E. {#aNgula#} is considered by the gramm. authorities as a sub-
<div n="lb">stitute of {#aNguli,#} as which it ought to occur only at the end
<div n="lb">of certain Tatpur., derived then with samāsānta aff. {#ac#} and
<div n="lb">at the end of certain Bahuvr., derived with samāsānta aff. {#zac#}.
<div n="lb">In both cases it is a neutre. The native dictionaries how-
<div n="lb">ever state as above.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-laH#}) A proper name of the sage Chāṇakya. E.
<div n="lb">{#aNg,#} uṇ. aff. {#ulan(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>716<pc>020-b<k1>aNgulapramARa<k2>aNgulapramARa
{#aNgulapramARa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) The linear measure called {#aNgula#}.
<div n="lb">See the preceding. E. {#aNgula#} and {#pramARa#}.
<LEND>

<L>717<pc>020-b<k1>aNgulamAna<k2>aNgulamAna
{#aNgulamAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The linear measure called {#aNgula#}
<div n="lb">q. v. E. {#aNgula#} and {#mAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>718<pc>020-b<k1>aNguli<k2>aNguli
{#aNguli#}¦ f. ({#-liH#}) <sup>1</sup> A finger. <sup>2</sup> A toe. <sup>3</sup> The same as {#aNguzWa#}
<div n="lb">q. v. <sup>4</sup> The tip of an elephant's trunk. This word is changed
[Page021-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">at the end of certain Tatpur. and of certain Bahuvr. to
<div n="lb">{#aNgula#} q. v. See also {#aNgulI, aNguri#} and {#aNgurI#}. E. {#aNg,#}
<div n="lb">uṇ. aff. {#uli#}.
<LEND>

<L>719<pc>021-a<k1>aNgulitoraRa<k2>aNgulitoraRa
{#aNgulitoraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Three semicircular lines drawn
<div n="lb">across the forehead, with sandal or ashes of burnt cow-
<div n="lb">dung &c., a sectarial mark, especially of the followers of
<div n="lb">Śiva, more commonly termed Tripunḍra. E. {#aNguli#} and
<div n="lb">{#toraRa#} the ornamented arch of a gateway, to which the mark
<div n="lb">made by the fingers upon the forehead may be compared.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#tra#} (what protects).

<div n="lb">prevent the bowstring from injuring it. E. {#aNguli#} and {#trARa#}.

<L>737<pc>021-a<k1>aNguzWa<k2>aNguzWa
{#aNguzWa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zWaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The thumb. <sup>2</sup> The great toe. <sup>3</sup> A
<div n="lb">thumb's breadth, as a linear measure which is said to be
<div n="lb">a measure of six barley corns. This seems, however, not
<div n="lb">to be correct, because twelve aṅguṣṭhas are given by the
<div n="lb">same authority as equal to a Vitasti or span. See {#aNgula#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#aNgu#} here said to mean the hand, and {#sTa#}.

<L>762<pc>022-a<k1>acala<k2>acala

<div n="lb">of Śiva. <sup>4</sup> A proper name, viz. the first of the nine ‘white
<div n="lb">Balas’, a class of deified persons peculiar to the Jainas.

<div n="lb">seven.

<L>779<pc>022-b<k1>acira<k2>acira
{#acira#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Not long (in time),
<div n="lb">brief, momentary. Adverbially are used: {#aciram, aci-#}
<div n="lb">{#reRa#} and {#acirAt,#} in a short time, soon, directly. In
<div n="lb">composition with a participle, {#acira#} means ‘not yet a
<div n="lb">long time, not long ago, recently’. See f. i. {#aciraprasUtA,#}
<div n="lb">{#aciramfta#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-rA#}) A proper name: the mother of Śānti, the
<div n="lb">sixteenth Arhat or Jaina saint of the present Avasarpiṇī.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#cira#}.
<LEND>

{#aciradyuti#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-tiH#}) Lightning. E. {#acira#} and {#dyuti;#}
<div n="lb">‘its light being of short duration’.
<LEND>

<L>793<pc>022-b<k1>acEtanya<k2>acEtanya

<div n="lb">this word may also be used in the three genders.

<L>795<pc>022-b<k1>acCa<k2>acCa
{#acCa#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-cCaH-cCA-cCam#}) Clear, transparent. See {#Ca#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-cCaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Crystal. <sup>2</sup> A bear (see {#fkza#}).
<div n="P">III. ind. (see {#nipAta#}) A kind of preposition (or {#gati#} q. v.)
<div n="lb">with the meaning of ‘to, unto, before, in front’, or ‘obtain-
<div n="lb">ing, taking possession of’. Its use seems to be restricted
<div n="lb">to the vaidik literature where it appears, for the most
<div n="lb">part, in the protracted form {#acCA#}. It occurs only in con-
<div n="lb">junction with verbs implying motion or speech--especially
<div n="lb">with {#aj, i, gam, yA, naS, nu, vA, vac, vad#}--either pre-
<div n="lb">ceding or following them and requiring the noun which de-
<div n="lb">pends upon this combination to stand in the accusative or in
[Page023-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the locative; the latter case, however, is only exceptional.--
<div n="lb">The word is given also in the form {#acCam#}. E. unknown.
<div n="lb">That which is given is: {#a#} neg. and {#Co,#} kṛt affix {#ka,#}
<div n="lb">‘not cutting or injuring sc. the sight’ and would refer
<div n="lb">only to I. and to II. 1. in the sense of ‘not easily cut’.
<LEND>

<L>796<pc>023-a<k1>acCaBalla<k2>acCaBalla
{#acCaBalla#}¦ Tatpur.(?) m. ({#-llaH#}) A bear. This is sometimes
<div n="lb">considered as two words. See {#acCa#} and {#Balla#}. E. {#acCa#}
<div n="lb">and {#Balla#}.
<LEND>

<L>797<pc>023-a<k1>acCAvAka<k2>acCAvAka
{#acCAvAka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) One of the sixteen Ṛtvijs or priests
<div n="lb">required for the performance of the great sacrifices with
<div n="lb">the juice of the Soma plant. He is one of the three priests
<div n="lb">who are subordinate to the {#hotf#} q. v. (see besides {#mEtrAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#ruRa#} and {#grAvastut#}) and one of the four priests who receive
<div n="lb">the third division of the Dakṣiṇā q. v. (See also {#nezwf,#}
<div n="lb">{#agnID#} and {#pratihartf#}.) E. {#vac#} with {#acCa#} in its protracted
<div n="lb">form, kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>798<pc>023-a<k1>acCAvAkIya<k2>acCAvAkIya

<div n="lb">{#vAka#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> A Sūkta or hymn in which the word {#acCA-#}

<L>817<pc>023-b<k1>aj<k2>aj (aja-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)
{#aj (aja-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)#}¦ r. 1st cl. par. ({#ajati#}.
<div n="lb">The tenses which require ārdhadhātuka affixes, are not
<div n="lb">to be formed of this radical, {#vI#} (q. v.) being then con-
<div n="lb">sidered as a substitute, of which the formation is to take
<div n="lb">place. According to others, however, there may be found.
<div n="lb">perf. {#AjiTa-#} fut. {#ajitA-ajizyati-#} aor. {#AjIt-#} cond.
<div n="lb">{#Ajizyat#}. Pass. {#ajyate-#} fut. {#ajitA-ajizyate-#} prec. {#aji-#}
<div n="lb">{#zIzwa-#} aor. {#Ajizwa#}. Des. {#ajijizati#}.) <sup>1</sup> To go. <sup>2</sup> To throw
<div n="lb">or cast, to impel. With <sup>1</sup> {#acCa-#} To impel to. <sup>2</sup> {#apa-#} To
<div n="lb">send away. <sup>3</sup> {#aBi-#} To impel to. <sup>4</sup> {#ava-#} To send down.
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> {#A-#} To direct hither (trans. and intrans.), to fetch, to
<div n="lb">scatter. <sup>6</sup> {#A#} pref. {#aBi- (aByA-)#} To direct hither. <sup>7</sup> {#ud-#}
<div n="lb">To drive out, to draw out. <sup>8</sup> {#upa-#} To direct near. <sup>9</sup> {#nir-#}
<div n="lb">To drive out. <sup>10</sup> {#vi-#} To throw asunder, to scatter. <sup>11</sup> {#sam-#}
<div n="lb">To throw or send together.
<LEND>

<L>818<pc>023-b<k1>aja<k2>aja
{#aja#}¦ I. 1. m. ({#-jaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The mover, the instigator. <sup>2</sup> As such,
<div n="lb">this word occurs in the Vedas, for the most part in con-
<div n="lb">junction with {#ekapAd#} (q. v.), as an epithet or as a syno-
<div n="lb">nyme of <sup>a.</sup> Indra, <sup>b.</sup> Rudra, one of the Maruts, <sup>c.</sup> Agni,
<div n="lb"><sup>d.</sup> Pūṣan or Sūrya; in the epic and paurāṇik literature as
<div n="lb">a synonyme of <sup>a.</sup> Brahmā (see also {#ajana#}), <sup>b.</sup> Viṣṇu, <sup>c.</sup> Śiva,
<div n="lb"><sup>d.</sup> Kāma; in philosophical texts, in its feminine form ({#ajA#})
<div n="lb">as a synonyme of <sup>a.</sup> Prakṛti or Nature, <sup>b.</sup> Māyā or Illusion,
<div n="lb">the unreality of Nature or Universe. <sup>3</sup> A proper name,
<div n="lb">viz. <sup>a.</sup> A descendant of Viśvāmitra. <sup>b.</sup> A prince of the solar
<div n="lb">race, the son of Raghu and father of Daśaratha, or ac-
<div n="lb">cording to others, the grandson of Raghu, the son of Di-
<div n="lb">līpa and father of Dīrghabāhu; or the son of Nābhāga and
<div n="lb">father of Daśaratha. <sup>4</sup> A he-goat. This animal was con-
<div n="lb">sidered as the vehicle of Pūṣan, the sun, (see {#ajASva#})
<div n="lb">and also as consecrated to Agni and Soma conjointly. <sup>5</sup> (In
<div n="lb">astronomy.) The sign Aries. <sup>6</sup> The name of a mineral sub-
<div n="lb">stance. See {#mAkzika#} and {#ajanAmaka#}. <sup>7</sup> A kind of rice, three
<div n="lb">or seven years old(?). <sup>8</sup> The moon(?).
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-jAH#}) The name of <sup>a.</sup> a sort of Ṛṣis in
<div n="lb">Brahma's heaven; <sup>b.</sup> a people mentioned in the Vedas.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-jA#}) <sup>1</sup> Prakṛti or Nature. <sup>2</sup> Māyā or Illusion
[Page024-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">(see {#aja#} m.). <sup>3</sup> A she-goat. <sup>4</sup> The name of a plant, the
<div n="lb">bulbs of which resemble the udder of a she-goat. E. {#aj,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ac;#} in the fem. with the aff. {#wAp#}. 1. 4. and 2. 3.
<div n="lb">implying ‘the quick animal’.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Unborn. This mean-
<div n="lb">ing has been applied to {#aja#} in the sense of Brahmā,
<div n="lb">Viṣṇu, Śiva, Kāma, and {#ajA#} in the sense of Prakṛti
<div n="lb">and Māyā. But see before. E. {#a#} neg. and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>819<pc>024-a<k1>ajaka<k2>ajaka
{#ajaka#}¦ I. m. ({#-kaH#}) A proper name: <sup>1</sup> A descendant of Purū-
<div n="lb">ravas, the son of Sumantu (or according to others of Su-
<div n="lb">naha) and grandson of Jahnu. <sup>2</sup> A king of Magadha, of
<div n="lb">the line of Pradyota.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-kA#}) <sup>1</sup> A young she-goat. (Also {#ajikA#}.) <sup>2</sup> A
<div n="lb">kind of disease of the pupil of the eye. See {#ajakAjAta#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#aja,#} taddh. aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>820<pc>024-a<k1>ajakarRa<k2>ajakarRa
{#ajakarRa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-rRaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The ear of a goat. <sup>2</sup> A tree (Ter-
<div n="lb">minalia alata tomentosa, Rox.); the leaf being compared
<div n="lb">to the ear of a goat. See also {#asana#}. E. {#aja#} and {#karRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>821<pc>024-a<k1>ajakarRaka<k2>ajakarRaka
{#ajakarRaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) A tree, vulg. Sāl (Shorea robusta, Rox.).
<div n="lb">See {#sAla#}. E. taddh. {#kan#} affixed to the preceding, denoting
<div n="lb">resemblance.
<LEND>

<L>822<pc>024-a<k1>ajakava<k2>ajakava
{#ajakava#}¦ m. ({#-vaH#}) The bow of Śiva. E. unknown; the follow-
<div n="lb">ing is evidently artificial: {#aja#} Viṣṇu, and {#ka#} Brahmā,
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#va,#} Brahmā being placed in the centre, and
<div n="lb">Viṣṇu on the upper part. See also {#ajakAva-ajagava-aja-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAva-ajIkava-Ajagava#}.
<LEND>

<L>823<pc>024-a<k1>ajakAjAta<k2>ajakAjAta
{#ajakAjAta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) A disease of the transparent cor-
<div n="lb">nea of the eye: small tumors like the litter of goats, slightly
<div n="lb">red, which protrude through the cornea, from which a bloody
<div n="lb">discharge proceeds mixed with pus. E. {#ajakA#} and {#jAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>824<pc>024-a<k1>ajakAva<k2>ajakAva
{#ajakAva#}¦ I. m. n. ({#-vaH-vam#}) The bow of Śiva; see {#ajakava#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-vaH#}) A poisonous little animal.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-vam#}) A sacrificial vessel consecrated to Mitra
<div n="lb">and Varuna. E. doubtful. Perhaps this word is derived
<div n="lb">from {#ajakA,#} taddh. aff. {#va,#} III. being explained as a vessel
<div n="lb">having a piece of wood in the shape of the throat nipples
<div n="lb">of a goat and II. as an animal poisonous or deadly as the
<div n="lb">disease {#ajakA#}.
<LEND>

<L>825<pc>024-a<k1>ajakUlA<k2>ajakUlA
{#ajakUlA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-lA#}) The name of a town of the Bodhis.
<div n="lb">E. {#aja#} and {#kUla#}.
<LEND>

<L>826<pc>024-a<k1>ajakzIra<k2>ajakzIra
{#ajakzIra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) Goat's milk. This word occurs only in
<div n="lb">the Vedas. E. {#aja,#} instead of {#ajA,#} and {#kzIra#}. See {#ajAkzIra#}.
<LEND>

<L>827<pc>024-a<k1>ajaga<k2>ajaga
{#ajaga#}.¦ See E. of {#ajagava#}.

<L>828<pc>024-a<k1>ajaganDA<k2>ajaganDA

<div n="lb">and {#japa#}.

<L>879<pc>025-b<k1>ajahatsvArTA<k2>ajahatsvArTA
{#ajahatsvArTA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-rTA#}) A figure of speech, the cha-
<div n="lb">racteristic of the {#upAdAnalakzaRA#} q. v. It consists in using
<div n="lb">a word in an elliptic meaning without depriving it of its
<div n="lb">primary sense; in such phrases as {#Sveto DAvati#} or {#kuntAH#}
<div n="lb">{#praviSanti,#} are to be supplied {#aSva#} &c. in the former, {#pu-#}
<div n="lb">{#ruza#} &c. in the latter, so as to impart the sense of ‘a white
<div n="lb">horse gallops’, ‘the men with lances enter’, while {#Sveta#}
<div n="lb">and {#kunta#} retain their original sense. See, on the contrary,
<div n="lb">{#jahatsvArTA#}.--E. {#a#} neg. and {#jahatsvArTA,#} scil. {#lakzaRA#}.
<LEND>

<L>880<pc>025-b<k1>ajahalliNga<k2>ajahalliNga

<L>892<pc>026-a<k1>ajAtaSatru<k2>ajAtaSatru
{#ajAtaSatru#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-truH-truH-tru#}) <sup>1</sup> Having no ene-
<div n="lb">mies existent. <sup>2</sup> Having no one existent who is worth be-
<div n="lb">ing called an enemy.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-truH#}) A proper name or a synonyme of <sup>1</sup> Śiva,
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Yudhiṣṭhira, <sup>3</sup> A king of Kāśi, <sup>4</sup> A son of Śamīka, <sup>5</sup> A
<div n="lb">son of Vidmisāra, or according to others, <sup>6</sup> A son of Bim-
<div n="lb">bisāra and contemporary of Śākyamuni. E. {#ajAta#} and {#Satru#}.
<LEND>

<L>910<pc>026-a<k1>ajita<k2>ajita
{#ajita#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unconquered. <sup>2</sup> Un-
<div n="lb">excelled, unsurpassed.
[Page026-b+ 56]
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> The proper name of several gods and per-
<div n="lb">sons, viz. <sup>a.</sup> Viṣṇu. <sup>b.</sup> Śiva. <sup>c.</sup> One of the seven Ṛṣis
<div n="lb">who preside during the reign of the fourteenth Manu. <sup>d.</sup> A
<div n="lb">name of Maitreya or a future Buddha. <sup>e.</sup> The second of
<div n="lb">the Arhats or Jaina saints of the present Avasarpiṇī,
<div n="lb">a descendant of Ikṣvāku and a son of Jitaśatru by Vijayā.
<div n="lb"><sup>f.</sup> The attendant of Suvidhi or the ninth Jaina Arhat of the
<div n="lb">present Avasarpiṇī. <sup>2</sup> The name of a powerful antidote.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> A kind of poisonous rat.
<div n="P">III. m. pl. ({#-tAH#}) A particular class of gods in the reign
<div n="lb">of the first Manu, the same as the {#jayAH#} in a former life.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#jita#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">are supposed to carry out the commands of the Arhats.

<L>971<pc>027-b<k1>aYc<k2>aYc
{#aYc#}¦ I. 1. ({#ancu-BvAdi-udAtta-svaritet#}) r. 1st cl. par. and
<div n="lb">ātm. ({#aYcati-te-AnaYca-ce-aYcitA-acyAt-aktvA#} p. p. {#akta#}.
<div n="lb">Pass. {#acyate#} and {#aYcyate#}. Desid. {#aYcicizati-te#}.--Caus.
<div n="lb">{#aYcayati#}). <sup>1</sup> To go. <sup>2</sup> To ask, to beg. <sup>3</sup> To speak indis-
<div n="lb">tinctly.--With {#apa-#} To go away; caus. to send away.
<div n="lb">--{#ud-#} To rise; caus. to raise, to draw up.--{#upa-#}
<div n="lb">To approach.--{#ni-#} To go down.--{#pari-#} To go round,
<div n="lb">to turn round.--{#vi-#} To approach in different ways;
<div n="lb">caus. to drive asunder.--{#sam-#} caus. To impel together.
<div n="P">2. r. 1st cl. par. and ātm. ({#aYcati-te-aYcitvA-#} p. p.
[Page028-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#aYcita#} and {#akna#}) To bend, to curve. With {#A-#} To bend.
<div n="lb">--{#ni-#} To bend down.--{#vi-#} To bend asunder.--{#sam-#}
<div n="lb">To bend together, to bend intensely.
<div n="P">3. ({#aci-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 1st cl. par. ({#aYca-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti-aYcyAt-aYcitvA-#} p. p. {#aYcita#}) To honour, to worship,
<div n="lb">to treat with respect.
<div n="P">4. ({#ancu-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. par. ({#aYcaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti#}) To make clear or distinct. With {#ud-#} The same.
<div n="P">See also {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-N-cI-k#}) Going.
<div n="P">2. m. f. n. ({#-N-YcI-k#}) Honouring, worshipping.
<div n="P">This word occurs only as the latter part of several,
<div n="lb">in most instances irregular compounds, the former part of
<div n="lb">which is, in the classic dialect, restricted to some prepo-
<div n="lb">sitions and indeclinables; see f. i. {#avAYc-udaYc-nyaYc-prAYc-#}
<div n="lb">{#samyaYc-vizvaYc-tiryaYc#}. In the Vedas it occurs also in com-
<div n="lb">position with pronominal and nominal themes, f. i. in {#vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvadryaYc-devadryaYc-GftAYc#}. When it has the meaning of ‘go-
<div n="lb">ing’, the nasal of the root appears only in the nom.,
<div n="lb">voc. and acc. of the sing. and du. masc., in the nom. and
<div n="lb">voc. of the plur. masc. and neuter and in the acc. of
<div n="lb">the plur. neuter; in all the other cases and in the formation
<div n="lb">of the fem. it is dropped. The declension and the fem. for-
<div n="lb">mation of {#aYc#} ‘honouring, worshipping’ is regular in re-
<div n="lb">taining the nasal of the root. E. {#aYc,#} kṛt aff. {#kvin#}.
<LEND>

<L>972<pc>028-a<k1>aYca<k2>aYca
{#aYca#}¦ m. ({#-YcaH#}) Going. It occurs only as the latter part of
<div n="lb">compounds; f. i. in {#romAYca#}. E. {#aYc,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>979<pc>028-a<k1>aYj<k2>aYj
{#aYj#}¦ I. ({#anjU-ruDAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 7th cl. par. ({#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nakti-#} ved. 1st cl. {#aYjati-te-AnaYja-aYjitA#} or {#aNktA-aYji-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyati#} or {#aNkzyati-AYjIt, AYjizuH-aYjitvA#} or {#aNktvA#} or {#aktvA-#}
<div n="lb">p. p. {#akta#}. Desid. {#aYjijizati#}. Caus. {#aYjayati-AYjijat#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> To anoint. <sup>2</sup> To make clear. <sup>3</sup> To glorify, to extol. <sup>4</sup> To
<div n="lb">go, to approach. <sup>5</sup> To be beautiful. With {#aBi-#} To anoint,
<div n="lb">to embellish.--{#A-#} <sup>1</sup> To anoint. <sup>2</sup> To glorify, to extol.
<div n="lb">--{#ni-pra-prati-#} To anoint, to embellish.--{#vi-#} <sup>1</sup> To
<div n="lb">anoint. <sup>2</sup> To make clear or manifest. Caus. To cause to be-
<div n="lb">come clear, to reveal.--{#aBivi-#} To make manifest.--
<div n="lb">{#sam-#} <sup>1</sup> To anoint, to embellish. <sup>2</sup> To extol, to glorify. <sup>3</sup> To
<div n="lb">join, to connect.
<div n="P">II. ({#aji-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. ({#aYjayati#}) To
<div n="lb">shine. (It seems to occur only in vulgar speech.)
<LEND>

<L>980<pc>028-a<k1>aYjaka<k2>aYjaka

<L>981<pc>028-a<k1>aYjana<k2>aYjana
{#aYjana#}¦ I. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, making clear or distinct &c.
<div n="lb">See the meanings of {#aYj#}. <sup>2</sup> A collyrium or application to
[Page028-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">the eye lashes, to darken and improve them; a universal
<div n="lb">article of the eastern toilet. <sup>3</sup> The name of particular kinds
<div n="lb">of the former, viz. lamp black, antimony, and one ex-
<div n="lb">tracted from the Ammonium zanthorrhiza. <sup>4</sup> Ink. <sup>5</sup> Night.
<div n="lb">(See {#aktu#}.) <sup>6</sup> Fire. <sup>7</sup> (In rhetoric.) Suggesting the special
<div n="lb">meaning of a word or a sentence. The special meaning of
<div n="lb">a word ({#Sabda#}) is suggested, according to Hindu rhetoric,
<div n="lb">by its connexion with either the real ({#aBiDA#}) or the el-
<div n="lb">liptic sense ({#lakzaRA#}) of other words; and the special mean-
<div n="lb">ing of a sentence ({#arTa#}) by circumstances connected with
<div n="lb">either the speaker or the addressed, or the occasion, place,
<div n="lb">time or the like. More usually called {#vyaYjanA#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> A species of lizard. <sup>2</sup> The elephant of the
<div n="lb">west or, according to others, of the south-west quarter.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> The name of a fabulous serpent. <sup>4</sup> The name of a king
<div n="lb">of Mithilā, the son of Kuni. <sup>5</sup> The name of a tree. <sup>6</sup> The
<div n="lb">name of a mountain. See {#aYjanAgiri#}.
<div n="P">III. f. 1. ({#-nA#}) <sup>1</sup> The mother of the monkey Hanumat.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The daughter of Vajrendra and mother of Pravarasena.
<div n="P">2. ({#-nI#}) <sup>1</sup> A woman who is fit to be perfumed with
<div n="lb">sandal &c. <sup>2</sup> The name of a medicinal plant. See {#kawukA,#}
<div n="lb">{#kAlAYjanI#} and {#aYjanakI#}.
<div n="P">E. {#aYj,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>982<pc>028-b<k1>aYjanaka<k2>aYjanaka

<L>1010<pc>029-b<k1>aw<k2>aw
{#aw#}¦ I. ({#awa-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet#}) r. 1st cl. par. ({#awati-#}
<div n="lb">{#Awa-awitA-awizyati-AwIt#}.--Caus. {#Awayati-Awi-#}
<div n="lb">{#wat#}.--Desid. {#awiwizati#}.--Intens. {#awAwyate#}.) To go round
<div n="lb">about, to roam, to rove, to ramble, to wander about, espe-
<div n="lb">cially as a religious mendicant. With {#pari#}--the same with
<div n="lb">an intense meaning.
<div n="P">II. ({#awa-curAdi-parasmEpadin#}) r. 10th cl. par. ({#Awayati#})
<div n="lb">To slight &c. See {#aww#} II, of which it is given as a various
<div n="lb">reading.
<LEND>

<L>1062<pc>030-b<k1>aRu<k2>aRu
{#aRu#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-RuH-RuH#} or {#RvI-Ru#}) Small, minute, atomic.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-RuH#}) <sup>1</sup> An atom, a minute and elementary par-
<div n="lb">ticle of matter. <sup>2</sup> (According to some Purāṇas) A measure
<div n="lb">of time, consisting of two Paramāṇus; 54,675,000 aṇus are
<div n="lb">said to be equal to one muhūrta. <sup>3</sup> A sort of grain (Pani-
<div n="lb">cum miliaceum). See {#DAnya#}. <sup>4</sup> A name of Śiva.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-RvI#}) (ved.) A finger.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-Ru#}) (In prosody.) The fourth part of a {#mAtrA#}
<div n="lb">q. v. E. {#aR,#} uṇ. aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">out altering the meaning of {#aRu;#} in 2. with the sense of
<div n="lb">comparison, ‘like one who sees minute objects, who is

<L>1122<pc>032-a<k1>ati<k2>ati
{#ati#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) <sup>1</sup> Over,
<div n="lb">beyond. <sup>2</sup> Exceedingly, very much. This word is used
<div n="lb">either as a separable preposition with a word following
<div n="lb">in the accusative, or as an inseparable prefix in compo-
<div n="lb">sition with verbal and nominal themes. If {#ati,#} in com-
<div n="lb">position with a nominal theme, constitutes a Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">pound, it must either express a higher degree (f. i. in
<div n="lb">{#atirAjan,#} a superior or excellent king) or the sense of
<div n="lb">the word {#krAnta#} must be supplied after it and the latter
<div n="lb">part of the compound understood in the sense of the accu-
[Page032-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">sative (f. i. in {#atiKawvaH#} which is explained as meaning
<div n="lb">{#atikrAntaH KawvAm#}). E. {#at,#} kṛt aff. {#in(?)#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">lief or trust. <sup>2</sup> Erring, deviating from the duties of a pro-
<div n="lb">fession or cast. E. {#ati#} and {#kaTA#}. Some works substitute
<div n="lb">for this word the reading {#itikaTa#} q. v., which seems to be
<div n="lb">the more correct form.
