<L>1153<pc>033-a<k1>atigraha<k2>atigraha
{#atigraha#}¦ m. ({#-haH#}) I. Overtaking, surpassing. E. {#grah#} with
<div n="lb">{#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. (In the philosophical terminology of the
<div n="lb">Upanishads) that which goes beyond the grahas or the
<div n="lb">eight instruments of apprehension i. e. the objects or func-
<div n="lb">tions of apprehension themselves: thus with the graha {#prARa#}
<div n="lb">(meaning there ‘the nose’) corresponds the atigraha {#apAna#}
<div n="lb">(meaning there ‘fragrant substance’), with the graha {#vAc,#}
<div n="lb">the atigraha {#nAman#} and likewise, with the other six grahas
<div n="lb">{#jihvA, cakzus, Srotra, manas, hasta, tvac,#} the atigrahas {#rasa,#}
<div n="lb">{#rUpa, Sabda, kAma, karman#} and {#sparSa#}.--Also called {#atigrAha#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#ati#} and {#graha#} (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">sophical meaning. E. {#ati#} and {#grAha#} (in the sense of the accus.).

<L>1158<pc>033-b<k1>aticara<k2>aticara
{#aticara#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Going very much.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-rA#}) The name of a plant which grows in Bengal
<div n="lb">(Hibiscus mutabilis). See also {#padmacAriRI, avyaTA, padmA#}
<div n="lb">and {#cArawI#}. E. {#ati#} (very much) and {#cara,#} or {#ati#} (sc.
<div n="lb">{#krAnta#}) and {#cara#} (going i. e. a living being, in the sense of
<div n="lb">the accusative); the plant being called so, because ‘it grows
<div n="lb">in impervious places and, therefore, goes beyond the reach
<div n="lb">of living beings’.
<LEND>

<L>1165<pc>033-b<k1>atijagatI<k2>atijagatI
{#atijagatI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tI#}) The name of a class of metres
<div n="lb">regulated by number and quantity. See {#aticCandas#}. It
<div n="lb">comprises sixteen varieties and consists of a stanza of
<div n="lb">four lines, with thirteen syllables in each line. (See
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> {#praharziRI,#} <sup>2</sup> {#rucirA#} (or {#atirucirA#}), <sup>3</sup> {#mattamayUra#} (or {#mA-#}

<div n="lb">{#lagati#}), <sup>7</sup> {#kalahaMsa#} (or {#citravatI,#} or {#siMhanAda#}), <sup>8</sup> {#caYcarikA-#}
<div n="lb">{#valI,#} <sup>9</sup> {#candraleKA,#} <sup>10</sup> {#vidyut,#} <sup>11</sup> {#mfgendramuKa,#} <sup>12</sup> {#tAraka,#} <sup>12</sup> {#ka-#}
[Page034-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#lAkanda#} (or {#kanda#}), <sup>14</sup> {#paNkajAvalI#} (or {#paNkAvalI#}), <sup>15</sup> {#caRqI,#}
<div n="lb"><sup>16</sup> {#praBAvatI#}.) E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#jagatI#} (in the sense

<L>1179<pc>034-a<k1>atityad<k2>atityad
{#atityad#}¦ Tatpur. Beyond that. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAnta#}) and {#tyad#}
<div n="lb">(in the sense of the accusative). This word seems to be
<div n="lb">only one of grammatical coinage, to show that the declen-
<div n="lb">sion of {#tyad#} in compositions like these is like that of other
<div n="lb">nouns ending in {#d#} and not that of the pronominal theme
<div n="lb">{#tyad;#} i. e. {#atityad, atityadO#} &c. (instead of {#atisyaH,#}
<div n="lb">{#atityO#} &c.).
<LEND>

<L>1180<pc>034-a<k1>atitvam<k2>atitvam
{#atitvam#}¦ Tatpur. m. Surpassing thee. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntaH#})
<div n="lb">and {#tvam#} (in the sense of {#tvAm#}). This word seems to be,
<div n="lb">like the last, only a grammatical one and scarcely in real
<div n="lb">use; its declension is equally purely fictitious and vary-
<div n="lb">ing, even, according to the different grammatical autho-
<div n="lb">rities. See the following and {#atitvAm, atiyUyam,#} also
<div n="lb">{#atyaham#}.
<LEND>

<L>1183<pc>034-b<k1>atiTi<k2>atiTi
{#atiTi#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-TiH-TI-Ti#}) One who arrives and,
<div n="lb">though entirely unknown, is entitled to the rites of hospi-
<div n="lb">tality, a guest. See {#atiTin#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-TiH#}) <sup>1</sup> A proper name of a king of Ayodhyā, the
<div n="lb">son of Kuśa and grandson of Rāma. <sup>2</sup> The vaidik name of an
<div n="lb">attendant of Soma. (This latter meaning is more likely to
<div n="lb">be taken in a figurative sense, Soma being mentioned as
<div n="lb">the name of a king and Agni, Atithi, Śyena as those of his
<div n="lb">attendants). E. {#at,#} uṇ. aff. {#iTin#}. ({#atiTi#} in the mean-
<div n="lb">ing of ‘guest’ is also explained as a Bahuvr. ‘one who has
<div n="lb">no kind of {#tiTi#} or holy day, who may arrive any day’
<div n="lb">or ‘one who does not sojourn a whole tithi, but only one
<div n="lb">single night’, or ‘one who is not steady (when {#tiTi#} is
<div n="lb">supposed to be a mutilated form of {#sTiti#})’; all these ex-
<div n="lb">planations are artificial.)
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-TiH#}) Wrath, anger. E. {#a#} priv. and
<div n="lb">{#tiTi#} ‘not restricted to a tithi, what may come at any time’.
<LEND>

<L>1212<pc>035-a<k1>atideSa<k2>atideSa
{#atideSa#}¦ m. ({#-SaH#}) A rule providing for something more than
<div n="lb">the ordinary or established rules (see {#pradeSa, upadeSa#}) pro-
<div n="lb">vide for and not comprehended by them; it may be either
<div n="lb">enjoined specially or derived from inference; if such a rule,
<div n="lb">in grammar, affects the form, gender &c. of a word,
<div n="lb">it is called {#rUpAtideSa, liNgAtideSa#} &c.; in philosophy
<div n="lb">atideśas of a general or comprehensive nature are called
<div n="lb">{#sAmAnyAtideSa#} and those restricted to a special case {#viSe-#}
<div n="lb">{#zAtideSa#}. See also {#SAstrAtideSa, kAryAtideSa, nimittA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tideSa, vyapadeSAtideSa#}. E. {#diS#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<L>1215<pc>035-a<k1>atiDfti<k2>atiDfti
{#atiDfti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a class of metres
<div n="lb">which are regulated by number and quantity. See {#ati-#}
<div n="lb">{#cCandas#}. It comprises thirteen varieties and consists of
<div n="lb">a stanza of four lines with nineteen syllables in each
<div n="lb">line. (See <sup>1</sup> {#SArdUla#} or {#SArdUlavikrIqita,#} <sup>2</sup> {#meGavisPurjita#} or
<div n="lb">{#vismita,#} <sup>3</sup> {#paYcacAmara,#} <sup>4</sup> {#puzpadAman,#} <sup>5</sup> {#bimbA,#} <sup>6</sup> {#CAyA,#} <sup>7</sup> {#maka-#}
<div n="lb">{#randikA,#} <sup>8</sup> {#samudratawA,#} <sup>9</sup> {#surasA,#} <sup>10</sup> {#maRimaYjarI,#} <sup>11</sup> {#candramAlA#}
<div n="lb">or {#candra,#} <sup>12</sup> {#DavalANka#} or {#Davala,#} <sup>13</sup> {#samBu#}.) <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic
<div n="lb">sometimes used to denote) the number nineteen. E. {#ati#}
<div n="lb">(sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#Dfti#} (in the sense of the accusative) ‘going
<div n="lb">beyond the metre {#Dfti#} q. v.’.

<div n="lb">(sc. {#krAntam#}) and {#prezita#} (in the sense of the accusative).

<L>1253<pc>036-a<k1>atibala<k2>atibala
{#atibala#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) Very strong,
<div n="lb">very powerful.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> An active soldier. <sup>2</sup> The name of a king.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-lA#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a medicinal plant ‘employed
[Page036-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">against disorders from wind, worms, sickness, burning
<div n="lb">heat and thirst, excess of saliva, in pregnancy &c. and
<div n="lb">considered as possessing strengthening properties’ (Sidonia
<div n="lb">cordifolia and rhombifolia, or according to others Annona
<div n="lb">squamosa). <sup>2</sup> A proper name, a daughter of Daksha and
<div n="lb">wife of Kaśyapa. <sup>3</sup> The name of a mystical verse or charm,
<div n="lb">used as a mystical weapon. E. {#ati#} and {#bala#}.
<LEND>

<L>1301<pc>037-b<k1>atirAtra<k2>atirAtra
{#atirAtra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-traH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of the fifth part or Soma-
<div n="lb">sansthā of the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice, for the complete per-
<div n="lb">formance of which, however, it is not considered nitya, es-
<div n="lb">sential or obligatory but kāmya, voluntary, viz. if the sacri-
<div n="lb">ficer institutes it for the sake of progeny, and therefore anitya,
<div n="lb">not always taking place, supererogatory. (See {#agnizwoma#}.)
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The usual beginning and concluding part of those Ahargaṇa
<div n="lb">sacrifices which are called Sattra (q. v.) and the beginning or
<div n="lb">the concluding part of those which are called Ahīna (q. v.).
<div n="lb">There are, however, exceptions to this rule, see f. i. {#paYcadaSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAtra, kuRqapAyinAmayana#}. <sup>3</sup> The name of the Sāmaveda verse
<div n="lb">which closes the ceremonies of the sacrifices mentioned before.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> A proper name, the son of Chākṣuṣa or the sixth Manu by
<div n="lb">Nadvalā. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntaH#}) and {#rAtri#} (in the sense of
<div n="lb">the accusative), samāsānta aff. {#ac;#} properly meaning ‘last-
<div n="lb">ing beyond a night’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">or sacrificial animal in the Atirātra (q. v.). It is a ewe con-
<div n="lb">secrated to Sarasvatī and subject to the regulations which
<div n="lb">exist for the {#agnIzomIyapaSu#} (q. v.) E. {#atirAtra#} and {#sava-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIyapaSu#}.
<LEND>

<L>1307<pc>037-b<k1>atirucira<k2>atirucira

[Page038-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">gulated by quantity, consisting of a stanza of four lines
<div n="lb">with twenty-nine syllables to each couplet, or according to
<div n="lb">others, a variety of the Gītyāryā, with thirty syllables in
<div n="lb">the first couplet and thirty-two in the second. Also called
<div n="lb">{#cUqikA#} or {#cUlikA#}. <sup>2</sup> A metre regulated by number and
<div n="lb">quantity; a variety of the metre {#atijagatI#} (q. v.) and con-
<div n="lb">sisting of a stanza of four lines with the following feet
<div n="lb">in each line: {??} Also called
<div n="lb">{#rucirA#}. E. {#ati#} and {#rucira#}.

<L>1340<pc>038-b<k1>ativiza<k2>ativiza
{#ativiza#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-zaH-zA-zam#}) <sup>1</sup> Bahuvr. Very poisonous.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Tatpur. Exceeding or subduing poison.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. (or Bahuvr.) f. ({#-zA#}) The name of a most
<div n="lb">poisonous plant growing in Nepal used in medicine as an
<div n="lb">antidote and also against disorders produced by bilious fe-
<div n="lb">vers, dysentery, sickness, preternatural parturition &c.
<div n="lb">Its bark is also employed in dying; it is of three kinds,
<div n="lb">white, red and black. The root is employed by the natives
<div n="lb">of India and Nepal to poison the barbs of arrows (Aco-
<div n="lb">nitum ferox). E. Bahuvr. {#ati#} and {#viza;#} Tatpur. {#ati#} (sc.
<div n="lb">{#krAnta#}) and {#viza#} (in the sense of the accusative).
<LEND>

<L>1357<pc>039-a<k1>atiSakvarI<k2>atiSakvarI
{#atiSakvarI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-rI#}) The name of a class of metres
<div n="lb">regulated by number and quantity. See {#aticCandas#}. It
<div n="lb">consists in the classic Sanskṛt of a stanza of four lines
<div n="lb">with fifteen syllables in each line and comprises eighteen
<div n="lb">varieties. (See <sup>1</sup> {#candrAvartA,#} <sup>2</sup> {#mAlA#} or {#sraj,#} <sup>3</sup> {#maRiguRani-#}
<div n="lb">{#kara,#} <sup>4</sup> {#mAlinI#} or {#nandImuKI,#} <sup>5</sup> {#candraleKA,#} <sup>6</sup> {#kAmakrIqA#} or
<div n="lb">{#lIlAKelA#} or {#saraNgaka,#} <sup>7</sup> {#praBadraka#} or {#suBadraka#} or {#sukesara,#} <sup>8</sup> {#e-#}
<div n="lb">{#lA,#} <sup>9</sup> {#upamAlinI,#} <sup>10</sup> {#vipinatilaka,#} <sup>11</sup> {#citrA,#} <sup>12</sup> {#tuRaka#} or
<div n="lb">{#cAmara,#} <sup>13</sup> {#BramarAvalI,#} <sup>14</sup> {#manahaMsa,#} <sup>15</sup> {#saraBa#} or {#SaSikalA,#} <sup>16</sup> {#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#SipAla,#} <sup>17</sup> {#utsara,#} <sup>18</sup> {#haMsa#}.) Also written, though not cor-
<div n="lb">rectly, {#atiSakkarI#}. E. {#ati#} (sc. {#krAntA#}) and {#SakvarI#} (in the
<div n="lb">sense of the accusative), another metre.
<LEND>

<L>1358<pc>039-a<k1>atiSaya<k2>atiSaya
{#atiSaya#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Excellent, superior, excessive.
<div n="lb">(The femin. is very seldom used.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Excellence, superiority, excessiveness.
<div n="lb">({#atiSayena#} used adverbially.) <sup>2</sup> Advantage, visible result
<div n="lb">of an action (opposed to {#apUrva#} q. v.). <sup>3</sup> A superhuman qua-
<div n="lb">lity inherent to a Jaina Arhat; there are thirty-four such
<div n="lb">qualities belonging to them, four of which regard their per-
[Page039-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">sonal accomplishment, eleven their supernatural powers and
<div n="lb">the remaining twenty-nine their celestial attributes.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-yam#}) used as adverb. Very much, excessive.
<div n="lb">E. {#SI#} with {#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a variety of the class called {#atyazwi#} (q. v.) and consisting
<div n="lb">of a stanza of four lines with the following feet in each
<div n="lb">line: {??} Also called
<div n="lb">{#citraleKA#}.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-nam#}) used as adverb. Excessively. E. {#SI#} with
<div n="lb">{#ati,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>1476<pc>042-a<k1>atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani<k2>atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani
{#atyantatiraskftavAcyaDvani#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-niH#}) (In rhetoric.)
<div n="lb">A metaphorical expression, when the word expressing the fi-
<div n="lb">gure or comparison drops its literal sense in order to be-
<div n="lb">come appropriate for the comparison; f. i. in the sentence
<div n="lb">‘the moon does not shine, like a mirror which has become
<div n="lb">blind by breathing upon it’--the word ‘blind’ loses its
<div n="lb">literal meaning, to serve as a comparison for ‘the not shin-
<div n="lb">ing’ of the moon with which it has no common quality.
<div n="lb">E. {#atyanta, tiraskfta, vAcya#} (these three words forming a
<div n="lb">Bahuvr.) and {#Dvani#}.
<LEND>

<L>1526<pc>043-b<k1>atra<k2>atra

<L>1533<pc>044-a<k1>atri<k2>atri
{#atri#}¦ m. ({#-triH#}) <sup>1</sup> Eater, devourer (in the Vedas especially as
<div n="lb">an epithet of Agni, the divinity of fire). <sup>2</sup> The name of a
<div n="lb">Maharshi or a great Saint, who in the Vedas occurs especi-
<div n="lb">ally in hymns composed for the praise of Agni, Indra, the
<div n="lb">Aśvins and the Viśvadevas; and who in the epic period
<div n="lb">is considered as one of the ten Prajāpatis or lords of crea-
<div n="lb">tion engendered by Manu for the purpose of creating the
<div n="lb">universe; at a later period he appears as a mindborn son
<div n="lb">of Brahmā and as one of the seven Ṛṣis who preside
<div n="lb">over the reign of Svāyambhuva, the first, or according to
<div n="lb">others of Svārochiṣa, the second, or of Vaivaswata, the
<div n="lb">seventh Manu; he is married to Anasūyā, the daughter of
<div n="lb">Daksha and their son is Durvāsas. Produced by a flash of
<div n="lb">light from his eye which was received by Space, the via
<div n="lb">lactea personified, or according to a more recent legend,
<div n="lb">by his penitence, is Soma or the moon. See {#atrijAta,#}
<div n="lb">{#atridfgja, atrinetraja#} &c. As sons of his are also named
<div n="lb">the Manes Barhishads and Udamaya; a daughter of his is
<div n="lb">Apālā. The name of Atri occurs also as that of the author
<div n="lb">of several vaidik hymns, as that of an inspired legislator,
<div n="lb">of the author of an astronomical and medical work and,
<div n="lb">in astronomy, as one of the seven Ṛṣis in the constel-
<div n="lb">lation of the great bear.--An Atri, son of Sāṅkhya, but
<div n="lb">probably a different personage, is the author of a hymn in
<div n="lb">the Ṛgveda.--Amongst the authors of vaidik hymns we
<div n="lb">find as sons or descendants of Atri the following: Archa-
<div n="lb">nāna, Avasyu, Bāhuvṛkta, Bhauma, Budha, Dvita, Ga-
<div n="lb">viṣṭhira, Gaya, Gopavana, Isha, Paura, Pratibhānu, Pra-
<div n="lb">tiprabha, the Prayaswats, Purīṣa, Ratahavya, Sadāpṛṇa,
<div n="lb">Saptavadhri, Śaśa, Satyaśravas, Śrutavid, Sutambhara,
<div n="lb">Śyāvāśva, Vasuśruta, the Vasūyus, Viśvasāman, Yajata;
<div n="lb">and as daughters of Atri, Apālā, Gātu, Viśvavārā. <sup>3</sup> m.
<div n="lb">pl. ({#atrayaH#}) The descendants (see {#gotra#}) of Atri collectively.
<div n="lb">(The masc. plur. {#atrayaH#} is considered as the plur. of the
<div n="lb">patronymic {#Atreya#} (q. v.) with luk of the taddh. aff. {#Qak;#}
<div n="lb">the plural of the fem., however, remaining regular, viz.
<div n="lb">{#AtreyyaH;#} but there is no necessity to adopt this artificial
<div n="lb">etymology which is given to connect the sense of the pa-
<div n="lb">tronymic with that of the plur. of the original form.) E.
<div n="lb">See {#attri#}.
<LEND>

<L>1548<pc>044-b<k1>aTa<k2>aTa
{#aTa#}¦ ind. An inceptive and auspicious particle. It serves to
<div n="lb">introduce the beginning of a work, a chapter, a sentence
<div n="lb">and with respect to the latter may imply doubt or inter-
<div n="lb">rogation or may serve as a conjunctive or disjunctive par-
<div n="lb">ticle. It may be accompanied by those particles or words
<div n="lb">which themselves are used in the same sense, giving them
<div n="lb">greater emphasis, especially by {#u, atas, anantaram, kim,#}
<div n="lb">{#tu, punar, vA, kimu, api#}. Without or with these particles
<div n="lb">{#aTa#} corresponds therefore with: <sup>1</sup> Now (inceptive or pre-
<div n="lb">mising); in the same sense but with greater emphasis {#aTo#}
<div n="lb">({#aTa#} and {#u#}), {#aTAtas, aTAnantaram#}. <sup>2</sup> Why? what? (in-
<div n="lb">terrogatively and doubtingly); (likewise {#aTavA#}.) <sup>3</sup> How
<div n="lb">else? certainly; (in the same sense {#aTakim#}.) <sup>4</sup> But, on the
<div n="lb">contrary; (in the same sense {#aTa tu, aTa punar#}.) <sup>5</sup> Or, or
<div n="lb">rather; (likewise {#aTavA, aTavApi, aTApi vA#} &c.) <sup>6</sup> More-
<div n="lb">over, so much the more, therefore, thus; (likewise {#aTaca,#}
<div n="lb">{#aTApi, aTo api, aTa kimu#}.) In the Vedas there occurs
<div n="lb">also the protracted form {#aTA#} which seems to be the more
<div n="lb">original one; (cf. {#taTA#} and {#yaTA#}). E. According to the native
<div n="lb">authorities from {#arT,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#} with {#r#} being dropped;
<div n="lb">but it is more probably derived from {#a,#} the pron. theme
<div n="lb">which is considered as a substitute for {#idam#} (pointing to
<div n="lb">what follows), taddh. aff. {#Ta#}.
<LEND>

<L>1549<pc>044-b<k1>aTakim<k2>aTakim
{#aTakim#}¦ ind. A particle of assent, how else, what else, as-
<div n="lb">suredly. (Better to be considered as two words. See {#aTa#}.)
<div n="lb">E. {#aTa#} and {#kim#}.
<LEND>

<L>1550<pc>044-b<k1>aTakimu<k2>aTakimu
{#aTakimu#}¦ ind. So much the more. (Better to be considered as
<div n="lb">two separate words and also written {#aTa kimu#}. See {#aTa#}.)
<div n="lb">E. {#aTa#} and {#kimu#}.
<LEND>

<L>1551<pc>044-b<k1>aTaca<k2>aTaca
{#aTaca#}¦ ind. Also, moreover. (Better to be considered as two
<div n="lb">words. See {#aTa#}.) E. {#aTa#} and {#ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>1552<pc>044-b<k1>aTatu<k2>aTatu
{#aTatu#}¦ ind. But, on the contrary. (More properly to be con-
<div n="lb">sidered as two distinct words and also written {#aTa tu#}. See
<div n="lb">{#aTa#}.) E. {#aTa#} and {#tu#}.
<LEND>
[Page045-a+ 56]

<L>1553<pc>045-a<k1>aTarI<k2>aTarI
{#aTarI#}¦ f. (occurs only as a plural in the Vedas; {#-ryaH#}) The
<div n="lb">finger. E. This word is given as an irregular derivation
<div n="lb">from {#at#} ‘to go constantly’; but it is more probable that
<div n="lb">it is derived, with aff. {#ari,#} from an obsolete rad. {#aT#}
<div n="lb">which seems to have had the same meaning as {#at#} (cf.
<div n="lb">{#aw#} and {#aW#}), but is found only in {#aTarI, aTarvan#} and their
<div n="lb">derivatives, implying quickness or agility. The same etymo-
<div n="lb">logical connexion between words meaning ‘finger’ and ‘fire’
<div n="lb">may be perceived in other derivations from a radical in the
<div n="lb">sense of ‘to go’ f. i. in {#aNguli#} or {#aNguri, agrU#} and {#agni, aNgiras,#}
<div n="lb">from {#aNg#}. It reappears distinctly in the denom. {#aTary#} and
<div n="lb">its derivatives {#aTarya, aTaryu#} qq. vv.
<LEND>

<L>1554<pc>045-a<k1>aTary<k2>aTary
{#aTary#}¦ par. ({#-ryati#}) To go, to move. (Only in the Vedas.)
<div n="lb">Probably a denominative from {#aTarI#} or {#aTar#} with aff. {#yak#}.
<LEND>

<L>1555<pc>045-a<k1>aTarya<k2>aTarya
{#aTarya#}¦ m. ({#-ryaH#}) Moving constantly; an epithet of Agni in the
<div n="lb">Vedas. See also the following. E. {#aTary,#} kṛt aff. {#ac(?)#}.
<div n="lb">A commentary explains, that {#aTarya#} is an epithet of {#dakzi-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAgni,#} because the sacred fire ‘goes always’ from the Gār-
<div n="lb">hapatya (q. v.) to his proper place; the epithet may be con-
<div n="lb">sidered, however, as one of a more general bearing.
<LEND>

<L>1556<pc>045-a<k1>aTaryu<k2>aTaryu
{#aTaryu#}¦ m. ({#-yuH#}) Moving constantly; an epithet of Agni in the
<div n="lb">Vedas. See the preceding. E. {#aTary,#} kṛt aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<L>1557<pc>045-a<k1>aTarva<k2>aTarva
{#aTarva#}¦ m. ({#-rvaH#}) A proper name of the eldest son of Brahmā,
<div n="lb">to whom Brahmā revealed the Brahmavidyā (q. v.) or know-
<div n="lb">ledge of God. See {#aTarvan#}. E. See {#aTarvan#} of which it is
<div n="lb">an abbreviated form.
<LEND>

<L>1558<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaRa<k2>aTarvaRa
{#aTarvaRa#}¦ m. ({#-RaH#}) A name of Śiva. E. {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#a(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>1559<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaRi<k2>aTarvaRi
{#aTarvaRi#}¦ m. ({#-RiH#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brahman versed in the Atharvaveda.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> A family priest. E. See {#ATarvaRi#} which is the better
<div n="lb">reading of this word.
<LEND>

<L>1560<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvan<k2>aTarvan
{#aTarvan#}¦ 1. m. ({#-rvA#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brāhmaṇa, a priest (probably one
<div n="lb">connected with offerings to fire or the attendance on the
<div n="lb">holy fire). <sup>2</sup> The proper name of a priest who is considered
<div n="lb">to have obtained the fire from heaven and who in the course
<div n="lb">of mythological personification appears as a Prajāpati or
<div n="lb">father of all beings, as the inspired author of the fourth
<div n="lb">or Atharvaveda, as the eldest son of Brahmā to whom
<div n="lb">Brahmā revealed the Brahmavidyā (q. v.) or knowledge of
<div n="lb">God (see also {#aTarva#}) and, at a later period, as the same
<div n="lb">as Angiras (q. v.). Sons of his are Agni (see also {#aNgiras#}),
<div n="lb">Dadhyanch, Bhishaj, Bṛhaddiva, Kabandha. <sup>3</sup> An epithet of
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> Vasiṣṭha q. v., <sup>b.</sup> Soma q. v., <sup>c.</sup> {#prARa#} q. v., <sup>d.</sup> Śiva (the god being
<div n="lb">supposed to carry into effect the charms of the Atharvaveda).
<div n="P">2. m. n. ({#-rvA-rva#}) The fourth or Atharvaveda q. v. (see
<div n="lb">also m. pl. {#aTarvARaH#}).
<div n="P">3. m. pl. ({#-rvARaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The descendants of Atharvan; they
<div n="lb">appear sometimes coupled with the descendants of Bhṛgu
<div n="lb">and of Angiras (see {#aTarvANgirasaH#}). <sup>2</sup> The hymns of the
<div n="lb">fourth or Atharvaveda collectively (considered as the descen-
<div n="lb">dants of Atharvan); the Atharvaveda (see also {#aTarvANgi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasaH#}). E. From an obsolete theme {#aTar,#} fire, with taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#vanip#}. See the E. of {#aTarI#}. The oldest etym. which
<div n="lb">derives {#aTarvan#} from {#a#} neg. and {#Tarvan#} (from {#Tarv#} ‘to go’),
<div n="lb">is without any probability. A similar etym. is given of
<div n="lb">{#aTarvI#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>1561<pc>045-a<k1>aTarvaBUta<k2>aTarvaBUta
{#aTarvaBUta#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-tAH#}) An epithet of the twelve Maharshis:
[Page045-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#Darma, dakza, marIci, atri, pulastya, pulaha, kratu, vasizWa, gO-#}
<div n="lb">{#tama, Bfgu, aNgiras, manu#} and (according to a commentary)
<div n="lb">of ‘Rudra, the Lord of the Universe’. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#BUta#}
<div n="lb">(according to a commentary from {#BU,#} to obtain, ‘having
<div n="lb">obtained i. e. versed in the Atharvaveda, the same as {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#Tarvavid#}’).
<LEND>

<L>1562<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvavat<k2>aTarvavat
{#aTarvavat#}¦ ind. Like Atharvan or the descendants of Atharvan.
<div n="lb">E. {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#vati#}.
<LEND>

<L>1563<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvavid<k2>aTarvavid
{#aTarvavid#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vit#}) One versed in the Atharvaveda.
<div n="lb">See {#aTarvaBUta#}. According to the Pariśiṣṭa of this Veda esp.
<div n="lb">an epithet of the priest called Brahman q. v. See {#brahmaveda#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#aTarvan#} and {#vid#}.
<LEND>

<L>1564<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaveda<k2>aTarvaveda
{#aTarvaveda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) The fourth or Atharvaveda (see
<div n="lb">{#fc, yajus, sAman#}), the Veda revealed by Atharvan or
<div n="lb">Angiras and sometimes considered, therefore, personified
<div n="lb">as a son of Angiras. See {#aTarvan, aTarvANgiras, pratyaNgiras,#}
<div n="lb">{#brahmaveda#}. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#veda#}.
<LEND>

<L>1565<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaSiKA<k2>aTarvaSiKA
{#aTarvaSiKA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-KA#}) The name of one of the Upani-
<div n="lb">shads of the Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#SiKA#} ‘the crest’
<div n="lb">i. e. (according to the comm.) the essence of the Atharvaveda.
<LEND>

<L>1566<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvaSiras<k2>aTarvaSiras

<div n="lb">the Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#Siras#} ‘the head’ i. e.
<div n="lb">the principal Upanishad of the A. V.
<LEND>

<L>1567<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvahfdaya<k2>aTarvahfdaya

<div n="lb">Atharvaveda. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#hfdaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1568<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvANgiras<k2>aTarvANgiras
{#aTarvANgiras#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-rAH#}) The Angiras of the Athar-
<div n="lb">vaveda. This use of the word, as a Tatpur. in the sing.,
<div n="lb">is of later origin than that of the Dwandwa in the plur.,
<div n="lb">and, as it seems, adopted to explain the form {#aTarvANgi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasa#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. Dwandwa. m. pl. ({#-rasaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The descendants of Athar-
<div n="lb">van and of Angiras. <sup>2</sup> The Atharvaveda hymns of both
<div n="lb">collectively; the Atharvaveda (q. v.), one part (or parvan)
<div n="lb">of which is considered to have been revealed by the descen-
<div n="lb">dants of Atharvan and another by the descendants of An-
<div n="lb">giras. According to another explanation, however, this
<div n="lb">name of the Atharvaveda would merely refer to Atharvan
<div n="lb">(q. v.) being the inspired author of one part and Angiras
<div n="lb">(q. v.) of the other. E. {#aTarvan#} and {#aNgiras#}.
<LEND>

<L>1569<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvANgirasa<k2>aTarvANgirasa
{#aTarvANgirasa#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-saH-sI-sam#}) Referring or belonging
<div n="lb">to the {#aTarvANgirasaH#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-sam#}) The religious observances ({#karman#}) connected
<div n="lb">with the ritual of the Atharvaveda.
<div n="P">III. m. pl. ({#-sAH#}) The mantras or hymns of the Athar-
<div n="lb">vaveda. E. {#aTarvANgiras,#} taddh. aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>1570<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvARa<k2>aTarvARa
{#aTarvARa#}¦ n. ({#-Ram#}) The religious observances ({#karman#}) connected
<div n="lb">with the ritual of the Atharvaveda. E. Irregular derivation
<div n="lb">from {#aTarvan,#} taddh. aff. {#aR(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>1571<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvARavid<k2>aTarvARavid

<L>1572<pc>045-b<k1>aTarvI<k2>aTarvI
{#aTarvI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-vI#}). This word occurs only in the Veda
<div n="lb">and is explained ‘not going, unable to move’, from {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#TarvI#} (from {#Tarv,#} to go). It would seem, how-
<div n="lb">ever, that it is a Tatpur. composed of the obsolete word
<div n="lb">{#aTar,#} fire, and {#vI,#} ‘surrounded by fire’(?). See the E.
<div n="lb">of {#aTarvan#} and {#aTarI#}.
<LEND>
[Page046-a+ 56]

<L>1573<pc>046-a<k1>aTavA<k2>aTavA

<div n="lb">and {#vA#}.

<L>1579<pc>046-a<k1>ad<k2>ad
{#ad#}¦ I. ({#ada-adAdi-anudAtta-udAttet#}) r. 2d cl. par.
<div n="lb">({#atti-#} imperf. {#Adat-#} imper. {#adDi,#} ep. {#adasva-#} perf. {#Ada,#}
<div n="lb">2d pers. {#AdiTa-#} fut. 1. {#atsyati,#} 2. {#attA-#} inf. {#attum-#} p. p.
<div n="lb">{#adita#} ({#anna#} only used as subst.). Pass. {#adyate#}. Caus. {#Ada-#}
<div n="lb">{#yati-te#}.--For the tenses which are not formed of {#ad,#}
<div n="lb">see {#Gas#} which is then considered as a substitute of it.)
<div n="lb">To eat. (Caus. To feed.)--With {#ava(?)-A-pra-sam#}
<div n="lb">to eat, to devour; {#vi-#} to gnaw, to nibble.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#at#}) Eating. This word occurs only as the
<div n="lb">latter part of a Tatpur., the former part of which may be
<div n="lb">any word but {#anna#} (which forms {#annAda#} and not {#annAd#}).
<div n="lb">See f. i. {#ahutAd, AmAd, kravyAd#}. E. {#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#viw#}.

<L>1581<pc>046-a<k1>adakza<k2>adakza
{#adakza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) Awkward, unskilful.

<LEND>

<L>1582<pc>046-a<k1>adakziRa<k2>adakziRa
{#adakziRa#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) I. Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> Not right, left.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Not clever, unskilful. E. {#a#} neg. and {#dakziRa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Being or being performed without the presents
<div n="lb">usually given to Brahmans (see {#dakziRA#}), as a sacrifice &c.
<div n="lb">The celebration of a sacrifice without the Dakṣiṇā oc-
<div n="lb">curs for instance under the following circumstances: at
<div n="lb">the Prātaḥsavana of the Jyotiṣṭoma, when about to sing
<div n="lb">the Vahiṣpavamāna stotra, the priests step out from the
<div n="lb">house where the sacred fire is kept, one going after the
<div n="lb">other and holding the one who precedes by the hem of his
<div n="lb">garment: if it so happens, at this procession, that the
<div n="lb">Udgātṛ inadvertently drops the hem, the sacrifice goes on
<div n="lb">without the Dakṣiṇā; once accomplished, however, it is
<div n="lb">to be repeated and then the Udgātṛ has to pay the Dakṣiṇā
<div n="lb">which should have been given at the first performance; if
<div n="lb">the Pratihartṛ meets with a similar accident, he has to pay
<div n="lb">his whole property at the renewal of the ceremony, which
<div n="lb">then is called {#sarvasvadakziRa#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#dakziRA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1583<pc>046-a<k1>adakziRatva<k2>adakziRatva
{#adakziRatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Leftness, unskilfulness &c. <sup>2</sup> The state
<div n="lb">of a sacrifice performed without the Dakṣiṇā. See the pre-
<div n="lb">ceding. E. {#adakziRa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>1592<pc>046-b<k1>adatta<k2>adatta

<L>1593<pc>046-b<k1>adadryaYc<k2>adadryaYc
{#adadryaYc#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dryaN-drIcI-dryak#}) Going to that.
<div n="lb">(This word is probably one of a mere grammatical coinage,
<div n="lb">to illustrate a rule concerning the pronom. theme {#adas#}.
<div n="lb">According to some it would have the same meaning as {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#damuyaYc, amudryaYc#} and {#amumuyaYc#} to which others add {#ada-#}
<div n="lb">{#mudryaYc, amumUyaYc, adamUyaYc#} qq. vv., but it might also be
<div n="lb">that {#adadryaYc#} (as well as {#adamuyaYc, adamudryaYc, adamUyaYc#})
<div n="lb">is formed to show that its first part represents not the
<div n="lb">whole theme, but merely the neuter of {#adas,#} while the
<div n="lb">first part of {#amudryaYc, amumuyaYc#} and {#amumUyaYc#} refer to its
<div n="lb">masc. and femin. For the declension of this word, see
<div n="lb">{#aYc#} II. E. {#adas#} and {#aYc#} (II. 1.), with {#adri#} instead of
<div n="lb">the final {#as#} of {#adas#}.
<LEND>

<L>1600<pc>047-a<k1>adabDavratapramati<k2>adabDavratapramati

<div n="lb">and {#Ayu#}.)

<L>1602<pc>047-a<k1>adaBra<k2>adaBra

<div n="lb">neg. and {#daBra#}.

<L>1615<pc>047-a<k1>adas<k2>adas
{#adas#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#asO-asO-adas#}). The pronoun (see {#sarva-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAman#}) which generally points to what is absent, remote
<div n="lb">or uncertain (differently from {#idam#} q. v.) and which cor-
<div n="lb">responds with <sup>1</sup> That. <sup>2</sup> A certain (so and so). In correlative
<div n="lb">phrases it stands therefore usually in the prior sentence,
<div n="lb">imparting greater emphasis. Its declension is defective in
<div n="lb">as far as most of its cases are supplied by the themes {#asu#}
<div n="lb">or {#asa, amu (amU)#} and {#ami (amI)#}. The theme which ap-
[Page047-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">pears in composition is {#adas#} (except in the forms {#ada-#}
<div n="lb">{#dryaYc#} &c. q. v. See also {#adDA#}). In some derivations of rare
<div n="lb">occurrence we meet also with the themes {#asu, asa#} and {#amu;#}
<div n="lb">see {#asuka, asaka, amuka#}.
<div n="P">II. ind. (esp. in composition with radicals (see {#gati#}),
<div n="lb">when employed reflectively). So, in such a manner, f. i.
<div n="lb">{#adaHkftya#} having done so &c.--In conjunction with a re-
<div n="lb">lative pronoun or particle it has the effect of giving em-
<div n="lb">phasis or of generalising, e. g. {#yadadas#} whatever, {#yatrAdas#}
<div n="lb">wherever, {#yaTAdas#} howsoever. E. unknown; but it is pro-
<div n="lb">bably derived from the theme {#ad#} which occurs in {#ada-#}
<div n="lb">{#dryaYc#} and {#adDA#}.
<LEND>

<L>1616<pc>047-b<k1>adasy<k2>adasy
{#adasy#}¦ denom. par. ({#-syati#}) To become that. E. {#adas,#} de-
<div n="lb">nom. aff. {#yak#}.
<LEND>

<L>1632<pc>048-a<k1>aditi<k2>aditi
{#aditi#}¦ is in the Vedas often used as an epithet of Indra,
<div n="lb">the Maruts and Agni, but it becomes personified especially in
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-tiH#}) which in the Vedas means <sup>1</sup> the earth, <sup>2</sup> a
<div n="lb">cow, <sup>3</sup> speech; but especially <sup>4</sup> Aditi, the first goddess of
<div n="lb">the intermediate space or air, the mother of the Gods, who
<div n="lb">at a later period was considered as the daughter of Daksha
<div n="lb">and wife of Kaśyapa, as the sister of Agastya and as the
<div n="lb">mother of the twelve Ādityas, of the eight Vasus, eleven
<div n="lb">Rudras and two Aśvins, besides of the thirty-six Tushitas.
<div n="lb">--Aditi is in a still later time also an appellative of Durgā.
<div n="P">3. f. du. ({#-tI#}) (In the Vedas.) Heaven and earth.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} priv. and {#diti#}.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-tiH#}) A name of Mṛtyu, the god of Death;
<div n="lb">literally: the eater or devourer. (This meaning of the word
<div n="lb">occurs only in a commentary of an Upanishad and is rather
<div n="lb">doubtful.) E. {#ad#} (uṇ. aff. {#ti?#}).
<LEND>

{#aditija#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) A son of Aditi, a deity, a god.
<div n="lb">See {#aditinandana#}. E. {#aditi#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>1660<pc>048-b<k1>adfzwa<k2>adfzwa

<div n="lb">flagration, inundation &c.). <sup>2</sup> Fortune, destiny, fate. <sup>3</sup> (In
<div n="lb">philosophy.) <sup>a.</sup> Virtue or vice ({#Darma#} or {#aDarma#}), as the even-
<div n="lb">tual cause of pleasure or pain. <sup>b.</sup> The remote or unforeseen
<div n="lb">consequence of an act, e. g. heaven as that of religious
<div n="lb">rites &c. See {#apUrva#}.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-zwaH#}) A kind of poison or poisonous reptile (in
<div n="lb">the Vedas). E. {#a#} neg. and {#dfzwa#}.

<div n="lb">posed of. See {#adatta, datta, deya#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#deya#}.

<L>1688<pc>049-a<k1>adButa<k2>adButa

<div n="lb">name of the Indra or chief of the ninth Manwantara.

<div n="lb">or marvellous phenomenon. <sup>2</sup> (In architecture.) A kind of
<div n="lb">temple or vimāna, the breadth of which is divided into

<div n="lb">(doubtful) {#ad#} ind. and {#BU,#} uṇ. aff. {#qutac#}. Compare {#ana-#}

<L>1702<pc>049-b<k1>adya<k2>adya
{#adya#}¦ I. ind. <sup>1</sup> To-day. <sup>2</sup> Now, at present. In the Vedas also
<div n="lb">written {#adyA#} which seems to be the more original form of
<div n="lb">this word. {#adyApi#} Even now, still. {#adyapUrvam#} before to-
<div n="lb">day, before now. E. {#aS,#} considered as a substitute of
<div n="lb">{#idam,#} taddh. aff. {#dya;#} but more probably a Karmadh. com-
<div n="lb">pound of {#a#} (the pronom. theme in {#idam#}) and {#dya#} or {#dyA#}
<div n="lb">(from {#dyu#} or {#div#}) = {#asmindyavi#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-dyaH-dyA-dyam#}) Fit to be eaten, eatable.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-dyam#}) Food in general. E. {#ad,#} kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>1703<pc>049-b<k1>adyatana<k2>adyatana
{#adyatana#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nI-nam#}) Of or belonging to the
<div n="lb">current day, of to-day.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-naH#}) The period of a current day, from mid-
<div n="lb">night to midnight in the usual acceptation, but sometimes
<div n="lb">considered to begin and to end with sun-set or to begin
<div n="lb">with the proper time of rising and to end with the proper
<div n="lb">time of going to rest.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-nI#}) (In grammar.) The aorist (or {#luN#}), as the
<div n="lb">tense employed in relating what has happened during the
<div n="lb">current day. E. {#adya,#} taddh. aff. {#wyul#} and āgama {#tuw#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">the current day. E. {#adyatana,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.

<L>1711<pc>050-a<k1>adri<k2>adri

<L>1744<pc>050-b<k1>advaya<k2>advaya
{#advaya#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not duality, unity. <sup>2</sup> The
[Page051-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">identity of Brahman (n.) and the Universe or of the divine
<div n="lb">essence and the human soul; the real truth. E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#dvaya#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Without a second,
<div n="lb">only, alone; esp. in the neuter as an epithet of Brahman (n.)
<div n="lb">which is not distinct from the Universe.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) A name of Buddha (acc. to a commentary,
<div n="lb">because wisdom and object of wisdom are identical with
<div n="lb">him). E. {#a#} priv. and {#dvaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>1759<pc>051-a<k1>aDa<k2>aDa
{#aDa#}¦ ind. ({#nipAta#}) An inceptive particle which occurs only
<div n="lb">in the Vedas. It is used very much in the same manner as
<div n="lb">{#aTa#} of which it is apparently a variety and corresponds
<div n="lb">chiefly with <sup>1</sup> Now, hereafter. <sup>2</sup> Moreover, so much the
<div n="lb">more. <sup>3</sup> Therefore. It occurs frequently in its protracted
<div n="lb">form {#aDA#} which seems to be the more original one. E.
<div n="lb">See {#aTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1776<pc>051-b<k1>aDama<k2>aDama
{#aDama#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) <sup>1</sup> Very low or inferior in
<div n="lb">place or degree. <sup>2</sup> Vile, despicable. (In the vituperative
<div n="lb">sense it stands often as the latter part of a Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">pound; f. i. {#pApADama, narADama#}.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-maH#}) (In rhetoric, according to some.) A para-
<div n="lb">mour of a low description, one without fear, pity or shame &c.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-mA#}) (In rhetoric, according to some.) A mistress
<div n="lb">of a low description, one ungrateful, whimsical, acting
<div n="lb">unkindly towards her lover &c. E. {#av,#} uṇ. aff. {#ama,#} with
<div n="lb">{#v#} changed to {#Da;#} or according to others a Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">posed of {#a#} neg. and {#Dama#} (from {#DmA#}); but a preferable
<div n="lb">etym. is that from {#aDas,#} taddh. aff. {#ma,#} with elision of
<div n="lb">{#s;#} or better from {#aD#} (the thematic form common to {#aDama,#}
<div n="lb">{#aDara, aDas, aDastAt#}), aff. {#ama#}.
<LEND>

<L>1785<pc>052-a<k1>aDara<k2>aDara
{#aDara#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Lower, inferior, in place.
<div n="lb">(In this sense the word is declined like the sarvanāman {#yat#}
<div n="lb">&c. (q. v.), but in the abl. and loe. sing. of the mase. and
<div n="lb">neuter and in the nom. plur. of the mase. it forms optionally
<div n="lb">{#aDarasmAt#} or {#aDarAt, aDarasmin#} or {#aDare, aDare#} or {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#DarAH;#} it may form Tatpur. compositions with nouns having
<div n="lb">the sense of the singular and considered then as depending
<div n="lb">upon {#aDara,#} which is the former part of the compound, in
<div n="lb">the genitive; for instance {#aDarakAyaH#} is explained, {#aDaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#kAyasya#}.) Adverbially used are {#aDarAt, aDarasmAt, aDareRa;#}
<div n="lb">qq. vv. <sup>2</sup> Low, vile. <sup>3</sup> Speechless, refuted, overcome in abuse
<div n="lb">or controversy. <sup>4</sup> Prior, preceding in time. See {#aDaredyus#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) The lower lip, the lip.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-rA#}) <sup>1</sup> The lower region. <sup>2</sup> The nadir (?).
<div n="P">IV. m. n. ({#-raH-ram#}) Pudendum muliebre. E. Probably
<div n="lb">from {#aD#} (see E. of {#aDama#}), aff. {#ara;#} the derivation given
<div n="lb">by the native authorities, from {#a#} neg. and {#Dara#} is not correct.
<LEND>

<L>1786<pc>052-a<k1>aDarakaRWa<k2>aDarakaRWa
{#aDarakaRWa#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-RWaH-RWam?#}) The lower part of the
<div n="lb">throat. E. {#aDara#} and {#kaRWa#}. See under {#aDara#}.
<LEND>

<L>1787<pc>052-a<k1>aDarakAya<k2>aDarakAya
{#aDarakAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) The lower part of the body,

<div n="lb">minative or locative, but in the latter with the restriction

<L>1806<pc>052-b<k1>aDarma<k2>aDarma
{#aDarma#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-rmaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Unrighteousness, injustice, all
<div n="lb">behaviour contrary to the Śruti and Smṛti, or religious
<div n="lb">and legal institutions. <sup>2</sup> (In philosophy.) According to the
<div n="lb">Nyāya and Vaiśeṣika: moral demerit, the result of doing
<div n="lb">what is forbidden, the peculiar cause of pain, one of the
<div n="lb">twenty-four qualities united with substance.--According
<div n="lb">to the Sāṅkhya, one of the changeable ({#vEkftika#}) dispo-
<div n="lb">sitions ({#BAva#}) of the mind, which being the efficient cause,
<div n="lb">makes the soul migrate into an animal, a deer, a bird, a
<div n="lb">reptile, a vegetable, a mineral.--According to the Bud-
<div n="lb">dhistic doctrine it is the consequence of upādāna or exertion
<div n="lb">of body or speech.--According to the Jainas it is that
<div n="lb">which causes the soul in general to continue embarrassed
<div n="lb">with body notwithstanding its capacity for ascent and na-
<div n="lb">tural tendency to soar. <sup>3</sup> As a personification Adharma oc-
<div n="lb">curs in the Purāṇas as one of the Prajāpatis or mind-born
<div n="lb">sons of Brahmā; his wife is Hinsā (mischief) on whom he
<div n="lb">begot Anṛta (falsehood) and Nikṛti (immorality) or ac-
<div n="lb">cording to others, Mṛṣā (falsehood) and his children Dam-
<div n="lb">bha (hypocrisy) and Māyā (deceit) who were adopted by
<div n="lb">Nirṛti (misfortune).--Adharma is also mentioned as one
<div n="lb">of the eighteen servants of the sun.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-rmA#}) According to the Śāktas a kalā or part of
<div n="lb">the original or Mūla-prakṛti and personified as the bride
<div n="lb">of Mṛtyu or Death. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Darma#}.
<LEND>

<L>1807<pc>052-b<k1>aDarmacArin<k2>aDarmacArin

<div n="lb">wicked. E. {#aDarma#} and {#cArin#}.
<LEND>
[Page053-a+ 56]

<L>1818<pc>053-a<k1>aDas<k2>aDas
{#aDas#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Underneath, downwards or from below. <sup>2</sup> The lower
<div n="lb">regions, the nadir, or: from or in the lower regions, the nadir.
<div n="lb">(In these meanings it is used in the sense of a nominative,
<div n="lb">ablative or locative; or governs in the first meaning a noun in
<div n="lb">the genitive, more seldom in the ablative; the reiterated {#aDo#}
<div n="lb">{#'Das#} implies proximity and is followed by the noun in the
<div n="lb">accusative, f. i. {#aDo'Do grAmam#} below the village, but in its
<div n="lb">neighbourhood; it may occur as the former and as the latter
<div n="lb">part of Tatpur. compounds.) <sup>3</sup> Pudendum muliebre. <sup>4</sup> Away,
<div n="lb">out(?). See {#aDastAt;#} cf. {#aDarAk#}. E. {#aD#} (considered as a
<div n="lb">substitute of {#aDara,#} but more probably the thematic form
<div n="lb">common to {#aDama, aDara, aDas#} and {#aDastAt#}), taddh. aff. {#asi#}.

<div n="lb">the ablative. See {#aDas#}. E. {#aD#} (considered as a substitute

<L>1828<pc>053-b<k1>aDi<k2>aDi
{#aDi#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) A par-
<div n="lb">ticle implying superiority in place, power, rank, quality
<div n="lb">and quantity and generally used as a separable prepo-
<div n="lb">sition or as a prefix to verbs, but in the Vedas also as
<div n="lb">an adverb. With nouns it may form Tatpur., Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">and Avyayībhāva compounds. It means.
<div n="P">1. (as adverb, in the Vedas) very much, excessively.
<div n="P">2. (as a separable preposition) <sup>1</sup> with a noun following
<div n="lb">or preceding in the locative, <sup>a.</sup> above (in place), <sup>b.</sup> over (in
<div n="lb">the sense of mastership, power &c.), <sup>c.</sup> under (see {#aDIna#}
<div n="lb">and {#aDika#} 4, cf. {#aDas#}); <sup>2</sup> with a noun following or pre-
<div n="lb">ceding in the accusative, <sup>a.</sup> on, above (in place), <sup>b.</sup> concerning,
<div n="lb">with respect to, <sup>c.</sup> repeated it implies also proximity; f. i.
<div n="lb">{#aDyaDi grAmam#} above the village but in its neighbourhood;
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> with a noun following or preceding in the ablative (in the
<div n="lb">Vedas), <sup>a.</sup> on, above, <sup>b.</sup> from above, <sup>c.</sup> from (in this meaning
<div n="lb">it occurs also in the classical language, when it is supposed
<div n="lb">to be merely an expletive, the preceding ablative implying
<div n="lb">already the notion ‘from’), <sup>d.</sup> in consequence of, on behalf of,
<div n="lb"><sup>e.</sup> in presence of, before, in front of; <sup>4</sup> with a noun following
<div n="lb">or preceding in the genitive (in the Vedas), amidst, amongst.
<div n="P">3. (as a prefix to verbs) Over, esp. in the sense of
<div n="lb">taking possession of, mastering &c. literally or metapho-
<div n="lb">rically; but used also as an expletive esp. when followed by
<div n="lb">another preposition: f. i. with {#kf#} to superintend, with {#i#} to
<div n="lb">obtain, to study &c.; but it does not alter the meaning of
<div n="lb">{#Agam,#} when forming with the latter {#aDyAgam#}.
<div n="P">4. (in composition) <sup>1</sup> (with Tatpur. or Bahuvr.) it implies
<div n="lb">superiority in place, rank, quantity &c., <sup>2</sup> (with Avyayībh.)
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> concerning, with respect to, <sup>b.</sup> over. E. unknown.
<LEND>

<L>1829<pc>053-b<k1>aDi<k2>aDi
{#aDi#}¦ 1. m. ({#-DiH#}) Anxiety, mental pain; more usually {#ADi#}
<div n="lb">q. v. of which it seems to be an incorrect reading. E. see {#ADi#}.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-DiH#}) A woman in her courses. See also {#avi#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#i#} and {#D#} substituted for {#d#} or a Tatpur.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#Di#} (from {#DA#}). (The first etym. doubtful.)
<LEND>

<L>1830<pc>053-b<k1>aDika<k2>aDika
{#aDika#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Exceeding, in addition to
<div n="lb">(the reverse of {#nyUna;#} between both {#sADAraRa#}). <sup>2</sup> More, more
<div n="lb">than, superior (in place, power, rank, quality or quantity).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Very much, excessive, excellent. <sup>4</sup> Less, smaller, inferior (cf.
<div n="lb">{#aDi#} 2. 1. c.). {#aDikam#} used as adverb. (If {#aDika#} has the first of
<div n="lb">these meanings, that by which the excess is caused, stands in
<div n="lb">the instrumental or (but seldom) in the locative or forms the
<div n="lb">first part of a Tatpur. compound of which {#aDika#} is the latter;
<div n="lb">if it has the second meaning, the object compared with, stands
<div n="lb">in the instrumental, the ablative or in the genitive; if it has
<div n="lb">the last meaning, the object compared with stands in the abla-
<div n="lb">tive. Cf. {#aDyArUQa#}. With numerals {#aDika#} may form Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">compounds, usually in the plural, if it is the former part of
<div n="lb">the compound; for instance {#aDikacatvAriMSAH#} (sc. {#saMKyAH#}) i. e.
<div n="lb">more than fourty. It is considered as dropped in Dwandwa
<div n="lb">compounds of numerals f. i. in {#paYcaviMSati,#} equal to {#paYcADi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kaviMSati#}.) <sup>5</sup> Embolismic, intercalary (only in composition
<div n="lb">with and prefixed to the name or numeral of a luni-solar
<div n="lb">year, to the name of a month and to the name of a day;
[Page054-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">f. i. {#aDikASvina#}. See also {#aDikatiTi, aDikadina, aDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kamAsa, aDikasaMvatsara,#} and compare {#kzaya#}). <sup>5</sup> Subsequent,
<div n="lb">following (as a day, a chapter or a passage in a book &c.;
<div n="lb">used very much in the same manner as {#UrDva#}).
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> The surplus, that which is exceeding.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In Nyāya.) Superfluity in reasons or instances, giving
<div n="lb">more reasons or instances than are required or relevant in
<div n="lb">a syllogism. <sup>3</sup> (In rhetoric.) Hyperbole (of which two
<div n="lb">kinds are enumerated: hyperbole concerning the recipient
<div n="lb">(substance, subject &c.) and hyperbole concerning that
<div n="lb">which is to be received (accidents, predicate &c.). E. {#aDi,#}
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>1831<pc>054-a<k1>aDikatA<k2>aDikatA
{#aDikatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Excess, addition; also {#aDikatva#} n. ({#-tvam#}).
<div n="lb">E. {#aDika,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>1832<pc>054-a<k1>aDikakzayakArin<k2>aDikakzayakArin
{#aDikakzayakArin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) Causing
<div n="lb">excessive loss, wasting too much. E. {#aDika-kzaya#} and {#kArin#}.
<LEND>

<L>1833<pc>054-a<k1>aDikatiTi<k2>aDikatiTi
{#aDikatiTi#}¦ Karmadh. m. f. ({#-TiH-TiH#}) An intercalary lunar
<div n="lb">day. When no tithi (q. v.) begins or ends in a solar day,
<div n="lb">the numeral of the preceding is repeated in the calendar,
<div n="lb">the first tithi being accounted the intercalated and the second
<div n="lb">the proper one. Compare {#kzayatiTi#}. E. {#aDika#} and {#tiTi#}.
<LEND>

<L>1834<pc>054-a<k1>aDikadanta<k2>aDikadanta
{#aDikadanta#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-ntaH#}) A tooth growing over an-
<div n="lb">other. See {#aDidanta#} and {#varDana#}. E. {#aDika#} and {#danta#}.
<LEND>

<L>1835<pc>054-a<k1>aDikadina<k2>aDikadina
{#aDikadina#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-nam#}) An intercalated day. See
<div n="lb">{#aDikatiTi#}. Also {#aDidina#}. E. {#aDika#} and {#dina#}.
<LEND>

<L>1838<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRa<k2>aDikaraRa
{#aDikaraRa#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Superiority, supremacy, govern-
<div n="lb">ment. <sup>2</sup> Title, right. <sup>3</sup> Town meeting, court of justice. <sup>4</sup> Sup-
<div n="lb">port, receptacle. <sup>5</sup> Substance ({#dravya,#} as the recipient of quali-
<div n="lb">ties &c.). <sup>6</sup> (In grammar.) Comprehension, location, gener-
<div n="lb">ally the sense of the seventh or locative case, but occa-
<div n="lb">sionally also that of the third or instrumental and of the
<div n="lb">sixth or genitive case. <sup>7</sup> (In grammar.) Government, re-
<div n="lb">gimen; see {#ekADikaraRa, yugapadaDikaraRa, samAnADikaraRa#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>8</sup> (In philosophy.) A case or topic; esp. in the Mīmānsā
<div n="lb">and Vedānta; in the former it comprehends usually five
<div n="lb">parts or members, the subject ({#vizaya#}), the doubt ({#saMSaya#}),
<div n="lb">the first side (or objectionable) argument ({#pUrvapakza#}), the fol-
<div n="lb">lowing (or right) argument ({#uttarapakza#}) and the conclusion
<div n="lb">({#sidDAnta#} or {#rAdDAnta#}). Sometimes, however, the second
<div n="lb">part is inherent in the third and the fifth in the fourth.
<div n="lb">In both philosophies an adhikaraṇa is a subdivision of a
<div n="lb">pāda, which is the division of an adhyāya. E. {#kf#} with {#aDi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-RaH-RI#}). See {#aDikAra#} II. E. {#aDi#} and
<div n="lb">{#karaRa;#} in the fem. with aff. {#NIp#}.
<LEND>

<L>1839<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRamaRqapa<k2>aDikaraRamaRqapa
{#aDikaraRamaRqapa#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-paH-pam#}) A hall of the town
<div n="lb">council, a hall of justice(?). E. {#aDikaraRa#} and {#maRqapa#}.
<LEND>

<L>1840<pc>054-a<k1>aDikaraRasidDAnta<k2>aDikaraRasidDAnta
{#aDikaraRasidDAnta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ntaH#}) (In the Nyāya philoso-
<div n="lb">phy.) A truth or conclusion which implies another truth or
<div n="lb">conclusion; one of the four kinds of {#sidDAnta#}. See also {#sarva-#}
<div n="lb">{#tantrasidDAnta, pratitantrasidDAnta#} and {#aByupagamasidDAnta#}. E. {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#DikaraRa#} and {#sidDAnta,#} a paramount truth.
<LEND>

<L>1855<pc>054-b<k1>aDikAra<k2>aDikAra

<div n="lb">rity. <sup>2</sup> Rule, government. <sup>3</sup> Duty, office. <sup>4</sup> Right, title, owner-

<div n="lb">forms the subject of the sixth adhyāya of the Mīmānsā.

<div n="lb">which follow. Also written {#aDIkAra#}. E. {#kf#} with {#aDi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<div n="lb">form, very busy. E. {#aDi#} and {#kAra;#} in the fem. with aff. {#NIz#}.

<div n="lb">king. (A noun depending upon it in these meanings stands in
<div n="lb">the gen. or loc., f. i. {#gavAmaDipati#} or {#gozvaDipati#}.) <sup>3</sup> (In me-
<div n="lb">dicine.) ‘That part of the trunk which is inside of the
<div n="lb">upper part of the head, at the passage of the vessel along
<div n="lb">the lateral sinus; wounds inflicted there produce instan-
<div n="lb">taneous death’. E. {#pA#} with {#aDi,#} uṇ. aff. {#qati#}.

<L>1901<pc>056-a<k1>aDiprazwiyuga<k2>aDiprazwiyuga

<div n="lb">phorically the Praṣṭi). E. {#aDiprazwi#} and {#yuga#}.

<L>1903<pc>056-a<k1>aDiBUta<k2>aDiBUta
{#aDiBUta#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tam#}) A subtile or invisible element,
<div n="lb">one which is the cause of the gross or visible elements
<div n="lb">(also as an attribute of the supreme soul that pervades and
<div n="lb">regulates all elements or existence).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-tam#}) Concerning or relating to the bhūta
<div n="lb">or elements; a chapter in the Upanishads includes under
<div n="lb">this topic, earth, atmosphere, material heaven, regions,
<div n="lb">intermediate regions, fire, air, sun, moon, lunar mansions,
<div n="lb">water, annual plants, trees, ether, soul. (In derivatives
<div n="lb">with a taddh. aff. which has an anubandha {#Y, R#} or {#k,#}
<div n="lb">both parts of this word assume vṛddhi, f. i. {#ADiBOtika#}.)
<div n="lb">E. {#aDi#} and {#BUta#}.

<L>1904<pc>056-a<k1>aDimanTa<k2>aDimanTa

<div n="lb">mia which is described as having the following symptoms:
<div n="lb">‘acute pains as if the eyes were torn; throbbing which ex-
<div n="lb">tends to half of the head’; it consists of four varieties ac-
<div n="lb">cording to its being produced by derangement of the air,
<div n="lb">bile, phlegm or blood. Also {#aDImanTa#}. E. {#aDi#} and {#manTa#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">(to cover with dress) with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<div n="lb">self at a person's door in order to enforce compliance with
<div n="lb">some demand. E. {#vas (vasu)#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<div n="lb">is to be summoned to inhabit it. <sup>3</sup> The same as {#aDivAsa#} III.

<L>1972<pc>058-a<k1>aDIna<k2>aDIna
{#aDIna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Dependant. <sup>2</sup> Docile. E.
<div n="lb">{#aDi#} and {#ina#} ‘having a master over one's self’. This word
<div n="lb">and the etymology as mentioned, are given by the native
<div n="lb">lexicographers; but according to the best grammatical autho-
<div n="lb">rities {#aDIna#} would not exist as a real word. Words as {#rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jADIna, brAhmaRADIna#} and the like, are explained by them as
<div n="lb">coming from {#rAjADi#} ({#rAjan#} and {#aDi#}), {#brAhmaRADi#} ({#brAhmaRa#}
<div n="lb">and {#aDi#}) with taddh. aff. {#Ka,#} or by others as derived from {#rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jan, brAhmaRa#} with taddh. aff. {#saDInan;#} it would seem therefore
<div n="lb">that the use of {#aDIna#} as an independant word is grammatically
<div n="lb">not correct. But see {#aDyaDIna#} and {#anaDInaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>1973<pc>058-a<k1>aDInatA<k2>aDInatA
{#aDInatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Subjection, dependance, slavery: so {#aDI-#}
<div n="lb">{#natva#} n. ({#-tvam#}). E. {#aDIna,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}. The gram-
<div n="lb">matical correctness of this word is questionable; see the E.
<div n="lb">of the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>1995<pc>058-b<k1>aDokzaja<k2>aDo'kzaja

<div n="lb">‘Kṛṣṇa, as a child, killed, when lying under a car, Pūtanā,

<div n="lb">bird, and thus, as it were, was born again (under the car)’;

<div n="lb">and {#ja,#} ‘a son of Adhoksha’; or, ‘because he is produced by
<div n="lb">or to such as have subdued or cast down their passions,
<div n="lb">i. e. because he becomes visible to them’; or a Bahuvr. from
<div n="lb">{#aDas#} and {#akzaja#} (n. knowledge derived from the senses;
<div n="lb">m. pl. living beings), ‘because he has subdued all untrue
<div n="lb">knowledge or because he is superior to all living beings’.

<div n="lb">gular compound formed of the phrase {#aDa upa ha Asa,#}
<div n="lb">‘she was or lay under (him)’.

<L>2011<pc>059-a<k1>aDoBakta<k2>aDoBakta

<div n="lb">which is to be taken after eating; one of the ten kinds of
<div n="lb">medicaments classified according to the time of their appli-
<div n="lb">cation; see besides {#nirBakta, prAgBakta, maDyeBakta, antarABakta,#}
<div n="lb">{#saBakta, sAmudga, muhurmuhurgrAsa#} (which is twofold) and {#grA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAntara#}. E. {#aDas#} and {#Bakta,#} scil. {#OzaDa#}.

<L>2018<pc>059-b<k1>aDomuKa<k2>aDomuKa

<L>2041<pc>060-a<k1>aDyarDa<k2>aDyarDa
{#aDyarDa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rDaH-rDA-rDam#}) One and a half, having
<div n="lb">an extra half. See also {#sArDa#}. (In derivatives of compounds
<div n="lb">the first part of which is {#aDyarDa#} and which have the meaning of
<div n="lb">‘measuring or weighing, worth, containing, bought for, pro-
<div n="lb">duced from, consisting of &c.’, the affix which would be re-
<div n="lb">quired, is dropped in many instances; see f. i. {#aDyarDakaMsa,#}
<div n="lb">{#aDyarDaSUrpa#} &c.) E. {#aDi#} and {#arDa#}.

<L>2059<pc>060-b<k1>aDyarDaSUrpa<k2>aDyarDaSUrpa

<div n="lb">and a half.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-rpaH-rpI-rpam#}) Measuring, worth, consisting of,
<div n="lb">bought for &c. one Śūrpa and a half. E. {#aDyarDa#} and {#SUrpa;#} in
<div n="lb">the meaning II. the taddh. aff. {#aY#} or {#Wak#} is considered as
<div n="lb">dropped.
<LEND>

<L>2060<pc>060-b<k1>aDyarDasahasra<k2>aDyarDasahasra
{#aDyarDasahasra#}¦ I. Dwandwa(?) n. ({#-sram#}) Thousand and a half
<div n="lb">(i. e. thousand five hundred).
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-sraH-srA-sram#}) Measuring, consisting of, worth,
<div n="lb">bought fort &c. thousand five hundred. E. {#aDyarDa#} and {#sahasra;#}
<div n="lb">in the meaning II. the taddh. aff. {#aR#} is considered as
<div n="lb">dropped. See also {#aDyarDasAhasra#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">half. See also the preceding. E. {#aDyarDasuvarRa#} (I.), taddh. aff.

<L>2064<pc>061-a<k1>aDyarbuda<k2>aDyarbuda
{#aDyarbuda#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-dam#}) An indolent swelling, the growth
<div n="lb">of which begins in the embryo and which is considered in-
<div n="lb">curable. According to the native commentaries it is a he-
<div n="lb">reditary disease and in so far always also {#dvirarbuda#} (q. v.),
<div n="lb">though the latter is distinct from it in some respects. E.
<div n="lb">{#aDi#} and {#arbuda;#} ‘an Arbuda or indolent swelling which
<div n="lb">reaches beyond (scil.) birth’, i. e. which takes place prior
<div n="lb">to birth.
<LEND>

<L>2065<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasAna<k2>aDyavasAna
{#aDyavasAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Determining, ascertaining. <sup>2</sup> Effort,
<div n="lb">energy. <sup>3</sup> (In rhetoric.) The simple enuntiation of elliptic
<div n="lb">or figurative speech without qualifying it by epithets &c.,
<div n="lb">as it were, leaving it on its own effort; such sentences as
<div n="lb">{#Sveto DAvati#} ‘the white (horse) gallops’, {#kuntAH praviSanti#}
<div n="lb">‘(men with) lances enter’ (see also under {#ajahatsvArTA#}), or
<div n="lb">{#kaliNgaH sAhasikaH#} ‘the (inhabitant of) Kalinga is impetuous’
<div n="lb">(see also under {#jahatsvArTA#}) would be lakṣaṇās or elliptic
<div n="lb">expressions by {#aDyavasAna,#} while {#aSvaH Sveto DAvati#} the
<div n="lb">white horse gallops, {#ete kuntAH praviSanti#} these (men with)
<div n="lb">lances enter, {#kaliNgaH puruzo yuDyate#} the man (inhabitant of)
<div n="lb">Kalinga fights would be qualified or lakṣaṇās by {#Aropa#}
<div n="lb">q. v. (See also under {#lakzaRA#}.) Or {#muKaM dvitIyaScandraH,#} (her)
<div n="lb">face is another moon, would be an {#atiSayokti#} (q. v.) or
<div n="lb">hyperbole in virtue of {#aDyavasAna,#} the comparison as it
<div n="lb">were resting on its own merit. E. {#so#} with {#ava#} and {#aDi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>2066<pc>061-a<k1>aDyavasAya<k2>aDyavasAya
{#aDyavasAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Ascertainment, determining. <sup>2</sup> As-
<div n="lb">siduous application, effort, energy. <sup>3</sup> (In philosophy.) The
<div n="lb">specific function of {#budDi#} or intellect (q. v.), apprehension
<div n="lb">by intellect, its taking hold of an object either by ascertain-
<div n="lb">ment or volition. <sup>4</sup> (In rhetoric.) The same as {#aDyavasAna#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#so#} with {#ava#} and {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#Ra#} and āgama {#yuk#}.
<LEND>

<L>2073<pc>061-a<k1>aDyAtma<k2>aDyAtma
{#aDyAtma#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-tmam#}) The supreme soul or {#Atman#}
[Page061-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(q. v.), sometimes considered as identical with {#prARa#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">and, in the sectarian doctrine, especially with Nārāyaṇa
<div n="lb">or Viṣṇu.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-tmam#}) Concerning or relating to soul, life
<div n="lb">&c.; see {#Atman#}. A chapter in the Upan. treating thereon con-
<div n="lb">tains the following subjects: the lower jaw, the upper jaw,
<div n="lb">speech and tongue; another passage comprises under this
<div n="lb">topic <sup>1</sup> the vital airs: prāṇa, apāna, vyāna, udāna, samāna,
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> the organs of sensation: eyes, ears, manas, speech, skin
<div n="lb">(tvach) and <sup>3</sup> the elementary parts of the body: skin (char-
<div n="lb">man), flesh, tendons, bones, marrow. E. {#aDi#} and {#Atman,#}
<div n="lb">samāsānta aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2074<pc>061-b<k1>aDyAtmajYAna<k2>aDyAtmajYAna
{#aDyAtmajYAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The knowledge of the supreme
<div n="lb">spirit or of the nature of ātman or soul. E. {#aDyAtma#} (I. or
<div n="lb">II.) and {#jYAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2080<pc>061-b<k1>aDyApaka<k2>aDyApaka
{#aDyApaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A teacher, esp. one who instructs
<div n="lb">in the sacred books. <sup>2</sup> (According to a legend in the Calcutta
<div n="lb">edition of the Harivanśa.) One of the sixteen Ṛtvijs (q. v.)
<div n="lb">or priests, who was produced together with the Neṣṭṛ from
<div n="lb">the thighs of Purushottama. The reading of the commen-
<div n="lb">tary, however, is {#acCAvAka#} (q. v.) and the list of priests
<div n="lb">mentioned there is differently given in the manuscripts; {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#DyApaka#} does not usually occur as the name of a Ṛtvij. (In
<div n="lb">the first meaning {#aDyApaka#} may be the latter part of Tatpur.
<div n="lb">compounds, the former of which stands in the sense of the
<div n="lb">genitive (f. i. {#brAhmaRADyApaka#} one who instructs a Brāhmana)
<div n="lb">and as the latter part of several Karmadh. compounds; see
<div n="lb">f. i. {#kumArADyApaka, kaWADyApaka#}.) E. {#i (iN)#} with {#aDi,#} in
<div n="lb">the caus., kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

{#aDyuzwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) Bound or tied over, coiled
<div n="lb">up. See the following. E. {#ucC#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2107<pc>062-b<k1>aDyuzwavalaya<k2>aDyuzwavalaya
{#aDyuzwavalaya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-yaH#}) Having the ringlets coiled,
<div n="lb">wound into rings. This word occurs in the poem Ānanda-
<div n="lb">laharī as the epithet of a serpent, to indicate that it is in
<div n="lb">profound sleep, forming, then, three ringlets and a half;
<div n="lb">the god Śiva is likened to a serpent coiled up in this man-
<div n="lb">ner, its half ringlet being compared to his Śakti or female
<div n="lb">energy and the three others to the god as representing the
<div n="lb">Trimūrti. E. {#aDyuzwa#} and {#valaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2108<pc>062-b<k1>aDyuzwra<k2>aDyuzwra
{#aDyuzwra#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-zwraH#}) A litter drawn or carried by a camel.
<div n="lb">E. {#aDi#} and {#uzwra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2109<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUQa<k2>aDyUQa
{#aDyUQa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-QaH-QA-Qam#}) <sup>1</sup> Borne or placed over,
<div n="lb">elevated. <sup>2</sup> Very prosperous, thriving. <sup>3</sup> Much, excessive.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-QaH#}) A name of Śiva.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-QA#}) A superseded wife, one whose husband has
<div n="lb">married others. E. {#vah#} with {#aDi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}. The com-
<div n="lb">mentaries explain I. 2. as derived from {#aDi,#} in the sense
<div n="lb">of {#aDika#} and {#UQa;#} II. as the god by whom the world has
<div n="lb">been upheld ‘first’ and III. also as derived from {#aDi,#} in
<div n="lb">the sense of ‘first’ and {#UQA#} married.
<LEND>

<L>2110<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUDnI<k2>aDyUDnI
{#aDyUDnI#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-DnI#}) The penis (or according to another
<div n="lb">interpretation perhaps, the urethra). This word occurs esp.
<div n="lb">in the ritual works, in passages treating on the Agnisho-
<div n="lb">mīyapaśu (q. v.) and the ceremonies connected with it. E.
<div n="lb">{#aDi#} and {#UDas,#} samāsānta ādeśa {#anaN#} and fem. aff. {#NIz,#}
<div n="lb">scil. {#iqA;#} literally: the tubular vessel above the scrotum.
<LEND>

<L>2111<pc>062-b<k1>aDyUzitASva<k2>aDyUzitASva

<div n="lb">descendant of Daśaratha. According to others his name
<div n="lb">would be {#aByutTitASva#} or {#dUzitASva#} or {#viDfti#}. E. {#aDyU-#}
<div n="lb">{#zita#} (very diseased, from {#aDi#} and {#Uzita#}) and {#aSva#}.

<L>2120<pc>063-a<k1>aDrigu<k2>aDrigu

<div n="lb">restrained or irresistible course; esp. as an epithet of Indra,
<div n="lb">Agni, Soma, the Rudras and the Aśvins. <sup>2</sup> The name of

<L>2135<pc>063-a<k1>aDvan<k2>aDvan
{#aDvan#}¦ m. ({#-DvA#}) <sup>1</sup> Sky, atmosphere (only in the Vedas).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> A road. <sup>3</sup> Time. <sup>4</sup> A place (perhaps, a place where four
<div n="lb">roads meet). <sup>5</sup> A branch or school of the Vedas or sacred
<div n="lb">literature.--In some Tatpurusha compounds the former
<div n="lb">part of which is an {#upasarga#} (q. v.), this word occurs in the
<div n="lb">form of {#aDva;#} i. e. the compound assumes the samāsānta
<div n="lb">aff. {#ac;#} e. g. {#prADva, niraDva, pratyaDva#}.--(The two last
<div n="lb">meanings of this word are rather unsettled through the
<div n="lb">variety of readings in the native dictionaries from which
<div n="lb">they are taken; some read {#aDvA…saMsTAne syAdavaskanDe,#}
[Page063-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">others {#saMsTAne sASravaskanDe;#} the best reading, however, that
<div n="lb">which has been adopted in the present translation, seems
<div n="lb">to be this: {#saMsTAne SAstravatskanDe#}.) E. doubtful; according
<div n="lb">to some, {#ad,#} uṇ. aff. {#kvanip,#} with {#D#} substituted for {#d#}
<div n="lb">‘because it eats up the strength of the traveller’; or ac-
<div n="lb">cording to others, {#at,#} uṇ. aff. {#kvanip,#} with {#D#} instead of {#t#}.
<LEND>

<L>2136<pc>063-b<k1>aDvanIna<k2>aDvanIna
{#aDvanIna#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Marching fast or fleet. <sup>2</sup> (m.) A
<div n="lb">traveller. E. {#aDvan,#} taddh. aff. {#Ka#}. According to some used
<div n="lb">in all the three genders.

<L>2138<pc>063-b<k1>aDvapati<k2>aDvapati
{#aDvapati#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tiH#}) An epithet of the sun, in the
<div n="lb">Vedas. Literally: ‘the lord of the roads’ or perhaps better
<div n="lb">‘the lord of the atmosphere’. E. {#aDvan#} and {#pati#}.
<LEND>

<L>2139<pc>063-b<k1>aDvara<k2>aDvara
{#aDvara#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Not crooked,
<div n="lb">honest proper (ved.) <sup>2</sup> Not perishable, lasting (in its con-
<div n="lb">sequences, as a sacrifice; ved.). <sup>3</sup> Intent, attentive. (It is
<div n="lb">doubtful whether this word in the two meanings ‘not crook-
<div n="lb">ed’ and ‘not perishable’, occurs in the femin. gender, as
<div n="lb">it is used in the Vedas either absolutely as a neuter or as
<div n="lb">epithet of {#yajYa#} in the mascul. Nor is the latter meaning
<div n="lb">‘intent, attentive’, a usual one, though it is given in
<div n="lb">several of the native dictionaries.)
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Sacrifice in general, but in the ritual works
<div n="lb">mostly used as the denomination of the greater sacrifices
<div n="lb">or those performed with the juice of the Soma plant; see
<div n="lb">also {#sOmyADvara#} and {#aDvarakARqa#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of a Vasu
<div n="lb">(q. v.). <sup>3</sup> The proper name of the chief of a renowned fa-
<div n="lb">mily. See {#ADvarAyaRa#}.
<div n="P">III. n. ({#-ram#}) Sky, atmosphere (ved.). E. {#a#} priv. and
<div n="lb">{#Dvara#} ‘having no crookedness, dishonesty &c.’ or according
<div n="lb">to others ‘preventing, not allowing of injury’; another
<div n="lb">etym. makes this word, but erroneously, a Tatpur. from
<div n="lb">{#aDvan#} and {#ra#} ‘giving or affording the road (scil. to heaven)’.
<LEND>

<L>2140<pc>063-b<k1>aDvarakarman<k2>aDvarakarman
{#aDvarakarman#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rmaH#}) The proceedings with an
<div n="lb">Adhwara-sacrifice (ved.). See the preceding. E. {#aDvara#}
<div n="lb">and {#karman#}.

<L>2141<pc>063-b<k1>aDvarakalpA<k2>aDvarakalpA

<L>2155<pc>064-a<k1>aDvaryu<k2>aDvaryu
{#aDvaryu#}¦ m. ({#-ryuH#}) <sup>1</sup> One desirous of having a sacrifice insti-
<div n="lb">tuted for one's self (used in this sense in the Rigveda). <sup>2</sup> A
<div n="lb">priest in general (ved.) <sup>3</sup> (In the ritual and the epic litera-
<div n="lb">ture.) A special priest, one conversant with and performing
<div n="lb">the ritual observances connected with the Yajurveda; he is
<div n="lb">one of the sixteen Ṛtvijs required for the performing of the
<div n="lb">great Soma sacrifices (see {#ftvij#}) and, amongst them,
<div n="lb">one of the four leading priests (see besides {#brahman, udgAtf#}
<div n="lb">and {#hotf#}) who receive the whole dakṣiṇā (q. v.); his pu-
<div n="lb">rushas or assistant priests are the {#pratiprasTAtf, nezwwa#} and
<div n="lb">{#unnetf#} who are called, like himself, the {#dIkzayitf#} (q. v.) because
<div n="lb">they initiate, viz. the {#aDvaryu#} the three other leading priests,
<div n="lb">the {#pratiprasTAtf#} the {#arDin-#} (q. v.), the {#nezwf#} the {#tftIyin-#}
<div n="lb">(q. v.) and the {#unnetf#} the {#pAdin-#} (q. v.) priests. The Mi-
<div n="lb">mānsā decides in doubtful cases, viz. whenever a sacrifice
<div n="lb">mentioned in and making part of the ritual of the Yajur-
<div n="lb">veda, is mentioned also and forms part of another Veda,
<div n="lb">whether the Adhwaryu has another priest to share in
<div n="lb">his functions or whether he has to abstain from the pro-
<div n="lb">ceedings altogether. The ten {#camasADvaryu#} (q. v.), who,
<div n="lb">are also assistants or purushas of the Adhwaryu, are dis-
<div n="lb">tinct from and do not bear the name of Ṛtvij.--According
<div n="lb">to a legend in the Harivanśa, Nārāyaṇa created the first
<div n="lb">Adhwaryu from his arms. The dual {#aDvaryu#} is the collective
<div n="lb">denomination of the {#aDvaryu#} and {#pratiprasTAtf,#} his principal
<div n="lb">assistant; the plur. {#aDvaryavaH#} of the {#aDvaryu#} and his three
<div n="lb">assistants, and in general of those devoted to the study or
<div n="lb">the practice of the Yajurveda. <sup>4</sup> The Yajurveda (also in the
<div n="lb">plur. {#aDvaryavaH#}). E. {#aDvary,#} kṛt aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<L>2156<pc>064-a<k1>aDvaryukARqa<k2>aDvaryukARqa
{#aDvaryukARqa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Rqam#}) A collection of mantras or
<div n="lb">prayers for the special use of the Adhwaryu (q. v.). Also
<div n="lb">called {#ADvaryavakARqa#}. E. {#aDvaryu#} and {#kARqa#}.
<LEND>
[Page064-b+ 56]

<L>2157<pc>064-b<k1>aDvaryukratu<k2>aDvaryukratu
{#aDvaryukratu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tuH#}) The Kratu (q. v.)--sacri-
<div n="lb">fices contained in the Yajurveda or to be performed by
<div n="lb">the Adhwaryu. E. {#aDvaryu#} (in the meanings of 3. or 2.)
<div n="lb">and {#kratu#}.
<LEND>

<L>2158<pc>064-b<k1>aDvaryuveda<k2>aDvaryuveda

<div n="lb">E. {#aDvaryu#} (in the meanings of 4. or 3.) and {#veda#}.

<L>2163<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>1
I. {#an#}.¦ See {#a#} III.
<LEND>

<L>2164<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>2
II. {#an#}.¦ Considered as a substitute of {#id#} in {#idam#} in some
<div n="lb">cases, viz. {#anena, anayA#} and {#anayoH#}. See {#idam#} and {#ana#}.
<LEND>

<L>2165<pc>064-b<k1>an<k2>an<h>3
III. {#an#}¦ I. ({#ana-adAdi-rudAdi-udAtta-parasmEpadin#}) r. 2d cl.
<div n="lb">par. ({#aniti-#} imp. {#AnIt#} or {#Anat-Ana-anitA-anizyati-#}
<div n="lb">{#AnIt#}.--Desid. {#aninizati#}.--Caus. {#Anayati#}) and
<div n="P">II. ({#ana-divAdi-udAtta-anudAttet#}) r. 4th cl. ātm. ({#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyate#} &c.) Also read {#aR#} q. v. <sup>1</sup> To breathe, to live. <sup>2</sup> (ved.)
<div n="lb">To go. (In composition with {#parA#} and {#pra,#} the {#n#} of the
<div n="lb">radical is changed to {#R#}.) With {#apa-#} To breathe away (in
<div n="lb">farting), to produce the action of the vital air {#apAna#} (q. v.);
<div n="lb">{#aByapa-#} The same ({#aBi#} implying moreover the direction
<div n="lb">towards); {#ava-#} To breathe out, to breathe forth; {#ud-#}
<div n="lb">To breathe up, to produce the action of the vital air {#udAna#}
<div n="lb">(q. v.); {#aByud-#} The same ({#aBi#} implying also the direction
<div n="lb">towards); {#parA-(parARiti-parARiRat-parARiRizati)(?);#}
<div n="lb">{#pari-(paryaniti)(?); pra-#} ({#prARiti#}. Des. {#prARiRizati#}.) <sup>1</sup> To
<div n="lb">breathe, to respire, to produce the action of the vital air
<div n="lb">{#prARa#} q. v. <sup>2</sup> To live. <sup>3</sup> (In the Upanishads, but doubtful.)
<div n="lb">To smell (see also {#prARa#} and {#atigraha#}). Caus. ({#prARayati-#}
<div n="lb">{#prARiRat#}) To revive; {#anupra-#} To breathe or to live in con-
<div n="lb">formity with (a following noun depends upon it in the ac-
<div n="lb">cusative); {#aBipra-#} To breathe into, to make one's breath
<div n="lb">enter into (the mouth of another); {#vi-#} To breathe, to pro-
<div n="lb">duce the action of the vital air {#vyAna#} (q. v.); {#aBivi-#} The
<div n="lb">same with the meaning of ‘towards’; {#sam-#} <sup>1</sup> To breathe,
<div n="lb">to live. <sup>2</sup> To produce the action of the vital air {#samAna#} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<L>2166<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>1
I. {#ana#}¦ ind. Not. E. g. {#anopamA te budDiH,#} explained by a
<div n="lb">commentator: ‘thy intellect is unequalled’. See also {#anA,#}
<div n="lb">and comp. {#anAnukftya, anAnuda#} &c.
<LEND>

<L>2167<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>2
II. {#ana#}.¦ Considered by some as a substitute of {#idam#} in some
<div n="lb">cases; viz. {#anena, anayA#} and {#anayoH#}. See {#idam#} and {#an#}.
<LEND>

<L>2168<pc>064-b<k1>ana<k2>ana<h>3
III. {#ana#}¦ m. ({#-naH#}) Spiration; it is explained as the action
<div n="lb">which is common to the five vital airs {#prARa, apAna, udAna,#}
<div n="lb">{#vyAna#} and {#samAna#} (qq. vv.). Compare {#anila#}. E. {#an,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2169<pc>064-b<k1>anaMSa<k2>anaMSa
{#anaMSa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) <sup>1</sup> Portionless, not en-
<div n="lb">titled to a share or portion. <sup>2</sup> (In law.) One excluded from
<div n="lb">participation in an inheritance viz. a eunuque, a degraded
<div n="lb">man, a blind or deaf person, a fool, an idiot, a dumb
[Page065-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">person or one deprived of one of his limbs or senses, a
<div n="lb">cripple &c. See also {#anaMSin#} and {#niraMSaka#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">share &c. See the preceding. Also {#anaMSatA#} f. ({#-tA#}). E.
<div n="lb">{#anaMSa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#} or {#tal#}.

<L>2176<pc>065-a<k1>anakadunduBi<k2>anakadunduBi

<div n="lb">of the Amarakosha. E. {#anaka#} (instead of {#Anaka#}) and {#dundu-#}

<div n="lb">when Kṛṣṇa was born’.

<L>2186<pc>065-a<k1>anagni<k2>anagni
{#anagni#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-gniH#}) Any thing not or different from
<div n="lb">fire. E. {#a#} neg. and {#agni#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-gniH-gniH-gni#}) <sup>1</sup> Having no sacrificial
<div n="lb">fire or being deprived of the arrangement of a sacrificial
<div n="lb">fire place (see {#agnicayana#}), as a sacrifice. <sup>2</sup> Impious, irre-
<div n="lb">ligious (as one not performing the observances which require
<div n="lb">a sacrificial fire; also an epithet of the Manes {#agnizvAtta#}
<div n="lb">q. v.). <sup>3</sup> Unmarried(?). <sup>4</sup> Having no domestic fire, no fire
[Page065-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">for worldly purposes (as an anchorite who has given up
<div n="lb">his house and retired to the wood). <sup>5</sup> Having a bad di-
<div n="lb">gestion. E. {#a#} priv. or (in 5.) deterior. and {#agni#}.
<LEND>

<L>2187<pc>065-b<k1>anagnitra<k2>anagnitra
{#anagnitra#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-traH-trA#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Not having Agni
<div n="lb">or the divinity of fire as protector, unprotected by Agni.
<div n="lb">Or according to another interpretation, <sup>2</sup> not maintain-
<div n="lb">ing a sacrificial fire, impious, wicked. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#agni-tra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2188<pc>065-b<k1>anagnidagDa<k2>anagnidagDa
{#anagnidagDa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-gDaH-gDA-gDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not burnt
<div n="lb">in or with fire. <sup>2</sup> Not burnt on the funeral pyre, not hav-
<div n="lb">ing received the obsequies in conformity with the religious
<div n="lb">rites.
<div n="P">II. m. pl. ({#-gDAH#}) The name of a particular class of Pi-
<div n="lb">tṛs or Manes, of those apparently who when alive did
<div n="lb">not observe religious rites. See {#agnidagDa#} and the following.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#agnidagDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2189<pc>065-b<k1>anagnizvAtta<k2>anagnizvAtta
{#anagnizvAtta#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-ttAH#}) The name of a particular
<div n="lb">class of Pitṛs or Manes. This word is explained by a
<div n="lb">commentator of the Yajurveda: ‘not tasted by ({#svAtta#}) i. e.
<div n="lb">not burnt by fire, not having received the obsequies in con-
<div n="lb">formity with the religious rites’ and it appears therefore as
<div n="lb">a synonyme of {#anagnidagDa,#} as well as the converse of {#agni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvAtta#} which, according to the same commentator, would
<div n="lb">be a synonyme of {#agnidagDa#}. Anagniṣvātta does not occur
<div n="lb">in the list of the Pitṛs which are given in the law books
<div n="lb">and in the Purāṇas, while {#agnidagDa#} and {#agnizvAtta#} (qq. vv.)
<div n="lb">are named there as distinct classes and explained in a
<div n="lb">different manner. The etymology given, which identifies
<div n="lb">{#svAtta#} and {#svAdita,#} seems moreover objectionable. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">and {#agnizvAtta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2190<pc>065-b<k1>anaGa<k2>anaGa
{#anaGa#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-GaH-GA-Gam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sinless, pure.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Clean, clear. <sup>3</sup> Handsome, pleasing.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-GaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Śiva. <sup>2</sup> The name of a Gan-
<div n="lb">dharva. <sup>3</sup> The name of a Sādhya. <sup>4</sup> The name of a prince,
<div n="lb">son of Surodha and Upadānavī. <sup>5</sup> The name of a son of
<div n="lb">Vasiṣṭha and Ūrjā. <sup>6</sup> White mustard; see {#gOrasarzapa#}. A
<div n="lb">less correct reading of this word in the latter sense is {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nadya#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#aGa#}.
<LEND>
