<L>2210<pc>066-a<k1>anaquh<k2>anaquh
{#anaquh#}¦ Tatpur. m. (sing. {#-qvAn, -qvan, -qvAham, -quhA, -quhe,#}
<div n="lb">{#-quhaH, -quhi;#} du. {#-qvAhO, -qudByAm, -quhoH;#} plur. {#-qvAhaH,#}
<div n="lb">{#-quhaH, -qudBiH, -qudByaH, -qutsu#}) f. ({#-quhI#} or {#-qvAhI#}) <sup>1</sup> A bull
<div n="lb">or ox, especially one fit to draw a cart or to bear a weight.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The sign of the zodiac, Taurus. <sup>3</sup> (According to a vaidik
<div n="lb">commentator also used in the adjective sense:) fit or able
<div n="lb">to draw a cart, as an epithet of a goat; but this expla-
<div n="lb">nation seems doubtful.--(The use of the femin. {#anaqvAhI#}
<div n="lb">would be restricted, according to one authority, to the
<div n="lb">Vedas, while others do not make any distinction between
<div n="lb">this form and {#anaquhI#}. In Avyayībh. compounds, the com-
<div n="lb">pound terminating with {#anaquh#} assumes the samāsānta aff.
<div n="lb">{#wac#} (see {#anaquha#}) and in Bahuvr. compounds, the samā-
<div n="lb">sānta aff. {#kap#} (see {#anaqutka#}); in the latter, however, it
[Page066-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">may also retain its original form, with the following de-
<div n="lb">clension in the neuter: sing. {#anaqut,#} du. {#anaquhI#} and plur.
<div n="lb">{#anaqvAMhi#}.) E. {#anas,#} with {#s#} changed to {#q,#} and {#vah#} (from
<div n="lb">{#vah,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}) with samprasāraṇa of {#v;#} in the fem.
<div n="lb">with aff. {#NIz#}.
<LEND>

<L>2246<pc>067-a<k1>ananuBAzaRa<k2>ananuBAzaRa
{#ananuBAzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Not repeating the argument for discussion, i. e. a tacit
<div n="lb">agreement with it or assent to the assertion of the person
[Page067-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">who has proposed it; viz. if, after the argument for dis-
<div n="lb">cussion has been announced, it has not been repeated by
<div n="lb">any one--the sign of taking it up--the proposer has to
<div n="lb">proclaim it three times; if then it does not meet with the
<div n="lb">anubhāṣana, it is considered as proved or as accepted as
<div n="lb">such. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anuBAzaRa#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">to, indifferent (as to pleasure &c.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaNgin#}.

<L>2250<pc>067-b<k1>ananta<k2>ananta
{#ananta#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-ntaH-ntA-ntam#}) Endless in time
<div n="lb">and space: eternal, unbounded, innumerable &c.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-ntaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Viṣṇu or Kṛṣṇa. <sup>2</sup> A name
<div n="lb">of Baladeva, the elder brother of Kṛṣṇa. <sup>3</sup> A name of
<div n="lb">Śiva. <sup>4</sup> A name of Rudra, in an Upanishad of the Athar-
<div n="lb">vaveda. <sup>5</sup> A name of Śeṣa, the chief of the Nāgas or ser-
<div n="lb">pent race that inhabit the infernal regions: the couch and
<div n="lb">constant attendant of Viṣṇu. <sup>6</sup> A name of Vāsuki, another
<div n="lb">king of the serpents, the brother of the former. <sup>7</sup> A name
<div n="lb">of one of the Viśvadevas. <sup>8</sup> The name of the fourteenth of
<div n="lb">the twenty-four Arhats or Jaina deified saints of the present
<div n="lb">Avasarpiṇī; see also {#anantajit#}. <sup>9</sup> The name of a king of
<div n="lb">Kashmir; see also {#anantadeva#}. <sup>10</sup> A proper name common to
<div n="lb">several authors &c. <sup>11</sup> The name of a plant, Vitex trifolia
<div n="lb">(Lin.); see {#sindavAra#}. <sup>12</sup> Talc (see {#aBraka;#} in this sense the
<div n="lb">word is given by some as a neuter). <sup>13</sup> (In arithmetic.)
<div n="lb">Infinite quantity: a fraction having a cypher for its deno-
<div n="lb">minator; see also {#anantarASi#} and {#Kahara#}. <sup>14</sup> The name of
<div n="lb">the twenty-third of the lunar asterisms; see {#SravaRa#}. <sup>15</sup> A
<div n="lb">silken cord with fourteen knots which the Hindus tie round
<div n="lb">the right arm at the festival of Anantachaturdaśī.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-ntA#}) <sup>1</sup> The earth. <sup>2</sup> (In arithmetic sometimes
<div n="lb">used to denominate) the numeral one. <sup>3</sup> A name of Pār-
<div n="lb">vatī, the wife of Śiva. <sup>4</sup> A name of Tārā, a Buddhist
<div n="lb">deity. <sup>5</sup> The proper name of the wife of Janamejaya. <sup>6</sup> The
<div n="lb">name of the following plants: <sup>a.</sup> Hedysarum alhagi; see
<div n="lb">{#yavAsa#} or {#rodanI#}. <sup>b.</sup> Echytes frutescens; see {#SyAmA#} or {#go-#}
<div n="lb">{#pI#}. <sup>c.</sup> A sort of potherb; see {#viSalyA#} or {#SakrapuzpI#}. <sup>d.</sup> Agrostis
<div n="lb">linearis (Koen.) or Panicum dactylon; see {#dUrvA#} or {#BArgavI,#}
<div n="lb">{#SvetadUrvA#} and {#nIladUrvA#}. <sup>e.</sup> Phyllanthus emblica (emblic my-
<div n="lb">robolan); see {#AmalakI#}. <sup>f.</sup> Menispermum glabrum or cordi-
<div n="lb">folium; see {#guqUcI#}. <sup>g.</sup> Gloriosa superba; see {#lANgalI#}. <sup>h.</sup> See
<div n="lb">{#hemamAnI#}. <sup>i.</sup> Premna spinosa; see {#asimanTa#}. <sup>k.</sup> Piper longum
<div n="lb">(Long pepper); see {#pippalI#} or {#kaRA#}. <sup>l.</sup> Terminalia chebula
<div n="lb">(yellow myrobolan); see {#harItakI#}. <sup>m.</sup> Asclepias pseudosar-
<div n="lb">sa; see {#SArivA#}. <sup>n.</sup> Justicia adhatoda(?). <sup>o.</sup> Bromelia Ana-
<div n="lb">nas(?). <sup>p.</sup> Echytes dichotoma(?). <sup>q.</sup> According to some
<div n="lb">also the same as {#anantamUla#} q. v.
<div n="P">IV. n. ({#-ntam#}) <sup>1</sup> Sky, atmosphere, æther. <sup>2</sup> Talc; (also
<div n="lb">given in the latter sense as a masculine). E. {#a#} priv. and
<div n="lb">{#anta#}.
<LEND>
[Page068-a+ 56]

<L>2251<pc>068-a<k1>anantaka<k2>anantaka
{#anantaka#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Endless, eternal, unlimited.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-kam#}) (In the Jaina doctrine.) The collective ex-
<div n="lb">pression for what is eternal viz. matter and soul; but in-
<div n="lb">cluding also, according to a commentary, planets or accord-
<div n="lb">ing to another, æther, regions &c. E. {#ananta,#} taddh. aff.
<div n="lb">{#kan,#} or rather a Bahuvr. composed of {#a#} neg. and {#anta,#}
<div n="lb">samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>2252<pc>068-a<k1>anantakara<k2>anantakara

<div n="lb">unlimited. E. {#ananta#} and {#kara#}.

<L>2254<pc>068-a<k1>anantacaturdaSI<k2>anantacaturdaSI
{#anantacaturdaSI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-SI#}) The fourteenth lunation of
<div n="lb">the light half i. e. the day of the full moon of the month
<div n="lb">Bhādra (August-September), when Viṣṇu under the
<div n="lb">form of the serpent Ananta is worshipped. E. {#ananta#} and
<div n="lb">{#caturdaSI#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#ananta#} and {#cAritra#}.

<L>2256<pc>068-a<k1>anantajit<k2>anantajit

<div n="lb">of the twenty-four Arhats or Jaina deified saints of the
<div n="lb">present Avasarpiṇī; also called {#ananta#}. E. {#ananta#} and {#jit#}
<div n="lb">‘who conquers, who gains eternity’.

<L>2264<pc>068-a<k1>anantara<k2>anantara
{#anantara#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Having nothing in-
<div n="lb">termediate, having no interval or defect, uninterrupted,
<div n="lb">entire; in the Upanishads also as an epithet of Brahman (n.)
<div n="lb">or the supreme soul, of which it is said that it has nothing
<div n="lb">before it nor after it, nor between ‘before’ and ‘after’
<div n="lb">it nor besides it, or that it exists without interruption
<div n="lb">or defect, entire. <sup>2</sup> Next, immediately following or pre-
<div n="lb">ceding. <sup>3</sup> Next of kin, in succession, in caste. <sup>4</sup> Close,
<div n="lb">compact.--{#anantaram#} immediately, afterwards; it is fol-
<div n="lb">lowed or preceded sometimes by a noun depending upon
<div n="lb">it in the ablative or genitive. E. {#a#} priv. and {#anantara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2265<pc>068-a<k1>anantaraja<k2>anantaraja
{#anantaraja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The son of a man of the three
<div n="lb">first castes, married to a woman of a caste inferior in order
[Page068-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">to his own, but not to a Sūdra woman viz. of a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">by a Kṣatriyā or Vaiśyā and of a Kṣatriyā by a Vaiśyā.
<div n="lb">The three kinds of sons got by parents of the same caste
<div n="lb">are called {#sajAtija#} and both, comprising six kinds, have
<div n="lb">the privileges of a Dvija or twice-born man. (This is
<div n="lb">the explanation given by a commentator of Manu and,
<div n="lb">according to him, {#anantaraja#} would have a different mean-
<div n="lb">ing than {#anantarajAta,#} though both words appear to be
<div n="lb">synonymes.) E. {#anantara#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>2266<pc>068-b<k1>anantarajAta<k2>anantarajAta
{#anantarajAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) The son of a father married to
<div n="lb">a woman of a caste next in order to his own, viz. of a
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa by a Kṣatriyā, of a Kshatriya by a Vaiśyā,
<div n="lb">of a Vaiśya by a Sūdrā. E. {#anantara#} and {#jAta#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {#antarAya#}.

<L>2273<pc>068-b<k1>anantavat<k2>anantavat
{#anantavat#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) Endowed with infinity,
<div n="lb">eternal.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-vAn#}) A name or epithet of one of the four pā-
<div n="lb">das or feet of Brahman (in the symbolical language of the
<div n="lb">Upanishads), consisting of four Kalās or parts, viz. earth,
<div n="lb">intermediate space, heaven and ocean. The other three
<div n="lb">feet are called {#prakASavat, jyotizmat#} and {#Ayatanavat#}
<div n="lb">(qq. vv.).
<LEND>

<L>2275<pc>068-b<k1>anantavAta<k2>anantavAta
{#anantavAta#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-taH#}) (In medicine.) One of the
<div n="lb">diseases of the head (see {#Siroroga#}). It is described in the
<div n="lb">following manner: ‘when the three humours (air, bile and
<div n="lb">phlegm) are deranged in the vessels of the back of the
<div n="lb">neck they make it very feverish and painful and it sup-
<div n="lb">presses the humours particularly in the region of the eyes,
<div n="lb">eyebrows and temples; it then produces shaking in the
<div n="lb">sides of the cheeks, cramp of the jaws and morbid affec-
<div n="lb">tions of the eyes’. E. {#ananta#} and {#vAta#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">giving no pleasure or joy’.

<L>2306<pc>069-b<k1>ananvaya<k2>ananvaya
{#ananvaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (In rhetoric.) One of the Ālaṅkā-
<div n="lb">ras or figures of speech: comparing an object to itself, with
<div n="lb">respect to its being the only one of its class as to the qua-
<div n="lb">lities expressed and therefore not liable to comparison with
<div n="lb">any thing else; e. g. the moon shines like a moon i. e. like
<div n="lb">a very moon, a moon indeed. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anvaya,#} literally:
<div n="lb">‘want of connexion sc. with other objects’.
<LEND>

<L>2307<pc>069-b<k1>ananvita<k2>ananvita
{#ananvita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unconnected with,
<div n="lb">inconsistent, incoherent. <sup>2</sup> Devoid of, not possessing. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#anvita#}.
<LEND>

<L>2377<pc>071-b<k1>anamitra<k2>anamitra
{#anamitra#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-traH-trA-tram#}) Free from enemies,
<div n="lb">without enemies.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-tram#}) The being free from or without enemies.
<div n="P">III. m. ({#-traH#}) A proper name of <sup>1</sup> A prince of the solar
<div n="lb">race, a descendant of Sagara, son of Nighna and brother
<div n="lb">of Raghu, the fifty-second king of Ayodhyā. <sup>2</sup> A son of
<div n="lb">the king Kroṣṭu or Kroṣtṛ by Gāndhāri and father of
<div n="lb">Śini or, according to others, a grandson of Vṛṣṇi, son
<div n="lb">of Sumitra by Mādrī and brother to Śini; or, again, a
<div n="lb">grandson of Dhṛṣṭa, son of Sumitra &c. E. {#a#} priv. and
<div n="lb">{#amitra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2378<pc>071-b<k1>anamIva<k2>anamIva
{#anamIva#}¦ Bahuvr. I. m. f. n. ({#-vaH-vA-vam#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Free from
<div n="lb">disease, healthy. <sup>2</sup> Removing diseases, healthy (as food,
<div n="lb">plants, fire).
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-vam#}) Freedom from disease, good health. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">priv. and {#amIvA#}.
<LEND>

<L>2379<pc>071-b<k1>anambara<k2>anambara

<div n="lb">unclothed.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) A Bauddha mendicant, going naked. See
<div n="lb">{#digambara#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#ambara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2382<pc>071-b<k1>anaraRya<k2>anaraRya
{#anaraRya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-RyaH#}) The proper name of a king of
<div n="lb">Ayodhyā, of the solar race; according to one authority, a
<div n="lb">son of Vāna and father of Pṛthu, according to others,
<div n="lb">a son of Sambhūta and father of Pṛṣadaśva or, again, a
<div n="lb">son of Sarwakarman and father of Nighna. Those who
<div n="lb">make him a son of Sambhūta, relate that he was slain by
<div n="lb">Rāvaṇa.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">wounded, sound, healed. (As a Tatpur. this word occurs
<div n="lb">only in the Vedas; it would be a Bahuvr. according to the
<div n="lb">use of {#arus#} in the classic language.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#arus,#}
<div n="lb">sore, wounded; (or as a Bahuvr. {#a#} priv. and {#arus,#} sore,
<div n="lb">wound).

<L>2400<pc>072-a<k1>anala<k2>anala
{#anala#}¦ m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> Fire. <sup>2</sup> A name of Agni or the god of fire.

<div n="lb">deva. <sup>5</sup> The proper name of a Muni. <sup>6</sup> The proper name
<div n="lb">of a monkey (in the Rāmāyaṇa). <sup>7</sup> The fire of the stomach,
<div n="lb">digestive faculty. <sup>8</sup> Bile. <sup>9</sup> The name of several plants,
<div n="lb">viz. <sup>a.</sup> Plumbago zeylanica (see {#citraka#}), <sup>b.</sup> Plumbago rosea
<div n="lb">(see {#raktacitraka#}), <sup>c.</sup> Semicarpus anacardium (see {#BallAtaka#}).

[Page072-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">of Bṛhaspati's cycle of sixty years. <sup>12</sup> (In astronomy.)
<div n="lb">The name of the third lunar mansion or Kṛttikā(?). <sup>13</sup> (In
<div n="lb">arithmetic sometimes used to denote) the numeral three; see
<div n="lb">{#agni#}(9.). E. {#an,#} in the causative, uṇ. aff. {#kalac;#} ({#anala#}
<div n="lb">belongs to the {#vfzAdi#}).

<L>2494<pc>075-a<k1>anA<k2>anA
{#anA#}¦ ind. (ved.) Certainly, indeed. (A commentator of the
<div n="lb">Amarakosha considers this particle as a synonyme of the
<div n="lb">negative {#na;#} his opinion rests, however, only on an arti-
<div n="lb">ficial interpretation of the word {#anAvfzwi#} (q. v.) and is
<div n="lb">refuted by others who explain it as derived, not from {#anA#}
<div n="lb">and {#vfzwi,#} but from {#a#} neg. and {#Avfzwi#}.) E. unknown;
<div n="lb">probably an obsolete third case of the pronominal theme
<div n="lb">{#a#} (q. v.).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">form. E. {#a#} priv. and {#AkAra#}.

<L>2498<pc>075-a<k1>anAkAlaBfta<k2>anAkAlaBfta

<L>2557<pc>076-b<k1>anADfzwi<k2>anADfzwi
{#anADfzwi#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-zwiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The proper name of <sup>a.</sup> a prince,
<div n="lb">the son of Śura by Bhojyā, or according to others by
<div n="lb">Māriṣā, and brother of Vasudeva; his wife is Aśmakī
<div n="lb">and his son Ninartaśatru or according to another reading,
<div n="lb">Nirvṛttiśatru; <sup>b.</sup> a son of Ugrasena and chief of the Yā-
<div n="lb">davas. <sup>2</sup> A name or epithet of Ṛcheyu, the son of Rau-
<div n="lb">drāśva. E. {#a#} priv. and {#ADfzwi,#} ‘suffering no defeat, in-
<div n="lb">vincible’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">follower, unaided, alone. <sup>2</sup> Unsurpassed in liberality (lit.

<div n="lb">haps {#ana#} priv. and {#anuda#}.

<L>2600<pc>077-b<k1>anAraByavAda<k2>anAraByavAda
{#anAraByavAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) An injunction (concerning sa-

<div n="lb">chapters which treat authoritatively on sacrifices &c. in the

<LEND>

<L>2601<pc>077-b<k1>anAraByADIta<k2>anAraByADIta
{#anAraByADIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Not read in con-
<div n="lb">nexion with chapters or books treating authoritatively on
<div n="lb">vaidik rites or sacrifices; said of passages, esp. in the
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇas, which treat on rites, sacrifices &c. not to be
<div n="lb">connected with other passages with which they may happen
[Page078-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">to be found together, the injunctions of the latter not be-
<div n="lb">ing applicable to those of the former. A ceremonial, for
<div n="lb">instance, taught in an anārabhyādhīta, would not be con-
<div n="lb">sidered as the essential part of another ceremonial, treated
<div n="lb">in passages, called ārabhyādhīta, which may precede or
<div n="lb">follow it, nor share in the general rules concerning these;
<div n="lb">and it is, therefore, always the object of special rules which
<div n="lb">define its position amongst the other parts of the ritual and
<div n="lb">its applicability. E. {#a#} neg. and {#AraByADIta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2668<pc>079-b<k1>anitya<k2>anitya
{#anitya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-tyaH-tyA-tyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Transient, not ever-
<div n="lb">lasting (as the body, or in the Sāṅkhya philosophy the
<div n="lb">discrete principles mahat, ahaṅkāra &c. or in the Nyāya
<div n="lb">the sound &c. <sup>2</sup> Occasional, not peremptory, not obligatory
<div n="lb">as a rule &c. (see also {#kAmya;#} as in the Jyotiṣṭoma the six
<div n="lb">samsthās: {#atyagnizwoma, ukTya, zoqaSin, atirAtra, aptoryAma#}
<div n="lb">and {#vAjapeya#} &c.). <sup>3</sup> Not necessary, not immutable. See
<div n="lb">{#anityasamAsa#}. <sup>4</sup> Unstable, inconstant. <sup>5</sup> Unusual, irregular.
<div n="lb">({#anityam#} not always.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#nitya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2669<pc>079-b<k1>anityakarman<k2>anityakarman
{#anityakarman#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-rma#}) An act of worship which is
<div n="lb">not peremptory, but voluntary and occasional. See {#kAmya-#}
<div n="lb">{#karman#}. E. {#anitya#} and {#karman#}.
<LEND>

<L>2671<pc>079-b<k1>anityatA<k2>anityatA

<div n="lb">transient existence. <sup>2</sup> The being occasional, not peremptory.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> The being not necessary. <sup>4</sup> Unstableness, inconstance.
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> Unusual occurrence. See the meanings of {#anitya#}. E. {#anitya#}.
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.

<L>2672<pc>079-b<k1>anityadatta<k2>anityadatta
{#anityadatta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ttaH#}) (In law.) A son given away by his
<div n="lb">natural parents temporarily or for a term. The adoption of such
<div n="lb">a son is performed without the homas or burnt offerings re-
<div n="lb">quired at the adoption of a nityadatta (q. v.). Also {#anityadattaka#}
<div n="lb">and {#anityadatrima#}. E. {#anitya#} and {#datta,#} temporarily given, scil. {#putra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2673<pc>079-b<k1>anityadattaka<k2>anityadattaka

<L>2675<pc>080-a<k1>anityapratyavekzA<k2>anityapratyavekzA

<L>2676<pc>080-a<k1>anityaBAva<k2>anityaBAva
{#anityaBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The state or condition of what
<div n="lb">is transient or perishable, perishableness. E. {#anitya#} (in
<div n="lb">the sense of the genitive) and {#BAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>2677<pc>080-a<k1>anityasama<k2>anityasama
{#anityasama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Wrongly generalizing the predicament of perishableness i. e.
<div n="lb">a sophism on perishableness; viz. arguing perishableness
<div n="lb">from the reason that every thing is perishable because it
<div n="lb">shares in some qualities with other things which are pe-
<div n="lb">rishable. E. {#anitya#} and {#sama#} (in the sense of {#jAti,#} sophism);
<div n="lb">the masc. form of this word is explained according to some,
<div n="lb">by the ellipsis of {#pratizeDa#} or contradiction, as a Sūtra in
<div n="lb">the Nyāya treating on a sophism is always followed by
<div n="lb">another containing the refutation; or, according to others,
<div n="lb">by the ellipsis of {#vikalpa#} (in the sense of {#viviDaH kalpaH#}
<div n="lb">i. e. {#prakAraH#} or variousness), there being various sophisms,
<div n="lb">viz. twenty-four; or according to others, by the ellipsis of
<div n="lb">{#prayoga#} i. e. a (logical) proceeding which likens or produces
<div n="lb">the plausibility of perishableness; or the word is taken as
<div n="lb">a Bahuvr. with the ellipsis of {#prayoga#} i. e. a logical proceeding
<div n="lb">in which perishableness is likened (viz. made plausible).--
<div n="lb">As a feminine, {#ºsamA#} is taken in the sense of {#jAti,#} sophism.
<LEND>

<L>2678<pc>080-a<k1>anityasamaprakaraRa<k2>anityasamaprakaraRa

<div n="lb">philosophy which treats on the sophism {#anityasama#} q. v. E.
<div n="lb">{#anityasama#} and {#prakaraRa#}.

<div n="lb">be dissolved into {#rAjYaH puruzaH#}. The converse of {#nityasamAsa#} q. v.

<P>P. = page; 1. = line; r. = read; a. = add; d. = take off; p. = instead of; {%a%} = first column; {%b%} = second column.

<>{#paYcikA#}) through not succeeding with one die’.--P. 6{%b,%} 1. 10, r. ‘{%Tuesday%}’ (p. {%Wednesday%}).--P. 7{%a,%} 1. 29, r. ‘{#rAjan,#} sam. aff. {#wac#}.--
<>P. 7{%b,%} 1. 25, a. ‘which is {#nit#}’.--P. 8{%b,%} d. 1. 23 and 24; 1. 53, a. ‘Bahuvr.’ and r. ‘E. {#agati#} (Bahuvr.), sam. aff. {#kap#}’.--P. 9{%b,%} d. 1. 1-4.
<>--P. 12{%a,%} 1. 52, r. ‘{#-rDikA#}’ (p. {#kA#} or {#kI#}).--P. 15{%a,%} 1. 13, {%b.%} 1. 1, 16{%a,%} 1. 14, d. ‘{#-rA#} or’.--P. 16{%a,%} 1. 38, r. {#-SikA#}.--P. 17{%a,%} 1. 2, r. E.
<>{#aNka,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.--P. 18{%a,%} 1. 5, a. ‘or {#am,#} uṇ. aff. {#gan; aNga#} (II. 1. 2.), in Bahuvr. comp. fem. aff. {#wAp#} or {#NIz#}.’--P. 21{%a,%} 1. 40, r. {#Ca#}
<>(p. {#ya#}).--P. 21{%b,%} 1. 29, r. {#NIz;#} 1. 35, d. ‘the ancle’ and ‘also’.--P. 23{%a,%} 1. 38, r. {#-kI#}.--P. 24{%a,%} 1. 47, r. E. {#ajaganDi#}.--P. 25{%b,%} 1. 44, r.

<>--P. 30{%b,%} 1. 56, a. ‘fem. I. {#NIz,#} III. {#NIn#}’.--P. 32{%a,%} 1. 32, d. ‘f. n. {#-vyasI-vyaH#}’.--P. 35{%a,%} 1. 24, d. ‘or {#-rI#}’.--P. 37{%b,%} 1. 50, a. ‘or {#-NgI#}’.
<>--P. 38{%a,%} 1. 33, a. ‘{%Tatpur%}’.--P. 39{%b,%} 1. 23, r. {#-strI;#} 1. 26, r. {#-rI#}.--P. 40{%a,%} 1. 2, r. ‘{#aN#}’ (p. {#qa#}).--P. 41{%b,%} 1. 46, r. ‘{#trinic;#} d. 1. 51.--
<>P. 42{%b,%} 1. 36, r. {#ac#} (p. {#aR#}).--P. 43{%a,%} 1. 16, d. ‘{#-hnA-hnam#}’.--P. 45{%a,%} 1. 51, r. ‘E. {%Probably%} &c.’--P. 46{%b,%} 1. 14, r. {#-datI;#} 1. 50, a. in

<>E. taddh. aff. {#kan#}.--P. 65{%a,%} 1. 32, r. {#-kzA#} (p. {#-kzI#}).--P. 69{%b,%} 1. 8, r. {#-sA#} (p. {#-sI#}).
<P>The Articles {#akta, agnizvAtta, agnisAt, aYjalika, at, ati, atidurlamBa, ada, adas#} and {#aDarozWa#} will be completed or amended
<>in the Supplement {%which will contain also the additional words and meanings.%}--It was originally intended to omit the name ‘{%Tatpur.%}’
<>when the {%Upapada-%}compounds had for their first part a {%gati,%} in order to distinguish them from common Tatpurushas. As the dif-
<>ference, however, appeared sufficiently marked by the method in which their Etym. is given and which, not being that of the native
<>grammarians, will have to be explained in the grammatical Appendix, the name ‘{%Tatpur.%}’ has been added already to all similar
<>compounds beginning with {#aDi;#} and the same may be done, for the sake of conformity, with the {%Upapada-%}compounds beginning
<>with {#ati#}.
[Page081-a+ 56]

<L>2712<pc>081-a<k1>animeza<k2>animeza

<L>2713<pc>081-a<k1>animezam<k2>animezam

<div n="lb">tively, watchfully, without interruption. See also {#animizam#}.

<L>2714<pc>081-a<k1>aniyata<k2>aniyata
{#aniyata#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not restrained, not
<div n="lb">fastened. <sup>2</sup> Not necessarily connected. <sup>3</sup> Not inevitable,
<div n="lb">not certain, not always occurring. <sup>4</sup> Not positive, not de-
<div n="lb">finite, undefined, undetermined. (The {#aniyatA DarmAH#} or
<div n="lb">‘undetermined rules’ of the Buddhists, are the topic of
<div n="lb">one of the chapters of their Phātimokkha, and treat on
<div n="lb">transgressions that involve exclusion, suspension and pe-
<div n="lb">nance, but not permanent exclusion, of a Bauddha priest.)
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#niyata#}.
<LEND>

<L>2720<pc>081-a<k1>aniyukta<k2>aniyukta

<div n="lb">not called, not appointed &c. See {#niyukta#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ktaH#}) (In Law.) A Brāhmaṇa who attends a court
<div n="lb">without having been appointed a member of it, whose vote
<div n="lb">is therefore not binding, and who is at liberty to attend
<div n="lb">the court meetings and to debate in them, or not. (See,
<div n="lb">on the contrary, {#saBAsad#}.)
<LEND>

<L>2724<pc>081-a<k1>anirukta<k2>anirukta
{#anirukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not spoken out,
<div n="lb">not declared. <sup>2</sup> Not explained, not defined (e. g. the di-
<div n="lb">vinity, if spoken of in general terms, or Brahma (n.) that
<div n="lb">is without qualities, or an invocation, not containing the
<div n="lb">special name of the god addressed, one addressed to the
<div n="lb">gods in general &c.). <sup>3</sup> Obscure, incomprehensible, literally
<div n="lb">and metaphorically; e. g. Prajāpati, Brahman (n.) or a
<div n="lb">hymn uttered inaudibly, so as not being comprehensible to
<div n="lb">the by-standers. E. {#a#} neg. and {#nirukta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2726<pc>081-b<k1>anirudDa<k2>anirudDa
{#anirudDa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unobstructed,
<div n="lb">unrestrained. <sup>2</sup> Self-willed, ungovernable, headstrong. <sup>3</sup> Move-
<div n="lb">able, unsteady(?).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-dDaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of the son of Pradyumna or
<div n="lb">Kāmadeva by Śubhāṅgī or, according to others, Kaku-
<div n="lb">dvatī, the daughter of Rukmin; his wife is Uṣā, the
<div n="lb">daughter of Vāna, or, according to others, Subhadrā, the
<div n="lb">granddaughter of Rukmin, and his son Vajra.--The
<div n="lb">Vaiṣṇava sect, called Pāñcharātra or Bhāgavatas, con-
<div n="lb">sider him as an incarnation or part of Viṣṇu and identify
<div n="lb">him with Ahaṅkāra, self-consciousness.--<sup>2</sup> A name of
<div n="lb">Śiva. <sup>3</sup> The name of a celebrated Bauddha Arhat and con-
<div n="lb">temporary of Śākyamuni. <sup>4</sup> The name of a member of the
<div n="lb">Vṛṣṇi tribe, the descendants of Vṛṣṇi. See also {#AnirudDa#}
<div n="lb">and {#AnirudDAyani#}. <sup>5</sup> A spy(?).
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-dDam#}) A rope for fastening cattle. E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#nirudDa#}. (It is doubtful whether the meaning 1. 3. (move-
<div n="lb">able) or the meaning 2. 4. (spy) is the correct one, the
<div n="lb">translation being founded on the word {#cara,#} given as one
<div n="lb">of the meanings of {#anirudDa,#} but without any further in-
<div n="lb">dication as to the gender. From the place, however, {#cara#}
<div n="lb">occupies in the explanation of some of the native dictio-
<div n="lb">naries, the meaning ‘spy’ is likely to be preferable to the
<div n="lb">meaning ‘moveable’.)
<LEND>

<L>2727<pc>081-b<k1>anirudDapaTa<k2>anirudDapaTa
{#anirudDapaTa#}¦ Bahuvr. n. ({#-Tam#}) Atmosphere, æther. E. {#anirudDa#}
<div n="lb">and {#paTin,#} samāsānta aff. {#a;#} lit. having an unobstructed path.
<LEND>

<L>2746<pc>082-a<k1>anila<k2>anila
{#anila#}¦ m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> Wind, viz. <sup>a.</sup> (in its usual acceptation) the
<div n="lb">motion of air; <sup>b.</sup> the deity of wind; <sup>c.</sup> one of the eight
<div n="lb">Maruts, and in this sense distinct from {#mAruta, vAyu#} &c.
<div n="lb">(see {#marut#}); <sup>d.</sup> one of the eight Vasus (see {#vasu#}); <sup>e.</sup> (in the
<div n="lb">plural {#anilAH#}) a class of the Gaṇadevatās, comprising
<div n="lb">forty-nine Anilas; <sup>f.</sup> (in medicine) one of the three Rasas
<div n="lb">or temperamental elements of the body (see {#rasa#}), subdi-
<div n="lb">vided into {#prARa, udAna, samAna, vyAna#} and {#apAna;#} in this
<div n="lb">sense used synonymously with {#mAruta, vAta, vAyu, samIraRa#}
<div n="lb">and other words meaning wind; <sup>g.</sup> (in the terminology of
<div n="lb">the Upanishads) the exterior wind or the surrounding air,
<div n="lb">in distinction from {#vAyu#} or {#prARa,#} the vital air of the body.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> A proper name of <sup>a.</sup> a son of Tansu and father of Du-
<div n="lb">shwanta; <sup>b.</sup> a Rākṣasa; <sup>c.</sup> a Ṛṣi, author of a vaidik
<div n="lb">hymn; <sup>d.</sup> (in the mythology of the Jainas) the seventeenth
<div n="lb">Arhat of the past Utsarpiṇī. <sup>3</sup> (In arithmetic, sometimes
<div n="lb">used to denote) the numeral 49 (there being forty-nine
<div n="lb">Anilas). <sup>4</sup> A mystic denomination of the letter {#ya#}. E. {#an,#}
<div n="lb">uṇ. aff. {#ilac#}.
<LEND>

<L>2747<pc>082-a<k1>anilakumAra<k2>anilakumAra
{#anilakumAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-rAH#}) (In the mythology of the
<div n="lb">Jainas.) One of the ten kinds of Bhavanapatis (q. v.) or
<div n="lb">Bhavanādhīśas (q. v.), the first of the four classes of Jaina
<div n="lb">divinities. E. {#anila#} and {#kumAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2748<pc>082-a<k1>anilaGna<k2>anilaGna
{#anilaGna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-GnaH-GnI-Gnam#}) Removing disorders
<div n="lb">from wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.), as a medicine &c. Also {#vAtaGna,#}
<div n="lb">{#vAyuGna#} &c. E. {#anila#} and {#Gna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2749<pc>082-a<k1>anilaGnaka<k2>anilaGnaka
{#anilaGnaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) A large tree (Terminalia belerica). See
<div n="lb">also {#viBItaka#}. E. {#anilaGna,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>2750<pc>082-a<k1>anilaparyAya<k2>anilaparyAya
{#anilaparyAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (In Medicine.) An inflammation
<div n="lb">affecting the whole eye, described as produced from the
<div n="lb">vitiated Rasa wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.) ‘which pervades the eye-
<div n="lb">lids, eye and eyebrows and makes them diseased one after the
<div n="lb">other’. The less correct reading of this word is {#anilapayaya#}.
<div n="lb">See also {#mArutaparyAya#} and {#vAtaparyAya#}. E. {#anila#} and {#paryAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>2751<pc>082-a<k1>anilaprakfti<k2>anilaprakfti
{#anilaprakfti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-tiH-tiH-ti#}) Of airy or windy
<div n="lb">nature; an epithet of the planet Saturn. E. {#anila#} and {#prakfti#}.
<LEND>

<L>2752<pc>082-a<k1>anilamBasamADi<k2>anilamBasamADi
{#anilamBasamADi#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-DiH#}) A fanciful name of a
<div n="lb">Buddhistic samādhi or profound meditation. E. {#anilamBa#}
<div n="lb">and {#samADi,#} meaning perhaps ‘a meditation that sur-
[Page082-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">passes all impediments or limits, one which nothing can
<div n="lb">resist’.
<LEND>

<L>2753<pc>082-b<k1>anilayana<k2>anilayana
{#anilayana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) No-resting place, no-support
<div n="lb">(an epithet of the neuter Brahman, in an Upanishad, be-
<div n="lb">cause it is devoid of qualities, impersonal &c.). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#nilayana#}.
<LEND>

<L>2754<pc>082-b<k1>anilavyADi<k2>anilavyADi
{#anilavyADi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-DiH#}) (In Medicine.) Derangement
<div n="lb">of the Rasa wind (see {#anila#} 1. f.), produced, according to
<div n="lb">the native theory, by the continued use of dry, cold or light
<div n="lb">articles of food, taken in unusually small quantities &c.
<div n="lb">and causing, according to some authorities, eighty varieties
<div n="lb">of nervous diseases. See also {#anilAmaya#} and {#vAtavyADi#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anila#} and {#vyADi#}.
<LEND>

<L>2772<pc>082-b<k1>aniSa<k2>aniSa

<div n="lb">priv. and {#niSA,#} according to some, implying here merely
<div n="lb">the period of time, according to others, the want of occu-

<L>2773<pc>083-a<k1>aniSita<k2>aniSita
{#aniSita#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) (ved.) Restless, incessant(?).
<div n="lb">E. {#aniSi#} (a denom. from {#aniSa#}), kṛt aff. {#kta(?)#}. (Mean-
<div n="lb">ing and etymology of this word are doubtful. According
<div n="lb">to the native commentaries it would be a Tatpur. compounded
<div n="lb">of {#a#} neg. and {#niSita,#} sharpened, sharp, and would mean
<div n="lb">either: <sup>1</sup> not sharp, not injurious, or: <sup>2</sup> not difficult, easy,
<div n="lb">or <sup>3</sup> not slender, not little; but these explanations, when
<div n="lb">applied to the passages to which they refer, seem artificial.
<LEND>

<L>2774<pc>083-a<k1>aniSitasarga<k2>aniSitasarga
{#aniSitasarga#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rgaH-rgA-rgam#}) (ved.) Of con-
<div n="lb">tinual effusion, continually flowing (an epithet of the wa-
<div n="lb">ters)(?). (This meaning is doubtful; according to the comm.
<div n="lb">it would be: of strong or abundant effusion. See the pre-
<div n="lb">ceding.) E. {#aniSita#} and {#sarga#}.
<LEND>

<L>2775<pc>083-a<k1>anizaNga<k2>anizaNga

<div n="lb">impeded by, scil. the Rākṣasas; this interpretation seems
<div n="lb">artificial.) E. {#a#} priv. and {#nizaNga#}.

<L>2780<pc>083-a<k1>anizwa<k2>anizwa
{#anizwa#}¦ Tatpur. I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unwished, un-
<div n="lb">desirable, bad, wrong. <sup>2</sup> Bad, evil. <sup>3</sup> Unlucky.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Bad luck, evil occurrence, misfortune.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Evil deed, crime.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-zwA#}) The name of a plant (Sida alba). See {#nAga-#}
<div n="lb">{#valA#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#izwa#} ({#iz,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}).
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not sacrificed. <sup>2</sup> Not honoured
<div n="lb">with a sacrifice (as a god). E. {#a#} neg. and {#izwa#} ({#yaj,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#kta#}).
<LEND>

<L>2781<pc>083-a<k1>anizwaduzwaDI<k2>anizwaduzwaDI

<div n="lb">what is undesirable, incongruous or wrong connexion, as
<div n="lb">that of a Yogin with worldly objects; or (in Nyāya) that
<div n="lb">of an inference with wrong premises, the former tending to
<div n="lb">prove the absurdity of the argument advanced; or (in gram-

<div n="lb">which has no relation to it. E. {#anizwa#} and {#prasaNga#}.

<L>2824<pc>084-b<k1>anu<k2>anu<h>1
I. {#anu#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}). A
<div n="lb">particle implying the notion of ‘after’ in its literal and
<div n="lb">metaphorical acceptations; it is used either as a separable
<div n="lb">preposition or as a prefix to verbs, but, in the latter ca-
<div n="lb">pacity, in the Vedas and in archaic passages of the epic
<div n="lb">literature, also detached from the verb, very much in the
<div n="lb">same manner as German prepositions when connected with
<div n="lb">verbs; in the Vedas it is sometimes also used adverbially.
<div n="lb">With nouns it may form Avyayībh., Tatpur. and Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">compounds. It means:
<div n="P">1. (as a separable preposition, with a noun following
<div n="lb">or preceding in the accusative) <sup>1</sup> After; <sup>a.</sup> in space (literally),
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> in time, implying successiveness, <sup>c.</sup> in rank or order, im-
<div n="lb">plying inferiority. <sup>2</sup> Along, lengthwise (in this sense also
<div n="lb">with a noun in the genitive). <sup>3</sup> With, together with (in this
<div n="lb">meaning, however, only in conventional phrases; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#parvatamanu#} or {#nadImanvavasitA senA#} ‘the army was (so placed
<div n="lb">as to be) in communication with a mountain or with a
<div n="lb">river’. <sup>4</sup> To the part or share of; e. g. {#yadatra mAmanu syAt#}
<div n="lb">‘what there may fall to my share’. <sup>5</sup> By (implying dis-
<div n="lb">tribution); e. g. {#vfkzaM vfkzamanu siYcati#} ‘he throws water tree
<div n="lb">by tree i. e. he waters every tree. <sup>6</sup> After, in the sense of
<div n="lb">to, towards, in the direction of; e. g. {#vfkzamanu vidyotate vidyut#}
<div n="lb">‘the lightning flushes after i. e. towards, in the direction of
<div n="lb">the tree’. <sup>7</sup> In regard to, in consequence of, on behalf of
<div n="lb">(only in conventional phrases), e. g. {#japamanu prAvarzat#} ‘it
<div n="lb">rained in consequence of prayers’ or {#SAkalyasya saMhitAmanu#}
<div n="lb">or {#anuqudyajYamanu prAvarzat#} ‘it rained in consequence of the
<div n="lb">hymns of Sākalya (having been recited) or in consequence
<div n="lb">of an ox having being sacrificed’. <sup>8</sup> In accordance with, agree-
<div n="lb">ably to, like, similar. <sup>9</sup> According to the statement of, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#sADurdevadatto mAtaramanu#} ‘Devadatta is an excellent man,
<div n="lb">according to what his mother tells’.
<div n="P">2. (as a prefix to verbs, undetached or detached) <sup>1</sup> After,
<div n="lb">in space or time, literally and metaphorically, e. g. {#gam,#}
<div n="lb">{#sajj, SI#} &c. with {#anu#} qq. vv. <sup>2</sup> Similarly, likewise (im-
<div n="lb">plying imitation); in accordance with, agreeably to, lit.
<div n="lb">and met., see f. i. {#kf, vac, jYA#} with {#anu#} &c.
<div n="P">3. (as adverb, in the Vedas) Afterwards.
[Page085-a+ 56]
<div n="P">4. (in composition with nouns) I. (In Avyayībh. com-
<div n="lb">pounds.) <sup>1</sup> After, <sup>a.</sup> in space (literally), e. g. {#anuraTam,#}
<div n="lb">after, behind the cart; <sup>b.</sup> in order or rank, e. g. {#anujyezWam,#}
<div n="lb">after, next to the eldest. <sup>2</sup> Along, lengthwise, on, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#anugaNgaM vArARasI#} ‘Benares is situated along, i. e. on the
<div n="lb">Ganges’. <sup>3</sup> Near to; e. g. {#anuvanamaSanirgataH#} ‘it lightens near
<div n="lb">the forest’. <sup>4</sup> According to, agreeably to, like; e. g. {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#kramam#} ‘according to order, in due order’. <sup>5</sup> Severally, by;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#anudinam#} ‘day by day, daily’.
<div n="P">II. (In Tatpur. compounds.) <sup>1</sup> After (in order or rank),
<div n="lb">subsequent, inferior, secondary; see f. i. {#anukanIyas, anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#kalpa, anunAyikA#}. <sup>2</sup> According to, in conformance with,
<div n="lb">similar, like to; e. g. {#anukUla, anuloma, anubrAhmaRa#}. <sup>3</sup> Again;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#anulApa#}.
<div n="P">III. (In Bahuvr. compounds.) In conformity with, si-
<div n="lb">milar, like, e. g. {#anuguRa, anurUpa#} &c. E. unknown; the
<div n="lb">native etym. {#an,#} uṇ. aff. {#u,#} is not plausible; {#anu#} is pro-
<div n="lb">bably connected in origin with {#A,#} towards, in its oldest
<div n="lb">form {#AM~ = aM~s#}. See s. v. {#A#} and the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>2825<pc>085-a<k1>anu<k2>anu<h>2
II. {#anu#}¦ m. ({#-nuH#}) <sup>1</sup> (in the Vedas; esp. in the plural {#anavaH#})
<div n="lb">Man in general; but it seems that this word is in the Vedas
<div n="lb">the name of a tribe or family, the meaning ‘men’ being
<div n="lb">an etymological interpretation of the commentaries. <sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb">proper name of a king in the North, the fourth son of
<div n="lb">Yayāti by Śarmiṣṭā; according to others, a son of Kuru-
<div n="lb">vaśa or of Kuru. E. {#an,#} uṇ. aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">E. Probably a further developement of the partic. {#anukarzat,#}
<div n="lb">from {#kfz#} with {#anu,#} conformably to the general origin of bases
<div n="lb">in {#an;#} the native dict. consider it as {#anukarza#} with an additional
<div n="lb">{#n,#} but {#anukarza#} is more likely the curtailed {#anukarzan#} as most
<div n="lb">bases in {#a#} probably originate in a fuller form on {#as, at, an#}.

<L>2853<pc>085-b<k1>anukUla<k2>anukUla
{#anukUla#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> Conformable to.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Well disposed to, friendly, favourable.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-laH#}) (In Rhetoric.) See {#anukUlanAyaka#}.
[Page086-a+ 56]
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-lA#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a medicinal plant (Croton
<div n="lb">polyandrum). See {#dantI#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of a metre regulated
<div n="lb">by number and quantity; it belongs to the class, called
<div n="lb">{#trizwuB#} q. v. and consists of a stanza of four lines with the
<div n="lb">following eleven syllables in each: {??}
<div n="lb">Also called {#kudmaladantI, mOktikamAlA#} and {#SrI#}.
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-lam#}) (In Rhetoric.) An alaṅkāra or mode of writing
<div n="lb">or speaking elegantly, viz. representing an act, unpleasant in
<div n="lb">itself, as arising out of kindness or affection; e. g. when ‘an
<div n="lb">ill-humoured mistress embraces her lover and apparently out
<div n="lb">of excess of love wounds him with her nails’. E. {#anu#} and {#kUla#}
<div n="lb">literally ‘along or according to the bank (of a river)’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">ing. <sup>2</sup> Followed, pursued. <sup>3</sup> Acquired, obtained, lit. and met.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Gone out, extinguished (as fire).
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) (In Music.) The middle measure, neither
<div n="lb">quick nor slow; the same as {#Gana#} q. v. E. {#gam#} with {#anu,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">meaning, one easily inferred from the etymon (as a word),
<div n="lb">e. g. the words {#garBADAna, annaprASana, udayagiri#} &c. E. {#anugata#}
<div n="lb">and {#arTa#}.

<L>2895<pc>087-a<k1>anugIti<k2>anugIti
{#anugIti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) The name of a metre regulated by
<div n="lb">feet and belonging to the class called {#gaRacCandas#} or {#gaRavftta#}
<div n="lb">qq. vv. It consists of a couplet of two verses with twenty-
<div n="lb">seven syllables in the first, and with thirty-two syllables
<div n="lb">in the second verse; it is measured by feet, denominated
<div n="lb">{#gaRa#} or {#mAtrAgaRa#} which are equivalent to two long syllables
<div n="lb">or to four short; its odd feet (the first, third, fifth and
<div n="lb">seventh) must never be amphibrachys, the sixth foot of
<div n="lb">the first verse consists of a single short syllable and that
<div n="lb">of the second verse of an Amphibrachys or Proceleusmaticus.
<div n="lb">The pause is commonly restricted to the close of the third
<div n="lb">foot. If the long verse precede the short one, the metre
<div n="lb">is called {#sugIti#}. E. {#anu#} and {#gIti#} (another metre).
<LEND>

<L>2896<pc>087-a<k1>anugu<k2>anugu
{#anugu#}¦ Avyayībh. After the cow or the cows. E. {#anu#} and {#go#}.
<LEND>

<L>2897<pc>087-a<k1>anuguRa<k2>anuguRa
{#anuguRa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) Of similar qualities,
<div n="lb">congenial with, corresponding with, suitable to.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. ({#-RaH#}) (In Rhetoric.) An alaṅkāra or mode
<div n="lb">of writing elegantly, representing the natural properties of
<div n="lb">a thing as more intense through contact with another thing.
<div n="P">III. Avyayībh. ({#-Ram#}) According to the quality or natural
<div n="lb">property (of an object). E. {#anu#} and {#guRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>2902<pc>087-b<k1>anugrahasarga<k2>anugrahasarga

<div n="lb">subdivided into {#viparyaya, aSakti, sidDi#} and {#tuzwi#} qq. vv.

<div n="lb">therefore restricted to the passage alone alluded to (book 5
<div n="lb">verse 58) and not generally applicable). <sup>2</sup> Born like or with
<div n="lb">similar qualities as (another). E. {#anu#} and {#jAta#}.

<L>2956<pc>089-a<k1>anuttama<k2>anuttama
{#anuttama#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) I. Tatpur. Very best, chief,
<div n="lb">principal. E. {#a#} compar. or expl. and {#uttama,#} or perhaps a
<div n="lb">compound framed after the analogy of {#anuttara#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. (In grammar.) Without the first person, used
<div n="lb">in any but the first person, i. e. in the second or third person
<div n="lb">(viz. a verb). E. {#a#} priv. and {#uttama#}.
<LEND>

<L>2957<pc>089-a<k1>anuttamanyu<k2>anuttamanyu
{#anuttamanyu#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-nyuH#}) (ved.) Of invincible wrath, an
<div n="lb">epithet of Indra. E. {#anutta#} and {#manyu#}.
<LEND>

<L>2958<pc>089-a<k1>anuttamAmBas<k2>anuttamAmBas
{#anuttamAmBas#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-mBaH#}) A technical term in the Sāṅkhya
<div n="lb">philosophy denoting one of the five sorts of external ac-
<div n="lb">quiescence or indifference (see {#tuzwi#}), viz. that condition of
<div n="lb">mind in which a man abstains from sensual enjoyments on
<div n="lb">the ground that there is no repose for the senses when at-
<div n="lb">tachment to sensual pleasures prevails. Some call this in-
<div n="lb">difference {#nArIka;#} compare also {#amBas, salila, oGa, vfzwi,#}
<div n="lb">{#sutamas, pAra, sunetra, supAra, apAra, pArApAra, uttamAmBas#}
<div n="lb">and the following. E. {#a#} neg. and {#uttamAmBas(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>2959<pc>089-a<k1>anuttamAmBasika<k2>anuttamAmBasika
{#anuttamAmBasika#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kam#}) A technical term in the
<div n="lb">Sāṅkhya philosophy denoting one of the five sorts of ex-
<div n="lb">ternal acquiescence or indifference (see {#tuzwi#}), viz. that con-
<div n="lb">dition of mind in which a man abstains from sensual enjoy-
<div n="lb">ments on the ground that it is sinful to injure created things,
<div n="lb">enjoyment however being impossible without doing so. Some
<div n="lb">call this indifference {#uttamAmBas#}. Compare the preceding and
<div n="lb">the terms named there. E. {#anuttama#} and {#AmBasika(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>2960<pc>089-a<k1>anuttara<k2>anuttara
{#anuttara#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Low, nether.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> South, southern. <sup>3</sup> Low, inferior, vile.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> No-answer. <sup>2</sup> A bad or evasive reply
<div n="lb">and held therefore to be no-answer (e. g. of the defendant,
<div n="lb">in a law-suit). E. {#a#} neg. and {#uttara#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Best, excellent,
<div n="lb">supreme, chief, principal (literally: than which there is no
<div n="lb">higher or better). <sup>2</sup> Fixed, firm. <sup>3</sup> Unable to answer or to
<div n="lb">give a proper answer.
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-rAH#}) In Jaina mythology, one of the two
<div n="lb">divisions (see also {#grEveyaka#}) of the gods called {#kalpAtIta#}
<div n="lb">(q. v.) which are one of the two divisions (see also {#kalpaBava#})
<div n="lb">of the gods called {#vEmAnika#} (q. v.); the {#anuttarAH#} comprise
<div n="lb">five classes. See {#vijaya, vEjayanta, jayanta, aparAjita#} and
<div n="lb">{#sarvArTasidDi#}. See also {#anuttaropapAtika#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#uttara#}.
<LEND>

<L>2961<pc>089-a<k1>anuttarayogatantra<k2>anuttarayogatantra
{#anuttarayogatantra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ntram#}) The name of the last of
<div n="lb">the four Bauddha Tantras, the Tantra of the supreme Yoga.
<div n="lb">(The other three are called {#kriyAtantra, AcAratantra#} and {#yo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gatantra#} qq. vv.) E. {#anuttara-yoga#} and {#tantra#}.
<LEND>

<L>2962<pc>089-a<k1>anuttaropapAtika<k2>anuttaropapAtika
{#anuttaropapAtika#}¦ m. pl. ({#-kAH#}) Apparently the same as {#anuttara#}
<div n="lb">m. pl.: the name of the Jaina gods so called. According
<div n="lb">to a commentary it would mean literally ‘those who have
<div n="lb">the highest origin i. e. who are born in the five Vimānas’
<div n="lb">from which the five classes of the {#anuttarAH#} derive their
<div n="lb">appellations. E. {#anuttaropapAtin#} ({#anuttara#} and {#upapAta,#}
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#ini#}), taddh. aff. {#kan(?)#}.
<LEND>

<L>2963<pc>089-a<k1>anuttaropapAtikadaSA<k2>anuttaropapAtikadaSA

<div n="lb">ninth of the twelve sacred writings of the Jainas: that
[Page089-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">treating on the {#anuttaropapAtikAH#} (q. v.). E. {#anuttaropapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tika#} and {#daSA#} (acc. to a comm. in the sense of {#aDyayana#});
<div n="lb">but more probably {#anuttaº#} and {#daSan,#} samāsānta aff. {#qac,#}
<div n="lb">like {#AsannadaSa#} &c.
<LEND>

<L>2964<pc>089-b<k1>anutpatti<k2>anutpatti
{#anutpatti#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) The not taking origin or birth,
<div n="lb">the not being produced, the not arising (as in philosophy,
<div n="lb">e. g. of all knowledge at once, or of Prakṛti &c.). See
<div n="lb">also {#anutpattisama#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#utpatti#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-ttiH-ttiH-tti#}) Having no origin or
<div n="lb">birth, not being produced. E. {#a#} priv. and {#utpatti#}.
<LEND>

<L>2965<pc>089-b<k1>anutpattika<k2>anutpattika
{#anutpattika#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kI-kam#}) (In Bauddha li-
<div n="lb">terature.) Having no origin or birth, not or not yet being
<div n="lb">produced. (The fem. {#-kI#} belongs to Bauddha writings; in
<div n="lb">the classic language, it would be {#-kA#}.) See the following.
<div n="lb">E. {#anutpatti#} II., samāsānta aff. {#kap#}.

<L>2966<pc>089-b<k1>anutpattikaDarmakzAnti<k2>anutpattikaDarmakzAnti
{#anutpattikaDarmakzAnti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ntiH#}) (In Bauddha literature.)
<div n="lb">Enduring conditions which have not yet taken place i. e.
<div n="lb">reconciling one's mind to the conditions of a future life;
<div n="lb">one of the hundred-eight {#DarmAlokamuKa#} (q. v.) or means to
<div n="lb">comprehend the doctrine of Śākyamuni; ‘it leads to the
<div n="lb">reception of revelations’ i. e. it enables an enquirer to get
<div n="lb">possessed of the mysteries of the Bauddha doctrine. E.
<div n="lb">{#anutpattika-Darma#} and {#kzAnti#}.
<LEND>

<L>2967<pc>089-b<k1>anutpattisama<k2>anutpattisama
{#anutpattisama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The sophism of the impossibility of origin or birth; viz.
<div n="lb">arguing that a thing cannot take origin, because a thing
<div n="lb">exists in consequence of an immaterial cause; as the latter,
<div n="lb">however, does not exist before the material cause and the
<div n="lb">instance proving the existence of such material cause, and
<div n="lb">as the material cause again depends upon what exists, and
<div n="lb">the instance upon the material cause, the thing itself can
<div n="lb">never come into existence: or origin in general is impossible.
<div n="lb">E. {#anutpatti#} and {#sama#}. (With respect to the gender of this
<div n="lb">word and the ellipsis required to explain it, see the E. of
<div n="lb">{#anityasama#}.)
<LEND>

<L>2968<pc>089-b<k1>anutpanna<k2>anutpanna
{#anutpanna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) Not born, not pro-
<div n="lb">duced &c. See {#utpanna#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#utpanna#}.
<LEND>

<L>2969<pc>089-b<k1>anutpAda<k2>anutpAda
{#anutpAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) The not taking origin or birth,
<div n="lb">the not arising. E. {#a#} neg. and {#utpAda#}.

<L>2970<pc>089-b<k1>anutpAdakzAnti<k2>anutpAdakzAnti
{#anutpAdakzAnti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ntiH#}) (In Bauddha literature.) En-
<div n="lb">during non-birth i. e. reconciling one's mind to not being

<div n="lb">conducive to a clear apprehension of all that may impede
<div n="lb">(sc. the attainment of this desirable end). E. {#anutpAda#} and {#kzAnti#}.

<L>2981<pc>090-a<k1>anudAtta<k2>anudAtta
{#anudAtta#}¦ Tatpur. (In Grammar.) 1. m. f. n. ({#-ttaH-ttA-ttam#})
<div n="lb">Not elevated, not being pronounced with the accent called
<div n="lb">{#udAtta#} (q. v.) or {#svarita#} (q. v.) (as the syllable of a word).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ttaH#}) The not elevated accent, the accent (see
<div n="lb">{#svara#} and {#vAhyaprayatna#}) which is neither {#udAtta#} (q. v.) nor
<div n="lb">{#svarita#} (q. v.) and which by the depression of the voice, it
<div n="lb">requires, prepares, as it were, for the greater effort in the
<div n="lb">pronunciation of the syllables accented with the {#udAtta#} or
<div n="lb">{#svarita#}. This depression being the greatest when the syl-
<div n="lb">lable having the {#anudAtta#} accent, is immediately followed
<div n="lb">by a syllable accented with the {#udAtta#} or {#svarita,#} the {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dAtta#} is called in this case {#anudAttatara#} ‘a very anudātta’.
<div n="lb">The mode of marking the {#anudAtta,#} is restricted, as is also
<div n="lb">the case with the other two accents, to the vaidik Sanhitās
<div n="lb">(Sanhitā-Pāṭhas) and Brāhmaṇas, and varies according to
<div n="lb">the different Vedas. In the Sanhitā, Pada and the Brāhmaṇas
<div n="lb">of the Ṛgveda, in the Sanhitā and Pada of the Yajur- and
<div n="lb">Sanhitā of the Atharvaveda the Anudātta is marked with a
<div n="lb">horizontal line under the syllable so accented ({%thus becoming%}
<div n="lb">{%comparable also in graphic value to the sign of the Virāma, the%}
<div n="lb">{%horizontal line representing as it were the repose in accentua-%}
<div n="lb">{%tion%}); in the Brāhmaṇas of the White Yajurveda, it is not
<div n="lb">marked at all; and in the Sanhitā of the Sāmaveda the anu-
<div n="lb">dātta syllable when anudāttatara before an udātta, or before
<div n="lb">a svarita syllable bearing the figures {#2#} or {#3,#} is marked with
<div n="lb">the figure {#3#} over it, except when it is preceded in the be-
<div n="lb">ginning of a verse by other anudātta syllables, in which
<div n="lb">case only the first anudātta syllable bears the figure {#3,#}
<div n="lb">while the following anudātta syllables are left unmarked.
<div n="lb">If the anudāttatara is followed by a svarita syllable bearing
<div n="lb">the sign {#2ra,#} the syllable so accented is marked with {#3ka#}.
<div n="lb">In the Pada-text of the Sāmaveda the sign {#3#} denotes the
<div n="lb">anudāttatara before an udātta, if the latter occupies the
<div n="lb">second syllable from the beginning, or the syllable before
<div n="lb">an anudāttatara, if the latter is followed by a svarita, or
<div n="lb">lastly the anudātta accentuation of a syllable so marked and
<div n="lb">of all the syllables following it until an udātta or svarita
<div n="lb">syllable comes; the sign {#3ka#} or {#ka#} denotes the anudāttatara
<div n="lb">immediately followed by a svarita. Compare also the terms
<div n="lb">{#nIca, nihata, nyasta, nyastatara, niyata, niGAta, nyAsa, niyama#}
<div n="lb">and the radd. {#han#} with {#ni#} and {#yam#} with {#ni#}.--In the native
[Page090-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">lists of radicals, the Dhātupāthas, certain radicals have the
<div n="lb">anudātta accent as an {#it#} (q. v.) or {#anubanDa#} (q. v.) connected
<div n="lb">with them i. e. as a technical sign for certain rules they are
<div n="lb">subject to with respect to derivation &c. See also {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dAttet#} and {#anudAttopadeSa#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#anudAtta#}.
<LEND>

<L>2982<pc>090-b<k1>anudAttatara<k2>anudAttatara
{#anudAttatara#}¦ m. ({#-raH#}) The {#anudAtta#} accent (or {#svara#}) or a syl-
<div n="lb">lable so accented when immediately preceding a syllable
<div n="lb">having the {#udAtta#} or {#svarita#} accent. See under {#anudAtta#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anudAtta,#} taddh. aff. {#tarap#}.
<LEND>

<L>2983<pc>090-b<k1>anudAttatva<k2>anudAttatva
{#anudAttatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The having or being the accent {#anudAtta#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anudAtta,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>2984<pc>090-b<k1>anudAttasvarita<k2>anudAttasvarita
{#anudAttasvarita#}¦ Karmadh. See {#nIcasvarita#}. E. {#anudAtta#} and
<div n="lb">{#svarita#}.
<LEND>

<L>2985<pc>090-b<k1>anudAttAdi<k2>anudAttAdi

<L>3021<pc>091-b<k1>anunAsika<k2>anunAsika
{#anunAsika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) (In Grammar.) Uttered
<div n="lb">through the nose, nasal (see also {#rakta#}), viz. <sup>1</sup> A nasal sound
<div n="lb">in general, it being pronounced through the nose and with
<div n="lb">the appropriate organ of speech, as {#N#} through the nose
<div n="lb">and the throat, {#Y#} through the nose and with the palate &c.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (Conditionally) a vowel or {#y, v, l;#} in this case the nasal
<div n="lb">nature of the sound is indicated by the sign {#M~#}. (N. B. {#yM~#} or
<div n="lb">{#vM~#} represent the value of {#y#} or {#v#} preceded by {#m; lM~#} that
<div n="lb">of {#l#} preceded by {#m#} or {#n#}. In the pause a final vowel may
<div n="lb">be anunāsika. A {%short%} anunāsika vowel, when not occurr-
<div n="lb">ing in a pause, represents apparently always the value of
<div n="lb">the same vowel and {#m#} or {#n;#} it must be, in general, the
<div n="lb">last vowel sound of the former part of a compound or of
<div n="lb">the word itself, followed by a final sibilant, e. g. {#saM~skartA#}
<div n="lb">instead of {#sams-kartA, puM~ScalI = pums-calI, tasmiM~stvA =#}
<div n="lb">{#tasmins-tvA#}. Only a few exceptions of this rule are mentioned
<div n="lb">by the vaidik grammarians, e. g. {#aminantaM~ evEH,#} when {#a#} of {#nta#}
<div n="lb">is anunāsika, although it does neither stand in a pause nor
<div n="lb">represent more than its own sound.--A {%long%} anunāsika
<div n="lb">vowel, when not occurring in a pause, may be generally
<div n="lb">considered as representing the value of its short vowel and
<div n="lb">an original {#nts#} or of its short vowel and {#nt,#} provided {#s#} or
<div n="lb">its substitute has been preserved; e. g. {#mahAM~ indraH = mahants#}
<div n="lb">{#indraH, daDanvAM~ yaH = daDanvants yaH, sargAM~ iva = sargants iva#}
<div n="lb">or {#mahAM~Scarati = mahants carati, dasyUM~rekaH = dasyunts ekaH#}.
<div n="lb">The material difference that prevails between the anunāsika
<div n="lb">({#M~#}) and the anusvāra ({#M#}) sound, does not appear to have
<div n="lb">been kept alive beyond the period of the vaidik literature,
<div n="lb">when an interchange between both was not deemed legiti-
<div n="lb">mate; according to the grammarians of the classical period,
<div n="lb">in the latter the anunāsika may be replaced by the anu-
<div n="lb">svāra. The sign of the anunāsika ({#M~#}), however, is but
<div n="lb">seldom met with in the ordinary Mss. referring to the post-
<div n="lb">vaidik literature; and from the reasons stated, its use in
<div n="lb">vaidik Mss. is objectionable, when it occurs in words like
<div n="lb">{#yaSAM~si, DanUM~zi, viSvezAM~ hitaH#} or in {#maM~hizWa, vAjaM~ sanizat, indraM~#}
<div n="lb">{#stavAma#} and similar instances in which the long nasal vowel
<div n="lb">does not represent more than the value of a short vowel
<div n="lb">and a nasal, or in which the short nasal vowel is not fol-
<div n="lb">lowed by a final sibilant.) E. {#anu#} and {#nAsikA#}.
<LEND>

<L>3081<pc>093-a<k1>anupalabDisama<k2>anupalabDisama
{#anupalabDisama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philo-
<div n="lb">sophy.) A sophism on non-perception; viz. arguing: ‘be-
<div n="lb">cause the non-perception of an object cannot be perceived,
<div n="lb">therefore the non-perception of the object does not exist
[Page093-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">and consequently the non-existence of the object cannot
<div n="lb">exist i. e. the object itself must exist’. This sophism is at-
<div n="lb">tributed by the Nyāya e. g. to those who maintain the eter-
<div n="lb">nity of sound on the ground that ‘the non-perception of
<div n="lb">sound antecedently to pronunciation’--the reason alleged
<div n="lb">by the Nyāya for its non-eternity--may be refuted in
<div n="lb">the manner explained. E. {#anupalabDi#} and {#sama#} (m. scil.
<div n="lb">{#pratizeDa#} or {#vikalpa#} or {#prayoga;#} f. scil. {#jAti;#} comp. for the
<div n="lb">meaning of these words the E. of {#anityasama#}).
<LEND>

<div n="lb">ceived, not being seen. E. {#a#} neg. and {#upalaByamAna#}.

<div n="lb">tible’. See {#anupalabDi#} and {#anupalabDisama#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#upalamBa#}.

<L>3088<pc>093-b<k1>anupasaMhArin<k2>anupasaMhArin

<div n="lb">Non-exclusive, purely affirmative, as an argument of all-
<div n="lb">comprehensiveness whose subject does not exclude any thing;
<div n="lb">as such an argument would lead to a conclusion of a purely
<div n="lb">formal kind, i. e. to no real conclusion, {#anupasaMhArin#} is
<div n="lb">the characteristic of one of the modes of {#hetvABAsa#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">or ‘semblance of argument’; compare also {#anEkAntika#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#upasaMhArin#}.

<L>3089<pc>093-b<k1>anupasarga<k2>anupasarga

<div n="lb">pounds like {#antarvaRa,#} or {#aBi, pari#} in formations like {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAvakIyati, parisAvakIyati,#} when {#aBi#} and {#pari#} do not quali-
<div n="lb">fy the radical {#su#} but the denom. {#sAvakIyati#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#upasarga#}.

<L>3097<pc>094-a<k1>anupasTita<k2>anupasTita

<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#upasTita#}.

<div n="lb">impaired, not obstructed. <sup>2</sup> Not polluted, not vitiated, not

<L>3100<pc>094-a<k1>anupahatakruzwa<k2>anupahatakruzwa

<div n="lb">great man, acc to the Buddhists. E. {#a#} priv. and {#upahata-kruzwa#}.

<L>3102<pc>094-a<k1>anupAkfta<k2>anupAkfta

<L>3103<pc>094-a<k1>anupAkftamAMsa<k2>anupAkftamAMsa

<div n="lb">of vaidik hymns, flesh of an animal which has not been
<div n="lb">killed at a sacrifice. (A Brahmaṇa is forbidden to eat such
<div n="lb">flesh.) E. {#anupAkfta#} and {#mAMsa#}.

<L>3105<pc>094-a<k1>anupAta<k2>anupAta
{#anupAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> Falling subsequently upon, alight-
<div n="lb">ing or descending upon in succession. <sup>2</sup> Following. <sup>3</sup> (In
<div n="lb">arithmetic.) Proportion, the rule of three. E. {#anu#} and {#pAta#}
<div n="lb">or {#pat#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Ra#}.
<LEND>

<L>3106<pc>094-a<k1>anupAtaka<k2>anupAtaka
{#anupAtaka#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kam#}) A heinous offence, one similar
<div n="lb">to the four great crimes ({#mahApAtaka#}) which are: <sup>a.</sup> Causing
<div n="lb">the death of a Brāhmaṇa (directly or indirectly). <sup>b.</sup> Drink-
<div n="lb">ing spirits. <sup>c.</sup> Stealing (acc. to the comm. ‘gold from a
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa’). <sup>d.</sup> Committing incest with the wife of a
<div n="lb">father, natural or spiritual. The {#anupAtaka#} mentioned by
<div n="lb">Manu are the following: 1. False boasting of superiority
<div n="lb">(as pretending to be a Brāhmaṇa or conversant with the
<div n="lb">four Vedas, if one is not); 2. Malignant report, before a
<div n="lb">king, of crimes (comm.: punishable by death)--omitted
<div n="lb">by Yājnavalkya--; 3. Falsely accusing a spiritual preceptor;
<div n="lb">4. Forgetting the Veda; 5. Showing contempt of the Veda
<div n="lb">(comm.: by resorting to heretical writings); 6. Giving false
<div n="lb">evidence (omitted by Yājnav.); 7. Killing a friend (comm.:
<div n="lb">not a Brāhmaṇa, this case being the first {#mahApAtaka#}); 8.
<div n="lb">(Knowingly) eating things prohibited (i. e. food fit only for
<div n="lb">a Śūdra, as garlick &c.) or unfit to be tasted (as excrements
<div n="lb">&c.); [9. (According to Yājnavalkya) Kissing a woman
[Page094-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">while in menstruation; 10. (Acc. to Yājn.) Deceitfulness
<div n="lb">(i. e. saying one thing and doing another)]; 11. Appro-
<div n="lb">priating a deposit (comm.: not the gold of a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">(this case being the third {#mahApAtaka#}) or acc. to another
<div n="lb">author. a deposit not of gold, if it belongs to a Brāhmaṇa);
<div n="lb">12--17. Stealing a man, a horse, silver, a piece of land, a
<div n="lb">diamond or a gem [acc. to Yājnavalkya, 12--17. a horse,
<div n="lb">a gem, a man, a woman, a piece of land, and a cow];
<div n="lb">18--22. Sexual intercourse with one's own sister, with little
<div n="lb">girls before they have attained to puberty, with women of
<div n="lb">the lowest tribe (comm.: a Chāṇdālī), with the wives of a
<div n="lb">friend or of a son [to which Yājnavalkya adds: 23--30. with
<div n="lb">a woman of the same gotra or family, the sister of a father
<div n="lb">or mother, the wife of a maternal uncle, the wife of one's
<div n="lb">father, the daughter or wife of a spiritual teacher or one's
<div n="lb">own daughter; Nārada adds moreover: 31--40. with a mother
<div n="lb">in law, the wife of a paternal uncle or of a pupil, the friend
<div n="lb">of a sister, one who comes for protection, the wife of one
<div n="lb">who carries on the government of the country--comm.:
<div n="lb">if he is not a Kshatriya--, a nurse, a female mendicant,
<div n="lb">a female devotee and a woman of the Brāhmaṇa class.]--
<div n="lb">Similar to the first Mahāpātaka are the Anupātakas, acc.
<div n="lb">to Manu, 1--3, acc. to Yājnavalkya, 3--5 and 7. Similar to
<div n="lb">the second Mahāpātaka are the Anup., acc. to Manu, 4--8;
<div n="lb">acc. to Yājnav., 1. 8. 9. 10. Similar to the third Mahāp.
<div n="lb">are the Anup., acc. to Manu and Yājnav., 11--17. Similar
<div n="lb">to the fourth Mahāp. are, according to Manu, the Anupāt.
<div n="lb">18--22, acc. to Yājnav. (and Nārada, Yama &c.), 18-40. E.
<div n="lb">{#anu#} and {#pAtaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>3107<pc>094-b<k1>anupAtam<k2>anupAtam
{#anupAtam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. Following, going after, having fol-
<div n="lb">lowed or gone after (used in phrases implying reiteration;
<div n="lb">for the construction comp. s. v. {#anuprapAtam#}); e. g. {#latAnu-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAtaM kusumAnyagfhlAt#} ‘following creeper for creeper &c.’,
<div n="lb">{#krIqanBujaNgena gfhAnupAtaM kaScidyaTA jIvati saMSayasTaH#} &c. ‘like
<div n="lb">as a snake-catcher who plays with the snake is always in
<div n="lb">uncertainty whenever he goes house for house &c.’. E. {#pat#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}.
<LEND>

<L>3108<pc>094-b<k1>anupAtin<k2>anupAtin

<div n="lb">sulting from e. g. {#SabdajYAnAnupAtI vastuSUnyo vikalpaH#} ‘imagi-
<div n="lb">nation is (a notion) devoid of reality, resulting from know-
<div n="lb">ledge conveyed by words’. E. {#pat#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.

<div n="lb">close by. E. {#anu#} and {#pAna#}.

<L>3137<pc>095-b<k1>anuprapAtam<k2>anuprapAtam

<div n="lb">{#Ramul#}).

<L>3159<pc>096-a<k1>anubanDa<k2>anubanDa
{#anubanDa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-nDaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Binding, confining. <sup>2</sup> Connexion,
<div n="lb">association, attachment; close relation; e. g. {#pUrvAByastasmftya-#}
<div n="lb">{#nubanDaH#} ‘connexion with the memory of things previously
<div n="lb">acquired’. {#nIvArAdizu codanAnubanDaH#} ‘the injunction relates
<div n="lb">to or concerns wild rice &c. (not {#vrIhi#}). <sup>3</sup> An uninterrupted
<div n="lb">series, e. g. {#vErAnubanDaH#} a series of hostilities or heroic deeds.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Consequence, result, e. g. {#pUrvakftaPalAnubanDAttadutpattiH#} ‘it
<div n="lb">(the body) is produced in consequence of the fruits of its
<div n="lb">former deeds’. <sup>5</sup> Cause esp. of a crime &c., e. g. {#anubanDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#parijYAya…daRqaM pAtayet#} let (the king) having ascertained
<div n="lb">the cause (comm.: of the offence) inflict punishment; or of
<div n="lb">an untoward event &c., e. g. {#virAtre cAgataM kasmAtko'nu-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDaSca te'Bavat#} ‘why hast thou come so late in the night
<div n="lb">and what was the cause (comm.: of the delay)?’ <sup>6</sup> Com-
<div n="lb">mencement, beginning. <sup>7</sup> A child (this meaning seems doubt-
<div n="lb">ful, at least as regards its etymol. interpretation; acc. to
<div n="lb">some it would be qualified as {#muKyAnuyAyin#} ‘following the
<div n="lb">chief i. e. the father &c. at the marriage ceremony &c.; the
<div n="lb">instance given however would not seem to countenance the
<div n="lb">meaning viz. {#bAlakAnubanDena yAtrABaNgo mA BUt#} ‘let the festival
<div n="lb">not be disturbed by the incumbrance of children’; accord.
<div n="lb">to others the meaning ‘child’ would imply the tie of af-
<div n="lb">fection). <sup>8</sup> (In the system of the native grammarians.) An
<div n="lb">indicatory letter which is annexed to radicals ({#DAtu#}), no-
<div n="lb">minal bases ({#prAtipadika#}), affixes ({#pratyaya#}), particles ({#nipAta#}),
<div n="lb">inserted letters ({#Agama#}) and substitutes ({#AdeSa#}), to mark
<div n="lb">some peculiarity in the accent, inflection or derivation; for
<div n="lb">instance an {%indicatory%} {#i#} denotes that verbs require the in-
<div n="lb">sertion of a nasal before their final consonant; the anu-
<div n="lb">bandha may be a vowel (in this case it is {#anunAsika#} q. v.
<div n="lb">in the system of Pāṇini) or a consonant. Being a mere
<div n="lb">technical element it cannot occur in real language. Instances
<div n="lb">of anubandhas may be gathered from the etymologies in this
[Page096-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">Dictionary. See also {#it#}. <sup>9</sup> Any thing small or little, a
<div n="lb">part, a small part. <sup>10</sup> (In Medicine.) A secondary or sym-
<div n="lb">ptomatic affection, one supervening on the principal disease.
<div n="lb"><sup>11</sup> (In Arithmetic.) Junction or union; see {#BAgAnubanDa#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>12</sup> (In the Vedānta philosophy.) An indispensable element
<div n="lb">of the study of the Vedānta; it consists of <sup>a.</sup> the {#aDikArin#}
<div n="lb">or the competent person, one who is well versed in the
<div n="lb">vaidik writings, observes the ceremonies &c., is purified in
<div n="lb">his heart &c.; <sup>b.</sup> the {#vizaya#} or the object-matter viz. the
<div n="lb">identity of the individual soul and Brahman (neuter); <sup>c.</sup> the
<div n="lb">{#saMbanDa#} or the relation viz. between that identity to be proved
<div n="lb">and the authoritative evidence contained in the Upanishads,
<div n="lb">and <sup>d.</sup> the {#prayojana#} or the purpose viz. the cessation of
<div n="lb">ignorance and attainment of eternal bliss.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-nDI#}) <sup>1</sup> Hickup. <sup>2</sup> Thirst. E. {#banD#} with {#anu,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#GaY,#} in the fem. with {#NIz#}.
<LEND>

<L>3162<pc>096-b<k1>anubanDya<k2>anubanDya
{#anubanDya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. ({#-nDyaH-nDyA#}) One of the three prin-
<div n="lb">cipal paśus or sacrificial animals in the Jyotiṣṭoma sacrifice.
<div n="lb">(See also {#agnIzomIyapaSu#} and {#savanIyapaSu#}.) It is a cow, and
<div n="lb">the proceedings with it take place after the Avabhṛtha on
<div n="lb">the fifth day of the Agniṣṭoma (q. v.). But as the sacrifice
<div n="lb">of a cow is forbidden in the present or Kali-yuga, a sub-
<div n="lb">stitute for it is an offering of curds of two-milk-whey.--
<div n="lb">Also written {#anUbanDya#}. E. {#banD#} with {#anu,#} kṛtya aff. {#yat;#}
<div n="lb">with the ellipsis of {#paSu#} for the masc. and of {#go#} for the
<div n="lb">feminine.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-nDyaH-nDyA-nDyam#}) Principal, primary, what
<div n="lb">may receive an adjunct, as a root, a disease &c. E. {#anubanDa,#}
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>3174<pc>097-a<k1>anuBAva<k2>anuBAva
{#anuBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Dignity, authority, power (such
<div n="lb">as results from wealth, a magisterial position &c.). <sup>2</sup> Cer-
<div n="lb">tainty, resolution (only in the positive sense of a good re-
<div n="lb">solution, e. g. {#mahAnuBAva#} q. v.). <sup>3</sup> (In rhetorical terminology.)
<div n="lb">‘A symptom which indicated the feeling ({#BAva#}) produced
<div n="lb">by its appropriate causes’. These causes being naturally
<div n="lb">various from the character ({#rasa#}) of a poetical composition,
<div n="lb">the rhetorical works enumerate the anubhāvas which are
<div n="lb">the concomitants of the different sorts of rasas; thus the
<div n="lb">symptoms of the Erotic ({#SfNgAra#}) are according to them,
<div n="lb">motion of the eye-brows, side-glances &c.; of the Comic
<div n="lb">({#hAsya#}), blinking with the eye, smiles &c.; of the Pathetic
<div n="lb">({#karuRa#}), cursing one's fate, falling to the ground, crying
<div n="lb">&c.; of the Terrible ({#rOdra#}), abuse, fierce looks &c.; of the
<div n="lb">Heroic ({#vIra#}), looking for a companion &c.; of the Fearful
<div n="lb">({#BayAnaka#}), change of colour, stammering &c.; of the Dis-
<div n="lb">gustful ({#bIBatsa#}), spitting, contracting the mouth, shutting
<div n="lb">the eyes &c.; of the Wonderful ({#adButa#}), wide opening of
<div n="lb">the eyes &c.; of the Quietistic ({#SAnta#}), horripilation (sic)
<div n="lb">&c.; of the Affectionate ({#vatsala#}), horripilation, joy, tears
<div n="lb">&c.--Compare {#BAva#} and {#viBAva#}. E. {#anu#} and {#BAva,#} lit.
<div n="lb">‘following or connected with condition, feeling &c.’.
<LEND>

<L>3175<pc>097-a<k1>anuBAvaka<k2>anuBAvaka
{#anuBAvaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vakaH-vikA-vakam#}) Making intel-
<div n="lb">ligible. E. {#BU,#} in the caus., with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<L>3176<pc>097-a<k1>anuBAvana<k2>anuBAvana
{#anuBAvana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (In rhetoric.) Representing feel-
<div n="lb">ings so as to make then the characteristic ({#SfNgAra#} &c. see
<div n="lb">{#rasa#} and {#anuBAva#}) of a poetical composition. E. {#BU,#} in the
<div n="lb">caus., with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>3177<pc>097-a<k1>anuBAvin<k2>anuBAvin
{#anuBAvin#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-vI-vinI-vi#}) Perceiving,
<div n="lb">knowing (e. g. a witness).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-vI#}) (In law.) According to some, the same as
<div n="lb">{#sapiRqa#} q. v., a near kinsman (i. e. ‘one who feels grief at
<div n="lb">a death in the family’), according to others, the same as
<div n="lb">‘a young son’ (i. e. ‘one who is or comes after’). E. {#BU#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-vI-vinI-vi#}) Having the symptoms which
<div n="lb">indicate feeling (see {#anuBAva#}). E. {#anuBAva,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>3178<pc>097-a<k1>anuBAzaRa<k2>anuBAzaRa
{#anuBAzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) (In the Nyāya phil.) Repeating
<div n="lb">an argument proposed for discussion, i. e. taking it up;
<div n="lb">the contrary (not-repeating it when it has been announced
<div n="lb">three times besides the first time) being considered as a
<div n="lb">tacit agreement or avowal of defeat. See {#ananuBAzaRa#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#BAz#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">ing of the Pica or Garrulus Argoratensis.) E. {#BAs (BAz?)#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac(?)#}.

<L>3182<pc>097-b<k1>anuBUti<k2>anuBUti

<L>3185<pc>097-b<k1>anuBoga<k2>anuBoga
{#anuBoga#}¦ Tatpur.(?) n. ({#-gam#}) (A modern law term.) Enjoy-
<div n="lb">ment, usufruct, a grant of hereditary land in Malabar,
<div n="lb">either rent-free or at pepper-corn-rent, in reward of service;
<div n="lb">also a present of betel or a cocoa nut, from the proprietor
<div n="lb">at the time of executing a deed of transfer of a garden or
<div n="lb">plantation to the person to whom the transfer is made, as
<div n="lb">symbolical of the character of the land made over. E. {#anu#}
<div n="lb">and {#Boga#}.

<L>3187<pc>097-b<k1>anumata<k2>anumata
{#anumata#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Accepted, assented
<div n="lb">to. <sup>2</sup> Agreeable, pleasant. <sup>3</sup> Loved, beloved. <sup>4</sup> Concurred

<L>3188<pc>097-b<k1>anumati<k2>anumati
{#anumati#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Assent, permission, acquiescence.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Conniving (at a criminal act). <sup>3</sup> The fifteenth day of the
<div n="lb">moon's age, on which she rises one digit less than full.
<div n="lb">(On this day it was held that the gods and the Manes of
<div n="lb">departed progenitors were favourable to the prayers of men;
<div n="lb">gifts made to Brāhmaṇas on this day were considered there-
<div n="lb">fore to be meritorious. The three other phases of the in-
<div n="lb">creasing moon are {#kuhU, rAkA#} and {#sinIvAlI#} qq. vv. Com-
<div n="lb">pare also {#pOrRamAsI, amAvAsyA, KarvikA#} and {#sadyaskAlA#}.)
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> The former personified as a goddess and invoked especi-
<div n="lb">ally in sacrificial acts connected with the Rājasūya sacrifice
<div n="lb">and the obsequial rites. The later mythology represents her
<div n="lb">as a daughter of Angiras and Smṛti. <sup>5</sup> The name of the
<div n="lb">offering made to the goddess Anumati in the Rājasūya sacri-
<div n="lb">fice and consisting of Puroḍāśa fried in eight bowls. E. {#man#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>3189<pc>097-b<k1>anumatipatra<k2>anumatipatra
{#anumatipatra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tram#}) (A modern law term.) A deed
<div n="lb">expressive of assent or concurrence; especially a deed
<div n="lb">executed by a husband about to die, authorising his widow
<div n="lb">to adopt a son. E. {#anumati#} and {#patra#}.
<LEND>

<L>3196<pc>098-a<k1>anumaraRa<k2>anumaraRa
{#anumaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Dying with or following in death;
<div n="lb">the term usually denotes the cremation of a Hindu widow,
<div n="lb">whose husband's corpse is not on the spot, and with whose
<div n="lb">shoes she, therefore, ascends the pile: this is prohibited to
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa women; or the cremation of a widow with the
<div n="lb">body of the husband (see {#sahamaraRa#}). E. {#anu#} and {#maraRa#}.

<L>3199<pc>098-a<k1>anumAdya<k2>anumAdya

<L>3200<pc>098-a<k1>anumAna<k2>anumAna
{#anumAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Inferring, as the cause of {#anumiti#}
<div n="lb">or of a conclusion drawn from given premises. According to
<div n="lb">the Sāṅkhya and Yoga-philosophies it is one of the {%three%}
<div n="lb">means (see {#pramARa#}) by which true knowledge may be ob-
<div n="lb">tained (see also {#pratyakza#} or {#dfzwa#} and {#Agama#} or {#Aptavacana#});
<div n="lb">according to the Nyāya and Vaiśeṣika phil., one of the
<div n="lb">{%four%} means for this end (see also {#pratyakza, upamAna#} and {#Sabda#}).
<div n="lb">Inference may be, according to the definitions of Sāṅkhya
<div n="lb">and Nyāya philosophers, either one by induction ({#pUrvavat#})
<div n="lb">e. g. that it will rain because clouds have gathered, or one
<div n="lb">by analogy ({#sAmAnyato dfzwam#}), e. g. that moon and stars are
<div n="lb">locomotive because they change their place and that a person
<div n="lb">therefore who changes his place is locomotive; or one by ne-
<div n="lb">cessity ({#Sezavat#}), e. g. that the ocean will be salt, because a
<div n="lb">drop taken from it, is salt. According to the Vaiśeṣika
<div n="lb">philosophers, inference may be either purely consecutive or
<div n="lb">positive ({#kevalAnvayin#}), i. e. when the major term is not
<div n="lb">excluded by any other notion (comp. {#anupasaMhArin#}), e. g.
<div n="lb">all that can be known can be named, because only positive
<div n="lb">(not negative instances) can be alleged to prove the asser-
<div n="lb">tion; or purely exclusive or negative ({#kevalavyatirekin#}), i. e.
<div n="lb">when only negative proof can be adduced, e. g. in asserting
<div n="lb">that earth is distinguished from all the other elements, be-
<div n="lb">cause it is possessed of the quality of smell, for the ar-
<div n="lb">gument would be that all that is not distinguished from
<div n="lb">all the other elements, is not possessed of the quality of
[Page098-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">smell; or positive and negative ({#anvayavyatirekin#}), i. e.
<div n="lb">when there exist positive and negative instances of the major
<div n="lb">term, e. g. where there is fire there is smoke, because the
<div n="lb">positive argument would be ‘on the hearth’ and the negative
<div n="lb">‘in the lake’. (The Mīmānsā and Vedānta philosophies do
<div n="lb">not discuss these topics, as inference is not considered by
<div n="lb">them to be a means of arriving at true knowledge.) <sup>2</sup> (In
<div n="lb">rhetoric.) A logical anakolouthon by the way of inference,
<div n="lb">an {#alaMkAra#} or mode of writing elegantly, e. g. ‘wherever
<div n="lb">falls the look of woman, there fall sharpened arrows; I
<div n="lb">think therefore that the God of Love runs before them while
<div n="lb">shooting off his arrows’. E. {#mA#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>3201<pc>098-b<k1>anumAnaKaRqa<k2>anumAnaKaRqa

<L>3223<pc>099-a<k1>anuyAja<k2>anuyAja
{#anuyAja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) A secondary sacrificial act; the
<div n="lb">name of several offerings of clarified butter mixed with
<div n="lb">curdled milk, which occur in various sacrifices, as the Dar-
<div n="lb">śapūrnamāsa &c. There are, for instance, nine Anuyājas
<div n="lb">in the Chāturmāsya; eleven in the Jyotiṣṭoma where they
<div n="lb">form part of the proceedings with the {#savanIyapaSu#} (q. v.).
<div n="lb">Eleven Anuyājas are also personified as divinities of one of
<div n="lb">the two classes comprising thirty three gods; comp. besides
<div n="lb">{#upayAja#} and {#prayAja#}. Also written {#anUyAja#}. Compare {#prayAja#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anu#} and {#yAja#}.
<LEND>
