<L>3263<pc>099-b<k1>anurADa<k2>anurADa
{#anurADa#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. Compare {#anUrADa#}. E. {#rAD#} with {#anu,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
[Page100-a+ 56]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-DA#}) The seventeenth Nakshatra (q. v.) or lunar
<div n="lb">mansion, described as a row of oblations; it consists of
<div n="lb">four, or according to a different reading, of three stars; its
<div n="lb">chief and middlemost star is placed by the authorities in
<div n="lb">3º or 2º or 1º 45'S. and in 224º or 224º 5'E., and must in-
<div n="lb">tend the star near the head of the Scorpion (<lang n="greek"></lang> Scorpionis)
<div n="lb">and the asterism probably comprises <lang n="greek"></lang> and <lang n="greek"></lang> Scorpionis.
<div n="lb">Also written {#anUrADA#}. See {#rADAnurADA#} and {#viSAKAnurADA#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anu#} and {#rADA,#} the name of the sixteenth Nakshatra.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-DaH-DA-Dam#}) Born under the constellation
<div n="lb">Anurādhā.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-DaH#}) A proper name, the son of Pāṇḍu-Śākya
<div n="lb">and founder of the village or town Anurādha (see {#anurADa-#}
<div n="lb">{#grAma#} and {#anurADapura#}), the ancient capital of Ceylon. E.
<div n="lb">{#anurADA#} with {#luk#} of the taddh. aff. {#aR#}.
<LEND>

<L>3264<pc>100-a<k1>anurADagrAma<k2>anurADagrAma
{#anurADagrAma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) The village (later the town)
<div n="lb">Anurādha; the same as {#anurADapura#} q. v. and the <lang n="greek"></lang>-
<div n="lb"><lang n="greek"></lang> or <lang n="greek"></lang> of Ptolemæus. E. {#anurADa#}
<div n="lb">and {#grAma#}.
<LEND>

<L>3265<pc>100-a<k1>anurADapura<k2>anurADapura
{#anurADapura#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-puram#}) The name of the ancient capital
<div n="lb">of Ceylon, founded according to the legends by Anurādha
<div n="lb">(q. v.), and the principal place of Buddhistic relics; it was
<div n="lb">possessed especially of the tooth of Buddha which has
<div n="lb">played a great part in the history of Ceylon and is still
<div n="lb">preserved in Kandi. See also {#anurADagrAma#}. Its geographical
<div n="lb">position is 8º 15'N. Lat. 98º 14'36'' E. L. E. {#anurADa#} and {#pura#}.
<LEND>

<L>3271<pc>100-a<k1>anurUpa<k2>anurUpa
{#anurUpa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-paH-pA-pam#}) <sup>1</sup> Like, resembling.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Fit, suitable. <sup>3</sup> According to.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-paH#}) The second of three {#tfca#} or stanzas (each
<div n="lb">consisting of three verses) recited at a sacrificial act; of the
<div n="lb">three {#tfca,#} for instance, in the beginning of the second
<div n="lb">portion of the Sāmaveda, {#upAsmE gAyata narAH#} &c., {#davi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyutatyA rucA#} &c., and {#pavamAnasya te kave#} &c. which form the
<div n="lb">{#bahizpavamAnastotra#} and are recited e. g. in the {#dvAdaSAha#} sacri-
<div n="lb">fice, the Tṛcha which begins with the words {#davidyutatyA#}
<div n="lb">{#rucA#} is called the {#anurUpa#}. (See besides {#stotrIya#} and {#paryAsa#}.)
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-pam#}) <sup>1</sup> Conformity, likeness, analogy ({#anurUpeRa#}
<div n="lb">conformably, agreeably to). <sup>2</sup> Fitness, suitableness.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-pam#}) Conformably, agreeably to. E. {#anu#}
<div n="lb">and {#rUpa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3282<pc>100-b<k1>anulA<k2>anulA
{#anulA#}¦ Tatpur.(?) f. ({#-lA#}) A proper name of <sup>1</sup> A female
<div n="lb">Buddhistic Arhat or Saint who is renowned for having in-
<div n="lb">troduced the Buddhistic religion in Laṅkā or Ceylon in the
<div n="lb">time of the king Aśoka; she was the wife of Mahānāga,
<div n="lb">the younger brother of Mahendra and received the dignity
<div n="lb">of a female Arhat from Saṅghamitrā, the sister of Ma-
<div n="lb">hendra. <sup>2</sup> A queen of Ceylon renowned for her profligacy.
<div n="lb">She was the wife of Koranāga, the brother of Mahākūla-
<div n="lb">mahātiṣya, whom she killed by poison as well as his son
<div n="lb">Tishya and four paramours whom she married in succession.
<div n="lb">A second son of Mahākūla, Kālakanatiṣya revolted at last
<div n="lb">against her and caused her death in the year 41 before
<div n="lb">Christ. E. doubtful.
<LEND>

<L>3291<pc>100-b<k1>anulepin<k2>anulepin

<div n="lb">e. g. {#gAtrAnulepin#}. E. {#lip#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}. (In
<div n="lb">compounds such as {#tAmramfzwAnulepin#} the E. is not {#tAmra-mfzwa#}
<div n="lb">and {#anulepin,#} but {#tAmra-mfzwa-anulepa,#} taddh. aff. {#ini,#} since

<div n="lb">compound, but to the whole.)

<L>3292<pc>101-a<k1>anuloma<k2>anuloma
{#anuloma#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) In natural
<div n="lb">order or direction, regular, successive (liter. with the hair),
<div n="lb">the reverse of {#pratiloma;#} comp. e. g. {#pratilomAnulomapAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#yamaka#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> A proper name; his descendants are called
<div n="lb">{#anulomAH#} or {#AnulomayaH#} (plur. of {#Anulomi#}); according
<div n="lb">to another authority, however, the name of the descendants
<div n="lb">ought to be {#anulomAnaH#} or {#AnulomayaH#} (plur. of {#Anulomi#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In vaidik grammar; scil. {#anvakzarasanDi#}) One of the two
<div n="lb">kinds of the Sandhi called {#anvakzarasanDi#} q. v., viz. when a
<div n="lb">final vowel or the last syllable of {#ezaH, syaH#} or {#saH#} is fol-
<div n="lb">lowed by a consonant (of a new word; the case in the latter
<div n="lb">three instances being similar to those of the meeting between
<div n="lb">a final vowel and a beginning consonant, since their Visarga
<div n="lb">is dropped). Compare {#pratiloma#}.
<div n="P">3. m. plur. ({#-mAH#}) scil. {#varRAH;#} mixed tribes or castes;
<div n="lb">for the special meaning, in which this word is used, see
<div n="lb">{#anulomaja#}.
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-mA#}) A woman of a caste inferior to that of the
<div n="lb">man; e. g. a Kṣatriyā woman when spoken of in reference
<div n="lb">to a Brāhmaṇa man. Comp. {#anulomaja#}.
<div n="P">[5. (In Buddhistic literature the word {#anuloma#} expresses
<div n="lb">the regular order in which certain ascetic rites are to be
<div n="lb">performed; e. g. the kasinānuloma consists of the eight
<div n="lb">first kasinas in their regular order, the dhyānānuloma of
<div n="lb">the four successive dhyānas.]
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-mam#}) In natural order, regularly, suc-
<div n="lb">cessively. E. {#anu#} and {#loman,#} samāsānta aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>3293<pc>101-a<k1>anulomakalpa<k2>anulomakalpa
{#anulomakalpa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-paH#}) The name of the 34th of the
<div n="lb">Pariśiṣṭhas of the Atharvaveda. E. {#anuloma#} and {#kalpa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3294<pc>101-a<k1>anulomakfzwa<k2>anulomakfzwa
{#anulomakfzwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) Ploughed (as it
<div n="lb">were) with the grain; e. g. {#anulomakfzwaM kzetraM punaH pratilomaM#}
<div n="lb">{#karzati#} ‘he ploughs the field first with and then against its
<div n="lb">grain’, i. e. first in one and then in its opposite direction.
<div n="lb">E. {#anuloma#} (II.) and {#kfzwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3295<pc>101-a<k1>anulomaja<k2>anulomaja
{#anulomaja#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Born in due gra-
<div n="lb">dation; applied especially to the mixed tribes or offspring
<div n="lb">of a father superior in caste to the mother, viz. the Mūr-
<div n="lb">dhāvasikta (son of a Brāhmaṇa and a Kṣatriyā mother),
<div n="lb">the Ambaṣṭha (son of a Brāhmaṇa and Vaiśyā mother),
<div n="lb">the Niṣāda or Pāraśava (son of a Brāhmaṇa and Śūdrī
<div n="lb">mother), the Māhiṣya (son of a Kshatriya and Vaiśya
<div n="lb">mother), the Ugra (son of a Kshatriya and Śūdrī mother)
<div n="lb">and the Karaṇa (son of a Vaiśya and Śūdrī mother). For
<div n="lb">the offspring of a mother superior in caste to the father
<div n="lb">see {#pratiloma#} and {#pratilomaja#}. E. {#anuloma#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>3296<pc>101-a<k1>anuloman<k2>anuloman

<div n="lb">(acc. to one authority; acc. to another their name is {#anulomAH#}
<div n="lb">or {#AnulomayaH#}. See {#anuloma#} I. 2.). E. {#anu#} and {#loman#}.

<L>3297<pc>101-a<k1>anulomana<k2>anulomana
{#anulomana#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nI-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Putting in due
<div n="lb">order, regulating; e. g. {#DarmAnulomana#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Medicine.) Di-
<div n="lb">recting into the proper channel; esp. applied to medicines
<div n="lb">intended to correct the vitiated air of the body or to ob-
<div n="lb">viate urinary and excretory impediments.
[Page101-b+ 56]
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Regulating. <sup>2</sup> Obviating the diseases men-
<div n="lb">tioned before by correcting vitiated air &c. E. {#anulomi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>3302<pc>101-b<k1>anuvaMSa<k2>anuvaMSa

<div n="lb">embodying such tables or lists. (A comm. renders this word
<div n="lb">simply with {#gATA#} ‘a song’ and {#anuvaMSya#} with {#gAtavya;#} the
<div n="lb">meaning ‘song’ however seems too general and would not
<div n="lb">always convey a distinct meaning of {#anuvaMSa#}.)
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-Sam#}) According to the families or races.
<div n="lb">(The word {#AnuvaMSya#} is derived from the Avyayībh., not
<div n="lb">from the Tatpur.) E. {#anu#} and {#vaMSa#} (the E. of I. 1. however
<div n="lb">according to the comm. mentioned, would have to be in
<div n="lb">conformity with that given of {#vaMSa, vam#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Sa#}).

<L>3305<pc>101-b<k1>anuvakra<k2>anuvakra
{#anuvakra#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kraH-krA-kram#}) Somewhat oblique
<div n="lb">(another reading of this word is {#ativakra#} q. v.); applied
<div n="lb">esp. to the diurnal motion of a planet in its orbit (see {#gati#}),
<div n="lb">of which motions eight are enumerated, subdivided again
<div n="lb">into two classes; the {#anuvakragati#} belongs to that class of
<div n="lb">motions which is called {#vakra#}. E. {#anu#} and {#vakra#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">direction (as a planet); see the preceding. E. {#anuvakra#} and {#ga#}.
<LEND>

<L>3307<pc>101-b<k1>anuvacana<k2>anuvacana
{#anuvacana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Speaking after or in conformity
<div n="lb">with, repeating, reciting; e. g. {#vedAnuvacana#} repeating the
<div n="lb">words of the Veda in the same manner as the teacher has
<div n="lb">enounced them, i. e. reading or studying the Veda; {#sAvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tryanuvacana#} reciting the Sāvitrī hymn. <sup>2</sup> A lecture or chapter
<div n="lb">(esp. in the Kāṭhaka recension of the black Yajurveda).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> (In the liturgical literature.) The speaking of and the name
<div n="lb">of certain vaidik passages or mantras which are addressed
<div n="lb">by certain priests at sacrifices to the deity in consequence
<div n="lb">of, and in conformity with, other passages spoken by other
<div n="lb">priests, esp. by the Adhvaryu, which contain an injunction or
<div n="lb">{#prEza#} (q. v. and compare {#anuvAcana#}); the {#anuvacana#} are either
<div n="lb">connected with the {#prEza#} immediately (see {#samasta#}), or separated
<div n="lb">from them by other words (see {#vyasta#}); e. g. such {#anuvacana#}
[Page102-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">as {#pra vo vAjA aBidyavaH . aYjanti tvAmaDvare devayantaH#} &c.
<div n="lb">are separated from {#prEza#} such as {#agnaye samiDyamAnAyAnubrUhi .#}
<div n="lb">{#yUpAyAjyamAnAyAnubrUhi,#} while in the instances {#hotAyakzadagniM#}
<div n="lb">&c. the {#anuvacana#} is immediately followed by the {#prEza ‘ho-#}
<div n="lb">{#turyaja’,#} or in the instance {#mEtrAvaruRaH prezyati cAnu cAha,#} the
<div n="lb">anuvachana {#‘anu cAha’#} follows immediately the praisha {#mEtrAº#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#vac#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">twelve years, the fifth which is presided over by Brahman (for
<div n="lb">the other four cycles see {#idvatsara#} &c.). E. {#anu#} and {#vatsara#}.

<L>3315<pc>102-a<k1>anuvazawkAra<k2>anuvazawkAra
{#anuvazawkAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) A second {#vazawkAra#} or exclama-
<div n="lb">tion at a sacrifice, the first {#vazawkAra#} being intended for the
<div n="lb">principal deity and the {#anuvazawkAra#} for the other deities;
<div n="lb">in the Jyotiṣṭoma, for instance, the Chamasas with the
<div n="lb">juice of the Soma plant are at the {#vazawkAra#} offered to Indra,
<div n="lb">and afterwards at the {#anuvazawkAra#} to the other deities, Mitra
<div n="lb">and Varuna &c. According to the decision of the Mimānsists,
<div n="lb">however, Indra the principal deity, would also have to be
<div n="lb">mentally supplied i. e. to share in the offering made at the
<div n="lb">Anuvaṣaṭkāra. E. {#anu#} and {#vazawkAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>3322<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAkyavat<k2>anuvAkyavat

<L>3323<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAkyA<k2>anuvAkyA
{#anuvAkyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kyA#}) The name of such verses of the
<div n="lb">Ṛgveda as are recited by the priest Hotṛ (q. v.), when the
<div n="lb">deity is invoked by him to partake of the Havis or clarified
<div n="lb">butter. This word is found frequently together with {#yAjyA#}
<div n="lb">(q. v.), the name of those hymns of the same Veda which
<div n="lb">are recited by the Hotṛ when the Havis-oblation is actually
<div n="lb">made. The Anuvākyās are spoken in a slow or as it were
<div n="lb">drawling tone, while the Yājyās are recited quickly. Accord-
<div n="lb">ing to the Mīmānsā no priest but the Hotṛ is allowed to
<div n="lb">recite either of them. Compare also {#puro'nuvAkyA#} and {#yA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jyAnuvAkyA#}. E. {#vac#} with {#anu,#} kṛtya aff. {#Ryat#}.
<LEND>

<L>3324<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAkyAvat<k2>anuvAkyAvat

<div n="lb">accompanied with an {#anuvAkyA#}. Compare {#anuvAkyavat#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#anuvAkyA,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>3326<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAcana<k2>anuvAcana

<div n="lb">the latter to invite the god or gods to partake of a sacri-
<div n="lb">fice, by reciting certain passages from the Ṛgveda. (Com-
<div n="lb">pare {#anuvacana#}.) E. {#vac#} in the caus., with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>3327<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAcanaprEza<k2>anuvAcanaprEza

<div n="lb">tras to partake of the sacrifice.

<div n="lb">ceding) and that of the Adhvaryu to the Maitrāvaruna (q. v.),
<div n="lb">to assign to them their respective portions of the sacrifice.

<L>3330<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAta<k2>anuvAta

<LEND>

<L>3331<pc>102-b<k1>anuvAda<k2>anuvAda
{#anuvAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> Reference or referring to what
<div n="lb">has been previously said, not in the way of a mere repetition
<div n="lb">or tautology, but in that of explanation, detailed comment
<div n="lb">or emphasis; explanatory and corroborative reference, ex-
<div n="lb">planation; e. g. {#BUpariDimAnAnuvAdaH#} ‘a detailed explanation
<div n="lb">with reference to the measure of the earth's circumference
<div n="lb">(mentioned before in the Golādhyāya)’; or, in Manu 2. 53.
<div n="lb">the words {#KAni saMspfSet#} are an {#anuvAda#} to {#nivedya#} &c. 2. 51.,
<div n="lb">because they give a detailed illustration of the general in-
<div n="lb">junction contained in the latter verse. If a word is repeated
<div n="lb">or an expression used which would seem superfluous, be-
<div n="lb">cause not conveying a new notion, such repeated word or
[Page103-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">such expression is {#anuvAda,#} provided a certain purpose be
<div n="lb">connected with it, otherwise it would be sipely {#punarukta#} or
<div n="lb">a meaningless tautology, e. g. {#Gawo GawaH#} or {#GawaH kalasaH#} ‘a
<div n="lb">jar is a jar’ would be a {#punarukta;#} but the repetition of {#paSyet#}
<div n="lb">in Yājnav. 2. 1. from 1. 359. is an {#anuvAdaH#} because it points
<div n="lb">to the connexion between both passages and to the detail
<div n="lb">which is to follow as an illustration of 1. 359.; or in Manu
<div n="lb">1. 72. {#parisaMKyayA#} might be taken as an {#anuvAda#} to {#sahasraM,#}
<div n="lb">because it imparts greater emphasis to the bare numeral.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> In the ritual literature {#anuvAda#} designates those passages
<div n="lb">of the Brāhmaṇa portion of the Vedas, which point to an
<div n="lb">injunction given before ({#viDi#} q. v.) and illustrate it by the
<div n="lb">way of comment, or by entering into greater detail, or by
<div n="lb">adding supplementary rules, but without stating the purpose
<div n="lb">of the injunction itself as the latter would be the object of
<div n="lb">the {#arTavAda#} (q. v.); the {#anuvAda#} being accessory, therefore,
<div n="lb">to the {#viDi#} portion of the Brāhmaṇa and precluded from
<div n="lb">giving independent regulations, the supplementary rites they
<div n="lb">contain are not considered of equal weight and as absolute
<div n="lb">as those of the {#viDi;#} there exists however sometimes a
<div n="lb">difficulty to decide whether a passage of the Brāhmaṇas is
<div n="lb">{#viDi#} or {#anuvAda,#} or in other words whether its injunctions
<div n="lb">are absolute or not, as appears from the discussion of the
<div n="lb">Mīmānsists. (The Nyāya, supported by the commentaries
<div n="lb">on the Mīmānsā, distribute the text of the Brāhmaṇa under
<div n="lb">the three heads of {#viDi, anuvAda#} and {#arTavAda#} qq. vv.; a
<div n="lb">later division makes {#anuvAda#} one of the three categories
<div n="lb">of the {#arTavAda#}.) <sup>3</sup> Report, e. g. {#kutsitArTAnuvAdaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Abuse,
<div n="lb">reviling (? this meaning is given by several dictionaries on
<div n="lb">the authority of the Śabdaratnāvalī, but, to judge from
<div n="lb">the Mss. at my disposal, it would seem to proceed from
<div n="lb">another reading or from a misunderstanding of the passage
<div n="lb">of this work which contains the synonymes of ‘rumour’:
<div n="lb">{#yaTArTAniScitA vArttA BavetsarvajanAtmikA . kutsitArTAnuvAdo#}
<div n="lb">{#vA kiMvadantI janaSrutiH ..;#} the same might be said of the
<div n="lb">meanings ‘abusive reply’ and ‘divulging another's misdeeds’
<div n="lb">which occur also in some dictionaries). E. {#vad#} with {#anu,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#GaY#} or {#anu#} and {#vAda#}.
<LEND>

<L>3332<pc>103-a<k1>anuvAdaka<k2>anuvAdaka
{#anuvAdaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) Being or pro-
<div n="lb">ducing an {#anuvAda#} (q. v.), concurrent, corroborative. E. {#vad#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<L>3333<pc>103-a<k1>anuvAdana<k2>anuvAdana
{#anuvAdana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}). Apparently the same as {#anuvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#cana#} q. v. E. {#vad#} in the caus., with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>3334<pc>103-a<k1>anuvAdanIya<k2>anuvAdanIya
{#anuvAdanIya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Apparently the same as

<LEND>

<L>3335<pc>103-a<k1>anuvAdavacana<k2>anuvAdavacana
{#anuvAdavacana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) A passage of the Brāhmaṇas
<div n="lb">which contains an {#anuvAda#} q. v. E. {#anuvAda#} and {#vacana#}.

<L>3336<pc>103-a<k1>anuvAdin<k2>anuvAdin

<div n="lb">by way of explanation, responding to (comp. {#anuvAda#}).

<div n="P">II. m. ({#-dI#}) (In music.) The name of either of the three

<div n="lb">tones (see {#Sruti#}), viz. the {#zaqja, maDyama#} and {#paYcama#} qq. vv.

<L>3362<pc>104-a<k1>anuveDa<k2>anuveDa
{#anuveDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DaH#}). The same as {#anuvyADa#} q. v. E. In
<div n="lb">following the native lexicographical etym. of {#veDa,#} this word
<div n="lb">would come from {#viD#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY,#} the radical
<div n="lb">{#viD#} assuming in this derivative the meaning of {#vyaD;#} it will
<div n="lb">appear however that the form {#veDa#} in the meaning of {#vyaDa,#}
<div n="lb">and {#anuveDa#} in that of {#anuvyADa#} are objectionable, from a
<div n="lb">gramm. point of view, since {#viD#} does not occur otherwise
<div n="lb">in the meaning “to pierce” and {#veDa#} is not mentioned by
<div n="lb">the best gramm. authorities as a derivative of either {#viD#}
<div n="lb">or {#vyaD#}.
<LEND>

<L>3372<pc>104-b<k1>anuvyAKyAna<k2>anuvyAKyAna
{#anuvyAKyAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) According to the Bṛhadāraṇ-
<div n="lb">yaka-Upan., one of the eight categories or characteristics of
<div n="lb">the text of a Brāhmaṇa; it is defined either as a synonyme
<div n="lb">of {#arTavAda#} q. v. or as a passage of a Brāhmaṇa in which
<div n="lb">short and obscure dicta (or {#sUtra#}) which have occurred in
<div n="lb">another portion of the Brāhmaṇa, are discussed and ex-
<div n="lb">plained. For the other categories comp. {#itihAsa, purARa,#}
<div n="lb">{#vidyA, upanizad, Sloka, sUtra#} and {#vyAKyAna#}. E. {#anu#} and
<div n="lb">{#vyAKyAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>3379<pc>104-b<k1>anuvrata<k2>anuvrata

<div n="lb">devout, faithful.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-taH#}) A Jaina devotee of the first class (the two
<div n="lb">other being the {#mahAvrata#} and the {#nirvARa#} qq. vv.). “To attain
<div n="lb">the rank of Anuvrata one must forsake his family, entirely
<div n="lb">cutting off his hair, throwing away the sacred thread, hold-
<div n="lb">ing in his hand a bundle of peacock's feathers and an earthen
<div n="lb">pot ({#kamaRqalu#}), and wearing only tawny coloured clothes:
<div n="lb">be must reside for some time in one of their temples (As.
<div n="lb">Res. IX. 248).” E. {#anu#} and {#vrata#}.
<LEND>

<L>3380<pc>104-b<k1>anuSatika<k2>anuSatika
{#anuSatika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Followed by one
<div n="lb">or something bought for a hundred. (A derivative of this
<div n="lb">word with taddh. aff. {#aR#} requires Vṛddhi in both parts
<div n="lb">of the compound, see {#AnuSAtika#}) E. {#anu#} and {#Satika#}.
<LEND>

<L>3381<pc>104-b<k1>anuSaya<k2>anuSaya
{#anuSaya#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, attachment; comp.
<div n="lb">{#anuSayin#}. <sup>2</sup> (In the Vedānta philos.) That consequence of
<div n="lb">an act which compels the soul to descend again on earth,
<div n="lb">after she has enjoyed in the other world those consequences
<div n="lb">of her acts which allowed her to soar; that consequence,
<div n="lb">as it were, that cleaves to the soul and does not permit
<div n="lb">her to enjoy freedom from transmigration ({#‘AmuzmikaPale#}
<div n="lb">{#karmajAte upaBukte'vaSizwamEhikaPalaM karmAntarajAtamanuSayaH’#});
<div n="lb">the {#anuSaya#} varies according to its qualities; if it is ‘hand-
<div n="lb">some’ ({#ramaRIya#}) the soul is reborn as a ‘Brāhmaṇa, Ksha-
<div n="lb">triya or Vaiśya’; if it is ‘contemptible’ ({#kapUya#}) it animates
<div n="lb">‘a dog, a hog or a Chānḍāla’. <sup>3</sup> Repentance, regret. <sup>4</sup> Hatred,
[Page105-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">resentment. <sup>5</sup> Deep or intense enmity, enmity which goes
<div n="lb">far in its consequences; e. g. {#SiSupAlo'nuSayaM paraM gataH#}
<div n="lb">(comm.: {#paramanuSayaM kevalaM na saptavyaH kiM tu hantavyaSceti dIrGa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvezaM gataH#}). <sup>6</sup> A certain country or place (? the meaning thus
<div n="lb">rendered in a comm. is {#deSaviSeza#}).
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-yI#}) (In Medicine.) <sup>1</sup> A disease of the feet, a small
<div n="lb">abscess on the upper part, ‘deep, causing little pain, and of
<div n="lb">the natural colour as the limb’. <sup>2</sup> (According to another)
<div n="lb">An abscess on the head ({#mastakopari#}) of the same symptoms
<div n="lb">as described before. E. {#SI#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac;#} the
<div n="lb">femin. in {#I#} would be an anomaly accord. to this etym.
<LEND>

<L>3382<pc>105-a<k1>anuSayavat<k2>anuSayavat
{#anuSayavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Vedānta phil.)
<div n="lb">Having or being fraught with the {#anuSaya#} (q. v. 2.); viz. the
<div n="lb">soul ({#‘kftAtyaye'nuSayavAndfzwasmftiByAM yaTetamanevaM ca’#}). <sup>2</sup> Re-
<div n="lb">penting, regretting. <sup>3</sup> Feeling hatred. <sup>4</sup> Feeling deep ani-
<div n="lb">mosity. E. {#anuSaya,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>3383<pc>105-a<k1>anuSayAna<k2>anuSayAna
{#anuSayAna#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Repenting, re-
<div n="lb">gretting.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-nA#}) One of the female characters described in
<div n="lb">the rhetorical literature; ‘a mistress who is overcome with
<div n="lb">sadness because she apprehends the loss of her lover, either
<div n="lb">on account of the breaking up of their actual meeting place,
<div n="lb">or for fear of not having one in future, or from the con-
<div n="lb">clusion she has arrived at that her husband might find her
<div n="lb">in a place which is not that of his family’.
<div n="P">[3. n. ({#-nam#}) This word occurs in a Pāli inscription
<div n="lb">where it would appear to mean ‘repentance’ or ‘confession’.]
<div n="lb">E. {#SI#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#SAnac#}.
<LEND>

<L>3387<pc>105-a<k1>anuSastra<k2>anuSastra
{#anuSastra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-stram#}) (In Medicine.) A subsidiary in-
<div n="lb">strument or surgical means in general, used either in want
<div n="lb">of the proper instrument or when the patient is afraid of
<div n="lb">the latter; as such are named: bambu ({#tvaksAra#}), crystal,
<div n="lb">glass ({#kAca#}), ruby ({#kuruvinda#}), leeches, fire, alkali ({#kzAra#}),
<div n="lb">the finger nail, and several plants ({#gojI, SePAlikA, SA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kapatra, karIra, bAlANguli#}). E. {#anu#} and {#Sastra#}.

<L>3402<pc>105-b<k1>anuSizwa<k2>anuSizwa

<L>3414<pc>106-a<k1>anuzaNga<k2>anuzaNga
{#anuzaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, conjunction, association,
<div n="lb">attachment (lit. and fig.) e. g. {#(vAriRA) antargalitena manma-#}
<div n="lb">{#TaSiKIsikto'nuzaNgodBavaH#} (comm. {#priyasmaraRAdutpannaH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Tenderness, compassion. <sup>3</sup> Necessary consequence, the
<div n="lb">connexion of a subsequent with a previous act. <sup>4</sup> Gram-
<div n="lb">matical relation, connexion of, or connecting a word of a
<div n="lb">preceding with those of a subsequent passage; e. g. {#kacci-#}
<div n="lb">{#dityasyAnuzaNgaM kecinnecCanti#} as the Schol. observes with re-
<div n="lb">ference to {#kaccit#} in Bhattik. 6. 67 when commenting on 6. 68,
<div n="lb">or in the Mīmānsā: {#anuzaNgo vAkyaparisamAptiH sarvezu tulya-#}
<div n="lb">{#yogitvAt#}. Comp. {#anuzaYjana#}. (Different from {#aDyAhAra#}.)

<div n="lb">nected with certain radicals and dropped in certain deriva-
<div n="lb">tives; e. g. the nasal in {#tfmp, dfmp, SumB, saYj#} &c. E. {#saYj#}
<div n="lb">with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.

<L>3421<pc>106-a<k1>anuzuka<k2>anuzuka
{#anuzuka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) Probably the epithet of a divinity;
<div n="lb">the same as {#Anuzuka#}. (Some read instead of this word {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#sUyaka#} which seems to be wrong, others {#anuzUka#} which is
<div n="lb">doubtful. Compare also {#Anusuka#}.) E. The Gaṇaratnama-
<div n="lb">hodadhi derives {#anuzuka#} from {#anusU#} and {#ka#} (from {#kE#}) with
<div n="lb">a short vowel before {#kaH anuzuvatIti anuzU . taM kAyatIti#}
<div n="lb">{#anuzuka . ke'Ra iti hrasvatve;#} this application, however, of
<div n="lb">Pāṇ. VII. 4. 13. to the etym. given, seems very objectionable.
<LEND>

<L>3425<pc>106-a<k1>anuzwubgarBA<k2>anuzwubgarBA
{#anuzwubgarBA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-rBA#}) The name of a metre in the Ve-
<div n="lb">das; it belongs to the class called {#uzRih#} and consists of
<div n="lb">four Pādas, the first of which contains five and each of the
<div n="lb">three others eight syllables. E. {#anuzwuB#} and {#garBa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3426<pc>106-a<k1>anuzwuB<k2>anuzwuB
{#anuzwuB#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-zwup#}) <sup>1</sup> Speech, in general. <sup>2</sup> A name of
[Page106-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">Sarasvatī. <sup>3</sup> The name of a class of metres which consists
<div n="lb">of 32 syllables and, in the Vedas, is regulated by the number
<div n="lb">of syllables only, in classical poetry by number and quantity.
<div n="lb">In the Vedas the 32 syllables are distributed either in Te-
<div n="lb">trastichs of 8 syllables in each line, or in Triplets of either
<div n="lb">12 + 8 + 12 or 12 + 12 + 8 or 8 + 12 + 12 syllables. For the
<div n="lb">varieties of the Anuṣṭubh in the classical poetry see {#citra-#}
<div n="lb">{#padA, vidyunmAlA, mARavaka#} or {#mARavakAkrIqA, haMsaruta, pramA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RikA#} or {#nagasvarUpiRI#} or {#matallikA, samAnikA#} or {#mallikA,#}
<div n="lb">{#vitAna, tuNgA, kamala, haMsapadI, mAtaNgI, ramBA#} and the metre
<div n="lb">which is most in use but the quantity of which is not so in-
<div n="lb">variable as that of the named varieties viz. the {#Sloka#}. In a
<div n="lb">vaidik hymn the Anuṣṭubh is represented as one of the
<div n="lb">primitive creations, that originated together with the moon;
<div n="lb">according to some Purāṇas it was created from the northern
<div n="lb">mouth of the fourheaded Brahman (m.) together with the
<div n="lb">Atharvaveda, a portion of the Sāmaveda and some hymns
<div n="lb">as well as the Āptoryāma portion of the Jyotiṣṭoma sacri-
<div n="lb">fice; accord. to another Purāṇa from the tendons of Brahman.
<div n="lb">(The Kāsikā considers the vaidik {#anuzwyA#} equivalent to the
<div n="lb">classical instrum. {#anuzwuBA;#} but {#anuzwyA#} is probably an er-
<div n="lb">roneous reading for {#anuzwyA#} q. v.) E. {#stuB#} with {#anu,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#kvip,#} so called according to the Nirukta ‘because it
<div n="lb">follows in praise ({#anuzwoBati#}) with its fourth Pāda the Gā-
<div n="lb">yatrī metre which consists only of three Pādas or stanzas’.
<LEND>

{#anuzwoBana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Praising after, following in praise.

<L>3433<pc>106-b<k1>anuzWAnaSarIra<k2>anuzWAnaSarIra
{#anuzWAnaSarIra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philos.) A
<div n="lb">body which is presumed to be intermediate between the subtle
<div n="lb">body ({#liNgaSarIra#} or {#sUkzmaSarIra#}) and the grosser body ({#sTU-#}
<div n="lb">{#laSarIra#}), composed of the five elements but tenuous or re-
<div n="lb">fined and the vehicle of the subtle body. Comp. {#aDizWAna-#}
<div n="lb">{#SarIra#}. E. {#anuzWAna#} and {#SarIra#}.
<LEND>

<L>3434<pc>106-b<k1>anuzWAnasmAraka<k2>anuzWAnasmAraka
{#anuzWAnasmAraka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) Remind-
<div n="lb">ing of religious ceremonies; said of certain vaidik passages
<div n="lb">which properly do not answer the general definition given
<div n="lb">of a Mantra, but which nevertheless are called so by the
<div n="lb">liturgical authors, because they remind of duties taught or
<div n="lb">explained in a more explicit manner by other Mantras. E.
<div n="lb">{#anuzWAna#} and {#smAraka#}.
<LEND>
[Page107-a+ 56]

<L>3440<pc>107-a<k1>anuzWu<k2>anuzWu
{#anuzWu#}¦ (ved.) I. Tatpur. f. ({#-zWuH#}) Proper order, succession;
<div n="lb">this word occurs only in the instrum. {#anuzWuyA#} which has
<div n="lb">the same meaning as the Avyayībh. E. {#sTA#} with {#anu,#} uṇ. aff. {#ku#}.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-zWu#}) In proper order, in regular succession,
<div n="lb">properly. E. {#anu#} and {#sTu;#} or {#anuzWu#} may be considered, ac-
<div n="lb">cording to the native comm., as a neuter used adverbially,
<div n="lb">when the etym. would be that of I.

<L>3454<pc>107-b<k1>anusanDAtavya<k2>anusanDAtavya
{#anusanDAtavya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) To be connected
<div n="lb">reasonably, to be investigated, to be looked after or inquired
<div n="lb">into. See {#anusanDeya#}. E. {#DA#} with {#sam#} and {#anu,#} kṛtya aff. {#tavya#}.

<L>3455<pc>107-b<k1>anusanDAna<k2>anusanDAna
{#anusanDAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Congruous or suitable con-
<div n="lb">nexion; e. g. {#yaTA vAkyadvayAnusaMDAnasaMpannaM prakaraRaM pfTakpramA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Ram . taTA prakaraRadvayAnusaMDAnasaMpannaH kramaH kuto na mAnaM syAt#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In the Vaiśeṣika phil.) the same as {#upanaya#} of the Nyāya
<div n="lb">phil.; viz. in a syllogism (see {#nyAya#}) which according to the
<div n="lb">native phil. consists of five parts, the fourth part or the appli-
<div n="lb">cation to the terminus major (i. e. the congruous connexion
<div n="lb">of the application with the latter); e. g. in a syllogism ‘<sup>a.</sup> a
<div n="lb">word is perishable (the {#pratijYA#}) <sup>b.</sup> because it is produced
<div n="lb">artificially (the {#apadeSa#}) <sup>c.</sup> all that is produced artificially is
<div n="lb">perishable (the {#nidarSana#}) <sup>d.</sup> now, the word has the proper-
<div n="lb">ties of what is artificially produced <sup>e.</sup> therefore it is perishable
<div n="lb">(the {#pratyAmnAya#} or {#nigamana#})--’ <sup>d.</sup> is the {#anusanDAna#} or in the
<div n="lb">Nyāya the {#upanaya#}. <sup>3</sup> Inquiry, investigation, searching. <sup>4</sup> Close
<div n="lb">or narrow inspection. E. {#DA#} with {#sam#} and {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">searching. E. {#DA#} with {#sam#} and {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#} and
<div n="lb">āgama {#yuk#}.

<L>3492<pc>108-b<k1>anusyUta<k2>anusyUta

<div n="lb">of the Sāmaveda, i. e. upon the mode in which its hymns
<div n="lb">are to be sung’. <sup>3</sup> Uninterrupted, continual. E. {#siv#} with
<div n="lb">{#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>3493<pc>108-b<k1>anusrayAman<k2>anusrayAman
{#anusrayAman#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-mA#}) (ved.) One who does not go
<div n="lb">in a waggon drawn by oxen, one who walks on foot. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#usrayAman#}.
<LEND>

<L>3494<pc>108-b<k1>anusvAna<k2>anusvAna
{#anusvAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) Sonnding in conformity with;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#SabdArToBayaSaktyutTavyaNgye'nusvAnasaMniBe . DvaniH#} &c.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#anuraRana#}. E. {#svan#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>3495<pc>108-b<k1>anusvAra<k2>anusvAra
{#anusvAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (In Grammar.) Literally, an after-
<div n="lb">sound; the name of a nasal sound which always belongs to
<div n="lb">the preceding vowel and according to some is weaker, ac-
<div n="lb">cording to others stronger than the {#anunAsika#} q. v. In
<div n="lb">writing it is marked by a dot over the vowel after which
<div n="lb">it sounds. It shares in the nature as well of consonants as
<div n="lb">of vowels: of consonants, in as much as it has but half a
<div n="lb">measure of time (or {#mAtrA#}) and with another consonant
<div n="lb">makes position: of vowels, by having their properties of
<div n="lb">shortness, length, {#pluti#} q. v., and of being capable of ac-
<div n="lb">centuation. (The vaidik grammarians call the consonants
<div n="lb">and the Anusvāra the ‘body of a syllable’--{#akzarANga#}--.)
<div n="lb">On account of the organ of speech with which it is pro-
<div n="lb">nounced it belongs to the {#nAsikya#} q. v., and on account of
<div n="lb">the mode in which it is uttered to the {#Uzman#} q. v. (see also
<div n="lb">{#mahAprARa#}). If a combined consonant follows an Anusvāra
<div n="lb">the vaidik grammarians want the first consonant of the group
<div n="lb">to be repeated; e. g. {#somAnaM ssvaraRaM#} &c. instead of {#somAnaM#}
<div n="lb">{#svaraRaM#} &c.; this rule, however, is neglected in most of our
<div n="lb">vaidik Mss. and in all referring to the post-vaidik literature,
<div n="lb">although the injunction of the grammarians is doubtless
<div n="lb">founded on correct physiological observation and the system
<div n="lb">of Sanskrit orthography on a correct imitation in writing
<div n="lb">the spoken sound.--At the end of a {#pada#} (q. v.) Anu-
<div n="lb">svāra is a substitute for {#m,#} in the middle of a {#pada#} that of
<div n="lb">{#m#} or {#n;#} at the end of a {#pada#} it is only allowed to occur
<div n="lb">when the {#pada#} does not stand in a pause, and in the middle
<div n="lb">not before any other sound than {#S, z, sa#} and {#h,#} before
<div n="lb">which it is the compulsory substitute. (These rules, too,
<div n="lb">are frequently neglected in spite of the grammatical author-
<div n="lb">ities.) It is compulsory, too, at the end of the {#pada,#} before
<div n="lb">the same letters and {#r#} save a few exceptions as {#samrAj#} or
<div n="lb">when {#h#} is followed by {#m, n#} &c., e. g. {#kiM hmalayati#} or
<div n="lb">{#kimhmalayati, kiM hnute#} or {#kinhnute#} &c. For the interchange
<div n="lb">and the confusion, that prevails in the classical literature,
<div n="lb">between the use of Anusvāra and Anunāsika before {#y,#}
<div n="lb">{#l, v#} see s. v. {#anunAsika#}.--A short syllable followed
<div n="lb">by Anusvāra (which itself as results from the preceding
<div n="lb">statement must always be followed by a consonant) becomes
<div n="lb">of the nature of a long syllable, i. e. it becomes {#guru#} or
<div n="lb">heavy; but though this is the constant case in the Vedas
[Page109-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">and generally in the later literature, it will seem that this rule
<div n="lb">may be departed from at the end of a Pāda, as in the instance
<div n="lb">of the following first Pāda of the Āryā verse: {#aTa lulitapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#tatrimAlaM rugnAsanavARakeSaratamAlam#} &c. where {#trimAlaM#} counts
<div n="lb">for {??} |. ({#‘yadyapi CandaHSAstre sAnusvArasya gurutvamanuSizwaM#}
<div n="lb">{#taTApi taTA pAdAntago'pi veti vacanAttasya laGutvAtpraTama-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAde dvAdaSa mAtrA Bavanti’#}.) E. {#svf#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>3496<pc>109-a<k1>anusvAravyavAya<k2>anusvAravyavAya
{#anusvAravyavAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) An interval (between two
<div n="lb">sounds) caused by the intervention of an Anusvāra. E.
<div n="lb">{#anusvAra#} (in the sense of an instrum.) and {#vyavAya#}.

<L>3539<pc>110-a<k1>anUpa<k2>anUpa
{#anUpa#}¦ I. 1. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-paH-pA-pam#}) Watery, rich in
<div n="lb">water. 2. m. ({#-paH#}) (Used in a comm. of the Rāmāyaṇa also
<div n="lb">as a neuter: {#-pam#}.) <sup>1</sup> A moist country. According to the di-
<div n="lb">vision of the medical Ātreya-Sanhitā one of the three cli-
<div n="lb">mates of India--see besides {#jANgala#} and {#sADAraRa;#} it is
<div n="lb">defined in Wise's Hindu system of Medicine as having much
<div n="lb">water on its surface, being intersected by rivers and irregular
<div n="lb">in its surface, with high mountains and tall trees; the air
<div n="lb">being there cool and the wind temperate; abounding in
<div n="lb">grass, water flowers, geese, ducks, cranes, fish, serpents &c.,
<div n="lb">unhealthy and its inhabitants being fat, indolent and weak.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (ved.) A jar ({#kalaSa#}). <sup>3</sup> The name of a country (mentioned
<div n="lb">f. i. amongst those conquered by Rudradāman, one of the
<div n="lb">Sinha-kings).
<div n="P">2. Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> A buffalo. [<sup>2</sup> Any animal living
<div n="lb">in the water or on shore. <sup>3</sup> The francoline partridge ({#ti-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttiraka#}). <sup>4</sup> An elephant. <sup>5</sup> A frog ({#plava#}). <sup>6</sup> Any shelled
<div n="lb">animal which lives in the water. <sup>7</sup> An amphibious animal.
<div n="lb"><sup>8</sup> A fish. (The last seven meanings are given on the authority
<div n="lb">of several medical authors.)] <sup>9</sup> A proper name, an abbre-
<div n="lb">viation of {#anUpasiMha#} q. v. See {#anUpavilAsa#}. E. {#anu#} and
<div n="lb">{#ap,#} changed, according to Pāṇini, to {#Up,#} samāsānta aff.
<div n="lb">{#a#} (the affix being the same in the Tatpur. and the Bahuvr.,
<div n="lb">according to the Kāśikā), but as regards the change of the
<div n="lb">vowel, it is more probable that {#a#} of {#ap#} has got lost and
<div n="lb">the preceding vowel lengthened by way of compensation,
<div n="lb">analogously to {#samIpa, pratIpa, dvIpa, vIpa#} &c. In {#darBAnUpa#}
<div n="lb">q. v. the {#n#} is not changed to {#R#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) (ved.) Throwing or effusing in re-
[Page110-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">gular succession or according to (scil. one's functions); an
<div n="lb">epithet of the three divinities Parjanya, Vāyu and Āditya
<div n="lb">‘who effuse on the earth (i. e. produce there) rain, cold and
<div n="lb">heat successively or according to their functions’ (accord.
<div n="lb">to Yāska and Sāyaṇa). E. {#vap#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac(?),#}
<div n="lb">but it is better perhaps to assume that this {#anUpa#} means
<div n="lb">originally ‘favourable, propitious’ and comes from {#anu#} and
<div n="lb">{#ap,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}. For the latter etym. see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>3569<pc>111-a<k1>anfta<k2>anfta
{#anfta#}¦ Tatpur. I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Untrue.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) Untruth, falsehood. (In the mythology
<div n="lb">of the Purāṇas Anṛta is the son of Adharma (vice) and
<div n="lb">Hinsā (violence), and the brother of Nikṛti (immorality);
<div n="lb">they intermarry and have two sons, Bhaya (fear) and Na-
<div n="lb">raka (hell) and twins to them, two daughters, Māyā (de-
<div n="lb">ceit) and Vedanā (torture) who became their wives.--In the
<div n="lb">Rāmāyaṇa Anṛta is the name of one of the mystical weapons
<div n="lb">delivered to Rāma by Viśvāmitra.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#fta#}.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-tam#}) Agriculture. E. According to the native comm.
<div n="lb">the etym. would be the same as before; their account for the
<div n="lb">meaning ‘agriculture’ however is not very plausible, some
<div n="lb">explain it: ‘because agriculture is like falsehood’ or ‘because
<div n="lb">agriculture cannot be carried on without falsehood’, another
<div n="lb">refers {#fta#} in this sense to the radical {#f#} ‘to hurt’ and ex-
<div n="lb">plains it as a Bahuvr. ‘that from which injury does not
<div n="lb">arise’. The etym. of this meaning and its probable con-
<div n="lb">nection with {#pramfta#} used in the same sense by Manu will be
<div n="lb">discussed in the Preface.
<LEND>

[Page113-b+ 56]

<L>3651<pc>113-b<k1>anEkAnta<k2>anEkAnta
{#anEkAnta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ntaH-ntA-ntam#}) The same as {#anE-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAntika#} q. v. E. {#a#} neg. and {#EkAnta#}.
<LEND>

<L>3652<pc>113-b<k1>anEkAntika<k2>anEkAntika
{#anEkAntika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) (In Philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Indeterminate, going astray, non-absolute.--In the Nyāya
<div n="lb">and Vaiśeṣika philosophies a quality which constitutes one
<div n="lb">of the five {#hetvABAsa#} (q. v.) or semblances of reason; in the
<div n="lb">Nyāya it is also called {#savyaBicAra#}. A ‘semblance of reason’
<div n="lb">‘goes astray’ or is ‘indeterminate’, if the argument is either
<div n="lb">too general ({#sADAraRa#}) i. e. if it may be applied to the sub-
<div n="lb">ject of conclusion and to an opposite one; e. g. ‘sound is
<div n="lb">eternal, because it is not the object of touch’ or ‘the hearth
<div n="lb">smokes, because it is fiery’; or not general enough ({#asA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAraRa#}) i. e. if it is excluded from either; e. g. ‘sound is
<div n="lb">eternal because it has the properties of sound’; or non-ex-
<div n="lb">clusive ({#anupasaMhArin#}) i. e. if the major may be predicated
<div n="lb">of any other notion; e. g. ‘every thing is eternal because
<div n="lb">it can be measured’ or ‘every thing can be named because
<div n="lb">it can be inferred’. E. {#a#} neg. and {#EkAntika#}.
<LEND>

<L>3653<pc>113-b<k1>anEkAntikatva<k2>anEkAntikatva
{#anEkAntikatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) Indeterminateness, uncertainty, non-
<div n="lb">absoluteness. See the preceding; e. g. {#arTApattirapramARamanE-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAntikatvAt#} or {#‘anuktasyArTApatteH pakzahAnerupapattiranuktatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danEkAntikatvAccArTApatteH’#} or {#duHKasya nivftteradarSanAdanEkA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntikatvam#}. E. {#anEkAntika,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>
[Page114-a+ 56]

<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Want of union, anarchy. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Ekya#}.

<L>3659<pc>114-a<k1>anokaSAyin<k2>anokaSAyin

<L>3660<pc>114-a<k1>anokaha<k2>anokaha
{#anokaha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) A tree. The native E. is very im-
<div n="lb">probable: {#anas-aka#} (going) and {#ha#} ‘because a tree impedes
<div n="lb">the progress of carts’; probably from {#a#} neg. and {#oka#} (in-
<div n="lb">stead of {#okas;#} compare the preceding) and {#ha#} (from {#hA#})
<div n="lb">‘because it does not quit its house’.

<L>3669<pc>114-a<k1>ant<k2>ant(ati-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)
{#ant(ati-BvAdi-udAtta-udAttet)#}¦ r. 1st cl. par. ({#antati-#}
<div n="lb">{#Anat-Ananta-antitA#}.--Caus. {#antayati-Antitat#}.--
<div n="lb">Desid. {#antitizati#}.) To bind. (According to Dhanapāla
<div n="lb">this radical is a provincialism of the Draviḍas instead of
<div n="lb">the classical {#and#} q. v. which occurs also in the variety of
<div n="lb">{#Int;#} Maitreya, Kāśyapa and others admit of both, {#ant#}
<div n="lb">and {#and,#} as classical forms.)
<LEND>

<L>3670<pc>114-a<k1>anta<k2>anta
{#anta#}¦ I. m. ({#-ntaH#}) <sup>1</sup> End. <sup>2</sup> Term, termination; e. g. {#kUpAntaH#}
<div n="lb">‘the bottom of a well’. <sup>3</sup> Limit, boundary, border. <sup>4</sup> A
<div n="lb">place in general (comp. {#antara#}); e. g. {#vanAntaH#} (explained
<div n="lb">as {#vanaBUmi#}) ‘a place in the forest, or the forest-ground’.
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> Part, portion; e. g. {#ekAntA anubanDAH (‘ekAnta ityekadeSo#}
<div n="lb">{#'vayava ityarTaH’)#} ‘anubandhas are essential portions of a word’
[Page114-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(comp. {#anekAnta#}); or {#aTavAyamantaSabdo'styevAvayavavAcI .#}
<div n="lb">{#tadyaTA . vastrAnto vasanAnta iti,#} as Patanjali comments on
<div n="lb">Pāṇini VIII. 4. 20. <sup>6</sup> End, completion; e. g. {#paSubanDAntamaDIte#}
<div n="lb">‘he reads (the work) as far as and inclusive of the chapter
<div n="lb">on the tying of the victim’; or {#svapnAnta#} Tatpur. ‘profound
<div n="lb">sleep’, Bahuvr. ‘in profound sleep’. <sup>7</sup> End of life, death.
<div n="lb"><sup>8</sup> End, separation (comp. {#antara#}); e. g. {#mEtreyIti hovAca#}
<div n="lb">{#yAjYavalkya udyAsyanvA are'hamasmAtsTAnAdasmi . hanta te#}
<div n="lb">{#'nayA kAtyAyanyAntaM karavARIti#} ‘o Maitreyī, quoth Yājna-
<div n="lb">valkya, I am about to leave this place; hence with thy con-
<div n="lb">sent I shall make a separation between (thee and my other
<div n="lb">wife) the daughter of Kātyāyana’. <sup>9</sup> (In Grammar.) The
<div n="lb">final letter of a word. <sup>10</sup> (In Grammar.) The last part of
<div n="lb">a compound. <sup>11</sup> (In Grammar.) A pause. <sup>12</sup> Proximity,
<div n="lb">vicinity; e. g. {#udakAntaM gataH;#} or {#AcAryasya vasedante#}. <sup>13</sup> Pre-
<div n="lb">sence; e. g. {#jAyAyA ante nASnIyAt (= na BAryAdarSane'SnI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAt)#}. <sup>14</sup> Positive conclusion, ascertainment.
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-ntam#}) Nature, disposition, essence.
<div n="P">III. m. n. ({#-ntaH-ntam#}) <sup>1</sup> The last portion, the remainder;
<div n="lb">compare {#antara#}. <sup>2</sup> Last; e. g. {#ante vayasi#} ‘in the last stage
<div n="lb">of life’. [According to a comm. on the Amarak. {#anta#} ‘last’
<div n="lb">remains masc. or neuter even when it is the attribute of a
<div n="lb">feminine ({#‘strIviSezaRatve'pi strIliNgatAnizeDaH . tatra puMna-#}
<div n="lb">{#puMsakaliNgatEva’#}).]
<div n="P">IV. m. f. n. ({#-ntaH-ntA-ntam#}) <sup>1</sup> Lowest, worst. <sup>2</sup> Last born,
<div n="lb">youngest. <sup>3</sup> Near (compare {#antama#} and {#antika#}). <sup>4</sup> Handsome,
<div n="lb">beautiful. (For this last meaning, given on the authority of
<div n="lb">Viśva, the only instance--quoted also by the Śabda-
<div n="lb">muktāmahārṇava--which has occurred to me, is that of
<div n="lb">Māgha's Śiśupālabadha 4. 40. where the last part of the
<div n="lb">compound {#vimalopalameKalAntAH#} is explained by the comm.
<div n="lb">on the authority of the Śabdārṇava {#antAH = ramyAH;#} yet
<div n="lb">as this meaning admits of no connexion with any of the
<div n="lb">other meanings of {#anta,#} it seems preferable to analyze the
<div n="lb">compound in {#ºmeKalA-AntAH,#} when {#Anta#} could be taken
<div n="lb">as the participle (comp. Pāṇini VII. 2. 28.) of {#am ‘saMBaktO’#} in
<div n="lb">the sense of {#Bakta#} ‘attached, served’; and this interpretation
<div n="lb">is the more probable, as the verse in question exhibits a
<div n="lb">permanent punning on words which either may be applied
<div n="lb">to women or to objects of nature, and as {#Anta#} would then
<div n="lb">correspond with {#Bajanti#} in the next line. E. {#am,#} uṇ. aff.
<div n="lb">{#tan#} or according to others, from {#ant,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#} or {#GaY#}.
<div n="lb">Both etym. are not satisfactory; perhaps the origin of {#anta#}
<div n="lb">is in the elements of which the accus. plural is composed;
<div n="lb">see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>3671<pc>114-b<k1>antaHkaraRa<k2>antaHkaraRa
{#antaHkaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) (In Philosophy.) <sup>1</sup> The interior
<div n="lb">sense (also called {#AByantarakaraRa#}) opposed to the {#vAhyakaraRa#}
<div n="lb">(q. v.) or exterior sense; this notion which in general may
<div n="lb">be termed {%‘the faculty of thinking’%} is thus modified in the
<div n="lb">Vedānta and in the Sāṅkhya: <sup>a</sup> (In the Vedānta it implies)
<div n="lb">the notion of what is the general substratum of {#Atman#} or
<div n="lb">Soul (Śaṅkara: {#taccAtmana upADiBUtamantaHkaraRam#}); its activity
<div n="lb">becomes manifest in two of the seventeen {#sUkzmaSarIra#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">or subtle bodies of creation, viz. in the {#budDi#} (q. v.) or that
<div n="lb">mental activity which forms positive conclusions, and in
<div n="lb">the {#manas,#} or that mental activity which ‘discerns and doubts’;
[Page115-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">and as {#citta#} or ‘logical combination’ is involved by the
<div n="lb">activity of {#budDi,#} and {#ahaNkAra#} or ‘self-consciousness’ is in-
<div n="lb">volved by {#manas,#} the activity of the {#antaHkaraRa#} is fourfold,
<div n="lb">viz. as that of {#budDi, manas, citta#} and {#ahaNkAra#}. Śaṅkara in
<div n="lb">his commentary on the Vedānta Sūtras varies slightly in this
<div n="lb">respect by substituting {#vijYAna#} for {#ahaNkAra;#} the difference
<div n="lb">however is merely apparent, {#vijYAna,#} worldly knowledge,
<div n="lb">being also one of the attributes of {#manas#} (Śaṅkara: {#‘antaH-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRaM mano budDirvijYAnaM cittamiti cAnekaDA tatra tatrABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#lapyate’#}). <sup>b.</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya it is not the substratum of {#puruza#}
<div n="lb">or Soul but) the generic name and characteristic of three
<div n="lb">successive productions of {#prakfti#} or Matter, viz. of {#budDi#} ‘as-
<div n="lb">certainment or positive conclusion’, of its product {#ahaNkAra#}
<div n="lb">self-consciousness’ and of the product of Ahaṅkāra, viz.
<div n="lb">{#manas#} which in this philosophy means ‘an organ both of sen-
<div n="lb">sation and of action’ (see {#budDIndriya#} and {#karmendriya#}), ‘the
<div n="lb">organ of volition’ (see {#saNkalpa#}). ‘The ten external organs
<div n="lb">(viz the five organs of sensation and the five of action)
<div n="lb">supply the objects for the ‘interior sense’, their time is the
<div n="lb">present time, while the interior sense embraces the past,
<div n="lb">present and future time’. <sup>2</sup> (In the non-philosophical lite-
<div n="lb">rature where philosophical terms are usually employed in
<div n="lb">a vague manner, this word means) Mind, heart, feeling,
<div n="lb">a synonyme of {#manas#} in its vague, unphilosophical sense;
<div n="lb">e. g. (in a verse of the Mālatīmādhava where an apparent
<div n="lb">show is made of philosophical accuracy) {#premArdrAH praRayaspf-#}
<div n="lb">{#SaH…cezwA Baveyurmayi . yAsvantaHkaraRasya vAhyakaraRavyApA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raroDIkzaRAdASaMsAparikalpitAsvapi BavatyAnandasAndrodayaH#}
<div n="lb">(var. lect. {#ºsAndro layaH#})--E. {#antar#} and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3672<pc>115-a<k1>antaHkaraRavftti<k2>antaHkaraRavftti
{#antaHkaraRavftti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) The activity of the {#antaH-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRa#} q. v. E. {#antaHkaraRa#} and {#vftti#}.
<LEND>

<L>3673<pc>115-a<k1>antaHkalpa<k2>antaHkalpa
{#antaHkalpa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-lpaH#}) A cycle of the Buddhistic era.
<div n="lb">‘From the time that man's age increases from ten years to
<div n="lb">an Asankhya and again decreases from an Asankhya to
<div n="lb">ten years, is an Antaḥkalpa. Were the surface of the earth
<div n="lb">to increase in elevation at the rate of one inch in a 1000
<div n="lb">years and the process to continue in the same proportion,
<div n="lb">the elevation would extend to 28 miles before the Antaḥ-
<div n="lb">kalpa would be concluded. Twenty Antaḥkalpas make an
<div n="lb">Asankhyakalpa. Four Asankhyakalpas make a Mahākalpa.’
<div n="lb">(Hardy, Manual of Buddhism.) E. {#antar#} and {#kalpa#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#kuwila#}.

<L>3688<pc>115-b<k1>antaHpAta<k2>antaHpAta
{#antaHpAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In ritual literature.) A pale
<div n="lb">which is fixed three steps eastward from a large post that
<div n="lb">stands before the {#AhavanIya#} (q. v.) fire in the fore part of
<div n="lb">the {#prAcInavaMSa#} (q. v.), and which thus comes to be placed
<div n="lb">in the middle between the {#Ezwikavedi#} q. v. and the {#mahAvedi#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In vaidik grammar.) A technical name for that Sandhi,
<div n="lb">which, according to some grammarians requires, the in-
<div n="lb">sertion of a {#k#} between a final {#N#} of one word and an initial
<div n="lb">sibilant of a following one (as in {#arvANkCaSvattamam#} instead
<div n="lb">of {#arvAN SaSvattamam#} or {#pratyaNksa#} instead of {#pratyaN sa#}), of a
<div n="lb">{#t#} between a final {#w#} or {#n#} and an initial {#s#} (as in the {#aprAwtsa#}
<div n="lb">instead of {#aprAw sa#} or in {#tAntsam#} instead of {#tAnsam#}), and of
<div n="lb">a {#c#} between a final {#Y#} and an initial {#S#} (as in {#vajriYcCna-#}
<div n="lb">{#Tihi#} instead of {#vajriYSnaTihi#}). E. {#antar#} and {#pAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>3704<pc>116-a<k1>antaHprajYa<k2>antaHprajYa

<L>3705<pc>116-a<k1>antaHpratizWAna<k2>antaHpratizWAna
{#antaHpratizWAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Residing in the interior,
<div n="lb">being in the interior; e. g. in a Pūrvapakṣa of a Sūtra of
<div n="lb">the Vedānta {#SabdAdiByo'ntaHpratizWAnAnna#} (the supreme Lord
<div n="lb">is) not (Vaiśvānara) on account of the “word” (Vaiśvānara
<div n="lb">itself which means fire)--{#SabdastAvat . vESvAnaraSabdo na#}
<div n="lb">{#parameSvare samBavati . arTAntare rUQatvAt#}--, on account of
<div n="lb">“and so on” (the word fire having other distinct appli-
<div n="lb">cations as in sacrificial acts &c.)--and on account of (it
<div n="lb">being said that it has) its residence in the interior (of the
<div n="lb">man, i. e. since it may have the meaning of stomachic or
<div n="lb">fire of digestion, according to the vaidik passage: {#sa yo#}
<div n="lb">{#hEtamagniM vESvAnaraM puruzaviDaM puruze'ntaHpratizWitaM veda sa sarva-#}
<div n="lb">{#trAnnamatti#}). [In the valuable edition of the Ved. Sūtra by
<div n="lb">Dr. Röer the comm. to. 1. 2. 26 is to be read like the native
<div n="lb">edit., viz. {#SabdAdiByo'ntaHpratizWAnAcca . Sabdaºº#}.] E. {#antar#}
<div n="lb">and {#pratizWAna#}.

<L>3724<pc>117-a<k1>antaHsTa<k2>antaHsTa
{#antaHsTa#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. ({#-sTaH-sTA-sTam#}) <sup>1</sup> Being amidst,
<div n="lb">being between, included, comprehended. <sup>2</sup> Being in the
<div n="lb">interior.
<div n="P">II. m. plur. ({#-sTAH#}) (ved.) An epithet of the {#avAYcaH prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAH#} or lower vital organs, viz. of the anus and of the
<div n="lb">organs of generation (as being amongst the vital organs or
<div n="lb">{#prARAH#} in general).
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-sTA#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) An epithet of one of the Sāmi-
<div n="lb">dhenī-Mantras or verses from the Ṛgveda recited at the
<div n="lb">kindling of the sacrificial fire, viz. of the Sāmidhenī which
<div n="lb">begins with the words {#‘agniM dUtaM vfRImahe’,#} because this
<div n="lb">Sāmidhenī is amongst the eleven Sāmidhenīs which praise
<div n="lb">the vital functions, in as much as it praises the {#maDyamaprARa#}
<div n="lb">or the vital function on which rest all the other, i. e. the
<div n="lb">vital energy which resides in the middle of the body. <sup>2</sup> (scil.
<div n="lb">{#devatA;#} ved.) The divinity of the vital organs. [As the
<div n="lb">meanings II. and III. 1. 2. are given on the authority of
<div n="lb">{%Sāyaṇa's%} comm. on the {%Śatapathabr.%} I. 4. 3. 8, it will be ne-
<div n="lb">cessary to quote the latter in full--from two Mss. of the
<div n="lb">E. I. H. and one of the Bodl.--as a so called Extract from
<div n="lb">it, which has appeared in print, is apt to mislead the reader
<div n="lb">completely on the bearing of the word and of the passage
<div n="lb">itself. The comm. runs thus: {#ya evo'yaM maDyamaH prARa iti .#}
<div n="lb">{#prARApAnAdipaYcavfttyASrayaBUto yaH kriyASaktyAtmako dehamaDye#}
<div n="lb">{#'vasTitaH prARaH . tasya saminDanamagniM dUtamityanayA dUto hyagniH#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvezAM devAnAM muKaM ca taTA prARe'pIti#} (v. 1. {#prARImIti#}) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#tena saminDanasyopapattiH . sA hEzAntasTetyAdi . sEzAgniM dUtaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vfRImaha iti sAmiDenI maDyamaprARarUpeRa prARApAnAdi saMstu-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnAnAmanyAsAmfcAmantasTA#} (the Mss. {#saMstuvAnAmaº#} or v. 1.
<div n="lb">{#saMstutAnAmaº#}) {#antaravasTitA Bavati . anye hi prARAScakzuH-#}
<div n="lb">{#SrotrAdayaH . ato'smAtprARAdAraByorDvAScaranti#} (v. 1. {#ºrantI-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti .#}) {#. pAyUpasTayonyo'nye#} (the Mss. {#pAyUpasTayo nye#} or {#ºsTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yonyo#}) {#prARAH . ato'smAnmaDyamAtprARAdevAraByAvAYco'vAN-#}
<div n="lb">{#muKA antaravasTitA Bavanti . evaMvedituH PalamAha . antasTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti . antasTAmantaravasTitAM prARadevatAmityarTaH . ke punarevaM#}
<div n="lb">(Mss. {#ºvAM#}) {#tezAM maDye'vAYco'ntasTAH#} (Mss. {#sTA#}) {#prARA#}
<div n="lb">(v. 1. {#prARAgrA#}) {#iti tAndarSayati#} (Mss. {#tAM daº#}) {#. SocizkeSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#stamImaha#} (I. 4. 3. 9.) {#ityAdinA ..#}. According to this comm.
<div n="lb">the word {#Bavanti (avAYco'ntasTA ha Bavantyaº)#} would have
<div n="lb">moreover to be substituted for {#Bavati (ººha Bavatyaº)#} in the
<div n="lb">presented. of the text, as {#Bavati#} would alter the sense ma-
<div n="lb">terially by disconnecting {#avAYcaH#} and {#antasTAH#}.] <sup>3</sup> (In
<div n="lb">vaidik grammar.) A technical name for the semivowels {#ya,#}
<div n="lb">{#ra, la, va,#} (because their position in the system of the
<div n="lb">grammarians is between the vowels and consonants).
<div n="P">[IV. n. ({#-sTam#}) (In modern terminology, with the Mahrat-
<div n="lb">tas.) Secret expenditure, sums expended in presents and
<div n="lb">bribes to official persons.] E. {#antar#} and {#sTa#}. This word is
<div n="lb">also written, in conformity with a grammatical rule, {#antasTa#}.
<LEND>

{#antaHsTatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The being amongst, the being included
<div n="lb">in or comprehended by. E. {#antaHsTa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.

<L>3728<pc>117-b<k1>antaka<k2>antaka
{#antaka#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ntakaH-ntikA-ntakam#}) Destroying,
<div n="lb">causing death.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ntakaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Yama, the god of Death.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The proper name of a royal Saint whom the Asuras
<div n="lb">threw into a pond and who was rescued by the Aśvins.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> The proper name of a king of the Śuṅga dynasty, a son
<div n="lb">of Vasumitra. (Some read the latter name {#andraka#} or {#Ardraka#}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-ntikA#}) See s. v. {#antikA#} III. E. {#anti,#} denomin.
<div n="lb">of {#anta,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-kaH#}) The same as {#anta#}. E. {#anta,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>3729<pc>117-b<k1>antakadruh<k2>antakadruh

<L>3738<pc>117-b<k1>antaga<k2>antaga
{#antaga#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gaH-gA-gam#}) <sup>1</sup> Going to the end
<div n="lb">(compare {#antacara#}), e. g. {#vAnarAnDarAsamudraSElAnAmantagAn#}
<div n="lb">‘monkeys which go to the end of earth, ocean and moun-
<div n="lb">tains’. <sup>2</sup> Accomplishing a duty or object in view, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#dUragErantagErvAREH#} ‘with arrows which go far and obtain their
<div n="lb">purpose’. <sup>3</sup> Thoroughly conversant with, e. g. {#SAKAntaga#}
<div n="lb">‘well conversant with Mantras and Brāhmaṇas’. <sup>4</sup> Being
<div n="lb">at the end, final (as of a word), e. g. {#akArAkArayorantaga#}
<div n="lb">{#UzmA#} ‘a sibilant which is the final of a word after the
<div n="lb">letters a or ā’. E. {#anta#} and {#ga#} ({#gam,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}).
<LEND>

<L>3745<pc>118-a<k1>antatas<k2>antatas
{#antatas#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> From the end, border &c. <sup>2</sup> On the end,
<div n="lb">border &c. <sup>3</sup> At the end, border &c. <sup>4</sup> At the time of death,
<div n="lb">e. g. {#etamu evAntato'vittvotkrAmati#}. <sup>5</sup> Lastly. <sup>6</sup> At last
<div n="lb">(in phrases implying an order or command); e. g. {#kiMcidapya-#}
<div n="lb">{#DIzva . antataH prajAmavApsyasi#}. <sup>7</sup> Consequently; e. g. {#guRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAn . antataSca me dAsyasi#} (this meaning is probably im-
<div n="lb">plied by the term {#saMBAvanA#} or {#utprekzA#} given in the native dict.
<div n="lb">and Gaṇas). <sup>8</sup> Partly(?). <sup>9</sup> (When opposed to {#muKatas#}
<div n="lb">and {#maDyatas#}.) In the worst manner or in the last stage of
<div n="lb">life (as in a passage of an Upanishad: {#etadvA antato'nnaM#}
<div n="lb">{#rAdDam . antato'smA annaM rADyate#}). <sup>10</sup> In the interior part(?).
<div n="lb">E. {#anta,#} taddh. aff. {#tasi#}.

<L>3747<pc>118-a<k1>antadIpaka<k2>antadIpaka
{#antadIpaka#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kam#}) (In Rhetoric.) One of the
<div n="lb">alaṅkāras or modes of writing or speaking elegantly, a
<div n="lb">variety of the alaṅkāra {#dIpaka#} q. v.; viz. when a variegated
<div n="lb">description reposes on, and is illustrated as it were by, a
<div n="lb">verb which is placed at the end of the sentence. (It would
<div n="lb">seem that the injunction of the principal rhetorical works
<div n="lb">according to which there must be several verbs and but
<div n="lb">one subject in a {#dIpaka#} has not been considered as absolute,
<div n="lb">as results from this instance: {#sa giriM taruzaRqamaRqitaM#}
<div n="lb">{#samavApya tvarayA latAmfgaH . smitadarSitakAryaniScayaH kapisE-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyErmuditEramaRqayat#} where there is but one verb viz. {#amaRqa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yat#} which has the properties required in this {#dIpaka#}. Com-
<div n="lb">pare also {#AdidIpaka, maDyadIpaka, pratIpadIpaka#} and {#mAlAdI-#}
<div n="lb">{#paka#}.) E. {#anta#} and {#dIpaka#}.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>3751<pc>118-a<k1>antama<k2>antama

<L>3752<pc>118-a<k1>antar<k2>antar
{#antar#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, gati, upasarga#}). A particle implying
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> within, in the middle, <sup>2</sup> between, <sup>3</sup> under, in its literal and
<div n="lb">metaphorical acceptations. It is used either adverbially or as
<div n="lb">a separable preposition or as a prefix to verbs and occurs
<div n="lb">also, but seldom, in the sense of a noun. With nouns, if
<div n="lb">preceding them it may form Tatpur., Bahuvr. and Avyayībh.,
<div n="lb">if following them indecl. Tatpur. compounds. It means:
<div n="P">I. (if used adverbially) <sup>1</sup> In the middle, within; mostly
<div n="lb">followed or preceded by a noun in the locat.; e. g. {#apsvanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ramftam#}. <sup>2</sup> In the interior (said of a kingdom &c.); e. g.
<div n="lb">{#laGuvfttitayA BidAM gataM vahirantaSca#}--comm. {#vahirmitrAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#janapadezu . antaramAtyAdizu--nfpasya maRqalam . aBiBUya#}
<div n="lb">{#haratyanantaraH#} &c.). <sup>3</sup> In the mind, in the heart, e. g. {#aByu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dayAnantarasAvaDita mudA nEzaDapriyAnantarasA#}. <sup>4</sup> By way of
[Page118-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">enclosing or seizing, e. g. {#antarhatvA mUzikAM Syeno gataH#}
<div n="lb">(comm. = {#parigfhya#}); comp. III. 1. [This meaning is meant
<div n="lb">by the native Koshas when they render {#antar#} by {#svI-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAre,#} for the Kaśikā interprets Pāṇini I. 4. 65. {#‘parigrahaH#}
<div n="lb">{#svIkaraRam’;#} Mathureśa has probably misunderstood the
<div n="lb">bearing of {#svIkaraRa#} when substituting for the latter word
<div n="lb">the interpretation {#aNgIkftO#}.]
<div n="P">II. (as a separable preposition) <sup>1</sup> Within, <sup>2</sup> Between;
<div n="lb">followed or preceded <sup>a.</sup> by the genitive, e. g. {#tasmAnnAkzyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dityayorantaH parameSvaraH;#} or {#hiraRmayyoH kuSyorantaravahita Asa;#}
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> (ved.) by the accus., e. g. {#rodasI antarurvI#}.
<div n="P">III. (as a prefix to verbs) <sup>1</sup> In the middle, between, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#antarhatya#} ‘having struck in the middle’; compare on the
<div n="lb">contrary {#antarhatvA#} 1. 3. <sup>2</sup> Under (implying disappearance);
<div n="lb">e. g. {#DA#} with {#antar#} to hide, to make invisible, comp. also
<div n="lb">{#antarDi, antarDA#} &c. [The intimate relation between {#antar#}
<div n="lb">and the radical or verb in the latter cases is indicated not
<div n="lb">only by the influence this particle exercises on the meaning
<div n="lb">of the radical and its derivatives, but also by the effect it
<div n="lb">has on the formation of the gerund (comp. {#antarhatvA#} I. 4.
<div n="lb">and {#antarhatya#} III. 1.) and by the change it may produce in
<div n="lb">the dental {#n#} of the radical and its derivation affixes, comp.
<div n="lb">e. g. {#antarayaRa, antarhaRana#} &c.]
<div n="P">IV. (as an indeclinable noun) <sup>1</sup> The interior, any thing
<div n="lb">not belonging to the exterior world, e. g. {#antarvahiriti#}
<div n="lb">{#kAryadravyasya kAraRAntaravacanAdakArye tadaBAvaH;#} or {#Buvo'nta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rUrDvamaDaSca#}. <sup>2</sup> The heart, e. g. {#rAkzama Bakza mAM…antaradAm#}
<div n="lb">{#(= hfdayaM dattavatI)#}. Compare also {#antarvat#} and {#antarA#}.
<div n="P">V. (in composition with nouns) In the middle of, in the in-
<div n="lb">terior of, in the heart of; <sup>1</sup> before the noun: <sup>a.</sup> in Tatpur., e.
<div n="lb">g. {#antarja, antarduzwa;#} in several comp. of this class, it may
<div n="lb">seem as if the latter part depended on {#antar#} in the genitive,
<div n="lb">e. g. {#antaHSarIra#} the interior of the body, {#antarhfdaya#} the
<div n="lb">interior of the heart, but it is more correct to consider
<div n="lb">these interpretations as arising from such as ‘the body
<div n="lb">in its interior &c.’; comp. several comp. beginning with
<div n="lb">{#agra,#} e. g. {#agranaKa, agrahasta#} &c.; the {#n#} is changed to
<div n="lb">{#Ra#} in the Tatpur. {#antarvaRa#} and {#antarayaRa#} qq. vv.; see also
<div n="lb">{#antarIpa#}. <sup>b.</sup> in Bahuvr., e. g. {#antaHsveda, antarvAzpa;#} some-
<div n="lb">times meaning ‘from the interior’, e. g. {#antaHsuKa, antaHprajYa#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>c.</sup> in Avyayībh., e. g. {#antarveSmam, antargiri#}. <sup>2</sup> After the
<div n="lb">noun, in indecl. Tatpur., e. g. {#te nAlikerAntarapaH pibantaH;#} or
<div n="lb">{#jalAntaScandracapalam;#} or {#udarAntaH praviSya;#} in such compounds
<div n="lb">some comm. consider the former part as representing the
<div n="lb">sense of a locative, not of a genitive ({#‘avyayatvAtzazWIsamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sapratizeDaH’#}), others not; e. g. {#saMpravezwumiva yozita IzuH Sli-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyatAM hfdayamizwatamAnAm . AtmanaH satatameva tadantarvartino na#}
<div n="lb">{#Kalu nUnamajAnan#} (comm. {#tezAmizwatamAnAmantarhfdaye#}).
<div n="P">VI. See {#antarA#}. E. {#am,#} uṇ. aff. {#aran#} and āgama {#tuw;#}
<div n="lb">but see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>3753<pc>118-b<k1>antara<k2>antara
{#antara#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram;#} is {#sarvanAman#} q. v. in the
<div n="lb">meanings I. 1. 1. 2. 4. and forms then sing. dat. {#-rasmE#}
<div n="lb">{#-rasyE-rasmE,#} ablat. {#-rasmAt#} or {#-rAt-rasyAH-rasmAt#}
<div n="lb">or {#-rAt,#} genit. {#-rasya-rasyAH-rasya,#} locat. {#-rasmin#}
<div n="lb">or {#-re-rasyAm-rasmin#} or {#-re;#} plur. nomin. {#-re#} or
<div n="lb">{#-rAH-rAH-rARi;#} but in the locat. sing. femin. only
[Page119-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#antarAyAm#} when referring to {#puri;#} see meaning I. 1. 1.)
<div n="P">1. <sup>1</sup> Interior, being in the middle of or between, the
<div n="lb">reverse of {#vAhya;#} e. g. {#AtmA sarvAntaraH;#} or {#aDyAvasAyABimA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nasaMkalpAlocanAni cAntarARi vAhyASca sarve vyApArA Atmani#}
<div n="lb">{#pratizidDAni bodDavyAni#}.--The words {#antaraH SAwakaH,#} plur.
<div n="lb">({#antare#} or {#antarAH SAwakAH#}) mean ‘lower garments’, ac-
<div n="lb">cording to some, ‘of three or four garments that which is
<div n="lb">nearest the body’ (lit. between the body and the exterior
<div n="lb">garment); {#antare#} or {#antarA gfhA#} (comp. {#antaragfha#}) may
<div n="lb">mean either ‘the houses in the interior of a town’, or
<div n="lb">‘those situated outside of the town and inhabited by
<div n="lb">Chāṇḍālas and other low-caste people’. (The apparent
<div n="lb">contradiction between these two meanings arises from the
<div n="lb">interpretation of {#vahiryoga#} in Pāṇ. I. 1. 36. which according
<div n="lb">to the comm. on the Mahābhāṣya may mean ‘connexion with
<div n="lb">an unenclosed place ({#vahis#}), and become applicable to
<div n="lb">what is outside’ or may mean ‘connexion with the exterior
<div n="lb">and then apply to what is interior’. Comp. however I. 2. 4.)
<div n="lb">{#antarA pur#} means ‘a place outside of a town or outside of
<div n="lb">a palace’ ({#pur#} implying according to the comm. on the
<div n="lb">Mahābhāṣya either the interior of a palace or what is
<div n="lb">outside of it; comp. {#antaHpura#}); e. g. {#antarAyAM#} (not {#antara-#}
<div n="lb">{#syAM#}) {#puri vasati;#} but see meaning I. 2. 4. <sup>2</sup> Different from,
<div n="lb">with a noun in the abl., e. g. {#yo'psu tizWannadByo'ntaro…#}
<div n="lb">{#eza ta AtmAntaryAmyamftaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Devoid of(?).
<div n="P">2. <sup>1</sup> Near, proximate (esp. ved.). <sup>2</sup> Similar; comp. also
<div n="lb">{#antaratama#}. <sup>3</sup> Related, dear; e. g. {#ayamatyantaro mama#}. Comp.
<div n="lb">also {#antaratara#}. <sup>4</sup> Exterior. (See the instances under I. 1. 1.
<div n="lb">and compare with {#antare#} or {#ºrA gfhA#} the word {#antevAsin#}
<div n="lb">‘a Chāṇḍāla’.)
<div n="P">II. n. ({#-ram#}) 1. <sup>1</sup> The interior lit. and fig. <sup>2</sup> Interval,
<div n="lb">middle, the space between; e. g. {#aNguleSca kanizWAyA maRi-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDasya cAntare#}. Comp. also {#svarAntara, avagrahAntara#}. <sup>3</sup> A
<div n="lb">distance, space; comp. also {#prAntara#}. <sup>4</sup> A period, e. g. {#mA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAntaradeyam;#} comp. also {#manvantara#}. <sup>5</sup> Occasion, e. g. {#atrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntare#}. <sup>6</sup> Difference, e. g. {#praDAnapuruzAntaram#}. <sup>7</sup> (In Algebra.)
<div n="lb">The difference between two figures, as resulting from sub-
<div n="lb">traction, e. g. {#kAryaH kramAdutkramato'TavANkayogo yaTAsTAna-#}
<div n="lb">{#kamantaraM vA;#} or {#vajrAByAsayorantaram#}. <sup>8</sup> An other manner,
<div n="lb">another way, another kind; in this meaning {#antara#} is
<div n="lb">always the latter part of a compound and will in most
<div n="lb">instances answer our word ‘other’ when preceding the
<div n="lb">noun, the gender of {#antara#} remaining, of course, the same
<div n="lb">i. e. neuter, whatever be the gender of the noun preceding
<div n="lb">it as first part of the compound, e. g. {#arTAntaram, hetvanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ram, budDyantaram, pratijYAntaram#} qq. vv. <sup>9</sup> A species, a va-
<div n="lb">riety, a kind; e. g. {#matsyo mInAntare,#} ‘{#matsya#} means a species
<div n="lb">of fish (viz. the Śapharī)’. <sup>10</sup> A hole, a breach. <sup>11</sup> A weak-
<div n="lb">ness, a deficiency, a failing; e. g. {#antarataH kaliH…#}
<div n="lb">{#antarataH nalasya viviSavAn#} (comm. {#antarataH . CidrataH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>12</sup> The interior in a philosophical sense, the supreme Soul,
<div n="lb">the soul, e. g. {#dfzwvAntaraM jyotirupArarAma;#} the mind, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#sAntaraduHKa#} (comm. {#antaHkaraRaduHKasahita#}). Comp. {#antara-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUruza#}. <sup>13</sup> A surety, a bondsman (‘one who stands between
<div n="lb">the creditor and debtor’). <sup>14</sup> Disappearance(?). See the
<div n="lb">following.
[Page119-b+ 56]
<div n="P">2. <sup>1</sup> End. <sup>2</sup> Destruction, annihilation. (Both meanings
<div n="lb">occur in a Ms. of Ajayapāla viz. {#‘anta’#} and {#‘vinASa’#} besides
<div n="lb">{#‘antarDi’;#} the copy I use, however, is too indifferent
<div n="lb">in this place to be relied upon; the meaning {#vyasana#} which
<div n="lb">is amongst the meanings given in one of the Mss. of the
<div n="lb">Nānārthamañjarī--E. I. H. 2544--may imply the same
<div n="lb">notion but may also coincide with II. 1. 11. ‘a weakness &c.’;
<div n="lb">‘{#ranDre maDye vinAvasre#} (sic; instead of {#vinA'vasare#} which
<div n="lb">would give one syllable too much) {#vyavaDAne'ntarAtmani .#}
<div n="lb">{#bahiryoge'vakASe ca viSeze vyasane'ntaram#}’; but there oc-
<div n="lb">curs a safer trace of the latter meaning in a comm. of
<div n="lb">the Nalodaya (3. 6.) where the various reading {#antaratadvfdDizu#}
<div n="lb">is amongst others explained {#‘antaraM vinASaM tanotIti anta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ratat . tAdfSA vfdDayaH . nalasya fdDayo DanAgamAstezu’#}).
<div n="P">III. See {#antaram#} and {#antareRa#}. E. The native etym. {#anta#}
<div n="lb">and {#ra#} (from {#rA,#} kṛt aff. {#ka#}) has no probability. It seems
<div n="lb">that the meanings arranged under I. 1. and II. 1. are con-
<div n="lb">nected in origin with those of {#antar#} and the meanings under
<div n="lb">I. 2. and II. 2. with the meanings of {#anta,#} the former in the
<div n="lb">lineage of the notions of <sup>a.</sup> within; <sup>b.</sup> 1. in the middle,
<div n="lb">between, 2. interval, 3. difference, 4. breach; <sup>c.</sup> under(?);
<div n="lb">the latter in the lineage of <sup>a.</sup> end, <sup>b.</sup> proximity, <sup>c.</sup> exterior.
<div n="lb">But in the same manner as the meanings of {#anta#} and {#antar#}
<div n="lb">coincide in many respects (comp. also {#antarA#}) as probably
<div n="lb">arising from the same origin, it would appear possible to
<div n="lb">derive {#antara#} (comp. {#antama#}), as well as {#anta#} and {#antar#}
<div n="lb">from a common source instead of assuming that {#antara#} re-
<div n="lb">presents two etym., one from {#anta#} and another from {#antar#}
<div n="lb">See the Preface. [In a Gaṇalist to Pāṇini, {#antara#} occurs
<div n="lb">among the words which as latter parts form Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">pounds with other words depending on them in the sense
<div n="lb">of a locative; but it seems that the reading {#antar,#} which
<div n="lb">is given in the Ganaratnam. and exemplified in its comm.--
<div n="lb">while only mention is made there of the reading {#antara#}--,
<div n="lb">is preferable; see s. v. {#antar#} V. 2.]
<LEND>

<L>3757<pc>119-b<k1>antaraNga<k2>antaraNga

<div n="lb">included, with a noun in the ablative; e. g. {#trayamantaraNgaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrveByaH#} ‘the three (viz. {#DAraRA, DyAna#} and {#samADi#}) are in-
<div n="lb">cluded in the former’ (instruments or parts of the Yoga
<div n="lb">viz. {#yama#} &c.) <sup>2</sup> Essential, indispensable; e. g. {#antaraNgasA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DanAni#} viz. {#SamadamanidiDyAsanAdIni,#} opposed to the ex-
<div n="lb">traneous or unessential {#ASramayajYAdIni#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Grammar.)
<div n="lb">Concerning the essential portion of the {#aNga#} q. v. or base
<div n="lb">of a word, affecting this (and not another portion of the
<div n="lb">word) as a rule, an {#AdeSa,#} an affix &c. See the follow-
<div n="lb">ing.--The reverse of {#vahiraNga#} q. v.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-NgaH#}) A proper name of a minister of Sangrama-
<div n="lb">deva, a king of Kashmir. E. {#antar#} and {#aNga#}.

<L>3759<pc>120-a<k1>antaraNgatara<k2>antaraNgatara
{#antaraNgatara#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) The same as {#vahiraNga#} q. v.,
<div n="lb">i. e. not affecting the essential portion of the base (see {#aNga#}) of
<div n="lb">a word, unessential to it (liter. ‘beyond what affects the es-
<div n="lb">sential portion of the {#aNga#}’); e. g. the Mahābh. in discussing
<div n="lb">on Pāṇ. I. 2. 48. gives the instance {#priyasenAnIkaH#} which is
<div n="lb">apparently in contradiction with the rule, as regards the
<div n="lb">{#I,#} and observes {#antaraNgaM hrasvatvaM . antaraNgataraH kap#} ‘the short-
<div n="lb">ness of the vowel is essential (in the rule) to the {#aNga,#} but
<div n="lb">the affix {#kap#} is unessential to it’; Kaiyy.: {#kap tu samAsavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SezaM bahuvrIhiM nadyuttarapadamapekzata iti vahiraNgaH#} ‘but {#kap#} con-
<div n="lb">cerns only the special Bahuvrīhi compound, the latter part
<div n="lb">of which is a noun of those termed {#nadI,#} hence it is un-
<div n="lb">essential to the base’. E. {#antaraNga,#} taddh. aff. {#tarap#}.
<LEND>

<L>3781<pc>120-b<k1>antarA<k2>antarA
{#antarA#}¦ ind. A particle used adverbially and as a prepo-
<div n="lb">sition. It means.
<div n="P">I. (as adv.) 1. <sup>1</sup> Between. <sup>2</sup> In the mean time. {#antarA-#}
<div n="lb">{#antarA,#} at intervals, now and then; e. g. {#so'patAnakasaMjYo#}
<div n="lb">{#yaH pAtayatyantarAntarA#}.
<div n="P">2. Near, in the neighbourhood, at hand.
<div n="P">II. (as prepos.) preceded or followed by a noun in the
<div n="lb">accusative. 1. Between. 2. Without. E. The native etym.
<div n="lb">{#antar#} and {#i,#} taddh. aff. {#qAc#} is improbable; {#antarA#} is
<div n="lb">more likely the instrum. of {#antar#}. As regards its mean-
<div n="lb">ings compare the remarks under the E. of {#antara#}. Compare
<div n="lb">also {#antareRa#} and {#antaram#}.
<LEND>

<L>3784<pc>120-b<k1>antarAgama<k2>antarAgama
{#antarAgama#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) (In Grammar.) An āgama or
<div n="lb">additional letter which is inserted between two letters; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#v#} when it is inserted between a final {#a#} or {#A#} and a fol-
[Page121-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">lowing non-labial vowel, after {#a#} or {#A#} have become the
<div n="lb">representatives of {#o#} or {#O#}--the native theory being that
<div n="lb">these latter vowels do not become {#av#} and {#Av#} but {#a#} and
<div n="lb">{#A#} before a vowel in general. E. {#antar#} and {#Agama#}.
<LEND>
