<L>3786<pc>121-a<k1>antarAtman<k2>antarAtman
{#antarAtman#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tmA#}) <sup>1</sup> The Supreme Soul (comp.
<div n="lb">{#paramAtman#} and {#puruza#}) as residing in the interior of man, as
<div n="lb">the inward Spirit or individual Soul. In the Upanishads
<div n="lb">the words {#puruza, Atman#} and {#antarAtman#} are often used
<div n="lb">apparently as synonymes, but the term {#antarAtman#} is, more
<div n="lb">especially, appropriated there to the notion of the Supreme
<div n="lb">Soul when it resides, according to their doctrine, in the
<div n="lb">interior of the heart, of a thumb's size ({#‘aNguzWamAtraH pu-#}
<div n="lb">{#ruzo'ntarAtmA sadA janAnAM hfdaye saMnivizwaH’#}); [a devia-
<div n="lb">tion, however, in this respect may be noticed in a passage
<div n="lb">of the same Kaṭha-Upan. which contains also the preceding
<div n="lb">quotation (viz. {#aNguzWamAtraH puruzo maDya Atmani tizWati#})
<div n="lb">where {#puruzaH#} seems to have been considered as distinct
<div n="lb">from {#Atman#} and not residing in the heart, although Śan-
<div n="lb">kara endeavours to effect a reconciliation with the general
<div n="lb">doctrine by interpreting {#Atman#} in that passage by {#SarIra#}].
<div n="lb">--In the Vedānta the notion of the {#antarAtman#} has passed
<div n="lb">into that of the {#jIvAtman#} q. v. In the other philosophies
<div n="lb">the terms {#Atman#} and {#puruza,#} in the sense they assume in these
<div n="lb">phil., have superseded the term {#antarAtman#}.--Manu uses
<div n="lb">the word {#antarAtman#} sometimes in the general sense of {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#tman,#} sometimes in the special sense of {#jIvAtman#} (e. g. {#jI-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasaMjYo'ntarAtmAnyaH sahajaH sarvadehinAm#}); Yājnavalkya, how-
<div n="lb">ever, employs the terms {#Atman#} and {#antarAtman#} as syno-
<div n="lb">nymes to denote the Universal Soul, while he associates
<div n="lb">with {#puruza#} the idea of the manifested or individual Soul ({#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAdirAtmA saMBUtirvidyate nAntarAtmanaH . samavAyo tu puruzo#}
<div n="lb">{#mohecCAdvezakarmajaH;#} comp. also {#mohajAlamapAsyeha puruzo dfSyate#}
<div n="lb">{#hi yaH sahasrakarapannetraH sUryavarcAH sahasrakaH . sa AtmA#} &c.).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In the non-philosophical literature.) Soul, mind, self;
<div n="lb">used in the same sense as {#Atman#}. E. {#antar#} and {#Atman;#}
<div n="lb">or perhaps a Karmadh., {#antara#} and {#Atman;#} comp. e. g.
<div n="lb">{#vapustuzAdiBiH kozEryuktaM yuktyavaGAtataH . AtmAnamantaraM SudDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vivicyAttaRqulaM yaTA ..#}.
<LEND>

<L>3787<pc>121-a<k1>antarAtmezwakam<k2>antarAtmezwakam
{#antarAtmezwakam#}¦ Avyayībh. (In ritual liter.) Between one's
<div n="lb">own self and the bricks, i. e. between the pot ({#uKA#}) that
<div n="lb">contains the impurities of a sacrificer, symbolically repre-
<div n="lb">senting his sins, and the sacrificial bricks consecrated to
<div n="lb">Nirṛti, which are supposed to possess the power of re-
<div n="lb">moving them. E. {#antar#} and the Dwandwa {#Atman-izwakA#}.
<LEND>

<L>3790<pc>121-a<k1>antarABakta<k2>antarABakta

<div n="lb">the time of their application; for the others see s. v. {#aDo-#}

<L>3791<pc>121-b<k1>antarABara<k2>antarABara
{#antarABara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (ved.) Removing intervals,
<div n="lb">filling up chasms; an epithet of Indra. E. {#antara#} and
<div n="lb">{#ABara (= Ahara)#}.
<LEND>

<L>3792<pc>121-b<k1>antarABavadeha<k2>antarABavadeha
{#antarABavadeha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) A body (i. e. the soul)
<div n="lb">after death and previous to its being born again, corre-
<div n="lb">sponding, in some respect, to the western notion of ghosts;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#antarABavadeho hi nezyate vinDyavAsinA;#} also {#antarA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavasattva#} and comp. {#yAtanASarIra#}. E. {#antarA-Bava#} and {#deha#}.
<div n="lb">The word may be considered also as a Bahuvr.
<LEND>

<L>3793<pc>121-b<k1>antarABavasattva<k2>antarABavasattva
{#antarABavasattva#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ttvam#}) (According to one comm.
<div n="lb">also taken as a Bahuvr. masc. {#-ttvaH,#} viz. {#antarABavasattvo#}
<div n="lb">{#guptaprARIti#}.) The same as the preceding. E. {#antarA-Bava#}
<div n="lb">and {#sattva#}.
<LEND>

<L>3794<pc>121-b<k1>antarAya<k2>antarAya
{#antarAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Obstacle, impediment. Comp. {#anta-#}
<div n="lb">{#raya, antarayaRa#}. <sup>2</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya and Yoga philos.) A men-
<div n="lb">tal, moral or physical obstruction by which the mind is ab-
<div n="lb">stracted and the knowledge of the Transcendent prevented
<div n="lb">({#cittavikzepa,#} the reserve of {#cittaprasAdana#}); there are nine,
<div n="lb">viz. sickness, dullness, uncertainty, careless indifference,
<div n="lb">laziness, covetousness, erroneous apprehension, non-at-
<div n="lb">tainment of the ground of meditation and having obtained
<div n="lb">the latter not keeping it (compare {#vyADi, styAna, saMSaya,#}
<div n="lb">{#pramAda, Alasya, avirati, BrAntidarSana, alabDaBUmikatva,#}
<div n="lb">{#anavasTitatva#}); they are accompanied by four kinds of
<div n="lb">pain, viz. fidget, trembling, sighing and farting (comp. {#duHKa,#}
<div n="lb">{#dOrmanasya, aNgamejayatva, SvAsa#} and {#praSvAsa,#} the latter term
<div n="lb">thus explained: {#yatkOkzyaM vAyuM niScArayati sa praSvAsaH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> (In the doctrine of the Jainas.) Obstruction offered to
<div n="lb">those engaged in seeking deliverance and consequent pre-
<div n="lb">vention of their accomplishment of it; one of the four cate-
<div n="lb">gories of mischievous acts (for the others compare {#jYAnava-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRIya, darSanavaraRIya#} and {#mohanIya#}). E. {#antara#} and {#Aya#}
<div n="lb">({#i,#} kṛt aff. {#aR#}).
<LEND>

<L>3795<pc>121-b<k1>antarAyaRa<k2>antarAyaRa
{#antarAyaRa#}.¦ A bad reading for {#antarApaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3796<pc>121-b<k1>antarArAma<k2>antarArAma
{#antarArAma#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-maH#}) One who finds his pleasures
<div n="lb">in his soul or heart (not in worldly objects; comm. {#antare-#}
<div n="lb">{#vArAmaH krIqA yasya na vahiH#}); comp. {#antaHsuKa#}. E. {#antar#}
<div n="lb">and {#ArAma#}.
<LEND>

<L>3797<pc>121-b<k1>antarAla<k2>antarAla
{#antarAla#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> Intermediate space (e. g. be-
<div n="lb">tween the cardinal points of the compass); comp. also
<div n="lb">{#sAntarAla#}. <sup>2</sup> Intermediate time, e. g. {#tadantarAlAnupalabDerahetuH#}
<div n="lb">‘this is no reason (for the eternity of sound) since (sound)
<div n="lb">is not perceived in the time between (the arrival of the
<div n="lb">pupil and the teaching of his Guru)’. <sup>3</sup> Middle, any
<div n="lb">thing between, e. g. {#suKasyApyantarAlanizpatteH#} ‘because also
<div n="lb">pleasure arises amidst pains’. <sup>4</sup> (In Arithmetic.) The
<div n="lb">same as {#antara#}. <sup>5</sup> (In Architecture.) The anti-temple, one
<div n="lb">of the three portions of a {#vimAna#} (see besides {#garBagfha#} and
<div n="lb">{#arDamaRqapa#}); of the four and a half or six parts into which
<div n="lb">the diameter of the whole length of the building, including
<div n="lb">the walls, is to be divided, the {#antarAla#} is to take up one
<div n="lb">and a half or two (acc. to Rām Rāz). E. {#antarA#} and {#la#}.
<LEND>

<L>3814<pc>122-a<k1>antarita<k2>antarita
{#antarita#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Separated, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#ekapadAntarita; bahuyojanAntarita; sPawikAntarita;#} or {#yaTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAgamanantaritAH pitaraH somapITAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Screened by, pro-
<div n="lb">tected by, e. g. {#sArasena svadehAntarito rAjA#}. <sup>3</sup> Impeded,
<div n="lb">obstructed by, e. g. {#yattu samyagupakrAntaM kAryameti viparyayam .#}
<div n="lb">{#pumAMstatrAnupalaByo dEvAntaritapOruzaH;#} or {#saMketitamarTaM boDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yantI Sabdasya SaktyantarAnantaritA SaktiraBiDA nAma#} ‘Abhi-
<div n="lb">dhā is called that power of a word which conveys the
<div n="lb">conventional meaning without being prevented (to do so)
<div n="lb">by any other power which the word may have (viz. the {#lakzaRA#}
<div n="lb">or {#vyaYjanA#})’. <sup>4</sup> Made to disappear, rendered invisible by
<div n="lb">interposition, e. g. {#meGErantaritaH sUryaH;#} or {#parvAntarito raviH;#} or
<div n="lb">{#kuqyAntaritAnupalabDerapratizeDaH#} ‘there is no contradiction (to
<div n="lb">our theory of vision) because we do not perceive what is
<div n="lb">made invisible by the interposition of a wall’. [Of com-
<div n="lb">pounds the latter part of which is {#antara#} in its meaning
[Page122-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">II. 1. 8., a denom. may be formed the past partic. of which
<div n="lb">will have the appearance of being a compound with a
<div n="lb">latter part {#antarita;#} such words however are not com-
<div n="lb">pounds, since the affix {#ta#} belongs to the whole denomin.;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {#suvarRajYAnaM prakArAntaritam#} ‘the rule of alligation
<div n="lb">illustrated by another method’ or in {#KilatvajYAnaprakArAnta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ritapadAnayanayoH karaRasUtram#} ‘a rule to discriminate impos-
<div n="lb">sible cases and to solve the problem by another method (in
<div n="lb">those cases which are possible)’, {#prakArAntarita#} is derived
<div n="lb">from {#prakArAntari,#} denom. of {#prakAra-antara,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.]
<div n="P">2. n.(?) ({#-tam#}) (In Arithmetic.) The same as {#antara(?)#}.
<div n="lb">(The latter is doubtful; it neither occurs in the present
<div n="lb">edition of the Līlāvatī nor in that of the Vījagaṇita.) E.
<div n="lb">{#antari#} (denom.), kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Gone within, into,
<div n="lb">e. g. {#nidrAntarita#} ‘gone into sleep’.
<div n="P">2. n.(?) ({#-tam#}) (In Architecture.) ‘One of the nine
<div n="lb">kinds of mouldings, of a quadrangular form, which enter
<div n="lb">into the composition of pedestals and bases; it has general-
<div n="lb">ly the same altitude with the fillet but as much recession
<div n="lb">as the {#AliNga,#} another kind of moulding, has projection
<div n="lb">over it; both these mouldings are placed alternately to-
<div n="lb">gether and when used, are always thus inseparably con-
<div n="lb">nected (accord. to Rām Rāz). E. {#antar#} and {#ita#}.
<LEND>

<L>3815<pc>122-b<k1>antarindriya<k2>antarindriya
{#antarindriya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) (In the Vedānta philos.) The
<div n="lb">same as {#antaHkaraRa#} q. v. E. {#antar#} and {#indriya#}.
<LEND>

<L>3816<pc>122-b<k1>antarIkza<k2>antarIkza
{#antarIkza#}¦ Tatpur. 1. n. ({#-kzam#}) <sup>1</sup> The intermediate region,
<div n="lb">viz. the region between earth ({#kziti, BU#} or {#pfTivI#}) and
<div n="lb">heaven ({#dyu, dyo#} or {#svar#}); also called {#Buvar;#} the æther or
<div n="lb">atmosphere between both: these three regions or worlds
<div n="lb">being, in the vaidik belief, the residences of the three pri-
<div n="lb">mitive deities, viz Earth of Agni (Fire), Atmosphere of
<div n="lb">Vāyu (Wind) and Heaven of Sūrya (Sun). [{#antarikza#} is
<div n="lb">the ritual name of the following verses of the Sāmaveda:
<div n="lb">1. 239 (= I. 3. 1. 5. 7), 2. 206. 207 (= II. 2. 2. 9, 1. 2), 2. 212. 213 (=
<div n="lb">II. 2. 2. 11), 2. 902. 903 (= II. 7. 2. 7), 2. 1039. 1040 (= II. 8. 2. 12);
<div n="lb">{#antarikzasya lokavratam#} of 1. 169 (= I. 2. 2. 3. 5); {#antarikzasya#}
<div n="lb">{#sarpam#} of the first half of 1. 270 (= I. 3. 2. 3. 8. a.)] <sup>2</sup> Talc
<div n="lb">({#aBraka#}). <sup>3</sup> (In Arithmetic.) A cypher.--Also written
<div n="lb">{#antarikza#} and {#AntarIkza#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of one of the great Ṛṣis who
<div n="lb">in the present Manwantara have arranged the Vedas, the
<div n="lb">Vyāsa of the thirteenth Dvāpara age. <sup>2</sup> A king of the
<div n="lb">family of Ikṣvāku, a son of Kinnara and father of Su-
<div n="lb">varna. E. {%Yāska%} explains {#antarikza#} amongst others as
<div n="lb">{#SarIrezvantarakzayam#} ‘because it resides in the bodies’ and de-
<div n="lb">rives it therefore from {#antari#} (a locat. of {#antar#}) and {#kza#}
<div n="lb">(from {#kzi#}), considering thus {#antarikza#} as the primitive
<div n="lb">and {#antarIkza#} as the later form. {%The comm. of the Amarak.%}
<div n="lb">explain {#antarIkza#} as {#‘antarIkzyate jagadasmin’,#} and {%Sāyaṇa%}
<div n="lb">as {#‘dyAvApfTivyormaDya IkzyamARaM vyoma’,#} the former deriving
<div n="lb">it from {#Ikz#} with {#antar,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#} and taking {#antarikza#}
<div n="lb">as the vaidik and secondary form ({#‘vede tu CAndasaM hrasvatvam’#}).
<div n="lb">The {%Śatapathabr.%} by describing {#‘imAvagre lokAvAsatustayorvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#yatoryo'ntareRAkASa AsIttadantarikzamaBavadIkzaM hEtannAma tataH#}
<div n="lb">{#purAntarA vA idamIkzamaBUditi tasmAdantarikzam’#} takes also
[Page123-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#antarIkza#} as the primitive form and identifies {#antarIkza#} with
<div n="lb">{#antarAkASa ‘AkASa#} being called {#Ikza’#}. The latter etym.
<div n="lb">which coincides in some respect with that of Sāyaṇa &c.
<div n="lb">has the most probability from the circumstance that the
<div n="lb">rad. {#Ikz,#} of which {#Ikza#} would be a deriv., has all the ap-
<div n="lb">pearances of a non-primitive radical (comp. {#Bikz, yakz,#}
<div n="lb">{#Sikz#} from {#Baj, yaj, SAs#}) and of having arisen from
<div n="lb">{#kAS,#} pref. {#A (AkAS),#} while the elision and change
<div n="lb">of {#A#} to {#I,#} in the latter, would have its analogies in the
<div n="lb">change of {#a#} and {#A#} to {#I#} under the influence of a final
<div n="lb">sibilant and an elision in the interior of the word, in {#Ips,#}
<div n="lb">{#jYIps#} &c. from {#Ap,#} the caus. of {#jYA#} &c.
<LEND>

<L>3823<pc>123-a<k1>antare<k2>antare
{#antare#}¦ ind. Amidst, amongst, between. E. The native comm.
<div n="lb">give this word as an ind. and derive it from {#antar#} and {#i,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#vic;#} but it is evidently the locat. of {#antara#}. Com-
<div n="lb">pare the following and {#antarA, antari#}.
<LEND>

<L>3824<pc>123-a<k1>antareRa<k2>antareRa
{#antareRa#}¦ ind. Used as an adverb and as preposition with the
<div n="lb">accusative.
<div n="P">I. (adv.) In the middle.
<div n="P">II. (prepos.) 1. <sup>1</sup> Amidst. <sup>2</sup> During. <sup>3</sup> [With regard to,
<div n="lb">on behalf of..?.] 2. <sup>1</sup> Without. <sup>2</sup> Except. [The comm. of
<div n="lb">Pāṇini restrict the construction of {#antareRa#} with the accus. to
<div n="lb">the meanings {#‘maDye’#} and {#‘vinA’#} rendered II. 1. 1. 2. and 2. 1. 2.,
<div n="lb">thus excluding II. 1. 3. In conformity with this restriction
<div n="lb">Bharata on Amarak. s. v. {#antara#} instances {#tavAntareRarRaM gf-#}
<div n="lb">{#hItam = tvadarTam#} &c. (not {#tvAmantareRaº#}), thus referring
<div n="lb">{#antareRa#} to the noun {#antara,#} not to the preposition. It may
<div n="lb">be observed, moreover, that in the only {%Sanskṛt%} passage
<div n="lb">which is quoted in support of the meaning ‘on behalf of’
<div n="lb">viz. Śakunt. in the beginning of the 5th act, {#‘tadasyA devIM#}
<div n="lb">{#vasumatImantareRa mahadupAlamBanaM gato'smi’,#} the reading given
<div n="lb">by the Calc. ed. and Chézy, but not noticed in its essential
<div n="lb">portion by subsequent editions, viz. {#tadahaM devIM haMsavatI-#}
<div n="lb">{#mantareRa#} &c., would render the passage itself less obscure
<div n="lb">than it is with the word {#vasumatI#} and allow {#antareRa#} to retain
<div n="lb">its legitimate construction in the sense ‘without’: ‘therefore,
<div n="lb">being without the queen Hansavatī (the same as the {#haMsa-#}
[Page123-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#badiA#} named by Vidūṣaka, but omitted in the ed. of
<div n="lb">Chézy, where the name of the queen is {#haMsavatI#}) I have
<div n="lb">incurred blame’. In another passage of the second act (ed.
<div n="lb">Williams p. 81) {#BavantamantareRa#} is explained by one comm.
<div n="lb">{#Bavannimittam#} but, in conformity with Pāṇini, by another
<div n="lb">{#BavanmaDye;#} in the Calc. and Chézy's ed. the words are {#tuha#}
<div n="lb">{#ubari#} and the whole passage is Prākṛt. In some {%Prākṛt%}
<div n="lb">passages of the dramas {#antareRa#} has been used, however,
<div n="lb">in this sense with the accus.] E. The native etym. {#antara#}
<div n="lb">and {#i,#} kṛt aff. {#na#} is improbable; it is the instrum. of
<div n="lb">{#antara#} (Kaiyyaṭa calls it ‘a particle resembling a case’,
<div n="lb">{#viBaktipratirUpakastu nipAtaH#}). For the two categories of
<div n="lb">the meanings v. s. v. {#antara#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">at particular periods. E. {#antar-gaNgA#} and {#mAhAtmya#}.

<L>3864<pc>124-b<k1>antarDAna<k2>antarDAna
{#antarDAna#}¦ Tatpur. 1. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Concealment, covering.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Disappearance, invisibility; also considered as one of the
<div n="lb">forms assumed by Brahman (m.) in the process of creation,
<div n="lb">according to the Bhāgavata Purāṇa. In the Yoga philo-
<div n="lb">sophy it means the capacity of making himself inaccessible
<div n="lb">to the senses, acquired by a Yogin through applying the
<div n="lb">highest degree of meditation to the notions of Shape,
<div n="lb">Sound &c.: {#kAyarUpasaMyamAttadgrAhyaSaktistamBe cakzuHprakASAsaMpra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoge#} (v. 1. {#ºSAsaMyoge#}) {#'ntarDAnam#} ‘Disappearance arises
<div n="lb">from {#saMyama#} (the highest degree of meditation which com-
<div n="lb">prises {#DAraRA, DyAna#} and {#samADi#} qq. vv.) being applied to
<div n="lb">Shape which inheres to Body, since thus the power (or
<div n="lb">possibility) of being seized by that--viz. the eye--is
<div n="lb">stopped and the clearness of vision has ceased to be’; this
[Page125-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">definition, add the commentators, implies also that the
<div n="lb">Yogin becomes inaccessible to the sense of ‘hearing &c.’
<div n="lb">when the same meditation extends to the notion of
<div n="lb">‘Sound &c.’
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-naH#}) A proper name; a son of Pṛthu and the
<div n="lb">father of Havirdhāna; also called {#antarDi#}. E. {#DA#} with
<div n="lb">{#antar,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>3865<pc>125-a<k1>antarDApita<k2>antarDApita
{#antarDApita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Made invisible.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Made irrecognizable; e. g. {#tato nalo virUpo baBUva . nAga-#}
<div n="lb">{#stvAha . janAstvAM na jAnantviti rUpamantarDApitam#}. E. {#DA,#} in
<div n="lb">the caus., with {#antar,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>3874<pc>125-a<k1>antarBAva<k2>antarBAva
{#antarBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) 1. Inclusion, the being included
<div n="lb">or comprehended by; e. g. {#viparyayASaktizu yaTAyogaM DarmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dInAM jYAnavarjamantarBAvaH;#} or {#sarvAkAramahaMkArarahitatvaM vrajanti#}
<div n="lb">{#cet . atrAntarBAvamarhanti dayAvIrAdayastadA#} (viz. by the
<div n="lb">rasas). E. {#BU#} with {#antar,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">2. Interior disposition, inward feeling(?). E. {#antar#}
<div n="lb">and {#BAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>3893<pc>125-b<k1>antaryAmin<k2>antaryAmin
{#antaryAmin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-mI#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Upan. and the oldest
<div n="lb">Vedānta phil.) The supreme Soul as the inward regulator
<div n="lb">of all the phenomena of the material and intellectual world,
<div n="lb">in this and in a future life: {#‘ya imaM ca lokaM paraM ca lokaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvARi ca BUtAnyantaro yamayati’; ‘aDidEvatamaDilokamaDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vedamaDiyajYamaDiBUtamaDyAtmaM ca kaScidantaravasTito yamayitA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntaryAmI’;#} not merely ‘the individual Soul of a divinity, of
<div n="lb">a living being &c.’, but the same as the {#paramAtman; ‘antaryAmya-#}
<div n="lb">{#DidEvAdizu tadDarmavyapadeSAt’…‘tasmAtparamAtmEvAntaryAmI’#}.--
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In the later Vedānta.) Brahman (m.) as creator of the
<div n="lb">world when under the influence of the first Gunā or of the
<div n="lb">cosmical quality of {#sattva#} ‘goodness’; as such however, he
<div n="lb">is not the purest form of Brahman, but inferior to Īśa who
<div n="lb">is freed of all cosmical qualities. <sup>3</sup> (In the Vedānta applied to
<div n="lb">the doctrine of the sects.) <sup>a.</sup> Viṣṇu or Purushottama when be-
<div n="lb">coming human or individual Soul; e. g. {#antaH praviSya BUtAni#}
<div n="lb">{#yo biBartyAtmaketuBiH . antaryAmISvaraH sAkzAtpAtu no yadvaSe#}
<div n="lb">{#sPuwam ..;#} <sup>b.</sup> Śiva. E. {#antar#} and {#yAmin#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {#lamba,#} ‘lit. where the perpendicular falls within’.

<L>3900<pc>126-a<k1>antarvat<k2>antarvat
{#antarvat#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) <sup>1</sup> Occupying the in-
<div n="lb">terior, e. g. of a hall, a house, {#GawaH#} ‘a jar in the interior
<div n="lb">of a hall’; {#antarvatI SAlA#} ‘a hall in the interior of another
<div n="lb">hall’. <sup>2</sup> Probably the same as {#Atmavat#} (comp. the mean-
<div n="lb">ing of {#antar#} IV. 2.), selfpossessed, composed, as in the
<div n="lb">vaidik instance {#pumAnantarvAntsTaviraH payasvAnvasoH kabanDamf-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaBo biBarti;#} (it has been proposed somewhere to translate
<div n="lb">{#antarvat#} in this instance ‘pregnant’).
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-tnI;#} in the Vedas also {#-vatI#}) A pregnant woman.
<div n="lb">[As the instance {#antarvatI SAlA#} has been taken from the
<div n="lb">Kāśikā on Pāṇ. IV. 1. 32, it is necessary to observe that
<div n="lb">Bhaṭṭojidīkṣsta in the Prauḍhamanor. rejects this forma-
<div n="lb">tion together with the counter-instance {#pativatI#} in the same
<div n="lb">rule: {#‘yattu prAcAntarvatI pativatIti pratyudAhftaM tadayuktam’#}.]
<div n="lb">E. {#antar,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#} and āgama {#nuk#}.

<L>3908<pc>126-a<k1>antarvAvat<k2>antarvAvat
{#antarvAvat#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-van-vantI-vat#}) (ved.) Con-
<div n="lb">cealed, hidden; {#antarvAvadakfRojjyotizA tamaH#} ‘he has hidden
<div n="lb">darkness with light’. E. {#vA,#} in the intens., with {#antar,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) (ved.) Endowed with trea-
<div n="lb">sures or with sons, cattle &c. in its interior; {#antarvAvatkzayaM#}
<div n="lb">{#daDe#} ‘he possesses a dwelling abounding internally with
<div n="lb">treasures or with sons &c.’. E. {#antarvA,#} taddh. aff. {#matup;#}
<div n="lb">Sāyaṇa explains {#antarvA#} as meaning liter. ‘going within,
[Page126-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">being within, belonging to’ and thus assuming the sense of
<div n="lb">treasure &c.; he makes it optional, however, to consider
<div n="lb">in the latter instance {#antarvAvat#} as representing also {#anta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rvAvad,#} when the word would come from {#antar#} and {#vAvad#}
<div n="lb">‘speaking much’ the intens. of {#vad,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip,#} the
<div n="lb">sense remaining the same, but the word being then a
<div n="lb">Tatpurusha.
<LEND>

<L>3926<pc>126-b<k1>antarhita<k2>antarhita

<div n="lb">e. g. {#yUni cAntarhite'prAptiH#} scil. {#caturTAdinA;#} or {#udAtta-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvaM niyataM vivfttyA vyaYjanena ca svaryate'ntarhitam#}. <sup>2</sup> Covered,
<div n="lb">e. g. {#ayastaptaM tu pARiByAmarkapatrEstu saptaBiH . antarhitaM haran#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Concealed, hidden, e. g. {#AyAtena daSAsyasya saMsTito#}
<div n="lb">{#'ntarhitaSciram#}. <sup>4</sup> Disappeared, vanished away, e. g. {#vraja#}
<div n="lb">{#suKamAyAhInaSrIrityantarhitaH SamAyAhInaH#}.-- E. {#DA#} with
<div n="lb">{#antar,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>
[Page127-a+ 56]

<L>3951<pc>127-b<k1>antAvasAyin<k2>antAvasAyin
{#antAvasAyin#}¦ m. ({#-yI#}) <sup>1</sup> A Chāṇḍāla, a man of a Śūdra
<div n="lb">father and Brāhmaṇī mother. <sup>2</sup> A barber. <sup>3</sup> The name
<div n="lb">(probably a nickname) of a Muni. Comp. {#antyAvasAyin#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anta#} and {#avasAyin#} ({#so#} with {#ava,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}) acc.
<div n="lb">to the native explanation ‘because he has the business of
<div n="lb">finishing off the end sc. of the nails i. e. of paring them’;
<div n="lb">but more probably ‘one who is engaged in the lowest (cf.
<div n="lb">{#anta#} IV. I.) occupations’. This word is therefore not con-
<div n="lb">nected with {#antevAsin#} q. v. An incorrect reading is {#antA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vaSAyin#}.
<LEND>

<L>3952<pc>127-b<k1>anti<k2>anti
{#anti#}¦ I. ind. Near, in the proximity of, before, in the pre-
<div n="lb">sence of. E. According to the native etym. an abbreviation of
<div n="lb">{#antika;#} but more probably arising from a common origin
<div n="lb">with {#anta;#} see the Preface.
<div n="P">II. denom. parasm. ({#-ntayati#}) To make an end of, to
<div n="lb">destroy. E. {#anta,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-ntiH#}) (In theatrical language.) An elder sister.
<div n="lb">E. An abbrevation of {#antikA#}.
<LEND>

<L>3953<pc>127-b<k1>antika<k2>antika
{#antika#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Near, proximate. Comp.
<div n="lb">{#anta, antara, antama, anti, antikatama, antitama, antiya,#}
<div n="lb">{#antya#}.--The words {#nedIyas#} and {#nedizWa#} are considered
<div n="lb">as the comparative and superl. of {#antika#}.--In the dramas
<div n="lb">{#janAntikam#} ‘what is spoken apart to a person so that none else
<div n="lb">may hear’ is opposed to {#svagatam#} ‘what is spoken to one's self’.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-kam#}) Vicinity, neighbourhood. [{#antikAt#} forms
<div n="lb">Tatpur. compounds with a following kṛt formation in {#kta#}
<div n="lb">(i. e. with a past participle), e. g. {#antikAdAgata;#}--such
<div n="lb">a word being a compound, because it has but one accent--;
<div n="lb">{#antikam, antikena, antikAt#} and {#antike#} are, besides in
<div n="lb">their literal acceptations, used like prepositions with a noun
<div n="lb">following or preceding in the genit. or ablat.; e. g. {#antikaM#}
<div n="lb">{#grAmasya#} or {#grAmAt#} ‘near a village’. The correctness of
<div n="lb">the restriction enjoined by some grammarians, not to com-
<div n="lb">bine the ablat. {#antikAt#} with a noun in the ablat., is de-
<div n="lb">nied by Patanjali and his comm.; comp. the instance s. v.
<div n="lb">{#dUra.--antikAt#} (lit. from the vicinity of) occurs also
<div n="lb">in the sense of ‘from’, much in the same manner as the
<div n="lb">ablat. {#sakASAt;#} e. g. {#krIRIyAdyastvapatyArTaM mAtApitroryama-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntikAt . sa krItakaH#} &c.; or {#nAparADnIdiyaM kiMcidaBraSyatpatyu-#}
<div n="lb">{#rantikAt#}. NB. Words like {#keSAntika, nAsAntika, grahaRA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntika, AmaraRAntika, prARAntika#} are not compounds of
<div n="lb">{#keSa, nAsA#} &c. and {#antika,#} but deriv. with taddh. aff. {#Wan#}
<div n="lb">of {#keSAnta, nAsAnta#} &c.] E. {#anta#} or {#anti,#} taddh. aff. {#Wan#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-kA#}) A fire place, a furnace. Also {#antI#} and
<div n="lb">{#andikA#}. E. The native comm. derive it from {#ant,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#Rvul#} ‘because it connects with itself the cooking uten-
<div n="lb">sils’; but though a similar ellipsis is implied by its synon.
<div n="lb">{#aDiSrayaRI,#} the same notion might be obtained by con-
<div n="lb">necting its etym. with that of {#antika#}.
<div n="P">III. f. ({#-kA#}) The name of a plant (Echites scholaris),
<div n="lb">a decoction of which is used for one of the urinary dis-
<div n="lb">eases. E. Perhaps from {#anti#} II., denom. of {#anta,#} kṛt aff.
[Page128-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#Rvul,#} the fem. of {#antaka;#} compare its synonyme {#SAtalA#}
<div n="lb">(probably from the caus. of {#Sad#}).
<div n="P">IV. f. ({#-kA#}) (In theatrical language.) An elder sister,
<div n="lb">the same as {#attikA#} of which it seems to be, like {#artikA,#}
<div n="lb">a degenerated form.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#antika#} and {#gati#}.

<L>3960<pc>128-a<k1>antikASraya<k2>antikASraya

<div n="lb">that given by a tree to a creeper &c. <sup>2</sup> The house of a
<div n="lb">neighbour (according to Hemachandra's Abhidh. 4. 67. (=
<div n="lb">v. 1001), where the two words {#upaGna#} and {#antikASraya#} are
<div n="lb">explained by Vallabhagaṇi: {#pAqosIGaranAmnI dve;#} but the
<div n="lb">quotation added by this comm. from Raghuvanśa 14. 1. would
<div n="lb">rather refer to the first meaning than qualify a house, as
<div n="lb">seems required by the context in which these words occur
<div n="lb">in Hemachandra). E. {#antika#} and {#ASraya#}.

<L>3975<pc>128-b<k1>antisumna<k2>antisumna

<L>3978<pc>128-b<k1>antevAsa<k2>antevAsa

<div n="lb">{#vAsin#}. E. {#ante#} (locat. of {#anta#}) and {#vAsa#}.
<LEND>

<L>3979<pc>128-b<k1>antevAsi<k2>antevAsi
{#antevAsi#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. In the condition of a pupil
<div n="lb">(lit. in the condition of one whose habitation is near, scil.
<div n="lb">the Guru). E. {#ante#} (locat. of {#anta#}) and {#vAsa,#} samās. aff.
<div n="lb">{#ic#}. [This word is thus explained by the Gaṇaratnamaho-
<div n="lb">dadhi: {#ante vAso'sminniti antevAsi tizWati;#} with the
<div n="lb">additional remark concerning the meaning, and to prevent
<div n="lb">its identification with the neuter of {#antevAsin,#} viz. {#ante-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAsI gurorityeByaSca . sa Sabdo'nte vasati tacCIla iti Ri-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyantaH#} (cf. Pāṇini III. 2. 78.) sic.]
<LEND>

<L>3980<pc>128-b<k1>antevAsin<k2>antevAsin
{#antevAsin#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-sI-sinI-si#}) Living, or
<div n="lb">being in, or on, the end or confines.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-sI#}) <sup>1</sup> A pupil in general (the same as {#Sizya#}),
<div n="lb">e. g. {#vESampAyanAntevAsin#} [bases in {#f#} when compounded
<div n="lb">with it as former parts of a Tatpur., retain in the com-
<div n="lb">position the sign of the genitive, e. g. {#hoturantevAsin, pitu-#}
<div n="lb">{#rantevAsin#}]. <sup>2</sup> An apprentice, one who is learning a
<div n="lb">mechanical art (according to Nārada, distinct from the {#Sizya#}
<div n="lb">who is to him the theological student, and one of the four
<div n="lb">categories of the {#karmakara#} q. v.; compare besides {#Sizya, Bftaka#}
<div n="lb">and {#aDikarmakft#}).--Both 1. and 2 so called from it being
<div n="lb">their duty to live near i. e. in the house of the Guru:
<div n="lb">{#‘AcAryasya vasedante kftvA kAlaM suniScitam . AcAryaH Sikza-#}
<div n="lb">{#yedenaM svagfhe dattaBojanam’#}. <sup>3</sup> A Chāṇḍāla (q. v.), a man of
<div n="lb">the lowest tribe (so called because he must live outside of
<div n="lb">a town; comp. {#antara#} I. 1). [In a Prākṛt passage of the
<div n="lb">Mālatīmādhava {#antevAsinI#} occurs in the sense of a female
<div n="lb">pupil: {#sAhakassa muRqaDAriRI aDoraGaRwaRAmaDeassa ante-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAsiRI mahAppahAvA karAlakuRqalA RAma#}.] E. {#ante#} (locat.
<div n="lb">of {#anta#}) and {#vAsin#}.
<LEND>

<L>3981<pc>128-b<k1>antodAtta<k2>antodAtta

<div n="lb">accent on the last syllable.

<div n="P">2. m. f. n. ({#-ttaH-ttA-ttam#}) Pronounced with the udātta
<div n="lb">accent on the last syllable. E. {#anta#} and {#udAtta#}.
<LEND>

<L>3982<pc>129-a<k1>antodAttatva<k2>antodAttatva

<div n="lb">with the udātta accent on the last syllable. E. {#antodAtta,#}
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>3983<pc>129-a<k1>antya<k2>antya
{#antya#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-ntyaH-ntyA-ntyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Last, ultimate. (In the
<div n="lb">Vaiśeṣika philos., {#antyo viSezaH#} is called ‘the ultimate
<div n="lb">degree of particularity or divisibility, which is the condition
<div n="lb">of eternal substances only’, viz. the condition of simple,
<div n="lb">non-compound substances, of atoms, since there is an end
<div n="lb">of discrimination when this last degree of elementary
<div n="lb">existence has been arrived at; compare also {#antyAvasTiti#}.)
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Final (as the letter of a word). <sup>3</sup> Nearest, e. g. {#navAntya#}
<div n="lb">nearest to nine i. e. ten. Comp. {#antima#} and the words
<div n="lb">named s. v. {#antika#}. <sup>4</sup> Inferior, lowest, belonging to the
<div n="lb">lowest tribe (see the following meanings). [Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">pounds--not Karmadh.--the latter part of which is
<div n="lb">{#antya#} have the udātta accent on the first syllable.]
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ntyaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A man of the lowest tribe. See {#antyaja#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> A Mlechchha or foreigner. See {#antyaja#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Astronomy.)
<div n="lb">The twelfth or last lunar month, called Phālguna. <sup>4</sup> A
<div n="lb">fragrant grass (Cyperus rotundus). See {#mustA#}. <sup>5</sup> m. pl.
<div n="lb">({#-ntyAH#}) The name of a people or country; read also {#anDAH#}
<div n="lb">or {#anDrAH#} or {#aDyAH#}.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-ntyA#}) <sup>1</sup> A woman of the lowest tribe. See {#antyaja#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In Astronomy) thus defined: {#ahorAtravfttavyAsArDaM trijyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tulyEraNkEraNkyate tAvattrijyAtulyaM Bavati tEraNkEryAvatkujyA gaRyate#}
<div n="lb">{#tAvaccarajyAtulyA Bavati . aTa carajyayA trijyA yutonA antyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMjYA Bavati#} (Siddhāntaśir. Gaṇitādhy. ed. Calc. p. 128).
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-ntyam#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Arithm.) A measure of number,
<div n="lb">a thousand billions (1000,000,000,000,000). <sup>2</sup> (In Astronomy.)
<div n="lb">The last or twelfth sign ({#lagna#}) of the Zodiac, the Pisces
<div n="lb">or {#mInarASi#}. See {#antyaBa#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Astronomy.) The last or
<div n="lb">twenty seventh mansion in the circumference of the moon's
<div n="lb">periodical revolution, the Nakshatra Revatī, the Yoga star
<div n="lb">of which is <lang n="greek"></lang> Piscium. See {#antyaBa#}. E. {#anta,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>3984<pc>129-a<k1>antyaka<k2>antyaka
{#antyaka#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) The same as {#antya#} q. v., e. g.
<div n="lb">fem. 3. 2. {#hftistrimOrvyA carajIvayA vA hatA dyumOrvyA kzitijIva-#}
<div n="lb">{#yA vA . BaktAntyakA syAdaTavAntyakAyA hftirguRacCedaviparyayeRa#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) A man of the lowest tribe; see {#antyaja#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#antya,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>3986<pc>129-a<k1>antyakriyA<k2>antyakriyA

<L>3987<pc>129-a<k1>antyagodAna<k2>antyagodAna
{#antyagodAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The giving away of a cow
<div n="lb">immediately after the performance of the main ceremony
<div n="lb">of an anuṣṭhāna in expiation of crime. E. {#antya#} and
<div n="lb">{#godAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>3988<pc>129-a<k1>antyaja<k2>antyaja
{#antyaja#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Latest born,
<div n="lb">youngest (? comp. {#antaja#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-jaH#}) A man of the lowest tribe; the same
<div n="lb">as {#antya#}.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-jA#}) A woman of the lowest tribe; the same as
<div n="lb">{#antyA#}. [This word (2. and 3.) is explained in various ways.
<div n="lb">{%Vijnāneśvara%} identifies it sometimes with {#cARqAla,#} in other
[Page129-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">places he and {%Kullūka%} explain it {#cARqAlAdi#} ‘Chāṇḍāla
<div n="lb">and so on’. Of more distinct definitions the following may
<div n="lb">be noticed: that of {%Yama,%} who comprises under the term
<div n="lb">{#antyajAH#} a washerman, a worker in leather, a dancer, a
<div n="lb">Varuḍa, a fisherman, a Meda or attendant on women, and
<div n="lb">a Bhilla ({#rajakaScarmakAraSca nawo varuqa eva ca . kEvartameda-#}
<div n="lb">{#BillASca saptEte hyantyajAH smftAH#}); of {%Samvarta,%} who com-
<div n="lb">prises under it a washerman, a hunter, an actor, a flute-
<div n="lb">player and a worker in leather ({#rajakavyADaSElUzaveRucarmopa-#}
<div n="lb">{#jIvinAm#} &c.); of {%Āpastamba,%} who enumerates a Chāṇḍāla,
<div n="lb">a Meda, a Śvapacha or Śvapāka (the son of an Ugrā woman
<div n="lb">by a Kshattriya male) and a man who belongs to the Kāpā-
<div n="lb">lika worshippers of Śiva ({#cARqAlamedaSvapacakapAlavratacAri-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAm#} &c.); of another lawbook which names, a Chāṇḍāla, a
<div n="lb">Pukkaśa, a Mlechchha, a Śvapāka and a man who has be-
<div n="lb">come an outcast ({#cARqAlaM puzkasaM mlecCaM SvapAkaM patitaM taTA#}).
<div n="lb">In a similar manner {%Śātātapa%} speaks of {#antyajA#} women as
<div n="lb">of {#kEvartI rajakIM cEva veRucarmopajIvinIm;#} {%Āpastamba%} as of
<div n="lb">{#mlecCI nawI carmakArI rajakI varuqI taTA,#} and {%Uśanas',%} ‘wife
<div n="lb">of a man who eats the food of a Kāpālika’ ({#kApAlikAnna-#}
<div n="lb">{#BoktFRAM tannArIº#}) refers probably also to the {#antyajA#}.--
<div n="lb">Halayudha who calls the Śūdra {#antyavarRa,#} enumerates the
<div n="lb">following under the head of {#antajAti#} (the same as {#antyaja#}):
<div n="lb">{#‘antAvasAyI caRqAlo nizAdaSca jalaNgamaH . SvapacaH pukkaSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScEva mAtaNgaH plavagaH smftaH .. kirAtAH SabarA nizWyAH pulindA#}
<div n="lb">{#nAhalA BawAH mAlA mlecCAdayo BillAH kaTyante hyantajAtayaH’#}.]
<div n="lb">Comp. {#antyajanman#} and {#antyajAti#}. E. {#antya#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>3989<pc>129-b<k1>antyajagamana<k2>antyajagamana

<div n="lb">tribes). E. {#antyaja#} and {#gamana#}.
<LEND>

<L>3994<pc>129-b<k1>antyajAtitA<k2>antyajAtitA

<L>3995<pc>129-b<k1>antyaDana<k2>antyaDana
{#antyaDana#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-nam#}) (In Arithmetic.) The last term
<div n="lb">of an arithmetical progression; comp. {#maDyaDana#} and {#sarvaDana;#}
<div n="lb">e. g. {#vyekapadaGnacayo muKayuksyAdantyaDanaM muKayugdalitaM tat .#}
<div n="lb">{#maDyaDanaM padasaMguRitaM tatsarvaDanaM gaRitaM ca taduktam#} ‘the in-
<div n="lb">crease multiplied by the period less one and added to the
<div n="lb">first quantity is the amount of the last; that added to the
<div n="lb">first and halved, is the amount of the mean: which multi-
<div n="lb">plied by the period is the amount of the whole, and is de-
<div n="lb">nominated the computed sum’. E. {#antya#} and {#Dana#}.
<LEND>

<L>3996<pc>129-b<k1>antyapada<k2>antyapada
{#antyapada#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-dam#}) (In Arithmetic.) The last or
<div n="lb">greatest root in the affected square; also called {#antyamUla,#}
<div n="lb">{#jyezWapada, jyezWamUla#} and opposed to the {#Adyapada#} or {#AdyamUla,#}
<div n="lb">{#kanizWapada#} or {#kanizWamUla#} ‘the least or first root’. These terms
<div n="lb">are thus explained after Brahmagupta by Colebrooke; ‘the
[Page130-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">least or first root: that quantity of which the square multi-
<div n="lb">plied by the given multiplicator and having the given ad-
<div n="lb">dend added, or subtrahend subtracted, is capable of af-
<div n="lb">fording an exact square root; the greatest or last root:
<div n="lb">the square root which is extracted from the quantity so
<div n="lb">operated upon’. E. {#antya#} and {#pada#}.
<LEND>

<L>3997<pc>130-a<k1>antyaPalajyA<k2>antyaPalajyA
{#antyaPalajyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-jyA#}) (In Astronomy.) The excen-
<div n="lb">tricity or the sine of the greatest equation of the centre of
<div n="lb">a planet. E. {#antya-Pala#} and {#jyA#}.
<LEND>

<L>3998<pc>130-a<k1>antyaBa<k2>antyaBa
{#antyaBa#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-Bam#}) (In Astronomy.) <sup>1</sup> The last sign
<div n="lb">of the Zodiac, the sign Pisces. <sup>2</sup> The last or twenty seventh
<div n="lb">mansion in the circumference of the moon's periodical re-
<div n="lb">volution, the Nakshatra Revatī, the Yoga star of which
<div n="lb">is <lang n="greek"></lang> Piscium. Compare {#antya#} 4. E. {#antya#} and {#Ba#}.
<LEND>

<L>3999<pc>130-a<k1>antyamUla<k2>antyamUla

<L>4004<pc>130-a<k1>antyavarRa<k2>antyavarRa

<L>4005<pc>130-a<k1>antyavipulA<k2>antyavipulA
{#antyavipulA#}¦ Karmadh. ({#-lA#}) The name of a metre regulated
<div n="lb">by quantity, a species of the Āryā and a variety of the
<div n="lb">Vipulā; it consists of two lines with 30 mātrās or (71/2) feet
<div n="lb">in the first and 27 mātrās or (71/2) feet in the second line,
<div n="lb">the pause in the first being after the 12th mātrā or 3<sup>d</sup> foot,
<div n="lb">in the second placed otherwise. Compare {#AdivipulA#} and
<div n="lb">{#uBayavipulA#}. E. {#antya#} and {#vipulA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4006<pc>130-a<k1>antyastrI<k2>antyastrI

<div n="lb">and {#strI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4007<pc>130-a<k1>antyAnuprAsa<k2>antyAnuprAsa
{#antyAnuprAsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) (In Rhetoric.) Alliteration of
<div n="lb">the final single or combined consonant together with its
<div n="lb">vowel, or as the case be, with its Anusvāra and Visarga;
<div n="lb">rhyme; one of the five varieties of {#anuprAsa#} q. v. It may
<div n="lb">occur either at the end of a Pāda, or at the end of words
<div n="lb">in the middle of a Pāda. E. {#antya#} and {#anuprAsa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4008<pc>130-a<k1>antyABigamana<k2>antyABigamana

<L>4009<pc>130-a<k1>antyAyana<k2>antyAyana

<L>4010<pc>130-a<k1>antyAvasAyin<k2>antyAvasAyin
{#antyAvasAyin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yI#}) A man of a degraded tribe,
<div n="lb">the offspring of a Niṣādī woman by a Chāṇḍāla male. Ac-
<div n="lb">cording to Angiras this term comprehends seven classes, viz.
<div n="lb">{#cARqAla, Svapaca, kzattf, sUta, vEdehaka, mAgaDa#} and {#Ayogava#}
<div n="lb">qq. vv.; Vijnāneśvara applies it to Chāṇḍālas and men who
<div n="lb">have become outcastes in general: {#‘cARqAlapatitAdInAm’#}.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#antAvasAyin#} and {#antyaja#}. E. {#antya#} and {#avasAyin#}
<div n="lb">lit. ‘engaged in the lowest occupations’.
<LEND>
[Page130-b+ 56]

<L>4011<pc>130-b<k1>antyAvasTa<k2>antyAvasTa
{#antyAvasTa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-sTaH-sTA-sTam#}) Being in reduced
<div n="lb">circumstances; e. g. {#antyAvasTo'pi mahAnsvAmiguRAnna jahAti#}.
<div n="P">II. Karmadh. f. ({#-sTA#}) Destruction, death; e. g. {#yatnAdra-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzansusTitatvAdanASaM niScityAnyaScetasA BAvitena . antyAvasTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAlayogyopayogaM daDre'BIzwaM nAgamApadDanaM vA .#}. E. {#antya#} and
<div n="lb">{#avasTA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4012<pc>130-b<k1>antyAvasTiti<k2>antyAvasTiti
{#antyAvasTiti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) The size of the Soul when,
<div n="lb">according to the Jaina doctrine, it has become liberated
<div n="lb">and thus arrived at a final i. e. atomistic state or one of
<div n="lb">indivisibility and eternity; or the established condition of
<div n="lb">the atomistic and consequently eternal size of the Soul,
<div n="lb">when it has attained its final state. (Compare {#antya#} 1. 1.) Śan-
<div n="lb">kara gives both interpretations of this word in the Vedānta
<div n="lb">Sūtra which alludes to the Jaina theory of the atomistic
<div n="lb">nature of the Soul: {#‘antyAvasTiteScoBayanityatvAdaviSezaH’#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#antya#} (in the sense of the genitive, scil. {#jIva#}) and {#ava-#}
<div n="lb">{#sTiti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4013<pc>130-b<k1>antyAhuti<k2>antyAhuti
{#antyAhuti#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-tiH#}) A funeral sacrifice. Comp.
<div n="lb">{#antyezwi#}. E. {#antya#} and {#Ahuti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4018<pc>130-b<k1>antra<k2>antra
{#antra#}¦ 1. n. ({#-ntram#}) and according to one author. also m. ({#-ntraH#}).
<div n="lb">An intestine (mostly used in the plur. {#antrARi#}); e. g.
<div n="lb">{#antrEH kalpitamaNgalapratisarAH…piSAcANganAH;#} or {#AttasnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#GvantranetraH#} (a. v. l. instead of {#ArttaH paryastanetraH#} in the Mā-
<div n="lb">latīm. ed. Calc. p. 78). According to Suśruta ‘the entrails
<div n="lb">of a male are three fathoms and a half long, those of a
<div n="lb">female half a fathom less’ ({#sArDatrivyAmAnyantrARi puMsAM strI-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAmarDavyAmahInAni#}). Charaka divides them in {#sTUlAntra#} and
<div n="lb">{#kzudrAntra,#} ‘the large and small intestines’. [The definition
<div n="lb">given by Vijnāneśvara (on Yaju. 3. 94.): {#kzudrAntraM hftsTAntram#}
<div n="lb">is probably therefore to be rendered ‘{#kzudrAntra#} are the entrails
<div n="lb">which are nearer the heart’, while the {#sTUlAntra#} are near
<div n="lb">the anus; comp. Suśruta: {#‘vAtavarconirasanaM sTUlAntrapratibadDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#gudaM nAma marma’#}. The {#sTUlAntra#} in taken also by Vijnān. (on
<div n="lb">Yajn. 3. 96.) in the usual sense, since he writes {#sTUlAntragu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dodarARi prasidDAni#} ‘the three words of the text {#sTUlAntra,#}
<div n="lb">{#guda#} and {#udara#} require no remark’.]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-ntrI#}) The name of a potherb (Convolvulus ar-
<div n="lb">genteus). [In the passage of the Amarak. {#CAgalAntryAvegI#}
<div n="lb">some comm. divide {#CAgala-antrI-AvegI,#} others make a
<div n="lb">compound of the two first; comp. also {#ajAntrI#}.] E. {#am,#}
<div n="lb">uṇ. aff. {#ktra;#} accord. to another author. uṇ. aff. {#zwran#}. Pro-
<div n="lb">bably, however, a contraction of {#antara,#} like {#avasra#} of {#avasara#}.
<LEND>

<L>4041<pc>131-b<k1>anD<k2>anD(anDa-curAdi-parasmEpadin)

<L>4042<pc>131-b<k1>anDa<k2>anDa
{#anDa#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-nDaH-nDA-nDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Blind; lit. and figur. <sup>2</sup> Mak-
<div n="lb">ing blind, obstructing the sight (as darkness &c.).
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-nDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Darkness. <sup>2</sup> Water; see also {#kabanDa#} and
<div n="lb">{#kamanDa#}. <sup>3</sup> Turbid water, foul water. <sup>4</sup> (In Astronomy.) The
<div n="lb">same as {#antya(?)#}.
<div n="P">3. m. pl. ({#-nDAH#}) The name of a people or country;
<div n="lb">also read {#anDrAH, antyAH#} or {#aDyAH#}. E. The native etym.
<div n="lb">‘{#anD,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}’ might apply to all the meanings but
<div n="lb">the first; for that of {#anDa#} ‘blind’ see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>4043<pc>131-b<k1>anDaka<k2>anDaka
{#anDaka#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-nDakaH-nDikA-nDakam#}) Blind. E. {#anDa,#} taddh. aff. {#ka#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) A proper name of: <sup>1</sup> a demon, a son of
<div n="lb">Kaśyapa and Diti ‘with thousand arms and heads, two
<div n="lb">thousand eyes and feet and called Andhaka because he walked
<div n="lb">like a blind man although he saw very well’; in his attempt
<div n="lb">of taking a Pārijāta tree of the Swarga he was slain by
<div n="lb">Śiva (see {#anDakaGAtin, anDakaripu#}); <sup>2</sup> a grandson of Kroṣṭṛ,
<div n="lb">and son of Yuddhājita, who together with his brother Vṛṣṇi
<div n="lb">is the ancestor of the celebrated family of the Andhaka-
<div n="lb">Vṛṣṇis; <sup>3</sup> a grandson of Vṛṣṇi (the brother of Andhaka)
<div n="lb">and son of Śvaphalka by Gāṇḍinī; <sup>4</sup> a son of Sattwat, be-
<div n="lb">longing to the same family, by Kauśalyā; <sup>5</sup> a son of Bhīma
<div n="lb">(of the same family) and father of Revata. [The forgoing
<div n="lb">lineage, 2--5, is taken from the Harivanśa. In the Linga
<div n="lb">Purāṇa an Andhaka is a son of Nahusha who, according
<div n="lb">to other Purāṇas, is the ancestor of Kroṣṭṛ; in the Kūrma
<div n="lb">Purāṇa an Andhaka is a son of Anśa and father of Sāttvata,
<div n="lb">while in the Viṣṇu P. a prince of that name is mentioned
<div n="lb">as the son of Sāttvata who is apparently the same as the
<div n="lb">Sattwat of the Hariv.] <sup>6</sup> The name of a Muni (in the Padma-
<div n="lb">purāṇa).
<div n="P">3. m. plur. ({#-kAH#}) The descendants of Andhaka (2. 2),
<div n="lb">(usually mentioned together with the Vṛṣṇis; see {#anDaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfzRi#}), apparently the ancient inhabitants of Berar.
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-nDikA#}) <sup>1</sup> Night. <sup>2</sup> A kind of play or gambling.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> A disease of the penis (? the same as {#sarzapI#} q. v.). <sup>4</sup> A
<div n="lb">diseased eye. <sup>5</sup> A woman. [The two latter meanings from
<div n="lb">the Śabdaratnāvalī, where the word is thus explained: {#anDikA#}
<div n="lb">{#rajanI nArI dyUtaBede'kzRi dUzite#}.] E. {#anDa,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4044<pc>131-b<k1>anDakaGAtin<k2>anDakaGAtin

<div n="lb">dhaka q. v., an epithet of Śiva. Comp. the following. E.
<div n="lb">{#anDaka#} and {#GAtin#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">of Andhaka q. v.). Comp. the preceding and {#anDakAri,#}
<div n="lb">{#anDakAsuhfd#}. <sup>2</sup> A name of Sun, Fire and Moon, figur., as

<L>4048<pc>132-a<k1>anDakavartakIya<k2>anDakavartakIya
{#anDakavartakIya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) As in the fable of the
<div n="lb">blind man and the quail; viz. when the blind man put his
<div n="lb">feet over the quail ({#‘anDakasya vartakAyA uparyantaHpAdanyAsa#}
<div n="lb">{#ucyate . tattulyamanDakavartakIyam’#}); said, according to another

<div n="lb">compare similar expressions as {#kAkatAlIya, KalvAwavilvIya,#}

<L>4050<pc>132-a<k1>anDakavfzRi<k2>anDakavfzRi

<L>4051<pc>132-a<k1>anDakAra<k2>anDakAra
{#anDakAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-raH-ram#}) Darkness; lit. and fig. E.

<L>4052<pc>132-a<k1>anDakAraprAyaScitta<k2>anDakAraprAyaScitta
{#anDakAraprAyaScitta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ttam#}) A penance mentioned in
<div n="lb">the Varāha-Purāṇa, to atone for the offence of approaching,
<div n="lb">in the dark, the image of Viṣṇu in his incarnation as a
<div n="lb">boar, without a lamp and without the Śāstra; such an offence
<div n="lb">degrading the offender and exposing him to becoming blind:
<div n="lb">the penance consists in veiling the eyes during fifteen days,
<div n="lb">taking only one meal on the following twentieth day and
<div n="lb">one meal on each twelfth day of the half of a month, and
<div n="lb">when the penitent is half dead in consequence of such diet,
<div n="lb">sitting in the water and ultimately eating a dish of barley
<div n="lb">and rice cooked in cow's urine. He is promised to be rid
<div n="lb">then of his crime. Another reading of this word is {#anDakA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raspfzwaprAyaScitta#}. E. {#anDakAra#} and {#prAyaScitta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4053<pc>132-a<k1>anDakAramaya<k2>anDakAramaya
{#anDakAramaya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yI-yam#}) Quite darkness, perfectly
<div n="lb">dark. E. {#anDakAra,#} taddh. aff. {#mayaw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4054<pc>132-a<k1>anDakArasaYcaya<k2>anDakArasaYcaya
{#anDakArasaYcaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) Complete darkness (lit. a
<div n="lb">collection of darkness, the negation, as it were, of ‘a col-
<div n="lb">lection of sun-rays; e. g. {#yato yato yato yato ravermarIcisaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#cayaH . mahAnDakArasaMcayastatastatastatastataH#}). E. {#anDakAra#} and {#saYcaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4055<pc>132-a<k1>anDakAraspfzwaprAyaScitta<k2>anDakAraspfzwaprAyaScitta

<L>4057<pc>132-a<k1>anDakArita<k2>anDakArita

<div n="lb">dicate that the word is udātta on the last syllable; which it
<div n="lb">would not be if {#anDakArita#} were analyzed (as it really ought

<L>4059<pc>132-a<k1>anDakAsuhfd<k2>anDakAsuhfd

<div n="lb">compound to become {#anDatamasa;#} it occurs however in the fol-

<div n="lb">{#yasarga#}) and comprehended in the eleven defects of the senses

<L>4066<pc>132-b<k1>anDatAmisra<k2>anDatAmisra
{#anDatAmisra#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-sram#}) (Literally: great darkness
<div n="lb">and hence) <sup>1</sup> A division of Tartarus, accord. to Manu the
<div n="lb">second, accord. to Yājnav. the eighteenth of the twenty-
<div n="lb">one hells (see {#naraka#}). <sup>2</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) A
<div n="lb">technical term denoting one of the five subdivisions of the
<div n="lb">{#viparyaya#} (q. v.) which is one of the four divisions of the
<div n="lb">{#pratyayasarga#} (q. v., the creation of mental conditions or con-
<div n="lb">ditions leading to an affection of the {#budDi#} q. v.), the {#vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#paryaya#} comprising the purely negative conditions or those
<div n="lb">opposed to the understanding of the true principles of cre-
<div n="lb">ation; among the latter {#anDatAmisra#} is the mental condition
<div n="lb">of excessive grief, arising when a man who has placed his
<div n="lb">happiness in the pleasures which may be derived from either
<div n="lb">of the ten provinces of the ten senses (see {#indriya#}) or from
<div n="lb">the possession of either of the eight superhuman faculties
<div n="lb">(see {#ESvarya#}), looses the exercise of the latter or dies in the
<div n="lb">midst of the enjoyments of the former. E. {#anDa#} and {#tAmisra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4068<pc>132-b<k1>anDapUtanA<k2>anDapUtanA
{#anDapUtanA#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-nA#}) A female imp or devil, one of
<div n="lb">the nine evil spirits which are supposed to possess children
<div n="lb">and to work in them diseases generally believed to be in-
<div n="lb">curable (see {#graha#}); she is imagined ‘of formidable size, tawny,
<div n="lb">bald and wearing yellow-red garments’. Compare the fol-
<div n="lb">lowing. E. {#anDa#} and {#pUtanA#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">arrhœa, hiccough, vomiting and fever, has a bad colour,
<div n="lb">sleeps on the ground and smells sour’. E. {#anDapUtanA#} and {#Artta#}.

<L>4085<pc>133-a<k1>anDra<k2>anDra
{#anDra#}¦ 1. m. pl. ({#-nDrAH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a people or country in
<div n="lb">the Dekhan, probably the northern part of the modern Te-
<div n="lb">lingana. Comp. {#AnDra#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of a dynasty; see {#anDraBftya#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-nDraH#}) A man of low caste: the offspring of a
<div n="lb">Vaideha father and a Kārāvara mother; he lives by killing
<div n="lb">game and is not allowed to reside within a village or town,
<div n="lb">but must live under Chaitya-trees, in cemeteries, on moun-
<div n="lb">tains or in forests; (according to Manu, who embodies in
<div n="lb">this manner the Andhra-aborigines into the Brahmanical
<div n="lb">system). Compare also {#AnDra#}. E. unknown.
<LEND>

<L>4088<pc>133-a<k1>anDraBftya<k2>anDraBftya
{#anDraBftya#}¦ Karmadh. m. pl. ({#-tyAH#}) The name of a dynasty of
<div n="lb">Andhra kings, apparently of low origin, thirty kings of
<div n="lb">which are said to have reigned four hundred and sixty-six
<div n="lb">years, the last in the year 431 or 435 after Chr. E. {#anDra#}
<div n="lb">and {#Bftya#} (an Andhra by caste and a servant by occupation).
<LEND>

<L>4089<pc>133-a<k1>anna<k2>anna
{#anna#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) Eaten. [The use of this word,
<div n="lb">as a past participle of {#ad,#} is restricted, according to He-
<div n="lb">machandra's Dhātupārāyaṇa, to such passive constructions
[Page133-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">as correspond with our use of a past partic.; but while
<div n="lb">{#jagDa#} may be substituted for {#anna#} also in these cases,
<div n="lb">{#jagDa#} alone is admissible when ‘eaten’ is used either sub-
<div n="lb">stantively with a genitive depending on it or impersonally;
<div n="lb">‘{#adyarTAcceti vADAre#} ({#ADAra#} is here equivalent to {#aDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRa#} of Pāṇ. III. 4. 76.) {#kte . idamezAM jagDam .. pakze karmaRi#}
<div n="lb">{#kte . jagDamannam .. BAve . jagDamanena ..#}’.]
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-nnam#}) <sup>1</sup> Food in general, eatable or drinkable;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#annaM pitfmanuzyeByo deyamapyanvahaM jalam#} (comm.: {#annagrahaRaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sakalAdanIyapradarSanArTam#}); or {#annamizwaM havizyaM ca dadyAdakro-#}
<div n="lb">{#Dano'tvaraH#} (comm.: {#annaM BakzyaBojyalehyacozyapeyAtmakaM paYca-#}
<div n="lb">{#viDaM dfzwam#}); also elliptically, the eating of food, e. g. {#sarvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nnAnumatiSca prARAtyaye taddarSanAt;#} comp. also {#annakAla, anna-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAnarakzA#} &c. In the post-vaidik literature, an exalted eulo-
<div n="lb">gium of food as the supporter of creation is given e. g. in the
<div n="lb">Anuśāsanaparvan of the Mahābhārata v. 3204--3251 and 5541
<div n="lb">--5562; comp. also {#annada#}. <sup>2</sup> (In the Upanishads and the Vedānta
<div n="lb">philos.) Food in a metaphysical or mystical sense, the essence
<div n="lb">of the elementary creation, that of which the coarsest sheath
<div n="lb">or the coarse body of the Supreme Soul (see {#annamayakoSa#}
<div n="lb">and {#sTUlaSarIra#}) is framed: the lowest and therefore not
<div n="lb">truest form in which Brahman (n.) or the Supreme Soul
<div n="lb">(comp. {#annabrahman#}) manifests itself in its worldly and con-
<div n="lb">scious existence ({#‘ye'nnaM brahmopAsate’; ‘annaM brahmetyeka Ahu-#}
<div n="lb">{#stanna’;#} see also {#annaja#}). Compare besides {#prARa, manas, vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#jYAna, Ananda#}. In this form the Supreme Soul is also called
<div n="lb">{#vESvAnara, virAj, viSva#} and {#jAgrat#} qq. vv., e. g. {#annaM vE virAw;#}
<div n="lb">or {#sEzA virAqdaSasaMKyA satyannaM cAnnAdinI ca#}. The process of
<div n="lb">this manifestation is thus imagined in the Taittirīya Upanishad:
<div n="lb">in the Supreme Soul originates æther, in æther air and so
<div n="lb">on in each preceding element successively fire, water, earth,
<div n="lb">herbs, food, from which comes semen and man; in food
<div n="lb">originate, too, all other creatures living on this earth ({#‘a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nnAdvE prajAH prajAyante yAH kASca pfTivIM SritAH . aTo'nnenEva#}
<div n="lb">{#jIvanti . aTEnadapi yantyantataH . annaM hi BUtAnAM jyezWaM tasmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tsarvOzaDamucyate’#}). In the Vedānta the theory of this primi-
<div n="lb">tive developement is more intricate; comp. s. v. {#annamayakoSa#}.
<div n="lb">(In the Aitareya Upan. food is represented as a being of
<div n="lb">organised form sprung forth from the heated waters, the
<div n="lb">process of creation differing materially from that imagined
<div n="lb">by the Taittirīya and the Vedānta.) <sup>3</sup> (The latter meaning
<div n="lb">applied in the doctrine of the Viṣṇuites to) Viṣṇu. <sup>4</sup> (ved.)
<div n="lb">Water. <sup>5</sup> Corn in general (comp. {#sarvOzaDa#} under meaning 2.).
<div n="lb"><sup>6</sup> Boiled rice. [In the two last meanings {#anna#} is used also
<div n="lb">as a term of contempt; when combined with {#man#} cl. 4. in
<div n="lb">this sense, it depends on the latter in the accusative (not
<div n="lb">in the dative as similar terms, e. g. {#tfRa, busa, Svan#} &c. also
<div n="lb">may); e. g. {#na tvAnnaM manye yAvadBuktaM na SrAdDam#} ‘not so much
<div n="lb">as a grain or a grain of boiled rice &c.’ (but {#na tvA tfRaM,#}
<div n="lb">{#busaM, SvAnaM#} or {#tfRAya, busAya, Sune manye#}); for similar terms
<div n="lb">comp. also {#nO, kAka, Suka, SfgAla#}.] <sup>7</sup> A soup or sauce made
<div n="lb">of flesh; see {#annaprASana#}. <sup>8</sup> A soup or sauce made of rice; see
<div n="lb">s. v. {#annamala#}. <sup>9</sup> Spirituous liquor made of rice; see s. v. {#annapeya#}
<div n="lb">and {#annamala#}. E. {#ad,#} uṇ. aff. {#kta;#} the native gramm. assign
<div n="lb">to {#anna#} in the meaning ‘boiled rice’, and probably also in
<div n="lb">the other meanings, the uṇ. aff. {#na#} which is {#nit#}. The Tait-
[Page134-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">tirīya-Upan. explains {#anna#} 2. 2. thus: {#adyate'tti ca BUtAni#}
<div n="lb">{#tasmAdannaM taducyata iti .#} ‘because it is eaten and because it
<div n="lb">eats what exists i. e. because what exists becomes again {#anna#}’.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-nnaH#}) The sun. E. According to an Uṇṇādisūtra
<div n="lb">as quoted in the Siddh. Kaum. and in Nṛsinha's Swara-
<div n="lb">mañjarī {#at,#} uṇ. aff. {#na;#} acc. to Hemach.'s Dhātupārāyaṇa,
<div n="lb">{#am (uRRAdO damyamIti ne . annaH),#} uṇ. aff. {#na#}.
<LEND>

<L>4093<pc>134-a<k1>annakUwayAtrA<k2>annakUwayAtrA
{#annakUwayAtrA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-trA#}) The festival of the mountain
<div n="lb">of boiled rice; a festival of the Hindus in the month of
<div n="lb">November when they make a pile of boiled rice as a type
<div n="lb">of the hill Govardhana in Vraja, near Mathurā, upheld by
<div n="lb">Kṛṣṇa for the shelter of the milkmaids. It is called also
<div n="lb">Govardhanapūjā and observed especially by cowherds. E.
<div n="lb">{#annakUwa#} and {#yAtrA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4098<pc>134-a<k1>annaja<k2>annaja
{#annaja#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Produced by food
<div n="lb">or by the essence of the elementary creation; e. g. {#kaTamannajo#}
<div n="lb">{#'nnAtmA'nnapralayo'haM tasmAdannaM brahmeti#} ‘how (is it that men
<div n="lb">adore Brahman under the form of {#anna?#} it is when they think:)
<div n="lb">I am the product of {#anna,#} I have the nature of {#anna,#} I shall
<div n="lb">be merged again into {#anna,#} therefore {#anna#} is Brahman’.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-jam#}) (In Medicine.) Water in which rice has
<div n="lb">been boiled, rice gruel. E. {#anna#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {#jala;#} ‘rice and water’.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">promises to a man who gives food, eternal happiness; Yā-
<div n="lb">jnavalkya, that he will be honoured in the Swarga; the Anu-
[Page134-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">śāsanaparvan of the Mahābh. however (see the passages quoted
<div n="lb">s. v. {#anna#}), gives a detailed account of the various benefits
<div n="lb">which accrue to the giver of food, and which comprise
<div n="lb">nearly all conceivable happiness in this and the future world.]

<L>4121<pc>134-b<k1>annaprASana<k2>annaprASana
{#annaprASana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Giving food to eat, scil. to a
[Page135-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">child: the seventh of the ten essential rites enjoined to the
<div n="lb">the three first castes (see {#saMskAra#}); it ought to take place
<div n="lb">according to Āsvālāyana, Manu, Yājnavalkya &c. in the
<div n="lb">sixth month after a child's birth; according to Kātyāyana
<div n="lb">and his school in the sixth (or, according to some, in the
<div n="lb">eighth month) if the child is a boy, in the fifth or seventh,
<div n="lb">if it is a girl. According to Āsvālāyana a father, if he
<div n="lb">desire plenty (for his child?) ought to give it a soup or
<div n="lb">sauce made of goat's flesh ({#‘AjamannAdyakAmaH’#}); if he de-
<div n="lb">sire holiness, a soup or sauce made of the flesh of a fran-
<div n="lb">coline patridge, called tittiri ({#‘tEttiraM brahmavarcasakAmaH’#}); if
<div n="lb">he desire strength, boiled rice sprinkled over with very
<div n="lb">little clarified butter, but not fried in butter, as it would
<div n="lb">then not be moist ({#‘GftOdanaM tejaskAmaH’#}) [The restriction
<div n="lb">made by the comm. in his explanation of the word {#GftOdana#}
<div n="lb">is not justified by himself, but countenanced by the gloss of
<div n="lb">Patanjali on a Vārttika ({#‘saMpratyayAcca tadarTADyavasAnam’#}) to
<div n="lb">Pāṇini II. 1. 34]; or if he have no particular desire, boiled
<div n="lb">rice mixed with curdled milk, honey and clarified butter
<div n="lb">({#‘daDimaDuGftamiSramannaM prASayet’#}). [The word {#anna#} supplied
<div n="lb">at {#Aja#} and {#tEttira#} is, as the comm. observes, not to be
<div n="lb">taken there in its usual sense ‘boiled rice’ but in that of
<div n="lb">soup or sauce, {#vyaYjana#}.] When giving the food, whatever
<div n="lb">be its substance, the father speaks the verse: {#annapate'nnasya#}
<div n="lb">{#no dehyanamIvasya SuzmiRaH#} &c. (Vājas. Sanh. 11. 83.), if the
<div n="lb">child is a boy; if it is a girl, the ceremony is performed
<div n="lb">without the recital of the mantra ({#‘AvftEva kumAryE’#}).--
<div n="lb">According to the school of Kātyāyana the food varies still
<div n="lb">more according to the nature of the desires: that cor-
<div n="lb">responding with the desire of eloquence is the flesh (pro-
<div n="lb">bably the sauce made of the flesh of) a skylark ({#BaradvAjI#});
<div n="lb">with the desire of plenty, that of a partridge, called {#ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#piYjala;#} with the desire of quickness that of a fish; with
<div n="lb">the desire of long life that of the partridge called {#kfkaRA;#}
<div n="lb">with the desire of holiness that of the Śaralī bird ({#AwI#});
<div n="lb">with the desire of all the advantages mentioned before that
<div n="lb">of all these animals together; the dish must moreover in
<div n="lb">general contain honey, clarified butter and bits of gold
<div n="lb">(Reṇuka in his Gṛhyakārikā: {#‘maDvAjyakanakopetaM sarvaM tadyuga-#}
<div n="lb">{#patpraBuH . mAMsaM tacca BaradvAjyA yadIcCedvAkprasAritAm . kA-#}
<div n="lb">{#piYjalaM cedannAdyaM mAtsyaM ca javanaM yadi . AyuScetkfkaRAyASca#}
<div n="lb">{#tadAwyAScedbrahmavarcasam . sarvaM cetsarvamAMsAni sahAnnaM prASayecCu-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bam’#}); the ceremony is performed while a mantra is in-
<div n="lb">audibly muttered and the child is sitting on the lap of its
<div n="lb">mother before the divinity of the family; preparatory pro-
<div n="lb">cedings are, according to Reṇuka, those connected with
<div n="lb">the fixing of an auspicious day, the Ābhyudayika-śrāddha
<div n="lb">(the same as the Vṛddhi-Śr.), austerities, as suspending
<div n="lb">the breath, meditation on the divinity and oblations (āhutis)
<div n="lb">with clarified butter while remembering the divine powers
<div n="lb">of speech ({#vAc#}), the vital airs {#prARa#} and {#apAna,#} eye
<div n="lb">({#cakzus#}) and ear ({#Srotra#}), lastly an oblation of {#caru#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">to Agni ({#agniH svizwakft#}).--According to Bhavadeva, as
<div n="lb">quoted by Rādhākānta, the order of the procedings is:
<div n="lb">fixing of an auspicious day, ablutions, performance of the
<div n="lb">Vṛddhi-Śrāddha, collecting of the sacrificial fire, making
[Page135-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">a heap of Kuśagrass(?) (acc. to Reṇuka: of fifty leaves of
<div n="lb">this grass), then silently throwing into the fire a piece of
<div n="lb">fuel smeared with clarified butter, of a span's length, then
<div n="lb">the oblation (homa) which is accompanied with the three
<div n="lb">sacred words bhūr, bhuvar and svar, then five oblations
<div n="lb">(āhutis) with clarified butter, then the homa of the five vital
<div n="lb">airs ({#prARa#}), or instead of the two latter(?) the ceremony
<div n="lb">practised in the north which begins with the Śāṭyāyana-
<div n="lb">homa and ends with the hymn called Vāmadevya; these
<div n="lb">procedings are followed by the essential rite of giving the
<div n="lb">food and by, what is essential too, the presents to the of-
<div n="lb">ficiating priest. (Comp. also {#annaBukti#}.) E. {#anna#} and {#prASana#}.
<LEND>

<L>4122<pc>135-b<k1>annabuBukzu<k2>annabuBukzu

<L>4130<pc>135-b<k1>annamaya<k2>annamaya
{#annamaya#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yI-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Made of, consisting of, the
<div n="lb">metaphysical or mystical {#anna#} (2. 2.) q. v.; e. g. {#annamayaM hi somyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#manaH;#} the quality of the Supreme Soul in its lowest form of
<div n="lb">manifestation; see {#anna#} 2. 2, {#prARamaya, manomaya, vijYAnamaya#}
<div n="lb">and {#Anandamaya;#} comp. also {#annarasamaya; annamayo rasaH,#} the same
<div n="lb">as {#annarasa#} (2. b.) q. v. <sup>2</sup> Chiefly (but not entirely) consisting of
<div n="lb">boiled rice &c. (see the meanings of {#anna#}); e. g. {#annamayo yajYaH#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-yam#}) Plenty of boiled rice, food &c. [The two
<div n="lb">latter meanings of this word result from the different inter-
<div n="lb">pretation of the commentators on Pāṇ. V. 4. 21; as regards
<div n="lb">the first, it may be observed that {#annamaya#} is not allowed to
<div n="lb">mean ‘made of, or consisting of, food, boiled rice &c.’ in the
<div n="lb">usual, non-mystical sense of this word; the word expressing
<div n="lb">this notion is {#Anna#}.] E. {#anna,#} taddh. aff. {#mayaw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4131<pc>135-b<k1>annamayakoSa<k2>annamayakoSa
{#annamayakoSa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-SaH#}) The sheath made of {#anna#} 2. 2.,
<div n="lb">of the essence of the elementary creation, i. e. the material
<div n="lb">creation: the lowest form in which Brahman (n.) or the
<div n="lb">Supreme Soul is considered as manifesting itself in its world-
<div n="lb">ly and conscious existence.--In the Taittirīya-Upan. {#anna#}
<div n="lb">of which the material creation is made, is the product of
<div n="lb">herbs, these of earth and so on in retrogression, of the
<div n="lb">elements water, fire and æther, the latter being the first
<div n="lb">product of the Supreme Soul; it would appear therefore
<div n="lb">that Brahman (n.) as {#annamayakoSa,#} in this Upanishad,
[Page136-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">is the totality of the {%animal kingdom%} only, since the vegetable
<div n="lb">kingdom precedes the creation of {#anna#} which is called also
<div n="lb">{#sarvOzaDa#} (see {#anna#} 2. 2.) and the beings ({#prajAH#} or {#BUtAni#})
<div n="lb">originating in {#anna,#} are represented as {%living%} through it
<div n="lb">({#‘aTo'nenEva jIvanti’#}); but as {#anna#} on the other hand,
<div n="lb">is the essence of the elements preceding it, this form of
<div n="lb">Brahman would become in the Upanishad, constructively,
<div n="lb">the same that it is in the Vedānta explicitly, viz. the to-
<div n="lb">tality of the whole material creation. Yet while the Upa-
<div n="lb">nishad uses the terms æther, air, fire, water and earth to
<div n="lb">denote the elements in a general sense, the Vedānta dis-
<div n="lb">tinguishes between ideal ({#sUkzma#}) and real ({#sTUla#}) elements
<div n="lb">and makes the {#annamayakoSa#} proceed from the latter which
<div n="lb">are an artificial mutual combination of portions of the former
<div n="lb">(see {#BUta, sUkzmaBUta#} and {#sTUlaBUta#}); and while the Upanishad
<div n="lb">contents itself with the general idea of totality, as expressed
<div n="lb">above, the Vedānta distinguishes between the conception
<div n="lb">that may be formed of the Supreme Soul as unity in this
<div n="lb">totality of the material creation (comp. {#samazwi#}) and the con-
<div n="lb">ception that may be formed of it as multiplicity in it (comp.
<div n="lb">{#vyazwi#}); as unity it is called {#vESvAnara#} or {#virAj,#} as multi-
<div n="lb">plicity {#viSva,#} in either case it is {#jAgrat#}.--The forms superior
<div n="lb">to the {#annamayakoSa#} are in successive gradation {#prARamayakoSa,#}
<div n="lb">{#manomayakoSa, vijYAnamayakoSa#} and {#AnandamayakoSa#} qq. vv.
<div n="lb">(the word {#koSa#} being supplied, in the Upanishad, by the
<div n="lb">comm. to {#annamaya#} &c.). Compare also {#sUkzmaSarIra#} and {#sTU-#}
<div n="lb">{#laSarIra#}. E. {#annamaya#} and {#koSa#}. Also written {#annamayakoza#}.
<LEND>

<L>4132<pc>136-a<k1>annamayakoza<k2>annamayakoza
{#annamayakoza#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-zaH#}) The same as {#annamayakoSa#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>4133<pc>136-a<k1>annamala<k2>annamala
{#annamala#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> Offal, sweepings. <sup>2</sup> The worst
<div n="lb">kind of spirituous liquor, viz. {#surA#}. [The latter meaning
<div n="lb">requires an explanation: Manu 11. 93 says: {#surA vE mala-#}
<div n="lb">{#mannAnAM#} &c. and forbids the drinking of the spirituous liquor
<div n="lb">{#surA#} to a man of the three first castes; Kullūka in his com-
<div n="lb">ment seems to take {#malamannAnAM#} or {#annamala#} in the general sense
<div n="lb">of ‘extract of rice’, because {#surA#} is made from the flower of
<div n="lb">rice ({#taRqulapizwasADyatvAtsurA annamalam#}); but Pulastya, as
<div n="lb">quoted by Vijnāneśvara in the Mitākṣara names twelve
<div n="lb">sorts of intoxicating drinks, stating that {#surA#} is the very
<div n="lb">worst description amongst them: {#pAnasaM drAkzaM mADUkaM KArjUraM#}
<div n="lb">{#tAlamEkzavam . maDUtTaM sEramArizwamEreyaM nArikelajam . samA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAni vijAnIyAnmadyAnyekAdaSEva tu . dvAdaSaM tu surAmadyaM sarve-#}
<div n="lb">{#zAmaDamaM smftam;#} and Vijnāneśvara in commenting upon the
<div n="lb">quoted passage of Manu and adducing Pāṇ. II. 1. 34. where
<div n="lb">the word {#anna#} means a preparation of rice &c. observes
<div n="lb">that it is intended to convey in this passage the sense of
<div n="lb">spirituous liquor, the latter being also an {#annavikAra#} or
<div n="lb">preparation of rice, and {#surA#} being used also in the Sautrā-
<div n="lb">maṇī libations in the sense of spirituous liquor made of rice:
<div n="lb">{#‘surA vE malamannAnAM pApmA ca malamucyata iti . annavikAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#syEva surAtvanirdeSAdannaSabdasya cAnnena vyaYjanamityAdizu vrIhyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#divikAra eva prayogadarSanAdguqamaDunoSca rasarUpatvAttaTA sO-#}
<div n="lb">{#trAmaRIgrahezu cAnnavikAra eva surASabdasya SrutatvAt . ’#}.
<div n="lb">For this meaning of {#anna#} compare also {#annapeya#}.] E. {#anna#}
<div n="lb">and {#mala#}.
<LEND>

<L>4135<pc>136-b<k1>annarasa<k2>annarasa

<div n="lb">{#vyADirannarase yaTA#} ‘just as disease may lurk in the good

<div n="lb">stances’; or {#yamastvannarasaM prAdAt#} ‘Yama gave (Nala) the
<div n="lb">distinguished properties of food’ (comm. {#‘annarasaM yAdfSe#}

<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> Semen virile, as the essence of {#anna#} 2. 2.; <sup>b.</sup> the same as

<L>4141<pc>136-b<k1>annavikAra<k2>annavikAra
{#annavikAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Transformation of food; used
<div n="lb">in general of any preparation of an article of food, e. g. of
<div n="lb">{#saktu, puroqASa, surA, yavasurA, pizwasurA#} (comp. s. v. {#anna-#}
<div n="lb">{#mala#}); according to an observation of Vardhamāna, however,
<div n="lb">only of an artificial preparation, of made dishes, e. g. of
<div n="lb">sweetmeats, {#SazkulImodaka#} &c. (which would include, too,
<div n="lb">the given instances {#saktu#} &c. occurring in the Mahābhāṣya,
<div n="lb">Kāśikā, Bhaṭṭikāvya &c.), not of preparations which re-
<div n="lb">present, as it were, the original substance only in a different
<div n="lb">shape, as of {#pfTuka,#} rice or grain flattened, {#apUpa,#} cake of
<div n="lb">flour &c. (This observation is in accordance, also, with
<div n="lb">the author of the gaṇa {#apUpAdi#} to Pāṇ. V. 1. 4. where the
<div n="lb">words {#apUpa#} and {#pfTuka#} occur besides {#annavikAra#}). <sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb">seminal secretion. <sup>3</sup> Transformation of the metaphysical
<div n="lb">or mystical food; see {#anna#} 2. 2. and compare {#annavikAratva#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anna#} and {#vikAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4153<pc>137-a<k1>annahoma<k2>annahoma

<div n="lb">corn ({#lAjAH#}). Comp. {#annADISa#}. E. {#anna#} and {#homa#}.

<L>4155<pc>137-a<k1>annAkAlaBfta<k2>annAkAlaBfta
[{#annAkAlaBfta#}.¦ A misreading for {#anAkAlaBfta#} q. v. As the
<div n="lb">reading {#annAkAlaBfta#} occurs in the present edition of the
<div n="lb">Vivādachintāmaṇi while the reading {#anAkAlaBfta#} is given
<div n="lb">in one E. I. H. Ms. of it, in both actual editions of the Mi-
<div n="lb">tākṣara and in the E. I. H. Mss. of this work in the same
<div n="lb">sense, it may be as well to observe that the meaning in-
<div n="lb">tended by the former part of the compound could not be ex-
<div n="lb">pressed by the word {#annAkAla#} but, if {#anna#} were to make part
<div n="lb">of it, would require a form {#anannakAla; anAkAla,#} however,
<div n="lb">similar in structure to {#anAvfzwi,#} is a correct formation im-
<div n="lb">plying ‘hard time in general i. e. time of distress, famine &c.’.]

<L>4160<pc>137-a<k1>annAda<k2>annAda
{#annAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dI-dam#}) Eating food &c. (see
<div n="lb">the meanings of {#anna#}); also eating the metaphysical or
<div n="lb">mystical {#anna#} 2. 2.; said e. g. of the Supreme Soul {#‘aha-#}
<div n="lb">{#mannamahamannAdaH’#} (comm. {#advEta AtmA niraYjano'pi sannaha-#}
<div n="lb">{#mevAnnamannAdaSca#}); or {#‘sEzA virAqannAdI’#} (comm. {#sEzA vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAqdaSasaMKyA satyannaM cAnnAdinI ca#}). E. {#anna#} and {#Ada#} ({#ad,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#aR#}). [NB. This etymol. is the regular one, but
<div n="lb">according to the comm. of Pāṇ., restricted to the classical
<div n="lb">dialect; in the Vedas the word is treated as if the latter
<div n="lb">part were {#ada#} ({#ad,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}) or, in other words: {#annAda,#}
[Page137-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">fem. {#ºdI#} is in the vaidik literature udātta on the last syl-
<div n="lb">lable, while in the classical dialect it would be udātta on
<div n="lb">the first. This is the bearing of the instance {#annAdAya#}
<div n="lb">(dative of {#annAda#}) in the comm. on the Kārikā to Pāṇini
<div n="lb">III. 1. 85., when the comm. observes {#‘aRvizaye'c’;#} comp.
<div n="lb">Mahābhāṣya on Pāṇ. III. 2. 1.; {#‘annAdAyeti ca kftAM vyatya-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaSCandasi’ . annAdAyeti ca kftAM vyatyayaSCandasi drazwavyaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#annAdAyAnnapataye . AhutimannAdIM hutvA . karmaRyaR;#} where-
<div n="lb">upon Kaiyyaṭa: {#annAdAyeti . annamattItyaRaH prasaNge'cpratyayaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kriyate . tena anna'adAyetyevamavagraha upapadyate#}.--In the
<div n="lb">present edition of Pāṇini there is a misprint {#annAdAyaH#} in-
<div n="lb">stead of {#annAdAya#} (the latter being correctly given in the
<div n="lb">corresponding place of the Siddh. Kaum. fol. 217 b. line 15);
<div n="lb">in the mutilated reprint of that edition the error has been
<div n="lb">repeated, as in similar cases, and somewhere else a new
<div n="lb">vaidik word has been founded on it viz ‘{#annAdAya#} adj. ved.’
<div n="lb">with a meaning ‘taking food’ and with an etymology ‘{#anna#}
<div n="lb">and {#AdAya#}’; it needs not be observed that the quoted words
<div n="lb">{#‘aRvizaye'c’#} would become quite meaningless with such a
<div n="lb">formation ‘{#annAdAya#} adj.’, since the āgama {#yuk#} could not
<div n="lb">occur in a derivative with kṛt aff. {#ac#}.]
<LEND>

<L>4164<pc>137-b<k1>annAdya<k2>annAdya
{#annAdya#}¦ I. Karmadh. n. ({#-dyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Food fit to be eaten, food
<div n="lb">in general, used in the same sense as {#anna;#} also elliptically:
<div n="lb">the eating of food; e. g. {#nivartaTAmyAyuze'nnAdyAya#} (comm.
<div n="lb">= {#annaBakzaRAya#}); or {#annAdyAya…aBiziYcAmi#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#annAdyamannaBakzaRasAmarTyam#} where the ‘fitness’ (of eating food)
<div n="lb">however, is rather implied by the dative instead of in-
<div n="lb">hering to the meaning of the base); or {#annAdyAdeH saMviBAgo#}
<div n="lb">{#BUteByaSca yaTArhataH;#} and in the mystical acceptation of {#anna;#}
<div n="lb">e. g. {#aTAtmane'nnAdyamAgAyat;#} or {#etamfgvedamaByatapaMstasyABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#taptasya yaSasteja indriyaM vIryamannAdyaM raso'jAyata#} (comm. {#annA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyamannaM ca tadAdyaM ca yenopayujyamAnenAhanyahani devAnAM sTitiH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAttadannAdyameza raso'jAyata yAgAdilakzaRAtkarmaRaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Food
<div n="lb">fit for the occasion at which it is eaten, proper food; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#kuryAdaharahaH SrAdDamannAdyenodakena#} (comm. {#annAdyeneti tilErvrI-#}
<div n="lb">{#hiBiryavErityAderupAdAnam#}); or {#annAdyena#} (scil. {#brAhmaRAnBo-#}
<div n="lb">{#jayet#}) i. e. with choice dishes (comm. = {#mizwAnnena#}). <sup>3</sup> Boiled
<div n="lb">rice. E. {#anna#} and {#Adya#} (to be eaten). [In Röer's valuable
<div n="lb">edition of Śaṅkara's comm. on the Bṛhadār., {#tadadyaM#} p. 279
<div n="lb">({#annAdyamannameva tadadyaM ca#}) is probably a misprint for {#tadAdyaM,#}
<div n="lb">conformably to similar explanations of the same author,
<div n="lb">e. g. Bṛhadār. p. 100, Chhānd. p. 161.]
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-dyaH-dyA-dyam#}) Rice and so on (see
<div n="lb">the meanings of {#anna#}); the same as if the latter part of the
<div n="lb">compound were {#Adi;#} e. g. {#sArvavarRikamannAdyaM saMnIyAplAvya#}
<div n="lb">{#vAriRA#} (comm. = {#sarvaprakAramannAdikaM vyaYjanAdiBirekIkftya#}
<div n="lb">&c.). E. {#anna#} and {#Adya#} (first).
<LEND>
