<L>4171<pc>138-a<k1>annAyu<k2>annAyu
{#annAyu#}¦ m. ({#-yuH#}) I. Tatpur. Seizing food (see {#anna#} 2. 2.); or
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Living through food (see {#anna#} 2. 2.); an epithet
<div n="lb">of the vital air {#apAna#} q. v., in the Aitareya Upanishad,
<div n="lb">because it alone was capable to seize the primitive food,
<div n="lb">created from the waters by the Supreme Soul, after speech,
<div n="lb">the vital air {#prARa#} q. v., eye, ear, skin (i. e. touch), manas and
<div n="lb">the generative organ were unable to take possession of, and
<div n="lb">thus of preserving, life through it. In the passage alluded
<div n="lb">to there is a quibble on the word {#Ayu,#} according to its
<div n="lb">having the sense of ‘obtaining’ from the corresponding
<div n="lb">meaning of the rad. {#I, vI,#} or the sense of {#Ayus#} ‘life’;
<div n="lb">as the word occurs in the nomin. {#annAyuH,#} it may, as a
<div n="lb">Bahuvr., represent also the form {#annAyus#}. The radical {#I#}
<div n="lb">having the same meaning as {#vI#} and probably being identical
<div n="lb">with it in origin, the words {#vayat#} and {#vAyu#} ‘air or taking’,
<div n="lb">in the same passage, complete the double sense of the pun:
<div n="lb">‘{#tad#} (i. e. {#annaM#}) {#apAnenAjiGfkzattadA vayat . sa ezo'nnasya#}
<div n="lb">{#graho#} (comm. = {#annagrAhakaH#}) {#yadvAyurannAyurvA eza yadvAyuH;#}
<div n="lb">comm.: {#yo vAyurannAyurannabanDano'nnajIvano vE prasidDaM sa eza#}
<div n="lb">{#yo vAyuH#}. E. {#anna#} and {#Ayu#}.
<LEND>

<L>4172<pc>138-a<k1>annAyus<k2>annAyus
{#annAyus#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-yuH#}) Living through food, an epithet
<div n="lb">of {#apAna;#} see {#annAyu#}. (A comm. on the passage quoted
<div n="lb">under the preceding word, adopts the form {#annAyus#} in ob-
<div n="lb">serving: {#annamadAmetyAdiSrutyantare prARasyAnnAyuzwvaM prasidDam#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#anna#} and {#Ayus#}.
<LEND>

<L>4173<pc>138-a<k1>annArTa<k2>annArTa
{#annArTa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) Concerning food; see
<div n="lb">the following. E. {#anna#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4174<pc>138-a<k1>annArTatA<k2>annArTatA
{#annArTatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) or {#annArTatva#} n. ({#-tvam#}) The concerning food;
<div n="lb">said of a religious act which does not concern the object
<div n="lb">or purpose of the sacrificer (comp. {#puruzArTatva#}), but merely
<div n="lb">the consecration of the substance to be offered in sacrifice.
<div n="lb">E. {#annArTa,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4175<pc>138-a<k1>annArTin<k2>annArTin

<div n="lb">asking for food. E. {#anna#} and {#arTin#}.

<L>4178<pc>138-a<k1>anya<k2>anya
{#anya#}¦ (see {#sarvanAman#}) 1. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyad(-nyat),#} dat. {#-nyasmE#}
<div n="lb">{#-nyasyE-nyasmE,#} abl. {#-nyasmAt-nyasyAH-nyasmAt,#} gen. {#-nyasya-nyasyAH#}
<div n="lb">{#-nyasya,#} loc. {#-nyasmin-nyasyAm-nyasmin;#} nom. plur. {#-nye-nyAH#}
<div n="lb">{#-nyAni,#} gen. {#-nyezAm-nyAsAm-nyezAm;#} also with the aff.
[Page138-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#akac,#} e. g. nom. plur. {#anyake,#} gen. plur. {#anyakezAm#} which
<div n="lb">forms therefore do not belong to a base {#anyaka#} q. v.) Other;
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> Other in general, e. g. {#kriyante kawAstvayA mayAnyESca;#} also
<div n="lb">in the sense {%‘besides, moreover, also’,%} e. g. {#fco yajUMzi cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyAni sAmAni viviDAni ca . eza jYeyastrivfdvedo yI vedEnaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sa vedavit . AdyaM yattryakzaraM brahma trayI yasminpratizWitA . sa gu-#}
<div n="lb">{#hyo'nyastrivfdvedo yastaM veda sa vedavit .#} ‘The Ṛchs, the Ya-
<div n="lb">jus, and {%besides%} the various Sāmans…and what was
<div n="lb">first, Brahman, the syllable of three letters (a-u-m) on
<div n="lb">which rest the three Vedas, that, {%too,%} is the hidden three-
<div n="lb">fold Veda &c.’.--The neuter {#anyad#} esp. with a follow-
<div n="lb">ing {#ca (anyacca)#} occurs frequently in the latter sense ‘besides,
<div n="lb">moreover’, to connect maximes or sentences loosely joined
<div n="lb">together; it is used then synonymously with {#aparaM ca#} and
<div n="lb">{#api ca#}.--In combinations {#anyasminnahani, anyasmindivase#}
<div n="lb">&c. ‘other’ is used in the same manner as in the corre-
<div n="lb">sponding ‘the other day’, lit. on some day other (than
<div n="lb">the present day). <sup>b.</sup> Other implying {%similarity, similar%} (Aja-
<div n="lb">yap.: = {#sadfSatara#}), e. g. {#mitralABaH suhfdBedo vigrahaH saMDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#revaca . paYcatantrAttaTAnyasmAdgranTAdAkfzya liKyate#} ‘Acquiring
<div n="lb">friends (the subject treated in the first) and the subjects
<div n="lb">treated in the three other books of the Hitopadeśa are re-
<div n="lb">presented such as they have been taken from the Pancha-
<div n="lb">tantra and a {%similar%} work’. <sup>c.</sup> Other, implying {%dissimilarity,%}
<div n="lb">{%difference, opposition,%} i. e. different, opposed, reverse; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#virAmapratyayAByAsapUrvaH saMskAraSezo'nyaH#} ‘the meditation
<div n="lb">which is preceded by the repeated exercise of calm recog-
<div n="lb">nition (is that defined before); different from it (the reverse
<div n="lb">of it) is the meditation devoid of a specific object’. This
<div n="lb">notion of difference or opposition is often expressed in a
<div n="lb">still more distinct manner by putting the correlative terms
<div n="lb">{#eka, apara, kiMcit, kiMcana#} or {#anya#} itself in the opposed
<div n="lb">sentence or words, answering thus our ‘the one…the
<div n="lb">other’; e. g. {#dfzwA mayetyupekzaka eko dfzwAhamityuparatAnyA;#} or
<div n="lb">{#yaTA kaScididaM kzetraM madIyamiti kaTayati . anyo'pi tadvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#roDena madIyamiti;#} or {#na yodDumaSakankecinnAQOkizata kecana#}
<div n="lb">{#…vanOkasaH . udare cAjarannanye#} &c.; or {#anyahaste tu vikrIya#}
<div n="lb">{#yo'nyahaste prayacCati#} &c.; or {#ahamanyaH SarIramanyat.--a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyAnyA#} (fem. ved.) one after the other, one in succession.
<div n="lb">(Sāy. = {#parasparavyatihAreRa,#} or = {#ekEkA#}.) A noun, depend-
<div n="lb">ing on {#anya#} ‘different from’ stands in the ablative, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#prajApate na tvadetAnyanyo viSvA rUpARi pari tA baBUva;#} or {#na#}
<div n="lb">{#tryambakAdanyamupAsTitAsO#} (scil. {#daSaraTaH#}); or {#prakftipuruzayo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ranyatsarvamanityam;#} or {#anyadanyasmAdananyatvAdananyadityanyatABAvaH#}.
<div n="lb">--In this case the noun, esp. a pronoun depending on {#anya#}
<div n="lb">forms in some rare instances, as a former part, a Tat-
<div n="lb">pur. with {#anya#} as a latter part; e. g. {#paro madanyo jagata-#}
<div n="lb">{#stasTuzaSca otaM protaM pawavadyatra viSvam;#} or {#anityA#} (scil. {#kzi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tiH#}) {#tu tadanyA syAt;#} or {#rUpAnyaccakzuzo yogyaM rUpamatrApi#}
<div n="lb">{#kAraRam#}. <sup>d.</sup> One; see {#anyatas#} and the quotation s. v. {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyatomuKa#}. [In opposed sentences containing the correlat.
<div n="lb">{#anya--anya#} ‘the one…the other’ the first verb following
<div n="lb">{#anya#} may become anudātta; an instance given in the comm.
<div n="lb">of Pāṇini is: {#tayoranyaH pippalaM svAdvattyanaSnannananyo aBi cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kaSIti#} (where {#atti#} may be anudātta). As former part of
<div n="lb">a {%Karmadh.%} compound {#anya#} retains in some formations the
[Page139-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">final {#d#} of its neuter; see {#anyadASA, anyadASis, anyadA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sTA, anyadAsTita, anyadutsuka, anyadUti, anyadrAga,#} but not
<div n="lb">in the {%Tatpur.%} {#anyASA#} &c. qq. vv.; optionally in the {%Kar-%}
<div n="lb">{%madh.%} {#anyadarTa#} or {#anyArTa#} qq. vv., and always in the {%Kar-%}
<div n="lb">{%madh.%} and {%Tatpur.%} {#anyatkAraka#} q. v.; comp. also {#anyatkAma#}
<div n="lb">and the derivative {#anyadIya#}.]
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-nyaH#}) An enemy. (ved.) [If the aff. {#akac#} is
<div n="lb">placed before the endings of {#anya#} 1. m. f. n. or 2. m. the
<div n="lb">word assumes besides its own meaning the notion of di-
<div n="lb">minution or deterioration, e. g. {#anyakezAm#} ‘of contemptible
<div n="lb">enemies’ (comm.: {#kutsitA anye'nyake…anyakezAM kutsi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAnAmanyezAM SatrURAm#}); or {#anyake#} ‘a few others’ (comm.:
<div n="lb">{#anyake . alpA ye'nye#}.]
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-nyad#}) A blunder in reading, esp. in accentuating
<div n="lb">words, e. g. {#anyattvaM karozi,#} thou blunderest, i. e. thou
<div n="lb">readest e. g. an anudātta instead of an udātta (comm.: {#udAtte#}
<div n="lb">{#kartavye yo'nudAttaM karoti#} &c.). Comp. {#EkAnyika, dvEyanyika,#}
<div n="lb">{#trEyanyika, dvAdaSAnyika, trayodaSAnyika, caturdaSAnyika#}.
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-nyA#}) <sup>1</sup> The same as {#anyastrI#} q. v. [<sup>2</sup> A medical
<div n="lb">dictionary quotes this word in the femin. professedly on the
<div n="lb">authority of Dhanvantari, with the appended meanings {#hartakI#}
<div n="lb">(i. e. {#harItakI#} q. v.), {#mahASradDA#} and {#kfzRacAriRI,#} the two
<div n="lb">latter of which seem to be unknown, however, to the author
<div n="lb">himself. The correctness of this name seems rather doubtful.]
<div n="lb">E. The native etym. {#an#} ‘to breathe’, kṛt aff. {#ya#} is not very
<div n="lb">plausible; it is probably derived from the pronominal base
<div n="lb">{#a#} or {#an#}.
<LEND>

<L>4179<pc>139-a<k1>anyaka<k2>anyaka
[{#anyaka#}.¦ N. B. The forms {#anyake, anyakezAm#} are not to be re-
<div n="lb">ferred to a base {#anyaka,#} but belong to {#anya#} q. v. which word
<div n="lb">like other {#sarvanAman#} q. v. may assume the affix {#akac#} placed
<div n="lb">before the endings. Such is the theory of Pāṇini, and it is
<div n="lb">countenanced not only by the pronominal declension endings
<div n="lb">of {#anyake#} &c. but by the analogy of a similar intrusion of
<div n="lb">{#ka#} in the middle of verbal forms such as {#BindDaki, CindDaki#}
<div n="lb">‘he cuts badly or a little’.]
<LEND>

<L>4183<pc>139-a<k1>anyakfta<k2>anyakfta

<div n="lb">on account of the elision of {#a#}.]

<L>4200<pc>139-b<k1>anyataHSitibAhu<k2>anyataHSitibAhu

<div n="lb">are tied together with six other animals, to the eighth of
<div n="lb">the twenty-one sacrificial posts required for the performance
<div n="lb">of the Aśvamedha. E. {#anyatas#} and {#enI#} (the femin. of {#eta#}).

<L>4203<pc>140-a<k1>anyatama<k2>anyatama
{#anyatama#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) Any one of many, either of
<div n="lb">many; e. g. {#vAtapittaSlezmaSoRitamedomUtrAntranimittAH sapta#}
<div n="lb">{#vfdDayaH . tAsAM mUtrAntranimitte vfdDI vAtasamutTe kevalamutpattihe-#}
<div n="lb">{#turanyatamaH;#} or in the dual, e. g. {#BujakowikarRAnAmanyatame jYAte#}
<div n="lb">{#'nyatamayorjYAnAya karaRasUtram;#} in the plur., e. g. {#tAsAmanya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tamAH#} (scil. {#rAkzasyaH#}) {#kzipraM rAvaRAyAcacakzire#}. Also ‘any’
<div n="lb">in general; e. g. {#hInamanyatamenApyavayavena nyUnam#}. Comp. {#anya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tara#}. [According to Vopadeva (7. 96.) {#anyatama#} is formed with
<div n="lb">the taddh. aff. {#qatama#} and would therefore be a pronoun,
<div n="lb">according to his rule 3. 9., which again would assimilate
<div n="lb">its declension to that of {#sarva#} (cf. 3. 35-37. 75); but as there
<div n="lb">is no evidence to this effect in Pāṇini or in the literature,
<div n="lb">and as Vopad. himself mentions {#anyatara#} in the rule 3. 9., the
<div n="lb">word {#anya#} in the rule 7. 96. must be an inaccuracy of this gram-
<div n="lb">marian, the correctness of the reading being placed beyond
<div n="lb">doubt by the comm. of Durgādāsa.] E. {#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#tamap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4204<pc>140-a<k1>anyatara<k2>anyatara
{#anyatara#}¦ 1. (see {#sarvanAman#}) m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-rad(-rat);#} the dat.,
<div n="lb">abl., gen. and loc. sing., the nom. and gen. plur. are similar
<div n="lb">to the corresponding cases of {#anya#} q. v.) <sup>1</sup> Either of two;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#uBayoH pakzayoranyatarasyADyApanAdapratizeDaH;#} or {#nityo-#}
<div n="lb">{#palabDyanupalabDiprasaNgo'nyataraniyamo vAnyaTA#} (Śaṅkara: {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyatarasyAtmana indriyasya vA SaktipratibanDaH#} &c.); or {#svApyaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMpattyoranyatarApekzamAvizkftaM hi#} (i. e. either of profound sleep
<div n="lb">or of final emancipation).--In the rules of Pāṇini {#anyata-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasyAm#} (the locat. sing. of the femin.) ‘in either way’ means
<div n="lb">that a given rule is optional, may take place or not; comp.
<div n="lb">for synonymous terms {#vA, viBAzA,#} and the more precise terms
<div n="lb">{#aprAptaviBAzA, prAptaviBAzA, uBayatraviBAzA, vyavasTitavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAzA, mahAviBAzA, sarvaviBAzA,#} also {#viBAzita, uBayaTA,#}
<div n="lb">{#vikalpa#}. <sup>2</sup> {%The%} other of two (one having been mentioned)
<div n="lb">[this meaning is probably meant when the Amarakosha, He-
<div n="lb">machandra &c. make {#anyatara#} a synonyme of {#anya#} ‘other’];
<div n="lb">e. g. in the Vārttika to Pāṇini V. 2. 47 {#eko'nyataraH,#} where
<div n="lb">{#anyataraH#} is opposed as {#nimeyam#} to the word expressing the
<div n="lb">{#nimAnam,#} as in the instance {#dvimayamudaSvidyavAnAm,#} where
<div n="lb">{#udaSvit#} ‘the object to be valued which is {#eka#} ‘one’, is
<div n="lb">{#nimeya,#} and the {#yava#} ‘the object determining the value ({#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnam#} or {#mUlyam#}) is {#nimAna#}’ (comp. Kaiyyaṭa: {#anyataraSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdena nimeyameva vivakzitam . eka eva yadi nimeyaguRo Bava-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti tadA pratyayaH#}). <sup>3</sup> One of two, each being one of many;
<div n="lb">in this sense its use is probably restricted to passages be-
<div n="lb">longing to the vaidik period, when it is followed by a cor-
<div n="lb">relate {#anyatara,#} both implying then ‘the one--the other,
<div n="lb">one--another’ (comp. {#anya--anya#}); e. g. Śatapathabr.
<div n="lb">I. 2. 1. 1. {#sa vE kapAlAnyevAnyatara upadaDAti . dfzadupale'nya-#}
<div n="lb">{#taraH#} (thus explained in the genuine comm. of Śāyaṇa: {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyataraH . ftvijAM maDya ekaH . AgnIDraH . sa kapAlAnAmupa-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAtA . anyataro'DvaryuH . sa pezaRArTaM dfzadupale upadaDyAt#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-raH#}) A proper name; comp. {#Anyatareya#} (and {#itara,#}
<div n="lb">{#Etareya#}). E. {#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#qatara#}.
<LEND>

<L>4205<pc>140-a<k1>anyataratas<k2>anyataratas
{#anyataratas#}¦ ind. On one of two sides. Comp. {#anyatas#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#anyatara,#} vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#tasil#}.
<LEND>

<L>4206<pc>140-a<k1>anyataratodanta<k2>anyataratodanta
{#anyataratodanta#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-ntaH-ntA-ntam#}) Having teeth
<div n="lb">on one side only, having but one row of teeth (as {#prajAH,#}
<div n="lb">living beings); opposed to {#uBayatodanta#} i. e. men, horses
<div n="lb">and other animals which have two rows of teeth; both
[Page140-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">categories being intended in a vaidik passage to comprise
<div n="lb">all living beings in general. E. {#anyataratas#} and {#danta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4207<pc>140-b<k1>anyataratoyukta<k2>anyataratoyukta

<div n="lb">beast) put to but one side of it; said in a vaidik passage of
<div n="lb">a cart which has one ox put to it. E. {#anyataratas#} and {#yukta#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and beholding it under the relation of either--or’; see
<div n="lb">the following. E. {#anyatara,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4209<pc>140-b<k1>anyataraDarma<k2>anyataraDarma

<div n="lb">{#nyatara,#} the same as {#anyataratva;#} e. g. {#samAnAnekaDarmADyavasA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAdanyataraDarmADyavasAyAdvA na saMSayaH#} ‘doubt can not arise
<div n="lb">from apprehending mentally an object under the relation
<div n="lb">of sameness (with), or difference (from, other objects), nor

<L>4212<pc>140-b<k1>anyatas<k2>anyatas
{#anyatas#}¦ ind. Used in the same manner as 1. the ablative and
<div n="lb">2. the locative of {#anya,#} absolutely or with the ellipsis of a
<div n="lb">word implying ‘place’, ‘manner’ &c., viz.
<div n="P">1. = the ablative of {#anya,#} ‘from another’; e. g. {#BAvitaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pakzato'BIzwO tyaktvA varRO sarUpakO . anyato BAvitANkena#}
<div n="lb">{#tataH pakzO viBajya ca#} &c., i. e. ‘removing the factum from one
<div n="lb">side and the simple colours and absolute numbers from the
<div n="lb">other, as optionally selected, and dividing both sides of the
<div n="lb">equation by the coefficient of the factum &c.’; also with a
<div n="lb">noun depending on it in the ablative, e. g. in the comm. of
<div n="lb">the Kāsikā on Pāṇ. IV. 1. 40. ‘{#topaDAdanyataH prAtipadikA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvarRavAcino'nudAttAtstriyAM NIzpratyayo Bavati#}.
<div n="P">2. = the locative of {#anya#} and in the same sense as {#anyatra,#}
<div n="lb">viz. <sup>1</sup> In another, on another; e. g. {#anyato vfttO#} (comm.
<div n="lb">= {#anyatra jAtO#}) ‘in another way’; or in Hemachandra's
<div n="lb">explanation of {#vijYAna, ‘mokze jYAnaM vijYAnamanyataH,#} i. e.
<div n="lb">{#jYAna#} means (knowledge of what concerns) final emancipa-
<div n="lb">tion, {#vijYAna#} other (knowledge), where {#anyataH#} represents
<div n="lb">the locative {#anyasmin,#} the explaining words being put in
<div n="lb">the locative, and does not mean ‘in another case, else-
<div n="lb">where’. <sup>2</sup> (Scil. {#deSe#}) Elsewhere; e. g. {#pratipattiSUnyamutTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pyAnyataH pravfttaH;#} or {#yAnto'nyataH…AtmavargyAH;#} also re-
<div n="lb">peated: ‘in one place--in another place’, e. g. {#aSfRvanna-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyataH SabdaM prapalAyanta cAnyataH . Akrandamanyato'kurvestenAhanyanta#}
<div n="lb">{#cAnyataH ..#}. Comp. {#anyatovAta#}. <sup>3</sup> (Scil. {#deSe#}) In one place,
<div n="lb">in one direction (ved.); comp. {#anyatoGAtin, anyatomuKa,#}
<div n="lb">{#anyato'raRya#}. <sup>4</sup> (Scil. {#deSe#}) On the other side, on the con-
<div n="lb">trary. <sup>5</sup> (Scil. {#prakAre#}) In another way or manner, otherwise;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#vAzpaBarastayA calitayA niHSvasya mukto'nyataH#}. E. {#anya,#}
<div n="lb">vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#tasil#}.
<LEND>

<L>4213<pc>140-b<k1>anyatastya<k2>anyatastya

<L>4214<pc>141-a<k1>anyatA<k2>anyatA
{#anyatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) The being other, otherness, difference; also
<div n="lb">{#anyatva#} q. v.; e. g. {#jAtilakzaRadeSEranyatAnavacCedAttulyayostataH#}
<div n="lb">{#pratipattiH#} (Difference) is understood through it (viz. through
<div n="lb">profound meditation), since it is impossible to remove the
<div n="lb">otherness which exists between two (apparently) like objects
<div n="lb">either with regard to species or characteristic properties or
<div n="lb">space; (as in the case, for instance of various atoms, or
<div n="lb">of Īśvara and the Yogin). E. {#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>4217<pc>141-a<k1>anyatomuKa<k2>anyatomuKa

<div n="lb">in one place; opposed to {#sarvatomuKa#} or (the sacrificer) who
<div n="lb">by shaving off his hairs, makes his scull, through its bald-
<div n="lb">ness, resemble the face and thus becomes as it were ‘face
<div n="lb">all over’ (according to the comm. of Sāyaṇa on Śatapa-
<div n="lb">thabr. II. 6. 3. 16, which unmutilated runs thus: {#ayaMSabda-#}

<L>4218<pc>141-a<k1>anyatoraRya<k2>anyato'raRya

<L>4219<pc>141-a<k1>anyatovAta<k2>anyatovAta
{#anyatovAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) (In Medicine.) A disease of the
<div n="lb">whole eye ({#sarvAkziroga#}); symptoms and etymology are con-
<div n="lb">veyed by the following verse: {#yasyAvawUkarRaSirohanusTo ma-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyAgato vApyanilo'nyato vA . kuryAdrujo'ti Bruvi locane vA#}
<div n="lb">{#tamanyatovAtamudAharanti#} ‘when the {%air%} of the back of the
<div n="lb">neck, of ears, head, jaw, the tendons which form the nape
<div n="lb">of the neck or {%elsewhere%} produces excessive pain in the eye-
<div n="lb">brow and eye, they call this (disease of the eye) {#anyato-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAta#}’. The word occurs also in its uncompounded state,
<div n="lb">e. g. {#hatADimanTo'nilaparyAyaSca SuzkAkzipAko'nyata eva#}
<div n="lb">{#vAtaH#}. E. {#anyatas#} and {#vAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4220<pc>141-a<k1>anyatkAma<k2>anyatkAma

<div n="lb">those compounds in which {#anya#} retains the {#d#} of its neuter;

<L>4221<pc>141-a<k1>anyatkAraka<k2>anyatkAraka

<L>4222<pc>141-a<k1>anyatra<k2>anyatra
{#anyatra#}¦ (ved. also {#anyatrA#}) ind. Used in the same sense as the
<div n="lb">locat. of {#anya,#} absolutely or with the ellipsis of a word im-
<div n="lb">plying ‘place’, ‘manner’ &c.; comp. {#anyatas;#} viz. <sup>1</sup> In
<div n="lb">another or others, on another or others, e. g. {#anyatra jAtO#}
<div n="lb">(see the instance s. v. {#anyatas#}); {#anyatrArTe; sarvABedAdanyatreme#}
<div n="lb">(which Vedānta Sūtra is explained: {#sarvaSAKAsu prARopA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sanasyABedAdanyatra SAKAntare ime vasizWatvAdiguRAH samAhA-#}
[Page141-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#ryAH#}); or {#sAhasasteyapAruzyago'BiSApAtyaye striyAm . vivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dayetsadya eva kAlo'nyatrecCayA smftaH#} (comm. {#anyatra = vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdAntarezu#}); also with a noun depending on it in the ablat.
<div n="lb">‘in another than’, e. g. in the Sūtra of Pāṇ. {#tAByAmanyatro-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAdayaH#} (Kāśikā: {#uRRAdayaH pratyayAstAByAM saMpradAnApAdAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByAmanyatra kArake Bavanti#}); or {#DAtvarTAnAM saMbanDe yatra kAle pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyayA uktAstato'nyatrApi Bavanti#}. <sup>2</sup> Elsewhere; in space or
<div n="lb">time, e. g. {#yadA CalaM vinEva kAryAtiSayAdanyatra gataH#} &c.;
<div n="lb">or {#etezAM#} (scil. {#rUparasaganDasparSAnAM#}) {#pAkajatvaM tu kzitO nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyatra kutracit;#} also with a noun in the ablat., e. g. (Kā-
<div n="lb">śikā on Pāṇini VIII. 1. 12. v. 10.) {#strInigadaBAvAdanyatrApi#}
<div n="lb">{#dfSyate#}. <sup>3</sup> In another manner, differently from; with a noun
<div n="lb">in the ablative, e. g. {#apatyADikArAdanyatra lOkikamapatyamAtraM#}
<div n="lb">{#gotram,#} i. e. {#gotra#} in Pāṇini's rule IV. 2. 39 is to be taken
<div n="lb">in the sense of a son only, differently from the chapter on
<div n="lb">{#apatya#} (IV. 1. 162) where it means the descendants beginning
<div n="lb">with the grandson ({#apatyamAtraM na tu pOtrapraBftyeva#} Kāś.). <sup>4</sup> In
<div n="lb">another or different sense; e. g. {#kAraskaro vfkzaH . anyatra kA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rakaraH;#} or {#ekatra rajo DUliranyatra guRaH#}. <sup>5</sup> Except, with a
<div n="lb">noun in the ablative, e. g. {#SabdArTayoH punarvacanaM punaruktamanya-#}
<div n="lb">{#trAnuvAdAt#} ‘repetition of word or sense is called {#punarukta,#}
<div n="lb">unless it be an {#anuvAda#} q. v.’; or {#ta indriyARi tadvyapadeSA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyatra SrezWAt#} ‘these (eleven prāṇas) are the senses except
<div n="lb">the principal one, because exception of it is taken (in a
<div n="lb">vaidik passage)’; {#anyatra nityadravyeBya ASritatvamihocyate#}
<div n="lb">‘dependence is said (to be the attribute of every thing) ex-
<div n="lb">cept (of) eternal substances. [More frequently used so in
<div n="lb">the Buddhistic than in the Brāhmanic writings, according
<div n="lb">to Burnouf, {%Lotus de la bonne loi,%} II. p. 653.] <sup>6</sup> Without;
<div n="lb">with a noun in the ablative; e. g. {#DenvEva hyupayuktaM tfRAdi#}
<div n="lb">{#kzIrIBavati na prahInamanaquhAdyupayuktaM vA . yadi hi nirnimi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttametatsyAt . DenuSarIrasaMbanDAdanyatrApi tfRAdi kzIrIBavet#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>7</sup> In the contrary case, otherwise; comp. {#anyaTA#} and {#itaratra;#}
<div n="lb">e. g. {#devikAdizu tadAdigrahaRam . anyatra hi tadgrahaRAttadanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaRAdvA#}. E. {#anya,#} vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#tral#}.
<LEND>

<L>4223<pc>141-b<k1>anyatradattAkza<k2>anyatradattAkza
{#anyatradattAkza#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzI-kzam#}) Turning the
<div n="lb">eyes elsewhere, e. g. {#anyEH pravartitAM SaSvatsAvaDAnA ca tatka-#}

<L>4224<pc>141-b<k1>anyatramanas<k2>anyatramanas
{#anyatramanas#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nAH-nAH-naH#}) Having the mind
<div n="lb">directed on another object, absent (mentally). [The passage
<div n="lb">of the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upan. {#anyatramanA aBUvaM nASrOzam#}
<div n="lb">&c. is given as a proof by the Sāṅkhya Pravachana Bh. for
<div n="lb">the orthodoxy of the Sāṅkhya tenet that {#manas#} is capable
<div n="lb">of becoming multifarious.] E. {#anyatra#} and {#manas#}.
<LEND>

<L>4225<pc>141-b<k1>anyatva<k2>anyatva
{#anyatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The being other, otherness, difference
<div n="lb">(the same as {#anyatA,#} but more frequently used as this
<div n="lb">word); e. g. {#anyatve'pyaByAsasyopacArAt#} ‘even if there
<div n="lb">were different (sounds, sound must be permanent) because
<div n="lb">it is possible to repeat it (in teaching)’; also with a noun
<div n="lb">in the ablative, e. g. {#vacanAttu tato'nyatvam#} ‘(if it is main-
<div n="lb">tained that {#itikartavyatA#} refers to profane things, the answer
<div n="lb">is:) but on account of a (distinct vaidik) passage its dif-
<div n="lb">ference from that (is established), i. e. it refers only to sacred
<div n="lb">or vaidik objects’; or {#tayoranyatve tucCatvam#} (comm. {#akA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ryasya prakftipuruzaBinnatve tucCatvam#} &c.).--The word occurs
[Page142-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">for the most part, however, as the latter part of a com-
<div n="lb">pound--e. g. {#sPawikAnyatvABimAnavattadanyatvABimAnaH#}--
<div n="lb">and especially in scientific writings, e. g. in the Vārttikas
<div n="lb">of Pāṇini in compounds as {#aNgAnyatva, kartranyatva, kArakAnyatva,#}
<div n="lb">{#kAlAnyatva,#} in the Vedānta Sūtras as in {#tadananyatva,#} in the
<div n="lb">Mīmānsā S. as in {#prayojanAnyatva, vedAnyatva, rUpAnyatva#} &c.,
<div n="lb">in the Nyāya S. as in {#sTAnAnyatva, karmAnyatva,#} in the Sāṅkhya
<div n="lb">S. {#uBayAnyatva,#} in the Yoga S. as in {#kramAnyatva#} &c. &c. E.
<div n="lb">{#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4226<pc>142-a<k1>anyatvakara<k2>anyatvakara
{#anyatvakara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rI-ram#}) Producing other-
<div n="lb">ness or difference; as species, characteristic properties,
<div n="lb">space. E. {#anyatva#} and {#kara#} ({#kf,#} kṛt aff. {#wa#}).
<LEND>

<L>4227<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTA<k2>anyaTA
{#anyaTA#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> In another manner, differently; e. g. {#kurvanneveha#}
<div n="lb">{#karmARi jijIvizecCataM samAH . evaM tvayi nAnyaTeto'sti na#}
<div n="lb">{#karma lipyate nare;#} or {#vipakzacittonmaTanA naKavraRAstirohitA#}
<div n="lb">{#viBramamaRqanena ye . hftasya SezAniva kuNkumasya tAnvikatTanIyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ndaDuranyaTA striyaH#} ‘…the women made these wounds
<div n="lb">different, i. e. not concealed; they laid them open (comm.:
<div n="lb">{#prakASaM daDurityarTaH#}); or {#tarkApratizWAnAdapyanyaTAnumeyamiti cet#}
<div n="lb">&c.; comp. {#anyaTAnumiti; anyaTA--anyaTA#} ‘in one way
<div n="lb">--in another way’, e. g. {#anyaTA hi prakramante vAjasaneyinaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#anyaTA CandogAH;#} also with a noun depending in the abl.,
<div n="lb">for the most part with {#atas (= asmAt),#} e. g. {#apfzwo'pi#}
<div n="lb">{#hitaM brUyAdyasya necCetparABavam . eza eva satAM Darmo viparI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tamato'nyaTA#}. <sup>2</sup> Otherwise, or else; e. g. {#gaterarTavattvamuBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaTAnyaTA hi viroDaH#} ‘the result of the (divine) way is
<div n="lb">doubtful, otherwise there would be contradiction (with a
<div n="lb">vaidik passage)’; or…{#drazwumaByAgato hyeza Barato nAnya-#}
<div n="lb">{#TAgataH#} ‘…or else he would not have come’; {#gurvagniho-#}
<div n="lb">{#trArTakfte prasTitaSca sutastava . na nivAryo nivAryaH syAdanyaTA#}
<div n="lb">{#prasTito vanam#} ‘…he was not to be prevented or else he
<div n="lb">ought to have been prevented: (but now) he is gone to the
<div n="lb">forest’. Comp. {#anyatra#}. <sup>3</sup> On the other hand, on the contrary;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#asati#} (scil. {#hetO#}) {#pratijYoparoDo yOgapadyamanyaTA#} (comm.:
<div n="lb">{#anyaTA = hetO sati#}). <sup>4</sup> Untruly; e. g. {#yasyocuH sAkziRaH satyAM#}
<div n="lb">{#pratijYAM sa jayI Bavet . anyaTA vAdino yasya Druvastasya parA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jayaH . ukte'pi sAkziBiH sAkzye yadyanye guRavattamAH . dviguRA#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnyaTA brUyuH kUwAH syuH pUrvasAkziRaH#} (comm.: {#anyaTA = vE-#}
<div n="lb">{#parItyena miTyA#}). Comp. also {#anyaTAstotra#}. <sup>5</sup> Badly, wrongly,
<div n="lb">erroneously; comp. {#anyaTAsidDa#} and {#anyaTAsidDi#}. E. {#anya,#}
<div n="lb">vibhakti-taddh. aff. {#TAl#}. Comp. {#itaraTA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4228<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTAkaraRa<k2>anyaTAkaraRa
{#anyaTAkaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Acting to the contrary, doing
<div n="lb">otherwise. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4229<pc>142-a<k1>anyaTAkAra<k2>anyaTAkAra
{#anyaTAkAra#}¦ Tatpur. I. m. ({#-raH#}) Altering, changing, e. g. the
<div n="lb">sense of an expression, by punning on it; {#vakroktO parokte-#}
<div n="lb">{#ranyaTAkAraH#}. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#kAra#}.
<div n="P">II. ind. ({#-ram#}) In another manner, differently; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#anyaTAkAraM BuNkte#} he eats in another manner. [According
<div n="lb">to the Kāśikā on Pāṇini III. 4. 27. {#kAram#} would in this
<div n="lb">case be a kind of expletive or superfluous, the word of the
<div n="lb">Sūtra {#sidDAprayogaH#} being thus commented by it: {#kaTaM puna-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasO sidDAprayogaH . nirarTakatvAnna prayogamarhati . evameva prayu-#}
<div n="lb">{#jyate;#} and similarly the Siddh. K.: {#kfYvyarTatvAtprayogAnarha#}
<div n="lb">{#ityarTaH;#} but Bhaṭṭoji in the Prauḍhaman. is probably more
<div n="lb">correct when he refers to the bearing of the word ({#SAbda-#}
<div n="lb">{#boDa#}) and says, that {#kAram#} effectuates a stronger connexion
[Page142-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">between the verb and the adverb than would be expressed
<div n="lb">without it, when {#sidDAprayoga#} in the Sūtra of Pāṇini would not
<div n="lb">convey the notion of ‘absolute superfluity’ but rather that
<div n="lb">of ‘not excessive necessity’: {#SAbdaboDe tu vElakzaRyamastyeva .#}
<div n="lb">{#taTA hi . kriyAsAmAnyavacanaH karotiH . tadIyaSca prakAro#}
<div n="lb">{#'nyaTAdiSabdacatuzwvenocyate . evaM ca . anyaTAkAramityAdiBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScaturBiH prakAraviSezaviSizwakriyA boDyate . sA ca BuNktePala-#}
<div n="lb">{#viSizwakriyAM prati viSezaRatayA saMbaDyate . ekasyA api kri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAyA viSezaRoparAgeRa BinnAyA viSezaRaviSezyaBAvasaMBavAt .#}
<div n="lb">{#kaTaM tarhi sidDAprayogaScedityuktamiti cet . anatiprayojanatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#diti gfhARa ..#} &c. Patanjali and his comm. give no gloss
<div n="lb">on this Sūtra.] E. {#anyaTA#} and {#kAram#} ({#kf,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>4230<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAkfta<k2>anyaTAkfta

<div n="lb">the sense of a word, by punning on it. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#kfta#}.

<L>4231<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAKyAti<k2>anyaTAKyAti

<L>4241<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAsidDa<k2>anyaTAsidDa
{#anyaTAsidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) I. (In the Vaiśeṣika
<div n="lb">philosophy.) Wrongly established, referred to a cause which
<div n="lb">is not the true cause (as an effect). See {#anyaTAsidDi#} I. E.
<div n="lb">{#anyaTA#} and {#sidDa#}.
<div n="P">II. Not established otherwise, not proved otherwise. See
<div n="lb">{#anyaTAsidDi#} II. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#asidDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4242<pc>142-b<k1>anyaTAsidDatva<k2>anyaTAsidDatva
{#anyaTAsidDatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The same as the following. E. {#anya-#}
<div n="lb">{#TAsidDa,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>
[Page143-a+ 56]

<L>4243<pc>143-a<k1>anyaTAsidDi<k2>anyaTAsidDi
{#anyaTAsidDi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-dDiH#}) I. (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The being wrongly established or the establishing wrongly,
<div n="lb">i. e. the being referred of an effect, or the referring an effect,
<div n="lb">to a cause which is not the true cause. This may happen
<div n="lb">in five ways, viz. <sup>a.</sup> by taking for cause what is prior to
<div n="lb">the effect but only accidental to the real cause ({#‘saha tena’#}),
<div n="lb">as by taking a potter's stick for the cause of a jar; or
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> by taking for cause something inherent to what is ac-
<div n="lb">cidental to the real cause ({#‘yasya’#}), as by taking the shape
<div n="lb">of a potter's stick for the cause of a jar; or <sup>c.</sup> by taking
<div n="lb">for cause what is prior but is known to be the cause of
<div n="lb">another effect ({#‘anyaM prati’#}), as by taking æther for the cause
<div n="lb">of a jar, æther being the known cause of sound; or <sup>d.</sup> by
<div n="lb">taking for cause what is prior but prior in so far only as
<div n="lb">the real cause is produced by it ({#‘janakaM prati’#}), as by tak-
<div n="lb">ing the potter's father for the cause of a jar; or <sup>e.</sup> by taking
<div n="lb">for cause any thing foreign to the effect ({#‘atiriktam’#}), as
<div n="lb">by taking the donkey carrying the earth of which the jar is
<div n="lb">made, for the cause of the jar. The last error comprises,
<div n="lb">indeed, in its generality all the preceding and is therefore
<div n="lb">called {#‘AvaSyaka’,#} the absolute error. E. {#anyaTA#} and {#sidDi#}.
<div n="P">II. Not being established or proved otherwise; in the Sān-
<div n="lb">khya Sūtra: {#uBayatrApyanyaTAsidDerna pratyakzamanumAnaM vA#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#uBayatrApi vESizwyapratyakze tadanumAne ca svarUpeREvAnyaTAsidDerna#}
<div n="lb">{#taduBayaM samavAye pramARamityarTaH . ayaM BAvaH . yaTA samavAyavE-#}
<div n="lb">{#SizwyabudDirapi guRAdisvarUpeREvezyatAm . atastatrApi pratyakzA-#}
<div n="lb">{#numAne'nyaTAsidDe#} &c.). E. {#anyaTA#} and {#asidDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4244<pc>143-a<k1>anyaTAstotra<k2>anyaTAstotra
{#anyaTAstotra#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tram#}) Untrue or ironical praise, a
<div n="lb">sneer; as saying to a deformed man ‘thou art a handsome
<div n="lb">one’ (comm.: {#yatra vikftAkftireva darSanIyastvamasItyucyate .#}
<div n="lb">{#tadanyaTAstotram#}). E. {#anyaTA#} and {#stotra#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#yitvA kaTaMcana . yadi SlezeRAnyaTA vA'nyaTayetsApyapahnutiH#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#anyaTA,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}.
<LEND>

<L>4248<pc>143-a<k1>anyadarTa<k2>anyadarTa
{#anyadarTa#}¦ I. Karmadh. m. ({#-rTaH#}) Another sense &c.

<div n="P">III. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) Having another sense
<div n="lb">&c. (see the meanings of {#arTa#}). Comp. also {#anyArTa#} and see
<div n="lb">{#anya#}. E. {#anya,#} āgama {#duk,#} and {#arTa#}.

<L>4249<pc>143-a<k1>anyadA<k2>anyadA
{#anyadA#}¦ I. ind. At another time; e. g. {#anyadA BUzaRaM puMsaH kzamA#}
<div n="lb">{#lajjeva yozitaH . parAkramaH pariBave vEyAtyaM suratezviva#} (where
<div n="lb">{#anyadA#} is opposed first to {#pariBave#} and then to {#suratezu#} and
<div n="lb">therefore must not be taken in a general sense ‘sometimes’
<div n="lb">--which it has not--but in the sense ‘at another time
<div n="lb">than that of defeat’, ‘at another time than that of amorous
<div n="lb">sport’; comm.: {#anyadA suratavyatirikte kAle yozito lajjeva#}
<div n="lb">{#puMso'nyadA apariBave Samo BUzaRaM pariBave tu yozitaH suratezu#}
<div n="lb">{#vEyAtyaM DArzwyamiva#}); or {#BartA tu yadA durBikze strIDanaM vinA#}
<div n="lb">{#vartanAkzamastadApi grahItumarhati nAnyadA#} ‘when the husband at
<div n="lb">a time of dearth cannot support himself without the property
[Page143-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">of his wife, he may take it, not {%at another time%}’. <sup>2</sup> At one
<div n="lb">time, once. Compare {#anyadina#}. E. {#anya,#} vibhakti-taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#dA#}. See the Preface.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. f. ({#-dA#}) A virtuous wife. [According to a
<div n="lb">comm. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya: {#anyezAM patiSvaSurAdInAM dA Su-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDiryAByastAH#} (acc. plur. in the passage referred to) {#anyadAH#}
<div n="lb">{#sADvIrityarTaH#}.] Comp. {#anyadIya#}. E. {#anya#} and {#dA#} (from {#dE,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#kvip#}).
<LEND>

<L>4253<pc>143-b<k1>anyadAsTita<k2>anyadAsTita

<L>4254<pc>143-b<k1>anyadina<k2>anyadina

<L>4255<pc>143-b<k1>anyadIya<k2>anyadIya
{#anyadIya#}¦ I. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Being in another (Kāśikā
<div n="lb">= {#anyasminBava#}). <sup>2</sup> Belonging to another (Kāśikā = {#anyasye-#}
<div n="lb">{#dam#}); e. g. {#anyadIyasyAdattasya grahItA na syAt#} (scil. {#dvijaH#});
<div n="lb">also used in the same sense as the genitive of {#anya#} ‘of an-
<div n="lb">other’; e. g. {#anyadIyapAWamAkarRya svayaM vA SAstramAkalpya ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#jjYAnaM jAyate taditi;#} or {#parasvAnyArjayannArIranyadIyAH parA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mfSan#}. E. {#anya,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} and āgama {#duk;#} see s. v. {#anya#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-yA#}) A virtuous wife. [This interpretation of the
<div n="lb">word is given, besides the usual one ‘wife of another’ (see
<div n="lb">meaning I.), by a comm. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya who after
<div n="lb">having explained the meaning and etym. of {#anyadA#} II. q. v.
<div n="lb">adds: {#tataH#} (i. e. from {#anyadA,#} a virtuous wife) {#svArTe IyaH#}.]
<div n="lb">E. {#anyadA#} II., taddh. aff. {#Ca#}.
<LEND>

<L>4263<pc>144-a<k1>anyadEvata<k2>anyadEvata

<L>4265<pc>144-a<k1>anyaDarma<k2>anyaDarma

<div n="lb">another, of something else.

<div n="lb">ferent qualities or characteristics. See the following. E.
<div n="lb">{#anya#} and {#Darma#}.

<L>4266<pc>144-a<k1>anyaDarmatva<k2>anyaDarmatva

<div n="lb">being another quality or characteristic. E. {#anyaDarma,#} taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#tva#}.

<L>4271<pc>144-a<k1>anyapadArTa<k2>anyapadArTa
{#anyapadArTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rTaH#}) (In Grammar.) The sense of
<div n="lb">another word; this term is used by Pāṇini and his com-
<div n="lb">mentators to qualify the nature of a {%Bahuvrihi%} compound
<div n="lb">which always depends on, or refers to, the meaning of an-
<div n="lb">other word, the word {#anyapadArTa#} being thus used in contra-
<div n="lb">distinction of {#svapadArTa;#} e. g. Patanjali: {#aTAnyagrahaRaM kima-#}
<div n="lb">{#rTam . anekaM padArTe . itIyatyucyamAne svapadArTe'pi bahuvrIhiH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt . rAjapuruzaH . takzapuruza iti nEtadasti prayojanam . tatpu-#}
<div n="lb">{#ruzaH svapadArTe bADako Bavizyati . ;#} Kaiyyaṭa: {#aTAnyagrahaRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti . antaraNgatvAtsvapadArTe samAse sidDe padArTagrahaRasAmarTyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyapadArTo lapsyata iti praSnaH . svapadArTe'pIti . apiSabdA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyapadArTe'pItyarTaH . padArTagrahaRaM vyAptisamASrayaRArTaM syA-#}
<div n="lb">{#diti svapadArTAnyapadArTayoH samAsaH syAt . tatpuruza iti .#}
<div n="lb">{#bahuvrIhestvanyapadArTo'vakASaH#}. [This word occurs only as
<div n="lb">a Tatpurusha. The quotation {#anyapadArTo bahuvrIhiH#} which
<div n="lb">is printed somewhere, is a misreading for {#anyapadArTapraDA-#}
<div n="lb">{#no#} &c. See the following.] E. {#anya-pada#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4272<pc>144-a<k1>anyapadArTapraDAna<k2>anyapadArTapraDAna
{#anyapadArTapraDAna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-naH#}) (In Grammar.) Essentially
<div n="lb">qualified by, or essentially resting on the sense of another
<div n="lb">word, viz. a {%Bahuvrīhi%} (see the preceding); in contradis-
<div n="lb">tinction from {#pUrvapadArTapraDAna,#} the quality of an {%Avyayībhāva,%}
<div n="lb">{#uttarapadArTapraDAna,#} the quality of a {%Tatpurusha,%} and {#uBaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#padArTapraDAna,#} the quality of a {%Dwandwa%} (Patanjali: {#iha ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScitsamAsaH pUrvapadArTapraDAnaH . kaSciduttarapadArTapraDAnaH . ka-#}
[Page144-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#ScidanyapadArTapraDAnaH . kaSciduBayapadArTapraDAnaH . pUrvapadArTapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAno'vyayIBAvaH . uttarapadArTapraDAnastatpuruzaH . anyapadArTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#praDAno bahuvrIhiH . uBayapadArTapraDAno dvandvaH ..#}). E. {#anya-#}
<div n="lb">{#padArTa#} and {#praDAna;#} scil. {#samAsa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4273<pc>144-b<k1>anyapadArTapraDAnatA<k2>anyapadArTapraDAnatA

<div n="lb">ponderance of the sense of another word, viz. in a Bahuvr.;

<L>4274<pc>144-b<k1>anyapadArTaprADAnya<k2>anyapadArTaprADAnya

<L>4275<pc>144-b<k1>anyapara<k2>anyapara

<div n="lb">something else for one's object (e. g. of worship). (Comp. the
<div n="lb">following.) <sup>2</sup> Expressing something else, having another
<div n="lb">sense, e. g. figurative speech; e. g. {#BedO Dvanerapi dvAvudIritO#}
<div n="lb">{#lakzaRABiDAmUlA . avivakzitavAcyo'nyo vivakzitAnyaparavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#cyaSca .#} (comm. on the latter word: {#vAcyaM vivakzitam . anya-#}

<L>4277<pc>144-b<k1>anyapuzwa<k2>anyapuzwa
{#anyapuzwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-zwaH-zwA#}) The Kokila or Indian cuckoo
<div n="lb">(supposed to be reared by a crow). Comp. {#kAkapuzwa, anya-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bfta, anyavApa;#} e. g. {#uditEranyapuzwAnAmArutErme hftaM manaH . u-#}
<div n="lb">{#ditErapi te dUti mArutErapi dakziREH ..#}. E. {#anya#} and {#puzwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4278<pc>144-b<k1>anyapUrvA<k2>anyapUrvA
{#anyapUrvA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-vA#}) A woman who has been given to,
<div n="lb">or has had intercourse with, another man than the one to
<div n="lb">whom she is married; this may be the case if she is either
<div n="lb">a {#punarBU#} or a {#svEriRI;#} as a {#punarBU#} (q. v.) again, she had either
<div n="lb">ceased to be a virgin before the nuptial ceremonies, or she
<div n="lb">had remained a virgin and become blemished through the
<div n="lb">repeated celebration of the marriage ceremonies; she is
<div n="lb">{#svEriRI#} or licentious, if she leaves her husband and goes,
<div n="lb">out of lust, to a man of the same caste. A woman, how-
<div n="lb">ever, is not considered to be a {#punarBU,#} if she is left without
<div n="lb">a son and, by order of her Guru, is approached, for the
<div n="lb">sake of getting a son, by her brother-in-law, or a relative
<div n="lb">of the class of the Sapiṇḍas or a man of the same Gotra,
<div n="lb">either of them having been previously anointed with clari-
<div n="lb">fied butter. (According to the Mitākṣara as founded on
<div n="lb">Yājnavalkya; Manu applies the term {#parapUrvA,#} the same as
<div n="lb">{#anyapUrvA,#} only to the licentious woman who leaves her hus-
<div n="lb">band for another man; Nārada uses the synonymous term
<div n="lb">{#parapUrvA#} in a similar manner as the Mitākṣara {#anyapUrvA,#} but
<div n="lb">divides the {#punarBU#} into three and the {#svEriRI#} into four cate-
<div n="lb">gories; for according to him a {#punarBU#} may be either a virgin-
<div n="lb">woman who is blemished by having gone through the mar-
<div n="lb">riage ceremonies for a second time, or a woman who first
<div n="lb">has been given to one and then on account of her love, to
<div n="lb">another, or a woman who, in want of a brother-in-law,
<div n="lb">is given by her relations to a Sapiṇḍa-relative of the same
<div n="lb">caste; a {#svEriRI#} a woman, whether having had children or
[Page145-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">not, who, while her husband is alive, goes to another from
<div n="lb">lust, or a woman who leaves her infant husband for another
<div n="lb">man and later returns to the house of her husband; or a
<div n="lb">woman who after the death of her husband slights her brother-
<div n="lb">in-law and the other relations (she may approach) and goes
<div n="lb">from lust to another man, or lastly, a woman who has come
<div n="lb">from the country and, purchased with money, under the
<div n="lb">pressure of hunger and thirst gives herself up to another
<div n="lb">man. E. {#anya#} and {#pUrva;#} scil. {#strI#}.
<LEND>

<div n="P">II. Karmadh. m. ({#-vaH#}) Another condition &c. (see the

<L>4293<pc>145-a<k1>anyalakzaRopapatti<k2>anyalakzaRopapatti
{#anyalakzaRopapatti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) The taking place (of some-
[Page145-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">thing) in consequence of the symptom i. e. the existence (of
<div n="lb">something else) being found somewhere else; in a Nyāya
<div n="lb">Sūtra, where the possibility of non-existence is argued from
<div n="lb">the circumstance that the existence of the counter-entity
<div n="lb">might be elsewhere: {#asatyarTe nABAva iti cennAnyalakzaRopapatteH#}
<div n="lb">‘if (you say that there is) no non-existence since the thing
<div n="lb">is not, it is not so, for (non-existence) might be, since (the
<div n="lb">counter-entity) might exist elsewhere’. E. {#anya#} (in the sense
<div n="lb">of a locative) {#-lakzaRa#} (of an instrum.) and {#upapatti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4302<pc>145-b<k1>anyavikrIta<k2>anyavikrIta
{#anyavikrIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Sold by another
<div n="lb">(applied to property which has been sold without owner-
<div n="lb">ship; comp. {#asvAmivikrIta#}). E. {#anya#} and {#vikrIta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4303<pc>145-b<k1>anyavIjaja<k2>anyavIjaja
{#anyavIjaja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) Liter. born from another's seed, i. e.
<div n="lb">a boy who may be adopted as a son in want of a legitimate
<div n="lb">son (see {#Orasa#}) and become heir to the property, but who
<div n="lb">remains nevertheless the son of his real father; such sub-
<div n="lb">stituted sons are the following eleven, each succeeding being
<div n="lb">inferior in degree to each preceding (according to the order
<div n="lb">assigned to them by Manu): the {#kzetraja, datrima#} (or {#dattaka#}), {#kf-#}
<div n="lb">{#trima, gUQotpanna#} (or {#gUQaja#}), {#apavidDa, kAnIna, sahoQa#} (or {#sahoQaja#}),
<div n="lb">{#krItaka#} (or {#krIta#}), {#pOnarBava, svayaMdatta#} and {#pAraSava#} qq. vv. See
<div n="lb">also {#anyavIjotpanna, anyavIjasamudBava, anyaSAKodBava, dvyAmu-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyAyaRa#} and {#putrapraticCandaka, putrapratiniDi#}. E. {#anya-vIja#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>
[Page146-a+ 56]

<L>4304<pc>146-a<k1>anyavIjasamudBava<k2>anyavIjasamudBava
{#anyavIjasamudBava#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The same as the preceding.
<div n="lb">E. {#anya-vIja#} and {#samudBava#}.
<LEND>

<L>4305<pc>146-a<k1>anyavIjotpanna<k2>anyavIjotpanna
{#anyavIjotpanna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-nnaH#}) The same as {#anyavIjaja#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anya-vIja#} and {#utpanna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4306<pc>146-a<k1>anyavrata<k2>anyavrata
{#anyavrata#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-taH#}) One who has other vows or fol-
<div n="lb">lows other practices. The vaidik commentators explain
<div n="lb">the word according to where it occurs either ‘one whose
<div n="lb">practices are different from those enjoined by the sacred
<div n="lb">books i. e. impious, a demon’ or ‘one whose practices are
<div n="lb">different from human practices i. e. the Supreme Spirit’.
<div n="lb">E. {#anya#} and {#vrata#}.
<LEND>

<L>4307<pc>146-a<k1>anyaSAKaka<k2>anyaSAKaka
{#anyaSAKaka#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A Brāhmaṇa who has been
<div n="lb">abandonned by his school (comm. = {#svakIyaSAKArahitaH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> One who has been given up by his own family (comm.
<div n="lb">{#atra SAKASabdaH pakzAntare saMtativiSezArTaH#}); comp. the follow-
<div n="lb">ing. E. {#anya#} and {#SAKA,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">vaidik school). E. {#anya-SAKA#} and {#udBava#}.
<LEND>

<L>4309<pc>146-a<k1>anyasaNgama<k2>anyasaNgama

<div n="lb">course with another wife than one's own (in the latter
<div n="lb">meaning the word deserves notice for the shortening of
<div n="lb">{#anyA#} to {#anya#}); e. g. {#nirAsa BfNgaM kupiteva pahminI na mAni-#}

<L>4311<pc>146-a<k1>anyasAmAnya<k2>anyasAmAnya

<L>4312<pc>146-a<k1>anyasfzwi<k2>anyasfzwi
{#anyasfzwi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-zwiH#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) The
<div n="lb">evolution (of Pradhāna or Matter) for the sake of another
<div n="lb">(i. e. Purusha or Soul) viz., after one Purusha has been liber-
<div n="lb">ated: {#anyasfzwyuparAge'pi na virajyate prabudDarajjutattvasyevoragaH#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#anya#} and {#sfzwi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4313<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrI<k2>anyastrI
{#anyastrI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-strI#}) A woman not one's own. [In
<div n="lb">Rhetoric she is one of the three categories of the principal
<div n="lb">female character in a poetical composition (the two other
<div n="lb">being {#svastrI#} or {#svIyA#} and {#sADAraRastrI#} or {#sAmAnyanAyikA#}
<div n="lb">qq. vv.; the {#anyastrI#} or {#parakIyA#} is either ‘another's wife’
<div n="lb">or a ‘damsel’; as ‘another's wife’ ‘she is fond of festivals
<div n="lb">and the like opportunities, is a disgrace to her family, bare
<div n="lb">of modesty’; the ‘damsel’ is ‘one not yet married, bashful
<div n="lb">and arrived at the period of youth’. Each of these two
<div n="lb">has again eight subdivisions; ‘she may be one who has an
<div n="lb">obsequious lover, or one who is ill-treated, or one who
<div n="lb">goes after her lover, or one who is separated from him by a
<div n="lb">quarrel, or one who is neglected, or one whose lover is abroad,
<div n="lb">or one who is prepared in her house to receive him, or one
<div n="lb">who is longing in absence of her lover’). E. {#anya#} and {#strI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4314<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrIga<k2>anyastrIga
{#anyastrIga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) An adulterer. E. {#anyastrI#} and {#ga#}.
<LEND>

<L>4315<pc>146-a<k1>anyastrIputrotpAdaka<k2>anyastrIputrotpAdaka

<LEND>
[Page146-b+ 56]

<L>4316<pc>146-b<k1>anyA<k2>anyA
{#anyA#}.¦ The feminine of {#anya#} ‘other, different’ &c. q. v. This
<div n="lb">word deserves notice only from the circumstance that it oc-
<div n="lb">curs in some vaidik passages with the udātta accent on the
<div n="lb">first syllable, instead of having this accent on the last syllable.
<div n="lb">[Sāyaṇa is not the author of the meaning ‘never drying-up’
<div n="lb">and of an etym. ‘{#a#} and {#nyA,#} contracted of {#ni-yA#}’ which have
<div n="lb">been lent to this word by a new kind of vaidik exegesis.]
<LEND>

<L>4317<pc>146-b<k1>anyAda<k2>anyAda

<div n="lb">less; e. g. {#AdareRa gamaM cakrurvizamezvapyasaMGasAH . vyApnuvanto#}
<div n="lb">{#diSo'nyAdAnkurvantaH savyaDAnharIn#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#nyAda#}.

<L>4318<pc>146-b<k1>anyAdfkza<k2>anyAdfkza
{#anyAdfkza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) The same as {#anyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dfS#}. [This word is given on the authority of the Siddhānta
<div n="lb">Kaum. fol. 181 a. 1. 14. ed. Calc. and on that of Durgādāsa's
<div n="lb">comm. on Vopadeva 26. 83. 85; it is not mentioned, however,
<div n="lb">in the commentaries of the Dhātupāṭhas, nor by the author
<div n="lb">of the Kāśikā who in his gloss on a Vārttika to Pāṇ. III.
<div n="lb">2. 60. gives only the words: {#tAdfkza, yAdfkza, Idfkza#} and {#kIdfkza;#}
<div n="lb">Patanjali and his commentators do not even speak of the
<div n="lb">Vārttika on which the Kāś. has founded {#tAdfkza#} &c., the
<div n="lb">only word of a similar formation, viz. {#sadfkza,#} being men-
<div n="lb">tioned by Patanjali in his gloss on a Vārtt. to Pāṇ. VI.
<div n="lb">3. 89. It will appear therefore, that {#anyAdfkza#} does not belong
<div n="lb">to the older period of the classical Sanskṛt.] E. {#anya#} and {#dfkza#}
<div n="lb">({#dfS,#} kṛt aff. {#ksa#}) with the prolongation of the middle vowel.
<LEND>

<L>4324<pc>146-b<k1>anyAya<k2>anyAya

<div n="lb">especially in philosophical Sūtras; e. g. in the Mīmānsā Sū-

<div n="lb">justice, an unlawful act; e. g. {#nyAyApetaM yadanyena rAjYA jYAna-#}

<div n="lb">{#asyAM damayantyAmanyAyaM parastryaBilAzalakzaRamanASaNkya#} &c.); or

<L>4357<pc>148-a<k1>anyonya<k2>anyo'nya
{#anyo'nya#}¦ (usually written {#anyonya#}) Tatpur. (see {#sarvanAman#})
<div n="lb">1. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam,#} not. {#anyonyad;#} in the other cases
<div n="lb">it follows the declension of {#anya#} q. v.) One-another, mutual.--
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> The verb in connexion with {#anyonya#} stands (acc. to Pāṇ.) in
<div n="lb">the Parasmaipada, not in the Ātmanepada; e. g. {#anyonyasya#}
<div n="lb">{#vyatipunanti, anyonyasya vyatilunanti#}.--<sup>b.</sup> If {#anyonya#} refers
<div n="lb">to the subject of the sentence and the subject is a mascu-
<div n="lb">line, it is possible to consider it as consisting of two dis-
<div n="lb">tinct not compound words {#anya,#} the former being a nomi-
<div n="lb">native as attribute to the subject, while the latter assumes
<div n="lb">the case required by the sentence (see the Etym.); e. g.
<div n="lb">{#anyo'nyamAhvayantO tu mattAviva mahAgajO;#} or {#te'nyonyamaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMsftya kzipanto nAmaBirmiTaH;#} or {#…kapirAkzasAH . anyo'nyenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByasUyanta vimardamasahanta ca;#} or in sentences in which the gerond
<div n="lb">is used elliptically; e. g. {#tAByAmanyo'nyamAsAdya samavApyata saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#SamaH#}.--<sup>c.</sup> There are however many instances in which
<div n="lb">{#anyonya#} does not refer to the subject, or in which it is the
<div n="lb">attribute of a subject which is not a masculine and there-
<div n="lb">fore cannot be looked upon otherwise than as a compound;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#anyonyena kftam;#} or {#anyonyasmE dattam;#} or {#anyonyezAM pu-#}
<div n="lb">{#zkarErAmfSanto dAnodBedAduccakErBugnavAlAH;#} or as an attribute
<div n="lb">of a neuter {#prItyaprItivizAdAdyErguRAnAmanyonyaM vEDarmyam;#} and
<div n="lb">the same must be observed of all the words in which {#anyonya#}
<div n="lb">is the first part of a compound; comp. e. g. the following
<div n="lb">articles and {#anyonyatas#}. <sup>d.</sup> {#anyonyam#} is frequently used ad-
<div n="lb">verbially, e. g. {#yadyapyAtmanAmanyonyaM BedavAkyavadaBedavAkyAnyapi#}
<div n="lb">{#santi taTApi nAdvEtaM nAtyantamaBedaH.--anyonyam#} or {#anyonyAm#}
<div n="lb">are used optionally in the sense of an accusative, if the
<div n="lb">subject to which they refer is either a feminine or a neuter;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#anyonyamime brAhmaRyO BojayataH#} or--{#anyonyAM BojayataH;#}
<div n="lb">{#anyonyamime brAhmaRakule BojayataH#} or--{#anyonyAM BojayataH;#}
<div n="lb">these are the instances given by Patanjali on the Vārttika
<div n="lb">12 to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12, and because they show either word
<div n="lb">as representing in meaning the accus. of {#anyonya,#} some
<div n="lb">grammarians (‘of the East’, according to the Prauḍhama-
<div n="lb">noramā on the same rule) contend that the option is re-
<div n="lb">stricted to the meaning of this case, but that {#anyonyam#} alone
<div n="lb">is admissible when expressing adverbially the sense of the
<div n="lb">other cases. Others, on the contrary, maintain that the quoted
<div n="lb">words are intended by Patanjali merely as an instance and
<div n="lb">that the option extends also to sentences in which {#anyonyam#}
<div n="lb">would imply the sense of an instrumental &c. Bhaṭṭoji, re-
<div n="lb">ferring in the Siddh. Kaum. on the quoted rule to Patanjali's
<div n="lb">gloss on the 5th Bhāṣyakārikā to Pāṇ. IV. 1. 3, sides with
<div n="lb">the former opinion. (Prauḍham. {#yadapi tftIyAdizu puMvaditi#}
<div n="lb">{#prAco granTaM vyAcakzARA AhuH . tftIyAdizu puMvadBAvaviSezaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tena wAp na . atra tftIyAdizvavivakzitam . dvitIyAyAmapi puM-#}
[Page148-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#vattvasyezwatvAditi . taccintyam . puMvattvaM viSeza iti viSezABiDA-#}
<div n="lb">{#namavivakzitamiti ca svokteH . parasparavyADAt . mUlakftA puMva-#}
<div n="lb">{#dBAvasyAspfzwatvAt . tadgranTasyAYjasyenEva vyAKyAtatvAcceti dik ..#});
<div n="lb">Jayamangala, however (in the printed ed. of the Bhaṭṭikāvya)
<div n="lb">differs materially from either of the quoted authorities; for in
<div n="lb">his comment on Bhaṭṭik. 8. 6. he not merely quotes apparently
<div n="lb">a Vārttika which varies in important points from that of Pa-
<div n="lb">tanjali, but justifies {#anyonyam#} of the text by adding: {#strInapuM-#}
<div n="lb">{#sakayorAmaBAva iti vaktavyam#} ‘if the subject is a feminine or a
<div n="lb">neuter, the form {#anyonyAm#} is not admissible’ (the subject of
<div n="lb">the commented sentence being {#udanvAn#} and the femin. {#rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzasI#}); yet the correctness of the printed text alluded to is
<div n="lb">very doubtful; for the E. I. H. Ms. 544 reads this comm. thus:
<div n="lb">{#anyonyamityAdi . anyonyamityasyetyarTaH . karmavyatIhAre sarvanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mnI dvirBavataH . samAsavacca bahulam . yadA samAsavattadA pUrvapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dasya praTamEkavacanam . uttarapadasyAmBAva iti vAcyam . anyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyasaMbanDiBiH SabdEH#} &c. &c. (Comp. also the comm. on Bhaṭṭ.
<div n="lb">1. 21.)--As regards the classical literature there can be no
<div n="lb">doubt that the adverbial use of {#anyonyam#} prevails almost ex-
<div n="lb">clusively over that of {#anyonyAm#}. <sup>e.</sup> The Gaṇaratnamaho-
<div n="lb">dadhi (which mentions {#anyonya#} among the {#sarvanAman#} q. v.) gives
<div n="lb">{#anyonyasya#} in the Gaṇa {#cAdi,#} imparting to the genitive the
<div n="lb">value of an adverb or that of {#anyonyam;#} but the instance,
<div n="lb">Vardhamāna gives in his comm. on this work, {#‘anyonyasya#}
<div n="lb">{#smaranti’#} is not happy, as the genitive could be the legitimate
<div n="lb">government of {#smaranti; ‘anyonyasya Bojayanti’,#} the instance
<div n="lb">of the Kāśikā to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12. Vārtt. 11; {#‘anyonyasya vya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tipunanti’#} of Patanjali to Pāṇ. III. 1. 16. and {#‘anyonyasya#}
<div n="lb">{#vyatilunanti’#} of the Kāś. to the same rule, seem more to the
<div n="lb">purpose; but the occurence of the genitive in the sense of
<div n="lb">other cases is, in general, rare.--Comp. {#itaretara#} and {#paraspara#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-nyam#}) (In Rhetoric.) An {#alaMkAra#} q. v. or mode
<div n="lb">of elegant expression; viz. conveying the mutual relation
<div n="lb">or intimacy of two objects by representing them as the
<div n="lb">mutual cause of the same action ({#‘arTayorekakriyAmuKena#}
<div n="lb">{#parasparaM kAraRatve satyanyonyaM nAmAlaMkAraH’#}), e. g. ‘she shineth
<div n="lb">through thee and thou shinest through her, like as the
<div n="lb">moon shineth through the night and the night shineth through
<div n="lb">the moon’. E. {#anyas#} and {#anya#}. [The oldest grammatical
<div n="lb">authorities do not consider {#anyonya#} as a compound, but
<div n="lb">take {#anyonyena#} and other cases as consisting of the two dis-
<div n="lb">tinct words: the nomin. of {#anya#} and the instrum. of {#anya#}
<div n="lb">&c.; see Vārtt. 11 to Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 12. and the remark of
<div n="lb">Kaiyyaṭa: {#tatra bahulagrahaRAdanyonyaSabde samAsavadBAvABAvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tsubluNga Bavati . nApi samAsAntodAttatvamityAmreqitAnudA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttatvaM Bavati#} (comp. Pāṇ. VIII. 1. 3); but it results from the
<div n="lb">foregoing statement that this etym. cannot be entertained.
<div n="lb">Jayamangala on the Bhaṭṭikāvya 17. 8. appears to consider
<div n="lb">{#anyonya#} not as a Tatpur., but as Karmadh. (in explaining
<div n="lb">{#anyonyam#} by {#‘anyasya anyasya’#}), probably in thinking of Pāṇ.
<div n="lb">VIII. 1. 11. which applies to VIII. 1. 12; but the possibility
<div n="lb">of this application is removed by the quoted words of
<div n="lb">Kaiyyaṭa and by the general remark he appends to the
<div n="lb">Vārttikas of VIII. 1. 12, viz. {#vArtikezu karmaDArayavaditi na#}
<div n="lb">{#saMbaDyata iti sublopAdi na Bavati#}. A modern theory takes
<div n="lb">{#anyonya#} for a compound (it does not say which), but calls
[Page149-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the former part of this word a ‘benumbed’ nominative. It
<div n="lb">seems, however, that the sense and accent of the word (it is
<div n="lb">udātta on the second syllable) decide in the first place for
<div n="lb">its being a Tatpur., and secondly its form, that it belongs
<div n="lb">to that class of compounds in which the former part has
<div n="lb">received a further developement by means of an affix {#s,#}
<div n="lb">the function of which {#s#} apparently consists in producing a
<div n="lb">stronger relation between the two parts of the compound and
<div n="lb">consequently a more intense unity of notion, than would be
<div n="lb">expressed without this {#s;#} comp. e. g. the derivatives of
<div n="lb">{#sam-kf#} and {#saMs-kf, pari-kf#} and {#pariz-kf, apa-kF#} and {#apas-#}
<div n="lb">{#kF; A-carya#} and {#AS-carya, apa-kara#} and {#apas-kara#} &c. and
<div n="lb">such words as {#hariS-candra, ajas-tunda, bfhas-pati, prAyaS-#}
<div n="lb">{#citti#} &c. &c. (comp. Pāṇ. VI. 1. 135-157.) which resemble closely
<div n="lb">in formation {#anyo'nya#} (and the synon. {#paraspara#}); the accent of
<div n="lb">this word would then fall under the category of Pāṇ. VI. 2. 2.]
<LEND>

<L>4358<pc>149-a<k1>anyonyakfta<k2>anyonyakfta

<L>4359<pc>149-a<k1>anyonyajanana<k2>anyonyajanana
{#anyonyajanana#}¦ Tatpur. (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) 1. n. ({#-nam#})
<div n="lb">The producing each other; see the following.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-naH#}) Producing each other; a condition of the
<div n="lb">three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and {#tamas#} qq. vv. ‘as a
<div n="lb">lump of clay produces a jar’; comp. also {#anyonyamiTuna, a-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyonyABiBava, anyonyASraya, anyonyavftti#}. [In the Sāṅkhya-
<div n="lb">kārikā v. 12, where these terms occur {#‘anyonyABiBavASraya-#}
<div n="lb">{#jananamiTunavfttayaSca guRAH’#} Vāchaspati combines {#vftti#} with
<div n="lb">each of the former and analyses therefore {#anyonyABiBavavftti#}
<div n="lb">&c., while Gauḍapāda takes {#anyonyavftti#} for a separate con-
<div n="lb">dition.] E. {#anyonya#} and {#janana#}.
<LEND>

<L>4362<pc>149-a<k1>anyonyatyAgin<k2>anyonyatyAgin

<div n="lb">{#tAnyonyatyAgI ca SatadaRqaBAk#} (Yājn. 2. 237, which verse how-

<L>4366<pc>149-a<k1>anyonyamiTuna<k2>anyonyamiTuna
{#anyonyamiTuna#}¦ (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) I. Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#})
<div n="lb">Mutual copulation or union (see the following).
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-naH#}) Consorting or joining mutually; a
<div n="lb">condition of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and
<div n="lb">{#tamas#} qq. vv.; i. e. ‘they consort like males and females;
[Page149-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%sattwa%} consorts with {%rajas, rajas%} with {%sattwa,%} and {%tamas%}
<div n="lb">with {%rajas%} and {%sattwa%}’. Compare the following and {#anyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyajanana#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#miTuna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4367<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyamiTunavftti<k2>anyonyamiTunavftti

<div n="lb">preceding and {#anyonyajanana#}. E. {#anyonyamiTuna#} (I.) and {#vftti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4368<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyaviBAga<k2>anyonyaviBAga
{#anyonyaviBAga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) (In Law.) Mutual partition
<div n="lb">made by the sharers of an inheritance without the presence
<div n="lb">of any other persons. E. {#anyonya#} and {#viBAga#}.
<LEND>

<L>4369<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyavftti<k2>anyonyavftti
{#anyonyavftti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-ttiH#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">One calling the other into action, reciprocally causing each
<div n="lb">other to act; a condition of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva,#}
<div n="lb">{#rajas#} and {#tamas#} qq. vv.; i. e. ‘one being or acting in the
<div n="lb">other; as a handsome and well behaved woman is at the
<div n="lb">same time a source of delight to every one else and one of
<div n="lb">misery to the other wives of her husband, as well as one
<div n="lb">of bewilderment to enamoured damsels, in the same manner
<div n="lb">{%sattwa%} calls into existence {%rajas%} and {%tamas%} &c.’, other similes
<div n="lb">being used to illustrate that {%rajas%} causes the action of {%sattwa%}
<div n="lb">and {%tamas,%} and {%tamas%} that of {%sattwa%} and {%rajas.%} (Vāchaspati
<div n="lb">does not recognise this condition of the three qualities;
<div n="lb">see {#anyonyajanana#}.) E. {#anyonya#} and {#vftti#}.
<LEND>

<L>4370<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyavEra<k2>anyonyavEra
{#anyonyavEra#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) Mutual enmity.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Hostile one to the other,
<div n="lb">hating each other; e. g. {#lokaH…anyonyavEraH suKaleSahetora-#}
<div n="lb">{#nantaduHKaM ca na veda mUQaH#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#vEra#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">ferently coloured rays on each other: {#anyonyavyatikaracAru-#}
<div n="lb">{#BirvicitrEratrasyannavamaRijanmaBirmayUKEH#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#vyatikara#}.

<L>4373<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyasaMSraya<k2>anyonyasaMSraya

<div n="lb">cause and effect; e. g. {#anyonyasaMSrayaM tvetatpratyakzeRa viruDyate#}

<L>4374<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyasaMyoga<k2>anyonyasaMyoga

<div n="lb">however to be a poetical liberty in Bhaṭṭik. 8. 61, instead of

<L>4376<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyasApekza<k2>anyonyasApekza

<L>4377<pc>149-b<k1>anyonyahastakalita<k2>anyonyahastakalita
{#anyonyahastakalita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Held reci-
<div n="lb">procally in (his several) hands. This word occurs in an
<div n="lb">example of permutation, given in the Līlavatī, where the
[Page150-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">question is put, ‘how many are the variations of form of
<div n="lb">the god Śiva by the exchange of his ten attributes held reci-
<div n="lb">procally in his hands viz. the rope, the elephant's hook &c.,
<div n="lb">as those of Viṣṇu by the exchange of the mace &c.?’ (the
<div n="lb">practical purpose apparently being to know the number of
<div n="lb">variations that may be effected in the representation of the
<div n="lb">idol): {#pASANkuSAhiqamarUkakapAlaSUlEH . KawvANgaSaktiSaracA-#}
<div n="lb">{#payutErBavanti . anyonyahastakalitEH kati mUrtiBedAH SamBorhareriva#}
<div n="lb">{#gadArisarojaSaNKEH#} (The answer is in the case of Śiva:
<div n="lb">3628800; in that of Viṣṇu: 24; and Colebrooke adds (Alg.
<div n="lb">p. 124 note): ‘the 24 different representations of Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb">arising from his diversity in the manner of placing the
<div n="lb">weapons or attributes in his four hands, are distinguished
<div n="lb">by as many discriminative titles of the god alloted to those
<div n="lb">figures in the theogonies of the Purāṇas. It does not ap-
<div n="lb">pear that distinct titles have been in like manner assigned
<div n="lb">to any part of the more than three millions of varied re-
<div n="lb">presentations of Śiva’.) E. {#anyonya-hasta#} and {#kalita#}.
<LEND>

<L>4378<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyahArABihata<k2>anyonyahArABihata
{#anyonyahArABihata#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Recipro-
<div n="lb">cally multiplied by the denominators; e. g. {#anyonyahArABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hatO harAMSO rASyoH samacCedaviDAnamevam#} ‘the denominator
<div n="lb">and numerator of two quantities being multiplied recipro-
<div n="lb">cally by their denominators, (the quantities) are thus re-
<div n="lb">duced to the same denominator’. E. {#anyonya-hAra#} and
<div n="lb">{#aBihata#}.
<LEND>

<L>4379<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyApahfta<k2>anyonyApahfta

<div n="lb">by one from another; (property taken thus and discovered
<div n="lb">at a partition of inheritance is divided again in equal por-
<div n="lb">tions among the heirs.) E. {#anyonya#} and {#apahfta#}.

<L>4380<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABAva<k2>anyonyABAva
{#anyonyABAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Mutual negation, one of the four divisions of {#aBAva#} q. v.;
<div n="lb">viz. that kind of negation or mutual exclusion which is held
<div n="lb">to exist between notions that have no property in common;
<div n="lb">indifference considered as a negation of heterogeneous notions;
<div n="lb">as if one says: ‘shape’ is not ‘jar’ ({#‘anyonyABAvatvaM tAdAtmyasaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDAvacCinnapratiyogitAkABAvatvam’#}). This notion is different
<div n="lb">therefore from that of {#pfTaktva#} q. v. E. {#anyonya#} and {#aBAva#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">E. {#anyonyABAva,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4382<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABiBava<k2>anyonyABiBava
{#anyonyABiBava#}¦ (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) I. Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#})
<div n="lb">The dominion of one over the other (see the following).
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#vaH#}) One predominating over the other;
<div n="lb">a condition of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and
<div n="lb">{#tamas#} qq. vv.; viz. when {%sattwa%} prevails, it overpowers
<div n="lb">{%rajas%} and {%tamas%} &c. Compare the following and {#anyonya-#}
<div n="lb">{#janana#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#aBiBava#}.
<LEND>

<L>4383<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyABiBavavftti<k2>anyonyABiBavavftti

<div n="lb">sophy.) Having the nature of predominating the one over
<div n="lb">the other; see the preceding and {#anyonyajanana#}. E. {#anyonyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BiBava#} (I.) and {#vftti#}.

<L>4385<pc>150-a<k1>anyonyASraya<k2>anyonyASraya
{#anyonyASraya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Mutual relation; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#BAvEH pratyayasargErvinA liNgaM na…liNgena tanmAtrasargeRa ca#}
<div n="lb">{#vinA BAvanirvfttirna…vIjANkurAvanyonyASrayaH#}. <sup>2</sup> The
[Page150-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">resting on one another, reciprocal support; see {#anyonyASra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yavftti#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Founded on the mutual relation (between two objects),
<div n="lb">one of the five modes of a {#tarka#} (q. v.), viz. an {%argumen-%}
<div n="lb">{%tatio ad absurdum,%} which consists in founding a premise
<div n="lb">on the imaginary relation between two objects and in
<div n="lb">drawing a conclusion from it which is inadmissible.
<div n="lb">This kind of argumentation may again ‘be threefold ac-
<div n="lb">cording to whether the argument of the premise is taken
<div n="lb">from the notion of origin or from that of actuality or from
<div n="lb">that of comprehension’ ({#‘sa cotpattisTitijYaptidvArA treDA#}
<div n="lb">{#…. tadapekzApekzitvanibanDano'nizwaprasaNgaH ..’#}). For
<div n="lb">the other four modes of a {#tarka#} see: {#AtmASraya, cakraka, ana-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasTA#} and {#tadanyabADitArTaprasaNga#}. [A commentator of the
<div n="lb">Sāṅkhya-Pravachana applies three of these terms to the ex-
<div n="lb">planation of the Sūtra: {#‘tadyoge tatsidDAvanyonyASrayatvam’#} in
<div n="lb">this manner: {#‘avidyAyogAdavidyAsidDO cAnyonyASrayatvamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tmASrayatvamanavasTA veti SezaH ..’#}.] <sup>2</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya philos.)
<div n="lb">Resting on one another, supporting one another; a property
<div n="lb">of the three {#guRa#} or qualities {#sattva, rajas#} and {#tamas,#} ‘these
<div n="lb">qualities resting on each other like binary atoms’; see {#anyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyajanana#} and {#anyonyASrayavftti#}. E. {#anyonya#} and {#ASraya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4386<pc>150-b<k1>anyonyASrayatva<k2>anyonyASrayatva
{#anyonyASrayatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) Argumentatio ad absurdum; see the
<div n="lb">preceding. E. {#anyonyASraya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4387<pc>150-b<k1>anyonyASrayavftti<k2>anyonyASrayavftti
{#anyonyASrayavftti#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-ttiH#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philo-
<div n="lb">sophy.) Having the nature of resting on one another, of
<div n="lb">supporting one another; see {#anyonyajanana#} and {#anyonyASraya#}.

<L>4390<pc>150-b<k1>anvak<k2>anvak
{#anvak#}¦ ind. <sup>1</sup> Following, after. <sup>2</sup> Favourably, friendly dis-
