<L>4391<pc>150-b<k1>anvakzam<k2>anvakzam
{#anvakzam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> After, afterwards. <sup>2</sup> Immediately, in-
<div n="lb">stantaneously. E. {#anu#} and {#akzi,#} samās. aff. {#wac#} (accord-
<div n="lb">ing to a Gaṇa to Pāṇini; the comm. on the Amarak. and
<div n="lb">Vijnānesvara in the Mitākṣara derive it from {#anu#} and {#akza#}
<div n="lb">{#(= indriya): ‘anugatamakzam’;#} equally so Vallabhagaṇi on
<div n="lb">Hemachandra {#‘akzasya paScAdanvakzam’#}. The second meaning
<div n="lb">would arise according to Vijnān. from rendering the word
<div n="lb">‘{#yAvaddarSanam,#} as far as a glance’. But it is more probable
<div n="lb">to consider {#anvakza#} as a deriv. from {#ac#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ksa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4392<pc>150-b<k1>anvakzarasanDi<k2>anvakzarasanDi
{#anvakzarasanDi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-nDiH#}) (In vaidik Grammar.) A
<div n="lb">technical name for certain Sandhi or meeting of letters at
<div n="lb">the end and beginning of words; viz. <sup>a.</sup> when a final vowel
<div n="lb">or {#ezaH, syaH#} or {#saH#} are followed by a consonant (the Vi-
<div n="lb">sarga of these three words then being dropped); see {#anu-#}
<div n="lb">{#loma;#} <sup>b.</sup> when a final consonant is followed by an initial
<div n="lb">vowel; see {#pratiloma;#} <sup>c.</sup> when a final Visarga is followed
<div n="lb">by a consonant called {#Uzman#} q. v. which itself is followed
<div n="lb">by a surd or hard consonant (the preceding Visarga then
<div n="lb">being dropped, e. g. {#samudrA sTaH,#} instead of {#samudrAH sTaH#});
<div n="lb">see {#vaktra;#} <sup>d.</sup> when the particle {#Im#} is followed by the words
[Page151-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#garBam, gAvaH, vatsam, mfjanti, pfcyate, saKAyaH, vivyAca,#}
<div n="lb">{#punar, riRanti#} and {#raTam#} (the final {#m#} of {#Im#} then being
<div n="lb">dropped). E. {#anu-akzara#} and {#sanDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4393<pc>151-a<k1>anvagBAvam<k2>anvagBAvam
{#anvagBAvam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. Favourably or friendly disposed;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#nAmagrAhaM kapiBiraSanEH stUyamAnaH samantAdanvagBAvaM ra-#}
<div n="lb">{#GuvfzaBayorvAnarendro virAjan…kizkinDyAdriM nyaviSata#}.
<div n="lb">(The same meaning may be expressed also by {#anvagBUya#} or
<div n="lb">{#anvagBUtvA;#} but in neither case these words mean ‘after’.)
<div n="lb">E. {#anvak#} and {#BAvam#} ({#BU,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>4394<pc>151-a<k1>anvac<k2>anvac
{#anvac#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nvaN-nUcI-nvak; nvaYcam-nUcIm-nvak;#}
<div n="lb">{#nUcA-nUcyA-nUcA#} &c.; du. {#nvaYcO-nUcyO-nUcI;#} plur. {#-nvaYcaH-nUcyaH#}
<div n="lb">{#-nvaYci; nUcaH-nUcIH-nvaYci#} &c.) <sup>1</sup> Following; {#anUci#} (loc. sing.),
<div n="lb">behind, from behind; e. g. {#AgacCato'nUci gajasya GaRwayoH#}
<div n="lb">{#svanaM samAkarRya samAkulANganAH#} &c. (comm. {#anUci pfzWadeSe#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (ved.) Going along or lengthwise; as opposed to {#udac#} and
<div n="lb">{#tiryac#} qq. vv.--The neuter {#anvak#} is used as adv. and as-
<div n="lb">sumes in conjunction with {#BUtvA#} or in composition with {#BUya#}
<div n="lb">and {#BAvam#} (see {#anvagBAvam#}) the meaning of ‘friendly or
<div n="lb">favourably disposed’. [Pāṇini, in the rule III. 4. 64. makes
<div n="lb">uses of the form {#anvaci#} which has the value there of a
<div n="lb">locat. of {#anvac;#} Patanjali blames him for this liberty: {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#yukto'yaM nirdeSaH . anUcIti Bavitavyam . sOtro'yaM nirdeSaH .#}.
<div n="lb">But as Pāṇini expresses himself in a similar manner when
<div n="lb">speaking of {#tiryac#} III. 4. 60. {#‘tiryacyapavarge’#}--when he in-
<div n="lb">curs a like remark from Patanjali--, it is perhaps more
<div n="lb">just to say that he did not intend to speak in these rules
<div n="lb">of the declinable {#anvac#} and {#tiryac,#} but of their neuters
<div n="lb">become indeclinable; and that, his method requiring in these
<div n="lb">rules the locative of the mentioned words, {#anvaci#} and {#ti-#}
<div n="lb">{#ryaci#} were less objectionable than {#anvaki#} and {#tiryaki,#} while
<div n="lb">{#anUci#} and {#tiraSci,#} as suggested by Patanjali, would not
<div n="lb">have necessarily conveyed the notion of indeclinable words.]
<div n="lb">E. {#ac#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kvin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4395<pc>151-a<k1>anvaDyAyam<k2>anvaDyAyam
{#anvaDyAyam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> Chapter for chapter. <sup>2</sup> According to,
<div n="lb">or conformably to, the chapters (esp. of the vaidik writings),
<div n="lb">e. g. (in Lāṭyāyana's Kalpasūtras) {#anvaDyAyamapavAdaniSA-#}
<div n="lb">{#manam#} (comm. {#aDyAyamanu anvaDyAyam . anvaDyAyamapavAdo#}
<div n="lb">{#niSAmayitavyaH . anvaDyAyaM nyAyyAnAM CandodEvatasAmAntAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapavAdaH#}). <sup>3</sup> In the vaidik language; used in this sense by
<div n="lb">Yāska in contradistinction from {#BAzAyAm#} ‘in the classical
<div n="lb">idiom’. E. {#anu#} and {#aDyAya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4396<pc>151-a<k1>anvaya<k2>anvaya
{#anvaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, association; e. g. {#di-#}
<div n="lb">{#gvyApinIrlocanaloBanIyA mfjAnvayAH snehamiva sravantIH . f-#}
<div n="lb">{#jvAyatAH SasyAviSezapaNktIstutoza paSyanvitfRAntarAlAH#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#mfjA SudDiH…tayA anvayo'nugamo yAsAM SudDyanugatA#}
<div n="lb">{#ityarTaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Retinue, attendance; e. g. {#kA tvamekAkinI BIru#}
<div n="lb">{#niranvayajane vane#} (comm. {#niranvayA niranugamA janA yasmi-#}
<div n="lb">{#nvane#}). <sup>3</sup> Family, race, lineage (in general); e. g. {#anvayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#diviBinnAnAM yaTA saKyamanIpsitam#} &c. Comp. {#anvavAya#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> The male descendants (in contradistinction from the fe-
<div n="lb">male succession); e. g. {#mAturduhitaraH SezamfRAttABya fte'nvayaH#}
<div n="lb">(scil. {#viBajerannfkTam;#} comm. {#anvayaH putrAdiH,#} or accord. to
<div n="lb">another comm. {#anvayapadena putrARAmaDikAraH#}). <sup>5a.</sup> {%Logical%}
<div n="lb">connexion (esp. of words); e. g. {#arpaRaM svasya vAkyArTe para-#}
<div n="lb">{#syAnvayasidDaye . upalakzaRahetutvAdezA lakzaRalakzaRA;#} also with
<div n="lb">a noun in the instrum.; e. g. {#SaNkAM mA kfTA iti pUrveRAnvayaH#}
[Page151-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(the words of the verse Bhaṭṭik. 1. 22. being logically con-
<div n="lb">nected with {#SaNkAM#} &c. of the preceding verse); more seldom
<div n="lb">with a word in the locative, e. g. in a comm. on the Ve-
<div n="lb">dānta Sūtra {#‘vAkyAnvayAt’#} which is explained: {#etAvadare Ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#lvamftatvam . ityupasaMhAreRAsya vAkyasya brahmaRyanvayAt#}. <sup>b.</sup> {%Gram-%}
<div n="lb">{%matical%} connexion of the words in a sentence, grammatical
<div n="lb">construction of a sentence; in this sense very frequently
<div n="lb">used in the commentaries, in the same manner as {#saMbanDa#}.
<div n="lb">Sometimes the two latter meanings will coincide, e. g. (in
<div n="lb">a Mīmānsā-discussion on the question: whether the bearing
<div n="lb">of a passage is conveyed by the words of a sentence or not,
<div n="lb">when the wrong thesis, that it is not, is thus refuted:) {#mE-#}
<div n="lb">{#vam . anvaye SezaSeziBAvasyAntarBAvAt . na hi guRapraDAnaBA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vamantareRAnvayaH saMBavati . dvayorguRayoH parasparAkANkzArahita-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvenAnvayayogyatvABAvAt . evaM dvayoH praDAnayorapi . ato#}
<div n="lb">{#vyutpattisaMBavAtkriyAkArakatadanvayo yaTA SAbdaH . taTA tada-#}
<div n="lb">{#nvayAntargataH SezaSeziBAvo'pi SAbdaH .#}. <sup>6</sup> (In Philosophy,
<div n="lb">esp. in the Nyāya and Vaiśeṣika, and in scientific language
<div n="lb">in general.) <sup>a.</sup> Logical consequence; e. g. in a comm. on a
<div n="lb">Yoga Sūtra {#na hi kvacidapi kleSAnAM viparyayAnvayanirapekzarU-#}
<div n="lb">{#pARAM svarUpamupalaByate;#} or in the Yoga Sūtra: {#sTUlasvarUpasU-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzmAnvayArTavattvasaMyamAdBUtajayaH,#} where the word {#anvaya#} is ex-
<div n="lb">plained: {#KyAtikriyAsTitiSIlAguRAH kAryasvaBAvAnupAtino#}
<div n="lb">{#anvayaSabdenoktAH;#} or in another Yoga Sūtra: {#grahaRasvarUpA-#}
<div n="lb">{#smitAnvayArTavattvasaMyamAdindriyajayaH,#} where it has the same
<div n="lb">meaning. <sup>b.</sup> Logical continuance; in this sense the word is
<div n="lb">opposed to {#vyatireka#} ‘logical discontinuance’ and occurs, for
<div n="lb">the most part, either combined with the latter to a Dwandwa
<div n="lb">(see also {#anvayavyatireka#}), or in reference to it. Again the
<div n="lb">general notion of {%‘logical continuance%} and {%discontinuance’%} be-
<div n="lb">comes modified <sup>aa.</sup> when applied to the notion of genus, into
<div n="lb">to the notion of {%species%} and {%variety;%} e. g. in a Mīmānsā dis-
<div n="lb">cussion: {#nanvAnantyavyaBicArAByAM na vyaktO vyutpattiH saMBavati .#}
<div n="lb">{#anantA hi govyaktayaH… . SuklavyaktO vyutpanno goSabdaH kf-#}
<div n="lb">{#zRavyaktO prayujyamAnaH svArTaM vyaBicaret…iti prApte brUmaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#anvayavyatirekAByAmAkfteH SaktigrahaRanimittatvAcCabdArTatvaM ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#syA evocitam .;#} or: {#anvayavyatirekAByAM jAtivAcitvAt;#}
<div n="lb"><sup>bb.</sup> when applied to the notion of subject and predicate or to
<div n="lb">syllogizing in general, this term expresses {%congruity%} and {%dis-%}
<div n="lb">{%parity, consecutiveness%} and {%exception%} (deviation), or {%affirmation%}
<div n="lb">and {%negation;%} e. g. {#kAvyasvarUpatvenABimatayoH SabdArTayoH raso#}
<div n="lb">{#'sti na vA . nAsti cet . guRavattvamapi nAsti . guRAnAM tada-#}
<div n="lb">{#nvayavyatirekAnuviDAyitvAt .#} (also in this sense in a verse
<div n="lb">of the Rājataraṅgiṇī: {#svadeSo'yaM videSo'yamiti budDeH#}
<div n="lb">{#pravartakaH anvayavyatirekAByAM sTityaByAsaH SarIriRAm;#} or of
<div n="lb">the Bhāgav. Purāṇa: {#etAvadeva jijYAsyaM tattvajijYAsunAtmanaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#anvayavyatirekAByAM yatsyAtsarvatra sarvadA#}); and comp. {#kevalAnva-#}
<div n="lb">{#yin, kevalavyatirekin, anvayavyatirekin, anvayavyApti, vya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tirekavyApti#}. <sup>cc.</sup> when applied to the notion of law, it ex-
<div n="lb">presses {%rule%} and {%exception,%} or {%positive%} and {%negative clause;%}
<div n="lb">e. g. {#anyodaryaH…saMsfzwI DanaM harenna punaranyodaryo DanaM hare-#}
<div n="lb">{#dasaMsfzwI . anenAnvayavyatirekAByAmanyodaryasya saMsfzwitvaM Danagra-#}
<div n="lb">{#haRe kAraRamuktam#}.--E. {#i (iR)#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4398<pc>151-b<k1>anvayavat<k2>anvayavat

<div n="lb">word occurs Manu 8. 382. and is explained {#‘samakzam’#} by
[Page152-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">Kullūka and Vijnāneśvara; it is an adverb in that passage,
<div n="lb">as it refers to the verb and not to {#karma#}.) Compare {#sAnvaya#}
<div n="lb">and {#niranvaya#}. E. {#anvaya,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.

<L>4399<pc>152-a<k1>anvayavyatireka<k2>anvayavyatireka

<div n="lb">the meaning of this term see {#anvaya#} <sup>6.</sup> b., where instances of
<div n="lb">the dual are given; the sing. occurs e. g. in the Sāṅkhya Sū-
<div n="lb">tras: {#atrApi pratiniyamo'nvayavyatirekAt;#} or {#viSizwasya jI-#}

<L>4400<pc>152-a<k1>anvayavyatirekin<k2>anvayavyatirekin

<L>4405<pc>152-a<k1>anvarTa<k2>anvarTa
{#anvarTa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) Having an obvious
<div n="lb">sense, having a sense easily to be understood from the
<div n="lb">etymon, as simple words like {#vftti, kazAyavat,#} or com-
<div n="lb">pounds, when analyzed into their constituent parts, such
<div n="lb">as {#nibanDa, dIrGapattra#} &c. The same as {#anugatArTa;#} comp. the
<div n="lb">following words. (The word is taken as a Bahuvr. by Val-
<div n="lb">labhagaṇi on Hemach. 257. = 2. 171: {#anugato milito'rTo#}
<div n="lb">{#'nayoranvarTe;#} but it may be also a Tatpur.)
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-rTam#}) According to the literal sense (arising
<div n="lb">from the etymon); literally; e. g. {#kriyAyAH pratizeDena tatPalasya#}
<div n="lb">{#viBAvanAt . jYeyA viBAvanEvAsO sAnvarTaM kaTyate yaTA .#}.
<div n="lb">Comp. the following. E. {#anu#} and {#arTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4406<pc>152-a<k1>anvarTagrahaRa<k2>anvarTagrahaRa
{#anvarTagrahaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Taking or understanding a
<div n="lb">word in its literal or etymological (not in its conventional
<div n="lb">or technical) sense; e. g. the word {#bahuvacane#} in Pāṇini VIII.
<div n="lb">2. 81, where it is not be taken in the technical sense ‘plural’,
<div n="lb">but in the sense {#bahUnAmarTAnAM vacane,#} as otherwise the form
<div n="lb">{#amI#} would not result from the rule. E. {#anvarTa#} (Avyayībh.)
<div n="lb">and {#grahaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4408<pc>152-b<k1>anvarTasaYjYa<k2>anvarTasaYjYa
{#anvarTasaYjYa#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-YjYA#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Grammar.) A technical
<div n="lb">name (see {#saMjYA#}) which conveys its own meaning (when
<div n="lb">etymologically analyzed) and therefore distinct from techni-
<div n="lb">cal names such as {#Gu, liw#} &c., which are purely technical;
<div n="lb">such {#saMjYAH#} as {#sarvanAman, karmapravacanIya, anunAsika, svara-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bakti#} &c. &c. are {#anvaº;#} thus Patanj. observes on the word
<div n="lb">{#‘karmapravacanIyAH’: kimarTaM mahatI saMjYA kriyate . anvarTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMjYA yaTA vijYAyeta,#} and Kaiyyaṭa on the latter: {#anvarTasaM-#}

<div n="lb">{#saMjYA anvarTasaMjYA#}. <sup>2</sup> A proper name in general which has
<div n="lb">preserved its etymological sense; e. g. {#dIrGabAhu#} the name
<div n="lb">of a Rākṣasa.

<div n="lb">{#gaNgA#}). E. {#anvarTa#} and {#saYjYA#}.

<L>4420<pc>153-a<k1>anvAKyAna<k2>anvAKyAna

<div n="lb">subject mentioned before; e. g. Kumārilabhaṭṭa in a Mīmānsā
<div n="lb">Vārttika: {#vyAkaraRenApi prasidDArTAnAmevAvinazwasvarUpAnvA-#}

<L>4421<pc>153-a<k1>anvAcaya<k2>anvAcaya
{#anvAcaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) Adding an object of secondary
<div n="lb">import, or such an object itself; used only in reference to
<div n="lb">{#praDAna, muKya#} or {#prADAnya,#} the subject of primary import:
<div n="lb">{#‘yatrEkasya prADAnyenAparasya gORyenAKyAnaM so'nvAcayaH’;#} thus
<div n="lb">a comm. of the Amarak. in explaining the various appli-
<div n="lb">cations of the particle {#ca,#} one of which is {#‘anvAcaye’#} in-
<div n="lb">stances (comp. the Siddhāntakaum. on Pāṇini II. 2. 29.):
<div n="lb">{#Bo Bikzo BikzAmawa gAM cAnaya,#} when the going out for alms
<div n="lb">is enjoined to the beggar as his principal object and his
<div n="lb">bringing a cow, when he can see one, as the matter of
<div n="lb">secondary import; or of the three Sūtras of Pāṇini VII. 3.
<div n="lb">117. 118. 119., the two former contain the {#praDAna#} and the latter
<div n="lb">the {#anvAcaya#}. See the following. E. {#anu#} and {#Acaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4422<pc>153-a<k1>anvAcayaSizwa<k2>anvAcayaSizwa
{#anvAcayaSizwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) Taught or laid
<div n="lb">down as a matter of secondary import, being the object of
<div n="lb">a secondary rule or observation; used in reference to {#praDA-#}
<div n="lb">{#naSizwa,#} what is taught or laid down as a matter of primary
<div n="lb">import; e. g. Patanjali observes on Pāṇ. VII. 3. 117-119. (comp.
<div n="lb">VII. 3. 118. Vārtt. 3): {#praDAnaSizwamOtvam . anvAcayaSizwama-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvam . yaTA kyaNi salopaH . tadyaTA praDAnaSizwaH kyaN prAti-#}
<div n="lb">{#padikamAtrAdBavati yatra ca sakArastatra lopaH . ;#} or the Kāśikā
<div n="lb">on the same rules: {#Odacca Geriti yezAmekamevedaM sUtraM tena pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnaSizwamidudByAmOtvaM ca varRayanti . anvAcayaSizwaM GerakAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti ..#}. In a similar manner Mallinātha explains in the
<div n="lb">Kirātārjunīya the words {#nanu lakzmIH PalamAnuzaNgikam#} thus:
<div n="lb">{#lakzmIH sampat . anuzaNgAdAgatamAnuzaNgikamanvAcayaSizwaM PalaM#}
<div n="lb">{#nanu . mAnatrARaM jaya sa eva muKyaM Palam . aByuccayastu lakzmIri-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti mAninAM mAna eva SlAGya ityarTaH ..#}. Comp. the preceding.
<div n="lb">E. {#anvAcaya#} and {#Sizwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4423<pc>153-a<k1>anvAcita<k2>anvAcita

<L>4424<pc>153-a<k1>anvAje<k2>anvAje

<div n="lb">may fall then under the predicament of the prefixes called
<div n="lb">{#gati#} q. v., e. g. {#anvAjekftya;#} or not, e. g. {#anvAje kftvA#}.

<L>4425<pc>153-a<k1>anvAdizwa<k2>anvAdizwa
{#anvAdizwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Mentioned in re-
<div n="lb">ference to (what is previously mentioned), referred to.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Being of secondary import, inferior; e. g. {#puruzaScAnvAdizwaH#}
<div n="lb">(Kāśikā: {#anvAdizwo'nvAcitaH kaTitAnukaTito vA#}). E.
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> {#diS#} with {#A#} and {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kta;#} <sup>2</sup> {#anu#} and {#Adizwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4426<pc>153-a<k1>anvAdeSa<k2>anvAdeSa
{#anvAdeSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) A reference made to a previous
<div n="lb">statement ({#anvAdeSaSca kaTitAnukaTanamAtram#}); sentences con-
[Page153-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">taining such a reference are introduced by the particles {#aTa#}
<div n="lb">or {#aTo,#} e. g. {#asmE CAtrAya kambalaM dehi . aTo asmE SAka-#}
<div n="lb">{#wamapi dehi;#} or {#asya cCAtrasya SoBanaM SIlam . aTo asya#}
<div n="lb">{#praBUtamapi svam#}. (For the use which is made in such sen-
<div n="lb">tences of the pronominal bases {#a#} and {#ena#} see s. vv. {#idam#}
<div n="lb">and {#etad,#} and of {#mA, me, nO, nas, tvA, te, vAm, vas#}
<div n="lb">see s. vv. {#asmad#} and {#yuzmad#}.) E. {#anu#} and {#AdeSa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4427<pc>153-b<k1>anvADAna<k2>anvADAna

<div n="lb">ficial fire); e. g. {#DAraRArTatvAtsome'gnyanvADAnaM na vidyate;#}
<div n="lb">or {#vEguRyAdiDmAbarhirna sADayedagnyanvADAnaM ca yadi devatA-#}

<L>4428<pc>153-b<k1>anvADi<k2>anvADi
{#anvADi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DiH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Law.) Property which is
<div n="lb">handed over by the person who has received it as a loan,
<div n="lb">to another, for the purpose of returning it to its lawfulowner.
<div n="lb">The same as {#anvAhita#} q. v. <sup>2</sup> A second deposit or pledge.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Mental anxiety subsequent to (an act). E. {#anu#} and {#ADi#}.
<LEND>

<L>4429<pc>153-b<k1>anvADeya<k2>anvADeya
{#anvADeya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) (In Law.) An item of a married
<div n="lb">woman's property; see {#strIDana#}. It is defined by {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">as property ‘which is received by a woman, after marriage,
<div n="lb">from the family of her husband or from her own relatives’
<div n="lb">(i. e. from her maternal uncle &c., according to Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb">or from the relatives of her parents, as the author of
<div n="lb">the Dāyabhāga interprets the latter word). [{#kAtyAyanaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#vivAhAtparato yattu labDaM BartfkulAtstriyA . anvADeyaM taduktaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tu labDaM banDukulAttaTA .. ‘vizRuvacane ca banDupadaM mAtulAdyaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#prAyam’#} or {#‘BartfkulAt . SvaSurakulAdeH . banDukulAt . pitfmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tfkulAt#}.--The reading in the printed edd. of the second
<div n="lb">portion of the Mitākṣara {#‘labDaM pitfkulAttaTA’#} would there-
<div n="lb">fore require {#pitf#} to be taken in the sense of {#‘pitaraH#} parents’
<div n="lb">not in that of ‘father’; but the given reading seems pre-
<div n="lb">ferable as it occurs in several Mss. (E. I. H.) of this work,
<div n="lb">in Kullūka on Manu 9. 195 (with the v. 1. {#banDukule taTA#}), in two
<div n="lb">passages of the Dāyabhāga (pp. 116 and 149) with the com-
<div n="lb">ment quoted, and in the Dāyakramas. p. 17, where the comm.
<div n="lb">is: {#banDukulAdityatra banDupadena mAtApitrorupalakzaRam#}. In the
<div n="lb">Vivādachintāmaṇi p. 139 the latter half of the verse reads
<div n="lb">thus: {#anvADeyaM tu tatproktaM yallabDaM svakulAttaTA#}.] {%Bhṛgu%} defines
<div n="lb">this property as ‘whatever is received with pleasure by a
<div n="lb">woman, after the marriage ceremony, from her husband and
<div n="lb">her parents’ [{#UrDvaM labDaM tu yatkiMcitsaMskArAtprItitaH striyA .#}
<div n="lb">{#BartuH pitroH sakASAdvA#} (or {#BartuH sakASAtpitrorvA#}) {#anvADeyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tu tadBfguH#}]; when the Dāyabhāga and Dāyakramas. in quoting
<div n="lb">this passage supply after ‘her husband’: ‘and from those re-
<div n="lb">lated to her through her husband, i. e. father-in-law &c.’ and
<div n="lb">after ‘her parents’: ‘and from those related to her through
<div n="lb">her parents, i. e. grandparents &c.’, so as to effectuate a con-
<div n="lb">cordance between Kātyāyana and Bhṛgu. [Dāyabh. {#mAtA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pitfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM pitroSca sakASAdyattu vivAhAtparato la-#}
<div n="lb">{#bDam . taTA BartuH sakASAdBartfkulAcca SvaSurAdito yallabDaM DanaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tadanvADeyam;#} Dāyakr. {#BartfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM SvaSurAdInAM mA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tApitfdvAreRa saMbanDinAM mAtAmahapitAmahAdInAM ca sakASAt#}
<div n="lb">&c.] E. {#anu#} (after, scil. marriage) and {#ADeya;#} scil. {#strIDana#} q. v.
<LEND>

<L>4442<pc>154-a<k1>anvAsana<k2>anvAsana

<div n="lb">--the reading {#satkriyAnvAsanaM#} seems preferable to the read-
<div n="lb">ing {#satkriyAM cAsanaM,#} since the Mitākṣara explains: {#tasmi-#}

<div n="lb">{#anuvAsana#} q. v.

<L>4443<pc>154-b<k1>anvAsyamAna<k2>anvAsyamAna

<L>4444<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhArya<k2>anvAhArya
{#anvAhArya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-ryaH#}) Rice which is given as a
<div n="lb">present to the priests upon certain sacrificial occasions, as
<div n="lb">at the performance of the Darśapūrṇamāsa; (presents there-
<div n="lb">fore of a garment or of a calf are not an {#anvAhArya;#}) the
<div n="lb">sacrificial acts must be, moreover, such as are connected
<div n="lb">with the ritual of the Yajurveda ({#‘anvAhAryadakziRADvaryu-#}
<div n="lb">{#vede’#}). Comp. {#anvAhAryapacana#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ryam#}) The monthly Śrāddha or funeral repast in
<div n="lb">honour of the Manes, held on the day of the new moon;
<div n="lb">it should consist of meat of an excellent quality and is so
<div n="lb">called, because it is partaken after the presentation of a
<div n="lb">piṇḍa to the Manes (comp. {#piRqAnvAhAryaka#}); according to
<div n="lb">this definition of Manu, it would be the same as the {#pArvaRa#}
<div n="lb">q. v.--others, as quoted by Bharatamalla on the Amarak.
<div n="lb">s. v., define it as the monthly Śrāddha at the end of the
<div n="lb">year, when the presentation of the piṇḍa has not taken
<div n="lb">place ({#‘akftasapiRqIkaraRasya vatsarAnte pratimAsaM yacCrAdDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tatrAnvAhAryamiti kecit’#}). According to the Gṛhyasūtra
<div n="lb">of Gobhila (as quoted by Rādhākāntadeva) it would be
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> the Śrāddha which is the preparatory act to any religious
<div n="lb">ceremony, <sup>b.</sup> the second Śrāddha performed on the day of
<div n="lb">the new moon, and <sup>c.</sup> the same as {#anvAhArya#} {%m.,%} but in the
<div n="lb">more general sense of a present given at the end of any
<div n="lb">sacrificial act: {#‘yacCrAdDaM karmaRAmAdO yA cAnte dakziRA Ba-#}
<div n="lb">{#vet . amAvAsyaM dvitIyaM yadanvAhAryaM vidurbuDAH . iti go-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bilagfhyam’#}.--See also {#anuhArya#} and the following. E. {#anu#}
<div n="lb">and {#AhArya,#} 1. scil. {#odana,#} 2. scil. {#SrAdDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4447<pc>154-b<k1>anvAhAryapacana<k2>anvAhAryapacana

<div n="lb">southern part of the Vedi, which serves for cooking the
<div n="lb">present of rice called {#anvAhArya#} q. v. ({#‘anvAhArya odanaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tasya pAkaheturBavizyati’;#} Sāyaṇa)--hence its name--and
<div n="lb">which is collected daily, as the destruction of enemies is
<div n="lb">supposed to be the result of the frequent repetition of this
<div n="lb">act. E. {#anvAhArya#} and {#pacana;#} scil. {#agni#}.

<L>4449<pc>154-b<k1>anvita<k2>anvita
{#anvita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Following, pursuing.

<div n="lb">cally connected, as in construction or sense. <sup>4</sup> Acquired
<div n="lb">(mentally), understood, become clear; e. g. {#yadyatsADu na#}

<L>4450<pc>154-b<k1>anvitArTa<k2>anvitArTa

<div n="lb">e. g. {#astavyastapadavyApi nigUQArTaM taTAkulam . vyAKyAgamyama-#}

<L>4457<pc>155-a<k1>anvIta<k2>anvIta

<div n="lb">(Jaṭādhara and the Bhūriprayoga). E. {#I#} with {#anu,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<div n="lb">{#anu#} and {#ap#} (changed to {#Ip#}), samās. aff. {#a#}. See the Preface.

<L>4472<pc>155-b<k1>ap<k2>ap
{#ap#}¦ f. ({#-p;#} in the classical literature only used in the plural:
<div n="lb">{#-ApaH-apaH-adBiH-adByaH-apAm-apsu#}) <sup>1</sup> Water.--Ac-
<div n="lb">cording to the Hindu doctrine it is one of the five elements
<div n="lb">the several denominations of which are {#AkASa#} (æther),
<div n="lb">{#vAyu#} (air), {#agni#} (fire), {#ap#} (water), {#pfTivI#} (earth), (each
<div n="lb">of these being also replaced by synonymes, as {#AkASa#}
<div n="lb">by {#vyoman, vAyu#} by {#marut, agni#} by {#tejas, ap#} by
<div n="lb">{#vAri, pfTivI#} by {#kziti#} &c.; comp. under {#AkASa#} &c.); the
<div n="lb">place, however, which {%water%} holds in the Hindu cosmogony
<div n="lb">varies according to the doctrines. Thus the {%Bṛhad-Āraṇ-%}
<div n="lb">{%yaka Upan.%} represents it as the first material creation, it
<div n="lb">being produced by Death after the creation of Soul; but
<div n="lb">its character in this Upanishad is not yet that of an element
<div n="lb">in the later sense of the word; nor is it such an element in
<div n="lb">the {%Aitareya-Upan.,%} where the order of the primitive ma-
<div n="lb">terial creation is {#amBas#} (the waters above the heavens),
<div n="lb">{#marIci#} (the sphere of sunbeams or atmosphere), {#mara#} (the
<div n="lb">sphere of death or earth) and {#ap#} (the sphere of waters
<div n="lb">beneath the earth).--In the {%Taittirīya-Upan.%} the order and
<div n="lb">successive origin of the elements is the same as in the Ve-
<div n="lb">dānta, viz. æther, in which originates air and thus suc-
<div n="lb">cessively fire, water, earth. But the {%Vedānta%} complicates
<div n="lb">this simple view by assuming a creation of subtle elements
<div n="lb">(see {#sUkzmaSarIra#}) æther &c., produced by Chaitanya or the
<div n="lb">worldly Brahman, whence arise through an intricate division
<div n="lb">and combination of the several parts of each, the material
<div n="lb">elements (see {#sTUlaSarIra#}) æther &c.; this system holds more-
<div n="lb">over that each successive element becomes possessed of the
<div n="lb">qualities of each preceding one, i. e. the quality of æther
<div n="lb">being sound, air obtains the qualities of sound and touch,
<div n="lb">and in a similar progress, fire the qualities of sound, touch
<div n="lb">and form, water of sound, touch, form and savour, earth
<div n="lb">of sound, touch, form, savour and odour.--According to
<div n="lb">the {%Sāṅkhya%} the coarse elements also arise from subtle ele-
<div n="lb">ments, but the latter ({#tanmAtra#} q. v.), produced by Ahaṅkāra
<div n="lb">or the type of {%I,%} are the qualities sound, touch, form,
<div n="lb">savour and odour, æther proceeding from sound, air from
<div n="lb">touch, fire from form, water from savour and earth from
<div n="lb">odour. (Compare also Suśruta's mythological developement
<div n="lb">of the Sāṅkhya-Yoga: {#avyaktaM mahAnahaMkAraH paYca tanmAtrARi ce-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyazwO prakftayaH SezAH zoqaSa vikArAH . svaH svaScEzAM vizayo'Di-#}
<div n="lb">{#BUtam . svayamaDyAtmamaDidEvataM ca . aTa budDerbrahmA . ahaMkArasye-#}
<div n="lb">{#SvaraH . manasaScandramAH . diSaH Srotrasya . tvaco vAyuH . sUryaScakzu-#}
<div n="lb">{#zoH . rasanasyApaH . pfTivI GrARasya .#} &c.)--The {%Nyāya%}
<div n="lb">systems, more especially the {%Vaiśeṣika,%} do not discuss the
<div n="lb">origin of these elements, the order of which they retain,
[Page156-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">but attach themselves chiefly to the definition of their
<div n="lb">properties; accord. to the {%Vaiśeṣika%} the qualities of water
<div n="lb">are touch, number, quantity, individuality, conjunction, dis-
<div n="lb">junction, greater or less comprehensiveness (extension), ve-
<div n="lb">locity, gravity, fluidity, colour, savour and viscidity. (For
<div n="lb">those of the other elements see s. vv. {#AkASa#} &c.) The cos-
<div n="lb">mogony of {%Manu%} which is neither the pure Sāṅkhya nor the
<div n="lb">pure Vedānta doctrine (although Kullūka endeavours to ex-
<div n="lb">plain his terms as if they were pure Vedānta terms), but
<div n="lb">a theory apparently prior to both and combining their views,
<div n="lb">imagines the coarse elements as proceeding from the subtle
<div n="lb">portions of the seven intellectual creations--{#puruzAH#} which
<div n="lb">are, according to Kullūka, {#ahaMkAra, mahat#} and the five
<div n="lb">subtle elements(?)--and endowed with the same qualities
<div n="lb">as assigned to them by the Vedānta.--According to the
<div n="lb">{%Viṣṇupurāṇa%} ‘elementary Egotism (the type of {%I,%} {#ahaMkAra#})
<div n="lb">becoming productive as the rudiment of sound, produced
<div n="lb">from it æther, of which sound is the characteristic, invest-
<div n="lb">ing it with its rudiment of sound; æther becoming produc-
<div n="lb">tive, engendered the rudiment of touch; whence originated
<div n="lb">strong wind, the property of which is touch; and æther
<div n="lb">with the rudiment of sound, enveloped the rudiment of
<div n="lb">touch; then wind becoming productive, produced the rudi-
<div n="lb">ment of form (colour); whence fire proceeded of which form
<div n="lb">is the attribute, and the rudiment of touch enveloped the
<div n="lb">wind with the rudiment of colour; fire becoming productive
<div n="lb">produced the rudiment of savour, whence proceed all juices
<div n="lb">in which savour resides, and the rudiment of colour invested
<div n="lb">the juices with the rudiment of savour; the waters becoming
<div n="lb">productive engendered the rudiment of smell; whence an
<div n="lb">aggregate (earth) originates, of which smell is the property.’
<div n="lb">In a note to this passage ({%Viṣṇup.%} p. 16) Professor Wilson
<div n="lb">observes that ‘the successive series of rudiments and ele-
<div n="lb">ments and their respectively engendering the rudiments and
<div n="lb">elements next in order occur in most of the Purāṇas in
<div n="lb">nearly the same words’, that ‘some of the Purāṇas, as the
<div n="lb">{%Matsya, Vāyu, Linga, Bhāgavata%} and {%Mārkaṇḍeya%} add a
<div n="lb">description of a participation of properties amongst the ele-
<div n="lb">ments, which is rather Vedānta than Sāṅkhya’ and mentions
<div n="lb">a passage of the Moksha Dharma (vv. 6778. 6779) of the
<div n="lb">Māhābhārata which is an exception, since its order of the
<div n="lb">elements is æther, water, fire, air, earth. [On the cosmo-
<div n="lb">gony of the chapter in which these latter verses occur, Arju-
<div n="lb">namiśra has the following gloss: {#ko'yaM sargaprakAraH . na hi#}
<div n="lb">{#sANKyAdisargezvayaM kramaH . ucyate . anyo'yaM prakAraH sargasya .#}
<div n="lb">{#pOrARikAdisaMmatezu#} &c.; but he omits to say which Pu-
<div n="lb">rāṇas give this anomalous order of the elements.] For the
<div n="lb">Bhāgav. Pur. comp. III. 26. 29. ff. and the two verses VII.
<div n="lb">12. 25 and 30: {#Ke KAni vAyO niHSvAsAMstejasyUzmARamAtmavAn .#}
<div n="lb">{#apsvasfkSlezmapUyAni kzitO SezaM yaTodBavam#} (scil. {#nyaset#}); and
<div n="lb">{#apsu kzitimapo jyotizyado vAyO naBasyamum . kUwasTe tacca ma-#}
<div n="lb">{#hati tadavyakte'kzare ca tat#} (this reverted order being that in
<div n="lb">which dissolution takes place).--In the Vedas, however,
<div n="lb">{#apAM garBaH#} ‘the child of the waters’ is an epithet of Agni,
<div n="lb">‘because he comes forth from amid the waters’ or ‘because
<div n="lb">he resides as lightning amidst the rain-waters’ (according to
[Page156-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">Mahīdhara); comp. also {#garBo apasAm#} s. v. {#apas;#} from the
<div n="lb">same reason probably Agni is also called {#apAM#} or {#apo#}
<div n="lb">{#napAt#} ‘the grandson of the waters’, but, in Sāyaṇa's
<div n="lb">opinion, ‘because trees grow through the agency of water
<div n="lb">and fire comes (through the friction of the wood) of trees.
<div n="lb">For the other explanations of these words see s. vv. {#apA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nnapAt, apAnnaptf;#} comp. also {#aponapAt, aponaptf, apona-#}
<div n="lb">{#ptriya, aponaptrIya, apAnnaptriya, apAnnaptrIya.--apAM vratam#}
<div n="lb">is the liturgical name of the Sāmav. verses 2. 25. 26. (= II. 1.
<div n="lb">1. 9.) and 2. 47-49. (= II. 1. 1. 18.); {#apAM sAma#} of 1. 544. (= I. 6.
<div n="lb">1. 4. 12.); {#apAmIvam#} of 2. 502-504. (= II. 4. 2. 7.); {#apAM niDiH#}
<div n="lb">of 1. 151. (= I. 2. 2. 1. 7.); {#apAM sarpam#} of the Āraṇyagāna (of
<div n="lb">the Sāmav.) II. 7. (not in the Sāmav.). <sup>2</sup> (ved.) The same as
<div n="lb">{#antarikza#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Astronomy.) The star <lang n="greek"></lang> {%Virginis.%} [Com-
<div n="lb">pounds the latter part of which is {#ap#} assume the samās. aff.
<div n="lb">{#a,#} e. g. {#pra#} or {#parA#} and {#ap#} form {#prApa, parApa;#} but some-
<div n="lb">times the word remains unchanged, if it is a Bahuvr. com-
<div n="lb">pound, e. g. {#svap, bahvap#} (in which case the neuter plur. is
<div n="lb">{#svAmpi, bahvAmpi#}); if the first part of the compound is {#anu,#}
<div n="lb">the grammarians assume that {#ap#} becomes {#Up#} provided
<div n="lb">the meaning refers to a place, i. e. {#anUpa#} (comp. also {#sUpa#});
<div n="lb">if it is {#dvi, antar#} or a prepositional prefix not ending in
<div n="lb">{#a#} or {#A,#} that {#ap#} becomes {#Ip;#} comp. {#dvIpa, antarIpa,#}
<div n="lb">{#nIpa, vIpa, anvIpa, pratIpa, samIpa#} ({#samApa#} being an ex-
<div n="lb">ception); if the prepos. prefix ends in {#a#} or {#A,#} that {#ap#}
<div n="lb">may change to {#Ip#} or not; comp. {#prApa#} or {#prepa, parApa#} or
<div n="lb">{#parepa#}.--(Another explanation of these compounds will be
<div n="lb">found in the Preface.)].--Compare also {#apa#} and {#apas#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#Ap,#} uṇ. aff. {#kvip#} with the shortening of the initial
<div n="lb">vowel. For another etym. see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>4473<pc>156-b<k1>apa<k2>apa<h>1
I. {#apa#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) A par-
<div n="lb">ticle implying the notion of ‘away’, in its literal and me-
<div n="lb">taphorical acceptations; it is used either as a prefix to verbs
<div n="lb">(and in this capacity, in the Vedas also detached from the
<div n="lb">verb, very much in the same manner as German prepositions
<div n="lb">when connected with verbs), or as a separable preposition,
<div n="lb">or in the Vedas sometimes also adverbially. With nouns it
<div n="lb">may form Tatpur., Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. compounds. [In
<div n="lb">many instances {#ava#} (q. v.) coincides in meaning with {#apa#}
<div n="lb">and in several also the prefix {#A#} q. v.]
<div n="P">1. (as adverb in the Vedas) Away; e. g. {#apa dvezo apa#}
<div n="lb">{#hvaro'nyavratasya saScima#} (comm.: ‘scil. {#gacCatu#}’).
<div n="P">2. (as a prefix to verbs it implies the notion of) <sup>1</sup> Away;
<div n="lb">e. g. with {#nI#} ‘to lead away’; with {#gam#} ‘to go away’;
<div n="lb">with {#hf#} ‘to take away, to rob’. <sup>2</sup> Deterioration; e. g. with
<div n="lb">{#kf#} ‘to act improperly, to injure’; with {#diS#} ‘to simulate’;
<div n="lb">with {#vad#} ‘to blame’. <sup>3</sup> Negation, contradiction; e. g. with
<div n="lb">{#lap#} ‘to deny’; with {#man#} ‘to behave the reverse of respect-
<div n="lb">fully, to despise; with {#ci#} ‘to diminish’; if the base itself
<div n="lb">implies a negative notion, the prefix {#apa#} imparts to it fre-
<div n="lb">quently greater emphasis, e. g. with {#han, trap, hnu#}.
<div n="P">3. (as a separable preposition with a noun depending
<div n="lb">on it in the ablative) <sup>1</sup> Away from; e. g. {#yatsaMpratyapa loke-#}
<div n="lb">{#Byo laNkAyAM vasatirBayAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Without; e. g. {#apa hareH saMsAraH#}
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> With the exception of; e. g. {#apa trigarteByo vfzwo devaH#}.
<div n="P">4. (in composition with nouns <sup>a.</sup> in Tatpur. and Bahuvr.
[Page157-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">compounds it implies the same meanings as the prefix to
<div n="lb">verbs, the notion of negation becoming in the Bahuvr. that
<div n="lb">of privation; <sup>b.</sup> in Avyayībh. compounds: <sup>1</sup> Away from;
<div n="lb">comp. {#apasalavi#} and {#apadiSam,#} and the explan. of the
<div n="lb">comm. {%‘between’.%} <sup>2</sup> Without; e. g. {#apavizRu saMsAraH#}. <sup>3</sup> With
<div n="lb">the exception of; e. g. {#apatrigaMrtaM vfzwo devaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Negation,
<div n="lb">contradiction; e. g. {#apakAmam#}. [As upapada before {#sTA,#}
<div n="lb">{#apa#} has in a few derivations of this radical the influence
<div n="lb">of changing its initial {#s#} into {#z;#} see {#apazWa, apazWu, apazWura,#}
<div n="lb">{#apazWula#}.--In the Ṛgveda {#apa#} occurs in its protracted form
<div n="lb">{#apA#} before {#vfDi,#} and in composition with such derivatives
<div n="lb">of {#vf#} as retain the vowel {#f#} of the radical, see {#apAvfta,#}
<div n="lb">{#apAvfti#}.] E. unknown. See {#pa#} and the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>4474<pc>157-a<k1>apa<k2>apa<h>2
II. {#apa#}¦ m. ({#-paH#}) A sea, an ocean. E. {#ap#} taddh. aff. {#ac#}.
<div n="lb">[Word and meaning are very doubtful; they are given on
<div n="lb">the authority of Rāyamukuṭa, who interprets the word {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#pagA#} in the Amarakosha: {#ApaH santyatreti arSaAdyaci apaH#}
<div n="lb">{#samudraH taM gacCatIti;#} comp. the E. of {#apagA#}. Comp. also {#apavat#}.
<div n="lb">--For beginners it is useful to observe that in compounds like
<div n="lb">{#SuzkApa, vimalApa#} &c., the latter part is not {#apa,#} but that such
<div n="lb">compounds are to be analyzed into {#Suzka#} and {#ap, vimala#}
<div n="lb">and {#ap#} &c., the whole word receiving the samās. aff. {#a#}.]
<LEND>

<L>4475<pc>157-a<k1>apaHsaMvarta<k2>apaHsaMvarta
{#apaHsaMvarta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rtaH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.) The destruc-
<div n="lb">tion of the earth by water. ‘A hundred thousand years pre-
<div n="lb">vious to the destruction of the earth by water, a Deva ap-
<div n="lb">pears to warn all the beings concerned of the event, as when
<div n="lb">it is destroyed by fire; a cloud forms at the same time in a
<div n="lb">Kela-laksha of Sakwalas and after raining for a short time
<div n="lb">disappears. After an immense interval another cloud appears,
<div n="lb">and the rain called Khārodaka begins to fall; at first in
<div n="lb">small drops, but gradually increasing in size until they are
<div n="lb">as large as a palm tree; this rain is so acrid that it dissolves
<div n="lb">entirely the earth and all things connected with it’ (Spence
<div n="lb">Hardy, Manual of Buddhism p. 32). E. {#apas#} and {#saMvarta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4476<pc>157-a<k1>apakara<k2>apakara
{#apakara#}¦ Tatpur. (?) m. ({#-raH#}) Probably the name of a place;
<div n="lb">see the following and {#Apakara#}. E. (?) {#kf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4477<pc>157-a<k1>apakaraka<k2>apakaraka
{#apakaraka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) Born in {#apakara#}. Com-
<div n="lb">pare {#Apakara#}. E. {#apakara,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4478<pc>157-a<k1>apakaraRa<k2>apakaraRa

<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> III treating, offending. E. {#kf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4479<pc>157-a<k1>apakartf<k2>apakartf

<L>4480<pc>157-a<k1>apakarman<k2>apakarman
{#apakarman#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rma#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Evil doing. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.) Tak-
<div n="lb">ing away; esp. in the combination {#dattasyAnapakarma#} or {#dattA-#}
<div n="lb">{#napakarma#} ‘not taking back again a thing given, non-resumption
<div n="lb">of a gift’. E. {#kf#} with {#apa,#} uṇ. aff. {#manin#}.
<div n="P">II. Any impure or degrading act or rite. Comp. {#apakriyA#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#apa#} deter. and {#karman#}.
<LEND>

<L>4481<pc>157-a<k1>apakarza<k2>apakarza
{#apakarza#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rzaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Drawing down, pulling away (the
<div n="lb">converse of {#utkarza,#} drawing up); e. g. (in a comm. on four
<div n="lb">lines of a stanza:) {#atra pAdatraye krameRa banDasya gAQatA . catu-#}
<div n="lb">{#rTapAde tvapakarzaH;#} also figuratively, {%taking off, diminishing,%}
<div n="lb">as in the following instance which combines both appli-
<div n="lb">cations: {#yaTA daRqApakarze tatsaMbanDasyApUpasyApyapakarzaH . taTA pu-#}
<div n="lb">{#trasaMkrAntaDanasya patnIgatatayApakarze tatsaMbanDasya kanyADanAvaSizwa-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaviSezaRasyApakarzaH .#}. <sup>2</sup> Depreciation, deterioration, inferiority,
[Page157-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">degraded condition; (in this sense also opposed to {#prakarza#})
<div n="lb">e. g. the words of Manu {#kuvivAhEH…kulAnyakulatAM yAnti#}
<div n="lb">are explained by Kullūka: {#AsurAdivivAhEH…praKyAta-#}
<div n="lb">{#kulAnyapakarzaM gacCanti;#} or on the affixes of the comparative
<div n="lb">{#tarap#} and {#Iyasun#} a Vārttika observes: {#tarabIyasunorekadra-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyasyotkarzApakarzayorupasaMKyAnam#}. <sup>3</sup> (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Denying or disputing away qualities which a thing possesses
<div n="lb">({#vidyamAnaDarmApacayo'pakarzaH#}); comp. {#apakarzasama#}. <sup>4</sup> Super-
<div n="lb">seding (as a rule); e. g. in the Vārtt. to Pāṇ. III. 4. 102. {#na#}
<div n="lb">{#vA vAkyApakarzAt#} where the last word is explained by
<div n="lb">Patanjali: {#vAkyApakarzAdyAsuw sIyuwaM bADizyate,#} and by
<div n="lb">Kaiyyaṭa: {#liNaH sIyuqityasya vAkyasya yAsuqviDivAkyenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pakarzo bADa ityarTaH .#}. <sup>5</sup> Anticipating something which oc-
<div n="lb">curs later (as a religious act or a word of a sentence);
<div n="lb">in this sense it is met with frequently in writings on the
<div n="lb">Mīmānsā; e. g. {#darSapUrRamAsayoH puroqASasya kapAlezu sTApi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tasyAcCAdanamAmnAtam . BasmanABivAsayatIti . tata UrDvaM ve-#}
<div n="lb">{#dirAmnAtA . tenEva krameRa pOrRamAsIyAge pratipadyanuzWAnaM kf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tam . darSayAge tu vederapakarza AmnAtaH . pUrvedyuramAvAsyAyAM#}
<div n="lb">{#vediM karotIti . tatra vedeH pUrvaBAvino'BivAsanAntasyANga-#}
<div n="lb">{#samUhasyApakarzaH kartavyaH#} &c. |. For the ind. {#apakarzam#} see under
<div n="lb">{#apakarzam#}. E. {#kfz,#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4485<pc>157-b<k1>apakarzasama<k2>apakarzasama
{#apakarzasama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The sophism of the non-existence of qualities; viz. arguing,
<div n="lb">that because two things have one quality not in common,
<div n="lb">they will have none in common; e. g. sound and a jar being
<div n="lb">both artificially produced are perishable; now the sophism
<div n="lb">in question would consist in concluding: that because sound
<div n="lb">has not the quality of shape, which belongs to jar, or because
<div n="lb">a jar does not refer to the sense of hearing as sound does,
<div n="lb">sound and jar are neither artificially produced nor perishable.
<div n="lb">E. {#apakarza#} and {#sama#}. (With respect to the gender of this word
<div n="lb">and the ellipsis required to explain it, see the E. of {#anityasama#}.)
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {#kalaNka#}.
<LEND>

<L>4528<pc>159-a<k1>apagAram<k2>apagAram
{#apagAram#}¦ Tatpur. ind. Having lifted up; the same as {#apago-#}
<div n="lb">{#ram#} q. v. and used either by way of repetition, to express
<div n="lb">the frequent occurrence of the act, or as the latter part of
<div n="lb">a compound, to convey the idea of haste; e. g. {#apagArama-#}
<div n="lb">{#pagAram#} or {#apagoramapagoram,#} ‘having frequently lifted up’;
<div n="lb">{#asyapagAraM#} (or {#asyapagoraM#}) {#yuDyante#} or {#KaqgApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#goraM#}) {#yuDyante#} ‘they fight having lifted up in haste their
<div n="lb">swords’. ({#‘tvarayA KaNgamudyamya yuDyanta ityarTaH’#}.) E. {#gur#} with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul,#} with {#A#} substituted for the guṇa {#o#}.
<LEND>

<L>4532<pc>159-a<k1>apaGana<k2>apaGana
{#apaGana#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) Any limb or member of the body,
<div n="lb">as hands, feet &c. (but not the whole body, as the {%Kāśikā%}
<div n="lb">explicitely observes on Pāṇ. III. 3. 81.: {#apaGano'NgAvayavE-#}
<div n="lb">{#kadeSo na sarvaH . kiM tarhi pARiH pAdaScABiDIyate;#} hence also
<div n="lb">the commentators on the {%Amarak.%} explain the word either
<div n="lb">{#hastAdyavayava#} or {#hastapAdAdyavayava#} or {#hastapAdAdyaNga#} &c. Yet
<div n="lb">{%Bharatasena%} on the Bhaṭṭik. 7. 62. not merely renders {#lali-#}
<div n="lb">{#tApaGanAM = manoharaSarIrAM (striyam),#} (equally so the {%Vaija-%}
<div n="lb">{%yantī%} and {%Kalāpapradīpa;%} the {%Bhaṭṭichandrikā%} = {#sundaraka-#}
<div n="lb">{#levarIm#}), but quotes the opinion of another: {#apahanyate#}
<div n="lb">{#'nenetyapaGano dehaH,#} according to which {#apaGana#} would there-
<div n="lb">fore mean ‘body’ in general; this interpretation, however,
<div n="lb">seems to be incorrect on account of the negative bearing of
<div n="lb">the preposition {#apa;#} comp. {#saMhanana#} and the words of the
<div n="lb">{%Bhāg. Pur.%} {#dehastu sarvasaMGAtaH#}). E. {#han#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">ing; e. g. {#duHKamADyAtmikamADiBOtikamADidEvikaM ca . ye-#}
<div n="lb">{#nABihatAH prARinastadapaGAtAya prayatante#}. <sup>2</sup> Any evil accident
<div n="lb">occasioning death. E. {#han#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4536<pc>159-a<k1>apaca<k2>apaca
{#apaca#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-caH#}) <sup>1</sup> A man who, from his mode of liv-
<div n="lb">ing, does not cook for himself; see the following; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#apacaH parivrAjaka;#} or {#apaco dIkzitaH;#} or a householder in
<div n="lb">a state of destitution: {#‘gfhasTaDarmavftto yo dadAtiparivarjitaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#fziBirDarmatattvajYErapacaH sa prakIrtitaH’;#} eating the food of
<div n="lb">such a man, entails on the receiver the penance of the
<div n="lb">Chāndrāyaṇa {#‘apacasya ca BuktvAnnaM dvijaScAndrAyaRaM caret’#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> One who cannot cook. <sup>3</sup> A bad cook. <sup>4</sup> Different from
<div n="lb">one who cooks. (In the second and third meaning the word
[Page159-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">is udātta on the last syllable; in the other meanings it is
<div n="lb">udātta on the first syllable.) E. {#a#} neg. or deter. and {#paca#}.
<LEND>

<L>4537<pc>159-b<k1>apacamAna<k2>apacamAna
{#apacamAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) A man whose mode of life does
<div n="lb">not allow him to cook for himself; {%Kullūka%} names as such
<div n="lb">the religious student, the religious mendicant, heretics and
<div n="lb">such like people ({#‘apacamAnA brAhmacAriparivrAjakAH pAza-#}
<div n="lb">{#RqAdayaH’#}); he observes however that the ‘heretics &c.’ are
<div n="lb">included in the definition by {%Medhātithi%} and {%Govindarāja%} who
<div n="lb">impart this bearing to {#apacamAna#} in Manu 4. 32, while ac-
<div n="lb">cording to his own opinion the word would rather refer in
<div n="lb">this passage to the {#snAtaka#} or initiated householder than to
<div n="lb">the ‘heretic &c.’--Comp. {#apaca#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pacamAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4538<pc>159-b<k1>apacaya<k2>apacaya
{#apacaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) Decrease, decline, deterioration,
<div n="lb">loss; e. g. {#parimARApacaye'lpaSabdaH;#} used in opposition
<div n="lb">to {#upacaya;#} e. g. {#priyaSirastvAdyaprAptirupacayApacayO hi Bede;#}
<div n="lb">or {#pratikzaRaM SarIrezUpacayApacayadarSanAnnAnAtvam;#} or in op-
<div n="lb">position to {#vfdDi;#} e. g. {#yA SabdasamUhatyAgaparigrahasaMKyAvf-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDyapacayavarRasamAsAnubanDAnAM vyaktAnupacArAdvyaktiH;#} also in op-
<div n="lb">position to {#udaya;#} e. g. in the passage {#cintayanvfdDikzayO#}
<div n="lb">{#munIndrARAm#} the word {#vfdDikzayO#} is explained {#udayApacayO#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In Astrology.) The collective name of eight {%bhāvas%} or
<div n="lb">planetary mansions, which are called severally {#tanu, Dana,#}
<div n="lb">{#suhfd, suta, jAyA, mftyu, Darma, vyaya#} (the remaining four, viz.
<div n="lb">{#sahaja, ripu, karman#} and {#aya#} being called {#upacaya#}). E. {#ci#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4545<pc>160-a<k1>apaciti<k2>apaciti

<div n="lb">but Arjunamiśra: {#pUjAm#}). <sup>2</sup> A proper name: a daughter of
<div n="lb">Marīchi (accord. to the Vāyu and Linga Purāṇas). E. {#cAy#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin,#} with an irregular change of {#cAy#} to {#ci#}.

<L>4546<pc>160-a<k1>apacI<k2>apacI
{#apacI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-cI#}) (In Medicine.) A disease consisting
<div n="lb">in ‘a number of tumors some of which are of the size of
<div n="lb">an Amalaka-stone and others like spawn, which cause
<div n="lb">itching, but otherwise little pain, burst, suppurate and dis-
<div n="lb">appear when others come again’. E. accord. to Suśruta
<div n="lb">{#apa#} and {#cI,#} i. e. ‘a bad gathering’; for he writes {#‘(granTi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BiH) ananyavarRErupacIyamAnaM cayaprakarzAdapacIM vadanti’;#} an
<div n="lb">etym. ‘{#a#} and {#paca#}’ would not merely be at variance with
<div n="lb">its femin. form. in {#I,#} but with the nature of the disease
<div n="lb">itself, since the tumors so called attain maturity; for they
<div n="lb">burst and suppurate: {#‘kaRqUyutAste'lparujaH praBinnAH sravanti#}
<div n="lb">{#naSyanti Bavanti cAnye’#}.
<LEND>

<L>4549<pc>160-a<k1>apacCeda<k2>apacCeda
{#apacCeda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) Cutting off, interrupting; used in
<div n="lb">the liturgical writings of the interruption of a procession
<div n="lb">of priests, caused by the inadvertence of one or several
<div n="lb">amongst them; thus, it being the rule that at the first Savana
<div n="lb">of the Jyotiṣṭoma the priests must proceed one after the
<div n="lb">order ‘in the black-ant fashion’ ({#pipIlikAvatpaNkyAkAreRa#}),
<div n="lb">the one who comes after holding his preceder by the hem
<div n="lb">of his garment, an interruption caused by the dropping of
<div n="lb">the hem, on the part of one priest would be an {#ekakartfko#}
<div n="lb">{#'pacCedaH,#} on the part of the Udgātṛ would be an {#udgAtra-#}
<div n="lb">{#pacCedaH#} or {#udgAturapacCedaH,#} on that of the Udgātṛ and Pratihartṛ
<div n="lb">{#udgAtfpratihatfkftAvapacCedO#}. E. {#Cid#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4559<pc>160-b<k1>apaYcIkfta<k2>apaYcIkfta

<div n="lb">interval caused by a screen’.
<LEND>

<L>4562<pc>160-b<k1>apawI<k2>apawI
{#apawI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-wI#}) A screen or wall of cloth, especially
<div n="lb">the {%Kānāt%} or screen surrounding a tent. Also {#pawI#}. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">expl. and {#pawI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4563<pc>160-b<k1>apawIkzepa<k2>apawIkzepa
{#apawIkzepa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) Literally: tossing up the curtain;
<div n="lb">the instrum. {#apawIkzepeRa#} is used in theatrical language, to
<div n="lb">indicate the precipitate entrance on the stage. E. {#apawI#}
<div n="lb">and {#kzepa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4564<pc>160-b<k1>apawu<k2>apawu
{#apawu#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-wuH-wuH#} or {#-wvI-wu#}) I. Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> Not clever,
<div n="lb">awkward, uncouth. <sup>2</sup> Diseased, sick. [The abstract noun
<div n="lb">of the Tatpur. is {#apawutA#} or {#apawutva#}.] E. {#a#} neg. and {#pawu#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Without clever people. [The abstract noun
<div n="lb">of the Bahuvr. is {#Apawava#}.] E. {#a#} priv. and {#pawu#}.
<LEND>

<L>4565<pc>160-b<k1>apawutA<k2>apawutA
{#apawutA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) or {#apawutva#} n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Uncleverness, awk-
<div n="lb">wardness. <sup>2</sup> Sickness, diseased condition. E. {#apawu#} I., taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>4566<pc>160-b<k1>apaWa<k2>apaWa
{#apaWa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-WaH#}) <sup>1</sup> One who does not read. <sup>2</sup> One who
<div n="lb">cannot read. <sup>3</sup> A bad reader. <sup>4</sup> Different from one who
<div n="lb">reads. (In the second and third meaning the word is udātta
<div n="lb">on the last syllable; in the two other meanings it is udātta
<div n="lb">on the first syllable.) E. {#a#} neg. or deter. and {#paWa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4567<pc>160-b<k1>apaRqita<k2>apaRqita
{#apaRqita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Unlearned, ignorant,
<div n="lb">foolish. E. {#a#} neg. and {#paRqita#}.
<LEND>

<L>4568<pc>160-b<k1>apaRya<k2>apaRya
{#apaRya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-RyaH-RyA-Ryam#}) Not to be sold, im-
<div n="lb">proper for sale. (Articles, for instance, a Brāhmaṇa is not
<div n="lb">permitted to sell, under the penalty of various penances,
<div n="lb">are, according to Hārīta: molasses, sesamum, flowers,
<div n="lb">roots, fruits, boiled rice--the penalty being the {%Somāyana%}
<div n="lb">--; red dye ({%lākṣā%}), sea-salt, honey, flesh, sesamum-oil,
<div n="lb">milk, curdled milk, buttermilk ({%takra%}), clarified butter,
<LEND>

<>DICTIONARY,
<>SANSKRIT AND ENGLISH,
<>EXTENDED AND IMPROVED FROM THE SECOND EDITION OF THE DICTIONARY
<>OF
<>PROFESSOR H. H. WILSON,
<>WITH HIS SANCTION AND CONCURRENCE;
<>TOGRTHER WITH
<>A SUPPLEMENT, GRAMMATICAL APPENDICES AND AN INDEX,
<>SERVING AS
<>AN ENGLISH-SANSKRIT VOCABULARY.
<>BY
<>THEODOR GOLDSTÜCKER,
<>PH. D., PROFESSOR OF THE SANSKRIT LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE IN
<>UNIVERSITY COLLEGE, LONDON.
<>VOL. I. PART 3.
<>{#apatantraka--aBicEdya#}

<>A. ASHER AND CO

<L>4568.1<pc>160-b<k1>apaRya<k2>apaRya
{#apaRya#}¦ [CONTINUED] scents, hides, cloth--the penalty being the {%Chāndrāyaṇa%}
<div n="lb">--; wool, hair, a horse ({%kesarin%}), land, a cow, a house,
<div n="lb">stones, weapons, eatable flesh, tendons, bones, horns, nails,
<div n="lb">shells--the penalty being the {%Taptakṛchchhra%}--; asafœtida,
<div n="lb">bdellium ({%guggula%}), yellow orpiment, red arsenic, collyrium,
<div n="lb">red chalk, medicinal and other salt ({%kṣāra%} and {%lavaṇa%}),
<div n="lb">precious stones, pearls, corals, bambu staves, wickerwork
<div n="lb">and earthen ware or what is appropriate for ornamental
<div n="lb">gardens, ponds, wells and lotus tanks--the penalty in
<div n="lb">the latter case consisting in three daily ablutions, sleeping
<div n="lb">on the ground, eating only once on the evening of every
<div n="lb">second day, and muttering ten thousand charms, all this
<div n="lb">during a whole year. See also {%Manu%} 10. 86 ff.--An idol, if
<div n="lb">it is carried about by a person for the sake of getting a
<div n="lb">living but not for the purpose of sale, is expressed by the
<div n="lb">same name as the divinity without an additional affix, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#vAsudeva, vizRu, skanda;#} but if it is offered for sale, it takes
<div n="lb">the affix {#kan,#} e. g. {#vAsudevaka#}.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#paRya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4569<pc>161-a<k1>apatantraka<k2>apatantraka
{#apatantraka#}¦ Tatpur.(?) m. ({#-kaH#}) (In Medicine.) One of the dis-
<div n="lb">eases of the vital air (see {#vAtavyADi#}), viz. a peculiar kind of
<div n="lb">spasmodic contraction of the body (tetanus?); described in the
<div n="lb">following manner: ‘if the vital air is deranged and rises from
<div n="lb">its situation, it produces pain in the chest, head and temples,
<div n="lb">convulses and bends the body; the patient is motionless,
<div n="lb">his eyes shut and fixed, he moans, he does not breathe or
<div n="lb">breathes with difficulty and has no consciousness; he feels
<div n="lb">well when the chest becomes free, otherwise he faints away’.
<div n="lb">E. {#tantri#} ({#tantra,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}), with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#} (?).
<LEND>

<L>4570<pc>161-a<k1>apatarpaRa<k2>apatarpaRa
{#apatarpaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) Fasting (in sickness &c.). E. {#tfp#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4571<pc>161-a<k1>apatAnaka<k2>apatAnaka
{#apatAnaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) (In Medicine.) One of the diseases
<div n="lb">of the vital air (see {#vAtavyADi#}), viz. a spasmodic contraction
<div n="lb">of the body; described thus: ‘if the vital air, much af-
<div n="lb">fected with phlegm, stops in the tubular vessels, it causes
<div n="lb">the patient to fall down at intervals’. E. {#tan,#} in the caus.,
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">of this word is like that of other nouns in {#i;#} comp. s. v.
<div n="lb">{#pati#}.]

<L>4580<pc>161-b<k1>apatya<k2>apatya
{#apatya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tyam#}) Offspring in general, whether male or
<div n="lb">female ({#‘apatyABiDAne strIpuM~lliNgasyAprasidDirnapuMsakatvAt’#});
<div n="lb">whether sons or the later generations of a Gotra ({#‘putrapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ryAyo'patyaSabdaH . pOtrapraBftO tu gORa iti BAvaH’;#} or {#‘a-#}
<div n="lb">{#patyaM pOtrapraBftigotramiti sUtrakAreRa sAmAnADikaraRyena nirdeSaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kftaH’#}); e. g. {#ftvikpurohitApatyaBAryAdAsasanABiBiH . vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdaM varjayitvA tu sarvAM~llokAnjayedgfhI;#} but sometimes the
<div n="lb">word means only ‘the children’ ({#‘apatyADikArAdanyatra lO-#}
<div n="lb">{#kikaM gotraM gfhyate . apatyamAtraM na tu pOtrapraBftyeva’#} as the {%Kā-%}
<div n="lb">{%śikā%} observes on {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 39).--Compare {#gotra, vfdDa#} and
<div n="lb">{#yuvan#}. [In the passage of the {%Amarak.%} {#‘strIpuMsayorapatyAntAH’#}
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘patronymics are masculines and feminines’, {#apatya#} im-
<div n="lb">plies ‘a patronymical affix’; comm.: {#‘apatyArTe vihitA ye#}
<div n="lb">{#'RRAdayastadantAH’#}.] E. According to the native etym. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#patya#} ({#pat,#} kṛtya aff. {#yat#}) ‘the family being preserved
<div n="lb">by them from decay’; it has been proposed to derive this
<div n="lb">word from {#apa,#} taddh. aff. {#tyap,#} which E. is plausible from a
<div n="lb">grammatical point of view; but the native E. is countenanced
<div n="lb">by the words {#napAt#} and {#naptf#} qq. vv. which convey a notion
<div n="lb">similar to that of {#apatya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4594<pc>161-b<k1>apatrasta<k2>apatrasta
{#apatrasta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) Afraid of; with a noun
<div n="lb">in the abl.; e. g. {#taraNgAdapatrastaH;#} it may form a Tatpur. with
<div n="lb">such a noun, but the instances of such compounds are few,
[Page162-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">according to Pāṇini, e. g. {#taraNgApatrastaH#} ‘afraid of a wave’;
<div n="lb">but {#BojanAdapatrastaH#} (not {#BojanApatrastaH#}) ‘afraid of food’.
<div n="lb">E. {#tras#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>4595<pc>162-a<k1>apatrApya<k2>apatrApya
{#apatrApya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-pyaH-pyA-pyam#}) To be ashamed of.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-pyam#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.) One of the 108
<div n="lb">{#DarmAlokamuKa#} q. v., probably: bashfulness; it leads to dis-
<div n="lb">passion for the exterior world. E. {#trap#} with {#apa,#} kṛtya aff. {#Ryat#}.
<LEND>

<L>4596<pc>162-a<k1>apatrigartam<k2>apatrigartam
{#apatrigartam#}¦ Avyayībh. Except in Trigarta. E. {#apa#} and {#trigarta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4597<pc>162-a<k1>apaTa<k2>apaTa
{#apaTa#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-Tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Absence of a road. <sup>2</sup> A bad or
<div n="lb">wrong road, literally and metaphorically; e. g. {#yaH kAki-#}
<div n="lb">{#nImapyapaTaprapannAM samudDarennizkasahasratulyAm . kadApi kowizva-#}
<div n="lb">{#pi muktahastastaM rAjasiMhaM na jahAti lakzmIH ..;#} or {#mA BUvannapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#TaharAstavendriyASvAH#}.--<sup>3</sup> The vulva (comp. {#avAcyadeSa#}).
<div n="lb">Comp. {#apaTin#}. E. {#a#} neg. or deter. and {#paTin,#} samās. aff. {#a#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-TaH-TA-Tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Roadless. <sup>2</sup> Hav-
<div n="lb">ing bad roads.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-TA#}) The name of several plants: <sup>a.</sup> = {#padmaka,#}
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> Dry ginger, <sup>c.</sup> Terminalia chebula, <sup>d.</sup> Saccharum sponta-
<div n="lb">neum, <sup>e.</sup> {#priyaNgu#} ({%Sureśvara:%} {#apaTA padmake SuRWyAM paTyAni-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzupriyaMguzu#}). E. {#a#} priv. or deter. and {#paTin,#} samās. aff. {#a#}.
<LEND>

<L>4600<pc>162-a<k1>apaTya<k2>apaTya

<L>4603<pc>162-a<k1>apad<k2>apad
{#apad#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-t-t-t#}) (ved.) Going on a road
<div n="lb">which does not exist or which is unknown. [In the passage
<div n="lb">in which this word occurs, {%Śatap.%} XIV. 8. 15. 10., it is an
<div n="lb">epithet of {#gAyatrI,#} which for mystical reasons has been
<div n="lb">called previously {#ekapadI#} ‘one-footed’, {#dvipadI#} ‘two-footed’,
<div n="lb">{#tripadI#} ‘three-footed’ and {#catuzpadI#} ‘four-footed’; {%Dwiveda-%}
<div n="lb">{%ganga%} on the {%Śatapathabr.%} explains {#apad#} ‘because a {#pada#} i. e.
<div n="lb">by what she may be known does not exist’--{#padyase jYA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yase yena tatpadaM na vidyate yasyAH sA tvamapadasi#}--; but ac-
<div n="lb">cording to this gloss {#apad#} would be a Bahuvr., while its
<div n="lb">accent--the udātta on the first syllable--assigns it to
<div n="lb">the class of Tatpur. compounds. The interpretation of {%Śan-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara%} on the same passage in the {%Bṛhadār.%} seems therefore
<div n="lb">preferable: {#avidyamAnaM padaM yena padyase sA tvamapadasi#} ‘thou
<div n="lb">art {#apad#} because thou goest on a road which does not
<div n="lb">exist or which is unknown’.--In no case can the word
[Page162-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">mean ‘footless’, for its form would then be {#apadI#} and its
<div n="lb">accent the udātta on the penultima.--Bahuvr. forms
<div n="lb">like {#apade, apadI#} &c. belong to the base {#apAd#} q. v., not
<div n="lb">to a base {#apad#}.] E. {#a#} neg. and {#pad#} (with an ellipsis of {#pada#}).
<LEND>

<L>4604<pc>162-b<k1>apada<k2>apada
{#apada#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-dam#}) <sup>1</sup> No-place. <sup>2</sup> A place which can-
<div n="lb">not be stepped or dwelt upon, a bad place. <sup>3</sup> (In Grammar.)
<div n="lb">A word which is not a {#pada#} (q. v.) or an inflected word;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#sagatigrahaRamapadatvAt#}. E. {#a#} neg. or deter. and {#pada#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) <sup>1</sup> Footless. <sup>2</sup> With-
<div n="lb">out a place, without a shelter; e. g. {#padApadA pariBramannayena#}
<div n="lb">{#yApadApadA#} (comm. {#apadA atrARA asTAnA vA damayantI#} &c.).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Unsteady, fickle; e. g. {#apadamA#} (comm. {#asTiralakzmIkA#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-daH#}) A reptile.
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-dam#}) (ved.) The æther (according to {%Sāyaṇa%}
<div n="lb">and {%Mahīdhara;%} the accent of the word in the latter sense
<div n="lb">is irregular, viz. the udātta on the second syllable). E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">priv. and {#pada#}.
<LEND>

<L>4614<pc>162-b<k1>apadiSam<k2>apadiSam
{#apadiSam#}¦ Avyayībh. Between two regions of the compass
<div n="lb">(as south-east &c.). [The {%Siddhāntakaum.%} appears to assume
<div n="lb">also a neuter {#apadiSa (-Sam)#} ‘intermediate space of the
<div n="lb">compass’, since it explains {#apadiSam#} as representing the
<div n="lb">value of the instrum. or locative of {#apadiSa#} viz. {#‘apadiSam .#}
<div n="lb">{#apadiSena . apadiSam . apadiSe’;#} but the comm. on the
<div n="lb">{%Amarak.%} I. 1. 2. 7. take the words {#‘klIvAvyayam’#} mentioned
<div n="lb">there, expressly as meaning ‘Avyayībh.’ and as imparting
<div n="lb">moreover to {#apa#} in {#apadiSam#} the meaning ‘in the middle of’.
<div n="lb">{%Svāmin%} explains {#apadiSam#} as representing the value of a
<div n="lb">case of {#diS#} (comp. Pāṇ. II. 1. 6), but {%Bhanūjid.%} refutes
<div n="lb">him in contending that the word could not imply then the
<div n="lb">notion of ‘in the middle of’: {#‘diSoridamapadiSaM viBaktyarTe#}
<div n="lb">{#'vyayIBAva iti svAmI . tanna . saMbanDamAtrasya viBaktyarTatve'pi#}
<div n="lb">{#maDyasya tadarTatvABAvAt’#}.--It seems unnecessary, however,
[Page163-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">to create a new meaning of {#apa#} on account of this com-
<div n="lb">pound, as {#apadiSam#} could well signify literally ‘away from
<div n="lb">one region and another’ i. e. between both. For a similar
<div n="lb">interpretation of {#apa#} comp. {#apasalavi#}.] E. {#apa#} and {#diS,#}
<div n="lb">samās. aff. {#wac,#} or {#apa#} and {#diSA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4618<pc>163-a<k1>apadeSa<k2>apadeSa
{#apadeSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Stating, adducing, as a reason
<div n="lb">&c.; e. g. in the {%Nyāya S.%} {#hetvapadeSAtpratijYAyAH punarvacanaM#}
<div n="lb">{#nigamanam#} (comm. {#apadeSaH kaTanam#}); or {#notpattikAraRAnapade-#}
<div n="lb">{#SAt#} (comm. {#anapadeSAdakaTanAt#}). <sup>2</sup> An argument, a reason;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Nyāya S.%} {#upalaByamAne cAnupalabDerasattvAdanapadeSaH#}
<div n="lb">(comm. {#heturanapadeSo'sADakaH#}); or in the {%Kaṇāda Sūtras:%}
<div n="lb">{#arTAntaraM hyarTAntarasyAnapadeSaH;#} or {#aprasidDo'napadeSo'saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#digDo vAnapadeSaH ..#}.--In the terminology of the {%Vaiśe-%}
<div n="lb">{%shika%} philosophy {#apadeSa#} is the second of the five parts
<div n="lb">of a syllogism; the same as the {#hetu#} of the Nyāya; com-
<div n="lb">pare the instance s. v. {#anusanDAna#}.--{%Suśruta%} defines and
<div n="lb">exemplifies it thus: {#anena kAraRenetyapadeSaH . yaTApadiSyate#}
<div n="lb">{#maDureRa SlezmABivarData iti ..#}. <sup>3</sup> A pretence, a pretext, a
<div n="lb">feint (this is the more usual meaning in which the word
<div n="lb">occurs). <sup>4</sup> Disguise; also metaphorically; e. g. {#vikArApade-#}
<div n="lb">{#SopadeSAtsaMSayaH#} (where the {#vikAra#} refers to the change
<div n="lb">of vowels into semivowels). <sup>5</sup> A butt, a mark; e. g. {#labDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#sApadeSaH#}. <sup>6</sup> Name, reputation; e. g. {#yaM svapadeSaM kamitaH sva-#}
<div n="lb">{#jano'yaM prApya janapadeSaM#} &c. (comm. {#apadeSo nAma . tAdfSaM#}
<div n="lb">{#SoBanAKyaM yaM#} &c.). <sup>7</sup> Place, quarter; e. g. {#tyaktApadeSo yatiH#}.
<div n="lb">(For beginners it is useful to notice that words like {#rAja-#}
<div n="lb">{#putrApadeSin#} are not to be analyzed into {#rAjaputra#} and {#apade-#}
<div n="lb">{#Sin,#} but into {#rAjaputra-apadeSa,#} when the whole compound
<div n="lb">receives the taddh. aff. {#ini#}.) E. {#diS#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4627<pc>163-a<k1>apaDvaMsaja<k2>apaDvaMsaja
{#apaDvaMsaja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The offspring of a father inferior
<div n="lb">in caste to that of the mother, as a Sūta, the son of a
<div n="lb">Kshatriya man and a Brāhmaṇī woman &c.; the same as
<div n="lb">{#pratilomaja#} q. v. Such men have not the rights of the twice-
[Page163-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">born, but the duties of a Śūdra; they do not receive the
<div n="lb">investiture with the sacred string and must follow occupa-
<div n="lb">tions which are held in disrespect by the three first castes.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#anantaraja#}. E. {#apaDvaMsa#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>4640<pc>163-b<k1>apanuda<k2>apanuda
{#apanuda#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Who or what removes;
<div n="lb">only in composition with {#Soka#} i. e. {#SokApanuda;#} on which
<div n="lb">word a {%Vārttika%} ({%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 5.) observes that it does not
<div n="lb">merely convey the negative notion ‘removing pain’ but the
<div n="lb">positive idea ‘affording joy’, for the word which would ex-
<div n="lb">press the negative meaning ‘removing pain’ is, according
<div n="lb">to {%Patanjali%} and his comm. {#SokApanoda#}. ({%Patanj.%} {#SokApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#nudaH putro jAtaH…yaSca Sokamapanudati SokApanodaH ..#}.
<div n="lb">{%Kaiyy.%} {#yaH saMsArAnityatodBAvanAdinA Sokameva nivartayati#}
<div n="lb">{#na tu suKamutpAdayati sa SokApanodaH ..#}. {%Siddhāntak.%} {#yaSca saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#sArAsAratvopadeSena Sokamapanudati sa SokApanodaH#}.) In this
<div n="lb">sense therefore are to be understood passages like: {#pOrA#}
<div n="lb">{#nivartaDvamiti nyagadIttAtasya SokApanudA Baveta;#} or {#SarmadaM mA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rutiM dUtaM vizamasTaH kapidvipam . SokApanudamavyagraM prAyuNkta ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#pikuYjaraH ..#}. E. {#nud#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>
[Page164-a+ 56]

<div n="lb">ing. E. {#nud,#} in the desider., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#u#}.
<LEND>

<L>4647<pc>164-a<k1>apapAtra<k2>apapAtra
{#apapAtra#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-traH-trA-tram#}) Deprived of vessels.
<div n="lb">According to {%Manu,%} Chāṇḍālas and Śvapachas--the lowest
<div n="lb">tribes who are not permitted to reside within the precincts
<div n="lb">of a Brāhmanic community--must be deprived also of
<div n="lb">vessels, since no vessel used by them, as Kullūka observes,
<div n="lb">is capable of purification. E. {#apa#} and {#pAtra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4648<pc>164-a<k1>apapAtrita<k2>apapAtrita

<div n="lb">not eat or drink from a common vessel, one who has lost
<div n="lb">caste through some great offence and thereby is incapaci-
<div n="lb">tated from inheritance; ({%Raghunandana:%} {#SaNKApastambO . apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAtritasya rikTapiRqodakAni nivartanta iti . apapAtrito#}
<div n="lb">{#'tyutkawadozeRa jYAtiBirBinnodakIkftaH pitfDanAdyanaDikArI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyarTaH#}). E. {#apapAtri#} ({#apapAtra,#} denom. aff. {#Ric#}), kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4652<pc>164-a<k1>apapitva<k2>apapitva
{#apapitva#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tvam#}) (ved.) Going away from, sever-
<div n="lb">ance. E. {#Ap#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#tvan;#} (in analogy with
<div n="lb">the etym. of {#sapitva#} as given by {%Sāyaṇa;%} but {%Benfey%}--s. v.
<div n="lb">{#prapitva#} in his Glossary to the Sāmaveda--is probably more
<div n="lb">correct in referring this and similar formations to a radical
<div n="lb">{#ap#} (comp. the E. of {#apta#}). The compound is irregular on
<div n="lb">account of the short vowel of the second syllable and belongs,
<div n="lb">in this respect, to the class of {#karkanDu, SakanDu, sImanta#} &c.).
<LEND>

<L>4664<pc>164-b<k1>apaBraMSa<k2>apaBraMSa
{#apaBraMSa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) 1. <sup>1</sup> Falling down. <sup>2</sup> Incorrect language;
<div n="lb">whether the form of the word be at variance with the rules
<div n="lb">of Sanskṛt grammar, or its sense not a Sanskṛtic one;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Kumārila in his Mīmānsā Vārttika:%} {#yaTA sADvanurUpatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tpramAdASaktijezvapi . jAyate vAcakaBrAntistaTEva mlecCaBAzite ..#}
<div n="lb">{#SabdApaBraMSavadeva gORaBrAntyAdiprayoganimittA arTApaBraMSA Ba-#}
<div n="lb">{#vanti;#} or the same: {#deSaBAzApaBraMSapadAni hi viplutiBUyi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zWAni na Sakyante vivektum#}. <sup>3</sup> The name of the lowest
<div n="lb">class of the Prākṛt dialects; according to some the same
<div n="lb">as the Paisāchī dialect, according to others different from
<div n="lb">the latter and inferior to it; the division of the Prākṛt
<div n="lb">dialect being either: the {%Bhāṣā%} (comprising the Prākṛt
<div n="lb">proper or the Māhārāṣtrī, the Śaurasenī, Māgadhī, Ardha-
<div n="lb">māgadhī and the southern dialects), the {%Vibhāṣā%} (compris-
<div n="lb">ing the Śākārī, Chāṇḍālī, Śābarī, Ābhīrī, Drāvidī and
<div n="lb">Odrī) and the {%Apabhranśa%} or {%Paisāchī%} (comprising the pro-
<div n="lb">vincial dialects as the Gurjarātī, Kārnatī &c.); or the {%Prā-%}
<div n="lb">{%kṛt proper,%} the {%Śaurasenī,%} the {%Māgadhī%} (with the Ardhamā-
<div n="lb">gadhī and the other dialects named before), the {%Paisāchī,%}
<div n="lb">and the {%Apabhranśa,%} the latter then being especially ap-
<div n="lb">propriated to the language of the Ābhīra and contiguous
<div n="lb">peoples and excluded from poetry where the other dia-
<div n="lb">lects may occur. See {%Lassen's%} Institutiones Linguae Pra-
<div n="lb">criticae, and compare the following remark of {%Bharatasena%}
<div n="lb">on a verse of the {%Bhaṭṭikāvya%} where several words are
<div n="lb">Sanskṛt as well as Prākṛt: {#kAvyaM saMskftaprAkftApaBraMSaBedA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttriviDam . prAkfto'pi saMskftaBavaH saMskftasamo deSI cetya-#}
<div n="lb">{#nekaviDaH . atra deSisaMskftaBavayoH prAkftayorapaBraMSasya cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sADuSabdatvenADarmajanakatvAt . upakrAnte saMskfte banDe samAveSA-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMBavAcca . mahAkavirBartfharirasAmarTyaM boDayaYCabdasamAyAH prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kftaBAzAyAH saMskftabanDe samAveSaM darSayati#} &c. According to
<div n="lb">several comm. on the {%Amarak.%} the word may be written
<div n="lb">also {#apaBraMsa;#} but this reading is rejected as wrong by {%Rā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yamukuṭa:%} {#dantyo'pItyeke . tadasat . sransu Bransu aDaHpatane .#}
<div n="lb">{#ityasya GaYi rUpaM na dfSyata iti BAzyAdAvuktatvAt#}.--E. {#BraMS#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">2. A bad fall. E. {#apa#} and {#BraMSa#} ({#BraMS,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}).
<LEND>

<L>4685<pc>165-a<k1>apamuKa<k2>apamuKa
{#apamuKa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-KaH-KA-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Having a bad or
<div n="lb">plain face or mouth. <sup>2</sup> Having the face averted.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Except the face or mouth. <sup>2</sup> With-
<div n="lb">out a face or mouth. [The word is udātta on the last syl-
<div n="lb">lable. Beginners may notice that the meaning I. 1. follows
<div n="lb">from {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 177. which rule is given as an exception to
<div n="lb">VI. 2. 168., the meaning I. 2. from VI. 2. 186. which rule is
[Page165-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">given as an exception to the word {#Druva#} of VI. 2. 177--
<div n="lb">‘averted’ not being the constant condition of a face--and
<div n="lb">the meanings II. 1. 2. also from VI. 2. 186. which is, then,
<div n="lb">an exception to VI. 2. 33.; comp. {%Patanjali%} to VI. 2. 186. {#kima-#}
<div n="lb">{#rTamidamucyate . na upasargAtsvANgamityeva sidDam . aBermuKamapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ccADruvArTam#} (Vārtt. 1.) {#. aDruvArTo'yamAramBaH .. abahuvrIhyarTo#}
<div n="lb">{#vA#} (Vārtt. 2.) {#. aTavAbahuvrIheriti vartate . abahuvrIhyarTo'ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAramBaH ..;#} {%Kāśikā:%} {#avyayIBAvo'pyatra prayojayati . tatrApi pa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ripratyupApA varjyamAnAhorAtrAvayavezvityuktam ..#}.] E. {#apa#} and {#muKa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4686<pc>165-b<k1>apamUrDan<k2>apamUrDan
{#apamUrDan#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rDA-rDA-rDa#}) Headless. E. {#apa#} and {#mUrDan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4687<pc>165-b<k1>apamftyu<k2>apamftyu
{#apamftyu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tyuH#}) <sup>1</sup> Sudden death, death caused by
<div n="lb">some casualty, as by animals, lightning &c., not by sick-
<div n="lb">ness or decay. <sup>2</sup> A minor death: a term applied to a des-
<div n="lb">perate sickness, an alarming danger, to any awful accident
<div n="lb">or perilous circumstance, from which, contrary to expectation,
<div n="lb">the subject recovers or escapes (Molesw.). E. {#apa#} and {#mftyu#}.
<LEND>

<L>4688<pc>165-b<k1>apamfzita<k2>apamfzita

<div n="lb">e. g. {#apamfzitaM vAkyamAha#} (= {#avispazwamityarTaH#}). E. {#mfz#} with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#} and āgama {#iw#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">cleaned (ved.); e. g. {#apamfzwaH SaRqaH#} (comm.: {#apamfzwa ABicA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rikaM yajuH . SaRqanAmako'surapurohitaH Sukraputro'pamfzwaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#apamArjanIkftaH#}). E. {#mfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
