<L>4694<pc>165-b<k1>apara<k2>apara
{#apara#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. (is {#sarvanAman#} q. v.--except as the latter part
<div n="lb">of Dwandwa and Bahuvr. compounds in general, as the latter
<div n="lb">part of Tatpur. the former part of which has the sense of an
<div n="lb">instrum., optionally as the latter part of Bahuvr. which have
<div n="lb">the sense of a region of the compass and as the latter part of
<div n="lb">a Dwandwa in the nom. plur. m., optionally too in general in the
<div n="lb">abl. and loc. sing. m. and n., and in the nom. plur. m.--sing.
<div n="lb">nom. {#-raH-rA-ram,#} abl. {#-rasmAt#} or {#-rAt-rasyAH-rasmAt#} or
<div n="lb">{#-rAt,#} dat. {#-rasmE-rasyE-rasmE,#} gen. {#-rasya-rasyAH-rasya,#} loc.
<div n="lb">{#-rasmin#} or {#-re-rasyAm-rasmin#} or {#-re;#} plur. nom. {#-re#} or {#-rAH#}
<div n="lb">{#-rAH-rARi,#} gen. {#-rezAm-rAsAm-rezAm#}). The converse of
<div n="lb">{#pUrva#}. <sup>1</sup> Distant, remote; e. g. {#sa viSvAcIraBicazwe GftAcIra-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntarA pUrvamaparaM ca ketum#} (comm.: {#pUrvamimaM lokamaparamamuM lokaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca#}); {#aparaM kUlam,#} the opposite shore (opposed to {#pUrvaM kUlam#}
<div n="lb">the nearer i. e. this side of the shore). <sup>2</sup> Posterior, follow-
<div n="lb">ing, later; e. g. {#prANmuhUrtAtpraBAte'haM BavizyAmi DruvaM suKI .#}
<div n="lb">{#AgAmini tataH kAle yo dvitIyaH kzaRo'paraH . tatra jetuM#}
<div n="lb">{#gamizyAmi tridaSendraM sahAmaram .; aparA saMDyA,#} the evening-
<div n="lb">twilight (opposed to {#pUrvA saMDyA,#} the morning-twilight). In
<div n="lb">this sense the word may be the first part of Karmadh. com-
<div n="lb">pounds, e. g. {#aparapakza#} q. v.--{#aparam#} is used adv. in the sense
<div n="lb">‘further, moreover’ to connect different sentences; for its
<div n="lb">sense ‘in future’ see I. 3. 2. and compare {#aparI#}. Comp.
<div n="lb">also {#pUrvApara#}. <sup>3</sup> Last, behind, in space and time; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#kIrtitastriviDastveza#} (viz. {#saMyogaH#}) {#Adyo'nyatarakarmajaH . ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ToBayakriyAjanyo BavetsaMyogajo'paraH ..#}. In this sense it
[Page166-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">may form with a noun depending on it in the genitive a
<div n="lb">Tatpur. (not a Karmadh.) compound of which it is the
<div n="lb">former part; e. g. {#aparakAya,#} the hind part of the body {#(=#}
<div n="lb">{#aparaM kAyasya); apararAtra,#} the last part of the night; {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAhla,#} the last part of the day qq. vv.; if the latter part of such
<div n="lb">a compound is a name of a season and a derivative is formed
<div n="lb">of it by means of a taddh. aff. which has a {#Y, R#} or {#k#}
<div n="lb">as anubandha, the first syllable of this latter part receives
<div n="lb">Vṛddhi, not that of {#apara;#} thus from {#aparavarzA,#} the last
<div n="lb">part of the rainy season, comes {#aparavArzika#} (taddh. aff.
<div n="lb">{#Wak#}); from {#aparahemanta#} comes {#aparahEmana#} (taddh. aff. {#aR#});
<div n="lb">from {#aparanidAGa, aparanEdAGa#} (taddh. aff. {#aR#}) &c. qq. vv.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Western (opp. to {#pUrva#} eastern); in this sense it may be
<div n="lb">the first part of Karmadh. compounds, <sup>a.</sup> if the com-
<div n="lb">pound expresses a conventional term (e. g. a proper name);
<div n="lb">e. g. {#aparezukAmaSamI, aparapARinIya#} qq. vv.; such compounds
<div n="lb">have the udātta accent on the third syllable, if the latter part
<div n="lb">is the name of a village, a country, a legend, or the word
<div n="lb">{#cAnarAwa,#} or if it implies the meaning pupil, being itself a
<div n="lb">derivative of the name of a teacher; if the latter part of such
<div n="lb">a compound is the name of a country--except {#madra#}--or that
<div n="lb">of a village or town of an eastern country and a derivative
<div n="lb">is formed of it by means of a taddh. aff. which has a {#Y, R#}
<div n="lb">or {#k#} as anubandha, the first syllable of this latter part re-
<div n="lb">ceives Vṛddhi, not that of {#apara,#} e. g. {#aparapAYcAlaka#} (from
<div n="lb">{#aparapaYcAla,#} taddh. aff. {#vuY#})--but {#Aparamadra#} (from {#apara-#}
<div n="lb">{#madra,#} taddh. aff. {#aY#})--, {#aparEzukAmaSama#} (from {#aparezukA-#}
<div n="lb">{#maSamI,#} taddh. aff. {#aR#}), {#aparakArzRamfttika#} (from {#aparakf-#}
<div n="lb">{#zRamfttikA,#} taddh. aff. {#aR#}) qq. vv. &c.; such derivatives
<div n="lb">have the udātta accent on the third syllable; <sup>b.</sup> if a de-
<div n="lb">rivative is to be made of such a compound by means of a
<div n="lb">taddh. aff.; e. g. {#apara#} and {#SAlA#} become {#aparaSAlA,#} the
<div n="lb">western hall, for the sake of deriving {#AparaSAla;#} or <sup>c.</sup> if
<div n="lb">such a compound is to become the former part of a com-
<div n="lb">pound; e. g. if {#apara#} and {#SAlA#} are to form a Bahuvr. with
<div n="lb">{#priya (aparaSAlApriya);#} otherwise {#apara#} (western) is not al-
<div n="lb">lowed to form a Karmadh. with another noun.--The in-
<div n="lb">strum. {#apareRa#} q. v. (which however is considered by {%Pāṇ.%} as
<div n="lb">a deriv. of {#apara#} by means of a taddh. aff. {#enap#}) governs in
<div n="lb">the sense ‘western of’ and with the implied sense ‘not far,
<div n="lb">near’ the accus. or genit., e. g. {#apareRa grAmam#} or {#grAmasya;#} it is
<div n="lb">used then in the sense of the nom., viz. ‘the western region
<div n="lb">which is near’, or in that of the locat., viz. ‘in the near west’.
<div n="lb">[The notion ‘western’--as has been observed already by
<div n="lb">{%Wilson%}--is derived from the meaning ‘behind’, as that of
<div n="lb">{#pUrva#} ‘eastern’ from its meaning ‘before’; comp. Viṣṇup.
<div n="lb">p. 219, note 7.] Comp. {#avara#}. <sup>5</sup> Other (in general), different,
<div n="lb">opposed; used in this sense in the same manner as {#anya;#} e. g.
<div n="lb">{#mAtaraM BrAtaraM jyezWaM kanizWamaparAnapi . parityajeta ko nvadya#} &c.;
<div n="lb">also with a noun in the abl. (like other synonymes of {#anya#}),
<div n="lb">‘different from’; e. g. {#yallABAnnAparo lABo yatsuKAnnAparaM su-#}
<div n="lb">{#Kam . yajjYAnAnnAparaM jYAnaM tadbrahmetyavaDArayet;#} comp. also III.
<div n="lb">When it occurs as opposed to ‘the one’ (the one…the
<div n="lb">other) the correlative term is {#apara#} or {#eka, anya, kiMcit,#}
<div n="lb">{#kiMcana;#} e. g. of two: {#cAturBOtikamityeke . ekaBOtikamityapare;#}
<div n="lb">or {#SAKinaH kecidaDyazWurnyamANkzurapare'mbuDO;#} of three: {#saMceruH#}
[Page166-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#sahasAH kecidasvanAH kecidAwizuH . saMyAmavanto yativanni-#}
<div n="lb">{#gadAnapare'mucan;#} of four: {#kecinninindurnfpamapraSAntaM vicu-#}
<div n="lb">{#kruSuH kecana sAsramuccEH . UcustaTAnye Baratasya mAyAM Dikkeka-#}
<div n="lb">{#yImityaparo jagAda ..;#} of five: {#anye tvalaNGizuH SElAnguhA-#}
<div n="lb">{#svanye nyalezata . kecidAsizata stabDA BayAtkecidaGUrRizuH . u-#}
<div n="lb">{#datArizuramBoDiM vAnarAH setunApare ..#} &c.; (these combina-
<div n="lb">tions of the correlative terms vary according to the authors,
<div n="lb">but the last term is usually {#apara#}). Sometimes {#apara#} is also
<div n="lb">opposed to {#sva#} ‘own’, when it assumes the sense of {%‘foreign,%}
<div n="lb">{%not belonging to one's self’,%} e. g. {#samIhitaM tasya nAcetansve#}
<div n="lb">{#na cApare#} (comm.: {#sve AtmIyAH…apare parakIyAH#}).--
<div n="lb">In this sense (5.) the word may form Karmadh. compounds
<div n="lb">of which it is the first part; e. g. {#aparapuruza, aparADyApaka#} q. v.
<div n="lb">[In the Vedas the feminine occurs also in the form {#aparI#}
<div n="lb">with the udātta on the last syllable, although {#apara#} is other-
<div n="lb">wise udātta on the first syllable; e. g. {#utAparIByo maGavA#}
<div n="lb">{#vi jigye;#} the present edition of Pāṇ. IV. 1. 30. notices this
<div n="lb">fact, but represents {#aparI#} as udātta on the first syllable;
<div n="lb">a Ms. of the Kāśikā (E. I. H. 2440) reads in this Sūtra in-
<div n="lb">stead of {#aparI#} the word {#avarI,#} but the instance alleged in
<div n="lb">this Ms. is rather of doubtful correctness: {#‘avarI kanyA ma-#}
<div n="lb">{#GavA vi jigye . avareti BAzAyAm’#}. Comp. {%Ṛgv.%} I. 32. 13.
<div n="lb">Patanjali gives no comment on this word, nor his com-
<div n="lb">mentators.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-raH#}) The hind foot of an elephant (scil. {#pAdaH#}).
<div n="P">3. n. f. <sup>1</sup> ({#-ram-rA#}) The hind quarter of an elephant.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> ({#-ram-rI#}) (ved.) Future time. [It may be doubtful
<div n="lb">whether the word is not a masc. instead of a neuter in this
<div n="lb">sense, since it occurs only in an oblique case, when the
<div n="lb">dative {#aparAya#} is explained by {%Sāyaṇa%} with the ellipsis of
<div n="lb">{#kAlaH = aparasminkAle#} ‘in future’, and the accus., which
<div n="lb">is also used adverbially: ‘in future’, with the same ellipsis
<div n="lb">(= {#aparasminkAle#}) or with that of {#dina#} (= {#aparasmindine#}).
<div n="lb">In the femin. the ellipsis is a word meaning night, as {#rAtri#}.
<div n="lb">In either gender the word is udātta on the last syllable; see
<div n="lb">the remark under I. 1. 5.] Comp. {#aparaja#}.
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-rA#}) <sup>1</sup> The hind quarter of an elephant. <sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb">womb. <sup>3</sup> Suppressed menstruation in pregnancy. <sup>4</sup> The west;
<div n="lb">comp. {#avarA#}.--E. Probably {#apa,#} taddh. aff. {#ra#}. Comp. {#apama#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) The reverse of {#para#} ({%superior,%}
<div n="lb">in its literal and figur. acceptations) and always contrasted
<div n="lb">with it: <sup>1</sup> Inferior, subordinate; e. g. {#dve vidye veditavye iti ha#}
<div n="lb">{#sma brahmavido vadanti parA cEvAparA ca . tatrAparA fgvedo ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#jurvedo sAmavedo'TarvavedaH SikzA kalpo vyAkaraRaM niruktaM Cando#}
<div n="lb">{#jyotizamiti . aTa parA yayA tadakzaramaDigamyate#} ({%Śaṅkara:%}
<div n="lb">{#parA ca paramAtmavidyA . aparA ca DarmADarmasADanatatPalavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zayA#}); comp. with this definition of the ‘superior and in-
<div n="lb">ferior wisdom’ in the {%Muṇḍaka Upan.,%} the definition given
<div n="lb">in the Viṣṇup. p. 494, where {%Wilson%} observes (note 9):
<div n="lb">‘the first ({#parA#}) is knowledge of Parabrahman, of spirit
<div n="lb">abstractly considered, perfect knowledge derived from ab-
<div n="lb">straction, the second ({#aparA#}) is knowledge of Śābda-
<div n="lb">brahman, of spirit as described and taught in the Vedas or
<div n="lb">their supplementary branches’. In the same manner {#paraM#}
<div n="lb">and {#aparaM brahma#} (of the {%Praśnopan.%}) are the ‘superior and
<div n="lb">inferior’ i. e. the transcendental and the mundane Brahman,
[Page167-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the one indefinable and incomprehensible, the other the re-
<div n="lb">verse.--In a passage of the {%Śvetāśv. Upan.%} {#brahma…#}
<div n="lb">{#yasmAtparaM nAparamasti kiMcit,#} {%Śaṅkara%} explains {#aparam#}
<div n="lb">{#= anyat,#} but it is more probable that the words mean:
<div n="lb">‘than which there is nothing superior nor inferior’ and
<div n="lb">merely express the incomparability of Brahman. <sup>2</sup> In the
<div n="lb">{%Vaiśeṣika%} philosophy the two correlative terms {#para#} and {#apara#}
<div n="lb">(superior and subordinate) express the notion of <sup>a.</sup> {%absolute%}
<div n="lb">({#para#}) and {%relative%} ({#apara#}), when applied to the notion of
<div n="lb">{#sAmAnya#} or {%generality%} ({%Bhāṣāp.%} {#sAmAnyaM dviviDaM proktaM paraM#}
<div n="lb">{#cAparameva ca#}), {%absolute%} generality belonging to the notion ‘to
<div n="lb">be’ or ‘existence’ in general as including the notion of sub-
<div n="lb">stance, quality and action ({#dravyAditrikavfttistu sattA parata-#}
<div n="lb">{#yocyate#}), and {%relative%} generality to the notion ‘genus’ ({#para-#}
<div n="lb">{#BinnA ca yA jAtiH sEvAparatayocyate#}); the notion ‘genus’
<div n="lb">again as including substances, qualities and actions being
<div n="lb">{%absolute%} or {%relative%} (see the meaning b.) ({#dravyatvAdikajAtistu#}
<div n="lb">{#parAparatayocyate#}); <sup>b.</sup> {%more comprehensive%} ({#para#}) and {%less com-%}
<div n="lb">{%prehensive%} ({#apara#}), when applied to a substance (see {#dravya#});
<div n="lb">thus earth, water, fire, wind and the organ of thinking
<div n="lb">have amongst other qualities also that of {%comprehending%}
<div n="lb">{%more%} or {%less%} matter ({#kzitirjalaM taTA tejaH pavano mana eva ca .#}
<div n="lb">{#parAparatvamUrtatvakriyAvegASrayA amI;#} or {#parAparatvasaMKyAdyAH#}
<div n="lb">{#paYca vegaSca mAnase#}); the eye seizes objects which amongst
<div n="lb">others have the quality of being {%more%} or {%less comprehensive%}
<div n="lb">({#viBAgasaMyogaparAparatvasnehadravatvaparimARayuktam…gfhlAti#}
<div n="lb">{#cakzuH#}); {#parAparatva#} is therefore one of the {%material%} qualities
<div n="lb">({#rUpaM rasaM sparSaganDO paratvamaparatvakam . dravo gurutvaM snehaSca vego#}
<div n="lb">{#mUrtaguRA amI#}); <sup>c.</sup> {%more remote%} and {%less remote,%} when applied
<div n="lb"><sup>aa.</sup> to the notion of {%space:%} i. e. {%far%} and {%near%} ({#dUratvamantikatvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca dESikaM paratvamaparatvaM boDyam;#} or {#yaTA pAwaliputrAtkASI-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapekzya prayAgaH paraH . pAwaliputrAtkurukzetramapekzya prayAgo'para#}
<div n="lb">{#iti#}), farness implying the idea of a more, and nearness
<div n="lb">that of a less extended area in contact with the sun ({#paratvaM#}
<div n="lb">--scil. {#dESikaM--sUryasaMyogaBUyastvajYAnato Bavet . aparatvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tadalpatvabudDitaH syAditIritam#}); <sup>bb.</sup> to the notion of {%time:%}
<div n="lb">i. e. {%old%} and {%young%} ({%Praśastapāda:%} {#ekasya drazwuryuvAnamavaDiM#}
<div n="lb">{#kftvA sTavire viprakfzwabudDirutpadyate tatastAmapekzya pareRa kAlapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#deSena saMyogAtparatvasyotpattiriti . sTaviraM cAvaDiM kftvA yU-#}
<div n="lb">{#ni saMnikfzwabudDirutpadyate tatastAmapekzyApareRa kAlapradeSena saMyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAdaparatvasyotpattiriti#}), old age implying the notion of
<div n="lb">prior, young age that of posterior existence with regard to
<div n="lb">the revolutions of the sun, i. e. the former implying the no-
<div n="lb">tion of more and the latter of fewer such revolutions ({%Bhāṣāp.%}
<div n="lb">{#divAkaraparispandapUrvotpannatvabudDitaH . paratvamaparatvaM#}--scil.
<div n="lb">{#kAlikaM--tu tadanantarabudDitaH;#} comm.: {#yasya sUryaparispandA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pekzayA yasya sUryaparispando'DikaH sa jyezWaH . yasya nyUnaH sa#}
<div n="lb">{#kanizWaH#}); time is thus the cause of understanding the notion
<div n="lb">of greater and lesser periods ({#kAlaH…parAparatvaDIhetuH#}).
<div n="lb">Comp. also {#apekzAbudDi#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#para#}.
<div n="P">III. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Than which there is
<div n="lb">nothing superior; supreme, absolute (for the formation
<div n="lb">comp. {#anuttara, anuttama#}); e. g. {#uBO#} (scil. {#prakftipuruzO#}) {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#pyanAdI . uBAvapyanantO . uBAvapyaliNgO . uBAvapi nityO .#}
<div n="lb">{#uBAvapyaparO . uBO ca sarvagatAviti#} (comp. for the mean-
<div n="lb">ing of {#apara#} in this passage from {%Suśruta%} the following
[Page167-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">from {%Gaurapāda's%} comm. on the verse 10 of the {%Sāṅkhya-%}
<div n="lb">{%kārikā:%} {#taTASritaM vyaktam#} (the discrete principle) {#anASritama-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyaktam#} (the indiscrete principle or Prakṛti) {#. akAryatvAt .#}
<div n="lb">{#na hi praDAnAtkiMcidasti paraM yasya praDAnaM kAryaM syAt ..#}). {#apara#}
<div n="lb">is used in this sense perhaps also in the instance p. 166, col. 1,
<div n="lb">1. 51. 52. E. {#a#} priv. and {#para#}.
<LEND>

<L>4704<pc>167-b<k1>aparagodAna<k2>aparagodAna
{#aparagodAna#}¦ Karmadh. n. (?) ({#-nam#}) (In Buddhistic cosmo-
<div n="lb">gony.) One of the four dvīpas or continents which are in
<div n="lb">each of the innumerable earths, and the inhabitants of which
<div n="lb">have faces of the same shape as the continent in which they
<div n="lb">are born; the Aparagodāna is in shape like a round mirror
<div n="lb">and 7000 Yojanas in extent, on the west of the Mahāmeru
<div n="lb">which is in the centre of the earth and from its base to its
<div n="lb">summit 168,000 Yojanas in height; in this continent merit
<div n="lb">cannot be obtained. (Spence Hardy, Manual of Buddhism
<div n="lb">pp. 4. 449.) E. {#apara#} and {#godAna#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#rajaH#}.) E. {#apara#} and {#ja#}.

<L>4738<pc>168-b<k1>aparavat<k2>aparavat
{#aparavat#}¦ ind. Like what is after or follows; in the instance
<div n="lb">{#tadetadbrahmApUrvamaparavat#} with the meaning ‘like the world’:
<div n="lb">‘that Brahman has nothing before itself (i. e. it is without
<div n="lb">a cause) and it is like what is after it (viz. the world)’.--
<div n="lb">[In this passage of the Sātap. X. 3. 5. 11. {#aparavat#} is indecl.,
<div n="lb">for it has the accent on the last syllable; if it were the
<div n="lb">neuter of an inflected word, formed with {#matup,#} it would
<div n="lb">be udātta on the first syllable.] E. {#apara,#} taddh. aff. {#vati#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">instance to the remark s. v. {#apara#} I. 1. 4.; {#apara-SAlA#} being as
<div n="lb">the former part of the Bahuvr. a Karmadh., it has the accent
<div n="lb">on the last syllable and the Bahuvr. therefore the accent on

<L>4747<pc>169-a<k1>aparasakTa<k2>aparasakTa
{#aparasakTa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kTam#}) (ved.) The part over the thigh
<div n="lb">(according to {%Sāyaṇa%}). [The gender of this word is neuter
<div n="lb">--comp. {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 98.--, not masc., as might be inferred
<div n="lb">from the present publication of so called {%‘Extracts’%} from
<div n="lb">{%Sāyaṇa'%}s comm. on the {%Śatapathabr.,%} in the passage III. 8.
<div n="lb">3. 27; for although the Ms. 657 of the E. I. H. is very incor-
<div n="lb">rect, it does not read {#sakTyo,#} as has been alleged, but some
<div n="lb">other mutilated form intended probably for {#sakTnoH;#} it runs
<div n="lb">literally thus: {#Urvorupari BUtO uCritAvapavo#} (sic) {#sACryo .#}
<div n="lb">(the {#Cya#} representing in this Ms. the value of {#Tya#} and the {#A-o#}
<div n="lb">that of {#o#}).] E. {#apara#} (see I. 1. 3.) and {#sakTi,#} samās. aff. {#wac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4748<pc>169-a<k1>aparasamam<k2>aparasamam
{#aparasamam#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. In the following year.
<div n="lb">(A various and probably more correct reading of the {%Kā-%}
<div n="lb">{%śikā%} (Ms. 2440. E. I. H.) and of the {%Gaṇaratnamahodadhi,%}
<div n="lb">instead of {#apasamam#} in the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} II. 1. 17.; explained
<div n="lb">by the {%Gaṇar.:%} {#aparA samA yatra kAle#}.) E. {#apara#} and {#samA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4749<pc>169-a<k1>aparaspara<k2>aparaspara
{#aparaspara#}¦ Dwandwa m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Continued, unin-
<div n="lb">terrupted. [According to {%Pāṇini%} this word expresses uninter-
<div n="lb">rupted continuation referring to a verbal action; accord. to {%Rā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yamukuṭa%} and other comm. on the {%Amarak.%} it may refer to the
<div n="lb">agent in the gender and number required, and to the verbal
<div n="lb">action in the neuter accus. sing.; the instance of the {%Kāśikā%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 144., {#‘aparasparAH sArTA gacCanti’#} would be
<div n="lb">in conformity with the former part of {%Rāyam.'%}s explanation
<div n="lb">which runs thus: {#…tasyA vahanAdikriyAyAstezAM vA kri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAvatAM parAparARAM sAtatye prakarzeRa gamyamAne'parasparAH syuH#}
<div n="lb">({%Amarak.%} III. 3. 1.) {#. tatra . apare ca pare ceti dvandvasamAsaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#aparasparAH . kriyAsAtatya iti nipAtanAt#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 144.) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#yadA kriyAvatAM viSezaRaM tadA yattezAM liNgaM tadevAparasparaSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdasyApi . yaTA . aparasparAH sArTA gacCanti . aparasparAH#}
<div n="lb">{#striyaH . aparasparARi kulAni . bahutvamatantram . yadA tu kri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAviSezaRaM napuMsakavacanaM ca . yaTA . aparasparaM gacCantIti .#}
<div n="lb">{#ekamavicCedena kriyAyAH kriyAvatAmavicCedasya ca#}.] Comp.
<div n="lb">{#aparapara#} and {#aparApara#}. The word being a Dwandwa, its
<div n="lb">latter part is not {#sarvanAman#} q. v. except optionally in the
<div n="lb">nom. plur. m., and its declension like that of other nouns in
<div n="lb">{#a#}. E. {#apara#} and {#para,#} with āgama {#suw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4750<pc>169-a<k1>aparasparasamBUta<k2>aparasparasamBUta
{#aparasparasamBUta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Produced by or
<div n="lb">in an uninterrupted series. (The verse of the {%Bhagavadgītā%}
<div n="lb">(16. 8.) where this word occurs: {#‘asatyamapratizWaM te jagadAhu-#}
<div n="lb">{#ranISvaram . aparasparasaMBUtaM kimanyatkAmahEtukam .’#} is to be
<div n="lb">rendered, in my opinion, thus: ‘they (the men of demoniac
<div n="lb">nature) affirm that the world is devoid of truth, of stability
<div n="lb">and without a Lord (a creator): but does there exist any thing
<div n="lb">else, that is produced by (or in) an uninterrupted series, and
<div n="lb">yet is the effect of arbitrariness?’; the uninterrupted series
<div n="lb">being that of causes and effects according to the Sāṅkhya-
[Page169-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">Yoga doctrine of the successive developement of the world.)
<div n="lb">E. {#aparaspara#} and {#samBUta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4758<pc>169-b<k1>aparAjita<k2>aparAjita
{#aparAjita#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Unconquered,
<div n="lb">unsurpassed, invincible; e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%} {#ko vA#}
<div n="lb">{#iha te'parAjito'parAjitayA mAyayA#} &c.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Viṣṇu. <sup>2</sup> A name of Śiva.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> One of the eleven Rudras (q. v.). <sup>4</sup> A poisonous insect,
<div n="lb">‘the sting of which produces swelling, itching, heaviness,
<div n="lb">and the wound becoming black’. <sup>5</sup> The seventh lunar day
<div n="lb">or tithi in the month Bhādra. <sup>6</sup> m. pl. ({#-tAH#}) One of the
<div n="lb">five divisions of the Jaina divinities called {#anuttara#} q. v.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-tA#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Durgā. <sup>2</sup> A name of the town
<div n="lb">of Brahman. <sup>3</sup> The north-east quarter (ruled by Śiva).
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> The name of a metre regulated by number and quantity,
<div n="lb">a species of the metre called Śakvarī; it consists of a stanza
<div n="lb">of four lines with the following fourteen syllables in each line:
<div n="lb">{??} | {??}. <sup>5</sup> The name of several
<div n="lb">plants: <sup>a.</sup> Clitoria ternatea; a species of a creeper with two
<div n="lb">varieties, the one with white, the other with blue flowers (the
<div n="lb">white variety described thus: {#latAviSezaH SvetAparAjitA .#}
<div n="lb">{#asya puzpaM yonyAkAraM Bavati#}); {#girikarRI#} and similar Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">the first part of which means ‘mountain’, as well as {#aSva-#}
<div n="lb">{#KurI#} and similar Bahuvr. the first part of which means
<div n="lb">‘horse’, are synonymes of it; comp. {#adrikarRI, nagakarRI;#}
<div n="lb">this plant is ‘cooling, acid, removes diseases arising from
<div n="lb">bile, diseases of the eye and calms disorders of the three
<div n="lb">temperamental elements of the body (air, bile and phlegm)’:
<div n="lb">{#‘girikarRI himA tiktA pittopadravanASinI . cakzuzyavizado-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaGnI tridozaSamanI ca sA’#}. (The word is used especially as
<div n="lb">the name of {%this%} plant.) <sup>b.</sup> Æschynomene sesban; compare
<div n="lb">{#jayantI#}. <sup>c.</sup> Marsilla quadrifolia ({#aSanaparRI#}). <sup>d.</sup> Nyctanthes
[Page170-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">arbor-tristis ({#SePAlI#}). <sup>e.</sup> Mimosa suma or a variety of it
<div n="lb">({#SamI; SamIBeda; laGuSamI#}). <sup>f.</sup> = {#SaNKinI#}. <sup>g.</sup> A variety of
<div n="lb">{#hapuzA,#} or a large species of the shrub called in Mahrat.
<div n="lb">{#SeraRI (hapuzABeda)#}. <sup>h.</sup> Crotolaria juncea, a plant from which
<div n="lb">a kind of hemp is obtained (Mahrat. {#tAga#}). <sup>i.</sup> The white
<div n="lb">{#nirguRqI#} ({#SvetanirguRqI;#} perhaps the same as d.). <sup>k.</sup> <sup>1.</sup> The
<div n="lb">white or blue Alethris hyacinthoides ({#gokarRI#}). <sup>m.</sup> = {#brAhmI#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>n.</sup> Trophis aspera (Mahrat. {#rSevarI#}). <sup>o.</sup> Achyranthes aspera
<div n="lb">({#pratyakparRI#}). <sup>p.</sup> Anthericum tuberosum ({#dravantI#}). <sup>q.</sup> A par-
<div n="lb">ticular esculent vegetable (called in Mahrat. {#PAMja#}). <sup>r.</sup> A
<div n="lb">species of the shrub {#SeraRI#} (Mahrat. {#laGuSeraRI#}). <sup>s.</sup> A large,
<div n="lb">white species of the tree called in Mahrat. {#kinhI#} (Mahrat.
<div n="lb">{#ToraSvetakinhI#}).
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-tam#}) The palace of Brahman. E. {#a#} neg. and {#parAjita#}.
<LEND>

<L>4773<pc>170-b<k1>aparAnta<k2>aparAnta
{#aparAnta#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-ntaH#}) The western extremity, the
<div n="lb">western border, the western sea-shore; e. g. {#so'parAntezu#}
<div n="lb">{#tIrTAni puRyAnyAyatanAni ca . tAni sarvAni gatvA sa praBAsa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mupajagmivAn#} ({%Arjunam.%} {#aparAntezu = samudrasamIpezu paScimezu;#}
<div n="lb">{%Nīlak.%} = {#paScimasamudratIrezu#}); or {#aparAntAdahaM kfzRa saMpratI-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAgataH#} ({%Rāmānanda:%} {#aparAntAt = paScimasamudratIrAt#}).--
<div n="lb">The plur. {#aparAntAH#} is the name of the country or the in-
<div n="lb">habitants of the western borders.--{%Wilson%} ({%Viṣṇup.%} p.
<div n="lb">189, n. 60) renders {#aparAntAH#} ‘the people not beyond the
<div n="lb">borders’, as opposed to {#parAntAH#} ‘the people beyond the
<div n="lb">borders’ (i. e. of {#parA#} and {#anta#}); but as {#para#} when opposed to
<div n="lb">{#apara#} assumes meanings corresponding with those of {#pUrva#} (see
<div n="lb">s. v. {#apara#} II.), {#parAntAH,#} as contradistinguished from {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAntAH,#} may mean perhaps ‘the people of the eastern borders’
<div n="lb">when {#aparAntAH#} would retain the sense given before. See
<div n="lb">the following.--<sup>2</sup> Last term, completion, e. g. in the {%Yoga-%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra:%} {#kzaRapratiyogI pariRAmo'parAntanirgrAhyaH kramaH#} ‘ma-
<div n="lb">turity (or change) is the reverse of what is but a moment;
<div n="lb">by the completion (of maturity) the order (of the moments)
<div n="lb">becomes comprehensible’. <sup>3</sup> Death. See the Yoga term {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#parAntajYAna#} and comp. {#pUrvAnta#} and {#parAnta#}. E. {#apara#} and {#anta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4774<pc>170-b<k1>aparAntaka<k2>aparAntaka
{#aparAntaka#}¦ 1. m. pl. ({#-kAH#}) The same as {#aparAntAH#} q. v.
<div n="lb">Comp. also {#SroRAparAntaka#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-kam#}) A sacred song, the singing of which is,
<div n="lb">according to {%Yājnavalkya,%} conducive to final liberation;
<div n="lb">comp. also as similar songs {#ullopya, madraka, prakarI, Ove-#}
<div n="lb">{#Raka, sarovindu, uttara#} (these are called {#gItaka#}); {#AsArita,#}
<div n="lb">{#varDamAnaka#} (these are called {#mahAgItaka#}); and those which
<div n="lb">have arisen from the former, viz. {#fggATA, pARikA, da-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzavihitA#} and {#brahmagItikA#} (these are called {#gItikA#}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-ntikA#}) The name of a metre regulated by quan-
<div n="lb">tity, a variety of the Vaitalīya q. v.; it consists of a stanza of
<div n="lb">four lines with sixteen mātrās in each line, the special con-
<div n="lb">ditions of each verse being similar to those of the Vaitalīya,
<div n="lb">q. v. E. {#aparAnta,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>4775<pc>170-b<k1>aparAntajYAna<k2>aparAntajYAna
{#aparAntajYAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (In the Yoga philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Foreknowledge of death; one of the perfections of a Yogin:
<div n="lb">{#sopakramaM nirupakramaM ca karma tatsaMyamAdaparAntajYAnamarizweByo#}
<div n="lb">{#vA#} i. e. ‘action (the consequence of which is preservation of
<div n="lb">life) is either deliberate or not; from the highest degree of
<div n="lb">meditation on it results the prescience of death, or also
<div n="lb">from ominous symptoms (such as one perceives in himself,
<div n="lb">when one loses the powers of hearing, seeing &c.--{#ADyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tmika#}--, or from apparitions of ghosts, Manes &c.--{#ADi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BOtika#}--, or from divine visions as that of the paradise,
<div n="lb">of the Siddhas &c.--{#ADidEvika#} qq. vv.). E. {#aparAnta#}
<div n="lb">and {#jYAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4776<pc>170-b<k1>aparApatantI<k2>aparApatantI
{#aparApatantI#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ntI#}) (In Medicine.) A woman from
<div n="lb">whom the secundines have not been removed; e. g. {#aTApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rApatantyAnAhADmAnO kurute#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#parApatantI#}.
<LEND>

<L>4777<pc>170-b<k1>aparApara<k2>aparApara
{#aparApara#}¦ Dwandwa m. f. n. pl. ({#-rAH#} or {#-re-rAH-rARi#}) One and
<div n="lb">another, another and another, various; e. g. {#sPawike'pyaparA-#}
<div n="lb">{#parotpatteH kzaRikatvAdvyaktInAmahetuH#}.--The word being a Dwan-
<div n="lb">dwa, {#apara#} q. v. is not {#sarvanAman#} q. v., except optionally in the
<div n="lb">nom. plur. m., but declined like other nouns in {#a#}.--See
<div n="lb">{#aparapara#} and comp. {#aparaspara#}. E. {#apara#} and {#apara#}.
<LEND>
[Page171-a+ 56]

<L>4779<pc>171-a<k1>aparApahARA<k2>aparApahARA
{#aparApahARA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-RA#}) [This word and the similar
<div n="lb">word {#pUrvApahARA#} are mentioned in a {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 4.
<div n="lb">on account of the irregular formation of the feminine in {#A,#}
<div n="lb">for the affix of {#apahAna#} being {#wit#} (i. e. {#lyuw#})--{%Kāśikā:%}
<div n="lb">{#winnipAtanAt#}--the word ought to end in {#I (NIp)#}. In ac-
<div n="lb">cordance with this view {%Mādhava%} explains both words in the
<div n="lb">{%Dhātuvṛtti%} {#pUrvAnparAMSca jahAti#}--in adopting apparently the
<div n="lb">reading {#parApahARA#} mentioned also by the {%Gaṇaratnam.%} i. e.]
<div n="lb">One (fem.) who or which leaves those who or which are be-
<div n="lb">hind &c. (see {#apara#}). [But the {%Gaṇaratnam.%} proposes some other
<div n="lb">queer meanings, viz. {#apahIyate'nayAsyAM vA#} (comp. {%Pāṇ.%} III. 3.
<div n="lb">117.) {#. apahARA . pUrvasyApahARA pUrvApahARA#} (comp. {%Pāṇ.%} II.
<div n="lb">2. 8. v. 1.) {#. aTa samAsAtprAgevAtra NI kasmAnna BavatIti vedane#}
<div n="lb">{#vacanAnarTakyaprasaNgaH . yadvA . pUrvaScAsAvapahAnaSceti pUrvApahAnaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#strI cetpUrvApahARA . RatvaM nipAtanAdeva . willakzaRaNIviDO#}
<div n="lb">{#prApta Apare RatvaM viDIyate . te hi ohAN gatAvityasminkf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tanizWAtakAranakAre pUrvamapahAnamasyA iti vAnAcCAdAjjAte-#}
<div n="lb">{#rityAdinA#} (sic? compare {%Pāṇ.%} II. 2. 36. v. 1. IV. 1. 52. v. 5.,
<div n="lb">VI. 2. 170.) {#NIprAptirbADyata ityAhuH . evamaparApahARA . kecittu#}
<div n="lb">{#parApahAReti paWanti ..,#} i. e. <sup>a.</sup> Tatpur. fem…by which (whom)
<div n="lb">or in which (whom) something or some one subsequent is
<div n="lb">left (i. e. similar to {%Mādhava'%}s explanation); but the Gaṇar.
<div n="lb">doubts of this meaning. <sup>b.</sup> Karmadh. fem. A subsequent
<div n="lb">woman(?) who is abandoned; with a corresp. masc. ending
<div n="lb">in a dental {#na#}. <sup>c.</sup> Bahuvr. fem…from which or whom
<div n="lb">something subsequent has gone away; when {#apahAna#} is the
<div n="lb">past partic. of {#hA#} ‘to go’ with {#apa#}. All these explanations
<div n="lb">are probably only etymological and refer to some conven-
<div n="lb">tional sense of the word which is not stated by the com-
<div n="lb">mentators of Pāṇini.] {%Bhoja%} and the {%Kāśikā%} give the reading
<div n="lb">{#aparApahAyaRA#}. E. {#apara#} and {#apahAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>4787<pc>171-a<k1>aparAhRa<k2>aparAhRa
{#aparAhRa#}¦ Tatpur. m. n. ({#-hRaH-hRam#}) The last part of the day;
<div n="lb">before sunset, e. g. {#aTa yadUrDvamaparAhlAtprAgastamayAtsa upa-#}
[Page171-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#dravaH#} &c.; the fourth part of the day or three Muhūrtas
<div n="lb">(= six Daṇḍas), if the day is divided into five equal parts,
<div n="lb">({%Mitākṣara:%} {#aparAhlaSca paYcaDAviBakte dine caturTo BAgastri-#}
<div n="lb">{#muhUrtaH#}).--Besides the last definition {%Rādhākāntadeva%} al-
<div n="lb">leges the following from vaidik and law texts: the last por-
<div n="lb">tion of the day, if the latter is divided into two halves;
<div n="lb">or the third portion of the day, if it is divided into three
<div n="lb">parts, i. e. the last ten Daṇḍas, if the division is into thirty
<div n="lb">Daṇḍas.--[The neuter gender of the word is given on the
<div n="lb">only authority of the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} II. 4. 31. and on that of
<div n="lb">the {%Gaṇaratnam.,%} where it is also mentioned amongst the
<div n="lb">{#arDarcAdi;#} but the {%Sūtra%} of {%Pāṇ.%} II. 4. 29. would be an ex-
<div n="lb">plicit authority {%against%} the correctness of the neuter gender
<div n="lb">of this word, at least at Pāṇini's period; comp. also the in-
<div n="lb">stances to V. 4. 88. and VIII. 4. 7.; and it may be observed,
<div n="lb">too, that the restriction, as regards the Dwigu compounds
<div n="lb">the latter part of which is {#rAtri,#} as {#dvirAtram, trirAtram#}
<div n="lb">(II. 4. 29. v. 1.), belongs to a Vārttika which neither occurs
<div n="lb">in the {%Mahābhāṣya%} nor in the {%Kāśikā;%} comp. also the masc.
<div n="lb">forms {#dvirAtraH, trirAtraH,#} {%Kāśikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 87.] E. {#apara#}
<div n="lb">(see I. 1. 3.) and {#ahna,#} a substitute of {#ahan#} (or as the Kā-
<div n="lb">śikā explains: of {#aha,#} i. e. {#apara#} and {#ahan,#} samāsānta aff.
<div n="lb">{#wac#}), with the change of {#n#} to {#Ra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4788<pc>171-b<k1>aparAhRaka<k2>aparAhRaka
{#aparAhRaka#}¦ m. ({#-kaH#}) The meaning of this word is a {%conventional%}
<div n="lb">one (perhaps a proper name), not stated by the comm. of Pā-
<div n="lb">ṇini; it must be observed, however, that its sense is {%not%} the
<div n="lb">purely etymological sense ‘born or produced in the last part
<div n="lb">of the day’--see {#aparAhla#}--, for the latter is expressed by
<div n="lb">{#aparAhlatana, aparAhletana#} or {#AparAhlika#}. Words of a similar
<div n="lb">formation and also in a conventional sense only are {#pUrvAhlaka,#}
<div n="lb">{#Ardraka, mUlaka, pradozaka, avaskaraka,#} qq. vv. E. {#aparAhla,#}
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#vun#}.
<LEND>

<L>4790<pc>171-b<k1>aparAhRatana<k2>aparAhRatana

<div n="lb">its {%locative%} sense, while {#aparAhlatana#} (q. v.) may have a mean-

<L>4797<pc>172-a<k1>aparigraha<k2>aparigraha
{#aparigraha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-encompassing, non-com-
<div n="lb">prehension; e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#aparigrahAccAtyanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#manapekzA#}. <sup>2</sup> Non-acceptance. In the latter sense this word
<div n="lb">has assumed a special bearing in the {%Yoga%} philosophy and
<div n="lb">in such passages of the {%Upan.%} and other writings (compare
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Wilson's Viṣṇup.%} p. 288. n. 2), as refer to the doctrine
<div n="lb">of this philosophy; it means there: {%renouncing every thing%}
<div n="lb">{%that can afford enjoyment,%} as a commentator observes,
<div n="lb">from the perception of the defects that inhere in mundane
<div n="lb">objects, as they must be acquired, preserved, as they pe-
<div n="lb">rish, produce affection and cause the infliction of injury
<div n="lb">({%Bhojadeva:%} {#aparigraho BogasADanAnAmasvIkaraRam;#} another:
<div n="lb">{#vizayARAmarjanarakzaRakzayasaNgahiMsAdozadarSanAdasvIkaraRamapari-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaH#}); it is in the Yoga phil. the last of the five categories of
<div n="lb">the term {#yama#} q. v., the latter being one of the eight Angas
<div n="lb">or constituent parts of the Yoga (see {#yogANga#}). Renun-
<div n="lb">ciation however must be understood there in its widest sense,
<div n="lb">also as indifference to one's own body, since the soul's as-
<div n="lb">suming a body is also {#parigraha#} or covetousness, for body
<div n="lb">is the instrument of enjoyment and passion is connected
<div n="lb">with it; and only the Yogin who is firm in the renun-
<div n="lb">ciation in this widest sense, obtains a knowledge of the
<div n="lb">condition of former and subsequent existences: {#aparigra-#}
<div n="lb">{#hasTErye janmakaTantAsaMboDaH#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#…na kevalaM Boga-#}
<div n="lb">{#sADanaparigraha eva parigrahaH . kiMtu yAvadAtmanaH SarIragrahI#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi parigrahaH . BogasADanatvAcCarIrasya tasminsati rAgAnu-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDAt . vahirmuKAyAmeva pravfttO na tAttvikajYAnaprAdurBAvaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#yadA punaH SarIrAdiparigrahanErapekzyeRa mADyasTyamAlambate tadA#}
<div n="lb">{#maDyasTasya rAgAdityAgAtsamyagjYAnaheturBavatyeva pUrvAparajanmasaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#boDaH#}). ({%Jayamangala%} in his comm. on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 1. 15. calls the
<div n="lb">fifth {#yama,#} contrary to the {%Yoga S.,%} {#akalmaza,#} equally so {%Hari-%}
<div n="lb">{%hara;%} but {%Vidyāvinodāchārya%} names it correctly in his comm.
<div n="lb">{#aparigraha#}.)--The comm. on the {%Sāṅkhya%} phil., while re-
<div n="lb">taining the definition of {#yama#} as given by Patanjali, have
<div n="lb">made {#yama#} one of the four categories of {#Darma#} (q. v.), righte-
<div n="lb">ousness, {#Darma#} being in the Sāṅkhya one of the four categories
<div n="lb">of {#budDi#} (q. v.), intellect, when it is {#sAtvika#} or under the in-
<div n="lb">fluence of the quality of goodness. E. {#a#} neg. and {#parigraha#}.
<LEND>

<L>4814<pc>172-b<k1>aparipanTin<k2>aparipanTin

<div n="lb">{#'paripanTinI Bavatu#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#paripanTin#}.

<div n="lb">{#ptamAtraM yena BuktaM svIkftyAparipanTinaH . tasya tatsidDimApnoti#}
<div n="lb">{#hAniScopekzayA taTA#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#paripanTin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4847<pc>173-b<k1>aparokza<k2>aparokza
{#aparokza#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzaH-kzA-kzam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not distant, not
<div n="lb">remote; e. g. in the {%Sūtra%} of {%Pāṇini%} III. 2. 119. and the
<div n="lb">{%Kār.%} 2. to III. 2. 118., where the past which is not remote is
<div n="lb">opposed to the past which is remote (as treated III. 2. 115 ff.).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Perceptible, clear; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhya Sūtras:%} {#yuktito#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi na bADyate diNgUQavadaparokzAdfte#} (scil. {#banDaH#} or the bon-
<div n="lb">dage of the soul; comm. = {#sAkzAtkAraM vinA#}); or {#nAnume-#}
<div n="lb">{#yatvameva kriyAyA nedizWasya tattadvatorevAparokzapratIteH#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#pratyakzeRApi pratItirasti#} &c.); {#aparokzam#} also used adver-
<div n="lb">bially. <sup>3</sup> Absolute, not qualified; as epithet of Brahman
<div n="lb">(neuter) in the {%Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upan.,%} where the ablative
<div n="lb">{#aparokzAt#} is used absolutely in the sense of the nomin.
<div n="lb">{#aparokzam#} viz. {#yatsAkzAdaparokzAdbrahma#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#yadbrAhma sAkzA-#}
<div n="lb">{#davyavahitaM kenacit . drazwuraparokzAdagORaM na SrotrabrahmAdivat .;#}
<div n="lb">{%Anandajnāna:%} {#muKyameva drazwuravyavahitasvarUpaM brahma . taTA ca#}
<div n="lb">{#drazwraDInasidDatvABAvAtsvato'parokzamityarTaH . SrotraM brahma mano#}
[Page174-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#brahmetyAdi yaTA gORaM na taTA gORam .#}). E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#parokza#}.

<L>4853<pc>174-a<k1>aparRa<k2>aparRa
{#aparRa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rRaH-rRA-rRam#}) Leafless.

<div n="lb">and Menā, so called because she did not even eat a leaf
<div n="lb">during her performance of religious austerities, while her
<div n="lb">sisters {#ekaparRA#} and {#ekapAwalA#} partook at least, the one of
<div n="lb">one leaf and the other of one Pāṭalā flower. E. {#a#} priv.
<div n="lb">and {#parRa#}.

<div n="lb">obligation; e. g. {#tatrAparRAya tatasvanayAdBEmI tapasyaparRAyatata .#}
<div n="lb">{#tulitasuparRAya tatastasyAgamanAya sartuparRAya tataH .#}. E. {#apa#}

<L>4872<pc>174-b<k1>apalApa<k2>apalApa
{#apalApa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Denial, abnegation; e. g. {#SrutyA#}
<div n="lb">{#sidDasya nApalApastatpratyakzabADAt;#} or {#na DarmApalApaH prakfti-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAryavEcitryAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Concealing. <sup>3</sup> Love, affection; (this mean-
<div n="lb">ing, given in some Koshas, arises perhaps from: self-denial,
<div n="lb">self-abnegation, scil. in favour of another). E. {#lap#} with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-paH#}) (In Medicine.) ‘The upper part of the sides
<div n="lb">under the shoulder’ ({%Suśruta:%} {#aMsakUwayoraDastAtpArSvopari-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAgayorapalApO nAma#}), of half a finger's dimension ({%Bhāva-%}
<div n="lb">{%prakāśa:%} {#arDANgulO#}), considered as one of the vital parts
<div n="lb">of the trunk, the wounding of which ‘causes death after
<div n="lb">the blood has passed into the state of pus’. E. unknown;
<div n="lb">perhaps related in etym., although not in meaning, to
<div n="lb">{#palApa#}.
<LEND>

<L>4873<pc>174-b<k1>apalApadaRqa<k2>apalApadaRqa

<div n="lb">on a defendant for denying a charge on which he gets con-
<div n="lb">victed; it consists in payment of the whole value of the
<div n="lb">object of litigation to the king, after the claimant has re-
<div n="lb">ceived his due. ({%Mitākṣara:%} {#…pratyarTI tadA dadyAdDanaM#}
[Page175-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#prakftamarTine rAjYe ca tatsamamapalApadaRqam#}). E. {#apalApa#} and
<div n="lb">{#daRqa#}.

<L>4890<pc>175-b<k1>apavana<k2>apavana

<L>4893<pc>175-b<k1>apavarga<k2>apavarga
{#apavarga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Completion, complete performance
<div n="lb">of an act (comp. {#apavfkti#}); e. g. {#kriyApavargezvanujIvisAtkf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAH kftajYatAmasya#} (scil. {#rAjYaH#}) {#vadanti saMpadaH;#} in this sense
<div n="lb">the word is used in the {%Mīmānsā Sūtras,%} e. g. {#kriyARAmarTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#SezatvAtpratyakzatastannirvfttyApavargaH syAt . DarmamAtre tvadarSanAcCa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdArTenApavargaH syAt;#} and in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtr.%} e. g. {#apavarge tf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIyA;#} or in the {%Vārtt.%} to III. 2. 123: {#nyAyyA tvAramBAnapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vargAt#} (see {#apavfkta#}). Comp. also {#kriyApavarga#} in distinction
<div n="lb">from {#sADanApavarga#}. <sup>2</sup> Complete delivery, i. e. the delivery
<div n="lb">of the soul from the body and consequent exemption from
<div n="lb">the sufferings connected with transmigration; final beatitude
<div n="lb">(Snonymous terms are {#mukti, mokza, niHSreyasa;#} but while
<div n="lb">{#apavarga#} is used in the sense ‘final beatitude’ especially in the
<div n="lb">{%Sāṅkhya-, Yoga-%} and {%Nyāya Sūtras,%} the former terms (qq. vv.)
<div n="lb">have been generally preferred, to express the same notion,
<div n="lb">by the authors of the {%Vedānta%} and {%Vaiśeṣika S.;%} for the latter
<div n="lb">and the {%Mīmānsā S.%} compare also the preceding and the
<div n="lb">following meaning.); e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtr.:%} {#tadatyantavimokzo#}
<div n="lb">{#'pavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is the complete deliverance from it
<div n="lb">(i. e. from pain)’; {%Sāṅkhya Sūtr.:%} {#dvayorekatarasya vOdAsInyama-#}
<div n="lb">{#pavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is the indifference of both or of either
<div n="lb">of them (viz. of Matter and Soul, i. e. their separation);
[Page176-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%Yoga Sūtr.:%} {#prakASakriyAsTitiSIlaM BUtendriyAtmakaM BogApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vargArTaM dfSyam#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#apavargo vivekaKyAtipUrvikA saMsA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ranivfttiH#} ‘{%apavarga%} is freedom from transmigration as the re-
<div n="lb">sult of clear discrimination’). Final beatitude being promised
<div n="lb">by each philosophy as the reward of a correct knowledge
<div n="lb">of its principles, the mode of attaining it differs, of course,
<div n="lb">with the doctrine; e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtr.:%} {#duHKajanmapravfttidoza-#}
<div n="lb">{#miTyAjYAnAnAmuttarottarApAye tadanantarApAyAdapavargaH#} ‘final
<div n="lb">beatitude takes place after the consecutive annihilation of
<div n="lb">wrong knowledge which is conducive to the annihilation of
<div n="lb">defects (i. e. passions, love, hatred &c.) and so on succes-
<div n="lb">sively to that of exertion (rightful or wrong), of re-birth
<div n="lb">and of pain; the topics of knowledge being in the {%Nyāya%}
<div n="lb">‘Soul, body, organs of sensation, objects of sense, intel-
<div n="lb">lect, imagination, exertion, defects as passions &c., the
<div n="lb">state of the soul after death or re-birth, retribution, pain
<div n="lb">and final beatitude’ ({#AtmaSarIrendriyArTabudDimanaHpravfttido-#}
<div n="lb">{#zapretyaBAvaPaladuHKApavargAstu prameyam#}); for the topics of the
<div n="lb">{%Vaiśeṣika%} comp. {#padArTa;#} {%Sāṅkhya Kār.:%} {#jYAnena cApavargaH#}
<div n="lb">‘through knowledge i. e. of the twenty-five Sāṅkhya prin-
<div n="lb">ciples comes final beatitude (comp. {#tattva#}); a comm. on the
<div n="lb">{%Yoga:%} {#BoktuH svarUpAvaDAraRamapavargaH#} ‘final beatitude is com-
<div n="lb">prehending the real nature of him who enjoys, i. e. of
<div n="lb">Purusha or Spirit’. <sup>3</sup> (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Speedy destruction, speedy cessation; in the {%Kaṇāda Sūtra:%}
<div n="lb">{#‘guRasya sato'pavargaH karmaBiH sADarmyam’#} which according to
<div n="lb">the {%Upaskāra%} of {%Śaṅkara%} means: ‘the speedy cessation of
<div n="lb">a quality of what exists (does not come under the category
<div n="lb">of action, but) has (only) properties similar to those of
<div n="lb">actions’ ({%Śaṅk.%} {#apavarga ASunASaH . sa ca guRatve'pi dvitvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#divadASuBAvinASakasaMnipAtADIna iti karmaBiH sADarmyamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tramasya na tu karmatvameva .#}). <sup>4</sup> The place or region where the
<div n="lb">final deliverance is obtained; e. g. in the verse of the {%Bhāgav.%}
<div n="lb">{%Purāṇa:%} {#sUryeRa hi viBajyante diSaH KaM dyOrmahI BidA . svargA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pavargO narakA rasOkAMsi ca sarvaSaH#} (comm. {#svargApavargO Boga-#}
<div n="lb">{#mokzadeSO#}). <sup>5</sup> A gift, a donation; e. g. {#na te'pavargaH sukftA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvinAkftastaTA yaTAnyezu varezu mAnada . varaM vfRe…#} <sup>6</sup> Re-
<div n="lb">striction of a general rule (according to {%Suśruta's%} definition:
<div n="lb">{#aBivyApyApakarzaRamapavargaH#}). E. {#vfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}
<div n="lb">lit. ‘leaving, abandoning’; comp. {#apavarjana#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">atitude. E. {#apavarga#} and {#da#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a donation. <sup>3</sup> Final beatitude. See {#apavarga#} and comp. {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#sarjana#}. E. {#vfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>4899<pc>176-b<k1>apavarta<k2>apavarta
{#apavarta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rtaH#}) (In Algebra.) The common measure,
<div n="lb">the divisor which is assumed for both or either of the quan-
<div n="lb">tities, without leaving a remainder ({%Colebr. Brahmagupta%}
<div n="lb">p. 363); e. g. {#utpatsyamAnayEvaM mUlakaraRyAlpayA caturguRayA .#}
<div n="lb">{#yAsAmapavartaH syAdrUpakftestA viSoDyAH syuH . apavartAdapi#}
<div n="lb">{#labDA mUlakaraRyo Bavanti tAScApi .#} ‘those terms are to be
<div n="lb">subtracted from the square of the rational number, which
<div n="lb">are exactly measured by four times the smaller radical surd
<div n="lb">thence to be deduced; the quotients found by that common
<div n="lb">measure are surds in the root’. (In this passage from the
<div n="lb">{%Vījagaṇita%} p. 18 Colebrooke (Alg. p. 153) has had however
<div n="lb">instead of the first {#apavarta,#} the reading {#apavartana#} q. v.) E.
<div n="lb">{#vft,#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>4900<pc>176-b<k1>apavartana<k2>apavartana
{#apavartana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Transferring, removing from one
<div n="lb">place to another; e. g. {#sTAnApavartana#}. <sup>2</sup> Taking away, de-
<div n="lb">priving one of; e. g. {#dAyApavartana#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Algebra.) Division
<div n="lb">without remainder by a common measure, reduction, abridg-
<div n="lb">ing; e. g. {#BAjyakzepApavartanena#} ‘through reducing the dividend
<div n="lb">and additive by the common measure’; or {#hArakzepApavartanena#}
<div n="lb">‘through reducing the divisor and additive by the common
<div n="lb">measure’. E. {#vft,#} in the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4901<pc>176-b<k1>apavartita<k2>apavartita
{#apavartita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Turned away, re-
<div n="lb">moved. <sup>2</sup> (In Algebra.) Divided without a remainder by a
<div n="lb">common measure; e. g. {#BAjyakzepO daSaBirapavartitO#} ‘dividend
<div n="lb">and additive reduced by the common measure 10’; or {#hA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rakzepO . 63 . 90 . navaBirapavartitO jAtO hArakzepO . 7 . 10 .#}

<div n="lb">measure 9 become divisor (7) and additive (10). E. {#vft,#} in
<div n="lb">the caus., with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>4903<pc>176-b<k1>apavAda<k2>apavAda
{#apavAda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Refutation, as of an erroneous
<div n="lb">imputation; e. g. {#…evamaDyAropaH . apavAdo nAma rajju-#}
<div n="lb">{#vivartasya sarpasya rajjumAtratvavat#} &c. ‘so much for the erro-
<div n="lb">neous imputation--to the soul of properties that do not
<div n="lb">belong to it--; now the refutation is: like as the rope
<div n="lb">alone becomes manifest, instead of the serpent (taken for
<div n="lb">a rope) which obscured (the reality) of the rope &c. <sup>2</sup> Re-
<div n="lb">striction of a previous rule, decree, definition &c.; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Manu%} 8. 341. is a {#cOryApavAda#} or a case which does not fall
<div n="lb">under the category of theft; {%Yājnav.%} 2. 83. is an {#apavAda#} to
<div n="lb">the rule that a witness must speak the truth.--In {%Gram-%}
<div n="lb">{%mar%} it means an exception to a rule and comprises as well
<div n="lb">those rules which supersede as those which restrict a general
<div n="lb">rule (compare {#viBAzA#}); the terms opposed to it are
<div n="lb">{#utsarga,#} e. g. {#prakalpya vApavAdavizayaM tata utsargo'Bini-#}
<div n="lb">{#viSate; kvacidapavAdavizaye'pyutsargo'pi pravartate;#} or {#viDi,#}
<div n="lb">e. g. {#purastAdapavAdA anantaraviDInbADante na parAn . maDye'pa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdAH pUrvAnviDInbADante na parAn;#} sometimes both com-
<div n="lb">bined, e. g. {#aByAsavikArezvapavAdA utsargAnviDInna bADante#}.
<div n="lb">--The term {#bADApavAda#} means ‘exception to an exception’
<div n="lb">i. e. the reestablishing of the previous rule, precept &c.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Censure, blame, evil report; e. g. {#AyurviprApavAdena#} (scil.
<div n="lb">{#kzarati#}); or {#lokApavAdAdapi na BIto'si#}. <sup>5</sup> An order, a
[Page177-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">command; (in this sense the more correct reading of the
<div n="lb">word is probably {#avavAda#}). E. {#vad#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<div n="P">II. A wrong assertion, a wrong tenet; e. g. {#apavAdamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tramabudDAnAm#} ‘--(to say that the void is the true reality)
<div n="lb">--is a wrong assertion of people who are not wise (comm.
<div n="lb">{#mUQAnAmapavAdamAtraM miTyAvAda eva#})’. E. {#apa#} and {#vAda#}.
<LEND>

<L>4914<pc>177-a<k1>apavAha<k2>apavAha
{#apavAha#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Arithmetic.) Deduction,
<div n="lb">lessening, subtraction; esp. of fractions; see {#BAgApavAha,#}
<div n="lb">{#lavApavAha;#} e. g. {#svAMSADikonaH Kalu yatra tatra BAgAnubanDe ca#}
<div n="lb">{#lavApavAhe . talasTahAreRa haraM nihanyAtsvAMSADikonena tu tena#}
<div n="lb">{#BAgAn,#} ‘but, if indeed the quantity be increased or di-
<div n="lb">minished by a part of itself, then in the addition and sub-
<div n="lb">traction of fractions, multiply the denominator by the de-
<div n="lb">nominator standing underneath and the numerator by the
<div n="lb">same augmented or lessened by its own numerator (comp.
<div n="lb">Colebr. Alg. p. 15 and the following). <sup>2</sup> The name of
<div n="lb">a metre regulated by number and quantity, a variety of
<div n="lb">Utkṛti; it consists of a stanza of four lines with the fol-
[Page177-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">lowing twenty six syllables in each line:

<div n="lb">also read {#upavAha#} or {#pravAha#}. E. {#vah#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<L>4919<pc>177-b<k1>apavidDa<k2>apavidDa
{#apavidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Rejected, discarded,
<div n="lb">disowned; {#apavidDaH putraH#} is, in law, a son who having
<div n="lb">been disowned by his natural parents or, in the case of the
<div n="lb">death of either of them, having been disowned by the sur-
<div n="lb">viving parent, is adopted by another; one of the twelve
<div n="lb">kinds of adopted sons, comp. s. v. {#anyavIjaja;#} also said of
<div n="lb">a girl, e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%} {#kaRqoH pramlocayA labDA kanyA#}
<div n="lb">{#kamalalocanA . tAM cApavidDAM jagfhurBUruhA nfpanandanAH#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#apavidDAM tyaktAm#}). <sup>2</sup> Abject, contemptible, e. g. (Rudra speaks
<div n="lb">to Viṣṇu in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%}) {#yadi racitaDiyaM mAvidyaloko#}
<div n="lb">{#'pavidDaM japati na gaRaye tattvatparAnugraheRa#} (comm. {#apavidDamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#cAraBrazwam#}), ‘if the ignorant world declares me whose mind
<div n="lb">is properly framed, to be abject, I do not mind it on ac-
<div n="lb">count of thy paramount grace’; {%Burnouf%} renders this pas-
<div n="lb">sage: ‘si pendant ce temps le monde ignorant m'appelle
<div n="lb">avec mépris contempteur des lois &c.’. <sup>3</sup> Disabled, broken
<div n="lb">(lit. or fig.), e. g. {#gargARAM vAhanamapavidDam;#} ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vidDamiti vahanaSaktivikalaM pranazwamityarTaH#}); or in the {%Mālatīm.%}
<div n="lb">{#hfdayamaSaraRaM me pakzmalAkzyAH kawAkzErapahftamapavidDaM pItamunmUlitaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca#}. <sup>4</sup> Neglected; (in this sense also in the Buddh. {%Dhamma-%}
<div n="lb">{%pada%} ed. {%Fausböll%} v. 292). E. {#vyaD,#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}
<div n="lb">and samprasāraṇa of the radical.
<LEND>

<L>4925<pc>178-a<k1>apavfkti<k2>apavfkti

<div n="lb">of an act (comp. {#apavarga#} 1.); e. g. of the {#agnicayana; nityA#}

<div n="lb">{#mittIkftito'ntimaH#}. E. {#vfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.

<L>4928<pc>178-a<k1>apavfta<k2>apavfta
{#apavfta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Opened, laid open.
<div n="lb">The {%Ṛgv. Prātiśākhya%} notices that this word occurs in the
<div n="lb">Ṛgveda in the form {#apAvfta#}. E. {#vf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4929<pc>178-a<k1>apavfti<k2>apavfti
{#apavfti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) Opening. [In the present edition
<div n="lb">of the {%Medinī%} it occurs as a meaning of {#AcCAdana,#} viz.
<div n="lb">{#‘AcCAdanaM saMpiDAne vastre'pavftimAtrake’;#} but a better read-
<div n="lb">ing instead of the latter word is clearly {#prAvftimAtrake,#} as
<div n="lb">{#AcCAdana#} does not mean ‘covering’ and ‘opening’ at the
<div n="lb">same time; the {%Śabdamuktāmahārṇava,%} which quotes this read-
<div n="lb">ing, explains therefore {#AcCAdanam na#} (i. e. {#napuMsakaM#}) {#tiroDAne#}
<div n="lb">{#aMSuke prAvaraRasAmAnye ca#}.] E. {#vf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>4930<pc>178-a<k1>apavftta<k2>apavftta
{#apavftta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ttaH-ttA-ttam#}) <sup>1</sup> Gone in a wrong
<div n="lb">direction; e. g. when {%Suśruta%} describes one of the various
<div n="lb">preternatural parturitions {#(mUQagarBa), antaHpArSvApavfttaSirAH#}
<div n="lb">{#kaScidekena bAhunA…yonimuKamaBipratipadyate,#} and the
<div n="lb">mode of promoting the parturition: {#pArSvApavfttaSirasamaMsaM pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#pIqyorDvamutkzipya Siro'patyapaTamAnIyApaharet#}. <sup>2</sup> Passed
<div n="lb">away, finished, ended, e. g. a sacrifice, as in the {%Mīmānsā%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra:%} {#ekacitirvA syAdapavftte hi codyate nimittena;#} comp.
<div n="lb">the following. E. {#vft#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ttam#}) (In Astronomy.) The ecliptic; comp. {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mavftta, apamaRqala, apamamaRqala;#} e. g. in the {%Golādhyāya%} of
<div n="lb">the {%Siddhāntaśiromaṇi%} {#…mezAdijIvAH Srutayo'pavftte tadBU-#}
<div n="lb">{#mije krAntiguRA BujAH syuH .#}. E. {#apa#} and {#vftta#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">the {%Mīmānsā Sūtra:%} {#‘apavftte tu codanA tatsAmAnyAtsvakAlaH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt’ . apavftte yAge codyate . yAgAntaramidamapavfttiSca sarve-#}

<L>4937<pc>178-b<k1>apavrata<k2>apavrata

<div n="lb">acts, impious, as haters of the Brāhmaṇas. <sup>2</sup> Destructive
<div n="lb">of holy acts, an epithet of {#tamas#} or darkness, ‘as the holy
<div n="lb">acts of those surrounded by darkness perish’; (explained in
<div n="lb">this sense by {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Sāmav.%} 2. 1210 and by {%Mahīdhara%} on
<div n="lb">the corresponding verse of the {%Vājas.%} 17. 47). E. {#apa#} and {#vrata#}.

<L>4945<pc>178-b<k1>apaSu<k2>apaSu

<L>4962<pc>179-a<k1>apazWa<k2>apazWa
{#apazWa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-zWam#}) [in the {%Kāśikā%} m. ({#-zWaH#})] The sharp,

<L>4963<pc>179-a<k1>apazWu<k2>apazWu
{#apazWu#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zWuH-zWuH-zWu#}) <sup>1</sup> Contrary, opposite,
<div n="lb">adverse. <sup>2</sup> Handsome, beautiful. <sup>3</sup> Ignorant, infantine.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zWuH#}) Time.
<div n="P">3. adv. ({#-zWu#}) <sup>1</sup> Contrary, adversely. <sup>2</sup> Faultlessly, bla-
<div n="lb">melessly. <sup>3</sup> Handsomely. [The {%Medinī%} has the meaning {#vAma;#}
<div n="lb">the latter word however, compared to {#cAru#} of the {%Bhūri-%}
<div n="lb">{%prayoga%} and to the meanings {#cAru#} and {#SoBana,#} for the ad-
<div n="lb">verb., of {%Hemach.%} and the {%Med.,%} can scarcely be taken in
<div n="lb">another sense than in that of ‘beautiful’; the meaning
<div n="lb">‘ignorant, infantine’ rests on the authority of the {%Bhūripr.%}
<div n="lb">and the {%Uṇṇādikoṣa%} which have the meaning {#bAla,#} the
[Page179-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">former together with, the latter without, {#kAla#}.--The form
<div n="lb">of the adv. {#‘apazWum’#} in the present ed. of the {%Śiśupālab.%}
<div n="lb">15. 17. has been expressly mentioned, as if it were something
<div n="lb">remarkable, but the mere scanning of the verse--without
<div n="lb">any reference to Mss.--might have shown that it is a mis-
<div n="lb">print, instead of {#apazWu#}.] E. {#sTA#} with {#apa,#} uṇ. aff. {#ku#}.
<LEND>

<L>4964<pc>179-b<k1>apazWura<k2>apazWura

<div n="lb">adverse. Comp. {#apazWu#} and {#apazWula#}. E. {#sTA#} with {#apa,#} uṇ.
<div n="lb">aff. {#urac#} or {#uran#} (?).

<L>4965<pc>179-b<k1>apazWula<k2>apazWula

<L>4966<pc>179-b<k1>apas<k2>apas
{#apas#}¦ I. 1. n. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Action, act, esp. a religious or sacri-
<div n="lb">ficial act. (ved.) <sup>2</sup> Water. [It is very doubtful whether
<div n="lb">the word is correct in the latter sense, as a {%neuter sing.;%}
<div n="lb">comp. I. 2., it occurs as such in the following Sūtra of
<div n="lb">{%Kaṇāda%} (E. I. H. Ms. 232) where the reading {#apas#} however
<div n="lb">may be a mistake for {#Apas,#} viz. {#pfTivyapastejo vAyurA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kASaM kAlo digAtmA mana iti dravyARi ..#}.] Compare also
<div n="lb">{#Apas#}. E. {#Ap,#} uṇ. aff. {#asun,#} the vowel of the radical
<div n="lb">being shortened; but more probably of {#ap,#} comp. the E.
<div n="lb">of {#apta#} and see the Preface.
<div n="P">2. f. plur. ({#-saH#}) (ved.) Water (comp. {#ap#}); e. g. {#bahvI-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAM garBo'pasAm#} ‘(Agni) is the child of abundant waters’;
<div n="lb">(according to {%Sāyaṇa,%} because he comes as lightning from the
<div n="lb">waters collected in the clouds; comp. {#apAM garBaH#} s. v. {#ap#}).
<div n="lb">E. {#Ap,#} uṇ. {#asi;#} and as before but see the Preface.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. plur. ({#-saH-saH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Active, engaged in pursuits
<div n="lb">in general, more esp. in the performance of religious or
<div n="lb">sacrificial acts; in the femin. also as an epithet of the fingers.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Fulfilling an act or business; as an epithet of {#triDAtavaH#}
<div n="lb">or ‘the three worlds upheld by the three divinities Fire,
<div n="lb">Wind and Sun’, ‘cold, heat, wind, rain &c.’ being, as
<div n="lb">{%Mahīdhara%} explains, ‘the doings of the world’. <sup>3</sup> Possessing
<div n="lb">activity (or perhaps, referring to religious acts) as an epi-
<div n="lb">thet of {#triDAtavaH,#} when, according to {%Mahīdhara,%} in the
<div n="lb">sense of {#paSu#} or sacrificial animal. <sup>4</sup> Rapid, swift; as a
<div n="lb">river; comp. {#apastama#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-pAH#}) The name of one of the seven Prajāpatis
<div n="lb">in the second or the Manwantara of Svārochiṣa, according
<div n="lb">to the Mātsya Purāṇa. E. {#apas,#} with luk of the taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#vini#}.
<div n="P">III. ind. A further developement of the prefix {#apa#} in com-
<div n="lb">bination with the inflected forms, and in composition with
<div n="lb">some derivatives, of {#kF#} q. v.; comp. {#apaskara#}. The native
<div n="lb">theory considers however {#apaskirate#} &c. as {#apa#} and {#kirate#}
<div n="lb">&c. with āgama {#suw;#} see the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>4967<pc>179-b<k1>apasada<k2>apasada
{#apasada#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> An offspring of either of six de-
<div n="lb">grading connexions, when the father is superior in caste to
<div n="lb">that of the mother, viz. of a Brāhmana with the women of
<div n="lb">the three lower castes; of a Kshatriya with women of the
<div n="lb">Vaiśya and Sūdra--, and of a Vaiśya with a woman of
<div n="lb">the Śūdra caste. Men of this kind must follow occu-
<div n="lb">pations which are held in disrespect by the three first
<div n="lb">castes. Compare also {#apaDvaMsaja#}. <sup>2</sup> A low or contemptible
<div n="lb">man in general; in this sense the word may form Karmadh.
[Page180-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">compounds of which it is the latter part; e. g. {#Srutiviro-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnna kutarkApasadasyAtmalABaH#}. Also read, but less correctly
<div n="lb">{#apaSada#}. E. {#sad#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>4968<pc>180-a<k1>apasamam<k2>apasamam
{#apasamam#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. (Probably.) In the past
<div n="lb">year, last year. Comp. {#aparasamam#}. E. {#apa#} and {#samA#}.
<LEND>

<L>4975<pc>180-a<k1>apasalavi<k2>apasalavi
{#apasalavi#}¦ Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Not from the
<div n="lb">right to the left, i. e. from the left to the right; the re-
<div n="lb">verse of {#prasalavi#} and {#pradakziRa;#} and the same as {#apasavyam#} II.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The space between the thumb and the forefinger, the
<div n="lb">space considered as sacred to the Manes and wherefrom
<div n="lb">the oblations to the latter are made. Comp. {#pitftIrTa#} and
<div n="lb">the following; {%Raghunandana%} in the {%Śrāddhatattva:%} {#taTA#}
<div n="lb">{#ca goBilagfhyam .…iti savyenEva pARinA sUtratantuM gfhItvA .#}
<div n="lb">{#apasalavi pUrvasyAM karzvAM piRqe nidaDyAt . piturnAma gfhItvA .#}
<div n="lb">{#asAvetatte vAso ye cAtra tvAmanu yAMSca tvamanu tasmE te svaDeti .#}
<div n="lb">{#apa upaspfSya . evamevetarayoH savyenEva pARinA udakapAtraM gfhI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvA . apasalavi piRqAnAmupari siYcet .…ezAmarTaH…#}
<div n="lb">{#‘sapuzpaM jalamAdAya tezAM pfzWe pfTakpfTak . apradakziRaM nenijyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dgotre nAmAnumantritam’ . iti brahmapurARavacanAt . apasalavi#}
<div n="lb">{#pitftIrTena pradeSinyaNguzWayorantarA apasalavi apasavyaM vA tena#}
<div n="lb">{#pitfByo nidaDAtIti BawwaBAzyaDftagfhyAntarAdapasavyaSabdena pi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tftIrTamucyate . asmAdeva vacanAt . taTA ca manuH . prAcInAvIti-#}
<div n="lb">{#nA samyagapasavyamatandriRA ityAdi#} ({%Manu%} 3. 279.) &c. E. {#apa#} and
<div n="lb">{#salavi#}. For the meaning of {#apa#} in this word comp. {#apadiSam#}.
<LEND>

<L>4976<pc>180-a<k1>apasavya<k2>apasavya
{#apasavya#}¦ I. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not left,
<div n="lb">right; the same as {#dakziRa.--apasavyaM kf,#} to keep the right
<div n="lb">side towards one, (comp. {#pradakziRaM kf#}), or to put on the right
<div n="lb">shoulder (scil. the sacrificial thread). <sup>2</sup> Contrary, adverse.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> The sacrificial thread worn over the right
<div n="lb">shoulder and passed under the left, at Śrāddhas; comp.
<div n="lb">{#prAcInAvIta#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Astronomy) defined thus: {#tArAgrahARAM#}
<div n="lb">{#caturDAsaMgarAntargatAparaM yudDam;#} e. g. in the {%Vasiṣṭha-Sid-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhānta:%} {#aMSAdUne'pasavAKyaM yudDameko'tra cedaRu#}.
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-vyam#}) The same as {#apasalavi#} in both
<div n="lb">meanings; comp. also the quotation under this word. E.
<div n="lb">{#apa#} and {#savya#}.
<LEND>

<L>4982<pc>180-b<k1>apasArvaseni<k2>apasArvaseni

<L>4983<pc>180-b<k1>apasidDAnta<k2>apasidDAnta
{#apasidDAnta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ntaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A false conclusion; e. g. {#mUrta-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAdGawAdivatsamAnaDarmApattAvapasidDAntaH#} ‘(to say that the
<div n="lb">Soul is limited) is a false conclusion, for this would lead
<div n="lb">to assert that, from its having shape, it shares in the
<div n="lb">properties of material substances (as in those of perishable-
<div n="lb">ness &c.)’; or {#AnandABivyaktirmuKyamokza iti navInavedAnti-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmapasidDAnta eveti Dik#} ‘to maintain that manifestation of
<div n="lb">happiness is real liberation is a wrong conclusion of the
<div n="lb">modern Vedāntists: shame (on such twaddle)’. <sup>2</sup> (In the
<div n="lb">Nyāya philosophy.) Logical inconsistency in argumentation,
<div n="lb">viz. arguing so as to come in contradiction with the tenets
<div n="lb">of one's own school; one of the twenty two {#nigrahasTAna#}
<div n="lb">or failures in discussion which lead to the defeat of the
<div n="lb">disputant; more especially it is thus defined: {#sidDAntamaByu-#}
<div n="lb">{#petyAniyamAtkaTAprasaNgo'pasidDAntaH#} ‘{%apasiddhānta%} is ar-
<div n="lb">gumentation without regard to the definitions contained in
<div n="lb">the tenets of a school which one has adopted as his own’.--
<div n="lb">The commentator adds however that there is no {#apasidDAnta#}
<div n="lb">or inconsistency of this kind, if one differs merely in a
<div n="lb">special topic from the authority of his school: {#yastvekade-#}
<div n="lb">{#Simatena kaTAmAraBate tasya SAstrakArAByupagamaviroDe nApasi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDAntaH;#} ‘the Saugatas’, he says, ‘do not consider logical
<div n="lb">inconsistency as a defect, but that is another question’ ({#sO-#}
<div n="lb">{#gatAstvapasidDAntaM dUzaRaM na manyanta ityanyadetat#}). E. {#apa#} and
<div n="lb">{#sidDAnta#}.
<LEND>

<L>4984<pc>180-b<k1>apasIra<k2>apasIra
{#apasIra#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}); II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#});
<div n="lb">and III. Avyayībh. ({#-ram#}); it has the same meanings as
<div n="lb">{#apalANgala#} and is also udātta on the last syllable. Comp.
<div n="lb">the remark s. v. {#apakukzi#}. E. {#apa#} and {#sIra#}.
<LEND>

<L>4987<pc>180-b<k1>apaskara<k2>apaskara
{#apaskara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Any part of a carriage, except
<div n="lb">the wheel. [Some comm. on the {%Amarak.%} II. 8. 2. 23. include
<div n="lb">the wheel, e. g. {%Rāyamukuṭa:%} {#akzayugacakrAdikam;#} but {%Bhā-%}
<div n="lb">{%nudīkṣita%} is apparently more in harmony with the context
<div n="lb">of the Amarak. {#‘raTANgamapaskaraH . cakraM raTANgam’,#} when he
<div n="lb">excepts the wheel: {#dve cakraBinnasya raTAramBakasya;#} and {%Valla-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhagaṇi%} on Hemach. 3. 422. (or verse 758) also comments:
<div n="lb">{#cakrAdanyAni raTasyANgAni AramBakARi raTANgAni apaskarA#}
<div n="lb">{#ityanvayaH#}.] <sup>2</sup> The organs of generation and the anus (i. e.
<div n="lb">the parts of the body whence dirt proceeds). <sup>2</sup> Fæces, ex-
[Page181-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">crements. [The two latter meanings according to {%Dharaṇi%}
<div n="lb">who gives the word in the first meaning as a {%neuter:%} {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#skarO guhyavizWe apaskaraM raTANgakam#}.] E. {#kF#} with {#apa,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#ap#} and āgama {#suw;#} but comp. the remark s. v. {#apas#}
<div n="lb">III.; in the first meaning explained: ‘because it is thrown,
<div n="lb">i. e. shaken, in its place: {#apakIryate svasvasTAne kzipyate#}’.
<LEND>

<L>4988<pc>181-a<k1>apaskAra<k2>apaskAra
{#apaskAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) The root of the leg or, according
<div n="lb">to others, the root of the knee. [In the verse of the {%Śiśu-%}
<div n="lb">{%pālabadha%} 18. 46. {%Mallinātha%} explains the words {#ApaskArAt#}
<div n="lb">by {#gAtramUlamApaskAram . ApaskArAdA mUlAt,#} when the
<div n="lb">word would not be {#apaskAra#} m., but {#ApaskAra#} n. {%Valla-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhachakravartin,%} however, explains {#apaskAro jAnumUlam,#}
<div n="lb">and in the same manner {%Vallabhabharatasena%} and {%Chandra-%}
<div n="lb">{%śekhara%} (the reading of the E. I. H. Ms. No. 79 {#ayaskAro#}
<div n="lb">or {#apaskaro#} in the commentary of the two latter being re-
<div n="lb">futed partly by the reading of the verse in other Mss., partly
<div n="lb">by the metre itself); and {%Vallabhagaṇi%} in his comment on
<div n="lb">the word {#gAtra#} in {%Hemach.'s Abhidh.%} 4. 294. (= v. 1228),
<div n="lb">after having quoted the verse in question continues: {#lUna-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAtrasya cCinnapUrvakAyasya . ApaskArAt . A jaNGAmUlAt . a-#}
<div n="lb">{#paskAraM yAvacCinnasyetyarTaH#}.] E. {#kF#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}
<div n="lb">and āgama {#suw#}.
<LEND>

<L>4989<pc>181-a<k1>apasKala<k2>apasKala
{#apasKala#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-laH#}) (ved.) A place which is not a
<div n="lb">threshing floor or outside of a threshing floor; a place which
<div n="lb">is useless for the purpose of threshing or unchaffing rice
<div n="lb">&c.; the word is used in the {%Śatapathabr.%} I. 7. 3. 26. as a
<div n="lb">comparison to the Gārhapatya fire on which the clarified
<div n="lb">butter is not to be fried, this fire being unfit for such a
<div n="lb">purpose; for ‘like as grain heaped up outside of a threshing
<div n="lb">floor is to no purpose, in the same manner clarified butter
<div n="lb">fried in the Gārhapatya can produce no result’. E. {#apa#} and
<div n="lb">{#sKala#}.
<LEND>

<L>4990<pc>181-a<k1>apastama<k2>apastama
{#apastama#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) (ved.) Most rapid, most swift;
<div n="lb">as a stream, e. g. {#(sarasvatI) apasAmapastamA#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#vegavatI-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAM nadInAM maDye'pastamA vegavattamA#}). E. {#apas#} II. 4., taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#tamap#}.
<LEND>

<L>4992<pc>181-a<k1>apastamBa<k2>apastamBa
{#apastamBa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-mBaH#}) (In Medicine.) One of the vital
<div n="lb">parts between the belly and chest; the name of two vessels
<div n="lb">which convey air to the chest and if wounded will, through
<div n="lb">cough and asthma, produce death. (According to the {%Bhā-%}
<div n="lb">{%vaprakāśa:%} half a finger long.) E. {#stamB#} with {#apa,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#GaY#}.

<L>4998<pc>181-b<k1>apaspfc<k2>apaspfc
{#apaspfc#}¦ (?) Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-k-k-k#}) (ved.) (Perhaps.) Yield-
<div n="lb">ing, giving; in the {%Ātharvav.%} 13. 1. 27: {#vi mimIzvava payasva-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIM GftAcIM devAnAM DenuranapaspfgezA#} ‘make her to have milk
<div n="lb">and to become possessed of butter for the gods: this cow
<div n="lb">does not yield any’. E. {#spfc (= pfc)#} with {#apa,#} or {#pfc#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} āgāma {#suw,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}. [This interpretation
<div n="lb">is hypothetical, in want of a comm. to the Atharv. The
<div n="lb">same meaning might result in deriving {#apaspfk#} from {#apaspfS#}
<div n="lb">‘sprinkling, shedding’, the radicals {#pfc#} and {#spfS#} being
<div n="lb">connected in origin; but the former seems more natural.]

<L>4999<pc>181-b<k1>apasPiga<k2>apasPiga

<L>5000<pc>181-b<k1>apasPur<k2>apasPur
{#apasPur#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-sPUH-sPUH-sPUH#}) (ved.) Very large,
<div n="lb">increased, excessive; an epithet of Soma (according to
<div n="lb">{%Sāyaṇa,%} viz. = {#atyantapravfdDa#}); {#anapasPur#} ‘not large’, an
<div n="lb">epithet of a cow ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#apravfdDa#}). But comp. {#apasPurat#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#sPur#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>5001<pc>181-b<k1>apasPura<k2>apasPura
{#apasPura#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) (ved.) Injured, hurt;
<div n="lb">{#anapasPura#} ‘uninjured, inviolable’, an epithet of a cow (ac-
<div n="lb">cording to {%Sāyaṇa,%} viz. = {#anapabADya#}). But comp. {#apasPurat#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#sPur#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5002<pc>181-b<k1>apasPurat<k2>apasPurat
{#apasPurat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) The same as {#apasPura;#}
<div n="lb">{#anapasPurat#} ‘not injured, unhurt’; also as an epithet of a
<div n="lb">cow (according to {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Ṛgv.%} 4. 42. 10., viz. {#anavahiM-#}
<div n="lb">{#sita#}). {%Mahidhara,%} however, explains the word {#apasPurat#}
<div n="lb">in the corresponding verse of the {%Vājas.%} 7. 10. ‘going to
<div n="lb">another’ i. e. running away, and {#anapasPurat#} ‘not going to
<div n="lb">another’ i. e. not running away. This latter sense being more
<div n="lb">congenial with the context, it is probably not unsafe to
<div n="lb">infer that the words {#apasPur#} and {#apasPura#} will also have to
<div n="lb">be taken in Mahīdhara's meaning of {#apasPurat,#} and {#anapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#sPur, anapasPura#} qq. vv. in Mahīdhara's meaning of {#anapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#sPurat#}.--E. {#sPur#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5003<pc>181-b<k1>apasmAra<k2>apasmAra
{#apasmAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (In Medicine.) Epilepsy, falling
<div n="lb">sickness; according to {%Suśruta,%} of four kinds, the three
<div n="lb">first produced by the derangement of air, bile and phlegm,
<div n="lb">the fourth by the combination of the three. (A definition
<div n="lb">of {%Ātreya%} is: {#pittaM raktaM marucCezmA udAnaH kupito BfSam .#}
<div n="lb">{#prARaH Sirasi saMkupya kurute nazwacezwatAm#}.) In Rhetoric it is
<div n="lb">mentioned as a {#vyaBicAriBAva#} or an accessory condition of
<div n="lb">the Erotic ({#SfNgAra#}), Pathetic ({#karuRa#}), the Fearful ({#BayAnaka#})
<div n="lb">and the Disgustful ({#bIBatma#}), and is defined--but happily
<div n="lb">this definition has not guided the Hindu poets in the re-
<div n="lb">presentation of their characters--as ‘dementation caused
<div n="lb">by the planets or similar evil influences and causing falls,
<div n="lb">trembling, perspiration, foaming at the mouth, slavering
<div n="lb">&c.’. E. {#smf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5004<pc>181-b<k1>apasmArin<k2>apasmArin
{#apasmArin#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) Afflicted with epilepsy.
<div n="lb">({%Manu%} enjoins not to marry a girl of a family where there
[Page182-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">are persons afflicted with epilepsy, the disease being con-
<div n="lb">tagious, according to {%Kullūka.%}) E. {#apasmAra,#} tadd. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>5005<pc>182-a<k1>apasy<k2>apasy
{#apasy#}¦ denom. par. ({#-syati;#} leṭ {#-syAt#}) (ved.) To be active,
<div n="lb">to be busy. E. {#apas#} I., denom. aff. {#kyac#}.
<LEND>

<L>5006<pc>182-a<k1>apasya<k2>apasya
{#apasya#}¦ I. 1. m. f. n. ({#-syaH-syA-syam#}) Fit for a (sacrificial) act.
<div n="lb">[{%Mahīdhara%} explains in {%Vājas.%} 10. 7. {#apasyo vasAnAH#} as epi-
<div n="lb">thets to the preceding word {#ApaH#} ‘waters’ and renders {#apasyaH#}
<div n="lb">in the stated sense; but the commentators on a {%Vārttika%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 30. {#‘vasuapasºº’#} (misprinted in the present
<div n="lb">edition and therefore in the reprint of that edition {#‘vasua-#}
<div n="lb">{#yasºº’#}) explain {#apasyAH#} as meaning ‘water’; and while {%Ma-%}
<div n="lb">{%hīdhara%} takes {#apasyaH#} as an irregular nom. plur. instead of
<div n="lb">{#apasyAH,#} {%Patanjali%} and, after him, the {%Kāśikā%} consider it as
<div n="lb">an irregular accus. (= {#apaH#}); {%Patanjali:%} {#apasyo vasAnAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#apo vasAnAH ..#}. {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apSabdAddvitIyAbahuvacanAntA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyatpratyayo viBakteScAluk#}. {%Kāśikā:%} {#dvitIyAbahuvacanasyAluk .#}
<div n="lb">{#apo vasAnA ityarTaH#}.]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-syA#}) <sup>1</sup> Water (see the preceding explanation).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> The name of the first fifteen bricks amongst the twenty
<div n="lb">bricks which are placed five in each quarter on a sacrificial
<div n="lb">ground; the last five being called {#CandasyA#}. E. {#apas,#} taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#yat#} (or in {%Vājas.%} 10. 7. according to the quoted {%Vārttika,%}
<div n="lb">{#ap#} in the accus. plur., taddh. aff. {#yat#}).
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-syA#}) <sup>1</sup> Activity, action. <sup>2</sup> Desire to act. E. {#apasy,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#a#}.
<LEND>

<L>5015<pc>182-a<k1>apaharaRa<k2>apaharaRa
{#apaharaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking away, carrying off, re-
<div n="lb">moving. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.) The same as {#steya,#} stealing or rob-
<div n="lb">bing, viz. ‘taking a thing either with, or without, the know-
<div n="lb">ledge of the owner, by force or by stealth, or without a
<div n="lb">valid title’; compare the following definition of the {%Mitā-%}
<div n="lb">{%kshara:%} {#apaharaRaSabdena samakzaM parokzaM vA balAccOryeRa vA#}
<div n="lb">{#krayAdisvatvahetuM vinA grahaRamucyate#} (and the following of {#steya#}
[Page182-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">by {%Kātyāyana:%} {#pracCannaM vA prakASaM vA niSAyAmaTavA divA .#}
<div n="lb">{#yatparadravyaharaRaM steyaM tatparikIrtitam;#} the term {#steya#} being
<div n="lb">also applied, in law, to the appropriation of goods with-
<div n="lb">out a valid title; compare e. g. the {%Dāyabhāga%} for the
<div n="lb">definition of {#stena, ‘ya eva hi parasyedamiti viSezeRa jAnAnaH#}
<div n="lb">{#parasve svatvahetumantareREva svatvamAropayati sa stena iti loka-#}
<div n="lb">{#prasidDo'rTaH’#}). See also {#apahAra#}. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5019<pc>182-b<k1>apahartf<k2>apahartf
{#apahartf#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rtA-rtrI-rtf#}) <sup>1</sup> One who takes
<div n="lb">away, carries off, removes. <sup>2</sup> One who steals. <sup>3</sup> One who
<div n="lb">conceals or secretes; e. g. {#nikzepasyApahartAram#} (comm. = {#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzepasyApahnotAram#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-rtA#}) The name of a brother of the serpent Śeṣa
<div n="lb">(according to the {%Harivanśa%} in the translation of {%Langlois%}
<div n="lb">vol. II. p. 481). E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#tfc#} or {#tfn#}. [N. B.
<div n="lb">When derived with the kṛt {#tfc,#} the word merely expresses
<div n="lb">the notion of the {%agens in general,%} as is the case with all
<div n="lb">other derivatives of radicals by means of {#tfc;#} a noun de-
<div n="lb">pending on it then stands in the genitive, e. g. {#nikzepasyApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#hartA#} ‘a man who secretes a deposit’. But when derived
<div n="lb">by means of the affix {#tfn#} it implies moreover {%habit%} and, a
<div n="lb">noun depending on it in this sense stands in the accus., e. g.
<div n="lb">{#annamapahartAra AhvarakA Bavanti SrAdDe sidDe sati#} ‘the in-
<div n="lb">habitants of Ahwara are in the {%habit of carrying off%} the food
<div n="lb">after the funeral oblation is performed’; it might seem doubt-
<div n="lb">ful, therefore, whether e. g. the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga%}
<div n="lb">p. 351, line 18: {#asuvarRaM suvarRabudDyApaharturna suvarRApahAraH#} is
<div n="lb">correct and ought not to be {#asuvarRasya#} &c., the word {#apahartf#}
<div n="lb">expressing there simply the agens without an additional
<div n="lb">notion, as results from the comparison of these words with
<div n="lb">p. 350. 1. 16. The word when derived by kṛt {#tfc#} is udātta
<div n="lb">on the last syllable; but when derived by {#tfn#} udātta on the
<div n="lb">first syllable.]
<LEND>

<L>5020<pc>182-b<k1>apahala<k2>apahala
