<L>5027<pc>183-a<k1>apahAra<k2>apahAra
{#apahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking away, carrying off, re-
<div n="lb">moving; also figuratively; comp. {#AtmApahAra#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.)
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> Stealing, robbing; see {#apaharaRa#} and the definition given
<div n="lb">of the latter word. <sup>b.</sup> Concealing, secreting; according to
<div n="lb">{%Jīmūtavāhana%} in the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga:%} {#na sADAraRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#DanApahAre steyanizpattiH#} ‘the notion of theft is not completed
<div n="lb">in a case of concealment of property common (to two or
<div n="lb">more)’, when the word {#apahAra#} is thus explained: {#apahA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rapadaM tu saMgopanABiprAyam . na ca saMgopanaM steyamuktam . asaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#guptaharaRe'pi steyapadapradarSanAt#}. <sup>c.</sup> Withholding property
<div n="lb">from its lawful owner; in the passage of the {%Dāyabhāga%}
<div n="lb">and the {%Dāyakramasaṅgraha:%} {#strIRAM svapatidAyastu upaBo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gaPalaH smftaH . nApahAraM striyaH kuryuH patidAyAtkaTaMcana;#} where
<div n="lb">{%Jīmūtavāhana%} explains {#apahAra#} in this manner: {#apahAraSca#}
<div n="lb">{#DanasvAmyanupayoge Bavati#}. (The quotation from the {%Dāyabhāga%}
<div n="lb">by {%Rādhākāntadeva%} s. v. {#apahAra,#} viz. {#‘DanasvAmyanupayogi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyayaH’#}--as well as the translations which have been founded
<div n="lb">on it--seem to arise from a mistake, the more so as the
<div n="lb">law point in question does not concern the ‘spending’ but
<div n="lb">‘the non-delivery to a wife of her lawful property’.) <sup>3</sup> Loss.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> (In Astronomy.) The configuration of the minor planets
<div n="lb">considered as influencing the fortune of man; comp. {#anta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rdaSA#} and {#apahAreSvara#}. E. {#hf#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5028<pc>183-a<k1>apahAraka<k2>apahAraka

<L>5033<pc>183-b<k1>apahArya<k2>apahArya
{#apahArya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ryaH-ryA-ryam#}) To be taken away,
<div n="lb">to be carried off, to be removed; e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.%}
<div n="lb">{#smarAture cetasi labDajanmA rarAja lolo'pi guRApahAryaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#kutUhalanetragavAkzasaMsTaH paSyannivAnyonyamuKAni rAgaH ..#}. E. {#hf#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛtya aff. {#Ryat#}.

<L>5044<pc>183-b<k1>apahnuti<k2>apahnuti
{#apahnuti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Denial, concealment of knowledge.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> (In Rhetoric.) A figure of speech, one of the alamkāras
<div n="lb">or modes of elegant expression, viz. with two varieties,
<div n="lb">each comprising again two subdivisions: <sup>a.</sup> a hidden com-
<div n="lb">parison, the simile being expressed by way of negation or
<div n="lb">denial, and that part of the sentence which contains the ne-
<div n="lb">gation or the denial either preceding or following the object
<div n="lb">of comparison, e. g. (preceding) {#nedaM naBomaRqalamamburASirnE-#}
<div n="lb">{#tASca tArA navaPenaBaNgAH#} &c.; or (following) {#etadviBAti cara-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAcalacUqacumbihiRqIrapiRqaruciSItamarIcibimbam . ujjvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#litasya rajanIM madanAnalasya DUmaM daDatprakawalAYCanakEtavena;#}
<div n="lb">comp. also {#antargatopamA;#} <sup>b</sup> a covert expression, the in-
<div n="lb">tended sense being conveyed either by way of a pun or by some
<div n="lb">other artful mode of language; e. g. (by way of a pun) {#kAle#}
<div n="lb">{#vAriDarARAmapatitayA nEva Sakyate sTAtum . utkaRwitAsi#}
<div n="lb">{#tarale na hi na hi saKi vicCilaH panTAH#} (where the intended
[Page184-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">sense is conveyed by the double etymology of {#apatitA#}
<div n="lb">({#apati,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#a-patitA#} (from {#pat,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#});
<div n="lb">or (by allusion) {#iha puro'nilakampitavigrahA milati kA na#}
<div n="lb">{#vanaspatinA latA . smarasi kiM saKi kAntaratotsavaM na hi GanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gamarItirudAhftA ..#}. Comp. also {#vakrokti#}. E. {#hnu#} with {#apa,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5067<pc>184-b<k1>apANga<k2>apANga

<div n="lb">or {#NIz#} according to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 54. v. 1.; and the same
<div n="lb">remark applies to {#apANga#} when it is a latter part of a
<div n="lb">Bahuvr. compound; the rule IV. 1. 56. not being to the con-
<div n="lb">trary, since it merely concerns uncompounded words of
<div n="lb">several syllables, in the sense of {#svANga#} q. v.

<div n="lb">{#dfzwA,#} which is thus explained by a comm.: {#parivfttamarDamuKaM#}

<L>5073<pc>185-a<k1>apAc<k2>apAc
{#apAc#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-N-cI-k#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Going down-
<div n="lb">wards; as opposed to {#prAc#} going upwards (to heaven).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Western. <sup>3</sup> Southern. [The meaning ‘western’ is that
<div n="lb">which is given usually by the commentators to the word
<div n="lb">when it occurs in the Vedas; the meaning ‘southern’ is
<div n="lb">given by the Koshas--comp. also {#avAc#}--, and belongs
<div n="lb">to the word also in {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 101. where {#‘prAc, apAc,#}
<div n="lb">{#udac, pratIc’#} are a complete enumeration of the four re-
<div n="lb">gions of the compass; {%Prauḍhamanor.%} {#apAcI dakziRA dik .#}
<div n="lb">{#dvitIyo varRaH pakAro na tu dantyozWyaH#}.]--See {#apAk#}. For
<div n="lb">the declension of this word comp. {#aYc#} II.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-cI#}) The South; comp. {#avAcI#}. E. {#aYc (ancu)#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kvin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5074<pc>185-a<k1>apAcItarA<k2>apAcItarA

<LEND>

<L>5075<pc>185-a<k1>apAcIna<k2>apAcIna
{#apAcIna#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Going downwards (ved.).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Opposite. <sup>3</sup> Western(?). <sup>4</sup> Southern. (For the two latter
<div n="lb">meanings comp. the remark s. v. {#apAc#}.)--According to
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇini%} the feminine is not allowed to express the region. E.
<div n="lb">{#apAc,#} taddh. aff. {#Ka#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#apAc,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}.

<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Indigestible. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pAcya#}.

<L>5088<pc>185-b<k1>apAdAna<k2>apAdAna
{#apAdAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Taking away. <sup>2</sup> (In Gram-
<div n="lb">mar.) The sense expressed by the fifth case or ablative;
<div n="lb">viz. ‘the point of departure in connexion with the notion of
<div n="lb">separation; the cause of fear in connexion with the notion
<div n="lb">of fear, protecting from; the object not bearable in con-
<div n="lb">nexion with the notion of being overpowered by; the object
<div n="lb">protected in connexion with that of withholding from; the
<div n="lb">object shunned or abandoned in connexion with that of hid-
<div n="lb">ing one's self from, being disgusted with, desisting from; the
<div n="lb">object deviated from in connexion with that of deviating from;
<div n="lb">the source of knowlege (teacher &c.) in connexion with that of
<div n="lb">learning from; birth, origin in connexion with the notion of
<div n="lb">descent, coming from’. E. {#dA#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<div n="P">II. Cutting off; in the following passage of the {%Jaiminīya-%}
<div n="lb">{%nyāyamālāvistara%} where the word is used in the same sense
<div n="lb">as {#avadAna,#} apparently only for the sake of distinguishing the
<div n="lb">second cutting off ({#pUrvArDAdavadyati#}) from the first {#(maDyAdava-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyati): darSapUrRamAsayoH puroqASAvadAne SrUyate . maDyAdavadyati .#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvArDAdavadyatIti . tadyadyavattaM naSyeta . tadAnImavaSizwAtpu-#}
<div n="lb">{#roqASAtpunarapyavadAtavyam . kutaH . avadAnApAdAnayormaDya-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvArDayoH Sizwe'pi saMBavAditi cet .. mEvam . kftsnapuroqA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Sagate maDyapUrvArDe apAdAnatvena SrUyete . na tvavaSizwaBAgagate#}
<div n="lb">{#maDyapUrvArDe .#} &c. E. {#do#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>5092<pc>185-b<k1>apAna<k2>apAna
{#apAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> The air which goes downwards; in
<div n="lb">the Vedas, in the doctrine of the Upanishads as well as in
<div n="lb">the philosophical and medical systems, the air (comp. {#vAta,#}
<div n="lb">{#vAyu#}) which is {%inhaled%} and {%descends%} the body, one of the
[Page186-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">five vital airs which are supposed to pervade the latter; (op-
<div n="lb">posed to {#prARa,#} the air which is {%exhaled%} or {%proceeds%} from the
<div n="lb">body; comp. besides {#udAna, samAna, vyAna#} and see {#ana#}); in
<div n="lb">the legend of the {%Aitareya Upan.%} it is therefore this vital air
<div n="lb">which is able to seize food, (for it introduces it into the body),
<div n="lb">and to give support to life; comp. {#annAyu#}. In the {%Śatapath.%}
<div n="lb">and {%Bṛhadār. Upan.%} it is called, from the same reason, the
<div n="lb">function of {%smelling%} (and the odour {%inhaled%}): {#prARo vE grahaH#}
<div n="lb">{#so'pAnenAtigrAheRa gfhIto'pAnena hi ganDaM jiGrati#}. In the
<div n="lb">{%Vedānta-Sāra%} it is defined: {#apAno nAmAvAggamanavAnpAyvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#disTAnavartI#} (comm. {#aDo nABeraDastAdgamanavAnmalAdyAnayana-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyApAreRa . pAyurgudam . tatsTAnavartItyarTaH . AdiSabdAdupasTagra-#}
<div n="lb">{#haH . tatrApi mUtraretovisargasyApAnakarmatvAt#}); in the {%Sāṅkhya%} it
<div n="lb">is like the other four vital airs the function which is common
<div n="lb">to {#budDi, ahaNkAra#} and {#manas#} qq. vv. ({%Sāṅkhya prav.%} {#sAmAnyaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRavfttiH prARAdyA vAyavaH paYca#}) and explained by the comm.
<div n="lb">{#apanayanAdapAnastatra yatsyandanaM tadapi sAmAnyavfttirindriyasya#}.
<div n="lb">In the {%Kaṇāda-Sūtra%} {#prARApAnanimezonmezaºº#} it is explained
<div n="lb">as having the property of {#aDogamanaM PutkArAdO vA tiryagga-#}
<div n="lb">{#manam#}. This theory is then more fully developed in {%Su-%}
<div n="lb">{%śruta's Nidānasthāna%} where the {%inhaled vital air%} ‘resides in
<div n="lb">the rectum and in time {%draws down%} the excrements, urine,
<div n="lb">semen, fœtus and menses’ ({#pakvADAnAlayo'pAnaH kAle#}
<div n="lb">{#karzati cApyayam . samIraRaH SakfnmUtraSukragarBArtavAnyaDaH#}), and
<div n="lb">‘when obstructed by bile produces burning, heat and a little
<div n="lb">blood, when obstructed by phlegm, heaviness in the lower
<div n="lb">part of the body’ ({#apAne pittasaMyukte dAhOzRye syAdasfgda-#}
<div n="lb">{#ram . aDaHkAye gurutvaM ca tasminneva kaPAvfte#}). Comp. also the
<div n="lb">following from the musical work {%Saṅgītadarpaṇa:%} {#prARApA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nO taTA vyAnasamAnodAnasaMjYakAH . nAgaM kUrmaM ca kfkalaM devadattaM#}
<div n="lb">{#DanaMjayam#} (sic, neuter; comp. these latter words in the {%Vedānta-%}
<div n="lb">{%Sāra%} p. 9) {#. tezAM muKyatamaH prARo nABikanDAdaDaH sTitaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#SabdoccAraRaniHSvAsocCvAsakAsAdikAraRam . apAnastu gude#}
<div n="lb">{#meQre kawIjaNGodare taTA . vyAno'kziSrotragulPezu kawyAM GrARe ca#}
<div n="lb">{#tizWati . samAno vyApya niKilaM SarIraM vahninA saha . udAnaH#}
<div n="lb">{#pAdayorAste hastayoraNgasaMDizu . tvagAdiDAtUnASritya paYca nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAdayaH sTitAH#}.--An improvement on Suśruta seems to have
<div n="lb">been intended by {%Hemachandra%} who makes the {#apAna#} run
<div n="lb">down from the nape of the neck to the {%heels%} ({#apAnapavano#}
<div n="lb">{#manyApfzWapfzWAntapArzRigaH;#} comm. {#pfzWAnto gudaH . pArzRI pAdapa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScAdBAgO#}). <sup>2</sup> A fart. <sup>3</sup> The anus. E. {#an#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5093<pc>186-a<k1>apAnat<k2>apAnat
{#apAnat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-tI-t#}) Inhaling, producing the
<div n="lb">function of the vital air {#apAna#} q. v.--In the verse of the
<div n="lb">{%Bhāgav. Pur.%} (2. 10. 16.) {#anu prARanti yaM prARAH prARantaM sarva-#}
<div n="lb">{#jantuzu . apAnantamapAnanti naradevamivAnugAH,#} it deserves no-
<div n="lb">tice that {%Srīdharasvāmin%} takes the word {#apAnat#} in the sense
<div n="lb">‘ceasing to perform vital functions’, viz. ‘they (according to
<div n="lb">the comm., the senses) cease to exercise their functions when
<div n="lb">it (the vital air {#prARa#}) ceases to perform its function’: {#prARA#}
<div n="lb">{#indriyARi yaM#} (scil. {#prARaM,#} the word of the preceding verse)
<div n="lb">{#prARantaM cezwAM kurvantamanu paScAtprARanti cezwAM kurvanti . apAnantaM#}
<div n="lb">{#cezwAM tyajantamanu apAnanti cezwAM tyajanti . rAjAnamanu BftyA iva;#}
<div n="lb">but it seems very doubtful whether he is correct in this con-
<div n="lb">struction of the verse, as {#prARAH#} might be taken in the
<div n="lb">general sense ‘vital airs’, and the sense ‘they perform the
<div n="lb">function of exhaling and inhaling according to the function
[Page186-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">of life ({#prARa#})’ would be in conformity with the usual mean-
<div n="lb">ing of the words in question. E. {#an#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5102<pc>186-b<k1>apAntaratamas<k2>apAntaratamas
{#apAntaratamas#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-mAH#}) The name of an ancient
<div n="lb">Ṛṣi, who in a subsequent birth became, according to the
<div n="lb">legend, the Vedavyāsa or Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana. ({%Śaṅkara%}
<div n="lb">in his comm. on a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#apAntaratamA nAma vedA-#}
<div n="lb">{#cAryaH purARarzirvizRuniyogAtkalidvAparayoH saMDO kfzRadvEpA-#}

<div n="lb">from interior darkness’.
<LEND>

<L>5103<pc>186-b<k1>apAnnapAt<k2>apAnnapAt
{#apAnnapAt#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-t#}) (ved.) An epithet or name of
<div n="lb">Agni (fire) and Savitri (sun).--{%Sāyaṇa%} explains this word
<div n="lb">as meaning literally either ‘not protecting ({#na-pAt,#} from
<div n="lb">{#pA,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}) or not allowing to fall down ({#na-pAt#}
<div n="lb">from the caus. of {#pat,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}) the waters’, fire or
<div n="lb">sun drying up the water; or ‘the grandson of the waters’,
<div n="lb">water bringing forth plants and trees, and plants and trees
<div n="lb">being the cause of fire; the latter explanation, apparently
<div n="lb">more congenial with the vaidik poetry than the former, is
<div n="lb">also given by {%Yāska.%} Comp. {#ap#} and {#apAnnaptf#}. [The word has
<div n="lb">two accents, viz. the udātta on the second and third syllable
<div n="lb">and is given by the Padatext of the Ṛgveda as representing
<div n="lb">not a compound, but two distinct words; that it may be
<div n="lb">analyzed so, is indubitable from passages where it occurs
<div n="lb">e. g. in the form {#napAtamapAm#}. On the other hand it must be ob-
<div n="lb">served that the double accent belongs also to other and similar
<div n="lb">Tatpur. mentioned in the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 140. (comp. e. g.
<div n="lb">{#tanUnapAt#}) and that this Gaṇa would comprise more words
<div n="lb">than those mentioned in the present edition of Pāṇ. and the
<div n="lb">ordinary Gaṇa lists as well as in the Kāśikā, if we may believe
<div n="lb">the {%Svaramañjarī%} of {%Nṛsinha,%} which mentions e. g. {#Sukagra-#}
<div n="lb">{#nTinO#} (not referring this word to VI. 2. 141.) and concludes
<div n="lb">with {#ityAdi;#} it may be observed too, that the {%Nighanṭu%}
<div n="lb">mentions {#apAnnapAt#} as {%one%} of the thirty-two {#pada#} enumerated
<div n="lb">V. 4., and that {%Sāyaṇa%} in his comm. cannot have looked
<div n="lb">upon it otherwise than as a compound when he writes e. g.
<div n="lb">{#apAMnapAtsaMjYako'gniH;#} comp. also the remark of {%Patanjali%}
<div n="lb">s. v. {#apAnnaptf#}. The genitive {%plur.%} as a former part of a com-
<div n="lb">pound, is of rare occurrence, but met with also in other
[Page187-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">compounds beginning with {#apAm,#} e. g. {#apAMvatsa, apAnnATa,#}
<div n="lb">{#apAmpati#} &c. and in the Tatpur. {#devAnAMpriya#} ({%Pāṇini%} VI. 3. 21.
<div n="lb">{%Vārtt.%} 4.). E. {#apAm#} (gen. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#napAt#}.
<LEND>

<L>5104<pc>187-a<k1>apAnnaptf<k2>apAnnaptf
{#apAnnaptf#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ptA#}) The grandson of the Waters, a
<div n="lb">vaidik epithet or name of Agni (see the explanation given
<div n="lb">s. v. {#apAnnapAt#}); but {%Sāyaṇa%} distinguishes on one occasion
<div n="lb">the sacrificial fire from the {#apAnnaptf#} whom he then calls the
<div n="lb">Fire of the lightning as being the {%son%} of the rain-waters.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#ap#} and {#aponaptf#}. [In the vaidik hymns this word does
<div n="lb">not occur as a compound; but that it must have been con-
<div n="lb">sidered as such in the ritual literature results from the deri-
<div n="lb">vatives {#apAnnaptriya#} and {#apAnnaptrIya#}. {%Patanjali%} in his com-
<div n="lb">ment on the latter forms ({%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 28.) denies the correct-
<div n="lb">ness of a combination {#apAMnaptf#} and assumes that the ending
<div n="lb">{#f#} of the latter word merely exists before the affixes in
<div n="lb">question, while otherwise the word would be {#apAnnapAt;#}
<div n="lb">{%Kaiyyaṭa,%} however, admits of such a combination in the
<div n="lb">Vedas. {%Mahābhāṣya%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 28.: {#aTa yadaponaptriya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapAMnaptriyaM vA haviH . kaTaM tasya prEzaH kartavyaH . aponapAte#}
<div n="lb">{#'nubrUhi . apAMnapAte'nubrUhi . aponaptrapAMnaptfBAvaH#} (the Ms.
<div n="lb">of the E. I. H. No. 330 reads wrongly {#aponaptfpAMnaBAvaH#})
<div n="lb">{#kasmAnna Bavati . pratyayasaMniyogena fkArAntatvamucyate . tenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sati pratyaye na Bavitavyam ..;#} but {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#aTeti . vede kva-#}
<div n="lb">{#cidaponaptre svAheti fkArAntaH prayogo dfSayate . kvacidapo-#}
<div n="lb">{#napAditi takArAntaH prayoga iti praSnaH . pratyayasaMniyogeneti .#}
<div n="lb">{#vede tu cCAndasatvAtkvacidfkArAntayogaH#} (the Ms.: {#CAndasatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tkaccidfkArAntayogaH#}).] E. {#apAm#} (gen. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#naptf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5115<pc>187-b<k1>apAmArga<k2>apAmArga
{#apAmArga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rgaH#}) The name of a plant (Achyranthes
<div n="lb">aspera) which is employed for sacrificial purposes, it being
<div n="lb">supposed to have the power of removing sins, and also as
<div n="lb">a medicament; it has three varieties: the white, the red and
<div n="lb">the water-Apāmārga. The white variety is described as ‘a
<div n="lb">little pungent, hot, bitterish, astringent or constipating,
<div n="lb">emetic, purgent (sic), increasing the digestion, or stomachic,
<div n="lb">and applied against diseases from phlegm, the itch, piles,
<div n="lb">diseases of the stomach, of the blood, of serous secretions,
<div n="lb">of the vital airs, against cutaneous eruptions, leprosy, in-
<div n="lb">dolent tumors and nausea’--; the red variety is ‘a little
<div n="lb">pungent, cold, constipating, emetic, obstructing the circu-
<div n="lb">lation of the vital air, and rough; it is employed against
<div n="lb">diseases from phlegm and of the vital airs, against ulcers,
<div n="lb">itch, and poison; its seed or fruit is cold, sweet, indiges-
<div n="lb">tive whether raw or cooked, constipating, causing flatulency,
<div n="lb">rough, emetic and good for cough and hemorrhages from
<div n="lb">the mouth, nose, rectum and cuticle’; the water-variety is
<div n="lb">‘pungent and used against pulmonary consumption, swell-
<div n="lb">ings, diseases from phlegm and of the vital airs, and against
<div n="lb">cough’.--The ashes of the plant are used in cleaning linen.
<div n="lb">E. {#mfj#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY,#} the final vowel of the prefix
<div n="lb">being lengthened; (or according to {%Bhānud.%} on the {%Amarak.,%}
<div n="lb">a Bahuvr. {#apa#} and {#A-mArga; ‘apamArjantyanena…, apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kfzwa AsamantAnmArgo'syeti vA’;#} but according to {%Rāyam.%}
<div n="lb">only the former: {#‘apamfjanti vastrAdikamanena’;#} and equally
<div n="lb">so the {%Siddhāntak.%} {#‘apamfjyate'nena vyADAdiH’,#} and the {%Kā-%}
<div n="lb">{%śikā%} which quotes {#apAmArga,#} besides {#vImArga#} as an instance
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 122.).
<LEND>

<L>5116<pc>187-b<k1>apAmArjana<k2>apAmArjana

<div n="lb">a hymn addressed to Viṣṇu, which has this power. E.
<div n="lb">{#mfj#} with {#A#} and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5117<pc>187-b<k1>apAmpati<k2>apAmpati

<div n="lb">ruṇa, the regent of the waters. <sup>3</sup> (In Astronomy.) The
<div n="lb">twenty-fifth of the Nakshatra or lunar mansions; compare
<div n="lb">also {#SataBizA#}. <sup>4</sup> (In Astronomy.) The thirteenth of the

<div n="lb">plur. of {#ap#}) and {#pati#}.

<L>5119<pc>187-b<k1>apAya<k2>apAya
{#apAya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Going away, passing away; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Mīm. Sūtra:%} {#anapAyaSca kAlasya lakzaRaM hi puroqASe;#} or
<div n="lb">in the {%Sāṅkhya S.%} {#pUrvApAya uttarAyogAt#} (comm. {#pUrvasya kA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRasyApAyakAla uttarasya kAryasyotpattyanOcityAt#}); comp. also
<div n="lb">the instance which follows meaning 3. <sup>2</sup> Separation, disunion;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} {#sarvatra dayitADInaM suvyaktaM rAmaRIyakam . yena#}
<div n="lb">{#jAtaM priyApAye kadvadaM haMsakokilam;#} comp. also the following
<div n="lb">instance. <sup>3</sup> Absence, disappearance; e. g. in the {%Nalodaya:%}
<div n="lb">{#tadvAsaH svApAyAM nItiriyaM ceti vipadi sasvApAyAm . ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#javAsaHsvApAyAnnikftya tAmamuYcadiha sasvApAyAm#} ‘(Nalus)
<div n="lb">thinking he acted rightly in his misery, abandoned her there
[Page188-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">(in the forest) when she was asleep, deprived of her own [in-
<div n="lb">stance to meaning 2.], her (good luck) having departed from
<div n="lb">her [instance to meaning 1.], after having torn (her garment)
<div n="lb">in the absence of garment or property of his own (comm.:
<div n="lb">{#nijaM svakIyaM yadvAsaH svaM ca DanaM tadapAyAt tadapagamAt#}); or
<div n="lb">{#saMniyogaSizwAnAmanyatarApAya uBayorapyapAyaH#} (in which {%Pa-%}
<div n="lb">{%ribh.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 4. 153. the E. I. H. Ms. No. 326. of the {%Ma-%}
<div n="lb">{%hābhāṣya%} reads however both times {#aBAva#} instead of {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAya#}); or {%Mahābhāṣya%} (introd.): {#apAyo lopaH . Gnanti Gnantu#}
<div n="lb">{#aGnan . varRApAyo nArTApAyaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Loss; e. g. in the {%Hitop.%}
<div n="lb">{#yatrApAyaH saMBavati tatropAyo'pyasti#}. <sup>5</sup> Destruction, cessa-
<div n="lb">tion; e. g. in the {%Nyāya S.%} {#duHKajanmapravfttidozamiTyAjYAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmuttarottarApAye tadanantarApAyAdapavargaH#}. <sup>6</sup> Death; e. g. in
<div n="lb">the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} {#banDUnaSaNkizwa samAkulatvAdAseduzaH snehavaSAdapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yam#}. <sup>7</sup> Misfortune, calamity, evil; e. g. in the {%Nalod.%} {#aTa#}
<div n="lb">{#tuNgopAyasya SravaRena nalasya sAnugo'pAyasya…svamano BI-#}
<div n="lb">{#maSciraM jugopa;#} (comm. {#nalasya apAyasyApakramaRasya duHKasya vA#}
<div n="lb">{#SravaRena#}). E. {#i (iR)#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>5120<pc>188-a<k1>apAyin<k2>apAyin
{#apAyin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yI-yinI-yi#}) <sup>1</sup> Going away, de-
<div n="lb">parting. <sup>2</sup> Perishing, transitory; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhya S.%}
<div n="lb">{#svaBAvasyAnapAyitvAdananuzWAnalakzaRaprAmARyam#}. E. {#i (iR)#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>5121<pc>188-a<k1>apAra<k2>apAra
{#apAra#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-ram#}) 1. The opposite bank of a river;
<div n="lb">the same as {#pAra;#} comp. also {#avAra#}. E. See s. v. {#pAra#}.
<div n="P">2. (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) <sup>1</sup> A technical term to
<div n="lb">denote that kind of mental acquiescence or indifference which
<div n="lb">arises from the reflection that sensual objects perish in con-
<div n="lb">sequence of enjoyment and that there is a feeling of pain
<div n="lb">or trouble when they perish; some call this kind of ac-
<div n="lb">quiescence {#sunetra,#} and others {#pArapAra#} (the latter word writ-
<div n="lb">ten thus in the Calc. ed. of the comm. of the {%Sāṅkhya-%}
<div n="lb">{%pravachana%} and in the E. I. H. Ms. 2668; in {%Wilson'%}s ed.
<div n="lb">of the {%Sāṅkhya-Kārikā%} {#pArApAra#}); it is among the nine
<div n="lb">kinds of acquiescence or {#tuzwi#} (q. v.) one of the five called
<div n="lb">{#vAhya#} or acquiences relating to exterior objects. [{%Wilson%}
<div n="lb">in his comment on the Kārikā (page 155) renders the literal
<div n="lb">meaning of this word ‘shoreless’, taking it therefore as a
<div n="lb">Bahuvr.; but it seems to me that the compound terms of
<div n="lb">this category, enumerated s. v. {#anuttamAmBas,#} are all Tat-
<div n="lb">pur., the simile inhering to these terms being taken from
<div n="lb">the notion of ‘water’ or ‘opposite shore’, and the dif-
<div n="lb">ferent mode in which the former is expressed ({#amBas, sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#lila, oGa, vfzwi#}) as well as the qualification conveyed by
<div n="lb">the former part of the compound terms ({#supAra, uttamAmBas#}
<div n="lb">&c.) being intended to express the higher or lower degree
<div n="lb">of the various acquiescences, none of which is conducive
<div n="lb">to final emancipation; the literal meaning of {#apAra#} would
<div n="lb">therefore be, in my opinion, ‘a bad or undesirable opposite
<div n="lb">shore’. In the list of {%Gaurapāda%} which differs from that of
<div n="lb">the other comm., the correctness of the term {#sunetra#} seems
<div n="lb">to me, for the reasons given, doubtful, unless {#netra#} is to be
<div n="lb">connected there with the sense of {#netrI#} ‘river’.] <sup>2</sup> The re-
<div n="lb">verse of the technical Sāṅkhya term {#pAra,#} i. e. <sup>a.</sup> non-ac-
<div n="lb">quiescence or not being indifferent through not reflecting
<div n="lb">that pain or trouble arises from the {%preservation%} of sensual
<div n="lb">objects when they have been acquired; or <sup>b.</sup> non-acquiescence
[Page188-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">through not reflecting that {%acquiring%} sensual objects causes
<div n="lb">trouble or pain; (the term {#pAra#} being used by {%Gaurapāda%}
<div n="lb">in the former, by {%Vāchaspati, Vijnānāchārya%} &c. in the
<div n="lb">latter sense); it is amongst the seventeen {#budDibaDa#} or ob-
<div n="lb">structions of intellect one of the nine which are the converse
<div n="lb">of the {#tuzwi#} or acquiescences. E. {#a#} 1. deter., 2. neg. and {#pAra#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Shoreless, unbounded,
<div n="lb">boundless, illimitable. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5122<pc>188-b<k1>apAraka<k2>apAraka
{#apAraka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rakaH-rikA-rakam#}) Incompetent,
<div n="lb">incapable; comp. {#apArayat#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pAraka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5123<pc>188-b<k1>apArapAra<k2>apArapAra
{#apArapAra#}¦ Tatpur. I. n. ({#-ram#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The reverse of {#pArapAra#} (see the remark s. v. {#apAra#} I. 2.),
<div n="lb">a technical term to denote the non-acquiescence or non-in-
<div n="lb">difference through not reflecting that since a sensual object
<div n="lb">perishes in consequence of enjoyment, pain or trouble arises
<div n="lb">from its cessation; it is amongst the seventeen {#budDibaDa#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">or obstructions of intellect one of the nine which are the
<div n="lb">converse of the {#tuzwi#} or acquiescences. According to others the
<div n="lb">term would be {#anapAra#} or {#asunetra#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pArapAra#}.
<div n="P">II. m. ({#-raH#}) The farthest bound of that which is illimi-
<div n="lb">table, an epithet of Viṣṇu; e. g. {#pAraM paraM vizRurapArapAraH#}
<div n="lb">{#paraM pareByaH paramArTarUpI . sa brahmapAraH parapAraBUtaH paraH parA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAmapi pArapAraH ..#}. (See the explanation of this verse by
<div n="lb">{%Wilson%} in his {%Viṣṇup.%} p. 113, note 3.) E. {#apAra#} II. and {#pAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5130<pc>188-b<k1>apArTa<k2>apArTa
{#apArTa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rTaH-rTA-rTam#}) <sup>1</sup> Purposeless, useless;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vyavahārat.%} {#mftAstu sAkziRo yatra DanikarRikale-#}

<div n="lb">deed). <sup>2</sup> Meaningless; e. g. {#apArTavAc#}. Comp. the following.
<div n="lb">E. {#apa#} and {#arTa#}.

<L>5131<pc>188-b<k1>apArTaka<k2>apArTaka
{#apArTaka#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rTakaH-rTikA-rTakam#}) The same as
<div n="lb">{#apArTa;#} <sup>1</sup> Purposeless, useless. <sup>2</sup> Disinterested, without a
<div n="lb">selfish motive; e. g. in the {%Sāṅkhyakār.%} {#nAnAviDErupAyEru-#}
<div n="lb">{#pakAriRyanupakAriRaH puMsaH . guRavatyaguRasya satastasyArTamapArTakaM#}
<div n="lb">{#carati#} (scil. {#prakftiH#}). <sup>3</sup> Meaningless; e. g. in the {%Kāśikā%} on
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇ.%} VII. 2. 58. {#tataH parasmEpadezviti niyamArTaH . sa ca niyamo#}
<div n="lb">{#yadyaviSezeRa syAtpUrvo yogo'pArTakaH syAt#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-kam#}) (In the Nyāya philos.) One of the twenty-
[Page189-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">two {#nigrahasTAna#} or failures in argument which lead to defeat
<div n="lb">in controversy; viz. speech which is incoherent from want
<div n="lb">of a causal nexus between what precedes and follows, al-
<div n="lb">though the single sentences or words, may give a sense,
<div n="lb">if taken individually; (it is different therefore from the {#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahasTAna#} which is called {#nirarTaka#} q. v.); {#‘pOrvAparyAyogAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#pratisaMbadDArTamapArTakam’#}. E. {#apa#} and {#arTa,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5132<pc>189-a<k1>apArTavAc<k2>apArTavAc
{#apArTavAc#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-k#}) Unmeaning speech, nonsensical
<div n="lb">discourse. E. {#apArTa#} and {#vAc#}.
<LEND>

<L>5133<pc>189-a<k1>apAla<k2>apAla
{#apAla#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) Unprotected; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#kA tvamekAkinI BIru niranvayajane vane . kzuDyanto'pyaGasanvyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#lAstvAmapAlAM kaTaM na vA#}.

<div n="lb">authoress of a hymn of the Ṛgveda. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pAla#}.
<LEND>

<L>5134<pc>189-a<k1>apAlaNka<k2>apAlaNka
{#apAlaNka#}¦ Tatpur. (?) m. ({#-NkaH#}) A plant (Cassia fistula).--
<div n="lb">The word is udātta on the last syllable. E.? (The {%Sid-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhāntakaum.%} in its chapter, the {#PiwsUtra,#} gives the word
<div n="lb">only in its crude form, whence the masc. gender could not
<div n="lb">be established; in the E. I. H. Ms. No. 98 of these Sūtras
<div n="lb">the comm. writes once {#apAlaNkA#} and another time {#apAlaNkaH,#}
<div n="lb">the latter being probably the correct form, to judge from the
<div n="lb">synonymes and the form {#pAlaNka#} which seems kindred to it.)
<LEND>

<L>5148<pc>189-b<k1>apASraya<k2>apASraya
{#apASraya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A support, a recipient, the
<div n="lb">person on which another reposes, as it were, by whom he
<div n="lb">is protected; e. g. {#brAhmaRApASrayo nityamutkfzwAM jAtimaSnute#}
<div n="lb">(scil. {#SUdraH#}) ‘a Śūdra who is supported by a Brahmaṇa
<div n="lb">obtains always a superior birth’; (speculation has been rife
<div n="lb">on this passage of {%Manu%} 9. 335.: both Calc. editions read
<div n="lb">{#brAhmaRAyASrayo#}--which is meaningless--, another reading
<div n="lb">is {#brAhmaRopASrayo,#} and the correctness of the word {#apASraya#}
<div n="lb">in this verse has been even doubted; but it occurs and is
<div n="lb">commented upon in the same sense ‘recipient, support’ e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Bhāgavata Pur.%} VI. 19. 12. where Viṣṇu is contrasted
<div n="lb">with Śrī:) {#tvaM hi sarvaSarIryAtmA SrIH SarIrendriyASayAH . nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#marUpe BagavatI pratyayastvamapASrayaH#} (comm. {#pratyayo nAmarUpayoH#}
<div n="lb">{#prakASaH . apASrayaH . tayorADAraH#}); i. e. ‘…thou
<div n="lb">makest them manifest and thou art their recipient or sup-
<div n="lb">port’.--Comp. also {#apASrita#}. <sup>2</sup> That which rests upon; (used
<div n="lb">in this sense {%Daśakumārach.%} ed. {%Wilson%} p. 90, 1. 13, where the
<div n="lb">word implies the meaning ‘head’ as resting on the hand).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> An awning spread over a court or yard. E. {#Sri#} with {#A#}
<div n="lb">and {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Unsupported, helpless.
<div n="lb">E. {#apa#} and {#ASraya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5154<pc>190-a<k1>apAsana<k2>apAsana

<div n="lb">a special meaning ‘carnage’ given to this word is without au-
<div n="lb">thority). E. Accord. to the commentators on the {%Amarak.%} like
<div n="lb">the former; but it seems preferable to derive the latter meaning

<L>5156<pc>190-a<k1>apAsarat<k2>apAsarat
{#apAsarat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) Going away; e. g.
<div n="lb">with the intention of defrauding, absconding: {#miTyAvadanpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rImARaM SulkasTAnAdapAsaran . dApyastvazwaguRaM yaSca savyAjakraya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vikrayI,#} (in which verse of {%Yājnav.,%} 2. 262., the Calc. 8<sup>vo</sup> ed.
<div n="lb">of the {%Vyavahāra%} section of the {%Mitākṣara%} has omitted to
<div n="lb">correct the misprint {#apAsarat#} although it is corrected in
<div n="lb">the 4<sup>to</sup> edition; the {%Vivādachint.%} (p. 81, 1. 18), however, reads
<div n="lb">in this verse {#apAkraman#} instead of {#apAsaran,#} which word
<div n="lb">would correspond in its strangeness with the quotation of
<div n="lb">the same work (p. 81, 1. 21) from {%Viṣṇu:%} {#SulkasTAnamanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kraman;#} but as the Calc. edition of {%Viṣṇu'%}s {%Sanhitā%} (fol. 3 {%a,%}
<div n="lb">1. 6) reads {#SulkasTAnamapakrAman,#} it is more likely that {#apA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kraman;#} and {#anAkraman#} are blunders of the editor than ar-
<div n="lb">chaisms of Yājnavalkya and Viṣṇu. The E. I. H. Mss. of
<div n="lb">the {%Mit.%} read {#apAsaran#}). E. {#sf#} with {#apa,#} the final vowel
<div n="lb">of the prefix being lengthened, or perhaps {#sf#} with {#A#} and
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>5158<pc>190-a<k1>apAsita<k2>apAsita
{#apAsita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Thrown about, scat-
<div n="lb">tered about. [In the insipid verse of the {%Nalodaya:%} {#vegaba-#}
<div n="lb">{#lApAsitayA veRyA BEmI yutA lalApAsitayA . nfpa sakalApA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sitayA hatvArInbAnDavAnkilApAsi tayA,#} the comm. has
<div n="lb">subjected the first compound to the following torture: it
<div n="lb">may mean according to him as an attribute of {#veRI#} ‘braided
<div n="lb">hair’: <sup>a.</sup> scattered about through the force of running (= {#DA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vanabalena vistftayA#}); or <sup>b.</sup> having lost its resting-place through
<div n="lb">the force of running (when {#apAsita#} is a Bahuvr. of {#apa#}
<div n="lb">and {#AsitA,#} the latter being {#Asin,#} taddh. aff. {#tal;#}
<div n="lb">{#= apagatA AsitA upaveSanatvaM yasyAH sA#}); or <sup>c</sup> having lost
<div n="lb">its existence through the force of running (when {#apAsita#}
<div n="lb">is a Bahuvr. of {#apa#} and {#asitA;#} the latter coming from
<div n="lb">{#asin,#} taddh. aff. {#tal; = apagatA vidyamAnatA yasyAH sA#});
<div n="lb">or not as an attribute of {#veRI#} and coming from {#vega-bala-#}
<div n="lb">{#Apa-asi,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} ‘through the effect of having a
<div n="lb">sword which possesses speed and power’; the second com-
<div n="lb">pound in this verse, viz. {#sakalApAsitayA#} is explained by
[Page190-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">him as the instrum. of {#sakala-apAsitA,#} the latter being
<div n="lb">{#apAsi#} q. v., taddh. aff. {#tal:#} ‘through all (scil. enemies)
<div n="lb">having lost their sword’.] E. {#as#} (cl. 4.) in the caus., with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5160<pc>190-b<k1>apAsta<k2>apAsta

<div n="lb">Pāli word {#apatTAni#} seems to represent rather the Sanskṛt
<div n="lb">{#apArTAni,#} then {#apAstAni#}.)--The same as {#parAsta#}. E.

<L>5161<pc>190-b<k1>apAsyat<k2>apAsyat

<L>5162<pc>190-b<k1>api<k2>api
{#api#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}). A par-
<div n="lb">ticle originally implying {%location%} and hence {%proximity,%}
<div n="lb">which, like other particles of location, then has become
<div n="lb">one implying {%emphasis.%} It is used, in some instances, as
<div n="lb">a prefex to verbs, is considered in one instance as a se-
<div n="lb">parable preposition governing a noun, but occurs more
<div n="lb">commonly as an adverb or conjunction. It forms with a
<div n="lb">following noun in a few instances Tatpur. and Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">compounds. Its older form is {#pi#} (see the Preface).
<div n="P">1. (as a {%prefix to verbs%}) <sup>1</sup> On; comp. e. g. {#DA, nah,#}
<div n="lb">{#banD#}. (In this sense it answers the cognate German or
<div n="lb">English particle be-, as in beschlagen, bestreichen, beget,
<div n="lb">bespeak &c., and passes, as other locative prefixes, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#aDi,#} into the meaning of {%much, very;%} comp. e. g. {#gF#} with
<div n="lb">{#api, apigIrRa#}.) Its older form {#pi,#} is met with esp. in
<div n="lb">this sense; comp. e. g. {#piDAna, pinadDa#}.--Before {#vf,#} in
<div n="lb">forms in which this radical preserves its vowel {#f,#} the final
<div n="lb">vowel of the prefix is lengthened in the Veda; comp. {#apI-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfta;#} equally so in the {#kvip#} derivation {#apIju#} (from {#jU#} with
<div n="lb">{#api#}). [<sup>2</sup> In; in combination with {#as#} cl. 2. ‘to be’; in
<div n="lb">the Vedas(?). As this radical is combined then with the
<div n="lb">locative, its sense remaining the same as if it were not con-
<div n="lb">nected with {#api,#} it is possible to refer {#api#} to another
<div n="lb">word of the sentence, instead of considering it as a prefix
<div n="lb">to {#as,#} in all instances in wich the radical {#s#} of {#as#} under-
<div n="lb">goes no change; but in combinations like {#api zyAt,#} it
<div n="lb">would seem necessary to look upon {#api#} as upon a prefix
<div n="lb">({#upasarga#}) if we follow {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 87. and implicitely I. 4.
<div n="lb">96.--since {#api#} is called there {#karmapravacanIya#} in other mean-
<div n="lb">ings than in that of location--; comp. also {%Kaiyyaṭa%} as
<div n="lb">quoted in the following {#yaTApiSabdasya#} &c. On the other
<div n="lb">hand, as {%Sāyaṇa%} considers also in the latter instances {#api#}
<div n="lb">not as a prefix to {#as,#} but as referring to some other word
<div n="lb">of the sentence, it must be said in favour of his opinion,
<div n="lb">that the change of {#s#} to {#z#} after preceding coloured vowels
[Page191-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">({#i, u#} &c.) takes place in many vaidik instances where it
<div n="lb">could not be justified from {%Pāṇini'%}s rules which chiefly con-
<div n="lb">cern the classical idiom (comp. e. g. as regards the radical
<div n="lb">{#as#} a combination {#api zmasi#}), that consequently in {#api#}
<div n="lb">{#zyAma#} the change of {#s#} to {#z#} might be ascribed to the in-
<div n="lb">fluence of the ultimate vowel of the {%adverb%} {#api#} in the same
<div n="lb">manner as in {#hi zWA#} ({%Sāyaṇa%} = {#BavaTa#}) to the {#i#} of {#hi#}. The
<div n="lb">combination of {#api#} and {#as#} is therefore, at least, matter
<div n="lb">of doubt, even in such cases where {#api#} immediately pre-
<div n="lb">cedes {#as,#} and still more doubtful where it is separated
<div n="lb">from it by other words.] <sup>3</sup> Near to, towards; comp. e. g.
<div n="lb">{#i, gam (apiyat, apigata);#} the commentators render it
<div n="lb">mostly in the latter instances by {#aBi#} or {#prati#}.
<div n="P">2. (as a {%separable preposition.%}) When used as such,
<div n="lb">{#api#} is considered to have no special meaning itself and the
<div n="lb">noun connected with, but not governed by, it in the geni-
<div n="lb">tive is to be rendered with the ellipsis of ‘a drop, a little’;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#sarpizo'pi syAt#} ‘there might be a drop of, or a
<div n="lb">little, clarified butter’. [This value and use of the word
<div n="lb">are stated on the authority of {%Patanjali%} (to {%Pāṇ.%} I. 4. 96.)
<div n="lb">whom it is necessary to quote here in full on account of
<div n="lb">the different interpretation given to this Sūtra by the native
<div n="lb">grammarians and perhaps, too, on behalf of the erroneous
<div n="lb">quotation {#‘yuktapadArTe’#} made elsewhere from {%Hemach.%} and
<div n="lb">the {%Med.%}--instead of {#ayuktapadArTe#}--which is apt to con-
<div n="lb">vey, if any, a totally different sense. {%Patanjali:%} {#api pa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dArTaº . iha kasmAnna Bavati . sarpizo'pi syAt . gomUtrasyApi#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt . kiM ca syAt . dvitIyApi prasajyeta karmapravacanIyayukte#}
<div n="lb">{#dvitIyeti#} ({%Pāṇ.%} II. 3. 8.) {#. nEza dozaH . neme'pyarTA nirdiSyante .#}
<div n="lb">{#kiM tarhi parapadArTA ime nirdiSyante . etezvarTezu yatpadaM vartate#}
<div n="lb">{#tatprati karmapravacanIyasaMjYo BavatIti . aTavA . yadatra karmaprava-#}
<div n="lb">{#canIyayuktaM nAdaH prayujyate . kiM punastat . vinduH . vinduostarhi#}
<div n="lb">{#kasmAnna Bavati . upapadaviBakteH kArakaviBaktirbalIyasIti pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#TamA Bavizyati ..#} {%Kaiyyaṭa%} on {%Patanjali:%} {#apiº . iheti .#}
<div n="lb">{#yaTApiSabdasya karmapravacanIyasaMjYAyAM satyAM syAdityatropasargA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SrayaM zatvaM na BavatyevaM sarpiHSabdAddvitIyA kasmAnna BavatIti praSnaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#itaro(ºrA?)BavatyevAtrApeH saMjYetyAha .. kiM ca syAditi . nema#}
<div n="lb">{#iti . yadyapiSabdArTA ime nirdiSyeran . padArTagrahaRamanarTakaM#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt . svapadArTAvyaBicArAt . saMBAvanAdInAM copAdAnama-#}
<div n="lb">{#narTakaM syAt . tezAmapi padArTatvAt .. parapadArTA iti . syA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dityAdeH parasya padasyAmI arTA ityarTaH . tadayamarTaH . syAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyAdipadaM kartfsAmAnyavAcyapi yadA sAmarTyAtkartfviSeze vindO#}
<div n="lb">{#vartate tadA tatpratyapiH karmapravacanIyaH . sarpiHSabdastu samudAya#}
<div n="lb">{#eva vartate nAvayave . ata evAvayavopajanitavyatireke zazWI Ba-#}
<div n="lb">{#vati .. aTaveti . vindukartfkatvaM kriyAyA dyotayitumapiH pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yujyata iti vinduM prati karmapravacanIyo'pirna tu sarpiH pratIti#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvaH .. vindostarhIti . nanu yadA vinduSabdo na prayujyate ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#dApiH karmapravacanIyaH . taducyate vfttikArEH . padAntarasyAprayu-#}
<div n="lb">{#jyamAnasyArTaH padArTa iti . na cAprayukte dvitIyA viDAtuM Sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kyA . atrAhuH . padArTagrahaRamihopalakzaRArTamupAttam . tena ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#sminpadArTe padAntarasyABiDAnaSaktirnAsti tatrApiH karmapravaca-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIyaH . tataSca gatArTo vinduSabdopAdAnavispazwapratipattaye pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yujyate tadApiH karmapravacanIyasaMjYo Bavati .. upapadaviBakteriti .#}
<div n="lb">{#kArakaviBaktiratra praTamA . sarvatrEva vAkye'vaSyaMBAvyaM kriyayA#}
<div n="lb">{#tataH sa tayA tatra vindoH praTamA syAdityanena saMbanDo'ntaraNgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#paScAttu tatkArako'piSabdena#} (the last sentence is rather in-
[Page191-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">correct in the E. I. H. Ms. 171, viz. {#sarvatrE vAkye'vaSyaMBAvya-#}
<div n="lb">{#kriyayAtaMtaH sa tayA tatra vidoH praTamaM smAdityanen saMbaMDotaMraMgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#paScAttu tadrArako'pi Sabdena#} sic).--To which may be added,
<div n="lb">to prevent a misunderstanding of the ellipsis {#vindu,#} from the
<div n="lb">{%Kāśikā:%} {#mAtrAvindustokamityasyArTe'piSabdo vartate#}.--It re-
<div n="lb">sults from this quotation that, according to {%Patanjali%} and
<div n="lb">{%Kaiyyaṭa%} <sup>a.</sup> the use of {#api#} in the given sense is restricted to
<div n="lb">sentences in which the word to be supplied stands in the {%nomi-%}
<div n="lb">{%native,%} no mention being made in the discussion of other cases
<div n="lb">or of an ‘&c.’, <sup>b.</sup> that the ellipsis is a word meaning ‘a little’,
<div n="lb"><sup>c.</sup> that {#api#} is Karmapr. with regard to, i. e. governing, this
<div n="lb">ellipsis, but not the genitive ({#sarpizaH#} &c.) and <sup>d.</sup> that the nomi-
<div n="lb">native of the word supplied ({#vinduH#}) results from the reason
<div n="lb">that the government required by the sentence overrules the
<div n="lb">claim of the Karmapr. But however ingenious this inter-
<div n="lb">pretation of what is, in truth, corresponding with the
<div n="lb">French ‘du beurre’ might be, it seems clear, that {#api#}
<div n="lb">cannot be considered, properly speaking, as a preposition
<div n="lb">governing a noun, but that it has in the alleged instances
<div n="lb">merely the emphatic sense or that of an expletive (see
<div n="lb">meaning 3. I.) and that {%Pāṇini'%}s rule only intended what
<div n="lb">{%Kaiyyaṭa%} remarks in the beginning and the {%Kāśikā%} at the
<div n="lb">end of the gloss on it, viz. to prevent its having the power
<div n="lb">of changing the initial {#s#} of a radical to {#z;#} {%Kāśikā:%} {#upa-#}
<div n="lb">{#sargasaMjYAbADanAtzatvaM na Bavati#}.--Quite a different and ap-
<div n="lb">parently a more simple construction has been put upon
<div n="lb">this rule by the comm. on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 8. 91., amongst whom {%Jaya-%}
<div n="lb">{%manjala%} explains the half-verse {#‘pariSezaM na nAmApi sTApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yizyati te viBuH’#} thus: {#(rAmo) viBuH praBuH . te pariSezaM nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mApi saMjYAmapi na sTApayizyati kimu deham . api padArTetyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dinA padArTe karmapravacanIyasaMjYA . padasya dehasyAprayujyamAnasyArTe#}
<div n="lb">{#'piSabdo vartate…. upasargabADanatvAtsaMjYAyA upasargAtsuno-#}
<div n="lb">{#tItyAdinA#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 65., and comp. {%Vārtt.%} 3.) {#zatvaM na#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati;#} in a similar manner {%Vidyāvinoda; Kandarpachakravar-%}
<div n="lb">{%tin,%} after having given an analogous interpretation, adds his
<div n="lb">opinion that {#api#} is in this instance an emphatic particle (comp.
<div n="lb">{#saMBAvane#} p. 192{%a,%} 1. 39) and {%Puṇḍarīkavidyāsāgara%} that it implies
<div n="lb">there the sense of {#ca;#} the {%former:%} {#pariSezameva SizwaM nAmApi saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#jYAmapi na sTApayizyati kiM punaH SarIram . atra zatvanizeDArTaM#}
<div n="lb">{#parErapeH karmapravacanIyasaMjYA kftA . svamate'peH stokArTasaMBAvane-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyAdinA saMBAvanArTAdapeH zatvaM nizidDam;#} the {%latter:…%}
<div n="lb">{#saMBAvanAgarhAmAtrezvaperupasargatvanizeDaH SrIpatinA kftaH . parEreta-#}
<div n="lb">{#darTaM karmapravacanIyasaMjYA kftA . dehena samuccayena cArTe#} &c.; comp.
<div n="lb">also {%Bharatas.:%} {#atrApiSabdena dehasya samuccayAt#} &c.; when {#padArTa#}
<div n="lb">accord. to {%Jayam.%} &c. is made to mean ‘any ellipsis (suitable
<div n="lb">to the context)’ and the sense of {#api#} would full under 3. I. A.]
<div n="P">3. (as an {%adverb%} or {%conjunction%}) it implies emphasis, either
<div n="lb">by imparting greater power to {%one%} word or by producing
<div n="lb">a stronger junction or a stronger antithesis between {%several%}
<div n="lb">words or sentences; I. {%by imparting greater power%} <sup>A.</sup> to {%one%}
<div n="lb">word in general, esp. to {%a noun;%} it is synonymous then
<div n="lb">with {#eva#} and placed in most instances after the word to
<div n="lb">which it refers, but sometimas also after a word depending
<div n="lb">on, or relating to, that to which it properly belongs, to
<div n="lb">effectuate, as it were, at the same time a stronger relation
<div n="lb">between both; e. g. {#nizWurASlIlatIvratvAttadapi#} (i. e. {#vAkpA-#}
[Page192-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#ruzyaM#}) {#triviDaM smftam;#} or {#janAnurAgeRa yuto'vasAdaH PalAnubanDaH#}
<div n="lb">{#suDiyAtmano'pi;#} or {#muktabadDayoranyatarABAvAnna tatsidDiH#} (scil.
<div n="lb">{#ISvarasya#}) {#. uBayaTApyasatkaratvam;#} or {#nyagjAtayo ratnavarEralaByA#}
<div n="lb">{#muKyAH kapInAmapi nopajapyAH#} (where {#api#} increases the
<div n="lb">power of {#muKyAH,#} but produces at the same time in {#muKyAH#}
<div n="lb">{#kapInAm,#} by being placed after the latter the effect of a
<div n="lb">stronger junction, like that of a compound {#kapimuKyAH#}).--
<div n="lb">In the same manner as the positive power of a word, if it
<div n="lb">implies, e. g. excellence &c., is rendered more prominent
<div n="lb">by {#api,#} also the negative value of a word implying ne-
<div n="lb">gation, diminution &c. becomes still more negative &c. by
<div n="lb">the same particle; thus {#muhurtamapi#} means ‘only a moment’,
<div n="lb">and {#na muhurtamapi#} ‘not even a moment’; e. g. {#kiM hi saMSaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mApanne tasminniha mayA tava . muhUrtamapyajIvantyA yannAnvezyasi rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Gavam;#} or {#nAhamenaM DanuzpARiM yuyutsuM samupasTitam . muhUrtamapi#}
<div n="lb">{#paSyeyaM prahareyaM na cApyuta;#} for the same reason it imparts to
<div n="lb">numerals the notion of {%totality%} or greater unity, e. g. {#dvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vapi#} ‘both two’, {#paYcApi#} ‘all five’ &c. <sup>B.</sup> To {%verbs;%} when
<div n="lb">imparting greater emphasis to the verbal action it is <sup>a.</sup> a
<div n="lb">particle of {%interrogation,%} although the verb would imply the
<div n="lb">same modality by itself alone, e. g. {#api BavAnkamaRqalu-#}
<div n="lb">{#pARiM CAtramadrAkzIt?#} or {#kuSalaM kOSiko rAjYaH paryapfcCatsu-#}
<div n="lb">{#DArmikaH . api te saMnatAH sarve sAmantA ripavo jitAH? ..#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> a particle of {%exclamation;%} <sup>α.</sup> in general, {%he! ho there!%} e. g.
<div n="lb">{#api vijahIhi dfQopagUhanam!;#} according to the {%Gaṇaratnam.%}
<div n="lb">it occurs combined with {#ayi,#} if the sentence is not com-
<div n="lb">pleted, e. g. {#ayyapi sAhasakAriRi!#} <sup>β.</sup> more especially it
<div n="lb">may impart to the {%imperative%} the notion of {%‘do as you please’%}
<div n="lb">({%Pāṇ.%} in the sense of {#anvavasarga,#} the same as {#kAmakArakriyA#}
<div n="lb">or {#kriyAkArakriyA#} of the Koshas), but rather with the
<div n="lb">implied meaning of ‘indifference’ than with that of a ‘kind
<div n="lb">permission’; e. g. (Sītā having told Rāvaṇa that her hus-
<div n="lb">band will entirely destroy him, continues: {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 8. 92.)
<div n="lb">{#api stuhyapi seDAsmAMstaTyamuktaM narASana#} ‘now do as you please:
<div n="lb">praise us ({%comm.%} say that I have spoken properly) or retain
<div n="lb">us: I have spoken the truth, man-eater!’; <sup>γ.</sup> to the {%potential%}
<div n="lb">or {%conditional%} (the natural value of which moods is uncertainty
<div n="lb">or insufficiency), it gives the notion of {%‘certainty’%} ({#‘vAQam’#}) or
<div n="lb">of {%‘exaggerated capacity’%} ({#saMBAvane#}), then meaning {%certainly!%}
<div n="lb">{%indeed!%} e. g. {#api kuryAt#} or {#apyaDIyIta#} ‘indeed he will do it,
<div n="lb">certainly he will study’; or {#api droRapAkaM BuYjIta#} ‘indeed he
<div n="lb">is capable to eat as much as a Drona full’; {#api siYcenmU-#}
<div n="lb">{#lasahasram#} ‘certainly he can water a thousand roots’; {#api#}
<div n="lb">{#sAkzAtpraSizyAstvaM kfcCrezvindrapurohitam#} ‘(Rāvaṇa) thou art in-
<div n="lb">deed capable of instructing the domestic priest of Indra (i. e.
<div n="lb">Vṛhaspati) when he is in need’; {#api tatra ripuH sItAM prArTayi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyata#} (conditional) {#durmatiH#} ‘surely, because (Rāvaṇa) thy enemy
<div n="lb">is wicked, he desired for Sītā; (comm. {#utApyoH samarTayoriti#}
<div n="lb">--{%Pāṇ.%} III. 3. 152.--{#. atrApi Sabdo vAQArTaH . liNgimi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttam . tasmiM~lliNgimitte kriyAtipattO#} (comp. {%Pāṇ.%} III. 3. 139.)
<div n="lb">{#satyAM BUte nityaM xN . tatra votApyorityanuvarvate#}); or it in-
<div n="lb">creases the original value of the potential by adding to it
<div n="lb">the notion of {%fear%} or {%anxiety%} ({#SaNkAyAm#}), implying then
<div n="lb">{%‘perhaps’%} ({#‘SaNkAyAm’#}); e. g. {#api cOro Bavet#} ‘there is
<div n="lb">perhaps a thief’; or of {%‘hope’%} ({#‘apekzAyAm’#}), e. g. {#api#}
<div n="lb">{#gfhlIyAM vedam#} ‘I hope I mīght master the Veda’; if the
[Page192-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">potential is used in the sense of the imperative, it may add
<div n="lb">to it the notion of {%‘contempt’%} ({#garhA#} or {#nindA#}), e. g. {#‘api#}
<div n="lb">{#stUyAdvfzalam’#} ‘let him be so mean as to praise a Śūdra’;
<div n="lb">{#DigjAlmaM devadattamapi siYcetpalARqum#} ‘shame over the
<div n="lb">wretched Devadatta, let him go and water the onion’;
<div n="lb">{#api siYceH kfSAnO tvaM darpaM mayyapi yo'BikaH#} ‘go (Rāvaṇa)
<div n="lb">and throw thy manhood into the fire, as thou art (base
<div n="lb">enough) to make love to me’; <sup>δ.</sup> when combined with the
<div n="lb">{%present%} tense, it may impart to it the notion of ‘contempt’
<div n="lb">({#garhA#}) and give it the value of any other tense, e. g. {#api#}
<div n="lb">{#tatra BavAnvfzalaM yAjayati#} ‘how wrong it is that thou makest
<div n="lb">a Śūdra perform a sacrifice’!; {#mantre jAtu vadantyajYAstvaM tA-#}
<div n="lb">{#napyanumanyase#} ‘fools sometimes tender advice; to those thou
<div n="lb">hast listened!’. <sup>C.</sup> To {%interrogatives%} (whether pronouns or
<div n="lb">interrogative particles); such words (implying doubt or un-
<div n="lb">certainty) assume with {#api#} the notion of {%indefiniteness;%}
<div n="lb">thus {#kimapi#} means ‘some one or some thing’, {#kutrApi#} or
<div n="lb">{#kvApi#} ‘somewhere’, {#kuto'pi#} ‘from somewhere, some-
<div n="lb">where’, {#kadApi#} ‘some time’, {#kaTamapi#} ‘somehow’, when
<div n="lb">{#api#} may also be added with increasing power to the in-
<div n="lb">terrogatives which have become indefinites by means of
<div n="lb">{#cit,#} e. g. {#kiMcidapi, kadAcidapi#} &c. in the same but a
<div n="lb">more emphatic sense as {#kimapi, kadApi#} &c. <sup>D.</sup> To {%particles%}
<div n="lb">or {%adverbs;%} combined with them it increases their original
<div n="lb">power; thus {#cApi, evApi, taTApi ca, api cEva, api tu#}
<div n="lb">(but on the contrary), {#apyuta, apyevam, nApi#} (not even), {#api#}
<div n="lb">{#vA#} (more seldom {#vApi;#} e. g. in the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%} {#apUrve#}
<div n="lb">{#vApi BAgitvAt;#} {%Śabara:%} {#vAapIti viparyAsena prayuktO .#}
<div n="lb">{#api vetyarTaH#}), {#BUyo'pi, punarapi, aTavApi, aTApi, aTo#}
<div n="lb">{#api#} &c., have in most instances only the meaning of {#ca,#}
<div n="lb">{#eva#} &c. but with greater emphasis.--{#api ca#} occurs often
<div n="lb">for the purpose of connecting sentences and verses loosely
<div n="lb">connected, in the same sense as {#anyacca#} (see s. v. {#anya#} 1. a.);
<div n="lb">{#api nAma#} in the beginning of sentences introduces an in-
<div n="lb">direct question and belongs therefore to 3. I. B. a., when
<div n="lb">{#nAma#} which is frequently the explanation of {#api#} in the com-
<div n="lb">mentaries, might be considered as the emphatic increase of
<div n="lb">the interrogative {#api;#} it means ‘perhaps, possibly’; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the sentence {#tataH kapInAM saMGAtA harzAdrAGavaBUtaye…#}
<div n="lb">{#samAjagmuH,#} the word {#rAGavaBUtaye#} is explained {#api nAma#}
<div n="lb">{#rAGavasya saMpatsyAditi samAjagmuH;#} in the middle of sentences
<div n="lb">{#api nAma#} has the same but more emphatic bearing as {#api#}
<div n="lb">or {#nAma#} alone; e. g. {#iti sa vinA mAnitayA jahre BEmyA nalo#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi nAmAnitayA#} (comm. {#nAma saMBAvanAyAm…DIro#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi nalaH#} &c.).--II. {#api#} {%implies emphasis by producing%}
<div n="lb">{%a stronger junction or a stronger antithesis between words or%}
<div n="lb">{%sentences;%} (when the junction or antithesis is effectuated al-
<div n="lb">ready by other conjunctions, the addition of {#api#} falls under
<div n="lb">the category of 3. I. D., but when used for this purpose
<div n="lb">alone it answers) <sup>a.</sup> {%and also, moreover, besides;%} e. g. {#da-#}
<div n="lb">{#DvAna meGavadBImamAdAya pariGaM kapiH . nedurdIptAyuDAste'pi#}
<div n="lb">{#taqitvanta ivAmbudAH;#} or {#vizayo'vizayo'pyatidUrAderhAno-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAdAnAByAmindriyasya;#} or {#trayam#} (i. e. {#DAraRADyAnasamADi-#}
<div n="lb">{#trayam#}) {#antaraNgaM pUrveByaH . tadapi vahiraNgaM nirvIjasya;#} or {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#mikzIyaM daDi kzIraM puroqASyaM taTOzaDam . havirhEyaNgavInaM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#nApyupaGnanti rAkzasAH#} (where the whole sentence is connected
[Page193-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">by means of {#api#} with a preceding one; comm. {#apiSabdaH#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvApekzayA#}). In the compressed style of the Sūtra literature
<div n="lb">{#api#} is used in this sense frequently in an elliptic manner,
<div n="lb">to indicate the omission of a word or passage to be in-
<div n="lb">ferred from the context and the junction with which it is in-
<div n="lb">tended then to effectuate; e. g. in {%Pāṇini:%} {#Candasyanekamapi#}
<div n="lb">{#sAkANkzam .#} ({%Kāśikā:%} {#Candasi vizaye . hi . ityanena yuktaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tiNNantaM sAkANkzamanekamapi nAnudAttaM Bavati . ekamapi#}); or
<div n="lb">{#anantyasyApi praSnAKyAnayoH .#} ({%Kāśikā:%} {#padasyeti vartate . sva-#}
<div n="lb">{#ritamiti ca . anantyasyApyantyasyApi padasya weH svaritaH pluto#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati praSna AKyAne ca;#} or in the {%Sāṅkhya Prav.%} {#nAnuSrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vikAdapi tatsidDiH sADyatvenAvfttiyogAdapuruzArTatvam .#} ({%Vi-%}
<div n="lb">{%jnānabhikṣu:%} {#apiSabdena na dfzwAttatsidDiriti prAguktadfzwasa-#}
<div n="lb">{#muccayaH,#} where the word {#api#} connects elliptically the quoted
<div n="lb">Sūtra (1. 82.) not with one immediately preceding but with
<div n="lb">the Sūtra 1. 2.--<sup>b.</sup> {%Therefore, consequently;%} e. g. {#smarAture#}
<div n="lb">{#cetasi labDajanmA rarAja lolo'pi guRApahAryaH…rAgaH#}
<div n="lb">(comm. {#ata eva lolaScaYcalaH . acirasTAyyapi rarAja#}). <sup>c.</sup> {%But,%}
<div n="lb">{%on the contrary;%} e. g. {#jAto nAryAmanAryAyAmAryAdAryo Bave-#}
<div n="lb">{#dguREH . jAto'pyanAryAdAryAyAmanArya iti niScayaH;#} or {%Bha-%}
<div n="lb">{%ratasena%} on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 1. 16.: {#SIlArTe kzvarabiti pare . svamate#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi#} &c. <sup>d.</sup> {%Even, though, notwithstanding;%} e. g. {#prAcakampa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dudanvantaM rAkzasAnapyatitrasta;#} or {#darSanIyatamAH paSyanstrIzu#}
<div n="lb">{#divyAsvapi striyaH . prApto vyAlatamAnvyasyanBujaMgeByo'pi rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzasAn;#} or {#mfduBirapi biBeda puzpavARErjalaSiSirErapi mA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rutErdadAha…madanaH;#} or {#jalaniDimagamat…salilasamuda-#}
<div n="lb">{#yErmahAtaraNgErBuvanaBarakzamamapyaBinnavelam;#} or {#yasyAM vAsayate sI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAM kevalaM sma ripuH smarAt . na tvarocayatAtmAnaM caturo vfdDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnapi#} (instead of {#caturo'pi vfº#}); frequently used in this
<div n="lb">sense with the absolute locative; e. g. {#maDyamaviveke'pi sati#}
<div n="lb">{#puruze bADitAnAmapi duHKAdInAM prArabDavaSAtpratibimbarUpeRa#}
<div n="lb">{#puruze'nuvfttyA Bogo Bavati#}. <sup>e.</sup> In {%correlate sentences;%} {#api#}
<div n="lb">added to the correlate word of the second sentence or to
<div n="lb">both, the relative and the correlative in either sentence,
<div n="lb">produces a stronger reciprocity between both, than would
<div n="lb">exist if it were omitted; e. g. {#yad…tadapi#} (more em-
<div n="lb">phatic than {#yad--tad#}): {#ye sUryamupatizWante mantrEH saMDyAtrayaM#}
<div n="lb">{#dvijAH . rakzoBistApitAste'pi sidDiM DyAyanti te'DunA;#}
<div n="lb">or {#yadA…tato'pi#} (more emphatic than {#yadA…tataH#}),
<div n="lb">e. g. {#yadAyaM brAhmaRaH prasaMKyAne'pyakusIdastato'pi na kiM-#}
<div n="lb">{#citprArTayate;#} or {#yaTA…evamapi#} (more emphatic than
<div n="lb">{#yaTA…evam#}), e. g. {#anvayAdiviBinnAnAM yaTA saKyamanI-#}
<div n="lb">{#psitam . nEzIrviroDamapyevaM sArDaM puruzavAnarEH;#} or {#yatrApi…#}
<div n="lb">{#tatrApi#} (more emphatic than {#yatra…tatra#}), e. g. {#yatrApi saMBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vastatrApi pratigrahapApAdyutTaduHKAvaSyakatvam;#} &c. &c. An anti-
<div n="lb">thesis of frequent occurrence is that of {#yadyapi…taTApi#}
<div n="lb">{%‘although…nevertheless’,%} e. g. {#praDAnasya svata eva sfzwiryadya-#}
<div n="lb">{#pi taTApi parArTamanyasya BogApavargArTam;#} or {#garuqAnilatigma-#}
<div n="lb">{#raSmayaH patatAM yadyapi saMmatA jave . acireRa kftArTamAgataM ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#mamanyanta taTApyatIva te;#} an instance where the whole sen-
<div n="lb">tence is to be supplied and merely indicated by {#taTApi#} is
<div n="lb">the following: {#taTApi vaktuM prasaBaM yatante yanmadviDAH sidDima-#}
<div n="lb">{#BIpsavastvAm . vilomacezwaM vihitAvahAsAH parErhi tatsneha-#}
<div n="lb">{#mayEstamoBiH#} (comm. {#yadyapi tvamevaMviDastaTApi#} &c.); or
<div n="lb">{#daRqena kozeRa ca manyase cetprakfzwamAtmAnamarestaTApi . ri-#}
<div n="lb">{#ktasya pUrRena vfTA vinASaH pUrRasya BaNge vahu hIyate tu#} ‘if
[Page193-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">thou considerest thyself superior to the enemy through
<div n="lb">strength and wealth, nevertheless (scil. that is wrong), for
<div n="lb">&c. (comm. {#taTApyevamapi na yuktam . yato riktasya#} &c.).--
<div n="lb">Correlate sentences the first of which contains {#api#} and
<div n="lb">the second a negation, answer our {%‘rather…than’;%} e. g.
<div n="lb">{#icCantyaBIkzRaM kzayamAtmano'pi na jYAtayastulyakulasya lakzmIm;#}
<div n="lb">or {#OzRyaM tyajenmaDyagato'pi BAnuH SEtyaM niSAyAmaTavA hi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAMSuH . anarTamUlaM BuvanAvamAnI manye na mAnaM piSitASinATa;#}
<div n="lb">or {#api vAhaM BfSaM dIptaM praviSeyaM hutASanam . spfSeyaM rAGavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyaM padApi puruzaM na hi.--#}
<div n="P">4. (in composition with nouns, in a few instances) <sup>a.</sup> Tat-
<div n="lb">pur. <sup>1</sup> {%near to;%} comp. {#apikakza, apiSarvara#}. <sup>2</sup> {%Again, re-;%} comp
<div n="lb">{#apikakzya#}. (In Tatpur. where it is {#upapada,#} e. g. in {#apigata,#}
<div n="lb">it retains the meaning which it has as prefix to the radical.)
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> Bahuvr. <sup>1</sup> {%moreover, besides, also;%} comp. {#apInasa#}. <sup>2</sup> {%Simi-%}
<div n="lb">{%lar, same;%} comp. {#apivrata#}. E. The etym. of a comm. on the
<div n="lb">{%Amarak.%} {#a#} neg. and {#pi#} (from {#pi#} to go, kṛt aff. {#kvip#})
<div n="lb">is not only improbable, but grammatically impossible. See
<div n="lb">the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>5163<pc>193-b<k1>apikakza<k2>apikakza
{#apikakza#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kzaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> The place near the arm-
<div n="lb">pits; when applied to horses, the part near the shoulder
<div n="lb">where the saddle is put (= {#paryARadeSaH#}). <sup>2</sup> A proper name;
<div n="lb">m. pl. ({#-kzAH#}) his descendants. E. {#api#} and {#kakza#}.
<LEND>

<L>5164<pc>193-b<k1>apikakzya<k2>apikakzya
{#apikakzya#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-kzyam#}) (ved.) A ligature or bandage
<div n="lb">for rejoining with the {#kakza#} (which word seems to mean in
<div n="lb">this case, {%shoulder%}) scil. the head. This word occurs in
<div n="lb">the {%Ṛgv.%} I. 117. 22., where the mystic science given by Da-
<div n="lb">dhyach to the Aśvins as a reward for having replaced his
<div n="lb">head, when it was cut off, with a horse's head, is called
<div n="lb">or likened to, a bandage, because, as {%Sāyaṇa%} interprets,
<div n="lb">it became the means by which the cut-off head was rejoined
<div n="lb">with the shoulder part. E. {#api#} and {#kakzya#}.
<LEND>

{#apikarRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rRam#}) (ved.) The part near the ear;
<div n="lb">{#apikarRe#} ‘near the ear’. E. {#api#} and {#karRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5172<pc>193-b<k1>apija<k2>apija
{#apija#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The name or epithet of several di-
<div n="lb">vinities in the {%Vājasaneyi-Sanhitā:%} <sup>1</sup> of Prajāpati, when in-
<div n="lb">voked at the third Sruvāhuti or ladle-oblation in the Vā-
<div n="lb">japeya sacrifice, (explained then by {%Mahīdhara%} as meaning
<div n="lb">‘born again and again’); <sup>2</sup> of the month Jyeṣṭha (May--
<div n="lb">June), when invoked at the Nāmagrahahoma, which forms
<div n="lb">part of the {#agnicayana#} q. v., (according to {%Mahīdhara%} meaning
[Page194-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">then liter. ‘born in the water’, on account of the water-
<div n="lb">sports which take place in that month); <sup>3</sup> of one of the
<div n="lb">{#annADISa#} q. v. in the {#annahoma#} q. v. (meaning perhaps then
<div n="lb">the same as 1.). E. <sup>1</sup> {#jan#} with {#api,#} kṛt aff. {#qa;#} <sup>2</sup> {#api,#} lo-
<div n="lb">cat. of {#ap,#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>5193<pc>194-b<k1>apivrata<k2>apivrata

<div n="lb">with the sacrificer, i. e. a relative, a man of the same fa-
<div n="lb">mily (or according to {%Harisvāmin,%} such relatives as hold
<div n="lb">and manage their inherited property jointly, not dividing it
<div n="lb">in severalty among themselves). E. {#api#} and {#vrata#}.
<LEND>

<L>5194<pc>194-b<k1>apiSarvara<k2>apiSarvara
{#apiSarvara#}¦ Tatpur. (ved.) 1. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Near the
<div n="lb">night, connected with the time near the night.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> The beginning of the night. ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
<div n="lb">{#rAtrImuKam;#} thus explained by him in the {%Ṛgv.%} verse {#tvAM#}
<div n="lb">{#yadagne paSavaH samAsate samidDamapiSarvare#}.) <sup>2</sup> The end of the
<div n="lb">night ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#gatarAtrakAlaH;#} thus explained by him in the
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.%} verse {#mama prapitve apiSarvare#} &c. where it is opposed
<div n="lb">to the time of sunrise, midday and evening.) The word
<div n="lb">occurs only in the locative sing. but is probably a masc.
<div n="lb">like the Tatpur. {#pUrvarAtra, maDyarAtra#} &c. with the ellipsis of
<div n="lb">{#kAla#}. E. {#api#} and {#SarvarI,#} probably with samās. aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>5201<pc>194-b<k1>apIjU<k2>apIjU
{#apIjU#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jUH-jUH-ju#}) (ved.) Urging on, im-
<div n="lb">pelling; an epithet of Dawn and Night. The word is no-
<div n="lb">ticed in the {%Ṛgv. Prātiśākhya%} on account of the lengthening
<div n="lb">of the middle syllable. E. {#jU#} with {#api#} (becoming {#apI#}
<div n="lb">v. s. v. {#api#} 1. 1.), kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>5204<pc>194-b<k1>apIta<k2>apIta

<L>5206<pc>195-a<k1>apIti<k2>apIti
{#apIti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Hostile encounter, battle; used
<div n="lb">so in the {%Ṛgv.:%} {#purA yatsUrastamaso apItestamadrivaH PaligaM#}
<div n="lb">{#hetimasya#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#saMgrAmAt#}). <sup>2</sup> Union, junction, used
<div n="lb">in this sense in the {%Māṇḍukya Upanishad,%} when the {#m#} of
<div n="lb">the word {#om#} is spoken of allegorically, as combining
<div n="lb">with the {#a#} and {#u#}. <sup>3</sup> Copulation; in this sense occurring
<div n="lb">in an allegorical description of the {%Śatapathabr.%} when thumbs
<div n="lb">and fingers, ears and eye-brows, lips and nose, teeth and
<div n="lb">tongue &c. are likened to man and wife. <sup>4</sup> Final liberation;
<div n="lb">in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#tadApIteH saMsAravyapadeSAt;#} {%Śaṅkara:%}
<div n="lb">{#tatteja AdiBUtasUkzmaM SrotrAdikaraRASrayaBUtamApIterA saMsAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#mokzAtsamyagjYAnanimittAdavatizWate#}. <sup>5</sup> Destruction or end of
<div n="lb">the Universe; in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#apItO tadvatprasaNgAdasama-#}
<div n="lb">{#Yjasam;#} {%Śaṅkara:%} {#yadi sTOlyasAvayavatvAcetanatvaparicCinnatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SudDyAdiDarmakaM kAryaM brahmakAraRakamaByupagamyeta tadApItO pralaye#}
<div n="lb">{#prati saMsfjyamAnaM kAryaM#} &c.; {%Anūpanārāy.:%} {#jagadupAdAnaM brahme-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyasamaYjasam . yaTA nimbayogAddugDaM tiktaM tadvadapItO pralaye#}
<div n="lb">{#svalInajagadyogAttajjAqyAdiprasaNgAt#}. [The three first mean-
<div n="lb">ings are applications of the liter. meaning ‘going towards,
<div n="lb">approaching’; the two latter of the meaning ‘going into’
<div n="lb">scil. of the world into Brahman, or perhaps also of the first
<div n="lb">viz. joining Brahman.] E. {#i#} with {#api,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5207<pc>195-a<k1>apInasa<k2>apInasa
{#apInasa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-saH#}) (In Medicine.) A cold; considered
<div n="lb">by {%Suśruta%} as a disease of the nose, and defined ‘as a
<div n="lb">disorder produced by a derangement of air and phlegm,
<div n="lb">when the nose is obstructed, painful, very hot and wet
<div n="lb">(dirty) and the patient can neither smell nor taste, nor has
<div n="lb">an appetite, the other symptoms being the same as those
<div n="lb">of catarrh ({#pratiSyAya#})’. Also {#pInasa#}. E. {#api#} (become {#apI#})
<div n="lb">and {#nas,#} ādeśa of {#nAsikA,#} samās. aff. {#ac;#} (it is difficult
<div n="lb">to imagine what {%Bhānudīkṣita%} might have thought, when
<div n="lb">be invented the following E. of {#pInasaH pi-na#} and {#sa,#} from
<div n="lb">{#so#} or {#sE,#} kṛt aff. {#ka; pIrna syati sAyati vA . zo'ntakarmaRi#}
<div n="lb">{#zE kzaye vA . Ato'nupeti#}--{%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 3.--{#kaH#}).
<LEND>

<L>5210<pc>195-a<k1>apIvyadarSana<k2>apIvyadarSana
{#apIvyadarSana#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Of very beautiful
<div n="lb">appearance. In the two verses of the {%Bhāgav. Purāna%} (1.
<div n="lb">12. 8.): {#dadarSa puruzaM…. aNguzWamAtramamalaM sPuratpurawamOli-#}
<div n="lb">{#nam . apIvyadarSanaM SyAmaM taqidvAsasamacyutam#} (comm. {#apIº#}
<div n="lb">{#= atisundaraM dfSyata iti darSanaM rUpaM yasya tam#}), and (3.
<div n="lb">28. 17.) {#apIvyadarSanaM SaSvatsarvalokanamaskftam#} &c. (epithets of
<div n="lb">Viṣṇu; comm. {#apIº = atisundaraM BaktivizayaM darSanaM yasya#}),
<div n="lb">the Bombay edition reads in the text as well as in the
[Page195-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">comm. {#apIcyadarSanaM;#} but the scrupulous care which distin-
<div n="lb">guishes {%Bournouf'%}s edition of this Purāṇa leaves no doubt
<div n="lb">that his reading {#apIvyaº#} has been adopted on account of
<div n="lb">better evidence; it is supported, too, by the quotation of
<div n="lb">the latter verse, in the valuable dictionary of {%Rādhākānta-%}
<div n="lb">{%deva.%} E. {#apIvya#} and {#darSana#}.

<L>5218<pc>195-b<k1>aputra<k2>aputra
{#aputra#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-traH#}) One who is not a son. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#putra#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-traH-trA#}) Sonless; one who has either
<div n="lb">had no son or lost his (her) son or sons ({#aputro'jAtaputro mfta-#}
<div n="lb">{#putro vA#}) and is legally held to adopt one ({%Atri:%} {#aputreREva#}
<div n="lb">{#kartavyaH putrapratiniDiH sadA . piRqodakakriyAhetoryasmAttasmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tprayatnataH#}). {%Manu%} uses the term also impliedly of a man
<div n="lb">who has no son by a woman of the three first classes,
<div n="lb">although he may have a son by a Śūdrā woman, as re-
<div n="lb">sults from this verse: {#yadyapi syAttu satputro yadyaputro'pi vA#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavet . nADikaM daSamAddadyAcCUdrAputrAya DarmataH#} (and {%Vṛ-%}
<div n="lb">{%haspati%} employs in a similar manner the term {#anapatya,#} viz.
<div n="lb">{#anapatyasya SuSrUzurguRavAYCUdrayonijaH . laBetAjIvanaM SezaM sapi-#}
<div n="lb">{#RqAH samavApnuyuH#}); when {%Jīmūtavāhana%} moreover observes
<div n="lb">that the son of a Śūdrā in this verse applies to the legiti-
<div n="lb">mate son, the Pāraśava (q. v.) being the son of a Brāhmana
<div n="lb">by a Śūdrā not wedded to him ({#yaccAha manuH . yaM brAhmaRastu#}
<div n="lb">{#SUdrAyAM#} &c. {%Manu%} 9. 178. {#. tadapariRItaSUdrAsutABiprAyam;#}
<div n="lb">contrary to {%Kullūka%} who defines him as {#pariRItAyAmeva#}
<div n="lb">{#SUdrAyAM brAhmaRaH kAmAdyaM putraM janayet#} &c.).--A wife who
<div n="lb">has no son must be approached for the sake of getting one
<div n="lb">by her brother-in-law or by one of her relatives of the
<div n="lb">Sapiṇḍa class.--Although {%Likhita%} places a man who has
<div n="lb">no son in the same category with an impious man, a usurer
[Page196-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">and a Śūdra, when he inflicts a fast of three days on any
<div n="lb">one who eats the food of such a person ({#BuktvA vArDuzika-#}
<div n="lb">{#syAnnamavratasyAsutasya ca . SUdrasya ca taTA BuktvA trirAtraM syAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bojanam#}), the present edition of {%Pāṇini%} gives {#aputra#} in a
<div n="lb">{%Gaṇa%} (to VIII. 1. 67.) as a {%honorific%} term when it is the first
<div n="lb">part of a {%Karmadh.%} (the latter part of such a compound
<div n="lb">being anudātta); but on the other hand, as {#aputra#} is one of
<div n="lb">the thirty-four nativities from the knowledge of which
<div n="lb">{%Śākyamuni%} derives a special name (comp. {#catustriMSajjAta-#}
<div n="lb">{#kajYa#}), it would seem that the word in this sense belongs
<div n="lb">rather to the Buddhistic than to the Brāhmanic literature;
<div n="lb">compare e. g. the Pāli word aputtakaseṭṭhī, in {%Fansböll'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Dhammapadam%} p. 415. The {%Kāśikā%} does not mention {#aputra#}
<div n="lb">in the {%Gaṇa%} alluded to. E. {#a#} priv. and {#putra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5219<pc>196-a<k1>aputraka<k2>aputraka
{#aputraka#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-trakaH-trikA-trikam#}) Sonless; the
<div n="lb">same as {#aputra#} II. For the Tatpur. {#aputrikA#} which is of a
<div n="lb">different Etym. see s. v. E. {#a#} priv. and {#putra,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5220<pc>196-a<k1>aputratA<k2>aputratA
{#aputratA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Sonlessness, e. g. {#na ha va asyAputratAyE kA#}
<div n="lb">{#cana SaNkA Bavati#}. E. {#aputra,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<L>5221<pc>196-a<k1>aputrapOtra<k2>aputrapOtra
{#aputrapOtra#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. ({#-traH-trA#}) Without either a son or
<div n="lb">a son of a son (the latter in contradistinction from a son
<div n="lb">of a daughter); e. g. {#aputrapOtre saMtAne#} (v. 1. {#saMsAre#}) {#dOhitrA#}
<div n="lb">{#DanamApnuyuH#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#putra-pOtra#} (Dwandwa).
<LEND>

<L>5222<pc>196-a<k1>aputrayozit<k2>aputrayozit
{#aputrayozit#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-t#}) A wife who has borne no son;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#aputrayozitaScEzAM#} (scil. {#anDapaNgvAdInAM#}) {#BartavyAH sADu-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfttayaH#}. E. {#aputra#} and {#yozit#}.
<LEND>

<L>5223<pc>196-a<k1>aputrikA<k2>aputrikA
{#aputrikA#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-kA#}) A daughter who is not {#putrikA#}
<div n="lb">i. e. who is not appointed by her father, on failure of a
<div n="lb">son, to raise up male issue for him, for the purpose of
<div n="lb">performing his obsequies; e. g. {#putrikOrasayoH samo DanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DikAraH . aputrikAyAstUQAyAH putrAdinyUnopakArakasvaputradvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#reRopakArakatvam#}. (Not to be confounded with the Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">{#aputrikA,#} fem. of {#aputraka#} q. v.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#putrikA#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. ({#-kaH#}) A father who has left no daughter
<div n="lb">appointed by him to be a {#putrikA#} q. v.--{%Jīmūtavāhana%} ex-
<div n="lb">plains in a verse of {%Devala%} which treats of the succession
<div n="lb">of daughters when the father leaves no widow: {#kanyAByaSca#}
<div n="lb">{#piturdravyAddeyaM vEvAhikaM vasu . aputrikasya kanyA svA DarmajA#}
<div n="lb">{#putravadBavet,#} the word {#putrikA#} as {%implying%} the meaning ‘son’:
<div n="lb">{#putrikApadaM putropalakzaRam#} when the verse would have to be
<div n="lb">rendered: ‘to unmarried daughters a nuptial portion must
<div n="lb">be given out of the estate of the father; of a father who
<div n="lb">has no {#putrikA#} in the place of a son, his own daughter (i. e.
<div n="lb">one of the same caste) lawfully begotten must be considered
<div n="lb">like a son (i. e. be entitled to the inheritance); the same
<div n="lb">sense is conveyed by {%Parāśara'%}s words: {#aputrasya mftasya ku-#}
<div n="lb">{#mArI rikTaM gfhlIyAt#} ({%Dāyabh.%} p. 271, {%Dāyakramas.%} p. 4,
<div n="lb">{%Vīramitrod.%} p. 204 a. with the v. 1. {#aputramftasya#}), and by the
<div n="lb">quotation of the {%Dāyakramas.%} p. 4: {#aputrasya ca svA kanyA#}
<div n="lb">{#DarmajA putravadDaret#} (which seems to have been the reading
<div n="lb">of {%Colebrooke%} when he translates in his Digest vol. III. p. 491.
<div n="lb">CCCCXX: ‘and his own daughter…shall {%take%} &c.’. But
<div n="lb">the more precise bearing of {%Devala'%}s clause is conveyed by
<div n="lb">a verse of {%Vṛhaspati%} which is to the same effect, viz. {#sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dfSI sadfSenoQA sADvI SuSrUzaRe ratA . kftAkftA vAputrasya#}
<div n="lb">{#piturDanaharI tu sA#} ({%Dāyabh.%} p. 273, {%Dāyakramas.%} p. 4, {%Vīra-%}
[Page196-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%mitr.%} p. 204{%b, Colebr. Dig.%} III. p. 186. CCXXIV. 2.); for he in-
<div n="lb">troduces there the terms {#kftA#} and {#akftA#} which apply only
<div n="lb">to a {#putrikA#} either appointed by a plain declaration or by
<div n="lb">an implied intention ({%Manu%} 9. 136., {%Dig.%} III. 164. CCVII) and
<div n="lb">the author of the {%Smṛtichandrikā%} (accord. to the {%Vīramitrod.%}
<div n="lb">p. 205 {%a%}) infers from this verse that the {#putrikA,#} whether
<div n="lb">{#kftA#} or {#akftA,#} precedes in succession the wife of the de-
<div n="lb">ceased, who herself precedes the daughter qualified by the four
<div n="lb">epithets {#sadfSI…ratA,#} viz. {#sadfSI sadfSenoQeti prAkpaWitaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vfhaspativacanaM smfticandrikAkAra itTaM vyAcaKyO . atrAdyAni#}
<div n="lb">{#catvAri viSezaRAni patnyA UrDvamarTagrAhiRIduhitfvizayARi .#}
<div n="lb">{#tataH prAgDanagrAhiRIduhitfviSezaRe dve avaSizwe . kftAkftA ve-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyatra putriketi viSezyADyAhAraH . itaratra duhiteti viSezyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DyAhAraH . vASabdaSca vyavasTitavikalpArTaH . evaM cAyamarTaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#OrasaputravihInasya piturDanaM dviviDApi putrikA patnyAH pUrvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#gfhlIyAt . savarRAdiviSezaRopetA tu duhitA tata UrDvamiti#}.
<div n="lb">Now as the regular line of succession is in the first rank
<div n="lb">a son, then on failure of him the widow, and on failure
<div n="lb">of her the daughter &c. (comp. {%Dig.%} III. p. 489. CCCCXVII)
<div n="lb">and as a {#putrikA#} is equal in right to a son ({%Kullūka%} on
<div n="lb">{%Manu%} 9. 130. and comp. 9. 127.), the word {#aputrikasya#} of {%De-%}
<div n="lb">{%vala,%} it is true, coincides in legal value with the word {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#putrasya#} of {%Parāśara%} &c., but on the other hand it is clear
<div n="lb">that the former is a more precise expression than the latter,
<div n="lb">since an {#aputrika#} will always be an {#aputra,#} but an {#aputra#}
<div n="lb">may not be an {#aputrika#}. (The Pandit who has supplied the
<div n="lb">notes to Colebrooke's Digest denies the necessity of the
<div n="lb">former part of this inference (vol. III. p. 188), for a father
<div n="lb">may, in his opinion, appoint his daughter even if he has a
<div n="lb">son, yet his argument is not founded on the law-authorities,
<div n="lb">but on a precedent mentioned in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%} (4. 1. 2.)
<div n="lb">where Manu appoints his daughter Ākūti as {#putrikA,#} when
<div n="lb">giving her in marriage to Ruchi, although she had brothers.)
<div n="lb">{%Jīmūtavāhana'%}s gloss is therefore not to be rendered ‘{#putrikA#}
<div n="lb">{%means%}’, but ‘{#putrikA#} {%implies%} the meaning son’, when the
<div n="lb">concordance between the quoted authorities becomes com-
<div n="lb">plete. As {%Colebrooke%} has probably translated the reading
<div n="lb">{#aputrasya ca svA kanyA#} &c., mentioned before, he has no re-
<div n="lb">mark on the difficulty conveyed by the reading {#aputrikasya#}
<div n="lb">(but comp. vol. III. p. 493. 1. 38 ff.).--[A conjecture has
<div n="lb">been proposed to read {#aputrakasya#} instead of the latter
<div n="lb">word; but as it is advanced without any argument what-
<div n="lb">ever, and is in the teeth of {%Jīmūtavāhana'%}s gloss which is
<div n="lb">misunderstood in rendering {#aputrika#} ‘sonless’, it seems
<div n="lb">merely to proceed from a gratuitous trifling with the text.]
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} priv. and {#putrikA#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{#kAra#}.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#punar#}.
