<L>5231<pc>197-a<k1>apuruzArTa<k2>apuruzArTa
{#apuruzArTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rTaH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.)
<div n="lb">A religious act which is not performed on account of the
<div n="lb">gratification of the sacrificer, but because it is essential to
<div n="lb">the sacrifice itself; see {#kratvarTa#}. <sup>2</sup> (In the Sāṅkhya philos.)
<div n="lb">Not the chief object of the Soul; occurring in the Sūtras
<div n="lb">in its abstract deriv. {#apuruzArTatva;#} e. g. {#apuruzArTatvamuBayaTA#}
<div n="lb">‘in neither way is (nihilism) the chief end of the Soul’; or
<div n="lb">{#nAnuSrAvikAdapi tatsidDiH sADyatvenAvfttiyogAdapuruzArTatvam#}
<div n="lb">‘the accomplishment thereof (i. e. of liberation) does not
<div n="lb">arise, moreover, from scriptural means, for since trans-
<div n="lb">migration is connected with the result (of religious acts,
<div n="lb">the performance of such acts) is not the chief object of the
<div n="lb">Soul’; or {#suKalABABAvAdapuruzArTatvamiti cenna dvEviDyAt#} ‘if
<div n="lb">you reason that, since there is no such a thing as obtain-
<div n="lb">ing happiness, (final liberation as the absence of pain) is not
<div n="lb">the chief object of the Soul, you are wrong, for its object
<div n="lb">is twofold (viz. obtaining happiness and not having pain)’.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#puruzArTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5235<pc>197-a<k1>apuzwa<k2>apuzwa
{#apuzwa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not nourished, not fat,
<div n="lb">lean. <sup>2</sup> (In Rhetoric.) Irrelevant, unassisting (as a word);
<div n="lb">irrelevancy is one of the 22 {#arTadoza#} q. v.; in the sentence
<div n="lb">e. g. {#‘vilokya vitate vyomni viDuM muYca ruzaM priye’,#} the word
<div n="lb">{#vitate#} is {#apuzwa,#} since the expansion of the sky is there ir-
<div n="lb">relevant for causing the cessation of anger. <sup>3</sup> Not loud, not
<div n="lb">violent; as crying. <sup>4</sup> (In Music.) Tenour (?); one of the
<div n="lb">five modifications of breath in its passage from the navel
<div n="lb">upwards, according to the native theory, which is thus ex-
<div n="lb">pressed in the {%Saṅgītadarpaṇa:%} {#brahmagranTisTitaM prARaM sa prera-#}
<div n="lb">{#yati pAvakaH . pAvakapreritaH so'Ta kramAdUrDvapaTe caran . a-#}
<div n="lb">{#tisUkzmaM DvaniM nABO hfdi sUkzmaM gale punaH . puzwaM SIrze tvapuzwaM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#kftrimaM vadane taTA . AvirBAvayatyevaM paYcaDA kIrtyate buDEH .#}
<div n="lb">{#kaTaM kaRWasTitaH puzwaH syAdapuzwaH SiraHsTitaH . ucyate tatra Si-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasi saMcAryArohivarRayoH . saMBUtirna BavedyasmAdapuzwaH Sirasi#}
<div n="lb">{#sTitaH . nakAraM prARanAmAnaM dakAramanalaM viduH . jAtaH prARA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gnisaMyogAttena nAdo'BiDIyate#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#puzwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5246<pc>197-b<k1>apUpa<k2>apUpa
{#apUpa#}¦ Tatpur. (?) m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> A cake of flour, meal &c.; comp.
<div n="lb">{#yavApUpa, guqApUpa, tilApUpa, vrIhyapUpa;#} (it is not an {#annavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAra#} q. v. according to the best authorities; but it would
<div n="lb">seem to be one, if the definition of a medical dictionary is
<div n="lb">correct: ‘a kind of light, rich and sweet cake’); used also
<div n="lb">of the {#puroqASa,#} e. g. in the {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vājas.%} verse: {#yaste#}
<div n="lb">{#adya kfRavadBadraSoce'pUpaM deva Gftavantamagne;#} or in the {%Mīmānsā%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra:%} {#akriyA vApUpahetutvAt;#} comp. also {#apUpavat#}. <sup>2</sup> Wheat
<div n="lb">(according to a medical dictionary, a {%large kind%} of wheat).
<div n="lb">Also {#pUpa#}. E. Probably a contraction of {#apavApa#} ({#vap#} with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}); the native comm. propose various im-
<div n="lb">probable etym. which are thus exhibited in the {%Śabdamukta-%}
<div n="lb">{%mahārṇava:%} {#pUY pavane . asmAtsaMpadAditvAtkvip#} ({%Pāṇ.%} III.
<div n="lb">3. 108. V. 9.) {#pavanaM pUH . na pUH apUH . apUpapadAtpAnArTAdrakza-#}
<div n="lb">{#RArTAdvA pADAtorAto'nupasarga iti kaH#} ({%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 3.) {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#to lopa iti#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 4. 64.) {#AkAralopaH . apuvaM pAti pi-#}
<div n="lb">{#bati vetyapUpaH . yadvA . pUyI viSaraRe asmAdvAhulakAtpaH .#} (comp.
<div n="lb">{%Uṇnādis.%} 3. 23 ff.) {#lopo vyorvalIti#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 66.) {#yalopaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#na pUyyata iti vigrahaH#} (these are the proposals of {%Bhānud.%}) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#mukuwastu . uktaDAtornopAdayaSceti papratyayamAha . tadapARinI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yam .. aTavA . wuvapa vIjasaMtAne . apSabdopapadAdasmAdGaYYarTe#}
<div n="lb">{#kaH . yajAditvAdvacisvapIti#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 15.) {#saMprasAraRam .#}
<div n="lb">{#anyezAmapIti#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 137.) {#dIrGaH . Apa upyante'treti#}
<div n="lb">{#vigrahaH#} (when the word would be a Bahuvr. of {#ap#} and
<div n="lb">{#Upa#} instead of {#upa;#} but even if such an {#upa#} existed, the
<div n="lb">word would then not be {#apUpa,#} but {#abUpa#}).
<LEND>

<L>5247<pc>197-b<k1>apUpamaya<k2>apUpamaya
{#apUpamaya#}¦ 1. m. ({#-yaH#}) Much cake, plenty of cake.
<div n="P">2. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yI-yam#}) Principally consisting of,
<div n="lb">having or containing much, cake. [Both meanings result
<div n="lb">from the different interpretation of the commentators on
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 21; in the first meaning the gender must be that
[Page198-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">of {#apUpa#}. {%Prauḍhamanor.:%} {#praTamAntAtprakfte dyotye pratyayaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#svArTikatvAtprakftito liNgam;#} but {%Bhaṭṭojid.'%}s opinion is at
<div n="lb">the same time, that with this first interpretation of the affix
<div n="lb">the word {#tat#} in the {%Sūtra%} of {%Pāṇini%} becomes meaningless:
<div n="lb">{#‘asminpakze tadgrahaRaM vyarTam’,#} and he gets somewhat out of
<div n="lb">temper when he speaks of an interpretation like that of the
<div n="lb">{%Kāśikā%} which tries to make it plausible: ({%Kāśikā:%} {#taditi#}
<div n="lb">{#praTamA samarTaviBaktiH . prAcuryeRa prastutaM prakftam . taditi praTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mA samarTAtprakftopADike'rTe vartamAnAtsvArTe mayawpratyayo#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati#}) viz. {#yattu prAcoktaM taditi praTamA samarTAtprAcuryeRa#}
<div n="lb">{#prastutamatretyarTe mayaw syAditi . yacca vyAcaKyuH . prAcuryeRetyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dipratyayArTaviSezaRamiti . tatredaM vaktavyam . vAcyArTatyAgAnnyUna-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA . aDikaraRasya kriyAsAkANkzatvena tadaDyAhAre gOravaM ceti#}
<div n="lb">{#mUle dozaH . wIkAyAM tu prakftyarTe'tivaktavye pratyayArTe'tyuktiH .#}
<div n="lb">{#raBasakftA AkaravirudDA cetyAstAM tAvat#}.] E. {#apUpa,#} taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#mayaw#}.

<L>5259<pc>198-a<k1>apUrva<k2>apUrva<h>1
I. {#apUrva#}¦ 1. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rvaH-rvA-rvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not preceded by (scil.
<div n="lb">any thing), as {#brahman#} n., e. g. {#tadetadbrahmApUrvamanaparamanantaramavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#hyam;#} (comp. also {#apUrvatA#} 4.); or as {#manas,#} it being the first of
<div n="lb">the organs ({#indriya#}), in the {%Vājasan.%} verse: {#yadapUrvaM yakzamantaH#}
<div n="lb">{#prajAnAM tanme manaH SivasaMkalpamastu;#} or as a word (not pre-
[Page198-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">ceded by any other word), e. g. in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtra%} {#jAtva-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvam#} (comp. also the {%Vārtt.%} 5. to VIII. 1. 72. and the {%Kāśikā%}
<div n="lb">to VIII. 1. 49. (50.)). <sup>2</sup> Not having existed before; e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Anuśāsana Parvan:%} {#apUrvaM ca BavetpAtramaTavApi cirozitaH#} &c.
<div n="lb">({%Nīlakanṭha:%} {#apUrvaH kadAcinnAgato na dfzwaSca#}); new (also
<div n="lb">applied to a religious act which does not follow as a con-
<div n="lb">sequence of other acts, but requires a special injunction);
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#kAryAKyAnAdapUrvam#} ({%Śaṅkara:%}
<div n="lb">{#apUrvatvAdviDyarham;#} {%Anūpanār.:%} {#apAM prARAcCAdakatvaDyAname-#}
<div n="lb">{#vApUrvaM viDeyam#} &c.); compare also the meaning 2. 1. a. b.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Unprecedented, extraordinary, wonderful; e. g. {#ayaM tva-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvaH pratimAviSezo yaH sevyamAno riputAmupEti;#} or {#vanamida-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapUrvasattvADizWitam#} &c.; or {#sarvaSuBakarmahetoH PalamidaM SfRu-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAsya karmasya . tasmAdBavata kftajYA apUrvaSuBasaMcayaM kzapitveha;#} or
<div n="lb">{#antargUQavizo vahirmaDumayaScAtIva mAyApawuH . ko nAmAyamapUrva-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAwakaviDiryaH Sikzito durjanEH .#}. <sup>4</sup> Not having had before
<div n="lb">(scil. a husband); used so in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#kOmArApUrvavacane#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-rvam#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.) <sup>a.</sup> The
<div n="lb">{%unseen or transcendental power%} (<lang n="greek"></lang>, = {#adfzwapUrvam#} or
<div n="lb">{#atyantamadfzwam#} liter. which has not been seen before or
<div n="lb">which is very invisible) of a {%religious or sacrificial%} act which
<div n="lb">produces the desired result at another than the present or
<div n="lb">at a distant time ({%Kumārila:%} {#PalAya vihitaM karma kzaRikaM ci-#}
<div n="lb">{#raBAvine . tatsidDirnAnyaTetyevamapUrvamapi gamyate;#} {%Mādhava:%}
<div n="lb">{#DAtvarTAtiriktaM kAlAntaraBAvi kAmyaPalasADanam;#} {%the same:%}
<div n="lb">{#yAgajanyA kAcicCaktirapUrvamastu#}); if a religious act includes
<div n="lb">one or several other acts, the unseen power which results
<div n="lb">from the performance of the latter and which consists in
<div n="lb">producing their relation with the former, is called {#avAnta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rApUrva,#} while the unseen power of the superior act is called
<div n="lb">with regard to the inferior acts {#paramApUrva#} or {#muKyApUrva#} or
<div n="lb">{#prakftApUrva#} or {#praDAnApUrva#}. That unseen power which is only
<div n="lb">the result of performing the principal sacrifices, such as
<div n="lb">the Jyotiṣṭoma or the Darśapūrṇamāsa, and which con-
<div n="lb">sists in producing {%the%} result, i. e. {%swarga%} or the enjoyment
<div n="lb">of heaven, is called {#PalApUrva#}. Since such acts include other
<div n="lb">acts which vary in degree or importance, there are various
<div n="lb">degrees of the {#apUrva#} with regard to the {#PalApUrva,#} viz. the
<div n="lb">{#samudAyApUrva,#} the {#utpattyapUrva#} and the {#aNgApUrva#} (the latter also
<div n="lb">called {#kalApUrva#}); thus, as the Darśapūrṇamāsa, the perfor-
<div n="lb">mance of which has the power of producing heaven, i. e.
<div n="lb">the {#PalApUrva,#} consists of the two distinct sacrifices Darśa
<div n="lb">and Pūrṇamāsa which are performed at distinct times, it
<div n="lb">requires an unseen power to effectuate their combining so
<div n="lb">as to constitute the sacrifice Darśapūrnamāsa, (for other-
<div n="lb">wise neither of both would have a relation to the other or
<div n="lb">to that sacrifice itself); this unseen power is the {#samudAyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrva;#} likewise the {#utpattyapUrva#} causes the six Yāgas ({#Agneya-#}
<div n="lb">{#puroqASayAgaH, EndrapayoyAgaH, EndradaDiyAgaH#} which con-
<div n="lb">stitute the Darśa, and the {#AgneyapuroqASayAgaH, Ajyeno-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAMSuyAjayAgaH, agnIzomIyapuroqASayAgaH#} which constitute
<div n="lb">the Pūrṇamāsa, and are performed, too, at different
<div n="lb">times,) to combine so as to become severally the Darśa
<div n="lb">and the Pūrṇamāsa; and lastly, as each of these six
<div n="lb">Yāgas comprises again a number of inferior acts, such
<div n="lb">as the beating of the {%vrīhi,%} the grinding of the {%taṇḍula,%}
[Page199-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the cleansing of the ladles &c., which also are done at
<div n="lb">different times, it requires an {#aNgApUrva#} (or {#kalApUrva#}) to
<div n="lb">produce the result of their constituting severally each of
<div n="lb">these Yāgas.--Such an unseen power might be predi-
<div n="lb">cated, indeed, of any act, whether sacrificial or not,
<div n="lb">but the term {#apUrva#} is expressly reserved by the Mīmān-
<div n="lb">sists to the former ({%Kumārila:%} {#lOkikaM cApi yatkarma Pale#}
<div n="lb">{#kAlAntarodgatO . tatrApi SaktirevAste na tvapUrvagirocyate#}), for
<div n="lb">the corresponding power of a non-sacrificial or profance act is
<div n="lb">called {#saMskAra#}. ({%Kumārila:%} {#yAnyapi ca lOkikAni kfziGf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tapAnAdDyayanapraBftIni karmARi kAlAntaraPalatvenezyante tezAmapi#}
<div n="lb">{#svarUpAvasTAnAsaMBavAtsaMskArEreva tizWadBirvyavahArasidDaH . te#}
<div n="lb">{#tvavEdikatvAtsaMskArA na tvapUrvaSabdABiDeyatvena prasidDAH;#} comp.
<div n="lb">also e. g. {%Mādhava%} in the Pūrvapakṣa of an Adhikaraṇa:
<div n="lb">{#yo'yaM svizwakfdyAgaH so'yamupayuktahaviHsaMskAra ityavivAdam .#}
<div n="lb">{#tatra saMskArasya dfzwaprayojanatvenAvaSayaMBAve sati tAvatEvopakzI-#}
<div n="lb">{#RaH svizwakfdyAgo nApUrvasyopakaroti#} &c.) A doubt may arise,
<div n="lb">whether the beating of rice and such like acts have an
<div n="lb">{#apUrva,#} if considered absolutely or by themselves, since their
<div n="lb">result is the unhusking of the rice and since they are per-
<div n="lb">formed for sacrificial purposes, but the Mīmānsists decide
<div n="lb">the question in the negative, as it is the characteristic
<div n="lb">property of the {#apUrva#} to be an {%unseen%} power, and the un-
<div n="lb">husking of rice is a {%visible%} result ({%Mādhava:%} {#dfzwaPale saMBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vatyapUrvaM na kalpanIyam#}); again whether the cleaning of the
<div n="lb">sacrificial ladles with kuśa grass and such like acts have an
<div n="lb">{#apUrva,#} for their result might be said not to be visible; but the
<div n="lb">solution is the same although from a different reason; viz. be-
<div n="lb">cause they are undertaken for the sake of the {#dravya,#} i. e. these
<div n="lb">inferior acts have an {#apUrva#} only in so far as it concerns
<div n="lb">their relation to the superior acts, but not in so far as the
<div n="lb">mere material result (of unhusking, the purity of the ves-
<div n="lb">sels &c.) is concerned; ({%Jaimini:%} {#tAni#} [scil. {#karmARi#}] {#dvEDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#guRapraDAnaBUtAni . yErdravyaM na cikIrzyate tAni praDAnaBUtAni#}
<div n="lb">{#dravyasya guRaBUtatvAt#}--such as the Prayājas, when the con-
<div n="lb">sideration of the {#dravya#} is subordinate to the superior object
<div n="lb">of the sacrifice--{#. yEstu dravyaM cikIrzyate guRastatra pratIyeta dra-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyapraDAnatvAt#}--as would be the case with the acts named
<div n="lb">before or with the paring of a sacrificial post, when the
<div n="lb">act is merely done for the sake of preparing a post &c.).
<div n="lb">As the {#apUrva#} produces {%the%} result (swarga), it follows more-
<div n="lb">over, that it is not the divinity of the sacrifice who pro-
<div n="lb">duces the result or influences the peculiar nature of the
<div n="lb">sacrifice, the latter being the consequence of the {#apUrva#} it-
<div n="lb">self, ({%Mādhava:%} {#kiM devatAyAH PalapradatvalakzaRaM prADAnyaM Sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdAdApAdyate . vastusAmarTyAdvA . nAdyaH#} &c. {#….. nApi vastu-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAmarTyAddevasya Palapradatvam .…tasmAtPalapradamapUrvameva#}
<div n="lb">{#DarmARAM prayojakam . taTA satyagnyAdidevABAve'pyapUrvaprayukta-#}
<div n="lb">{#DarmARAmatideSAdasti tatrohasyAvakASaH#}); and that the sacri-
<div n="lb">fice itself is not the chief object, since it, too, has not the
<div n="lb">(immediate) power of producing the result ({%Mādhava:%} {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#pUrvaM muKyam . PalavattvAt . yajirna muKyaH . PalarahitatvAt#}).--
<div n="lb">A discussion (interesting on account of the questions of
<div n="lb">philosophy of grammar implied by it) is raised by the Mī-
<div n="lb">mānsā writers, viz. whether many words or a single word
<div n="lb">of a sentence and, again, in the latter case which word
[Page199-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">and which part of such a word will convey the notion of
<div n="lb">the {#apUrva#}. The question is decided in this way: in vaidik
<div n="lb">passages, enjoining an act which possesses the unseen
<div n="lb">power, such as {#somena yajeta,#} or {#hiraRyamAtreyAya dadAti,#}
<div n="lb">or {#tasmAtsuvarRaM hiraRyaM BAryam,#} or {#SyenenABicaranyajeta,#} or
<div n="lb">{#citrayA yajeta paSukAmaH,#} not all the words of the sentence
<div n="lb">collectively convey the {#apUrva,#} nor a single word expressing
<div n="lb">the substance ({#dravya#}) of the sacrificial act, as {#soma#} and {#hi-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRya,#} nor the word expressing a quality ({#guRa#}), as {#suvarRa,#}
<div n="lb">nor the word expressing the name ({#karmavAci#}) of the sacri-
<div n="lb">fice, as {#Syena#} and {#citrA,#} but the {%inflected verb%} or the word
<div n="lb">representing it, as {#yajeta, dadAti, BAryam#}. Again, in the
<div n="lb">verb the {#apUrva#} is not conveyed by the meaning of the radical
<div n="lb">but by that part of it which implies the {%verbal notion%} ({#BA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vanA#}), lastly, so far as the {%implicit%} understanding of the
<div n="lb">verbal notion ({#arTaBAvanA#} or {#arTAtmaBAvanA#}) is concerned,
<div n="lb">any inflection-affix added to the radical might convey it,
<div n="lb">provided the connex of the sentence leaves no doubt, as
<div n="lb">when the word {#-kAma#} (e. g. {#svargakAmaH#}) is added; but an
<div n="lb">{%explicit%} understanding of it ({#SabdaBAvanA#} or {#aBiDABAvanA#})
<div n="lb">is only imparted by the inflection-affixes of the {%potential,%}
<div n="lb">{%leṭ, the imperative%} and by the affixes of the {%participles of the%}
<div n="lb">{%passive future.%} ({%Mādhava:%} {#liNleqlowtavyapratyayamAtragatA Sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdaBAvanA . sarvAKyAtagatArTaBAvanA . taduktam . aBiDABAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmAhuranyAmeva liNNAdayaH . arTAtmaBAvanA tvanyA sarvAKyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tezu gamyata iti .;#} and: {#seyaM SabdaBAvanA liNNAdiBireva ga-#}
<div n="lb">{#myate . arTaBAvanA sarvAKyAtapratyayErgamyata ityuktam . tasyAM cArTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvanAyAM svargasya BAvyatvaM kamiyogAdavagamyate;#} in referring to
<div n="lb">{%Kumārila:%} {#…vEdikaliNNAdInAM tadaBiDAyakatvAt#} (for this
<div n="lb">reason {#apUrva#} is authoritative) {#. tato DAtvarTAtiriktaM kAlAnta-#}
<div n="lb">{#raBAvi#} &c., see above, p. 198{%b,%} 1. 25).--As the unseen power
<div n="lb">is the consequence of the performance of a sacrificial act which
<div n="lb">‘has not existed before’ i. e. which is absolute ({%Mādhava:%} {#kaTaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vinaSvareRa PalaM kartavyamityapekzAyAmapUrvaM kftvetyucyate . kaTamapUrvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#kriyata ityapekzAyAM yAgAnuzWAnaprakAreReti#}) the term {#apUrva#}
<div n="lb">assumes also the meaning of such a sacrificial act, and as
<div n="lb">the latter requires always an authoritative injunction or
<div n="lb">{#viDi,#} since it would not take place otherwise, {#apUrva#} occurs
<div n="lb">also in the sense of such an authoritative injunction, viz.
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> a {%sacrificial act,%} especially a principal act, one not sub-
<div n="lb">ordinate to another act and therefore possessing the un-
<div n="lb">seen power of producing {%the%} result (i. e. heaven); e. g. in
<div n="lb">{%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#apUrve ca vikalpaH syAdyadi saMKyABiDAnam,#}
<div n="lb">{%Śabara:%} {#apUrve ca darSapUrRamAsakarmaRi#} &c.; or in {%Jaimini'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra:%} {#apUrve vApi BAgitvAt,#} {%Śabara:%} {#api vA apUrve ete#}
<div n="lb">{#uBe#} (viz. {#agnihotra#} and {#mAsAgnihotra#}) {#api karmaRI syAtAm;#}
<div n="lb">or in {%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#apUrve tvavikAropadeSAtpratIyeta,#} {%Śa-%}
<div n="lb">{%bara:%} {#apUrve tvaprakftipUrvake karmaRi#} (i. e. in an act not sub-
<div n="lb">ordinate to a superior act); or in {%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#praDAnaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaNgasaMyuktaM taTABUtamapUrvaM syAttasya viDyupalakzaRAt;#} or {%Mādhava%}
<div n="lb">in an Adhikaraṇa: {#vErUpyAcca nirarTatvAdapUrvaM karma yujyate#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>c.</sup> the authoritative or binding {%injunction%} (comp. {#viDi#})
<div n="lb">which produces the unseen power &c.; e. g. {%Kumārila%} (on
<div n="lb">the Sūtra {#codanA punarAramBaH#}): {#AramBacodanEvApUrvasyApi co-#}
<div n="lb">{#danA,#} thus commented upon by {%Mādhava:%} {#guruRA yanniyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAKyamapUrvamaBipreyate#} &c.; or {%Mādhava:%} {#coditaM yadapUrvaM tasyEva#}
[Page200-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#PalavattvenAnuzWeyatayetikartavyatAkANkzA yuktA;#} the relation be-
<div n="lb">tween {#viDi#} and {#apUrva#} may be seen e. g. from the follow-
<div n="lb">ing Adhikaraṇa of {%Mādhava:%} {#upavyAne'nuvAdo vA viDirvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyo yataH smftO . prAptaM mEvamapUrvatvAtkratO lewA viDIyate;#} or
<div n="lb">from {%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#viDirvA syAdapUrvatvAdvAdamAtraM hyanarTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kam;#} (where the {#apUrvatva#} expresses the quality of what may
<div n="lb">be a {#viDiH#}). <sup>2</sup> (In the non-philosophical literature.) Con-
<div n="lb">sequence (perhaps: remote consequence) of an act; e. g. the
<div n="lb">{%Mitākṣara%} on the word {#caritra#} ({%Yājnav.%} 2. 61.): {#caritraSabdena#}
<div n="lb">{#gaNgAsnAnAgnihotrAdijanitamapUrvamucyate#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pUrva#}.
<div n="P">2. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rvaH-rvA-rvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not first, subse-
<div n="lb">quent, last; e. g. in {%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#prakfteH pUrvoktatvAdapUrva-#}
<div n="lb">{#mante syAnna hyacoditasya SezAmnAnam#} ({%Śabara:%} {#prAkftaM pUrvaM ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#danantaramapUrvaM vEkftam;#} in the corresponding Adhikaraṇa of
<div n="lb">{%Mādhava%} thus expressed: {#prAkfte praTamo boDo vEkfte carama-#}
<div n="lb">{#stataH . nArizwahomAH pUrvAH syurupahomAstu pfzWataH,#} these two
<div n="lb">Homas being there the subject of discussion). <sup>2</sup> Not easter-
<div n="lb">ly(?). E. {#a#} neg. and {#pUrva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5260<pc>200-a<k1>apUrva<k2>apUrva<h>2
II. {#apUrva#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-rvaH-rvA-rvam#}) (In Pāṇini's grammar.)
<div n="lb">Preceded by the vowel {#a#} or {#A (= avarRapUrva),#} as the con-
<div n="lb">sonant {#s (ru);#} in the {%Sūtra:%} {#BoBagoaGoapUrvasya yo'Si#}
<div n="lb">(where {#a#} according to {%Pāṇini'%}s terminology comprises the
<div n="lb">sound {#a#} in general, i. e. the short, long and pluta {#a#}). E.
<div n="lb">{#a,#} the vowel, and {#pUrva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5261<pc>200-a<k1>apUrvakarman<k2>apUrvakarman
{#apUrvakarman#}¦ Karmadh. n. ({#-rma#}) <sup>1</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.)
<div n="lb">A sacrificial act called {#apUrva#} q. v. (I. 1. 2. 1. b.); e. g. {#darvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#homAnAmapUrvakarmatvAnnAsti tatra kasyApi viDyantasyAtideSaH#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> An extraordinary deed. E. {#apUrva#} and {#karman#}.
<LEND>

<L>5262<pc>200-a<k1>apUrvajanaka<k2>apUrvajanaka
{#apUrvajanaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nakaH-nikA-nakam#}) (In the Mī-
<div n="lb">mānsā philosophy.) Producing the unseen power or the
<div n="lb">sacrificial act called {#apUrva#} q. v. (I. 1. 2. 1. a. b.). Comp. also
<div n="lb">{#apUrvanizpAdaka#}. E. {#apUrva#} and {#janaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5263<pc>200-a<k1>apUrvatA<k2>apUrvatA
{#apUrvatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) or {#apUrvatva#} n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> The not being pre-
<div n="lb">ceded by any thing. <sup>2</sup> The being unprecedented, wonderful,
<div n="lb">extraordinary. <sup>3</sup> The not having existed before, the being
<div n="lb">new (and therefore requiring an authoritative injunction or
<div n="lb">{#viDi#}); e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#stutimAtramupAdAnAditi#}
<div n="lb">{#cennApUrvatvAt#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#na stutimAtramAsAM SrutInAM prayojanaM#}
<div n="lb">{#yuktam . apUrvatvAt . viDyarTatAyAM hyapUrvArTo vihito Bavati#}
<div n="lb">{#stutyarTatAyAM tvAnarTakyameva syAt#}); or in the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%}
<div n="lb">{#vacanAni tvapUrvatvAttasmAdyaTopadeSaM syuH#} ({%Śabara:%} {#evamapUrvamarTaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vidaDato'rTavattA Bavizyati#} &c.); or {%Jaimini:%} {#apUrvatvAdvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnaM syAt .#} ({%Śabara:%} {#na tatra kaScitpurvaprApto yAgo vidyate#}
<div n="lb">&c.); or in an Adhik. of {%Mādhava:%} {#nivItaM tu manuzyARAM#}
<div n="lb">{#viDirvEzo'rTavAdakaH . apUrvatvAtprakaraRAnnuH kratorvA viDI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yate ..…nivItasya pUrvaM mAnAntareRAprAptatvAdviDeyatvamaByu-#}
<div n="lb">{#peyam#} &c. <sup>4</sup> (In the Vedānta philosophy.) Acquiring an under-
<div n="lb">standing of the {%Real besides which there is nothing else%} ({#advi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIyavastu#}) from no other authority than the vaidik writings;
<div n="lb">it is one of the six characteristics of the {#SravaRa#} or ascer-
<div n="lb">taining by means of study the purport of the Vedānta;
<div n="lb">(comp. besides {#upakramopasaMhAra, aByAsa, Pala, arTavAda#} and
<div n="lb">{#upapatti;#} and see also {#manana, nidiDyAsana#} and {#samADi#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.) <sup>a.</sup> The being or having the
<div n="lb">unseen power {#apUrva#} q. v. I. 1. 2. 1. a.; e. g. in the {%Jaimini%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra:%} {#SrapaRAnAM tvapUrvatvAtpradAnArTe viDAnaM syAt#} (opposed
[Page200-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">as pūrvapakṣa, to the siddhānta: {#saMskAraM prati BAvAcca#}
<div n="lb">{#tasmAdapyapradAnaM syAt;#} comp. for the term {#saMskAra#} s. v. {#apUrva#}
<div n="lb">I. 1. 2. 1. a.). <sup>b.</sup> The being a sacrificial act called {#apUrva#} q. v.
<div n="lb">I. 1. 2. 1. b.; e. g. in the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%} {#apUrvatAM tu darSayedgraha-#}
<div n="lb">{#RasyArTavattvAt;#} or in the Adhikaraṇa of {%Mādhava:%} {#darvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#home somaDarmA apUrvatvamutAgrimaH . avyakteryajyaBAvAcca svAho-#}
<div n="lb">{#ktyAderapUrvatA#} (comp. {#apUrvakarmatva#} in the instance s. v. {#apUrva-#}
<div n="lb">{#karman#}. [<sup>c.</sup> For the meaning ‘the being an injunction {#apUrva#}’
<div n="lb">q. v. I. 1. 2. 1. c. I have no safe instance to adduce.] <sup>6</sup> The
<div n="lb">not having had before (scil. a husband); used so in the
<div n="lb">{%Vārttika%} and the {%Kārikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 2. 13: {#striyA apUrvatve,#}
<div n="lb">or {#apUrvatvaM yadA tasyAH#}. E. {#apUrva,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5264<pc>200-b<k1>apUrvanizpAdaka<k2>apUrvanizpAdaka
{#apUrvanizpAdaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) The
<div n="lb">same as {#apUrvajanaka#}. E. {#apUrva#} and {#nizpAdaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5265<pc>200-b<k1>apUrvapati<k2>apUrvapati

<L>5271<pc>200-b<k1>apUrvArTa<k2>apUrvArTa

<L>5276<pc>201-a<k1>apUrvya<k2>apUrvya
{#apUrvya#}¦ I. (ved.) Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) Not referring
<div n="lb">to, not being in, not visible in, what is prior or has
<div n="lb">existed before; e. g. {#uzas,#} dawn, ‘since it is not seen in the
<div n="lb">night-time which precedes it’; hence also: new, not made
<div n="lb">or existed before, as hymns (‘which have never been com-
<div n="lb">posed before’), or as Agni (as he is ever new through his
<div n="lb">splendour’) &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pUrvya#} (referring &c. to what
<div n="lb">precedes or is prior).
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-rvyaH-rvyA-rvyam#}) Worth of what has not existed
<div n="lb">before, deserving what is extraordinary or excellent (viz.
<div n="lb">the Soma-drink), an epithet of Vāyu (according to {%Sāyaṇa,%}
<div n="lb">who explains the word in the {%Ṛgv.%} verse: {#tvaM no vAyave-#}
<div n="lb">{#zAmapUrvyaH somAnAM praTamaH pItimarhasi,#} in this way: {#na vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyate pUrvaM yasmAttatpAnamapUrvam . tadarhatItyapUrvyaH#}--comp. {%Pāṇ.%}
<div n="lb">V. 1. 67.--; but as the word is udātta on the first syllable
<div n="lb">the correctness of his interpretation, seems doubtful; the
<div n="lb">word might well be, and have the meaning of, the Tatpur.
<div n="lb">also in the quoted verse. E. {#apUrva,#} taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>5277<pc>201-a<k1>apfkta<k2>apfkta
{#apfkta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. n. ({#-ktaH-ktam#}) (In the Prātiśakhyas.) A
<div n="lb">particle consisting of a single vowel, viz. the prepos. {#A#}
<div n="lb">and the particle {#u#} (which becomes {#U#}); e. g. {%Prātiś. of the%}
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#ekavarRaM padamapfktam;#} or {#apfktaH sa u;#} {%Prātiś. of the%}
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#ukAraScetikaraRena yukto rakto'pfkto drAGitaH SAkalena#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ktaH#}) (In the system of Pāṇini.) An affix the
<div n="lb">real value of which consists of a single letter (according to
<div n="lb">the {%Sūtra%} I. 2. 41.; but the practical purport of this general
<div n="lb">rule is conveyed by the restrictions of two {%Vārttikas%} and
<div n="lb">{%Patanjali'%}s {%Bhāṣya%} to this effect, that in {%Pāṇini%} the term ap-
<div n="lb">plies amongst affixes of a single consonant, to the affix {#v#}
<div n="lb">which is technically called {#kvip, kvin#} and {#Rvi#}--comp.
<div n="lb">VI. 1. 67.--, to the nom. sing. aff. {#s#}--technic. {#su#}--and
<div n="lb">to the second and third pers. sing. of the imperf. {#s#} and {#t,#}
<div n="lb">substitutes of {#si#} and {#ti#}--; amongst affixes of a single
<div n="lb">vowel, to {#a#} which is technically {#aR,#} to {#i#} which is tech-
<div n="lb">nically {#iY#}--comp. II. 4. 58.--, and, as {%Patanjali%} adds,
<div n="lb">to {#a,#} technically {#Ra#}--comp. IV. 1. 150.--). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#pfkta,#} 1. scil. {#kAra#} or {#pada,#} 2. scil. {#pratyaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5284<pc>201-b<k1>apekzA<k2>apekzA
{#apekzA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kzA#}) <sup>1</sup> Regard, {%attention, heedfulness;%} e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Bhaṭṭik.%} (Rāma speaks to Hanūmat): {#vaRikpragrAha-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnyadvatkAle carati sidDaye . deSApekzAstaTA yUyaM yAtAdA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yANgurIyakam;#} or in a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#kftaprayatnApekzastu vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hitapratizidDA vEyarTyAdiByaH#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#kfto yaH prayatno jI-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasya DarmADarmalakzaRaH . tadapekza eva cEnamISvaraH kArayati#} &c.).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Regard, {%respect, deference;%} e. g. in the {%Mitākṣara:%} {#loka-#}
<div n="lb">{#vedavedANgavidvAkovAkyetihAsapurARakuSalastadapekzastadvfttiH#} &c.;
<div n="lb">or in a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#aparigrahAccAtyantamanapekzA#} ({%Śaṅkara:%}
<div n="lb">{#ayaM tu paramARukAraRavAdo na kEScidapi SizwEH kenacidapyaMSena#}
<div n="lb">{#parigfhIta ityatyantamevAnAdaraRIyo vedavAdiBiH#} &c.); or
<div n="lb">{#sarvApekzA ca yajYAdiSruteraSvavat#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#kiM vidyAyA atya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntamevAnapekzASramakarmaRAmutAsti kAcidapekzeti#} &c. when in
<div n="lb">the latter instance {#apekzA#} may also be rendered ‘attention’).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Regard, {%consideration, reason;%} e. g. in the {%Dāyabhāga:%}
<div n="lb">{#tadAnIM duhitrAdInAmevAnyApekzayA#} (from another reason)
<div n="lb">{#mftopakArakatvAdyukto DanADikAraH#}. <sup>4</sup> Regard, {%care, desire,%}
<div n="lb">{%expectation;%} e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#AgArAdaBinizkrAntaH pavitro-#}
<div n="lb">{#pacito muniH . samupoQezu kAmezu nirapekzaH parivrajet#} ({%Kullūka:%}
<div n="lb">{#vigataspfhaH#}). <sup>5</sup> Regard, {%reference, relation%} (used in this
<div n="lb">sense esp. in scientific writings, Sūtras, philosophy, com-
<div n="lb">mentaries &c.); e. g. in the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#svApyayasaMpattyora-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyatarApekzamAvizkftaM hi;#} or in the {%Nyāya S.:%} {#Akftistadape-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzatvAtsattvavyavasTAnasidDeH;#} or in a {%Vārttika%} to {%Pāṇ.%} on the
<div n="lb">aff. of the compar. and superl. {#maDyamAcCuklaSabdAtpUrvaparApe-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzAdutpattirvaktavyA;#} or in a {%Kārikā%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#saMyoge gurusaMjYAyAM#}
<div n="lb">{#guRo Betturna siDyati . viDyapekzaM laGoScAsO kaTaM kuRqirna duzya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti .;#}--the instrum. and locative, {#apekzayA#} and {#apekzAyAm,#}
<div n="lb">are used also absolutely in the sense {%‘with regard to, with%}
<div n="lb">{%reference to’,%} the word referred to standing in the locative,
<div n="lb">or if a whole sentence is referred to, being followed by {#iti;#}
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#hfdyapekzayA tu manuzyADikAratvAt;#} or
<div n="lb">in the {%Sāhityadarp.:%} {#tatkiM svarUpaM tAvatkAvyamityapekzAyAM ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#Scit#} &c.; comp. also the instance s. v. {#apUrva#} p. 199{%b,%} 1. 33
<div n="lb">-35). See besides {#apekzin#} and the following. E. {#Ikz#} with
<div n="lb">{#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#a#}.

<L>5285<pc>201-b<k1>apekzAbudDi<k2>apekzAbudDi
{#apekzAbudDi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-dDiH#}) (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.)
<div n="lb">Thinking founded on the category of relation; this term
<div n="lb">designates more especially:
<div n="P">{%A.%} When applied to the notion of {%quantity%} in general,
[Page202-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">that {%mental process in which originates the notion of multipli-%}
<div n="lb">{%city;%} it is conceived and defined in the following manner:
<div n="lb">‘the eye having come into contact with two substances,
<div n="lb">there arises a notion of what is general to the two notions
<div n="lb">of ‘unity’ inherent in either substance, viz. the class of
<div n="lb">the notions of unity or the {%class of monads;%} these two sub-
<div n="lb">stances or unities having become determined, there arises
<div n="lb">a thinking of the quality ‘unity’ previously determined by
<div n="lb">the general notion (monad) [for the special unity could not
<div n="lb">be conceived without a previous knowledge of the general
<div n="lb">notion to which it belongs; comp. also the instance in the
<div n="lb">comm. to the {%Bhāṣāparichchheda%} v. 57]; this thinking is
<div n="lb">the {#apekzAbudDi;#} through it is produced a duality consisting
<div n="lb">of these two substances (unities); it leads to the generality
<div n="lb">or {%class of dyads;%} this class of dyads is reflected upon,
<div n="lb">and through such reflection the {#apekzAbudDi#} ceases; again
<div n="lb">that special thinking whose object is the quality ‘duality’,
<div n="lb">determined by the general notion (dyad), having produced
<div n="lb">the duality of the two substances (unities), the quality
<div n="lb">‘duality’ ceases after the {#apekzAbudDi#} (i. e. that thinking
<div n="lb">itself) has ceased. [{%Śaṅkara%} in the {%Upaskāra%} on {%Kaṇāda%}
<div n="lb">(E. I. H. 232, an indifferent Ms.) {#samAnajatIyayorvA#} (probably
<div n="lb">to be read {#samAnajAtIyayorasamAnajAtIyayorvA,#} for {%Pra-%}
<div n="lb">{%śastapāda%} who is anterior to the author of the Upaskāra
<div n="lb">(Ms. 760) commences his own interpretation {#samAnAsamAna-#}
<div n="lb">{#jAtIyayordravyayoH#}) {#dravyayoScakzuHsaMnikarze sati tannizWEkatvasaMKya-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoryatsAmAnyamekatvatvaM#} (the Ms. reads {#ºmekatvaM#} which is wrong)
<div n="lb">{#tayorvikalpAnantaraM tadviSizwEkatvaguRabudDirutpAdyate . sEva cApe-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzAbudDistayA tayordravyayordvitvamutpAdyate . utpannasya ca dvitvasya#}
<div n="lb">{#sAmAnyaM dvitvatvaM tadAlocanaM tenAlocanenApekzAbudDernASo dvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvatvaviSizwadvitvaguRavizayA viSizwabudDistayA tayordravyayordvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvamutpAdyEkadA#} (? Ms. {#ºtpAScEkadA#}) {#Bavati tadagrIyakzaRe#} (Ms.
<div n="lb">{#tadagrImakzaRe#}) {#ca dvitvaguRasyApekzAbudDinASAdvinASaH#}.] Or in
<div n="lb">other terms: {%the notion of multiplicity ceases as soon as the%}
<div n="lb">{%notion of generality or the class-notion has arisen%} and vice
<div n="lb">versa ({%Kaṇāda:%} {#sAmAnyajYAnAdapekzAbudDinASaH#}). From the
<div n="lb">moment when the eye comes into contact with the objects
<div n="lb">till the moment when the {#apekzAbudDi#} ceases there are eight
<div n="lb">phases, viz. 1. contact &c., 2. comprehension of the class
<div n="lb">of monads, based on the quality ‘unity’, 3. {#apekzAbudDi#} or
<div n="lb">mental reproduction founded on the various qualities ‘unity’
<div n="lb">determined by the class of monads, 4. origin of the quality
<div n="lb">‘duality’, 5. comprehension of the class of dyads, 6. com-
<div n="lb">prehension of the quality ‘duality’ determined by its class,
<div n="lb">7. comprehension of the substance determined by the com-
<div n="lb">prehension of the class of dyads, 8. mental reproduction.
<div n="lb">[{%Śaṅkara:%} {#utpatsyamAnadvitvADAreRendriyasaMnikarzastata ekatvagu-#}
<div n="lb">{#RagatasAmAnyajYAnaM tata ekatvatvasAmAnyaviSizwEkatvaguRasamUhA-#}
<div n="lb">{#lambanA saMskArarUpApekzAbudDistato dvitvaguRotpattistatastadgatasA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnyasya jYAnaM tatastatsAmAnyaviSizwadvitvaguRajYAnaM tato dvitva-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvasAmAnyajYAnaviSizwadravyajYAnaM#} (Ms. {#ºmAnyajYAviSizwe draºº#})
<div n="lb">{#tataH saMskAra itIndriyasaMnikarzamAraBya saMskAraparyantamazwO kza-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAH#}.] Again the cessation of the comprehension of multi-
<div n="lb">plicity and of the comprehension of generality takes place
<div n="lb">in the following order: ‘the comprehension of the class of
<div n="lb">monads ceases when the comprehension of multiplicity com-
[Page202-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">mences, the latter ceases when the comprehension of the
<div n="lb">class of dyads arises, this comprehension ceases when the
<div n="lb">comprehension of the quality ‘duality’ commences, and
<div n="lb">the latter ceases when the comprehension of the substance
<div n="lb">determined by the quality ‘duality’ commences’. [{%Śan-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara:%} {#vinASakramastu . ekatvatvasAmAnyajYAnasyApekzAbdDito vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#nASaH . dvitvatvasAmAnyajYAnAdapekzAbudDervinASaH . dvitvatvasAmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyajYAnasya ca dvitvaguRabudDito vinASaH . dvitvaguRabudDeSca dvitva-#}
<div n="lb">{#viSizwadravyajYAnAt;#} (the terms {#budDi#} and {#jYAna#} have both
<div n="lb">here been rendered ‘comprehension’, to indicate that no
<div n="lb">distinction is intended by the author in chosing two dif-
<div n="lb">ferent words; comp. {%Praśastapāda:%} {#budDirupalabDirjYAnaM pratyaya#}
<div n="lb">{#iti paryAyAH#}).]--According to the foregoing definition
<div n="lb">the mental process {#apekzAbudDi#} and, consequently, the notion
<div n="lb">of multiplicity itself commences with the notion of ‘two’;
<div n="lb">others however hold that it begins with the notion of ‘three’.
<div n="P">{%B.%} When applied to the notion of {%space%} and {%time,%} it
<div n="lb">designates {%that mental process in which originate the notions%}
<div n="lb">{%of ‘far and near’, ‘old and young’%} (see {#paratva#} and {#apa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ratva#}); this process, too, which is founded on the dividing
<div n="lb">of the same unity (space or time) into two quantities, ceases
<div n="lb">as soon as the notion of generality is comprehended; and
<div n="lb">the relative notions ‘far and near’, ‘old and young’
<div n="lb">cease themselves when the notions ‘space’ and ‘time’ are
<div n="lb">conceived; in a similar manner as the {#apekzAbudDi#} ceases
<div n="lb">when applied to quantity as soon as the {#sAmAnyajYAna#} com-
<div n="lb">mences, and as the quality ‘two &c.’ disappears when the
<div n="lb">substance to which it applies, is conceived. [{%Śaṅkara:%} {#ape-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzAbudDinASAtsaMyogasyAsamavAyikAraRasya nASAddravyasya ca sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mavAyikAraRasya nASAnnimittAsamavAyikAraRayornASAnnimi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttasamavAyikAraRanASeByaSca tatrApekzabudDinASAttAvatparatvotpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttiH paratvasAmAnyajYAnaM tato'pekzAbudDivinASastadvinASAtpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ratvaviSizwadravyajYAnakAle paratvanASaH dvitvanASavadeva sarvamUha-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIyam#} &c.] E. {#apekzA#} and {#budDi#}.
<LEND>

<L>5286<pc>202-b<k1>apekzita<k2>apekzita
{#apekzita#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Regarded, looked
<div n="lb">upon; e. g. in the {%Māghakāvya:%} {#apekzitAnAyatavalgamagre tu-#}
<div n="lb">{#raNgiBirTatnanirudDavAhEH#}. Comp. {#avekzita#}. <sup>2</sup> Considered, re-
<div n="lb">spected, obeyed, followed; e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kasmAnna#}
<div n="lb">{#tvayApekzitaH pitA#} (comm. = {#anuvfttaH#} or = {#cintitaH#}). <sup>4</sup> Ex-
<div n="lb">pected, required, wanted. <sup>5</sup> Desired, agreeable. <sup>6</sup> Re-
<div n="lb">ferred to.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Consideration, regard. <sup>2</sup> A desired or
<div n="lb">agreeable circumstance, a requisite; e. g. {%Kullūka:%} {#yataH#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvatejomayo nfpatistasmAdapekzitezu yamizwaM SAstrAnuzWeyaM SAstrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#virudDaM niScitya vyavasTApayati . anapekzitezu cAnizwaM niyamaM#}
<div n="lb">{#nAtikrAmet#}. E. {#Ikz#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5289<pc>203-a<k1>apekzin<k2>apekzin
{#apekzin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kzI-kziRI-kzi#}) <sup>1</sup> Looking to, ex-
<div n="lb">pecting, hoping. <sup>2</sup> Considering, respecting. <sup>3</sup> Referring to
<div n="lb">(in the latter sense mostly used in scientific writings); e. g.
<div n="lb">in a comm. on the {%Sāṅkhyakār.%} {#anyonyASrayo na dozAya ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttajjAtIyApekzitve'pi tattadvyaktInAM parasparAnapekzitvAt;#} or
<div n="lb">in a {%Yoga Sūtra:%} {#taduparAgApekzitvAccittasya vastu jYAtAjYA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tam;#} or in a comm. on the {%Nyāya S.%} {#svasya svApekzitve'ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwaprasaNgaH#} (see s. v. {#AtmASraya#}); also used in contradistinction
<div n="lb">from ‘what is referred to’, e. g. {#tadapekzApekzitvanibanDano#}
<div n="lb">{#'nizwaprasaNgaH#} ‘an incongruous connexion founded on the
<div n="lb">mutual (imaginary, but not real) relation of the object
<div n="lb">which has the reference, i. e. which is referred to, and the
<div n="lb">object referring to (when {#tadapekzApekzin#} is equal to {#tadapekza-#}
<div n="lb">{#tadapekzin;#} comp. s. v. {#anyonyASraya#}); or {#tadapekzApekzyapekzitva-#}
<div n="lb">{#nibanDano'nizwaprasaNgaH#} ‘an incongruous connexion founded
<div n="lb">on the relation between an object referred to, another re-
<div n="lb">ferring to this and another referring to the latter; (comp.
<div n="lb">s. v. {#cakraka#}). In all these instances the affix {#tva#} does not be-
<div n="lb">long to {#apekzin#} but to the whole compound of which this
<div n="lb">word is the latter part; i. e. {#tattajjAtIyApekzin, parasparA-#}
<div n="lb">{#napekzin, taduparAgApekzin, svApekzin, tadapekzApekzin#} &c.,
<div n="lb">taddh. aff. {#tva#}.--E. {#Ikz#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<LEND>

<L>5291<pc>203-a<k1>apeta<k2>apeta
{#apeta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Gone away, departed,
<div n="lb">lost; lit. or metaphorically; e. g. in the {%Māghak.%} {#apetayu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDABiniveSasOmyo harirhariprasTamaTa pratasTe;#} or in {%Suśruta:%}
<div n="lb">{#apetasarvadozAsu nAqIzviva vahajjalam . sarvadozaharaScAsO Sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rIrasya ca jIvanaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Separated from, deprived of, with a
<div n="lb">noun in the ablat.; e. g. {#suKAdapetaH#}. <sup>3</sup> In contradiction,
<div n="lb">contrary to, with a noun in the abl.; e. g. {#AcArAdapetaM#}
<div n="lb">{#kurvantaH;#} or {#DarmAdanapetam#}.--In either of the last two mean-
<div n="lb">ings {#apeta#} may form with the noun depending on it in the
<div n="lb">ablative, a Tatpur. compound; but the instances of such
<div n="lb">compounds are few, according to {%Pāṇini;%} e. g. ({%deprived of%})
<div n="lb">{#suKApetaH;#} or in the {%Nalod.%} {#vasApetena#} (comm. {#vasA medasta-#}
<div n="lb">{#yApetena hInena#}); or in the {%Yoga S.%} {#tadA sarvAvaraRApetasya#}
<div n="lb">(v. 1. {#sarvAvaraRamalApetasya#}) {#jYAnasyAnantyAjjYeyamalpam#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#sarvEH kleSakarmAvaraRErviyuktasya#}); or ({%contrary to%}) in {%Yājnav.%}
<div n="lb">{#rAgAlloBAdBayAdvApi smftyapetAdikAriRaH#} ({%Vijnāneśv.%} {#smftyapetaM#}
<div n="lb">{#smftivirudDam#}). E. {#i#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>5301<pc>203-b<k1>apehivARijA<k2>apehivARijA
{#apehivARijA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-jA#}) A festival or ceremony
<div n="lb">where tradespeople are denied admission. The {%Gaṇaratna-%}
<div n="lb">{%mahodadhi%} explains this word and the word {#ehivARijA#}
<div n="lb">as specimens of the similar formations (see the preceding
<div n="lb">and the following articles) which occur in the {%Gaṇa%} {#mayU-#}
<div n="lb">{#ravyaMsakAdi#} to {%Pāṇini%} II. 1. 72., in this manner: {#ehi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vARijeti yasyAM tiTO kriyAyAM vA sA ehivARijA . keci-#}
<div n="lb">{#dAyAnti gacCanti vARijA yasyAmiti vigfhya nipAtanAdehi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvaH . apehi apasara vARijeti yasyAM#} (Ms. E. I. H. 949.
<div n="lb">{#vARije asyAM#} sic) {#sA apehivARijA . evamehisvAgatA . ape-#}
<div n="lb">{#hisvAgatA . ehidvitIyA .#} ({#apehidvitIyA#} is omitted, through
<div n="lb">carelessness, by the copyist, not by the author) {#. ehivi-#}
<div n="lb">{#GasA . apehiviGasA .#} ({#ehipraGasA#} and {#apehipraGasA#} are omit-
<div n="lb">ted by the copyist, not by the author) {#. ehiprakasA . ape-#}
<div n="lb">{#hiprakasA . apehi prakasaM dUramiti yasyAM#} ({#sA#} omitted) {#ape-#}
<div n="lb">{#hiprakasA iti SAkawAyanaH#}. This explanation and the words
<div n="lb">enumerated (except the two latter) are in conformity with
<div n="lb">the {%Vārttika:%} {#apehi ca vARijasvAgatadvitIyaviGasapraGasAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BiH kriyAyAm,#} which the {%Kāśikā%} comments upon: {#ape-#}
<div n="lb">{#hyAKyAtaM vARijasvAgatadvitIyaviGasapraGasAdiBiH saha sama-#}
<div n="lb">{#syate . cakArAdehIti ca . ehivARijeti yasyAM kriyAyAM sA#}
<div n="lb">{#ehivARijA . apehivARijA#} &c. The word {#apehikawA#}
<div n="lb">which occurs in the present edition of Pāṇini, and there-
<div n="lb">fore in the reprint of that edition, is neither mentioned in
<div n="lb">the {%Gaṇar.%} nor in the {%Kāśikā%} and becomes doubtful when
<div n="lb">compared with such formations as {#AharakarawA, prohakarawA#}
<div n="lb">(the latter being the reading of the {%Kāśikā%} instead of {#pre-#}
<div n="lb">{#hikawA#}); the word {#apehivAta,#} although of an analogous
<div n="lb">formation, belongs to a different category, the ellipsis being
<div n="lb">probably {#ozaDi#} or {#latA,#} and does not occur in any of the
<div n="lb">lists referring to the mentioned Gaṇa.--From the quoted
<div n="lb">comment it results that all these compounds have to be
<div n="lb">analyzed literally as meaning a {#kriyA#} or proceeding in which
<div n="lb">an injunction is uttered or implied, the component parts
[Page204-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">being originally a sentence, e. g. {#apehi vARija#} ‘be off
<div n="lb">tradesman’, {#apehi prakasam#} ‘go far away’ &c. and hence
<div n="lb">{#apehivARijA#} &c. festivals where such people are kept off
<div n="lb">or kept at a distance.--E. {#apehi#} (imper. of {#i#} with {#apa#})
<div n="lb">and {#vARija,#} scil. {#kriyA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5302<pc>204-a<k1>apehivAtA<k2>apehivAtA
{#apehivAtA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-tA#}) The name of a plant (Pœderia
<div n="lb">fœtida), a decoction of which is given against the disease
<div n="lb">{#granTi#} q. v.; e. g. in {%Suśruta:%} {#apehivAtAdaSamUlasidDaM vEdya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScatuHmnehamaTo dvayaM vA#} (scil. {#vidaDyAt#}). E. {#apehi#} (imper. of
<div n="lb">{#i#} with {#apa#}) and {#vAta,#} scil. (probably) {#ozaDi#} or {#latA;#}
<div n="lb">liter. ‘a plant by which wind is expelled’; see the expla-
<div n="lb">nation s. v. {#apehivARijA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5304<pc>204-a<k1>apehisvAgatA<k2>apehisvAgatA
{#apehisvAgatA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-sA#}) A festival or ceremony
<div n="lb">where undesired or uninvited people are denied admission.

<div n="lb">hypothetical; but as all the similar formations mentioned
<div n="lb">in the last named article imply the shutting out of un-
<div n="lb">desired objects, it will seem that {#svAgata#} is either to be taken
<div n="lb">in this compound as {#su-Agata#} ‘welcome’ in an ironical
<div n="lb">sense--comp. e. g. {#satya, sADu--,#} or as {#sva-Agata#} ‘come
<div n="lb">on one's own account, uninvited’.) E. {#apehi#} (imper. of {#i#}
<div n="lb">with {#apa#}) and {#svAgata,#} scil. {#kriyA#}.

<L>5306<pc>204-a<k1>apogaRqa<k2>apogaRqa
{#apogaRqa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-RqaH-RqA-Rqam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Having a
<div n="lb">limb too many or too few (e. g. twenty-one or nineteen,
<div n="lb">fingers and toes together), deformed. <sup>2</sup> A child, an infant.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Very timid, very fearful. The same as {#pogaRqa#} and {#pOgaRqa#}
<div n="lb">(comp. {%Viśva'%}s {%Śabdabheda%} E. I. H. Ms. 1539. 246. and Ms.
<div n="lb">R. S. {#pOgaRqaH syAdapogaRqaH#}). E. According to the native
<div n="lb">Etym., a Tatpur. {#apas#} (= {#apa,#} āgama {#suw#}) and {#gaRqa#} ({#gam#}
<div n="lb">uṇ. aff. {#qa#}) lit. ‘going badly: {#apakfzwaM gacCati#}’; but it would
<div n="lb">seem preferable to assume that the word is in this sense
<div n="lb">a Bahuvr. of {#apa#} (in its form {#apas#}) deter. and {#gaRqa#} (in a
<div n="lb">lost sense ‘limb’).
<div n="P">II. Not under sixteen years of age.--In this sense the
<div n="lb">word occurs in the edd. of {%Manu%} 8. 148., according to {%Kul-%}
<div n="lb">{%lūka;%} when {#pogaRqa#} which, according to the {%Koshas,%} has
<div n="lb">the meanings of {#apogaRqa#} I., assumes the special meaning
<div n="lb">‘under sixteen years of age’; the two edd. of the {%Vyavah.%}
<div n="lb">section of the {%Mitākṣara%} and several E. I. H. Mss. of the
<div n="lb">Mit. who quote this verse (8<sup>vo</sup> ed. p. 43{%a,%} 1. 1; 4<sup>to</sup> ed. {#vyaº#}
<div n="lb">fol. 12{%a,%} 1. 13) read it {#apOgaRqa#} and repeat it in the same
<div n="lb">form immediately afterwards (1. 4. and 1. 14), while the {%Vīra-%}
<div n="lb">{%mitrodaya%} fol. 66{%a,%} 1. 1 reads {#apogaRqa#}. Comp. also the {%Mit.%}
<div n="lb">8<sup>vo</sup> ed. p. 74, 1. 9, 4<sup>to</sup> ed. {#vyaº#} fol. 20{%a,%} 1. 15. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pIgaRqa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5307<pc>204-a<k1>apoQa<k2>apoQa
{#apoQa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-QaH-QA-Qam#}) Removed from; with
<div n="lb">a noun in the ablat., e. g. {#kalpanAyA apoQaH;#} it may form
<div n="lb">with such a noun a Tatpur., e. g. {#kalpanApoQaH;#} but the in-
<div n="lb">stances of such compounds are few, according to {%Pāṇini.%}
<div n="lb">E. {#vah#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5308<pc>204-a<k1>apodaka<k2>apodaka
{#apodaka#}¦ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Without water.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Watertight.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. f. ({#-dikA#}) The name of a potherb (Basella
[Page204-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">rubra or lucida), liter. ‘risen from the water: {#apagatoda-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAt#}’. Comp. {#upodikA#}. E. {#apa#} and {#udaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5316<pc>204-b<k1>apoSAna<k2>apoSAna

<L>5317<pc>204-b<k1>apoha<k2>apoha
{#apoha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) Removing, taking off; e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Jaiminīya-nyāyam.:%} {#viSizwasya yadAdAnamanyApohena vastunaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#arTAntaranyAsavatI parivfttirasO yaTA#}. Comp. {#apohana#} and
<div n="lb">{#vyapoha#}. <sup>2</sup> Reasoning away, i. e. a reasoning which {%removes%}
<div n="lb">one object from another or {%disconnects%} two objects; the re-
<div n="lb">verse of {#Uha,#} the reasoning which establishes a relation
<div n="lb">between two objects, i. e. which {%connects%} them (for the de-
<div n="lb">tailed explanation of the latter term see, however, s. v. {#Uha#});
<div n="lb">e. g. on the words of the {%Bhāgav. Purāṇa%} which speak of
<div n="lb">the difference between Soul and Body: {#‘dehastu sarvasaMGAto#}
<div n="lb">{#jagattasTuriti dviDA . atrEva mfgyaH puruzo neti netItyatattya-#}
<div n="lb">{#jan’#} {%Śrīdharasvāmin%} observes: {#neti netItyanyApohe kriya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mARe#} &c.; or in the {%Siddhāntamuktāvalī:%} {#apoharUpo nIla-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAdirvijYAnaDarma iti cet . na . nIlatvAdInAM virudDAnAme-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasminnasamAveSAt#} ‘are blue, yellow and similar qualities
<div n="lb">such properties of knowledge as must be disconnected from
<div n="lb">it by reasoning? no, for contrary notions as blue, yellow &c.
<div n="lb">cannot take place (at the same time in the same thing)’;
<div n="lb">the Dwandwa {#UhApoha#} ‘positive and negative reasoning,
<div n="lb">reasoning which {%connects%} and reasoning which {%disconnects’%}
<div n="lb">is therefore also used in the sense of ‘thorough or clever
<div n="lb">reasoning, sharpness or cleverness of intellect’; e. g. in
<div n="lb">{%Bharatasena%} on a verse of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#UhApohakzamErna SukA-#}
<div n="lb">{#divadaDItavaktftvam;#} or {%Mādhava%} says of a work on car-
<div n="lb">pentry: {#UhApohakuSalapuruzotprekzAmUlA takzasmftirna vedaM kalpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yituM praBavati#}.--{%Hemachandra%} calls {#apoha#} one of the eight
<div n="lb">qualities of intellect ({#SuSrUzA SravaRaM cEva grahaRaM DAraRaM taTA#}
<div n="lb">{#Uho'poho'rTavijYAnaM tattvajYAnaM ca DIguRAH#}), but this piece
<div n="lb">of psychology seems to belong to him as exclusively as his
<div n="lb">definition of {#apAna#}. E. {#Uh#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>5318<pc>204-b<k1>apohana<k2>apohana
{#apohana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Removing, taking off, destroying;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Bhagavadgītā%} (15. 15.) Viṣṇu says: {#mattaH smf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tirjYAnamapohanaM ca#} ‘from me comes recollection and know-
[Page205-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">ledge (scil. of virtuous acts) and the removal (i. e. the
<div n="lb">cessation of recollection and of knowledge of sinful acts)’.
<div n="lb">{%Śaṅkara:%} {#matta AtmanaH sarvaprARinAM smftirjYAnaM tadapohanaM ca .#}
<div n="lb">{#yezAM puRyakarmaRAM puRyakarmAnuroDena jYAnasmftI BavataH . taTA#}
<div n="lb">{#pApakarmaRAM pApakarmAnuroDena smftijYAnayorapohanamapagamanaM ca;#}
<div n="lb">{%Sadānanda:%} {#matta Atmana evAtaH prARijAtasya ca smftiH .#}
<div n="lb">{#etajjanmani pUrvAnuBUtArTavizayA ca sA . janmAntarAnuBUtArTavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zayApyasti yoginAm . vizayendriyasaMyogajanyaM jYAnaM taTAtmanaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#dikkAlaviprakfzwEkavizayaM cApi yoginAm . matta eva tayoH#}
<div n="lb">{#kAmakroDAdyAkulacetasAm . pApakarmAnuroDena vinASaH smfti-#}
<div n="lb">{#boDayoH ..;#} {%Arjunamiśra:%} {#matta eva hetoH prARijAtasya pUrvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nuBUtArTavizayA smftirBavati . jYAnaM ca vizayendriyasaMprayogajaM#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati . apohanaM ca tayoH pramozo Bavati ..;#} similarly {%Madhu-%}
<div n="lb">{%sūdhana:%} {#…apohanaM ca smftijYAnayorapApaSca matta eva#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati#}.] E. {#Uh#} with {#apa,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>5326<pc>205-a<k1>apkftsnasamADi<k2>apkftsnasamADi

<L>5330<pc>205-b<k1>aptu<k2>aptu
{#aptu#}¦ m. ({#-ptuH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Soma. <sup>2</sup> A sacrificial animal. <sup>3</sup> Body.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> A desired object, or object of desire (perhaps more cor-
<div n="lb">rectly: attainment, scil. of a desired object). <sup>5</sup> Possessing,
<div n="lb">comprising. [The two first meanings are two various inter-
<div n="lb">pretations of the word in {%Vājas.%} 5. 35. or {%Śatap.%} III. 6. 3. 8.:
<div n="lb">{#juzARo apturAjyasya vetu#} (quoted also by the {%Kāśikā%} on {%Pāṇ.%}
<div n="lb">VI. 1. 118.), viz. {%Śayaṇa:%} {#aptuH sUkzmarUpaH somaH,#} or {%Mahīdh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aptuScAtra somaH . Apnoti pItaH saYCarIram#} i. e. ‘Soma, be-
<div n="lb">cause it comes into the body’; and {%Nṛsinha%} in the {%Swara-%}
<div n="lb">{%mañjarī:%} {#apturyajYiyaH paSuH#} (probably as connected with
<div n="lb">{#aptas#}); the third meaning is that given by {%-Bhaṭṭojid.%} on
<div n="lb">the {%Uṇ. Sūtra%} 1. 74. (perhaps because body is pervaded by
<div n="lb">Soma); the fourth meaning results from {%Bhaṭṭoj.'%}s {%Prauḍham.%}
<div n="lb">but belongs apparently to the word only in {#aptoryAma#} q. v.
<div n="lb">where it would have also the fifth meaning, according to a
<div n="lb">passage from the Śatap. quoted s. v. {#aptoryAma;#} in either
<div n="lb">of the last two meanings {#aptoH#} represents probably the
<div n="lb">{%abl.%} of the abstract noun in {#-tu#} which in the Vedas often
<div n="lb">assumes the function of our infinitive, expressed in the
<div n="lb">classical idiom by the accus. {#-tum, aptos#} being thus equal
<div n="lb">in value to the classical {#Aptum#}.] E. {#Ap#} with shortened
<div n="lb">{#A#} (accord. to the native etym., but more correctly {#ap,#}
<div n="lb">comp. the etym. of {#apta#}), uṇ. aff. {#tu#}.
<LEND>

<L>5331<pc>205-b<k1>aptur<k2>aptur

<L>5333<pc>205-b<k1>aptoryAma<k2>aptoryAma
{#aptoryAma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> The name of a sacrifice,
<div n="lb">viz. of the seventh or last part ({%somasansthā%}) of the {%Jyo-%}
<div n="lb">{%tiṣṭoma;%} ({%Mādhava%} in enumerating the seven parts of the
<div n="lb">{%Jyotiṣṭoma,%} in his {%Jaiminiyanyāyam.,%}--accord. to all the
<div n="lb">Mss. of this work within my reach--makes it, the sixth part
<div n="lb">of the latter, but he is at variance in this respect with the
<div n="lb">older authorities of the {%Kalpasūtras%} and of {%Kumārila'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Vārttikas%}); it is not {%nitya%} or obligatory for the performance
<div n="lb">of this sacrifice, like the {%Agniṣṭoma%} (q. v.), but {%kāmya%} or
<div n="lb">voluntary, and instituted merely for the attainment of a
<div n="lb">specific desire. See {#jyotizwoma#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of a Śamaveda-
<div n="lb">verse, becauses it closes the ceremonies connected with the
<div n="lb">sacrifice of this name. E. {#aptos#} (abl. of {#aptu#}) and {#yAma#}.
<div n="lb">The literal meaning of this word would be in conformity
<div n="lb">with the definition of the {%Prauḍhamanoramā,%} ‘a sacrifice
<div n="lb">which procures the attainment of the desired object’: {#aptuH#}
<div n="lb">{#SarIramiti . aBilazitArTaSca . AptavyatvAt . ata evAptoryA-#}
<div n="lb">{#maSabdasyABilazitArTaprApaka ityavayavArTamAhuH,#} when {#aptoH#}
<div n="lb">would be, not the ablat., but the genitive of {#aptu#} 4. q. v.,
<div n="lb">and {#yAma#} have the sense of {#prApaka;#} but it is more probable
<div n="lb">that {#yAma#} means ‘termination’ and that {#aptoH#} represents
<div n="lb">the abl. of {#aptu#} q. v., i. e. ‘the last part (scil. of the Jyoti-
[Page206-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">ṣṭoma, performed) on account of obtaining, scil. the de-
<div n="lb">sired object’; according to the comm. of {%Śatap.%} XIII. 7.
<div n="lb">1. 9., however, the word would derive its meaning from
<div n="lb">‘the Aptoryāma sacrifice and verse {%including%} the sacrifices
<div n="lb">and verses called severally Agniṣṭoma, Ukthya, Shoḍaśin
<div n="lb">and Atirātra qq. vv.’: {%Śatap.%} {#sarvezAM yajYakratUnAmAptyE;#} {%Ha-%}
<div n="lb">{%risvāmin:%} {#sarvezAM yajYakratUnAmiti . sarvARyagnizwomokTyazoqa-#}
<div n="lb">{#SyatirAtranAmAni#} [to be read thus probably instead of the
<div n="lb">meaningless {#‘ºnAmiM#} (?)’ in the present publication of Ex-
<div n="lb">tracts from this comm.] {#stotraSastrARi cAptoryAme'ntarBavantI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyaBiprAyaH;#} when {#aptoH#} would mean ‘on account of ob-
<div n="lb">taining or comprising’, scil. Agniṣṭoma &c.
<LEND>

<L>5339<pc>206-a<k1>apnavAna<k2>apnavAna

<LEND>

<L>5340<pc>206-a<k1>apnavAnavat<k2>apnavAnavat

<L>5341<pc>206-a<k1>apnas<k2>apnas
{#apnas#}¦ n. ({#-pnaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Work; also, religious work, a sacri-
<div n="lb">ficial act. <sup>2</sup> Wealth. <sup>3</sup> Shape. (The meaning ‘progeny’ be-
<div n="lb">longs to the base {#apna#} q. v., according to {%Madhīdhara.%}) E.
<div n="lb">{#Ap#} with {#A#} shortened (according to the native E., but
<div n="lb">more correctly {#ap,#} comp. the E. of {#apta#}), uṇ. aff. {#asun,#}
<div n="lb">āgama {#nuw#}.

<div n="lb">work is done, or speech joined to sacrificial acts). E.
<div n="lb">{#apnas,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.

<L>5343<pc>206-a<k1>appa<k2>appa
{#appa#}¦ m. ({#-ppaH#}) The name of a Telugu poet, who ‘wrote a
<div n="lb">work on prosody called Appakavi-chhāndasa and another
<div n="lb">work called Vrindāsambhava which is an account of the
<div n="lb">birth and parentage of Vrinda, the chaste wife of a giant’
<div n="lb">…‘the manner of the death of this poet is unknown, nor
<div n="lb">have the names of any of his (other) works been preserved’.
<div n="lb">--He is not considered to be the same as {#apyayadIkzita#}
<div n="lb">q. v. E. unknown.
<LEND>
[Page206-b+ 56]

<L>5348<pc>206-b<k1>apya<k2>apya
{#apya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-pyaH-pyA-pyam#}) (ved.) I. To be reached, to be
<div n="lb">obtained, accessible; (= {#Apya#} or {#AptuM yogya#}). E. {#ap#}
<div n="lb">(comp. the E. of {#apta#}), kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.
<div n="P">II. <sup>1</sup> Made with water, as Havis. <sup>2</sup> Born or produced
<div n="lb">in water, as Soma. E. {#ap#} (water), taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<div n="P">III. Connected with work, fit for work (also, for sacri-
<div n="lb">ficial acts), active. [The nom. sing. {#apyaH#} is a poetical li-
<div n="lb">cense in {%Ṛgv.%} VI. 67. 9. instead of the nom. plur.--The
<div n="lb">assumption of a femin. {#apI#} instead of {#apyA#} is arbitrary.]
<div n="lb">E. {#apas#} (shortened to {#apa,#} compare {#aptya#}), taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>5351<pc>206-b<k1>apyaya<k2>apyaya
{#apyaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Union, junction. <sup>2</sup> Going
<div n="lb">into, esp. metaphorically, absorption, e. g. {#svApyaya#} ‘pro-
<div n="lb">found sleep’ q. v.; destruction, when contrasted with {#praBava#}
<div n="lb">‘birth, origin’ ({#praBavApyayO = utpattipralayO#}). Comp. {#apI-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti#} and {#apyayana#}. E. {#i#} with {#api,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>5352<pc>206-b<k1>apyayadIkzita<k2>apyayadIkzita
{#apyayadIkzita#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-taH#}) The name of a celebrated
<div n="lb">Dravida Brahmaṇa, the son of {%Nārāyaṇadīkṣita;%} he lived
<div n="lb">at Agrahara and flourished in the 16<sup>th</sup> century of Śālivā-
<div n="lb">hana; his contemporaries considered him as an emanation
<div n="lb">of Śiva on account of his devotion for this god and his
<div n="lb">great learning, for ‘at the age of twelve years he perfectly
<div n="lb">studied the Vedas and was besides master of several ab-
<div n="lb">struse sciences’. In his crusade for establishing the supe-
<div n="lb">riority of Śivaism he was once waylayed in a forest by
<div n="lb">ruffians, hired by one of his unvictorious opponents at the
<div n="lb">court of Vankatapati, but rescued by timely aid. He
<div n="lb">died at Chillumbrum, as it appears, at the age of ninety.
<div n="lb">He is said to be the author of 84 books on theology, rhe-
<div n="lb">toric and philosophy. {%Colebrooke%} names (essays I. 333. 337)
<div n="lb">two of his Vedānta works; {%Wilson%} (in the introd. to the
<div n="lb">{%Daśakumārach.%} p. 5) his abridged version of the first portion
<div n="lb">of the Daśak. and his work on rhetoric, the {%Kuvālayānanda%}
<div n="lb">(comp. also Journal As. serie IV. vol. XI. p. 529); a vo-
<div n="lb">cabulary of his is mentioned in {%Weber'%}s Catalogue of the
<div n="lb">Berlin Sanskr. Ms. (No. 806), and the Pandit {%Cavelly Ven-%}
<div n="lb">{%kata Rāmasvāmin%} who is answerable for the data alleged
<div n="lb">before, enumerates among his Śivaitic writings the {%Śivār-%}
<div n="lb">{%chanā-chandrikā, Śiva-tattwa-viveka, Śiva-maṇi-dīpika%} and
<div n="lb">the {%Ātmārpaṇa.%}--His name occurs also in the shape of
<div n="lb">{#apyAyadIkzita, apyEdIkzita, apyadIkzita, appidIkzita, appa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dIkzita, apyayya;#} but he is not the same as {#appa#} q. v. E.
<div n="lb">{#apyaya#} and {#dIkzita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5363<pc>207-a<k1>aprakaraRa<k2>aprakaraRa
{#aprakaraRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) The not being the principal or
<div n="lb">relevant matter, incidental or irrelevant matter (of a book,
<div n="lb">a discussion &c.); e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} on a passage of the {%Bṛhadār.:%}
<div n="lb">{#jYAnakarmaRI eva hi meDAtapaHSabdavAcye . tayoH prakftatvAnnetare#}
<div n="lb">{#meDAtapasI . aprakaraRAt;#} applied also to those passages in
<div n="lb">the Brāhmaṇas which are considered as not connected with,
<div n="lb">or irrelevant to, the principal topics of an injunction with
<div n="lb">which they may happen to be found together in the same
<div n="lb">chapter or book, and which therefore do not share in the
<div n="lb">rules that apply to the latter, but become the subject of
<div n="lb">special injunctions; comp. {#anAraByADIta#} and the following;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%} {#aprakaraRe tu tadDarmato viSezAt#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#prakaraRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5364<pc>207-a<k1>aprakalpaka<k2>aprakalpaka
{#aprakalpaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-lpakaH-lpikA-lpakam#}) Not en-
<div n="lb">joining, not making principal or relevant, not having the
<div n="lb">effect of making one injunction as relevant or obligatory
<div n="lb">as other injunctions with which the former may happen to
<div n="lb">be found together in the same book or chapter, e. g. of a
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa (comp. the preceding and {#anAraByADIta#}); e. g. in
<div n="lb">the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%} {#SAstraM syAdaprakalpakam#} (scil. {#smfteH#}); {%Śabara:%}
<div n="lb">{#tasmAnnAsyAH smfteH SAstraM prakalpakam#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prakalpaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5367<pc>207-a<k1>aprakASa<k2>aprakASa
{#aprakASa#}¦ I. Tatpur. or Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not
<div n="lb">bright, not clear, dark; e. g. in the {%Hidimb.:%} {#aprakASA diSaH#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvAH#}. <sup>2</sup> Private, secret, not evident, without a witness;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vīramitrodaya:%} (of a deed) {#aprakASAtsAkziyuktaM#}
<div n="lb">{#leKakAkzaramudritam . lokaprasidDaM svakftAdvaramanyakftaM SuBam;#}
<div n="lb">{#aprakASam#} also used as adv.; e. g. {%Kullūka:%} {#pitfgfhe kanyA#}
<div n="lb">{#yaM putramaprakASaM janayettaM kanyApariRetuH putraM nAmnA kAnInaM vadet;#}
<div n="lb">or {#aprakASamutpannaH putraH#}. E. {#a#} neg. or priv. and {#prakASa#}.
<div n="P">II. Tatpur. m. ({#-SaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Want of brightness or clearness,
<div n="lb">darkness, lit. or figur.; e. g. in the comm. of the {%Raghu-%}
<div n="lb">{%vanśa:%} {#so'haM…prakASaScAnDakAraSca lokAloka ivAcalaH#}
<div n="lb">(comm. {#ekasminpArSve prakASayuktaH . aparasminpArSve'prakASayukta#}

<L>5382<pc>207-b<k1>apragama<k2>apragama
{#apragama#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) I. Tatpur. Invincible; or
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Not going well (with others), i. e. going too
<div n="lb">fast to be accompanied by others a long distance. (Both
<div n="lb">interpretations of the word are given in the passage of the
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭṭikāvya:%} {#udapatadviyadapragamaH parE ruciram#} &c. ({%Jayam.%}
<div n="lb">and {%Bharatas.:%} {#parEH SatruBirapragamo'naBiBavanIyaH;#} or {%Jayam.:%}
<div n="lb">{#apragamo'nyezAmityarTAt;#} {%Bharatas.:%} {#parEH saha nAsti prakfzwaM#}
<div n="lb">{#gamanaM yasyetyarTaH . atiSIGragAmitvAt,#} the word {#parEH#} of the
<div n="lb">text depending in the latter interpretation not upon {#apragamaH#}
<div n="lb">but on {#ruciram#} and not meaning then ‘enemy’, but ‘ex-
<div n="lb">cellent’). E. I. {#a#} neg. and {#pragama#} (= {#na pragamyate'sO,#} i. e.
<div n="lb">{#gam#} with {#pra,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}). II. {#a#} priv. and {#pragama#} (i. e. {#pra#}
<div n="lb">and {#gama#}).
<LEND>

<L>5383<pc>207-b<k1>apragalBa<k2>apragalBa

<L>5395<pc>208-a<k1>apraja<k2>apraja
{#apraja#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unborn; e. g. in
<div n="lb">the {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aprajAH santvatriRaH#} ‘may the demons not come
<div n="lb">into existence’ ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#anutpannAH santu#}). <sup>2</sup> Not productive
<div n="lb">(of children), unprolific; e. g. {#mETunam#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-jaH#}) A man who has not begot (children);
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Vṛhaspati%} (as quoted by the {%Vīramitrodaya%}): {#sapiRqa-#}
<div n="lb">{#syAprajasyAMSaM sTAvaraM saptaDAkftam#}.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-jA#}) <sup>1</sup> A female who has not borne (a child); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Vṛddhakātyāyana%} (as quoted in the {%Dāyat.%}): {#pitfByAM cEva#}
<div n="lb">{#yaddattaM duhituH sTAvaraM Danam . aprajAyAmatItAyAM BrAtfgAmi#}
<div n="lb">{#tu sarvadA#}. <sup>2</sup> One who cannot bear, a barren female; e. g.
<div n="lb">in {%Kumārila'%}s {%Mīmānsā Vārtt.:%} {#prajA daSa mAsAngarBaM DftvA#}
<div n="lb">{#ekAdaSamanu prajAyante tasmAdaSvataryo'prajAH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#praja#}. (This word is always {%Tatpur.,%} with the udātta on
<div n="lb">the first syllable, and must not be analyzed as a {%Bahuvr.%}
<div n="lb">of {#a#} priv. and {#prajA,#} for {%Pāṇini%} enjoins V. 4. 122., that the
<div n="lb">latter assumes {%‘always’%} the form {#aprajas,#} and his rule is
<div n="lb">neither contradicted nor restricted by any of his commen-
<div n="lb">tators; the meanings of {#apraja#} and {#aprajas#} will often coin-
<div n="lb">cide in bearing--comp. also {#aprajAtA, apaprajAtA, apra-#}
<div n="lb">{#sUtA--,#} but their difference will be porceived in such in-
<div n="lb">stances as given above, e. g. in {#aSvataryo'prajAH#} when the
<div n="lb">Bahuvr. epithet ‘without progeny’ would alter the sense,
<div n="lb">or in {%Chāṇakya'%}s {#mETunamaprajam,#} since it would be absurd to
<div n="lb">speak of a {#mETuna#} ‘without children’, instead of an unpro-
<div n="lb">lific one.)
<LEND>
[Page208-b+ 56]

<L>5396<pc>208-b<k1>aprajajYi<k2>aprajajYi

<div n="lb">and {#prajajYi#} I. and II.

<L>5408<pc>208-b<k1>aprati<k2>aprati

<L>5430<pc>209-b<k1>apratipatti<k2>apratipatti
{#apratipatti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Want of understanding or
<div n="lb">ascertaining, not understanding, not ascertaining; e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Nyāya Sūtra:%} {#vipratipattirapratipattiSca nigrahasTAnam#} (comm.:
<div n="lb">{#apratipattiH prakftAjYAnam#}); or {%Patanjali%} in the introd. to
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇini:%} {#SabdApratipattiH . SabdAnAM cApratipattiH prApnoti vyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRAcCabdAnpratipadyAmaha iti#}. <sup>2</sup> Confusion, perplexity; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#apratipattirjaqatA syAdizwAnizwadarSanaSrutiBiH#}. <sup>3</sup> Not returning
<div n="lb">(an answer); e. g. {#uttarasyApratipattirapratiBA;#} comp. {#apra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tiBA#}. <sup>4</sup> (In the Mīmānsā philosophy.) A sacrificial act which
<div n="lb">is not immaterial to the performance of a sacrifice (see {#saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#skAra#} and comp. {#apUrva#} I. 1. 2. 1.), one essentially required for
<div n="lb">the completion of the sacrifice. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratipatti#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">confused, perplexed; in the {%Vājas.:%} {#sarpadevajaneByo'prati-#}
<div n="lb">{#padam#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#apratipadam . pratipadyate jAnAtIti pratipat .#}
<div n="lb">{#ataTAviDaM vikalamityarTaH#}). Comp. {#apratipatti#}. E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#pratipad#}.
<LEND>

<L>5435<pc>209-b<k1>apratibanDa<k2>apratibanDa
{#apratibanDa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-nDaH#}) Non-obstruction, non-hin-
<div n="lb">drance; e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#tannirDAraRAniyamastaddfzweH#}
<div n="lb">{#pfTagGyapratibanDaH Palam#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#…karmaPalasidDyapratibanDaH#});
<div n="lb">{#apratibanDena#} ‘without obstruction’; e. g. {#apratibanDena pravarta-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratibanDa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nDaH-nDA-nDam#}) Unobstructed, un-
<div n="lb">impeded.--In {%Law,%} when applied to {#dAya#} ‘inheritance’,
<div n="lb">{%unconditional%} or {%direct,%} viz. such property as devolves in
<div n="lb">direct descent from the father on the son, from the son on
[Page210-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the grandson &c., and is the converse of {#sapratibanDa,#} the
<div n="lb">{%conditional%} or {%collateral%} inheritance, viz. property which
<div n="lb">devolves on the lateral line, the uncle &c. on the condition
<div n="lb">that there be no direct heirs, their existence being the ob-
<div n="lb">struction or impediment, as it were, of the title to the
<div n="lb">property which in the former case arises by birth-right or
<div n="lb">‘without impediment’. [{%Mitākṣara:%} {#sa ca#} (scil. {#dAyo#}) {#dvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#viDaH . apratibanDaH sapratibanDaSca . tatra putrARAM pOtrARAM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#putratvena pOtratvena ca pitfDanaM pitAmahaDanaM ca svaM BavatItyaprati-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDo dAyaH . pitfvyaBrAtrAdInAM tu putrABAve svAmyaBAve ca#}
<div n="lb">{#svaM BavatIti putrasadBAvaH svAmisadBAvaSca pratibanDastadaBAve BrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tftvena ca pitfvyatvena ca svaM BavatIti sapratibanDo dAyaH . evaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tatputrAdizvapyUhanIyaH ..;#} {%Viramitrodaya:%} {#putrAdInAM pitrAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#Dane putratvAdinEva satyapi svAmini pitrAdO janmanEva svatvo-#}
<div n="lb">{#tpatteH sa tezAmapratibanDo dAyaH . svAmisadBAvasyApratibanDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#katvAt . yastu viBaktasyAsaMsfzwino'putrasya mftasya pitfBrAtrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dInAM tadDanarUpo dAyaH sa sapratibanDaH . svAmisadBAvasya prati-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDakasyApagama eva tatra svatvotpatteH#}.] E. {#a#} priv. and {#pratibanDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5439<pc>210-a<k1>apratiBa<k2>apratiBa
{#apratiBa#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-BA#}) <sup>1</sup> Want of boldness. <sup>2</sup> (In the
<div n="lb">Nyāya philosophy.) Want of ready wit or of presence of
<div n="lb">mind, in a discussion, viz. inability of returning an answer,
<div n="lb">although one has understood the argument of the opponent
<div n="lb">(therefore not necessarily the same as {#ananuBAzaRa#} q. v.),
<div n="lb">one of the twenty-two {#nigrahasTAna#} or shortcomings in dis-
<div n="lb">cussion. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratiBA#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-BaH-BA-Bam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not bold. <sup>2</sup> Not
<div n="lb">of ready wit, dull. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pratiBA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5444<pc>210-a<k1>apratiraTa<k2>apratiraTa
{#apratiraTa#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. ({#-TaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A leader in combat, a
<div n="lb">prominent warrior (liter. ‘with incomparable chariots’:
<div n="lb">= {#atulyaraTaH#} or {#mahAraTaH#}). <sup>2</sup> The name of a Ṛṣi, a son
<div n="lb">of Indra and the reputed author of the {%Sāmaveda%} verses
<div n="lb">2. 1199-1225. (= II. 9. 3. 1-9.), but according to some only of
<div n="lb">2. 1199-1212. (= II. 9. 3. 1-5. a. b. or {%Ṛgv.%} 10. 103. or {%Vāj.%} 17.
<div n="lb">33-44. 46.; for {%Vāj.%} 17. 60. see {#pratiraTa;#} see the very careful
<div n="lb">compilation of the names of the poets &c. by {%Benfey%} in his
<div n="lb">ed. of the {%Sāmaveda%}). <sup>3</sup> The name of a descendant of Puru:
[Page210-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">a son of Rantināra and the father of Kaṇva (accord. to the
<div n="lb">{%Viṣṇup.;%} the {%Agni-%} and {%Brāhmapur.%} read his name: Pratiratha).
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-Tam#}) The name of the hymn composed by the
<div n="lb">Ṛṣi Apratiratha; chanting it on journeys is considered an
<div n="lb">auspicious act. E. {#aprati#} and {#raTa;#} (but as the word is udātta
<div n="lb">on the first syllable, it might have to be analyzed perhaps
<div n="lb">as a Tatpur. of {#a#} neg. and {#pratiraTa#}).
<LEND>

<L>5451<pc>210-b<k1>apratizidDa<k2>apratizidDa
{#apratizidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not forbidden,
<div n="lb">not prohibited, e. g. a religious act. <sup>2</sup> (In Grammar.) Not
<div n="lb">accompanied with a particle or word expressing negation,
<div n="lb">as a verb; e. g. in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#kiM kriyApraSne'nupasarga-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapratizidDam#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratizidDa#}.

<L>5452<pc>210-b<k1>apratizeDa<k2>apratizeDa
{#apratizeDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Absence of a prohibition, non-
<div n="lb">prohibition, as of a religious act; e. g. in the {%Jaimini Sūtra:%}
<div n="lb">{#apratizeDo vA darSanAdiqAyAM syAt#}. Comp. also {#paryudAsa#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Absence of negation or contradiction, non-denying (as of
<div n="lb">an argument alleged); e. g. in the {%Nyāya Sūtras:%} {#SabdArTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyavasTAnAdapratizeDaH;#} or {#pratizeDAnupapatteSca pratizedDavyAprati-#}
<div n="lb">{#zeDaH;#} or in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#vijYAnAdiBAve vA tadapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tizeDaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Non-exception (as to a rule); e. g. in the {%Vārttika%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 4. 3.: {#apratizeDo vA yaTA sarvanAmasaMjYAyAm#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> A bad or invalid objection (against an argument), used
<div n="lb">frequently in this sense in the {%Nyāya Sūtras;%} e. g. {#ganDatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyavyatirekAdganDAdInAmapratizeDaH#} ‘(what is said before) is an
<div n="lb">invalid objection, for odours (scents &c.) have no other
<div n="lb">nature than that of odour’. <sup>5</sup> A useless exception, an ex-
<div n="lb">ception which need not have been made; e. g. when {%Kātyā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yana%} criticises the mentioning of the word {#nyubja#} in {%Pāṇini'%}s
<div n="lb">rule VII. 3. 61.: {#nyubjeH kartftvAdapratizeDaH#} ({%Patanjali:%} {#anarTakaH#}
<div n="lb">{#pratizeDo'pratizeDaH#}); or when a successor of {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">criticises the latter for finding fault with {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 4. 110.,
<div n="lb">he says of the {#pratizeDa#} of {%Kātyāyana%} that it is an {#apratizeDa;#}
<div n="lb">and in the same manner he turns into ridicule the criticism
<div n="lb">of {%Kātyāyana%} on {%Pāṇ.%} I. 1. 22.: {#GasaMjYAyAM nadItare pratizeDaH#}
<div n="lb">by substituting for the latter words {#nadItare'pratizeDaH,#}
<div n="lb">when {%Patanjali%} gives the same explanation and {%Kaiyyaṭa%}
[Page211-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">observes: {#na pratizeDa iti pratizeDanakriyA naYA niziDyate .#}
<div n="lb">{#BAzyakArastu vastvarTaM vyAcazwe#}.--E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratizeDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5453<pc>211-a<k1>apratizkuta<k2>apratizkuta

<L>5455<pc>211-a<k1>apratizWa<k2>apratizWa
{#apratizWa#}¦ I. Tatpur. f. ({#-zWA#}) <sup>1</sup> Want of solidity or stability,
<div n="lb">lit. and fig.; e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} on a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#anyaTA va-#}
<div n="lb">{#yamanumAsyAmahe yaTA nApratizWAdozo Bavizyati na hi pratizWi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tastarkaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Want of fame or celebrity. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratizWA#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zWaH-zWA-zWam#}) <sup>1</sup> Without stability,
<div n="lb">unsettled; comp. the instance s. v. {#aparasparasamBUta#}. <sup>2</sup> Fluc-
<div n="lb">tuating, without result, unprofitable. <sup>3</sup> Having no or a
<div n="lb">bad reputation, disreputable.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zWaH#}) The name of a hell (according to the {%Vi-%}
<div n="lb">{%ṣṇupur.%}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#pratizWA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5456<pc>211-a<k1>apratizWAna<k2>apratizWAna
