<L>5457<pc>211-a<k1>apratizWita<k2>apratizWita
{#apratizWita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unfixed, unsettled;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Chhāndogya-Upan.:%} {#apratizWitaM vE kila te dAlBya#}
<div n="lb">{#sAma#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#asaMsTitaM parovarIyaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Not strong, not
<div n="lb">valid; e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} on a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#yasmAnnirAgamAH#}
<div n="lb">{#puruzotprekzAmAtranibanDanAstarkA apratizWitAH saMBavanti#} &c. <sup>3</sup> (In
<div n="lb">Law.) Poor, as a married daughter entitled on the score
<div n="lb">of poverty to her parents' estate; (according to {%Vijnāneśvara%}
<div n="lb">the word would imply: poor {%or childless,%} but the latter qua-
<div n="lb">lification is denied by {%Mitramiśra; Gautama:%} {#strIDanaM duhi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tFRAmaprattAnAmapratizWitAnAM ca;#} {%Mitākṣara:%} {#apratizWitA a-#}
<div n="lb">{#napatyA nirDanA vA;#} {%Vīramitrodaya:%} {#apratizWitA nirDanA . ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyapi strIDanamityuktaM taTApi tulyanyAyatayA pitfDanavizayamapye-#}
<div n="lb">{#tat . banDyatvAdinA saMtAnarahitApratizWiteti tu na yuktam .#}
<div n="lb">{#tasyAH saMtAnamuKenAdfzwopakArABAvena DanahAritvAyogAt#}. On
<div n="lb">one occasion, however, {%Vijnāneśvara%} explains likewise {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#pratizWitA#} merely by {#nirDanA#}. Comp. the following). E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#pratizWita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5458<pc>211-a<k1>apratizWitatva<k2>apratizWitatva
{#apratizWitatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> The same as {#apratizWAna;#} e. g. {%Śan-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara%} on a {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#etadapi hi tarkARAmapratizWitatvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tarkeREva pratizWApyate#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Law.) Poverty; see {#apratizWita#} 3.;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Vīramitr.:%} {#patnyA UrDvaM savarRAdiviSezaRopetapratizWitApra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tizWitoQAnUQAnAM duhitFRAM samavAye prAganUQEva gfhlAti . pitrA#}
<div n="lb">{#BartavyatvAt . tadaBAva UQApratizWitA . BartrA Bartavyatve'pi#}
<div n="lb">{#BarturBaraRAsAmarTyenApratizWitatvAt#}. E. {#apratizWita,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5459<pc>211-a<k1>apratisaNkrama<k2>apratisaNkrama
{#apratisaNkrama#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-maH-mA-mam#}) Having no as-
<div n="lb">sociations with, free from connexion with; as Purusha or
<div n="lb">his <lang n="greek"></lang> (of the Yoga philosophy) who is immutable
<div n="lb">and does not intermix with wordly objects; e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Yoga Sūtra:%} {#citterapratisaMkramAyAstadAkArApattO budDisaMveda-#}
<div n="lb">{#nam#} ({%Bhojadeva:%} {#puruzaScidrUpatvAccittiH . sA apratisaMkramA .#}
<div n="lb">{#na vidyate pratisaMkramo'nyatragamanaM yasyAH sA . taToktA . anyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMkIrReti#} &c.; {%another comm.:%} {#apariRAminI hi BoktfSakti-#}
<div n="lb">{#rapratisaMkramA ca#}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#pratisaNkrama#}.
<LEND>
[Page211-b+ 56]

<L>5460<pc>211-b<k1>apratisaNKyAniroDa<k2>apratisaNKyAniroDa
{#apratisaNKyAniroDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DaH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.)
<div n="lb">Unobserved nullity, cessation (of existence) the process of
<div n="lb">which cannot be perceived; one of the three categories of
<div n="lb">non-existence or cessation of existence (see {#nirUpa#}); for
<div n="lb">the two others see {#pratisaNKyAniroDa#} and {#AkASa;#} {%Śaṅkara%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Vedānta Sūtra%} {#‘pratisaMKyApratisaMKyAniroDAprAptira-#}
<div n="lb">{#vicCedAt’: api ca vEnASikAH kalpayanti budDiboDyaM trayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyatsaMskftaM kzaRikaM ceti . tadapi ca trayam . pratisaMKyApratisaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#KyAniroDAvAkASaM cetyAcakzate . trayamapi cEtadavastu aBAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAtraM nirUpAKyamiti manyante . budDipUrvakaH kila vinASo BA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnAM pratisaMKyAniroDo BAzyate . tadviparIto'pratisaMKyAni-#}
<div n="lb">{#roDaH . AvaraRABAvamAtramAkASamiti#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#pratisaNKyAniroDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5477<pc>212-a<k1>apratIta<k2>apratIta
{#apratIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not encountered,
<div n="lb">unattackable (by enemies), a vaidik epithet, in the {%Ṛgveda,%}
<div n="lb">esp. of Indra; e. g. {#apUruzaGno apratIta SUra#} &c., also of a
<div n="lb">horse; in the {%Vājasan.%} and {%Atharvav.,%} also of {%Viṣṇu%} and
<div n="lb">{%Varuṇa:%} {#apratItA sahoBirvizRU#} &c. <sup>2</sup> Not understood, not
<div n="lb">clearly intelligible, as a word; being {#apratIta#} is according
<div n="lb">to the {%Kāvyaprakāśa%} one of the seventeen, according to the
<div n="lb">{%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} one of the thirteen defects of a word,
<div n="lb">which must be avoided in composition; a word is defined
<div n="lb">as {#apratIta#} in these works, if it is used in a sense which
<div n="lb">it properly has not or may have only in a certain work, as
<div n="lb">if in the sentence {#samyagjYAnamahAjyotirdalitASayatAjuzaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#viDIyamAnamapyetanna BavetkarmabanDanam,#} or in the sentence {#yo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gena dalitASayaH#} the word {#ASaya#} is used in the sense {#vAsanA#}
<div n="lb">which it has only in the Yoga philosophy.--See also
<div n="lb">{#doza#} and {#padadoza#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratIti#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">composition; see the preceding. E. {#apratIta,#} taddh. aff.
<div n="lb">{#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5488<pc>212-b<k1>apratyaya<k2>apratyaya<h>1
I. {#apratyaya#}¦ 1. Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Distrust, want of confidence;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Śihlana:%} {#dozARAM saMniDAnaM kapawaSatamayaM kzetramapratyayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAm#} (scil. {#strIrUpam#}) ‘a woman's figure is…a field for
<div n="lb">all kinds of distrust’. <sup>2</sup> The not being perceived, under-
<div n="lb">stood or intelligible, the not resulting clearly (comp. {#apra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIti#}); e. g. {%Bharatasena:%} {#rAmeRa…SravaRasuKakAriBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rninAdEH kalahaMsamAlAH pratIyire… . ninAdaSrutivyatireke-#}
<div n="lb">{#RApratyaye hetugarBaviSezaRamAha#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Grammar.) <sup>a.</sup> No-affix,
<div n="lb">a letter not being an affix or not belonging to an affix;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#idudupaDasya cApratyayasya#}. <sup>b.</sup> Absence
<div n="lb">of an affix; e. g. the {%Kāśikā%} on the ved. loc. sing. {#carman#} or
<div n="lb">the voc. {#rAjan#} &c., {#nalopapratizeDavacanAdapratyaya iti pratyaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#lakzaRena prAtipadikasaMjYA na pratiziDyate;#} or in the {%Vārtt.%} to
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇini:%} {#apratyaye taTEvezwaH#} ({%Kaiyy.:%} {#pratyayABAve'pi pUrvapado-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttarapadayoranyatarasya vA lopa ityarTaH#}); or {%Patanjali%} on the
<div n="lb">formation {#aBisusU, aBisusUzaterapratyayaH;#} or the same on
<div n="lb">{#anusU, anusUterapratyayaH#} (comp. also the remark under 2. 2.).
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratyaya#}.
<div n="P">2. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Having no confi-
<div n="lb">dence, distrusting; e. g. in the {%Śakunt.:%} {#A paritozAdviduzAM#}
<div n="lb">{#na sADu manye prayogavijYAnam . balavadapi SikzitAnAmAtmanya-#}
<div n="lb">{#pratyayaM cetaH#}. <sup>2</sup> (In Grammar.) Having no affix; e. g. {%Pa-%}
<div n="lb">{%tanjali%} on the word {#pAd, ayamasti pAdayaterapratyayaH pAt;#}
<div n="lb">(as the absence of an affix is in this and similar instances
<div n="lb">the effect of the disappearance of an assumed affix {#v#} which
<div n="lb">is always dropped, {#apratyaya#} and {#vpratyaya,#} or as the latter word
<div n="lb">is written for the sake of euphony {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 2. 52. and VI.
<div n="lb">3. 92: {#vapratyaya,#} become synonyms;--comp. the insertion of
<div n="lb">an {#a#} for a like purpose in the ādeśa {#adq#} and {%Kaiyyaṭa'%}s
<div n="lb">remark on VII. 1. 25.: {#tenoccAraRArTo'kAro dakAramAtraM#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAdeSaH#}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#pratyaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5489<pc>212-b<k1>apratyaya<k2>apratyaya<h>2
II. {#apratyaya#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-yaH#}) (In Grammar.) The affix
<div n="lb">{#a,#} esp. when {#a#} is also the technical name of the affix,
<div n="lb">as in {%Pāṇini;%} e. g. the samās. aff. {#a, fc . pur . ap . Dur .#}
<div n="lb">{#paTin . ityetadantAtsamAsAtsamAsAnto'pratyayaH syAt;#} or the
[Page213-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#a#} (in the {%Kāśikā%} on the word {#BikzA#} of the com-
<div n="lb">pound {#BikzAmAtra#} VI. 2. 14.): {#tatra BikzASabdo guroSca hala#}
<div n="lb">(III. 3. 103.) {#ityapratyayAnto'ntodAttaH#}. (Instead of II. {#apra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyaya,#} however, the commentaries prefer in general the ex-
<div n="lb">pression {#akArapratyaya#}.) E. {#a#} (the letter) and {#pratyaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5490<pc>213-a<k1>apratyayasTa<k2>apratyayasTa
{#apratyayasTa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-sTaH-sTA-sTam#}) (In Grammar.)
<div n="lb">Not being in, not belonging to, an affix; e. g. in the {%Vārtt.%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#tatrApratyayasTasya pratizeDo vaktavyaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#pratyayasTa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5491<pc>213-a<k1>apratyAKyAta<k2>apratyAKyAta
{#apratyAKyAta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Unrefuted, un-
<div n="lb">contradicted. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pratyAKyAta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5492<pc>213-a<k1>apratyAKyAna<k2>apratyAKyAna
{#apratyAKyAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Non-denial, non-refutation &c.;
<div n="lb">see the meanings of {#pratyAKyAna;#} e. g. in the {%Nyāya Sūtra:%}
<div n="lb">{#nityasyApratyAKyAnaM yaTopalabDivyavasTAnAt#}. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#pratyAKyAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>5493<pc>213-a<k1>apratyAKyeya<k2>apratyAKyeya

<L>5507<pc>213-b<k1>apraDAna<k2>apraDAna
{#apraDAna#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Not principal,
<div n="lb">subordinate, secondary; e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#karawako brUte . AvAM#}
<div n="lb">{#tAvadapraDAnO#}.--In most instances, however, the word
<div n="lb">occurs only as a {%neuter%} either as an attribute to a noun or
<div n="lb">absolutely or as part of a compound, in the sense: ‘any
<div n="lb">thing secondary, a secondary object, a secondary act &c.’,
<div n="lb">e. g. in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#sahayukte'praDAne;#} or in the {%Kāsikā%}
<div n="lb">on {%Pāṇ.%} {#(halAdiH SezaH):…apare tu bruvate . SezaSabdo'yaM#}
<div n="lb">{#nivfttyA viSizwamavasTAnamAha . tadavasTAnamuktito yadyapi pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnam . aviDeyattvAttu tadapraDAnam . nivfttireva tu viDeyatvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tpraDAnam;#} or in the {%Kārikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} {#(akaTitaM ca): praDAna-#}
<div n="lb">{#karmaRyAKyeye lAdInAhurdvikarmaRAm . apraDAne duhAdInAM Ryante#}
<div n="lb">{#kartuSca karmaRaH;#} or in {%Bharatas.%} (on {%Vopadeva'%}s {%Sūtra%} {#sahavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRaºº#}) {#sahayogasya praDAnApraDAnatvAviSezokteH#} &c. {#… . na#}
<div n="lb">{#ca pitAputrasaMbanDena praDAnApraDAnatA#} &c., where the affixes
<div n="lb">{#tva#} and {#tal#} belong to the whole compound {#praDAnApraDAna;#}
<div n="lb">or in the {%Jaiminīya-nyāyam.:%} {#praDAnasya prayoktftvamapraDAnapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoktftA#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#praDAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>5519<pc>214-a<k1>apramatta<k2>apramatta

<L>5520<pc>214-a<k1>apramada<k2>apramada
{#apramada#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Joyless, sad; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the following {#yamakAvalI#} (q. v.) of the {%Bhaṭṭik.,%} describing
<div n="lb">the effects of the conflagration of Laṅkā: {#na gajA nagajA#}
<div n="lb">{#dayitA dayitA vigataM vigataM lalitaM lalitam . pramadApramadA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mahatA mahatAmaraRaM maraRaM samayAtsamayAt;#} ‘the excellent
<div n="lb">mountain elephants were not saved, the motion of the birds
<div n="lb">ceased, women (lit. woman) became joyless, struck (as it
<div n="lb">were) by disease (or by flight), in time there came death
<div n="lb">unto the brave, (but) not in battle’; (the commentaries
<div n="lb">divide either {#pramadA apramadA#} the latter = {#pramadarahitA harza-#}
<div n="lb">{#SUnyetyarTaH,#} or {#pramadA pramadA#} the latter = {#pragato mado yasyA#}
<div n="lb">{#iti pramadA harzaSUnyetyarTaH#} i. e. in either case to the same
<div n="lb">effect). E. {#a#} priv. and {#pramada#}.
<LEND>

<L>5521<pc>214-a<k1>apramaya<k2>apramaya
{#apramaya#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) (ved.) Immeasurable,
<div n="lb">infinite; an epithet of the neuter Brahman ({%Śaṅkara:%} = {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#prameya#}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#pramaya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5522<pc>214-a<k1>apramA<k2>apramA
{#apramA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-mA#}) The reverse of {#pramA,#} viz. <sup>1</sup> The same
<div n="lb">as {#apramARa#} I. q. v.; e. g. in {%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaiminīya-nyāyam.:%}
<div n="lb">{#sadAcAro'pramA mA vA nirmUlatvAdamAnatA . azwakAderivE-#}
<div n="lb">{#tasya samUlatvAtpramARatA .. holAkotsavAdisadAcArasya mUlaBU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tavedABAvAdaprAmARyamiti cet .. na#} &c.; or {#guRanAmatvasaMde-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAdapramA codaneti cet . noktanyAyena saMGasya nAmaDeyatvanirRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAt#}. <sup>2</sup> (In the Vaiśeṣika philosophy.) Knowledge which
<div n="lb">is not absolute, viz. knowledge which is either at variance
<div n="lb">with the properties of the thing supposed to be known (see
<div n="lb">{#viparyAsa#}), as if one believes, he knows ‘Soul or Self when
<div n="lb">he attributes to it properties belonging to Body’, or know-
<div n="lb">ledge based on doubt (see {#saMSaya#}), as if one does not know
<div n="lb">whether ‘an object is a man or a post’. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5523<pc>214-a<k1>apramARa<k2>apramARa
{#apramARa#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) No-authority, a rule, injunction,
<div n="lb"> reasoning, saying, precedent &c. which is not binding, no
<div n="lb">standard to be guided by, irrelevancy; (comp. the similar
<div n="lb">terms {#apramA, aprAmARya, amA, amAtva, amAna, amAnatA,#}
<div n="lb">also {#pramARABAsa#}); e. g. in {%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaiminīya-nyāyam.:%}
<div n="lb">{#arTAboDAdapramARaM pikAlamBanacodanA . mEvaM mlecCaprasidDyApi#}
<div n="lb">{#tadboDAdavirudDayA;#} or {#aguRatvAdanAmatvAdamantratvAdananvaye .#}
<div n="lb">{#azwatvAdyapramARaM cennArTavAdatayAnvayAt;#} or in the {%Nyāya S.:%}
<div n="lb">{#roDopaGAtasAdfSyeByo vyaBicArAdanumAnamapramARam,#} or in the
<div n="lb">instance s. v. {#anEkAntikatva;#} or {%Śaṅkara%} in the comm. on
<div n="lb">the {%Bṛhadār.:%} {#yadi tAvadupanizado brahmEkatvapratipattipramAM#}
<div n="lb">{#kurvanti kaTamapramARaM BaveyuH;#} or in a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇini:%} {#tadDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tArTanirdeSe liNgavacanamapramARaM tasyAvivakzitatvAt#} ‘gender
<div n="lb">and number are irrelevant (i. e. not the subject of the rule)
[Page214-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">in the chapter on the derivations with taddhitas &c.’
<div n="lb">({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apramARamiti . tadvaSAtkAryasya viDinizeDO na#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavata ityarTaH#}); or in the {%Śakunt.:%} {#tasyApramARaM vacanaM janasya#}
<div n="lb">‘the word of such a person is no-authority, (where {#apramARam#}
<div n="lb">is not to be considered as a Bahuvr.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramARa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) Immeasurable, im-
<div n="lb">mense, infinite; (the word occurs scarcely in this sense in
<div n="lb">the classical Sanskṛt; comp. the following articles). E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">priv. and {#pramARa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5524<pc>214-b<k1>apramARaSuBa<k2>apramARaSuBa
{#apramARaSuBa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. pl. ({#-BAH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.)
<div n="lb">The name of a class of divinities which belong to the
<div n="lb">second degree of the third dhyāna or contemplation (literally,
<div n="lb">according to the Buddh. interpretation, ‘of immeasurable
<div n="lb">virtue’). E. {#apramARa#} and {#SuBa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5525<pc>214-b<k1>apramARABa<k2>apramARABa
{#apramARABa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. pl. ({#-BAH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.)
<div n="lb">The name of a class of divinities which belong to the second
<div n="lb">degree of the second dhyāna or contemplation (liter. ‘of
<div n="lb">immeasurable splendour’). E. {#apramARa#} and {#ABA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5526<pc>214-b<k1>apramAda<k2>apramAda
{#apramAda#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> Attentiveness, assiduity, vi-
<div n="lb">gilance; e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} in the comm. on the {%Kaṭha-Upan.:%}
<div n="lb">{#na hi budDyAdicezwABAve pramAdasaMBavo'sti . tasmAtprAgeva bu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDyAdicezwoparamAdapramAdo viDIyate;#} or {%Śāntiparv.:%} {#apramA-#}
<div n="lb">{#daSca SOcaM ca rAjYo BUtikaraM mahat;#} or {#apramAdena SikzeTAH kza-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAM budDiM DftiM matim#}. ({%Kullūka%} mentions it as one of the {%five%}
<div n="lb">kinds of {#niyama#} q. v., but differs in this respect from the
<div n="lb">Yoga philosophy where it does not belong to the latter
<div n="lb">notion; comp. {#apramAdatA#}. In the Buddh. {%Dhammapada%} it
<div n="lb">is the subject of the second chapter.) <sup>2</sup> The former personified
<div n="lb">as a son of Dharma (righteousness) who is a son of (the
<div n="lb">masc.) Brahman, by Buddhi (intellect), a daughter of Da-
<div n="lb">ksha, accord. to the {%Linga Purāṇa.%} E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramAda#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Attentive, vigilant,
<div n="lb">assiduous. Comp. {#apramAdam#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#pramAda#}.
<LEND>

<L>5527<pc>214-b<k1>apramAdatA<k2>apramAdatA
{#apramAdatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) Attentiveness, vigilance, assiduity. {%Yā-%}
<div n="lb">{%jnavalkya%} calls it one of the {%ten%} kinds of {#niyama#} q. v.; but
<div n="lb">the Yoga philosophy does not mention it in the definition
<div n="lb">of this term; comp. {#apramAda#} I. E. {#apramAda#} II., taddh. aff. {#tal#}.
<LEND>

<L>5528<pc>214-b<k1>apramAdam<k2>apramAdam
{#apramAdam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. Attentively, watchfully, assiduously;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#sapta fzayaH pratihitAH SarIre sapta rakzanti sada-#}
<div n="lb">{#mapramAdam#}. [The meaning of this word would apparently
<div n="lb">also result from the Bahuvr. {#apramAda#} taken as a neuter in
<div n="lb">the accus., but as the latter is udātta on the last syllable,
<div n="lb">and as {#apramAdam#} is in the Vedas udātta on the first, it
<div n="lb">seems necessary to distinguish both forms etymologically.]
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramAdam#} ({#mad#} with {#pra,#} kṛt aff. {#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>5529<pc>214-b<k1>apramAdin<k2>apramAdin

<div n="lb">{#apramAda#} II. or {#apramatta#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramAdin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5530<pc>214-b<k1>apramAdyat<k2>apramAdyat

<div n="lb">or {#apramatta;#} e. g. {%Yāska,%} in explaining {%Vājas.%} 34. 55.: {#rakzanti#}
<div n="lb">{#sadamapramAdaM saMvatsaramapramAdyantaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramAdyat#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">Immense, very long (comp. {#apramaya#}); in the {%Atharv.:%} {#BadraM#}
<div n="lb">{#puruzajIvanaM kfRotvapramAyukam#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramAyuka#}.

<L>5532<pc>214-b<k1>apramita<k2>apramita
{#apramita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not authoritatively
<div n="lb">established, unproved; e. g. {%Rāmakṛṣṇatīrtha:%} (the {#mahA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAkya#} of the {%Vedānta%} is) {#nApi rAjapuruze rAjAyamitivadO-#}
[Page215-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#pacArikam . apramitaBedayorEkyasyOpacArikatvAnupapatteH#}. <sup>2</sup> Un-
<div n="lb">bounded, unmeasured. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5533<pc>215-a<k1>apramudita<k2>apramudita
{#apramudita#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Not delighted,
<div n="lb">not happy.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) The reverse
<div n="lb">of {#pramudita#} q. v., a technical term to denote the incapacity
<div n="lb">of removing the pains that are produced by any created
<div n="lb">beings viviparous, oviparous, generated by heat and moisture
<div n="lb">or springing from the soil (as men, beasts, tame and wild,
<div n="lb">birds, reptiles, gnats, musquitoes, lice, bugs, fish, alliga-
<div n="lb">tors, trees, stones &c.), by not attending for this purpose
<div n="lb">a holy teacher (the removal of such pains being required
<div n="lb">for the attainment of final liberation); it is amongst the
<div n="lb">seventeen {#budDibaDa#} or obstructions of intellect one of the
<div n="lb">eight which are the converse of the {#sidDi#} or perfections.
<div n="lb">For the other terms of this category see {#atAra#} (Supple-
<div n="lb">ment), {#atAratAra#} (Supplement), {#apramoda, apramodamAna,#}
<div n="lb">{#aramyaka, asadApramudita, asutAra#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramudita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5534<pc>215-a<k1>apramUra<k2>apramUra
{#apramUra#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) (ved.) Not foolish,
<div n="lb">not heedless, prudent. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramUra#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">preceding (of which it occurs as an explanation). E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#pramUrcCita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5536<pc>215-a<k1>apramfzya<k2>apramfzya

<div n="lb">{#pramfzya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5537<pc>215-a<k1>aprameya<k2>aprameya
{#aprameya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Immeasurable,
<div n="lb">unbounded, infinite; e. g. in the {%Lalitav.:%} {#(boDisattvaH)#}
<div n="lb">{#vyavalokayata pUrvadakziRapaScimottarAsvaDa UrDvaM samantAddaSadi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzvaprameyAsaMKyeyAgaRanAsamatikrAntAnboDisattvAn;#} comp. also
<div n="lb">{#aprameyAnuBAva#}. <sup>2</sup> Not to be established or proved from
<div n="lb">authorities (philosophical writings &c.), unproveable, as
<div n="lb">Brahman; e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#tvameko hyasya sarvasya viDAnasya#}
<div n="lb">{#svayaMBuvaH . acintyasyAprameyasya kAryatattvArTavitpraBo#} ({%Kullūka:%}
<div n="lb">{#aprameyasya mImAMsAdinyAyanirapekzatayAnavagamyamAnaprameyasya#});
<div n="lb">or as Viṣṇu; e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#avyaktasyAprameyasya#}
<div n="lb">{#nAnASaktyudayasya ca . na vE cikIrzitaM tAta ko vedAdDA svasaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavam#} ({%Śrīdharasv.:%} {#avyaktasyAta evAprameyasya#}); or as the
<div n="lb">Veda; e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#aSakyaM cAprameyaM ca vedaSAstram#} ({%Kullūka%}
<div n="lb">as before).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name or epithet of Viṣṇu; e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Viṣṇusahasran.:%} {#aprameyo hfzIkeSaH padmanABo'marapraBuH#}. <sup>2</sup> A
<div n="lb">name or epithet of Śiva; e. g. in the {%Śivasahasran.:%} {#atarkyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAprameyAya pramARAya namo namaH;#} or in the {%Vāyu Pur.:%} {#namaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kapAlahastAya…aprameyAya#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prameya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5538<pc>215-a<k1>aprameyAtman<k2>aprameyAtman
{#aprameyAtman#}¦ Bahuvr. m. ({#-tmA#}) A name of Viṣṇu (lit. ‘of
<div n="lb">unproveable spirit’); e. g. in the {%Viṣṇusahasran.:%} {#asaMKye-#}
<div n="lb">{#yo'prameyAtmA viSizwaH SizwakfcCuciH#}. E. {#aprameya#} and {#Atman#}.
<LEND>

<L>5539<pc>215-a<k1>aprameyAnuBAva<k2>aprameyAnuBAva
{#aprameyAnuBAva#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-vaH-vA-vam#}) Of unbounded
<div n="lb">energy; e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.%} (said of Prahrāda): {#apra-#}
<div n="lb">{#meyAnuBAvo'yamakutaScidBayo'maraH#}. E. {#aprameya#} and {#anuBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5540<pc>215-a<k1>apramoda<k2>apramoda
{#apramoda#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-dam#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The reverse of {#pramoda#} q. v., a technical term to denote the
<div n="lb">incapacity of removing the pains that are produced by cor-
<div n="lb">poreal causes (fever, and other disorders of the three tem-
<div n="lb">peramental elements air, bile or phlegm) or by mental causes
[Page215-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(privation of what is liked and approximation of what is
<div n="lb">disliked), by not attending for this purpose a holy teacher
<div n="lb">(the removal of such pains being required for the attain-
<div n="lb">ment of final liberation); it is amongst the seventeen {#budDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#baDa#} or obstructions of intellect one of the eight which are
<div n="lb">the converse of the {#sidDi#} or perfections. Comp. {#apramudita#}
<div n="lb">and the following. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pramoda#}.
<LEND>

<L>5541<pc>215-b<k1>apramodamAna<k2>apramodamAna
{#apramodamAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">The reverse of {#pramodamAna#} q. v., a technical term to denote
<div n="lb">the incapacity of removing the pains that are produced by
<div n="lb">superhuman, i. e. divine or atmospheric influences (cold,
<div n="lb">heat, wind, rain, lightning &c.), by not attending for this
<div n="lb">purpose a holy teacher (the removal of such pains being
<div n="lb">required for the attainment of final liberation); it is amongst
<div n="lb">the seventeen {#budDibaDa#} or obstructions of intellect one of
<div n="lb">the eight which are the converse of the {#sidDi#} or perfections.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#apramudita#} and {#apramoda#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#apramodamAna#}.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>5548<pc>215-b<k1>aprayAvam<k2>aprayAvam
{#aprayAvam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) Assiduously, attentively; ({%Mahīdh.%}
<div n="lb">= {#apramattam#}). E. According to this comm. the word would
<div n="lb">be the acc. neuter of a Bahuvr. {#a#} priv. and {#prayAva,#} but as
<div n="lb">it is udātta on the first syllable it seems more correct to
<div n="lb">derive it from {#a#} neg. and {#prayAvam#} ({#yu#} with {#pra,#} kṛt aff.
<div n="lb">{#Ramul#}).
<LEND>

<L>5549<pc>215-b<k1>aprayukta<k2>aprayukta
{#aprayukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not employed, not
<div n="lb">applied; e. g. in the {%Mīmānsā S.:%} {#nyAyyAni vAprayukte prasaNgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Wrongly used. <sup>3</sup> Not usual, strange, as a word,
<div n="lb">although it may be grammatically correct; e. g. in the {%Vārtt.%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#astyaprayuktaH;#} {%Patanjali:%} {#santi vE SabdA aprayuktAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tadyaTA . Uza tera cakra peceti#} (comp. s. v. {#aprayoga#}) {#. kimato#}
<div n="lb">{#yatsantyaprayuktAH . prayogAdDi BavAYCabdAnAM sADutvamaDyavasyati .#}
<div n="lb">{#ya idAnImaprayuktA nAmI sADavaH syuH . idaM vipratizidDam .#}
<div n="lb">{#yaducyate santi vE SabdA aprayuktA iti yadi santi nAprayuktAH .#}
[Page216-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#aTAprayuktA na santi . santi cAprayuktASceti vipratizidDam#} &c.
<div n="lb">(Compare {#aprayoga#}.) According to the {%Kāvyaprak.,%} being
<div n="lb">{#aprayukta#} is one of the seventeen, accord. to the {%Sāhityad.,%}
<div n="lb">one of the thirteen defects of a word (see {#padadoza#}), which
<div n="lb">must be avoided in composition; e. g. in the sentence:
<div n="lb">{#yaTAyaM dAruRAcAraH sarvadEva viBAvyate . taTA manye dEvato'sya#}
<div n="lb">{#piSAco rAkzaso'Ta vA,#} or in the sentence: {#BAti padmaH#}
<div n="lb">{#sarovare,#} the {%masc.%} forms {#dEvataH#} and {#padmaH#} are {#aprayukta;#} or as
<div n="lb">the {%Kāvyapr.%} says, although the masc. of {#dEvata#} is gramma-
<div n="lb">tically correct, no body uses the word in this gender:
<div n="lb">{#atra dEvataSabdo dEvatAni puMsi veti puMsyAmnAto'pi na kena-#}
<div n="lb">{#citprayujyate#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prayukta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5550<pc>216-a<k1>aprayuktatA<k2>aprayuktatA

<div n="lb">applied. <sup>2</sup> The being unusual or strange; one of the de-
<div n="lb">fects of a word in composition; see the preceding and comp.
<div n="lb">{#aprayoga#}. E. {#aprayukta,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5554<pc>216-a<k1>aprayoga<k2>aprayoga
{#aprayoga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-application, non-use; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Mīmānsā S.:%} {#aprAptA cAnupapattiH prayoge hi viroDaH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAcCabdArTastvaprayogaBUtastasmAdupapadyeta;#} or in {%Pāṇini'%}s {%S.:%}
<div n="lb">{#saMBAvane'lamiti cetsidDAprayoge#} (i. e. if the word {#alam#} is
<div n="lb">not used in the sentence; {%Kāśikā:%} {#sidDAprayoga ityalamo vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SezaRam . sidDaScedalamo'prayogaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Wrong application (as
<div n="lb">of an argument, i. e. arguing, or speaking wrongly); e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Nyāya S.:%} {#na vyAGAtAdaprayogaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Strangeness, un-
<div n="lb">usualness (as of a word), an unusual expression (although
<div n="lb">it be grammatically correct); e. g. in the {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇini:%}
<div n="lb">{#aprayogaH prayogAnyatvAt;#} {%Patanjali:%} {#aprayogaH KalvapyezAM#}
<div n="lb">{#SabdAnAM nyAyyaH#} (comp. the words {#Uza#} &c. in the instance
<div n="lb">s. v. {#aprayukta#} 3.) {#. kutaH . prayogAnyatvAt . yadetezAM SabdAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#marTe'nyAnprayuYjate . tadyaTA . Uzetyasya SabdasyArTe kva yUyamuzi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAH . teretyasyArTe kva yUyaM tIrRAH . cakretyasyArTe kva yUyaM kftavantaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#pecetyasyArTe kva yUyaM pakvavanta iti#}. Comp. {#aprayuktatA#}. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. or deter. and {#prayoga#}.
<LEND>

<L>5555<pc>216-a<k1>aprayojaka<k2>aprayojaka
{#aprayojaka#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jakaH-jikA-jakam#}) Not causing
<div n="lb">to be applicable or to exist, not effecting the applicability
<div n="lb">or existence of; e. g. in the {%Yoga Sūtra:%} {#nimittamaprayojakaM#}
<div n="lb">{#prakftInAM#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prayojaka#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-jakaH-jakA-jakam#}) Not having a
<div n="lb">sufficient cause for being applied, not being properly ap-
<div n="lb">plicable, useless, irrelevant; e. g. {%Mallinātha%} in his comm.
<div n="lb">on the {%Kirāt.:%} {#samarTanIyapraDAnopasarjanaBAvastvaprayojaka iti#}
<div n="lb">{#vyaktavivekakAraH;#} or in the {%Kaṇthābharaṇa:%} {#yadaprayojakaM yacca#}
<div n="lb">{#gatArTaM vyarTameva vA#} (viz. a word) {#. tasyApi kvApi nirdozaH#}
[Page216-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#prayogo dfSyate yaTA;#} or in the {%Jaiminīya-nyāyam.:%} {#na ca kra-#}
<div n="lb">{#meREva tatsidDerliNgamaprayojakamiti vAcyam#} &c.; or in the
<div n="lb">{%Dattakamīm.:%} {#nanvidamaprayojakaM yatpiRqa fkTABAvAdaputra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvamiti#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#prayojaka#}.
<LEND>

<L>5556<pc>216-b<k1>aprayojakatva<k2>aprayojakatva
{#aprayojakatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The being without a sufficient cause, the
<div n="lb">not being properly applicable, irrelevancy, uselessness; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Mīmānsā S.:%} {#aprayojakatvAdekasmAtkriyeraYCezasya guRaBU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tatvAt#} ({%Śabara:%} {#aprayojakatvAt . akasmAtkriyeran . aprayoja-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAni SezakAryARi havizAm#}); or {%Vijnānabh.%} on a {%Sāṅkhya S.:%}
<div n="lb">{#mahadAdikaM sakartfkaM kAryatvAdityAdyanumAnezvaprayojakatvena vyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pyatvAsidDyA neSvare'numAnam;#} or {%Viśvan.%} on a {%Nyāya S.:%}
<div n="lb">{#yatra nAprayojakatvAdyASaNkA tatra nApekzEva;#} or the {%Siddhānta-%}
<div n="lb">{%mukt.:%} {#na ca pratyaBijYAM prati tattAsaMskArasya hetutvena pratyaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#jYAyAH saMskArajanyatvena smftitvApattiriti vAcyam . aprayo-#}
<div n="lb">{#jakatvAt#}. E. {#aprayojaka,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5565<pc>217-a<k1>apravftti<k2>apravftti
{#apravftti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ttiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Not proceeding, not commenc-
<div n="lb">ing, not taking place; e. g. in the {%Mīmānsā Sūtra:%} {#karmaRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#stvapravfttitvAtPalaniyamakartfsamudAyasya#} &c.; or in {%Mādhava'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Jaim.-nyāyam.:%} {#praDAnakarmaRo'nAkANkzitasya vikftAvapravftte-#}
<div n="lb">{#statsaMbadDAH PalAdayo'pyanAkANkzitatvAnnAtidiSyante;#} or in the
<div n="lb">modern compilation of a comm. to {%Pāṇini%} (VIII. 1. 73.):
<div n="lb">{#uttarasUtrasTaM sAmAnyavacanapadaM BAzyakfdBiratra yojitam . paryA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaSabdezvapravfttaye#} ‘that the word {#sAmAnyavacana#} may not take
<div n="lb">place in, i. e. may not be applied to, synonymes of a word’.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Inactivity, inertion; e. g. in the definition of the term
<div n="lb">{#Alasya#} in a comm. of the {%Yoga S.:%} {#AlasyaM kAyacittaguru-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAdapravfttiH#}. <sup>3</sup> (In Medicine.) Stoppage of the natural func-
<div n="lb">tions of the body, as suppression of the evacuations &c.;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {%Suśruta:%} {#taTA majjagate rukca na kadAcitpraSAmyati .#}
<div n="lb">{#apravfttiH pravfttirvA vikftiH Sukrage'nile#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pravftti#}.
<LEND>

<L>5566<pc>217-a<k1>apravfdDa<k2>apravfdDa
{#apravfdDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) Not full grown, not
<div n="lb">very large &c.; see the meanings of {#pravfdDa#}. [N. B. This
<div n="lb">word is mentioned in the modern compilation of a comm.
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇini%} as an instance to the ākritigaṇa {#pravfdDAdi#} (VI. 2.
<div n="lb">147.), when it would be udātta on the last syllable; but it
<div n="lb">occurs neither in the {%Kāśikā,%} nor in the {%Siddhaṇtak.%} and
<div n="lb">its comm., the {%Praudhamanor.,%} nor in {%Nṛsinha'%}s {%Swara-%}
<div n="lb">{%mañjarī;%} and as {%Patanjali%} and his commentators {%Kaiyyata%}
<div n="lb">and {%Nagojibhaṭṭa%} have no gloss on this Sūtra, it becomes
<div n="lb">very doubtful whether the quoted Gaṇa extends to the word
<div n="lb">{#pravfdDa#} in composition with the neg. {#a#}.] E. {#a#} neg. and {#pravfdDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5571<pc>217-a<k1>apraSasta<k2>apraSasta
{#apraSasta#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) I. Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> Not good, in-
<div n="lb">ferior, bad, evil; e. g. in the {%Nalop.:%} {#viBItakaScApraSastaH#}
<div n="lb">{#saMvfttaH kalisaMSrayAt;#} or {%Viṣṇu%} (as quoted in the {%Mitākṣ.%}):
<div n="lb">{#apraSastAstu kAnInagUQotpannasahoQajAH#} &c. (i. e. inferior to
<div n="lb">the {#savarRAH#} sons); or {%Mādhava%} in the {%Jaim.-nyāyam.%} (on
<div n="lb">the choice of a priest belonging to one, two or three Go-
<div n="lb">tras, in the performance of the Darśapūrṇamāsa-sacrifice):
<div n="lb">{#ekavaraRadvivaraRe apraSaste api yadA kartavye . tadA trivaraRasya#}
<div n="lb">{#kartavyatvaM kimu vaktavyamiti stutiH;#} or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#pAnti mitrAvaru-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAvavadyAccayata Imaryamo apraSastAn#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apraSastAn =#}
<div n="lb">{#kzIRAnapi padArTAn#}); or {%Parāśara%} (as quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}):
<div n="lb">{#apraSastaM niSi snAnaM rAhoranyatra darSanAt#} ‘it is not good to
<div n="lb">bathe at night time as Rāhu might see it’.--The neuter
[Page217-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">occurs in {%Manu%} in the sense of {%‘dirt, natural excretion’,%}
<div n="lb">{#apraSastaM tu kftvApsu mAsamAsIta BEkzaBuk#} ({%Kullūka:%} {#apraSastaM#}
<div n="lb">{#mUtrapurIzotsargAdikam#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#praSasta#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Worthless, contemptible; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#indra…viSo dAsIrakfRorapraSastAH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apraSastA#}
<div n="lb">{#garhitAH#}). <sup>2</sup> Without property, poor; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#apraSastA#}
<div n="lb">{#iva smasi praSastimamba naskfDi#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apraSastA iva DanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvAdasamfdDA iva#}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#praSasta#}.

<L>5581<pc>217-b<k1>aprasavaDarmin<k2>aprasavaDarmin

<L>5584<pc>218-a<k1>aprasidDa<k2>aprasidDa
{#aprasidDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not established,
<div n="lb">not fixed. <sup>2</sup> Not generally known, uncommon, unusual;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Kāvyaprakāśa:%} {#kAmasya cakraM loke'prasidDam;#} or
<div n="lb">{#nihatArTaM yaduBayArTamaprasidDe'rTe prayuktam;#} comp. s. v. {#niha-#}
<div n="lb">{#tArTa;#} (in the present ed. of the {%Kirātārj.%} there occurs in
<div n="lb">the comm. on 3. 18. a quotation from the {%Kāvyapr.:%} {#aprasi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDAnuBUtArTavizayastacCabdo yacCabdopAdAnaM nApekzate;#} but the
<div n="lb">present ed. of the {%Kāvyapr.%} reads it p. 77: {#prakrAntaprasidDAºº;#}
<div n="lb">comp. also {%Ballantyne'%}s ed. of the {%Sāhityad.%} p. 216: {#tacCabdasya#}
<div n="lb">{#prakrAntaprasidDAnuBUtArTatve yacCabdasyArTatvam#}); or in the {%Jaim.-%}
<div n="lb">{%nyāyam.:%} {#…vapAvacana urUkaSabdaH . yadyapi vapAyAmaprasidDaH#} &c.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Inconclusive, as a reason; e. g. in the {%Kaṇāda Sūtra:%}
<div n="lb">{#aprasidDo'napadeSo'satsaMdigDaScAnapadeSaH;#} where the term
<div n="lb">{#aprasidDa#} comprehends according to {%Śaṅkara'%}s {%Upaskāra,%} the
<div n="lb">two categories of semblances of reason called {#asidDa#} and
<div n="lb">{#virudDa#} qq. vv.; {%Śaṅkara:%} {#aprasidDa iti . avyApto'gfhIta-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyAptikaSca viparItavyApyatvAsidDavirudDayoH saMgrahaH#}. E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#prasidDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5585<pc>218-a<k1>aprasidDatva<k2>aprasidDatva

<LEND>

<L>5586<pc>218-a<k1>aprasidDi<k2>aprasidDi

<div n="lb">{#rayituM na Sakyate#}); or {#apatyABiDAne strIpuMliNgasyAprasidDirnapuM-#}

<L>5589<pc>218-a<k1>aprastAvika<k2>aprastAvika

<div n="lb">the subject matter (as of a composition); e. g. in the {%Mālatīm.%}
<div n="lb">(Kāmandakī answering the question of Lavaṅgikā: ‘who
<div n="lb">is Mādhava?’): {#aprastAvikI mahatyezA kaTA;#} ({%Wilson%} takes
[Page218-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">the word in the sense ‘requiring no preface’: ‘the story,
<div n="lb">though of import, needs no preface’; {%Theatre of the Hindus%}
<div n="lb">vol. II. p. 36). E. {#a#} neg. and {#prastAvika#}.
<LEND>

<L>5592<pc>218-b<k1>aprastutapraSaMsA<k2>aprastutapraSaMsA
{#aprastutapraSaMsA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-sA#}) (In Rhetoric.) One of the
<div n="lb">{#alaNkAra#} q. v. or elegant modes of composition; viz. implied
<div n="lb">or indirect expression (literally: conveying--the subject
<div n="lb">matter--by what is not the subject matter); more espe-
<div n="lb">cially defined as conveying the subject matter, if it is of a
<div n="lb">specific nature by means of generalisation, or if it is of a
<div n="lb">general kind, by means of specification, or if it is viewed
<div n="lb">as a cause, by stating the effect, or if it is viewed as an
<div n="lb">effect, by stating the cause, or hinting at the subject matter
<div n="lb">by stating what is similar to it, (the latter category being
<div n="lb">divided in two varieties which are again split in two other
<div n="lb">varieties; while each of the named categories may be,
<div n="lb">moreover, threefold, according to whether the expressed
<div n="lb">special or general subject, fact, cause or similarity is of a
<div n="lb">real or imaginary or mixed nature); an instance of the
<div n="lb">second category is the following: {#sragiyaM yadi jIvitApahA#}
<div n="lb">{#hfdaye kiM nihitA na hanti mAm . vizamapyamftaM kvacidBavedamftaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vA vizamISvarecCayA,#} where the {%general%} idea that the will
<div n="lb">of God may turn evil into good and good into evil, is
<div n="lb">conveyed by the special instance of poison and amṛta. E.
<div n="lb">{#aprastuta#} and {#praSaMsA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5593<pc>218-b<k1>aprahata<k2>aprahata

<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Untilled, waste, fallow.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-tA#}) An uncultivated ground, fallow; (according
<div n="lb">to the comm. on the {%Amarak.%}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#prahata#}.
<LEND>

<L>5598<pc>218-b<k1>aprAkfta<k2>aprAkfta

<div n="lb">on sacrificial acts of the Darśapūrnamāsa and the subordi-
<div n="lb">nate rites connected with it, says: {#AstaraRakAryaM vikftO vi-#}

<L>5605<pc>219-a<k1>aprARin<k2>aprARin
{#aprARin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-RI-RinI-Ri#}) Inanimate, lifeless;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#aprARiBiryatkriyate talloke dyUtamucyate#}. (As in
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇini'%}s {%Sūtras%} the neg. {#a#} is sometimes used in compo-
<div n="lb">sition with a noun, when in ordinary writing it would be
<div n="lb">more correct to employ the uncompounded {#na,#} as referring
<div n="lb">to the verb of the sentence, the interpretation of the word
<div n="lb">{#aprARizu#} in VIII. 3. 72. and therefore the bearing of the
<div n="lb">rule itself becomes doubtful; the {%Kāśikā%} takes the Sūtra as
<div n="lb">if it ended: {#na prARizu;#} {%Patanjali%} is less positive, for he ex-
<div n="lb">claims, after showing the possibility of either acceptation:
<div n="lb">{#kiM punaratrArTasatattvam . devA etajjYAtumarhanti;#} but {%Kaiyyaṭa%}
<div n="lb">seems to think that if the gods {%must%} know it, the Paṇḍits may
<div n="lb">have at least an opinion on the matter, viz. that {#aprARizu#} is
<div n="lb">not to be taken there in the sense of {#na prARizu,#} as the unity
<div n="lb">of the Sūtra would become disturbed by such an interpre-
<div n="lb">tation: {#devA iti . paRqitAH paryudAsaM manyante . saMBavatyekavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kyatve vAkyaBedASrayaRasyAyuktatvAt . prasajyapratizeDe hi vAkyaBe-#}
<div n="lb">{#do'vaSyaMBAvI;#} this latter view is also taken by {%Bhaṭṭojid.%})
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#prARin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5609<pc>219-a<k1>aprApta<k2>aprApta
{#aprApta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ptaH-ptA-ptam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not obtained, not
<div n="lb">taken possession of; e. g. in the {%Bhāṣāp.:%} {#aprAptayostu yA#}
<div n="lb">{#prAptiH sEva saMyoga IritaH#} ‘conjunction is called the taking
<div n="lb">possession (mutually) of two objects that did not possess
<div n="lb">each-other (before)’. <sup>2</sup> Not arrived, not taken place, not
<div n="lb">occurred; e. g. in the {%Hitopad.:%} {#aprApte prastAve na vaktumarhasi#}.
[Page219-b+ 56]
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Not authorized, not justified or established by a rule, in-
<div n="lb">junction &c., unproved; e. g. in a {%Pūrvap.%} of an {%Adhikar.%} of
<div n="lb">{%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaimin.-nyāyam.:%} {#prAptasya pravfttiratIteti na tanni-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAraRaM Sakyam . aprAptasya bADAvizayatvenAvasTAnameva nAsti;#}
<div n="lb">or {#vazawkartA hotA . tasya BakzaRaM samAKyayA prAptam . prATamyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaprAptam#} &c.; or in a {%Vārttika%} to {%Pāṇini%} (VI. 3. 10.): {#aprApte#}
<div n="lb">{#samAsaviDAnam#} (the preceding Vārttika having established
<div n="lb">an {#aprAptaviBAzA#} q. v.: {%Patanjali%} on the latter {%Vārtt.:%} {#ki-#}
<div n="lb">{#miyaM prApte viBAzA . AhosvidaprApte .…astu tarhyaprAptA#});
<div n="lb">compare also the following articles {#aprAptabADa#} &c. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#prApta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5610<pc>219-b<k1>aprAptakAla<k2>aprAptakAla
{#aprAptakAla#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> Under age;
<div n="lb">comp. {#aprAptavyavahAra#}. <sup>2</sup> Out of time, not yet im time, in-
<div n="lb">opportune, unseasonable; e. g. in the {%Hitopad.:%} {#aprAptakA-#}
<div n="lb">{#lavacanaM vfhaspatirapi bruvan . prApnuyAdbudDyavajYAnamapamAnaM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#SASvatam;#} comp. {#aprAptAvasara#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-lam#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.) A discussion
<div n="lb">contrary to the order in which it ought to be conducted
<div n="lb">(one of the twenty-two {#nigrahasTAna#} or failures in argumen-
<div n="lb">tation), the regular order of a discussion being ‘first the
<div n="lb">statement and the general argument on the part of the pro-
<div n="lb">poser of the argument, then the reply of the opponent,
<div n="lb">then the defence of the proposer and lastly victory or de-
<div n="lb">feat’. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prAptakAla#}.
<LEND>

<L>5620<pc>220-a<k1>aprAptaviBAzA<k2>aprAptaviBAzA
{#aprAptaviBAzA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-zA#}) (In Grammar, esp. in the com-
<div n="lb">mentaries on {%Pāṇini.%}) An option, enjoined by a rule, if the
<div n="lb">latter does not refer to, and therefore is not a restriction of,
<div n="lb">another, previous or subsequent, rule; it is distinct there-
<div n="lb">fore from the {#prAptaviBAzA#} or the option enjoined by a rule
<div n="lb">which is a restriction of another rule, and the {#uBayatravi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAzA#} or the option enjoined by a rule some portion of
<div n="lb">which is and some portion of which is not a restriction of
<div n="lb">another rule. It follows from this distinction that in {%Pā-%}
<div n="lb">{%ṇini'%}s definition of {#viBAzA#} (I. 1. 44. {#‘na veti viBAzA’#}) both
<div n="lb">terms {#na#} and {#vA#} apply {%simultaneously%} only to the {#prAptavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAzA#} and {#uBayatraviBAzA#} and even more properly to the
<div n="lb">latter alone, while only {#vA#} can be predicated of the {#aprA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ptaviBAzA,#} its purport not being negative with regard to
<div n="lb">another rule but purely optional in itself; {%Patanjali:%} {#tatra#}
<div n="lb">{#yA tAvadaprApte viBAzA tatra pratizeDyaM nAstIti kftvA vetyanena#}
<div n="lb">{#vikalpo Bavizyati . yA hi prApte viBAzA tatroBayamupasTitaM#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati . neti ca veti ca . tatra netyanena pratizidDe vetyanena vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kalpo Bavizyati ..…uBayatraviBAzArTA ceyaM saMjYA . prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ptaviBAzAyAmaprAptaviBAzAyAM ca saMjYAkaraRasyAnupayogAt .#}
<div n="lb">{#taTA hi . prAptaviBAzAsu pakze nivfttiH kriyate pakze tu pravfttiH#}
<div n="lb">{#sTitEva . aprAptaviBAzAsu ca pakze kAryasya pravfttiH kriyate pa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzAntare tvapravfttiH sTitEveti nAsti tatra saMjYAPalam#} &c.…
<div n="lb">({%Nagojibh.:%} {#evaM ca kevalaprAptaviBAzAyAmuBayatraviBAzAyAM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca krameRa nizeDavikalpayorupasTitiH . SudDAprAptaviBAzAyAM#}
<div n="lb">{#tu nizeDasyAnvayAyogyatvAcCudDavikalpopasTitiriti tAtparyam#}
<div n="lb">&c. &c.) Such {#aprAptaviBAzA#} are in {%Pāṇini,%} e. g. in the
<div n="lb">{%Sūtras:%} I. 1. 32, 2. 3, 2. 16, 3. 43; II. 4. 12; III. 1. 38, 1. 61,
<div n="lb">3. 188, 4. 24; VI. 1. 208(?), 2. 161, 3. 59, 3. 72, 3. 106; VII. 3. 9,
<div n="lb">4. 81; VIII. 1. 26, 2. 21; when in consequence of such an in-
<div n="lb">terpretation of the option, the Sūtra I. 2. 16 e. g. becomes dis-
<div n="lb">connected from I. 2. 15, II. 4. 12 from II. 4. 6, III. 1. 61 from
<div n="lb">III. 1. 66, III. 4. 24 from III. 4. 22 &c. &c.--Compare also
<div n="lb">{#prAptaviBAzA, uBayatraviBAzA#} and {#vyavasTitaviBAzA#}. E. {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#prApta#} (in the sense of a locative) and {#viBAzA#}.
<LEND>

<L>5621<pc>220-a<k1>aprAptavyavahAra<k2>aprAptavyavahAra
{#aprAptavyavahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (In law.) A minor, one
<div n="lb">incapable from nonage of conducting his own affairs; (ac-
<div n="lb">cording to {%Kṛṣṇa Tarkal.,%} a boy not more than fifteen
<div n="lb">years old: {#aprAptavyavahArA vAlakAH paYcadaSavarzAdanaDikava-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaskAH;#} according to the {%Mitākṣara,%} a boy under sixteen
<div n="lb">years, the same as {#pOgaRqa#}); his inherited property must
<div n="lb">be confided to the care of relatives or friends; ({%Kātyāyana:%}
<div n="lb">{#aprAptavyavahArARAM DanaM vyayavarjitam . nyaseyurbanDumitrezu#}); he
<div n="lb">is not amenable for the debts of his deceased father, ({%Nā-%}
<div n="lb">{%rada:%} {#aprAptavyavahAraScetsvatantro'pi hi narRaBAk;#}) nor liable
[Page220-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">to arrest or summons, ({#aprAptavyavahAraSca dUto dAnonmuKo#}
<div n="lb">{#vratI . vizamasTaSca nAseDyo na cEtAnAhvayennfpaH#}). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#prAptavyavahAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5622<pc>220-b<k1>aprAptavyavahArakAla<k2>aprAptavyavahArakAla
{#aprAptavyavahArakAla#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-laH#}) (In Law.) The same
<div n="lb">as the preceding. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prAptavyavahArakAla#}.
<LEND>

<L>5624<pc>220-b<k1>aprApti<k2>aprApti
{#aprApti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-ptiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-attainment, non-acquisition; e. g.
<div n="lb">a quot. in the {%Kāvyaprak.:%} {#tadaprAptimahAduHKavilInASezapAta-#}
<div n="lb">{#kA…cintayantI jagatsUtim#} &c. <sup>2</sup> The not taking place,
<div n="lb">the not occurring; e. g. in the {%Vedānta Sūtra:%} {#pratisaMKyApra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tisaMKyAniroDAprAptiravicCedAt#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#aprAptirasaMBava#}
<div n="lb">{#ityarTaH#}); or in the {%Sāṅkhya Sūtra:%} {#nAprAptaprakASakatvamindri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yARAmaprApteH sarvaprAptervA#}. <sup>3</sup> The not being justified or
<div n="lb">established by a rule, injunction, the not being authorized &c.;
<div n="lb">e. g. in a {%Vārttika%} to {%Pāṇini:%} {#yUni cAntarhite'prAptiH,#} or
<div n="lb">{#grAmaRiputrAdizvaprAptiH,#} or {#itve kagrahaRaM saMGAtagrahaRaM cedeti-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAsvaprAptiH;#} or in an {%Adhikar.%} or {%Mādhava:%} {#yaTA deSakA-#}
<div n="lb">{#lakartfdravyARAM pakze'prAptO niyamo vihitaH . evamavaGAto#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi…niyamyate,#} or {#lOkikAgnO hotuM pustakapAWenADigantuM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca SakyatvenADAnopanayanayorakalpane brAhmaRAdInAmaprApteH#} &c.
<div n="lb">Compare {#aprAptatva#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prApti#}.
<LEND>

<L>5625<pc>220-b<k1>aprAptisama<k2>aprAptisama
{#aprAptisama#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-maH-mA#}) (In the Nyāya philosophy.)
<div n="lb">One of the two sophisms on the irrelevancy of the notion
<div n="lb">‘cause’; viz. arguing that if a cause is stated the charac-
<div n="lb">teristics of which cannot be proved--as by saying that
<div n="lb">the Śyena sacrifice inflicts pain on enemies--, such charac-
<div n="lb">teristics prevent a cause from proving the effect, i. e. from
<div n="lb">being a valid cause; ({#‘yadi cAprAptaM liNgaM sADyabudDiM janayati#}
<div n="lb">{#sADyABAvabudDimeva kiM tena na janayet’#}); the refutation is:
<div n="lb">that such a cause is nevertheless valid, since it is an ideal
<div n="lb">cause, mentioned in the Veda.--For the other sophism
<div n="lb">on the irrelevancy of cause see {#prAptisama#}. E. {#aprApti#} and
<div n="lb">{#sama#}. (For the gender of this word and the ellipsis required
<div n="lb">to explain it, see the etym. of {#anityasama#}.)
<LEND>

<L>5633<pc>221-a<k1>aprAyu<k2>aprAyu

<L>5634<pc>221-a<k1>aprAyus<k2>aprAyus

<div n="lb">brilliant vigour; an epithet of Agni whose life or brilliancy
<div n="lb">does not vanish before daylight, although all other beings
<div n="lb">appear, as it were, lifeless during night (according to
<div n="lb">{%Sāyaṇa'%}s interpretation of {%Ṛgv.%} I. 127. 5.). E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#prAyus#}.
<LEND>

<L>5636<pc>221-a<k1>apriya<k2>apriya
{#apriya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unkind, un-
<div n="lb">friendly; e. g. in the {%Taittirīya-Up.:%} {#pari ye'priyA BrAtfvyAH#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Disliked, disagreeable, offensive; e. g. in the {%Hitopad.:%}
<div n="lb">{#na strIRAmapriyaH kaScitpriyo vApi na vidyate . gAvastfRami-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAraRye prArTayanti navaM navam;#} or {#apriyasyApi paTyasya pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAmaH suKAvahaH;#} or in the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#UrDvaM mriye muhUrtAdDi#}
<div n="lb">{#vihvalaH kzatabAnDavaH . mantre sma hitamAKyAmi na karomi tavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#priyam;#} or in {%Gaurapāda%} on the {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#priyasamAga-#}
<div n="lb">{#mApriyaparihArakawutiktakazAyAdikvATAdiBirdfzwa eva ADyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tmikopAyaH#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A foe, an enemy. <sup>2</sup> The name of a
<div n="lb">Yaksha (in Buddhistic mythology).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-yA#}) A sort of skeat (Silurus pungentissimus).
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#priya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5637<pc>221-a<k1>apriyaMvada<k2>apriyaMvada

<L>5641<pc>221-a<k1>apriyavAdin<k2>apriyavAdin

<L>5642<pc>221-a<k1>aprIti<k2>aprIti
{#aprIti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Absence of affection, aversion
<div n="lb">enmity ({%Mallinātha:%} {#aparAgo'prItirdvezaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Pain, grief.
[Page221-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">--In the {%Śaṅkhya philosophy%} {#aprIti#} ‘pain’ is the essential
<div n="lb">characteristic of the elementary quality {#rajas#} q. v., the
<div n="lb">middle quality between clearness (goodness) and darkness
<div n="lb">(sinfulness); {%Sāṅkhya Sūtra:%} {#prItyaprItivizAdAdyErguRAnAma-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyonyaM vEDarmyam;#} {%Gaurapāda%} on the {%S. Kār.:%} {#aprItyAtmakaM rajaH;#}
<div n="lb">but the term ‘pain’ is there, according to the commenta-
<div n="lb">tors, a general term which comprises besides its own notion
<div n="lb">that of {%hatred, violence, envy, abuse%} and {%wickedness,%} or various
<div n="lb">kinds of {%grief%} in general: {%Sāṅkhya Chandrikā:%} {#aprItirduHKa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mupalakzaRaM pradvezadrohamatsaranindAnikftInAm;#} {%Vijnānāch.:%} {#rajo#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi SokAdinAnABedaM samAsataH duHKAtmakam;#} in a similar
<div n="lb">manner {%Manu,%} who names however {#duHKa#} and {#aprIti#} as
<div n="lb">two distinct qualities connected with {#rajas,#} the first, as it
<div n="lb">were, as the quality inherent in it, the second as the effect
<div n="lb">produced by it, while the term {#aprIti#} is used by the
<div n="lb">Sāṅkhya writers in either acceptation; {%Manu:%} {#yattu duHKasa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAyuktamaprItikaramAtmanaH . tadrajaH#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prIti#}.
<LEND>

<L>5643<pc>221-b<k1>aprItikara<k2>aprItikara
{#aprItikara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rI-ram#}) <sup>1</sup> Unkind, adverse,
<div n="lb">offensive. <sup>2</sup> Causing pain; (the essential characteristic of
<div n="lb">the quality {#rajas#} q. v.; see the preceding). E. {#aprIti#}
<div n="lb">and {#kara#}.
<LEND>

<L>5644<pc>221-b<k1>aprItyAtmaka<k2>aprItyAtmaka
{#aprItyAtmaka#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-tmakaH-tmikA-tmakam#}) Having
<div n="lb">the nature of pain, being pain itself; (the essential charac-
<div n="lb">teristic of the quality {#rajas#} q. v.; see {#aprIti#}). E. {#aprIti#}
<div n="lb">and {#Atman,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5645<pc>221-b<k1>aprIyamARa<k2>aprIyamARa
{#aprIyamARa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) Not being pleased
<div n="lb">or propitiated. (A various reading of a Ms. of the {%Kāśikā%}
<div n="lb">instead of {#aDriyamARa#} which results from the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%}
<div n="lb">VI. 2. 160., when the word in a {%conventional meaning%} would
<div n="lb">be udātta on the last syllable, instead of being udātta on
<div n="lb">the first; but this meaning is not mentioned). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#prIyamARa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5646<pc>221-b<k1>apretarAkzasI<k2>apretarAkzasI

<L>5649<pc>221-b<k1>aprokzita<k2>aprokzita
{#aprokzita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Not sprinkled; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Śatapath.:%} {#dvO prokzitO yUpaSakalO BavataH . dvAvapro-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzitO . prokzitaM cEvADvaryurAdatte'prokzitaM cEvameva pratiprasTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA#} &c. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prokzita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5650<pc>221-b<k1>aprowa<k2>aprowa
{#aprowa#}¦ Tatpur. (?) m. ({#-waH#}) The skylark (= {#BAradvAja#}). E.?
<LEND>

<L>5651<pc>221-b<k1>aprozivas<k2>aprozivas
{#aprozivas#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-zivAn-zuzI-zivat#}) Not gone
<div n="lb">away, always present or near; a vaidik epithet of Agni
<div n="lb">({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#sarvadA saMnihitaH#} or {#sarvadA vartamAnaH#}). E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#prozivas#}.
<LEND>

<L>5652<pc>221-b<k1>aprOQa<k2>aprOQa
{#aprOQa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-QaH-QA-Qam#}) Not bold, gentle,
<div n="lb">timid; e. g. in the {%Rājataraṅg.:%} {#ekAkinIM rahaH kzIvAM labDvA#}
<div n="lb">{#durlaBayozitam . aprOQo'nupaBujyAnyadine dUtyArTayeta yaH#}.
[Page222-a+ 56]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-QA#}) An unmarried girl, or one very recently
<div n="lb">married and not come to womanhood. E. {#a#} neg. and {#prOQa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5653<pc>222-a<k1>aplava<k2>aplava

<div n="lb">{#a#} priv. and {#plava#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">protracted (as a vowel; see {#pluta#}); e. g. in {%Pāṇini:%} {#ato#}
<div n="lb">{#roraplutAdaplute#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#pluta#}.

<L>5656<pc>222-a<k1>apvA<k2>apvA
{#apvA#}¦ f. ({#-pvA#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Disease. <sup>2</sup> Danger ({%Yāska:%} {#vyADirvA#}
<div n="lb">{#BayaM vA#}). <sup>3</sup> The throat ({%Uṇṇādikoṣa:%} {#…apvA tu strI#}
<div n="lb">{#kaRWadeSake#}). E. According to {%Yāska%} and {%Mahīdhara,%} a Tatpur.
<div n="lb">of {#apa#} (with the loss of the final {#a#}) and {#vA,#} kṛt aff. {#qa,#}
<div n="lb">‘because it removes happiness and life’; for the third
<div n="lb">meaning the comm. of the {%Uṇnādik.%} gives the etym. {#Ap#}
<div n="lb">(shortened to {#ap,#} but see the etym. of {#apta#}), uṇ. aff. {#va#}
<div n="lb">(which would correspond with the uṇ. aff. {#kvan#} of the {%Uṇ.%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtras%}). Neither etym. is very probable.
<LEND>

<L>5657<pc>222-a<k1>apsa<k2>apsa
{#apsa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) (ved.) I. Spending water; (according
<div n="lb">to {%Mahīdh.%} on the {%Vājas.%} verse: {#pfTivyAH purIzamasyapso#}
<div n="lb">{#nAma,#} viz. {#apaH sanoti dadAtyapso nAmApAM kAraRIBUto rasaSca#}
<div n="lb">{#tvamasi,#} when the mascul., although used in addressing the
<div n="lb">{#izwakA,#} would require the ellipsis of {#rasa#}). E. {#ap#} and {#sa#}.
<div n="P">II. Not destroying, protecting; (according to {%Mahīdhara%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Vājas.%} verse: {#agneH purIzamapso nAma,#} viz. {#psA BakzaRe .#}
<div n="lb">{#na psAti Bakzayati vinASayatItyapso rakzako nAma yo'gni-#}
<div n="lb">{#stasya#} &c., when the mascul. requires the ellipsis of {#agni;#}
<div n="lb">comp. also {%Nirukta%} 5. 13.). E. {#a#} neg. and {#psa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5658<pc>222-a<k1>apsara<k2>apsara
{#apsara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) An aquatic animal; e. g. in {%Manu:%}
<div n="lb">{#trIRyAdIni#} (scil. {#durgARi#}) {#ASritAstezAM mfgagartASrayApsarAH#}
<div n="lb">(comp. the remark s. v. {#apcara#}). E. {#ap#} and {#sara,#} ‘moving
<div n="lb">in the water’.
<LEND>

<L>5659<pc>222-a<k1>apsaraHpati<k2>apsaraHpati
{#apsaraHpati#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-tiH#}) Indra (the Lord of the Apsa-
<div n="lb">rasas); comp. {#apsarApati#}. E. {#apsaras#} and {#pati#}.
<LEND>

<L>5660<pc>222-a<k1>apsaras<k2>apsaras
{#apsaras#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-rAH#}) The name of female divinities,
<div n="lb">not often met with in the three Vedas, but frequently in the
<div n="lb">classical poetry:
<div n="P"><sup>a.</sup> The {%Sāmaveda%} makes no mention of them; the {%Ṛgveda%}
<div n="lb">names as such Urvaśī, (the {%Anukram.%} of the {%Ṛgv.%} two
<div n="lb">Apsarasas Śikhaṇḍinī as authoresses of a hymn); in the {%Vā-%}
<div n="lb">{%jasan. S.%} of the {%Yajurveda%} there occur five pairs of Apsarasas:
<div n="lb">Puñjikasthalā and Kratusthalā, Menakā and Śahajanyā,
<div n="lb">Pramlochantī and Anumlochantī, Visvāchī and Ghṛtāchī,
<div n="lb">Urvaśī and Pūrvachitti; in the {%Śatapathabr.,%} Śakuntalā and
<div n="lb">Urvaśī; in the {%Atharvaveda,%} Ugrampaśyā, Ugrajit and Rā-
<div n="lb">ṣṭrabhṛt. In the {%Ādiparvan%} of the {%Mahābhārata%} several of
<div n="lb">these divinities are enumerated under two heads, the first
<div n="lb">comprising: Anūchānā ({%v. l.%} Anūnā, another Ms. Anṛṇā),
<div n="lb">Anavadyā, Guṇamukhyā ({%v. l.%} Priyamukhyā), Guṇāvarā
<div n="lb">({%v. l.%} Gaṇāvarā), Adrikā ({%v. l.%} Attikā), Somā ({%v. l.%} Sāchī),
<div n="lb">Miśrakeśī, Alambuṣā, Marīchi, Śuchikā ({%v. l.%} Iṣukā),
<div n="lb">Vidyutparṇā, Tilottamā ({%v. l.%} Tulā and Anaghā), Ambikā,
[Page222-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">Lakṣaṇā, Kṣemā, Devī, Rambhā, Manoramā [{%v. l.%} Mano-
<div n="lb">harā, or devī ‘divine’ and manoramā (or manoharā) ‘beauti-
<div n="lb">ful’ are perhaps epithets of Rambhā], Asitā, Subāhu, Su-
<div n="lb">priyā, Vapus ({%v. l.%} Suvapus), Puṇḍarīkā, Sugandhā, Su-
<div n="lb">rasā ({%v. l.%} Surathā), Pramāthinī, Kāmyā and Śāradvatī;
<div n="lb">the second comprising the following eleven: Menakā, Saha-
<div n="lb">janyā, Karṇikā ({%v. l.%} Parṇini), Puñjikasthalā, Ṛtusthalā
<div n="lb">({%v. l.%} Kratusthalā), Ghṛtāchī, Viśvāchī, Pūrvachitti ({%v. l.%}
<div n="lb">Viprachitti), Umlochā, Pramlochā ({%v. l.%} Pramlā) and Ur-
<div n="lb">vaśī. ({%Hemachandra%} mentions two Apsaras Saudāminī and
<div n="lb">Chitrā; other names too, will occur in the following.)
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> As regards their origin, the {%Rāmāyaṇa%} makes them
<div n="lb">arise from the Ocean when it was churned by the gods for
<div n="lb">obtaining the Amṛta; {%Manu%} represents them as one of the
<div n="lb">creations of the seven Manus, themselves created by the
<div n="lb">seven Prajāpatis Marīchi, Atri &c.; in the later mythology
<div n="lb">they are daughters of Kaśyapa by Muni (e. g. according to
<div n="lb">the {%Viṣṇu-%} and {%Bhāgav. Pur.%}), or by Vāch (according to
<div n="lb">the {%Padma P.%}), or some by Muni, some by Prādhā, while
<div n="lb">a third class is created by the mere will of Kaśyapa; thus,
<div n="lb">according to the {%Harivanśa,%} the daughters of K. and Prādhā
<div n="lb">are: Anavadyā, Anūkā, Anūnā ({%v. l.%} Aruṇā), Aruṇapriyā,
<div n="lb">Anugā, Subhagā, (two names seem omitted); of K. and
<div n="lb">Muni: Alambuṣā, Miśrakeśī, Puṇḍarīkā, Tilottamā, Su-
<div n="lb">rūpā, Lakṣmaṇā, Kṣemā, Rambhā, Manoramā (or ‘the
<div n="lb">beautiful Rambhā’), Asitā, Subāhu, Suvrittā, Sumukhī,
<div n="lb">Supriyā, Sugandhā, Surasā ({%v. l.%} Suramā), Pramāthinī,
<div n="lb">Kāmyā ({%v. l.%} Kāśyā) and Śāradvatī; those created by the
<div n="lb">will of the Prajāpati and called the {%vaidik%} Apsarasas are:
<div n="lb">Menakā, Sahajanyā, Parṇinī ({%v. l.%} Parṇikā), Puñjikasthalā,
<div n="lb">Ghṛtasthalā, Ghṛtāchi, Visvāchī, Urvaśī, Anumlochā,
<div n="lb">Pramlochā and Manovatī. (The two Śikhaṇdinī of the
<div n="lb">{%Anukr.%} of the {%Ṛgv.%} are also daughters of K.)--Another
<div n="lb">and more elaborate list is that of the {%Vāyu-Purāṇa.%} [It is
<div n="lb">omitted in two E. I. H. Mss. of this P. and very incorrect
<div n="lb">in four other Mss. that I consulted, belonging severally
<div n="lb">to the E. I. H., the R. A. S. and the R. S.; in some in-
<div n="lb">stances, as Miśrakeśī instead of Mitrakeśī, Puñjikasthalā
<div n="lb">p. Puñjakastanā, Kratusthalā p. Vṛtastanā &c. the cor-
<div n="lb">rection appeared safe, in others it was preferable to give
<div n="lb">the doubtful reading.] This Purāṇa mentions in the first
<div n="lb">place thirty-four Apsarasas, called the Gandharva-Apsarasas
<div n="lb">or wives of the Gandharvas, and daughters of Kaśyapa by
<div n="lb">Muni (but the Mss. in question give only twenty-nine, or
<div n="lb">if Devī and Manoramā are proper names, thirty-one names):
<div n="lb">Antachārā, Daśavadyā(?), Priyaśiṣyā, Surottamā, Miśra-
<div n="lb">keśī, Śāchī, Piṇḍinī ({%v. l.%} Parṇinī), Alambuṣā, Mārīchi,
<div n="lb">Śuchikā, Vidyudvarṇā, Tilottamā, Adrikā, Lakṣaṇā(?),
<div n="lb">Devī, Rambhā, Manoramā (or: the divine, beautiful Rambhā),
<div n="lb">Sucharā, Subāhū, Sūrṇitā (?, Sūnṛtā ?), Supratiṣṭhitā, Pu-
<div n="lb">ṇḍarīkā, Akṣagandhā ({%v. l.%} Sugandhā), Sudantā, Surasā, He-
<div n="lb">mā, Śāradvatī, Suvrittā, Kamalāchayā, Subhujā, Hansapādā;
<div n="lb">these are called the {%laukikī%} or {%worldly%} Apsarasas; then six
<div n="lb">daughters of Gandharvas: Suyaśā, Gāndharvī, Vidyāvatī,
<div n="lb">Aśvavatī, Sumukhī, Varānanā; and four daughters of Suyaśā,
<div n="lb">also called Apsaras: Lauheyī, Bharatā, Kṛśāṅgī ({%v. l.%} Kṛ-
[Page223-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">ṣṇāṅgī) and Viśālā; then eight daughters of Kaśyapa by
<div n="lb">Ariṣṭā: Anavadyā, Anavaśā, Atyantamadanapriyā, Surūpā,
<div n="lb">Subhagā, Bhāsī, Manovatī and Sukeśī; then the {%daivati%} or
<div n="lb">{%divine%} Apsarasas: Vedakā (sic, but {%v. l.%} Menakā), Sahajanyā,
<div n="lb">Parṇinī, Puñjikasthalā, Kratusthalā, Ghṛtāchī, Viśvāchī,
<div n="lb">Pūrvachitti, Pramlochā, Anumlochantī, to whom are added
<div n="lb">Urvaśī, born from the thigh of Nārāyaṇa, and Menakā
<div n="lb">the daughter of Brahman. Besides these the {%Vāyu-P.%} men-
<div n="lb">tions fourteen Gaṇas or classes of Apsarasas: 1. The Śobha-
<div n="lb">yantyas, produced by the mind (manas) of Brahman, 2. the
<div n="lb">Vegavatyas born in heaven (? the Mss. {#svarizwAH#}), 3. the
<div n="lb">Ūryās (?, perhaps Ūrjas, comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 41.), produced by
<div n="lb">Agni (comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 38.), 4. the Āyuvatyas, by the Sun
<div n="lb">(comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 39.), 5. the Śubhañcharās, by Wind (comp.
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.%} 18. 41.), 6. the Kuravas(?), by the Moon (Mss.: {#…#}
<div n="lb">{#somasya jYeyAste kuravaH SuBAH;#} perhaps their name is Bheku-
<div n="lb">rayas, as occurring also in another passage of one Ms.;
<div n="lb">comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 40.), 7. the Śubhās (?), by Sacrifice (; their
<div n="lb">name is perhaps Stāvās, comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 42.), 8. the Vahna-
<div n="lb">yas (? perhaps Eṣṭayas, comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 43.), by the Rich-
<div n="lb">and Sāman-verses, 9. the Amṛtās, by Amṛta, 10. the Mu-
<div n="lb">das by Water; (three Mss. have {#vAyutpannAH#} and one Ms.
<div n="lb">{#vAyUtpannAH#} which however must be corrected {#vAryutpannAH,#}
<div n="lb">since {#vAyujAH#} occurs under 5; comp. {%Vājas.%} 18. 38), 11. the
<div n="lb">Bhavās(?), by the Earth, 12. the Ruchas, by Lightning,
<div n="lb">13. the Bhairavās, by Death (comp. {%Vājas.%} 24. 37.) and 14.
<div n="lb">the Śoṣayantyas, by Love; (this list is probably meant
<div n="lb">by the author of the Kādambarī, who--ed. Calc. p. 122--
<div n="lb">professes to give fourteen classes of Apsarasas, but, in fact,
<div n="lb">only names thirteen, fathering moreover one class on Da-
<div n="lb">ksha).--The {%Harivanśa%} (v. 6798) speaks of seven Gaṇas
<div n="lb">of Apsarasas, but, without naming them. {%Vyādi,%} ad quoted
<div n="lb">in a comm. on Hemachandra, mentions an Apsaras Prabhāvatī
<div n="lb">as born from a hole in the ground for receiving the fire con-
<div n="lb">secrated to Brahman, Vedavatī as born from an altar-ground,
<div n="lb">Sulochanā from Yama, Urvaśī from the left thigh of Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb">Rambhā from the mouth of Brahman, Chitralekhā from
<div n="lb">his hand, and from his head Mahāchittā, Kākalikā, Mā-
<div n="lb">rīchī, Sūchikā, Vidyutparṇā, Tilottamā, Adrikā, Lakṣaṇā,
<div n="lb">Kṣemā, the divine and beautiful Rāmā (or Divyā, Rāmā,
<div n="lb">Manoramā), Hemā, Sugandhā, Suvasu, Subāhū, Suvratā,
<div n="lb">Asitā, Śāradvatī, Puṇḍarīkā, Surasā, Sūnṛtā, Suvātā,
<div n="lb">Kāmalā, Hansapadī, Sumukhī, Menakā, Sahajanyā, Parṇinī,
<div n="lb">Puñjikasthalā, Ṛtusthalā, Ghṛtāchī and Viśvāchī.
<div n="P"><sup>c.</sup> Originally these divinities seem to have been personi-
<div n="lb">fications of the vapours which are attracted by the Sun
<div n="lb">and form into mist or clouds; their character may be thus
<div n="lb">interpreted in the few hymns of the Ṛgveda where mention
<div n="lb">is made of them. At a subsequent period when the Gan-
<div n="lb">dharva of the Ṛgveda who personifies there especially the
<div n="lb">Fire of the Sun, expanded into the Fire of Lightning, the
<div n="lb">rays of the Moon and other attributes of the elementary
<div n="lb">life of heaven as well as into pious acts referring to it, the
<div n="lb">Apsarasas become divinities which represent phenomena or
<div n="lb">objects both of a physical and ethical kind closely associated
<div n="lb">with that life; thus in the {%Yajurveda%} Sunbeams are called
[Page223-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">the Apsarasas associated with the Gandharva who is the Sun;
<div n="lb">Plants are termed the Apsarasas associated with the Gan-
<div n="lb">dharva Fire: Constellations are the Apsarasas of the Gan-
<div n="lb">dharva Moon: Waters the A. of the G. Wind: Sacrificial gifts
<div n="lb">the A. of the G. Sacrifice: Rich- and Sāman hymns the A.
<div n="lb">of the G. Manas (creating will); in another passage of the
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.%} Fire is connected ({%Mahīdhara:%} in the two months
<div n="lb">of Vasanta or spring) with the two Apsarasas Puñjikasthalā
<div n="lb">and Kratusthalā (considered by the comm. as personifi-
<div n="lb">cations of a principal and an intermediate point of the com-
<div n="lb">pass), Wind (Viswakarman) with Menakā and Sahajanyā
<div n="lb">({%comm.:%} in the two months of Grīṣma or the hot season),
<div n="lb">Sun (Viśvavyachas) with Pramlochantī and Anumlochantī
<div n="lb">({%comm.:%} in the two months of Varṣā or the rainy season),
<div n="lb">Sacrifice (Samyadvasu) with Viśvāchī and Ghṛtāchī ({%comm.:%}
<div n="lb">in the two months of Śarad or the sultry season), Parjanya
<div n="lb">(Arvāgvasu) with Urvaśī and Pūrvachitti ({%comm.:%} in the
<div n="lb">two months of Hemanta or the cold season).--This latter
<div n="lb">idea becomes then more systematized in the {%Purāṇas,%} when
<div n="lb">a description is given of the Genii that attend the chariot
<div n="lb">of the Sun in its yearly course; thus the {%Bhāgavata P.%}
<div n="lb">mentions that besides the Ṛṣis, Gandharvas &c. also one
<div n="lb">Gaṇa or troup of Apsarasas pays adoration to the Sun every
<div n="lb">month; and the {%Viṣṇu P.,%} that among the Genii who pre-
<div n="lb">side each in every month over the chariot of the Sun, Kra-
<div n="lb">tusthalā performs this function in the month Madhu, Punji-
<div n="lb">kasthalā in the month Mādhava, Menā in Śuchi, Sahajanyā
<div n="lb">in Śukra, Pramlochā in Nabhas, Anumlochā in Bhādra-
<div n="lb">pada, Ghṛtachī in Āsvina, Visvāchī in Kārttika, Urvaśī
<div n="lb">in Agrahāyaṇa, Pūrvachitti in Pausha, Tilottamā in Māgha,
<div n="lb">Rambhā in Phālguna; an analogous description is given in
<div n="lb">the {%Vāyu P.%} with the only difference that Viprachitti takes
<div n="lb">the place of Pūrvachitti, apparently with less correctness,
<div n="lb">as this account is a strict developement of the quoted pas-
<div n="lb">sage of the Yajurveda ({%Vājas.%} 15. 15-19.). In the last my-
<div n="lb">thological epoch when the Gandharvas have saved from
<div n="lb">their elementary nature merely so much as to be the musi-
<div n="lb">cians in the paradise of Indra, the Apsarasas appear amongst
<div n="lb">other subordinate deities which share in the merry life of
<div n="lb">Indra's heaven, as the wives of the Gandharvas, but more
<div n="lb">especially as wives of a licentious sort, and they are pro-
<div n="lb">mised therefore, too, as a reward to heroes fallen in battle
<div n="lb">when they are received in the paradise of Indra; and while,
<div n="lb">in the Ṛgveda, they assist Soma to pour down his floods,
<div n="lb">they descend in the epic literature on earth merely to shake
<div n="lb">the virtue of penitent Sages and to deprive them of the
<div n="lb">power they would have otherwise acquired through un-
<div n="lb">broken austerities.--To this association of the ethical with
<div n="lb">the physical element in the character of the Apsarasas
<div n="lb">belongs also that view expressed by {%Manu,%} according to
<div n="lb">which the Soul in its transmigrations is reborn as Apsaras
<div n="lb">when it was in its previous existence under the influence of
<div n="lb">rajas or passion; and probably too the circumstance, that in
<div n="lb">the {%Atharvaveda%} they are fond of dice, and three Apsarasas,
<div n="lb">whose names are given above, are supposed to have the
<div n="lb">power of removing faults committed at gambling with dice.
[Page224-a+ 56]
<div n="P">The word occurs also in the form {#apsarA,#} and may be
<div n="lb">written, besides, {#apssaras#} accord. to {%Kātyāyana,%} or {#aPsaras#}
<div n="lb">accord. to {%Pauṣkarasādi;%} (these latter forms however are not
<div n="lb">varieties of the form {#apsaras,#} but the consequence of general
<div n="lb">Sandhi rules; the first is given as an instance by {%Patanjali,%}
<div n="lb">the latter by the {%Kāśikā%}). E. {#ap#} and {#saras#} ({#sf,#} uṇ. aff.
<div n="lb">{#asi#}), {%liter.%} ‘coming from the waters’ ({%Rāyam.:%} {#vAruRapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnatvAdadByaH sftA ityapsarasaH#}); this is the most probable
<div n="lb">E.; it is given also by {%Yāska%} who mentions besides an im-
<div n="lb">probable one by {%Śākapūṇi,%} viz. from {#apsas#} ‘form, beauty’
<div n="lb">which he completes by adding the latter part of the comp.,
<div n="lb">{#ras#} (from {#rA#}), when the word would mean according to
<div n="lb">him, ‘a woman endowed with beauty ({#rUpavatI#})’ or ‘one
<div n="lb">by whom beauty is taken ({#tad#}--scil. {#rUpam--anayAttam#})’
<div n="lb">or ‘one to whom beauty is given ({#tadasyE dattam#})’; a similar
<div n="lb">E. is intended by the passage of the {%Śatapath.%} (IX. 4. 1. 4.):
<div n="lb">{#ganDarvApsaraso hi BUtvodakrAmannaTo ganDena ca vE rUpeRa ca ga-#}
<div n="lb">{#nDarvApsarasaScaranti,#} on which the comm. of {%Sāyaṇa%} runs
<div n="lb">thus (E. I. H. 149): {#ganDena ca#} (Ms. {#cA#} sic) {#vE rUpeRa#}
<div n="lb">(Ms. {#vE Sca rUpeRa#} sic) {#ca ganDarvApsarasaScarantItyanena#} (Ms. {#ga-#}
<div n="lb">{#nDarvopsaºº#} sic) {#ganDarvaSabdo'psaraHSabdaSca nirucyate . ganDena#}
<div n="lb">{#viSantIti#} (Ms. {#ganDona viSintIti#} sic) {#ganDarvAH . apsaSabdena#}
<div n="lb">(Ms. {#apraSabdena#} sic) {#rUpamaBiDIyate . tena viSizwAScarantIti#}
<div n="lb">{#apsarasaH . ganDarvApsarasaH . ganDarvApsaraHSabdayoH pfzodarAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAt#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 109.) {#varRAgamAditi viDAnenokta evArTe#}
<div n="lb">{#sADutvaM drazwavyam,#} when the word would literally mean: ‘go-
<div n="lb">ing (distinguished) with beauty’; (comp. the quotation of
<div n="lb">{%Patanj.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} V. 2. 95: {#urvaSI vE rUpiRyapsarasAm#}), but
<div n="lb">this kind of popular E. of the word is as little plausible as
<div n="lb">that given by the {%Rāmāyaṇa,%} according to which these deities
<div n="lb">would derive their name from the circumstance that they
<div n="lb">arose from the essence ({#rasa#}) which was obtained from the
<div n="lb">churning ‘in the waters’ ({#apsu#}) of the ocean.
<LEND>

<L>5661<pc>224-a<k1>apsarastIrTa<k2>apsarastIrTa

<div n="lb">rasas, a proper name of a place mentioned in the drama Śa-
<div n="lb">kuntalā. E. {#apsaras#} and {#tIrTa#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">a shorter form.
<LEND>

<L>5666<pc>224-a<k1>apsava<k2>apsava

<L>5667<pc>224-a<k1>apsavya<k2>apsavya
{#apsavya#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Conversant with water. <sup>2</sup> Fit
<div n="lb">or appropriate for water. <sup>3</sup> Being in the water. [The two
<div n="lb">first meanings are given according to the explanation of
<div n="lb">{%Kaiyyaṭa,%} the last according to that of the {%Prauḍhaman.,%}
<div n="lb">on the word in {%Vārtt.%} 6. to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 1.--mentioned also
<div n="lb">in the {%Vārtt.%} of the {%Kāśikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 18.--and by
<div n="lb">{%Nagojibh.%} on I. 1. 7., viz. {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#apsavyamiti . apsu sA-#}
[Page224-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#DuH . tatrasADuriti yat#} (comp. {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 4. 98., where {#sADu#}
<div n="lb">has the two meanings ‘conversant with’ or ‘appropriate
<div n="lb">for’); {%Prauḍh.:%} {#apsavya iti . digAdiByo yat#}--{%Pāṇ.%} IV.
<div n="lb">3. 54.] E. {#apsu#} (loc. plur. of {#ap#}), taddh. aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>5668<pc>224-b<k1>apsas<k2>apsas
{#apsas#}¦ n. ({#-psaH#}) (ved.) The same as {#rUpa;#} esp. form, beauty.
<div n="lb">E. {%Śākapūṇi,%} as quoted by {%Yāska,%} derives this word as a
<div n="lb">Tatpur. from {#a#} neg. and {#psas#} ({#psA,#} probably uṇ. aff.
<div n="lb">{#asun#}) and interprets it as meaning liter. ‘what ought to
<div n="lb">be looked upon ({#AdarSanIya#})’ or ‘what ought to be diffused’
<div n="lb">i. e. manifest to sight {#‘vyApanIyaM vA spazwaM darSanAya’;#} but in
<div n="lb">the latter acceptation probably from {#ap#} (comp. the E. of
<div n="lb">{#apta#}) and implying perhaps the meaning of {#Ipsita#}.
<LEND>

<L>5669<pc>224-b<k1>apsA<k2>apsA
{#apsA#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-psAH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Giving water, giving rain,
<div n="lb">an epithet of Soma; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vājas.:%} {#azAhLaM yutsu pf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tanAsu papriM svarzAmapsAM vfjanasya gopAm#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apsAmapAM#}
<div n="lb">{#vfzwilakzaRAnAmudakAnAM dAtAram;#} {%Mahīdhara:%} {#apo jalAni#}
<div n="lb">{#sanotItyapsAH . tam#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#pavasva devamAdano vicarzaRi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rapsA indrAya varuRAya vAyave#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apsA apAM dAtA#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Liking water, an epithet of Soma; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Sāmav.:%}
<div n="lb">{#apsA indrAya vAyave varuRAya marudByaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#apsA vasa-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIvarInAmaDeyAnAmapAM saMBaktA#}). <sup>3</sup> Liking work, active; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#agnirapsAmftIzahaM vIraM dadAti satpatim#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#psAmapAmAptavyAnAM karmaRAM sanitAraM saMBaktAram#}). E. {#ap#}
<div n="lb">(1. 2. water, 3. work) and {#sA#} ({#san,#} kṛt aff. {#viw#}).
<LEND>

<L>5670<pc>224-b<k1>apsu<k2>apsu
{#apsu#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-psuH-psuH-psu#}) Deprived of beauty,
<div n="lb">altered in form or appearance; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#mA tvA vayaM#} (scil.
<div n="lb">{#vasizWAH#}) {#sahasAvannavIrA mApsavaH pari zadAma mAduvaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
<div n="lb">{#apsavo rUparahitAH#}); comp. {#ahrutapsu#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#psu#}
<div n="lb">(instead of {#psus#}), with udātta on the first syllable.
<LEND>

<L>5671<pc>224-b<k1>apsukzit<k2>apsukzit
{#apsukzit#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-t#}) (ved.) Residing in the intermediate
<div n="lb">region, in the region between heaven and earth, viz. the
<div n="lb">eleven gods which form one class, besides the class of eleven
<div n="lb">gods which reside in heaven, and another class of eleven
<div n="lb">gods which reside over the earth. (An interpretation ‘re-
<div n="lb">siding in the waters’ has been applied to these gods pro-
<div n="lb">bably in order to suggest what Hindu mythology {%ought%} to
<div n="lb">have been, but it is neither countenanced by Sāyaṇa nor
<div n="lb">by Mahīdh. nor by any other authority.) E. {#apsu#} (loc. of
<div n="lb">{#ap#} 2.) and {#kzit#}.
<LEND>

<L>5672<pc>224-b<k1>apsucara<k2>apsucara

<div n="lb">waters or in the intermediate region, in the region between
<div n="lb">heaven and earth. E. {#apsu#} (loc. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#cara#}.

<L>5675<pc>224-b<k1>apsujit<k2>apsujit

<div n="lb">and earth, an epithet of Indra ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#antarikze vartamA-#}
[Page225-a+ 56]

<div n="lb">‘conquering for the sake of water (scil. Vṛtra)’, is less
<div n="lb">probable, in the Ṛg-or Sāmav. verse: {#vajraM ca vfzaRaM Bara-#}
<div n="lb">{#tsamapsujit#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#apsujit . udakArTaM vftrasya jetA yadvA Apa#}

<L>5677<pc>225-a<k1>apsumat<k2>apsumat
{#apsumat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-mAn-matI-mat#}) <sup>1</sup> Having or possessing
<div n="lb">what is in water or arises from water; e. g. Agni so called
<div n="lb">from his combination with the fire of lightning which is in,
<div n="lb">or comes from, the rain-waters; or in the {%Chhāndogya Up.:%}
<div n="lb">{#na hApsu prEtyapsumAnBavati ya etadevaM vidvAnsarvAsvapsu paYcaviDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sAmopAste#} (where {%Ānandajn.%} explains the word ‘possessed
<div n="lb">with water’, viz. {#asAvupAsako marusTalIzvapi yaTecCamudaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnBavatItyarTaH,#} but it is perhaps better to say that such a
<div n="lb">worshipper becomes possessed with all the benefits that
<div n="lb">are in, or come from, water). <sup>2</sup> Containing, or accom-
<div n="lb">panied with, the word {#apsu;#} as verses, e. g. in the {%Śatap.:%}
<div n="lb">{#apsumatIByAmagneretadvESvAnarasya stotram;#} or as oblations, e. g.
<div n="lb">{#apsumantAvAjyaBAgO,#} whereon the {%Prauḍham.%} observes:
<div n="lb">{#apsumantAviti . kArIryA AjyaBAgayoH . apsu agne saDizWa#}
<div n="lb">{#ca . apsu me somo'bravIdityanuvAkye . tatra cApsuSabdo'sti#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#apsu#} (loc. plur. of {#ap#}), taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>5678<pc>225-a<k1>apsumati<k2>apsumati
{#apsumati#}¦ Bahuvr. (?)…[The meaning of the word is not
<div n="lb">given anywhere, to my knowledge; its form is mentioned
<div n="lb">in the {%Vārtt.%} {#apoyAniº#} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 1., but on its cor-
<div n="lb">rectness the doctors disagree: {%Nagojibh.%} (who alone of the
<div n="lb">older comm. on Pāṇini subjects it to a remark) finds that
<div n="lb">it is a proper form, but states at the same time that some
<div n="lb">believe it a wrong reading in the Bhāṣya instead of {#apsu-#}
<div n="lb">{#mat#} (aff. {#matu#}); {%Bhaṭṭojid.%} in the {%Prauḍham.,%} on the other
<div n="lb">hand, denies flatly its occurence in Patanjali or anywhere
<div n="lb">else; {%Nagojibh.:%} {#apsumatiriti . vfttiharidattAdayastu vArttike#}
<div n="lb">{#matuzviti paWitvA apsumantAvAjyaBAgAvityudAharanti#} (see
<div n="lb">{#apsumat#} 2.) {#. BAzye'pyevameva pAWaH . dfSyamAnapAWaH . dfSyamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#napAWastu leKakapramAdAditi tadanuyAyinaH . halo'nantara iti#}
<div n="lb">{#sUtre#} (I. 1. 7.) {#. harigranTe tu apsumatirityeva pAWo dfSyate yuktaM#}
<div n="lb">{#cEtat;#} {%Prauḍham.:%} {#yattu prAcA matizviti paWitvA apsumati-#}
<div n="lb">{#rityudAhftaM tadBAzyAdO na dfzwam#}. The E. I. H. Mss. 326 of the {%Ma-%}
<div n="lb">{%hābh.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 1. and 2441 of the {%Kāś.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 3. 18.
<div n="lb">read also {#ºmatizu#} and {#apsumatiH,#} but Ms. 831 of the {%Kāś.:%}
<div n="lb">{#ºmatuzu#} and {#apsumantO#}.]--E. {#apsu#} (loc. plur. of {#ap#}) and {#mati#}.
<LEND>

<L>5685<pc>225-b<k1>aPala<k2>aPala

<div n="P">2. m. ({#-laH#}) The name of a plant (Tamarix Indica;
<div n="lb">see {#JAvuka#}).
