<L>5693<pc>225-b<k1>abadDa<k2>abadDa
{#abadDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dDaH-dDA-dDam#}) <sup>1</sup> Unbound, not re-
<div n="lb">strained. <sup>2</sup> Unmeaning, nonsensical, as speech ({%Halāy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#…avispazwamabadDaM viyutArTakam#}); {%Rāyamukuṭa%} on the {%Ama-%}
<div n="lb">{%rak.%} has an instance to show what kind of unmeaning
<div n="lb">speech is intended by the word: {#yaTA . jaradgavaH kambalapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dukAByAM dvAri sTito gAyati maNgalAni . brAhmaRI pfcCati putra-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAmA rAjanagaryAM lavaRasya ko'rGa iti#}. Also {#abadDaka#} (or
<div n="lb">{#abanDaka?#}) and {#avaDya#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#badDa#}.
<LEND>
[Page226-a+ 56]

<L>5694<pc>226-a<k1>abadDaka<k2>abadDaka
{#abadDaka#}¦ 1. m. f. n. ({#-dDakaH-dDikA-dDakam#}) Unmeaning, nonsensical
<div n="lb">(as speech); comp. the preceding. ({%Śabdaratnāv.:%} {#samudA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yArTaSUnye syAdvirudDaM cApyabadDakam#}.) {%Bharatsena'%}s {%Dvirūpak.%}
<div n="lb">(E. I. H. 1334) reads the word {#abanDaka,#} viz.: {#abadDaM syAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDakam#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) The proper name of the chief of a re-
<div n="lb">nowned family; his descendants are called {#abadDakAH#} or
<div n="lb">{#AbadDakayaH;#} others read the name {#abanDaka#} and the descen-
<div n="lb">dants {#abanDakAH#} or {#AbanDakayaH#}. E. {#abadDa,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.
<LEND>

<L>5695<pc>226-a<k1>abadDamuKa<k2>abadDamuKa
{#abadDamuKa#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-KaH-KA-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Foulmouthed,
<div n="lb">abusive, scurrilous. ({%Amarak.:%} {#durmuKe muKarAbadDamuKO;#} {%Rā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yam., Bhānud.%} &c.: {#durninditaM muKamasya#}.) <sup>2</sup> Mendacious,
<div n="lb">false, untrue (according to {%Vallabhagaṇi'%}s interpretation of
<div n="lb">{#durmuKe#} &c. in {%Hemach.:%} {#virudDaBAzinAmAni trIRi . labAqa#}
<div n="lb">{#iti BAzA#}); it seems doubtful, however whether the latter
<div n="lb">comm. is correct and whether it is not preferable to restrict
<div n="lb">the sense of the word to the interpretation given by the
<div n="lb">commentators of the Amarak. (A meaning ‘talkative’ lent
<div n="lb">to this word is devoid of authority.) E. {#abadDa#} and {#muKa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5696<pc>226-a<k1>abaDa<k2>abaDa<h>1
I. {#abaDa#}.¦ See {#avaDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5697<pc>226-a<k1>abaDA<k2>abaDA<h>2
II. {#abaDA#}¦ Tatpur. (?) (In Geometry.) (Thus defined by
<div n="lb">{%Colebrooke:%}) ‘From the point, where a perpendicular fall-
<div n="lb">ing from the apex meets the base, the two portions or di-
<div n="lb">visions of the ground on their respective sides (or, if the
<div n="lb">perpendicular fall without the figure in an obtuse-angled
<div n="lb">one, on the same side) are distinguished by this name’
<div n="lb">({#‘lambasya pArSvadvayayoranyatamA BUmiH’#}); e. g. in the {%Līlavatī:%}
<div n="lb">{#daSasaptadaSapramO BujO triBuje yatra navapramA mahI . abaDe vada#}
<div n="lb">{#lambakaM taTA gaRitaM gARitikASu tatra me#}.--Also {#AbADA#}
<div n="lb">or {#avabADA#} (not {#avabaDA#}). E. Probably the curtailed form
<div n="lb">of {#AbADA,#} unless it be more correct to write the word
<div n="lb">{#avaDA,#} when the etym. would be {#DA,#} with {#ava,#} kṛt aff.
<div n="lb">{#aN;#} for the connexion between {#DA#} and {#han#} see s. v. {#DA#}.
<LEND>

{#abaDArha#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rhaH-rhA-rham#}) See {#avaDArha#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">and {#baDira#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">sensical; see {#abadDa#} 2. E. {#a#} neg. and {#baDya#}.
<div n="P">II. See {#avaDya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5707<pc>226-a<k1>abanDaka<k2>abanDaka
{#abanDaka#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nDakaH-nDikA-nDakam#}) Not
<div n="lb">binding, not confining.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) A proper name, the same as {#abadDaka#} (q. v.)
<div n="lb">of which it is a various reading; the descendants are called
<div n="lb">{#abanDakAH#} or {#AbanDakayaH#} ({%Gaṇaratnam.:%} {#banDaM karotIti banDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ko na banDako'banDaka;#} but see also the Bahuvr.). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#banDaka#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nDakaH-nDikA-nDakam#}) Without a
<div n="lb">tie &c., see the meanings of {#banDa#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Law.) A case (scil. of a loan) when
[Page226-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">no pledge has been given; (in such cases the monthly in-
<div n="lb">terest is in the direct order of the classes, two, three, four
<div n="lb">or five in the hundred; according to Yājnavalkya); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mitākṣara:%} {#sarve brAhmaRAdayo'DamarRA abanDake sabanDake vA#}
<div n="lb">{#svakftAM sAByupagatAM vfdDiM sarvAsu jAtizu dadyuH#}. (<sup>2</sup> The proper
<div n="lb">name I. 2. is explained by the {%Gaṇaratnam.%} also as a Ba-
<div n="lb">huvr.: {#‘na vidyate banDo'syetyabanDakaH’#}.) E. {#a#} priv. and {#banDa,#}
<div n="lb">in the first meaning with the ellipsis {#prayoga#}.
<LEND>

<L>5708<pc>226-b<k1>abanDana<k2>abanDana
{#abanDana#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) Without fetters, un-
<div n="lb">impeded. E. {#a#} priv. and {#banDana#}.
<LEND>

<LEND>

<L>5711<pc>226-b<k1>abanDya<k2>abanDya

<div n="lb">ful, having a result; lit. and fig.; e. g. (fig.) in the {%Hitop.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aYjanasya kzayaM dfzwvA valmIkasya ca saMcayam . abanDyaM divasaM#}
<div n="lb">{#kuryAddAnADyayanakarmaBiH;#} comp. also the following. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#banDya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5712<pc>226-b<k1>abanDyakopa<k2>abanDyakopa

<div n="lb">or impetuosity bears results; e. g. in the {%Kirātarj.:%} {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#banDyakopasya vihanturApadAM Bavanti vaSyAH svayameva dehinaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#amarzaSUnyena janasya jantunA na jAtahArddena ca vidvizAdaraH#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#abanDya#} and {#kopa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5715<pc>226-b<k1>abala<k2>abala
{#abala#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-lam#}) Want of strength, weakness;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Daśakumārach.:%} {#itaH kila janAdBagavatastrivarga-#}
<div n="lb">{#balAbalajYAnam;#} also figur., comp. {#arGabalAbala#}. E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#bala#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-laH-lA-lam#}) <sup>1</sup> Weak, feeble,
<div n="lb">infirm; e. g. in the {%Bhāgavata Pur.:%} {#aho vayaM DanyatamA ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#datra tyaktAH pitfByAM na vicintayAmaH . aBakzyamARA abalA#}
<div n="lb">{#vfkAdiBiH sa rakzitA rakzati yo hi garBe;#} or in the {%Hitop.:%}
<div n="lb">{#vipannAyAM nItO sakalamabalaM sIdati jagat#}. <sup>2</sup> Without a
<div n="lb">protector, unprotected; see the instance 3. 1.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-laH#}) <sup>1</sup> The name of a plant (Tapia cratœva).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Time (?). <sup>3</sup> A hole (?). [The two last meanings which
<div n="lb">are very suspicious, occur in the fourth chapter of an E.
<div n="lb">I. H. Ms. (2544) of the {%Anekārthamañjarī;%} this chapter it-
<div n="lb">self, however, is omitted in three other E. I. H. Mss. of
<div n="lb">the same work and, to judge from its character, seems
<div n="lb">added by a latter writer; these two meanings would suggest
<div n="lb">the assumption of an error in the copyist, for they remind
<div n="lb">us of {#velA#} and {#vila,#} but the word occurs in the beginning
<div n="lb">of the Śloka and is written with the initial {#a#}.]
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-lA#}) <sup>1</sup> A woman; e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#naSyanti#}
<div n="lb">{#dadarSa vfndAni kapIndraH . hArIRyabalAnAM hArIRyabalAnAm,#}
<div n="lb">where the first {#abalAnAm#} means ‘of the women’, and the
<div n="lb">second ‘unprotected’ or ‘weak’ (comm. {#abalAnAM strIRAM .#}
<div n="lb">{#abalAnAmavidyamAnarakzakARAm#} or {#atikfSAnAm#}). <sup>2</sup> (In
<div n="lb">Astronomy.) The sign of the zodiac, {%Virgo.%} <sup>3</sup> One of the
<div n="lb">ten Buddhist earths (?); comp. {#acalA#}. [An E. I. H. Ms.
<div n="lb">(1512) of {%Ajayapāla'%}s {%Nānārthasaṅgraha%} has the following
[Page227-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">extraordinary explanation of {#abalA, ‘abalAKyA SyAlA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kastrI pUgaraktamuKAmBasoH’#}.] E. {#a#} priv. and {#bala#}.
<LEND>

<L>5716<pc>227-a<k1>abalatA<k2>abalatA
{#abalatA#}¦ f. ({#-tA#}) or {#abalatva#} n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> Weakness. <sup>2</sup> Woman-
<div n="lb">hood. Both interpretations are given by a comm. on the
<div n="lb">following mock-poetry of the {%Nalodaya:%} {#prabalatamAnabalatayA#}
<div n="lb">{#saMyojya nale surottamAnavalata yA . tenAmA navalatayA taruReva#}
<div n="lb">{#tayAsyatAM na mAnavalatayA#} (comm. {#abalatayA abalatvena…#}
<div n="lb">{#yadvA…abalAyA BAvo'balatA . tvatalorguRavacanasyeti puM-#}
<div n="lb">{#vadBAvaH#}). E. 1. {#abala#} II. 1., 2. {#abalA#} II. 3., taddh. aff. {#tal#} or {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5725<pc>227-a<k1>abADa<k2>abADa

<div n="lb">structed; e. g. in the {%Nalop.:%} {#vItaSoka BayAbADaM kaccittvaM dfzwa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnnfpam#} (i. e. free from fear). E. {#a#} priv. and {#bADa#}.

<L>5741<pc>227-b<k1>abudDi<k2>abudDi

<div n="lb">foolishness. E. {#a#} neg. and {#budDi#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-dDiH-dDiH-dDi#}) <sup>1</sup> Devoid of intellect.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Ignorant, foolish. E. {#a#} priv. and {#budDi#}.

<L>5743<pc>227-b<k1>abudDipUrva<k2>abudDipUrva

<div n="lb">by reflection (as an act), unintentional, spontaneous; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#gate'tiBUmiM praRaye prayuktAnabudDipUrvaM pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#luptasaMjYaH . AtmAnuBUtAnapi nopacArAnsmarAturaH saMsmarati sma#}
<div n="lb">{#lokaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#budDipUrva#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. Commencing with non-intellect or with be-
<div n="lb">ings that have no intellect (as creation); e. g. in the {%Vāyu%}
<div n="lb">{%Pur.:%} {#abudDipUrvakaM tadvE cetanArTaM pravartate . tena hyabudDipUrvaM tacce-#}
<div n="lb">{#tane na hyaDizWitam#}. E. {#abudDi#} and {#pUrva#}.

<L>5757<pc>228-a<k1>abja<k2>abja
{#abja#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-bjaH-bjA-bjam#}) Born or produced
<div n="lb">in, or by, water.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-bjaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The moon. <sup>2</sup> Dhanwantari, the physi-
<div n="lb">cian of the gods (he having arisen from the ocean when it
<div n="lb">was churned for the amṛta). <sup>3</sup> A fish. <sup>4</sup> The ratan (Calamus
<div n="lb">rotang). <sup>5</sup> The name of two other aquatic plants: <sup>a.</sup> Valisneria
<div n="lb">octandra; <sup>b.</sup> Barringtonia acutangula. <sup>6</sup> The proper name of
<div n="lb">the father of Viśala; see also {#abjakakuBa#}. <sup>7</sup> (In Arithmetic
<div n="lb">sometimes used to denote) the numeral {%1.%} Comp. {#candra#}.
<div n="P">3. m. n. ({#-bjaH-bjam#}) The conch.
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-bjam#}) <sup>1</sup> A lotus; (according to the {%Sārasvatā-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhidhāna%} the white esculent variety; {#‘paNkajakErave’#}). <sup>2</sup> A
<div n="lb">large number, a million of millions; {%Līlavatī:%} {#ekadaSaSata-#}
<div n="lb">{#sahasrAyutalakzaprayutakowayaH kramaSaH . arbudamabjaM KarvaniKarvama-#}
<div n="lb">{#hApadmaSaNkavastasmAt . jalaDiScAntyaM maDyaM parArDamiti daSagu-#}
<div n="lb">{#RottarAH saMjYAH . saMKyAyAH sTAnAnAM vyavahArArTaM kftAH pUrvEH#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> A sort of collyrium; see {#rasAYjana#}.
[Page228-b+ 56]
<div n="P">5. f. ({#-bjA#}) A pearl oyster. [The meanings 2. 3. 4. 5. a.,
<div n="lb">4. 3. and 5. are given in {%Sureśvara'%}s {%Śabdapratīpa,%} where
<div n="lb">the word is thus defined: {#abjaM rasAYjane padme striyAM SuktO#}
<div n="lb">{#ca puMsi ca . SaNKaSEvalamatsyezu vetase rajanIkare#}.] Compare
<div n="lb">{#abjA#}. E. {#ap#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">compound; otherwise the descendants of {#abja#} would be

<div n="lb">the reading of, and explained by, the {%Kāśikā%} (E. I. H. 2440)
<div n="lb">in the {%Gaṇa%} to {%Pāṇ.%} II. 4. 68.; the present edition of {%Pāṇ.%} and

<L>5771<pc>228-b<k1>abjA<k2>abjA
{#abjA#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-bjAH#}) <sup>1</sup> Born or produced, in, or by,
<div n="lb">water; a vaidik epithet of Fire (see {#ahi#} and comp. {#ap#}),
<div n="lb">and of Āditya or the Sun in the type Dadhikrā, when he
<div n="lb">is identified with Parabrahman or the universal deity, ac-
<div n="lb">cording to {%Sāyaṇa,%} because the Sun is born in the midst
<div n="lb">of the water; according to {%Mahīdhara,%} because he has
<div n="lb">horses which are born from the waters, or as the Aitareya
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa intimates, on account of the Sun's apparent ris-
<div n="lb">ing from the ocean and setting in the same (see {%Wilson'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgveda%} vol. 3, p. 200 note). <sup>2</sup> A lotus. <sup>3</sup> The moon.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-bjAH#}) Lakṣmī or Śrī. [The last three meanings
<div n="lb">are given by the {%Śabdaratnāvalī%} where the two E. I. H.
<div n="lb">Mss., 1512 and 1585, refer the name of Śrī to the {%masc.;%}
[Page229-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">both words {#abja#} and {#abjA#} are thus explained: {#abjaH SaNKe#}
<div n="lb">{#striyAM#} (which must be read {#'striyAM#}) {#nA tu Danvantaryambuje#}
<div n="lb">{#trizu . klIvaM padme taTAbjAstu padmenduSrIzvasO pumAn;#} there
<div n="lb">seems to be no incorrectness in the text of the Mss., for
<div n="lb">{%Mathureśa%} takes now and then the liberties of a verse-
<div n="lb">maker, but a male Śrī appears nevertheless to be a stronger
<div n="lb">license even than a curtailed {#Danvantf#} (loc. {#Danvantari#}) instead
<div n="lb">of {#Danvantari#} (loc. {#DanvantarO#}).] E. {#ap#} and {#jA#} ({#jan,#} kṛt aff. {#viw#}).
<LEND>

<L>5772<pc>229-a<k1>abjAhva<k2>abjAhva

<L>5776<pc>229-a<k1>abda<k2>abda
{#abda#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-bdaH-bdA-bdam#}) Giving water, giv-
<div n="lb">ing rain; the fem. instrum. {#abdayA#} is used in the {%Ṛgv.%}
<div n="lb">verse: {#marutaH…abdayA cinmuhurA hrAdunIvftaH#} &c. in
<div n="lb">the sense of an adverb, viz. ‘in giving rain’, which in
<div n="lb">this passage becomes equivalent to a nom. plur. referring
<div n="lb">to {#marutaH,#} hence {%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#udakAnAM dAtAraH . Saso yA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jAdeSaH#}.--For this vaidik use of the fem. instr. in an
<div n="lb">adverbial sense (i. e. in the sense of the acc. neuter) com-
<div n="lb">pare also {#sADuyA = sADu#} ({%Kāś.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 1. 39.) and the
<div n="lb">use of the fem. acc. in {#-Am,#} esp. in {#-tarAm#} and {#-tamAm#}
<div n="lb">instead of {#-taram#} or {#-tamam,#} e. g. {#prataram#} or {#pratarAm,#}
<div n="lb">{#kiMtaram#} or {#kiMtamAm#} &c. (comp. {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 11. and 12).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-bdaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A cloud; e. g. in the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#tataH kza-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAwEH pfTupiNgalAkzEH KaM prAvfzeRyEriva cAnaSe'bdEH#}. <sup>2</sup> A
<div n="lb">year; (comp. {%Śaṅkara%} on the {%Vedānta S.%} IV. 3. 2.: {#vAyu-#}
<div n="lb">{#mabdAdaviSezaviSezAByAm#}). <sup>3</sup> The name of a mountain.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> The name of a grass (Cyperus rotundus); see {#mustaka;#} ac-
<div n="lb">cording to the {%Nighantaprakāśa,%} Cyperus pertenuis; see {#Ba-#}
<div n="lb">{#dramustaka#} or {#nAgaramustaka#}. E. {#ap#} and {#da,#} with the udātta on
<div n="lb">the first syllable; the {%Uṇṇādi S.%} however propose to derive
<div n="lb">the word from {#av#} ‘to protect’, uṇ. aff. {#dan,#} when the word
<div n="lb">would sound {#abda;#} and {%Nṛsinha'%}s {%Swaramanjari%} pretends
<div n="lb">that it comes from {#ad#} ‘to eat’, with {#d#} changed to {#b,#} uṇ.
<div n="lb">aff. {#dan#}. [The Calc. and Petersb. edd. of {%Hemachandra'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Abhidhānach.%} have (2. 73. or v. 159.) the incorrect reading
<div n="lb">{#abdam,#} as if the word were a neuter; an excellent Ms. of
<div n="lb">this portion, belonging to the R. A. S. has the correct form
<div n="lb">{#abdaH#} and the comm. of {%Vallabhagaṇi%} says nothing of the
<div n="lb">word being m. or n.].
<LEND>

<div n="lb">work. E. {#abda#} and {#tantra#}.

<L>5787<pc>229-b<k1>abdurga<k2>abdurga
{#abdurga#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-rgam#}) A water-fortress, i. e. a place sur-
<div n="lb">rounded by deep water; {%Manu%} recommends it, amongst
<div n="lb">other sites, as one where a king should build his town:
<div n="lb">{#DanvadurgaM mahIdurgamabdurgaM vArkzameva ca . nfdurgaM giridurgaM vA sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mASritya vasetpuram#} ({%Kullūka:%} {#jaladurgamagADodakena sarvataH pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#vftam#}); the best fortress for a king is, however, the {#gi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ridurga#} q. v., for the {#abdurga#} is, in the view of Manu, the
<div n="lb">appropriate fortress for aquatic beings, the {#Danvadurga#} q. v.
<div n="lb">for wild animals, the {#mahIdurga#} q. v. for mice or other ani-
<div n="lb">mals living in holes, the {#vfkzadurga#} q. v. for monkeys, while
<div n="lb">the {#nfdurga#} q. v. is the fortress for men and the {#giridurga#}
<div n="lb">for gods. E. {#ap#} and {#durga#}.
<LEND>

<L>5788<pc>229-b<k1>abdevatAka<k2>abdevatAka
{#abdevatAka#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) The same as
<div n="lb">{#abdEvata#} q. v. E. {#ap#} and {#devatA,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5789<pc>229-b<k1>abdEvata<k2>abdEvata
{#abdEvata#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Having water for
<div n="lb">its divinity, addressed to the divinity Water, as a hymn;
<div n="lb">(the {#abdEvataM sUktam#} or {#tfcam,#} mentioned by {%Manu%} is the
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.%} hymn X. 9. 1-3., or {%Sāmav.%} 2. 1187-1189. = II. 9. 2. 10.).
<div n="lb">Comp. {#abliNga#}. E. {#ap#} and {#devata#}.
<LEND>

<L>5790<pc>229-b<k1>abDi<k2>abDi
{#abDi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-DiH#}) <sup>1</sup> The ocean; lit. and figur.; e. g.
<div n="lb">(figur.) in the {%Nalodaya:%} {#api yo dAyAdAya kzayaprado'haMsi#}
<div n="lb">{#satAM yadAyA dAyaH . karamAdAyAdAya Sriyo'bDiraDirAja-#}
<div n="lb">{#masigadAyAdA yaH;#} or in the {%Rudrayāmalat.:%} {#sadA sevyo devEH#}
<div n="lb">{#sa Bavati naro BaktisulaBaH . sa jIvanmukto'pi tarati ca BavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#bDimacirataH#}. <sup>2</sup> The name of one of the attendants of the
<div n="lb">Sun (acc. to {%Vyāḍi%} on {%Hemach.%}). <sup>3</sup> (In mathematical lan-
<div n="lb">guage sometimes used to denote) the numeral {%4;%} e. g. in
<div n="lb">{%Brahmagupta'%}s {%Brāhmasiddhānta:%} {#parivartAKacatuzwayaSarAbDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasaguRayamadvivasutiTayaH#} (comp. {%Colebr. As. Res.%} XII. p. 231
<div n="lb">note); or {#kasyAsO GawikAsaMGo dyugaRasya yadudBavam . paYcABra-#}
<div n="lb">{#candrAbDimitaM viDormaRqalaSezakam;#} or in the {%Keralagrantha,%} as
<div n="lb">quoted by {%Rādhāk.%} (s. v. {#aBiGAta#}): {#aBiGAtaM syAtpUrvaM veda-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvitryabDivarRAScet . nagavargARAM parato DaraRIcandradvirAmAQyAH;#}
<div n="lb">or in the {%Sūryasiddh.%} quoted Journ. As. XVI. p. 35. 1. 12.
<div n="lb">{%Schlegel%} is probably correct when he ascribes this use of
<div n="lb">the word to the division of the ocean according to the four
<div n="lb">cardinal points of the compass ({%Refl. sur l'étude des langues%}
<div n="lb">{%as.%} p. 198), but he is mistaken when he adds, that ‘ocean’
<div n="lb">may designate also the numeral {%7,%} for all the synonymes
<div n="lb">of this word are only used to denote {%4;%} comp. {%E. Jacquet%}
<div n="lb">Journ. As. vol. XVI. (1835) p. 17. 104. and, besides {%Raffles%}
[Page230-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">quoted there, {%Humboldt'%}s {%Kawi%} Sprache I. p. 32.--E. {#ap#}
<div n="lb">and {#Di#}.
<LEND>

<L>5792<pc>230-a<k1>abDikaPa<k2>abDikaPa
{#abDikaPa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-PaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Froth, foam. <sup>2</sup> Cuttle fish bone,
<div n="lb">the dorsal scale of the cuttle fish (Sepia officinalis); so
<div n="lb">called because it looks like the froth of the sea; {%Rāyamu-%}
<div n="lb">{%kuṭa%} &c.: {#abDeH kaPa iva#}. Compare {#samudrakaPa, abDiPena,#}
<div n="lb">{#arRavamala#} and the following. E. {#abDi#} and {#kaPa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5793<pc>230-a<k1>abDija<k2>abDija
{#abDija#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Born in or by the
<div n="lb">ocean.
<div n="P">2. <sup>a.</sup> m. sing. ({#-jaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The moon; comp. {#abja#}. <sup>2</sup> (In
<div n="lb">mathematical language sometimes used to denote) the nu-
<div n="lb">meral {%1.%} <sup>3</sup> Cuttle fish bone; the same as {#abDikaPa#} or {#sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#mudraPena#} (according to the {%Nigh. Prak.%}), comp. also {#arRavaja#}.
<div n="lb">(The meaning ‘moon’ is not given in the Koshas; but as
<div n="lb">the word occurs in the second meaning, in a mathematical
<div n="lb">Index, similarly as {#amftadIDiti,#} and as the synonymes
<div n="lb">of {#candra#} q. v. are used likewise so, it seemed to me neces-
<div n="lb">sary to infer this mathematical application from the mean-
<div n="lb">ing ‘moon’, which would arise from the etymon of the
<div n="lb">word in the same way as {#abja#} 2. 1. q. v. Comp. also {#Sve-#}
<div n="lb">{#taDAman#} ‘moon and cuttle fish bone’.)
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> m. du. ({#-jO#}) A name of the Aśvins q. v., these two
<div n="lb">gods having sprung from the ocean when it was churned
<div n="lb">for the amṛta.
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-jam#}) Salt (according to the {%Nigh. Prak.%}).
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-jA#}) Spirituous liquor; see {#surA,#} the latter hav-
<div n="lb">ing come from the ocean when it was churned for the amṛta.
<div n="lb">E. {#abDi#} and {#ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>5821<pc>230-b<k1>abrahmaRya<k2>abrahmaRya
{#abrahmaRya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-RyaH-RyA-Ryam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not proper or
<div n="lb">fit for a Brāhmaṇa ({%Halāyudha:%} {#abrahmaRyamavarRyaM syAdbrahmaRyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#brahmaRo hitam#}). <sup>2</sup> Not well disposed to, hostile to, the
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇas; e. g. in the {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#SocatyaSrukalA sA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DvI durBagevojJitADunA . abrahmaRyA nfpavyAjA SUdrA Bokzyanti#}
<div n="lb">{#mAmiti#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-Ryam#}) <sup>1</sup> A disgraceful act, a horrible act; e. g.
<div n="lb">in the {%Panchatantra:%} {#nAndukastArasvareRa provAca . Bo abra-#}
<div n="lb">{#hmaRyamabrahmaRyaM vartate . mama SiSuranena cOreRApahftaH#}. <sup>2</sup> An
<div n="lb">exclamation of distress, uttered by a Brāhmaṇa, answer-
<div n="lb">ing our: oh, alas! ({%Rāyamuk., Bhanūd.%} &c. on the {%Ama-%}
<div n="lb">{%rak.:%} {#vaDaM nArhatItyuktO;#} {%Svāmin%} on the {%Amarak., Valla-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhag.%} on {%Hemach.:%} {#vaDAnarhasya brAhmaRasya pUtkaraRe;#} according
<div n="lb">to this interpretation the word {#avaDya,#} in the explanatory
[Page231-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">compound of the {%Amarak.%} and of {%Hemach.%} {#‘avaDyoktO’,#}
<div n="lb">would simply mean {%‘Brāhmaṇa’,%} the etymological sense
<div n="lb">of this word having disappeared in the conventional mean-
<div n="lb">ing; {%Nīlak.:%} {#vaDaM nArhatItyuktO brahmaRi sADu . tatra sADuriti#}
<div n="lb">({%Pāṇ.%} IV. 4. 98.) {#yat . brahmaRyam . tato naYsamAsaH#}) e. g. in
<div n="lb">the {%Uttararāmach.:%} {#atrAntare brAhmaRena mftaM putramAropya rAM-#}
<div n="lb">{#jadvAri sorastAqanamabrahmaRyamudGozitam;#} or <sup>3</sup> A cry of distress
<div n="lb">uttered by a person (in general) who craves for his life,
<div n="lb">answering our ‘mercy!’; (according to this interpretation
<div n="lb">of {#avaDyoktO, avaDya#} would not have the conventional, but
<div n="lb">the literal or etymological sense: {%Rāyamuk., Mathureśa,%}
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāśraya%} &c. on the {%Amarak.:%} {#avaDayAcYcArTamityeke;#} {%Valla-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhag.%} on {%Hemach.:%} {#avaDyayAcYArTaM pUtkaraRa ityeke,#} when {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#brahmaRya#} has lost its etymological sense, ‘an act which is
<div n="lb">not proper for a Brāhmaṇa’ and assumed the meaning 1.);
<div n="lb">but the word occurs also in the still more general sense
<div n="lb">of a plaintive cry: ‘woe!’; e. g. in the {%Panchatantra:%} {#sarve#}
<div n="lb">{#te pakziRo vizaRRavadanA vAzpapUritadfSaH karuRasvareRa vEnateya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAsAdya PUtkartumArabDAH . aho abrahmaRyamabrahmaRyam#}. ({%Amarak.%}
<div n="lb">and {%Hemach.%} restrict the use of the word in the two last
<div n="lb">meanings to the dramas, but it occurs also elsewhere in
<div n="lb">the dialogue, as results e. g. from the given instance.--
<div n="lb">{#abrahmaRya#} is, contrary to the general rule on Tatpur. com-
<div n="lb">pounds with {#a#} neg., udātta on the last syllable.) Also
<div n="lb">{#abrAhmaRya#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#brahmaRya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5822<pc>231-a<k1>abrahmatA<k2>abrahmatA
{#abrahmatA#}¦ f. ({#-tAM#}) (ved.) The condition of what is not endowed
<div n="lb">with the bliss of wisdom, i. e. the condition of what is
<div n="lb">perishable (according to {%Mahīdhara%}). E. {#abrahman,#} taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#tal#} ({%Mahīdhara%} analyzes the word {#a#} neg. and {#brahmatA,#}
<div n="lb">but he can be scarcely correct in doing so, as it is udātta
<div n="lb">on the penultimate, not on the first syllable).
<LEND>

<L>5823<pc>231-a<k1>abrahman<k2>abrahman
{#abrahman#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-hmA-hmA-hma#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Without hymns,
<div n="lb">unaccompanied by hymns (as libations). <sup>2</sup> (ved.) Not hav-
<div n="lb">ing the bliss of wisdom (comp. {#abrahmatA#}). <sup>3</sup> Without Brā-
<div n="lb">hmaṇas; e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#nAbrahma kzatramfDnoti nAkzatraM brahma varDate .#}
<div n="lb">{#brahma kzatraM ca saMpfktamiha cAmutra varDate#}. The word is udātta
<div n="lb">on the first syllable. E. {#a#} priv. and {#brahman#}.
<LEND>

<L>5826<pc>231-a<k1>abrAhmaRa<k2>abrAhmaRa
{#abrAhmaRa#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-RaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Not a Brāhmaṇa, any
<div n="lb">one in general except a Brāhmaṇa; e. g. in the {%Śatapath.:%}
<div n="lb">{#…tadvE nAbrAhmaRaH pibedagnO hyaDiSrayanti tasmAnnAbrAhmaRaH#}
<div n="lb">{#pibet;#} or in the {%Chhānd. Upan.:%} {#taM hovAca nEtadabrAhmaRo#}
<div n="lb">{#vivaktumarhati#} (where ‘none but a Brāhmaṇa’ implies ‘be-
<div n="lb">cause the Brāhmaṇas alone are upright’); or in the {%Mi-%}
<div n="lb">{%tākṣ.:%} {#aSvAdvaqavAyAmaSvaH . tasmAdbrAhmaRAdbrAhmaRyAmutpanno'brA-#}
<div n="lb">{#hmaRa iti virudDam;#} [but so far, by the fact of negation,
<div n="lb">comparable to a Brāhmaṇa, that a man, not a lump of
<div n="lb">earth &c. is implied; this sense is conveyed when {%Patanjali%}
<div n="lb">gives {#abrAhmaRa#} as an instance to the meaning ‘similar’ of
<div n="lb">{#na,#} in his comment on the {%Nyāya%} to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 1. 12. and VI.
<div n="lb">1. 71., omitted in the mutilated reprint of the Calc. edition:
[Page231-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#naYyuktamivayuktaM vA#} (to VI. 1. 71.: {#naYyukta ivayukte vA#}) {#ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tkiMcidiha dfSyate . anyasmiMstatsadfSe kAryaM vijYAyate . taTA#}
<div n="lb">{#hyarTo gamyate .#} (VI. 1. 71.: {#tadyaTA .#}) {#abrAhmaRamAnayetyukte brA-#}
<div n="lb">{#hmaRasadfSa evAnIyate#} (to VI. 1. 71.: {#brAhmaRasadfSamevAnayati#})
<div n="lb">{#nAsO lozwamAnIya kftI Bavati;#} or the latter words more
<div n="lb">completely to the same Nyāya, VI. 1. 135. (omitted in the
<div n="lb">Calc. ed. and therefore also in the reprint of that edition):
<div n="lb">{#abrAhmaRamAnayetyukte brAhmaRasadfSaM kzatriyamAnayati . nAsO#} &c.].
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> A {%twice-born%} man who is not a Brāhmaṇa, i. e. a Ksha-
<div n="lb">triya or a Vaiśya; e. g. in {%Manu:%} {#abrAhmaRAdaDyayanamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#patkAle viDIyate#} ({%Kullūka:%} {#brAhmaRAdanyo yo dvijaH kzatri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yastadaBAve vESyo vA#}); or in {%Jaimini'%}s {%Sūtra:%} {#abrAhmaRe ca#}
<div n="lb">{#darSanAt#} (where a Kshatriya is meant); or in the {%Vārttika%}
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#abrAhmaRagotramAtrAdyuvapratyayasyopasaMKyAnam#} ({%Kaiyy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#tena vESyagotrAdapi siDyati,#} i. e. a Kshatriya and a Vaiśya;
<div n="lb">comp. the other {%Vārtt.%} of II. 4. 58. in the Calc. ed.); or in
<div n="lb">the {%Vājas.:%} {#aSUdrA abrAhmaRAste prAjApatyAH#} (scil. {#paSavaH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> A Śūdra (i. e. the reverse of a Brāhmaṇa, the last of the
<div n="lb">castes, while the Brāhmaṇa is the first &c.); e. g. in {%Manu:%}
<div n="lb">{#abrAhmaRaH saMgrahaRe prARAntaM daRqamarhati;#} ({%Kullūka:%} {#abrAhmaRo#}
<div n="lb">{#'tra SUdraH#}). <sup>4</sup> A bad Brāhmaṇa, an impious Brāhmaṇa;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Ādiparvan%} of the {%Mahābh.:%} {#sa pIqito deva-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAnyA maharziH samAhvayatsaMramBAccEva kAvyaH . asaMSayaM mAmasurA#}
<div n="lb">{#dvizanti ye me SizyAnAgatAndUzayanti . abrAhmaRaM kartumicCanti#}
<div n="lb">{#rOdrAste mAM yaTA vyaBicaranti nityam#}.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-RI#}) The fem. of {#abrAhmaRa#} in the foregoing mean-
<div n="lb">ings; e. g. {%Nārada:%} {#svEriRyabrAhmaRI veSyA dAsI nizkAsinI#}
<div n="lb">{#ca yAH . gamyAH syurAnulomyena striyo na pratilomataH#} ({%Vīra-%}
<div n="lb">{%mitr.:%} {#abrAhmaRIti svEriRyaviSezaRam#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#brAhmaRa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-RaH-RA-Ram#}) Without Brāhmaṇas;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vāyu Pur.:%} {#mamADvare SaMsitAraH stuvanti raTaMtare#}
<div n="lb">{#sAma gAyanti geyam . abrAhmaRe brahmasatre yajante#} &c. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">priv. and {#brAhmaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5832<pc>231-b<k1>aBakta<k2>aBakta
{#aBakta#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not worshipping,
<div n="lb">undevout; e. g. in the {%Ṛgv.:%} {#BaktamaBaktamavo vyanto ajarA#}
<div n="lb">{#agnayo vyanto ajarAH;#} or in the {%Rudrayāmalatantra:%} {#aBa-#}
[Page232-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#kteByo'pi putreByo datvA narakamApnuyAt#}. <sup>2</sup> Detached, not con-
<div n="lb">nected with; said by the commentators on {%Pāṇini%} of a gram-
<div n="lb">matical element which stands part, as it were, of the other
<div n="lb">elements of the word, and therefore prevents the application
<div n="lb">of rules which would have to take place, if it were {#Bakta,#} i. e. if
<div n="lb">it were essentially connected with the other elements of the
<div n="lb">word; e. g. the {%Kāśikā%} on {#suw#} VI. 1. 136.: {#pUMrva DAturupasargeRa#}
<div n="lb">{#yujyata iti tatra DAtUpasargayoH kAryamantaraNgamiti pUrvaM suwkriyate .#}
<div n="lb">{#paScAdaqaByAsO . aBaktaSca suqityuktam;#} or {%the same%} on {#suw#} VI.
<div n="lb">1. 135.: {#kAtpUrvagrahaRaM suwo'BaktatvajYApanArTam;#} but {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">differs in opinion on this point, for he says: {#aBakte svare#}
<div n="lb">{#dozaH#} ‘if {#suw#} were extraneous there would be a flaw in the
<div n="lb">application of Pāṇini's rule of accentuation VIII. 1. 28.’;
<div n="lb">or the latter {%Vārtt.%} applied to āgama {#tuk#} VI. 1. 71., or to
<div n="lb">āgama {#muk#} VII. 2. 82. ({%Patanjali,%} however, refutes {%Kātyā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yana%} in this view.)--An {#aBakta#} element is in these comm.
<div n="lb">therefore opposed as well to a grammatical element which
<div n="lb">is {#pUrvAnta#} i. e. one added {%after%} what precedes, as to an
<div n="lb">element {#parAdi#} i. e. one which is placed {%before%} what follows.
<div n="lb">As it is important to know, in the application of {%Pāṇini'%}s
<div n="lb">rules, whether an element is {#aBakta#} or not, it will be expedient
<div n="lb">to convey the bearing of this term from the following expla-
<div n="lb">nation of {%Patanj.%} on a {%Vārtt.%} to 1. 1. 47.: {#kiM punarayaM pUrvAntaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#AhosvitparAdiH . AhosvidaBaktaH . kaTaM vAyaM pUrvAntaH syA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tkaTaM vA parAdiH kaTaM vABaktaH . yadyanta iti vartate tataH pUrvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntaH . aTAdiriti vartate tataH parAdiH . aToBayaM nivfttaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tato'BaktaH . kaScAtra viSezaH . aBakte dIrGanalopasvaraRatvAnu-#}
<div n="lb">{#svAraSIBAvAH . yadyaBakto dIrGatvaM na prApnoti . kuRqAni va-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAni#} (cf. VII. 1. 72.) {#. nopaDAyAH#} (VI. 4. 7.) {#. sarvanAmasTAne cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMbudDAviti#} (VI. 4. 8.) {#dIrGatvaM na prApnoti .. dIrGa .. nalopa . na-#}
<div n="lb">{#lopaSca na siDyati . agne trI te vAjinA trI zaDasTA tA tA#} (cf.
<div n="lb">VI. 1. 70.) {#piRqAnAm . nalopaH prAtipadikAntasyeti#} (VIII. 2. 7.)
<div n="lb">{#nalopo na prApnoti .. nalopa .. svara . svaraSca na siDyati . sarvARi#}
<div n="lb">{#jyotIMzi . sarvasya supItyAdyudAttatvaM#} (VI. 1. 191) {#na prApnIti ..#}
<div n="lb">{#svara .. Ratva . RatvaM ca na siDyati . mAzavApARi vrIhivApA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Ri . pUrvAnte prAtipadikAntanakArasyeti sidDam#} (VIII. 4. 11.) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#parAdO viBaktinakArasyeti#} (VIII. 4. 11.) {#. aBakte numo#} (VIII.
<div n="lb">4. 11.) {#grahaRaM kartavyam . na kartavyam . kriyata etannyAsa eva . prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tipadikAntanumviBaktizu ceti#} (VIII. 4. 11.) {#.. Ratva .. anusvAra .#}
<div n="lb">{#anusvAraSca na siDyati . dvizaMtapaH paraMtapaH . mo'nusvAro ha-#}
<div n="lb">{#lItyanusvAro#} (VIII. 3. 23.) {#na prApnoti . mA BUdevam . naScA-#}
<div n="lb">{#padAntasya JalItyevaM Bavizyati#} (VIII. 3. 24.) {#. yastarhi na Jalpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#raH . vahaMliho gOH . aBraMliho vAyuH .. anusvAra .. SIBAva .#}
<div n="lb">{#SIBAvaSca na siDyati . trapuRI jatunI tuMvuruRI . napuMsakAdutta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasyONaH SIBAvo#} (VII. 1. 19.) {#na prApnIti#} &c. (i. e. the
<div n="lb">āgama {#num#} is not {#aBakta,#} for otherwise the quoted rules could
<div n="lb">not be applied; comp. also the term {#vahiraNga#}). <sup>3</sup> Not eaten;
<div n="lb">see also the other meanings of {#Bakta#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bakta#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) Without food; e. g.
<div n="lb">in {%Suśruta:%} {#muhurmuhurnAma saBaktamaBaktaM vA yadOzaDaM muhurmuhuru-#}
<div n="lb">{#payujyate#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#Bakta#}.
<LEND>

<L>5839<pc>232-b<k1>aBakzya<k2>aBakzya

<div n="lb">{#kzutpratihantum . tatra niyamaH kriyate . idaM BakzyamidamaBakzyamiti#}.

<div n="lb">fifth book, {%Yājnavalkya%} in the first (v. 160 ff.); a list of such
<div n="lb">eatables may be found too in the {%Sāntiparvan%} v. 1313 seqq.
<div n="lb">(comp. also {%Mitramiśra'%}s {%Dharmaś.%} Ms. E. I. H. 930. I. fol.
<div n="lb">192{%b.%} seqq.); on the penances inflicted for eating such food
<div n="lb">see {%Manu%} 11. 152 ff., {%Yājnav.%} 3. 282, {%Viṣṇu-Dharmaś.%} fol. 17 {%a.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Mit.%} {#prAº#} fol. 91 {%b.%} ff., {%Raghunand.%} I. p. 317 ff. &c. &c. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#Bakzya#}.

<L>5843<pc>232-b<k1>aBaga<k2>aBaga

<div n="lb">(compare also the other meanings of {#Baga#}). E. {#a#} priv.
<div n="lb">and {#Baga#}.
<LEND>

<L>5844<pc>232-b<k1>aBagna<k2>aBagna

<LEND>

<L>5845<pc>232-b<k1>aBagnamAna<k2>aBagnamAna

<div n="lb">pride; e. g. in the {%Hitop.:%} {#yajjIvyate#} (ed. Seramp. {#yajjI-#}
<div n="lb">{#vati#}) {#kzaRamapi praTitaM manuzyErvijYAnavikramayaSoBiraBagnamAnam#}

<L>5846<pc>232-b<k1>aBaNgura<k2>aBaNgura

<div n="lb">e. g. (of the soil) in {%Suśruta:%} {#aBaNgurAM…BUmimOzaDArTaM#}

<div n="lb">{#kzmaRo gatvarAnkapIn#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BaNgura#}.

<L>5847<pc>233-a<k1>aBadra<k2>aBadra
{#aBadra#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-draH-drA-dram#}) Unpropitious, inau-
<div n="lb">spicious; e. g. in the {%Bhāgav.-Pur.:%} {#apyaBadraM na yuzmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BirBArgavasya vicezwitam . vyaktaM kenApi nastasya kftamASramadUza-#}
<div n="lb">{#Ram;#} or {%Āpastamba%} (as quoted by {%Kullūka%}): {#nABadramaBadraM#}
<div n="lb">{#brUyAtpuRyaM praSastamiti brUyAt#} (scil. a Brāhmaṇa); in {%Manu%}
<div n="lb">4. 139. the first word {#Badra#} is used euphemistically, implying
<div n="lb">there {#aBadra,#} for a Brāhmaṇa, even if he has something
<div n="lb">unfavourable to say, should always use an auspicious word;
<div n="lb">a similar euphemism is implied by {#Badra#} in the word {#paYcaBadra#}
<div n="lb">(m. f. n.) ‘profligate’, for the compound means one who
<div n="lb">has five {%inauspicious%} marks on chest, back &c. ({%Vyāḍi on%}
<div n="lb">{%Hemach.:%} {#paYca BadrARi kalyARAnyasya paYcaBadraH . aBadro vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#parItalakzaRayA BadramuKavat#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#Badra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5848<pc>233-a<k1>aBaya<k2>aBaya
{#aBaya#}¦ I. Tatpur. n. ({#-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Absence of fear; (with a noun
<div n="lb">in the abl.); e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Sāmav.:%} {#yata indra BayAmahe tato#}
<div n="lb">{#no aBayaM kfDi;#} or {%Vājas.:%} {#yato yataH samIhase tato no#}
<div n="lb">{#aBayaM kuru;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#sarvataScABayaM prApnonnECannfByastu rAvaRaH#}
<div n="lb">({%Jayam.:%} {#sarvato devAdiByaH . aBayaM rAvaRaH prApnot…#}
<div n="lb">{#nfByastu sakASAdaBayaM nEcCannezwavAn . ke mama mAnuzA iti…#}).
<div n="lb">Comp. also II. 4. 1. <sup>2</sup> Absence of danger; e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#indraH…bADatAM dvezo aBayaM kfRotu suvIryasya patayaH#}
<div n="lb">{#syAma#}. Comp. also II. 4. 2. <sup>3</sup> Bewilderment, negligence
<div n="lb">[? = {#pramAda;#} this suspicious meaning is given by the {%Śabda-%}
<div n="lb">{%ratnāvali%} with the qualification of its occurring ‘somewhere’:
<div n="lb">{#‘pramAde'pi ca kutracit’,#} where the conjecture {#‘prasAde’#}
<div n="lb">which might suggest itself from the meaning ‘security or
<div n="lb">protection’--comp. e. g. also {%Mahīdh.%} on the quoted pas-
<div n="lb">sage of the {%Vājas.%} 20. 51.--seems precluded in some mea-
<div n="lb">sure by the concordance of both E. I. H. Mss. of this Kosha,
<div n="lb">the one in Devanāg., the other in Beṅgāli characters]. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#Baya#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Free from fear, fearless;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#niragamadaBayaH puruzaripupurAt#} (scil. {#viBIzaRaH#});
<div n="lb">in the {%Upanishads%} and in {%philosophical%} passages of other
<div n="lb">works based on the doctrine of the latter, the word is ap-
<div n="lb">plied to that condition of the mind which results from a
<div n="lb">proper knowledge of the nature of Soul, more esp. from
<div n="lb">a knowledge of the Soul or of creation not being other
<div n="lb">than (the neuter) Brahman, hence also it is used as an epi-
<div n="lb">thet of (the neuter) {%Brahman,%} and of {%‘knowledge’%} itself: for
<div n="lb">the mental condition of fear, arising from birth, change,
<div n="lb">passion &c., is the result of ignorance; e. g. in the {%Taitti-%}
<div n="lb">{%riya-Up.:%} {#yadA hyevEza etasminnadfSye'nAtmye'nirukte'nila-#}
<div n="lb">{#yane'BayaM pratizWAM vindate . aTa so'BayaM gato Bavati#} (where
<div n="lb">the first {#aBayam#} is to be taken as adv. and the second as
<div n="lb">the noun, see II. 4. 1.); or in the {%Bṛhadār. Up.:%} {#sa vA eza#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAnaja AtmAjaro'maro'mfto'brahmABayaM vE brahmABayaM hi vE#}
<div n="lb">{#brahma Bavati ya evaM veda#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#yasmAjjanipraBftiBistri-#}
<div n="lb">{#BistriBirBAvavikArErvarjitastasmAditarErapi BAvavikArEstriBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#statkftESca kAmakarmamohAdiBirmftyurUpErvarjita ityetadaBayo'ta#}
<div n="lb">{#eva . yasmAccEvaM pUrvoktaviSezaRastasmAdBayavarjitaH . BayaM hi nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAvidyAkAryam#} &c.); or {%Śaṅkara%} in the introd. to the {%Tala-%}
<div n="lb">{%vakāra-Up.:%} {#na cAsmAkaM lokatrayamanityaM sADanasADyamizwaM#}
<div n="lb">{#yezAmasmAkaM svABAviko'jo'jaro'mfto'Bayo na varDate#}
<div n="lb">{#karmaRo no kanIyAnnityaSca loka izwaH;#} comp. also {%Wilson'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Viṣṇup.%} p. 156, n. 6, where ‘fearless’ as an epithet of wis-
[Page233-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">dom ({#jYAna#}) is explained by the comm. as ‘not dreading
<div n="lb">agitation or perplexity by ideas of duality: {#dvEtasPUrteraBayam#}’.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A proper name of, <sup>a.</sup> A son of Dharma
<div n="lb">(righteousness) by Dayā (tenderness, a daughter of Daksha);
<div n="lb">according to the {%Bhāgavata-Pur.%} <sup>b.</sup> A king of Laṅkā; acc.
<div n="lb">to the {%Mahāvanśa;%} (and the epithet of Duṣṭagāmani and
<div n="lb">Vartagāmani); comp. {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. A.%} vol. II. pp. 92 ff. 105 ff.
<div n="lb">and 415. 419 ff. 434. <sup>c.</sup> A king of Uraśā, the father of
<div n="lb">Vibhavamatī who was the wife of Bhoja (see {%Rājatar.%} VII.
<div n="lb">587., VIII. 16. and {%Troyer'%}s transl.). <sup>3</sup> A name of Śiva.
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-yA#}) The name of several plants: <sup>a.</sup> Yellow or
<div n="lb">chebulic myrobolan (Terminalia chebula Retz.); {%Suśruta%}
<div n="lb">mentions it as an ingredient of medicines given against
<div n="lb">urinary diseases, leprosy, nervous diseases, also of a de-
<div n="lb">coction used as an antidote for certain poisons; it is given
<div n="lb">also against a disease of the eye; comp. {#harItakI;#} <sup>b.</sup> The
<div n="lb">white {#nirguRqI (SvetanirguRqI);#} <sup>c.</sup> Bengal madder (Rubia
<div n="lb">mangith Roxb.); comp. {#maYjizWA;#} <sup>d.</sup> Orris root (Iris pseuda-
<div n="lb">corus); called in Mahr. {#veKaMqa;#} <sup>e.</sup> Andropogon muricatum;
<div n="lb">comp. {#mfRAla#} and {#aBaya#} II. 4. 4. (neuter); <sup>f.</sup> = {#jayA;#} <sup>g.</sup> = {#ja-#}
<div n="lb">{#yantI;#} <sup>h.</sup> = {#kAYjikA#}. [The first of these meanings occurs
<div n="lb">in several Koshas; the others, b.-h., are taken from the {%Ni-%}
<div n="lb">{%ghanṭa-Prak.%} which quotes for its authority {%Narahari'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Chūḍāmaṇij.%}]
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-yam#}) <sup>1</sup> Freedom from fear, fearlessness; comp.
<div n="lb">I. 1. <sup>2</sup> A state of things where there is no danger, public
<div n="lb">peace, safety, security; e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#nAtaH parataro Darmo#}
<div n="lb">{#nfpARAM yadraRArjitam . vipreByo dIyate dravyaM prajAByaScABayaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sadA;#} or {%Manu:%} {#jitvA saMpUjayeddevAnbrAhmaRAMScEva DArmikAn .#}
<div n="lb">{#pradadyAtparihArAMSca KyApayedaBayAni ca#} (after a victory the
<div n="lb">king should make a proclamation of peace); sometimes
<div n="lb">used in the sense of a place of security (comp. {#aBayasani#})
<div n="lb">or an assurance of safety or immunity (comp. {#aBayadakziRA#});
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kecitsaMcukuwurBItA lejire'nye parAjitAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#saMgrAmAdbaBraSuH kecidyayAcuScApare'Bayam#}. Compare I. 2.
<div n="lb">(N. B. Although there is a logical difference between the
<div n="lb">{%Tatpur.%} and {%Bahuvr.,%} {#aBaya#} n., it will be difficult some-
<div n="lb">times to decide whether the author has used the word under
<div n="lb">the former or the latter category, more esp. in the second
<div n="lb">meaning ‘security’, since also the accent would not assist
<div n="lb">in solving the doubt, as the Bahuvr. adj., for instance,
<div n="lb">occurs in the Vedas not merely with the udātta on the
<div n="lb">last and penultimate, but also on the first syllable, i. e. ac-
<div n="lb">centuated like the Tatpur. n.) <sup>3</sup> The name of the seventh
<div n="lb">division of the Plaksha Dvīpa; according to the {%Bhāgavata-%}
<div n="lb">{%Purāṇa;%} (for the others see {#Siva, yavayasa, suBadra, SAnta,#}
<div n="lb">{#kzema#} and {#amfta#}). <sup>4</sup> The root of a fragrant gras (Andro-
<div n="lb">pogon muricatum). E. {#a#} priv. and {#Baya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5849<pc>233-b<k1>aBayagiri<k2>aBayagiri

<div n="lb">proper name) and {#giri#} (a proper name).
<LEND>

<L>5850<pc>233-b<k1>aBayagirivAsin<k2>aBayagirivAsin
{#aBayagirivAsin#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-sI#}) An inhabitant of the
<div n="lb">Buddhist monastery {%Abhayagiri;%} {#aBayagirivAsinaH#} is the
<div n="lb">name of a Buddhist sect, one of three pretending to be
<div n="lb">founded by Kātyāyana, and one of the four divisions of
<div n="lb">the Vaibhāṣikas, (the three other divisions having for
<div n="lb">founders Rāhula, Upāli and Kāśyapa); for the two other
[Page234-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">sects founded by Kātyāyana see {#mahAvihAravAsin#} and
<div n="lb">{#jetavanIya#}. Comp. {#aBiDarma#}. (See {%Burnouf'%}s {%Lotus de la bonne%}
<div n="lb">{%loi%} II. p. 357 and {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} II. pp. 457. 1005. 1086.)
<div n="lb">E. {#aBayagiri#} and {#vAsin#}.
<LEND>

<L>5851<pc>234-a<k1>aBayagirivihAra<k2>aBayagirivihAra
{#aBayagirivihAra#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-raH#}) The Buddhist mona-
<div n="lb">stery Abhayagiri in Anurādhapura which is said to have
<div n="lb">been founded by the king {%Vartagāmani,%} in commemoration
<div n="lb">of a taunt held out to him by a Nighaṇṭa Brāhmaṇa of the
<div n="lb">name of {%Giri,%} when he fled after an unsuccessful encounter
<div n="lb">with the Damila, the king making a vow to build a mona-
<div n="lb">stery if he should be victorious; he called it Abhayagiri
<div n="lb">from the name of the Brāhmaṇa ({%Giri%}) and the surname
<div n="lb">{%Abhaya%} he had assumed himself. (Comp. {%Turnour'%}s {%Mahāv.%}
<div n="lb">p. 206 and {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} II. p. 433.) The monastery is
<div n="lb">famed for the sect which inhabited it (see {#aBayagirivAsin#})
<div n="lb">and a tope erected in it. (Comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%Ariana Antiqua%}
<div n="lb">p. 39 and {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} II. p. 1008.) E. {#aBaya-giri#}
<div n="lb">and {#vihAra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5852<pc>234-a<k1>aBayaNkara<k2>aBayaNkara
{#aBayaNkara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) Freeing from danger
<div n="lb">or fear, giving safety; also a vaidik epithet of Indra.--
<div n="lb">{#indrasyABayaMkaram#} is the ritual name of the Sāmaveda verses
<div n="lb">1. 171. (= I. 2. 2. 3. 7.), 1. 200. (= 1. 3. 1. 1. 7.) and 1. 274. (= I.
<div n="lb">3. 2. 4. 2.)--E. {#aBaya#} and {#kara#} ({#kf,#} kṛt aff. {#Kac#}), āgama
<div n="lb">{#mum;#} (or rather the accus. of {#aBaya#} and {#kara,#} with the
<div n="lb">udātta on the last syllable).
<LEND>

<L>5854<pc>234-a<k1>aBayajAta<k2>aBayajAta

<div n="lb">of a family; his descendant is {#ABayajAtya;#} the pupils of
<div n="lb">the latter are called {#ABayajAtAH#}. E. {#aBaya#} and {#jAta#} ‘born
<div n="lb">without fear or in safety’.

<L>5855<pc>234-a<k1>aBayaqiRqima<k2>aBayaqiRqima
{#aBayaqiRqima#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> A war-drum. <sup>2</sup> (Molesw.)
<div n="lb">A proclamation of re-assurance, a promise of safety and
<div n="lb">security, as made on taking possession of an enemy's
<div n="lb">country; ({%Wilson'%}s {%Glossary:%}) a proclamation by beat of
<div n="lb">drum of general security to all who submit in the case of
<div n="lb">a captured town or conquered country. E. {#aBaya#} and
<div n="lb">{#qiRqima#}.
<LEND>

<L>5856<pc>234-a<k1>aBayada<k2>aBayada
{#aBayada#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) Granting safety,
<div n="lb">removing fear or danger. Comp. {#aBayandada#} and {#aBayaprada#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> A Jaina Arhat. <sup>2</sup> A proper name: the
<div n="lb">son of Manasyu (a descendant of Puru) and father of Dhundu
<div n="lb">(according to the {%Vāyu-Pur.;%} the son of Manasyu and father
<div n="lb">of Sudhanwan, according to the {%Harivanśa%} and {%Brahma-%}
<div n="lb">{%Pur.;%} the {%Viṣṇu-Pur.%} reads instead of Abhayada, Bhayada
<div n="lb">and instead of Dhundu, Sudyumna; comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%V. P.%}
<div n="lb">p. 447 n. 1. and {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%} 1. Anhang p. xx n. 7.).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-dA#}) The name of a plant (Phyllanthus emblica).
<div n="lb">E. {#aBaya#} and {#da#}.
<LEND>

<L>5857<pc>234-a<k1>aBayadakziRA<k2>aBayadakziRA
{#aBayadakziRA#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-RA#}) A promise or assurance of
<div n="lb">protection from danger (which a Brahman may receive
<div n="lb">from even a Śūdra or any body else except from an un-
<div n="lb">chaste woman, a eunuch, an outcaste and an enemy); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Manu:%} {#eDodakaM mUlaPalamannamaByudyataM ca yat . sarvataH pratigf-#}
<div n="lb">{#hlIyAnmaDvaTABayadakziRAm#} ({%Kullukā:%} {#aBayaM cAtmatrARAtmakaM#}
[Page234-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#prItihetutvAddakziRAtulyaM#}). E. {#aBaya#} and {#dakziRA,#} lit. ‘safety,
<div n="lb">as it were, a present’.
<LEND>

<L>5859<pc>234-b<k1>aBayanAga<k2>aBayanAga

<L>5868<pc>234-b<k1>aBayasani<k2>aBayasani
{#aBayasani#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-niH-niH-ni#}) (ved.) Procuring
<div n="lb">a place of safety, i. e. heaven; according to {%Mahīdhara%} on
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#Atmasani prajAsani paSusani lokasanyaBayasani#} (scil.
<div n="lb">{#haviH;#} {%Mah.:%} {#aBayasani . aBayaM svargaM sanoti . svargo vE lo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ko'BayaM svarga eva loke'ntataH pratitizWatIti SruteH#}). E.
<div n="lb">{#aBaya#} and {#sani#}.
<LEND>

<L>5872<pc>234-b<k1>aBavanmatayoga<k2>aBavanmatayoga
{#aBavanmatayoga#}¦ I. Karmadh. m. ({#-gaH#}) (In Rhetoric.) One of
<div n="lb">the twenty one defects to be avoided in the composition of
<div n="lb">a sentence (see {#doza#} and {#vAkyadoza#}); viz. not conveying ac-
<div n="lb">curately by a sentence the intended sense, <sup>a.</sup> by connecting
<div n="lb">syntactically words which have no logical relation to each
<div n="lb">other, or <sup>b.</sup> by disconnecting syntactically words which are
<div n="lb">logically connected, or <sup>c.</sup> by erring in the mode of con-
<div n="lb">nexion; e. g. <sup>a.</sup> in the sentence {#yezAM tAstridaSeBadAnasaritaH#}
<div n="lb">{#pItAH pratApozmaBirlIlApAnaBuvaSca candanatarucCAyAsu yEH ka-#}
<div n="lb">{#lpitAH . yezAM huMkftayaH kftAmarapatikzoBAH kzapAcAriRAM kiM#}
<div n="lb">{#tEstvatparitozakAri vihitaM kiMcitpravAdocitam#} there is no
<div n="lb">logical relation between the words in the relative and those
<div n="lb">in the correlative sentence; or in the sentence {#anena cCi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ndatA mAtuH kaRWaM paraSunA tava . badDasparSaH kfpARo'yaM la-#}
<div n="lb">{#jjate mama BArgava,#} the word {#paraSu,#} although intended to ex-
<div n="lb">press the reason, has no logical connexion with the blame
[Page235-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">uttered against Paraśurāma; (thus the old critics: the mo-
<div n="lb">dern critics however find no fault with this sentence); or
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> in the verse {#yA jayaSrIrmanojasya yayA jagadalaMkftam . yAme-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAkzIM vinA prARA viPalA me kuto'dya sA,#} the word {#eRA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzIm#} ought to stand in the correlative sentence so as to
<div n="lb">become connected with the {%three%} preceding relative sen-
<div n="lb">tences which it is not now; (the {%Sāhityad.%} proposes to mend
<div n="lb">the latter part of this Śloka thus: {#yAM vinAmI vfTA prARA#}
<div n="lb">{#eRAkzI sA kuto'dya me#}); or <sup>c.</sup> in the verse {#jyotsnA ca yaH#}
<div n="lb">{#payaHpUrastArakAH kEravARi ca . rAjati vyomakAsArarAjahaMsaH#}
<div n="lb">{#suDAkaraH,#} the word {#kAsAra#} standing in the same relation
<div n="lb">to {#vyoma,#} as {#payaHpUra#} to {#jyotsnA#} &c., it ought not to be part
<div n="lb">of a compound, as this kind of syntax would affect the
<div n="lb">whole simile; or in the sentence {#Ikzase yatkawAkzeRa tadA DanvI#}
<div n="lb">{#manoBavaH#} the connexion between the two sentences ought
<div n="lb">not to have been effected by {#yad--tadA,#} but by {#cet--#}
<div n="lb">{#tadA#}. See also {#aBavanmatasaMbanDa#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. n. ({#-gam#}) A sentence in which this defect
<div n="lb">occurs. E. {#a-Bavat-mata#} and {#yoga;#} the Bahuvr. scil. {#vAkya;#}
<div n="lb">(the word does not occur as a Karmadh., but only as a
<div n="lb">Bahuvr., in the {%Kāvyaprakāśa;%} comp. the following).
<LEND>

<L>5873<pc>235-a<k1>aBavanmatasambanDa<k2>aBavanmatasambanDa
{#aBavanmatasambanDa#}¦ Karmadh. m. ({#-nDaH#}) (In Rhetoric.) The same
<div n="lb">as {#aBavanmatayoga#}. (The word does not occur as a Bahuvr.
<div n="lb">n., but only as a Karmadh., in the {%Sāhityadarpaṇa;%} comp.
<div n="lb">the preceding). E. {#a-Bavat-mata#} and {#sambanDa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5876<pc>235-a<k1>aBavya<k2>aBavya
{#aBavya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-vyaH-vyA-vyam#}) <sup>1</sup> What is not to be,
<div n="lb">predestined not to be. <sup>2</sup> Not destined to; (in this sense
<div n="lb">with the dative, in the Buddh. {%Dhammapada:%} {#aBabbo pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#hARAyA#}). <sup>3</sup> Inauspicious, unhappy; e. g. in {%Pushpadanta'%}s
<div n="lb">{%(Śiva-) Mahimastotra:%} {#aBavyAnAmasminvaradaramaRIyAmaramaRIM#}
<div n="lb">{#vihantuM vyAkroSIM vidaData ihEke jaqaDiyaH#}. <sup>4</sup> Fraudulent,
<div n="lb">deceitful; e. g. in the {%Vanaparvan%} of the {%Mahābh.:%} {#etasmi-#}

<div n="lb">{#ivAnalaH#} (Rāvaṇa became visible, deceitful on account of
<div n="lb">his future appearance, like fire which is deceitful when covered
<div n="lb">with ashes; {%‘ignes suppositi cineri doloso’%}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bavya#}.
<LEND>

<L>5885<pc>235-b<k1>aBAva<k2>aBAva
{#aBAva#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The not being, the not existing, ab-
<div n="lb">sence; e. g. a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} ({#yasya ca BAvena BAvalakzaRam#}):
<div n="lb">{#BAvalakzaRe saptamIviDAne'BAvalakzaRa upasaMKyAnam;#} or in the
<div n="lb">{%Mīm. Sūtras:%} {#aBAvadarSanAcca,#} or {#aBAvAccetarasya syAt;#} comp.
<div n="lb">also the definition of {#na#} s. v. {#aprASastya;#} but mostly and
<div n="lb">frequently used in this sense as the latter part of a com-
<div n="lb">pound, esp. in scientific writings; e. g. in the {%Mīm. Sūtras:%}
<div n="lb">{#arTABAvAnnEvaM syAt,#} or {#karmABAvAnneti parArTatvAt#} &c.; in
<div n="lb">the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#tadaBAvo nAqIzu tacCruterAtmani ca,#} or {#kA-#}
<div n="lb">{#myAstu yaTAkAmaM samuccIyeranna vA pUrvahetvaBAvAt#} &c.; in the
<div n="lb">{%Sāṅkhya S.:%} {#mUle mUlABAvAdamUlaM mUlam,#} or {#na pOruzeyatvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tatkartuH puruzasyABAvAt#} &c.; in the {%Yoga S.:%} {#hetuPalASrayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#lambanEH saMgfhItatvAdezAmaBAve tadaBAvaH,#} or {#tataH pratyakcetanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Digamo'pyantarAyABAvaSca#} &c.; in the {%Nyāya S.:%} {#vartamAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAve sarvAgrahaRaM pratyakzAnupapatteH,#} or {#prAgutpatteH kAraRABAvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danutpattisamaH#} &c.; in the {%Vaiśeṣika S.:%} {#kAraRABAvAtkAryA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvaH,#} or {#kAryABAvAtkAraRABAvaH;#} or {%Pāṇini:%} {#avyayaM vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BaktisamIpasamfdDivyfdDyarTABAvaººvacanezu#}. <sup>2</sup> Absence, want,
<div n="lb">failure; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.:%} {#aBAve#} (scil. {#yUpasya#}) {#Kadi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ravilvarOhitakAn#} (scil. {#yUpAnkuryAt#}); or {%Vyāsa:%} {#BrAtFRAM#}
<div n="lb">{#jIvatoH pitroH sahavAso viDIyate . tadaBAve viBaktAnAM Darma-#}
<div n="lb">{#stezAM vivarDate;#} or {%Vṛhaspati:%} {#pitroraBAve putrARAM viBAgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#saMpradarSitaH#} (see meaning 4.); or {%Bhūripr. (= Trik.%}): (scil.
<div n="lb">{#aNganAnAm#}) {#aBAvAdaNganAtyAgasturagabrahmacaryakam#}. <sup>3</sup> Non-
<div n="lb">existence, non-entity; in this sense mostly occurring in the
<div n="lb">philosophical Sūtras; e. g. in the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#nABAva upa-#}
<div n="lb">{#labDeH;#} or in the {%Sāṅkhya S.:%} {#anAdAvadya yAvadaBAvAdBavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyadapyevam;#} or in the {%Yoya S.:%} {#aBAvapratyayAlambanA vfttirnidrA;#}
<div n="lb">or in the {%Nyāya S.:%} {#aBAvAdBAvotpattirnAnupamfdya prAdurBAvAt,#}
<div n="lb">or {#sarvamaBAvo BAvezvitaretarABAvasidDeH#}. The category ‘non-
<div n="lb">existence or non-entity’ is originally not to either of the
<div n="lb">six philosophical systems a {#pramARa#} (q. v.) or instrument of
<div n="lb">forming a right notion; it has been adopted, however, as
<div n="lb">such by {%Kumārila-Svāmin,%} the commentator of {%Jaimini%} and
[Page236-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">his followers, and equally by the Vedāntists, although no
<div n="lb">mention is made of it, as of a {%pramāṇa,%} in the {%Brahma-%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtras;%} ({%Gauḍapāda%} is mistaken in mentioning it in his comm.
<div n="lb">on the {%Sāṅkhyakār.%} v. 4. as one of {%Jaimini'%}s {%pramāṇa%}); the
<div n="lb">{%Sāṅkhya%} systems consider it as comprised under the {%pra-%}
<div n="lb">{%māṇa%} {#Aptavacana#} q. v. and the {%Nyāya%} under the {%pramāṇa%}
<div n="lb">{#anumAna#} q. v. In {%Kaṇāda'%}s or the {%Vaiśeṣīka%} system it is
<div n="lb">the seventh or last {#padArTa#} or category, and distinguished as
<div n="lb">{#saMsargABAva#} and {#anyonyABAva,#} the former again as {#prAgaBAva,#}
<div n="lb">{#DvaMsa#} and {#atyantABAva;#} for the definition of these terms see
<div n="lb">s. vv.; (hence the word occurs also in the plural, e. g. in
<div n="lb">the {%Bhāṣaparichchheda:%} {#viSezaRatayA tadvadaBAvAnAM graho#}
<div n="lb">{#'Bavat#}); {%Gauḍapāda%} divides {#aBAva#} in {#prAgaBAva, itaretarA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAva, atyantABAva#} and {#sarvABAva#} qq. vv. <sup>4</sup> Destruction, death;
<div n="lb">e. g. in the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#aBAvaM bAdarirAha hyevam#} ({%Anū-%}
<div n="lb">{%panar.:%} {#muktasya dehAdyaBAvaM bAdarirAha#} &c.; {%Śaṅkara:%} {#…#}
<div n="lb">{#tasmAdaBAvaH SarIrendriyARAM mokze#}); or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBAve#}
<div n="lb">{#BavatAM yo'smiYjIvettasyAstvajIvaniH#} ({%Jayam.%} and {%Bharatas.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBAve vinASe#}). The instances from {%Vyāsa%} and {%Vṛhasp.%}
<div n="lb">under 2. and similar ones might be referred apparently to
<div n="lb">the meaning ‘death’, but it seems more correct to render
<div n="lb">them ‘if the parents are no more’ or ‘in the absence of
<div n="lb">the parents’ &c. instead of ‘on the death of the parents’ &c.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#BAva#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. f. ({#-vA#}) A shade, a shadow (? according
<div n="lb">to the {%Nighanta-Prakāśa%}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#BAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>5893<pc>236-a<k1>aBAzitapuMska<k2>aBAzitapuMska

[Page236-b+ 56]

<L>5894<pc>236-b<k1>aBi<k2>aBi
{#aBi#}¦ ind. (see {#nipAta, upasarga, gati, karmapravacanIya#}) A particle
<div n="lb">implying the notion of proximity, hence of conjunction,
<div n="lb">relation, superiority, excess, in their literal and metapho-
<div n="lb">rical acceptations (and thus becoming in many instances
<div n="lb">synonymous as well with {#A, anu#} as with {#aDi, api,#}
<div n="lb">{#ati#}); it is used either as a prefix to verbs, and as such,
<div n="lb">in the Vedas and archaic passages of the classical literature,
<div n="lb">also detached from the verb (very much in the same man-
<div n="lb">ner as German prepositions when connected with verbs):
<div n="lb">or as a separable preposition: or, in the Vedas and archaic
<div n="lb">passages of the classical literature, as an adverb. With
<div n="lb">nouns it may form Tatpur., Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. com-
<div n="lb">pounds. It appears, too, in the protracted form {#aBI;#} e. g.
<div n="lb">(ved.) {#aBI zu RaH,#} and comp. {#aBIka, aBIGAta, aBIzaNga#} &c.
<div n="P">1. ({%as a prefix to verbs%} it means) <sup>1</sup> Towards, to (im-
<div n="lb">plying proximity); e. g. {#gam#} or {#i#} or {#yA,#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to
<div n="lb">go towards, to approach’; {#kram#} or {#DAv,#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to
<div n="lb">attack’; {#vah#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to carry towards’; {#vad#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">‘to salute’; in many instances where the radical itself im-
<div n="lb">plies this notion, it increases merely the power of the verbal
<div n="lb">meaning and becomes often untranslateable in English; e. g.
<div n="lb">{#pIq#} ‘to squeeze, to vex’ has the same meaning, but in an
<div n="lb">increased degree, with {#aBi, grah#} with {#aBi#} means, like
<div n="lb">{#grah,#} ‘to receive’; {#Barts#} ‘to reproach, to threaten’ has the
<div n="lb">same sense with {#aBi; han#} with {#aBi#} means the same as
<div n="lb">{#han#} &c. <sup>2</sup> Towards, for, against (implying relation, when
<div n="lb">the same remark applies as before); e. g. {#laz#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">‘to desire, to wish for’, {#rAD#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to be favourable
<div n="lb">towards’, {#druh#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to have animosity against’;
<div n="lb">{#yuj#} with {#aBi#} (esp. pass.), ‘to bring an action against,
<div n="lb">to accuse’. <sup>3</sup> On, upon (implying contiguity and answer-
<div n="lb">ing frequently the cognate English be-); e. g. {#su#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">‘to pour the juice of the Soma upon’, {#sic#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">‘to sprinkle upon, to be-sprinkle, {#jan#} with {#aBi,#} ‘to be
<div n="lb">be-got’. <sup>4</sup> On, above, over (implying superiority or master-
<div n="lb">ship); e. g. {#BU#} or {#as#} (cl. 2.) with {#aBi,#} ‘to overpower’;
<div n="lb">{#as#} (cl. 1. or cl. 4.) with {#aBi,#} ‘to study’ (comp. {#gam, i#}
<div n="lb">&c. with {#aDi#}).
<div n="P">2. ({%as a separable preposition%}) with a noun following
<div n="lb">or preceding in the accusative; <sup>1</sup> Towards, to, in the di-
<div n="lb">rection of; e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#suprajAH prajAH prajanayanparIhyaBi rA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaspozeRa yajamAnam;#} or {%Manu:%} {#taM cedaByudiyAtsUryaH#} &c.; (comp.
<div n="lb">s. v. {#aBinirmukta#}); or {%comm. on Pāṇ.:%} {#vfkzamaBi vidyotate vidyut#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Towards, with regard to (implying relation); e. g. {%Ṛgv.%} or {%Vā-%}
<div n="lb">{%jas.:%} {#tripAdUrDva udEtpuruzaH pAdo'syehABavatpunaH . tato vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvaNvyakrAmatsASanAnaSane aBi;#} or {%Siddh. K.:%} {#Bakto harimaBi#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> For the sake of, on behalf of, on account of; e. g. {%Sāmav.:%}
<div n="lb">{#yatra na pUrve pitaraH padajYA svarvido aBi gA adrimizRan;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBi dyotizyate rAmo BavantamacirAdiha#}. <sup>4</sup> In, on;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#saDrIcInena manasA tamindra ojizWena hanmanAhannaBi#}
<div n="lb">{#dyUn#} ‘…on certain days’; or {#yatte gAtrAdagninA pacyamAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#daBi SUlaM#} (on the spit) {#nihatasyAvaDAvati#} &c. <sup>5</sup> Over (im-
<div n="lb">plying dominion, mastership); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sa tu SruDi SrutyA#}
<div n="lb">{#yo duvoyurdyOrna BUmABi rAyo aryaH#}. <sup>6</sup> By (implying distri-
<div n="lb">bution), severally; e. g. {%comm. on Pāṇ.:%} {#vfkzaM vfkzamaBi siYcati#}
<div n="lb">or {#devaM devamaBi siYcati#}.
[Page237-a+ 56]
<div n="P">3. ({%as adverb%}) <sup>1</sup> Before, in front of, towards; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} or {%Atharv.:%} {#gA na vrARA avanIramucadaBi Sravo dAvane#}
<div n="lb">{#sacetAH#} (scil. {#indraH#}), where {%Sāyaṇa%} explains {#aBi#} with the
<div n="lb">ellipsis {#dadAti (aByABimuKyena dadAtIti SezaH)#}. <sup>2</sup> All round,
<div n="lb">everywhere, entirely (comp. {#aBitas#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv:%} {#aBi#}
<div n="lb">{#tvA deva savitarISAnaM vAryARAm . sadAvanBAgamImahe#} (where
<div n="lb">{#tvA#} is not to be connected with {#aBi,#} but with {#Imahe;#} {%Sā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yaṇa:%} {#tvAM prati BAgaM BajanIyaM DanamaBi sarvata Imahe#}); or {%Sā-%}
<div n="lb">{%mav.%} or {%Vājas.:%} {#aBi tyaM devaM savitAramoRyoH kavikratumarcAmi#}
<div n="lb">{#satyasavaM ratnaDAmaBi priyaM matim;#} or {%Śāntip.%} of the {%Mahābh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#DanAdDarmaH praBavati SElAdaBi nadI yaTA#}.
<div n="P">4. ({%in composition with nouns%}) <sup>a.</sup> Tatpur. <sup>1</sup> if it is {#upapada,#}
<div n="lb">it retains the meaning which it has as prefix to the radical;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {#aBikrama, aBiGAta, aBizeka#} &c.; <sup>2</sup> if it is not {#u-#}
<div n="lb">{#papada,#} it implies superiority or excess: excellently, very,
<div n="lb">very much; e. g. {#aBiDarma, aBinIta, aByaDika#}.
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> Bahuvr. <sup>1</sup> Towards, in the direction of; e. g. {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#manas, aBimuKa, aBidyu,#} <sup>2</sup> Excellently, very, very much;
<div n="lb">e. g. {#aBirUpa, aByaNka, aBikratu#}.
<div n="P"><sup>c.</sup> Avyayībh. Towards, in the direction of; e. g. {#aBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#gni, aBidakziRam, aBivAtam#}. E. doubtful; the native E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#Bi#} ({#BA,#} uṇ. aff. {#ki#}) is not very plausible.
<div n="lb">See {#Bi#} and the Preface.
<LEND>

<L>5920<pc>238-a<k1>aBiKyayAdava<k2>aBiKyayAdava

<div n="lb">ed. of {%Hemach. nān.%} and the Mss. of the E. I. H. and of
<div n="lb">the R. A. S.; in several Mss. of the {%Viśvaprak.,%} belonging
<div n="lb">to the E. I. H. and the R. S., this verse runs: {#ºººvirA-#}

<div n="lb">a correction {#virAwABiKye yAdave#} would be at variance with
<div n="lb">the metre, it must be assumed that it ought to be the same
<div n="lb">as in the text of {%Hemachandra%}). E. {#aBiKya#} and {#yAdava#}.

<L>5923<pc>238-a<k1>aBigacCat<k2>aBigacCat

<L>5924<pc>238-a<k1>aBigata<k2>aBigata

<L>5925<pc>238-a<k1>aBigantf<k2>aBigantf

<div n="lb">who has sexual intercourse; comp. {#gantf#}. E. {#gam#} with {#aBi,#}

<L>5926<pc>238-a<k1>aBigama<k2>aBigama
{#aBigama#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> Coming near, approaching;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#lolaM kUlABigame Ke tuNgAmalanibadDapurupari-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAham#} (scil. {#lavaRajalam#}); or {#tataH pravivrAjayizuH kumAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAdikzadasyABigamaM vanAya#}. <sup>2</sup> Arrival; e. g. {#uzRABigama#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Sexual intercourse; e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#prasahya dAsyaBigame daRqo#}
<div n="lb">{#daSapaRaH smftaH#} ‘at a forced intercourse with a {%harlot%} &c’;
<div n="lb">or {%Vivādach.:%} {#SUdrAyAmananyapUrvAyAM kftABigama Aryo…#}
<div n="lb">{#nASyaH;#} comp. {#gama#}. [In derivatives of this word made by
<div n="lb">means of a taddh. aff. which has a {#Y, R#} or {#k#} as anu-
<div n="lb">bandha, both parts of the comp. receive Vṛddhi; comp.
<div n="lb">{#ABigAmika#}.] E. {#gam#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>5928<pc>238-b<k1>aBigamana<k2>aBigamana

<div n="lb">ration of the divinity, by cleansing the temples, images
<div n="lb">&c.’. <sup>2</sup> Sexual intercourse; e. g. {%Vivādach.:%} {#AryastryaBiga-#}
<div n="lb">{#mane liNgodDAraH;#} or {%Dāyabh.:%} {#putrArTaM prATamikABigamana#}

<div n="lb">{#BAryA varamapi ca garBezu vasatirna vAvidvAnrUpadraviRagaRayukto#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi tanayaH;#} comp. {#gamana#} and {#upagamana#}. E. {#gam#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>5944<pc>239-a<k1>aBiGAta<k2>aBiGAta
{#aBiGAta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-taH#}) <sup>1</sup> Striking, beating, wounding; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Kaṇāda S.:%} {#aBiGAtAnmusalasaMyogAdDaste karma;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#GAtAdaBiGAtAdvA hInasattvasya#} &c.; or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#dvizkurvatAM ca-#}
<div n="lb">{#tuzkurvannaBiGAtaM nagErdvizAm . vahizkarizyansaMgrAmAdripUYjva-#}
<div n="lb">{#lanapiNgalaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Pain, infliction; e. g. in a comm. of the
<div n="lb">{%Yoga S.%} (on the word {#dOrmanasya#}): {#dOrmanasyamicCABiGAtA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ccetasaH kzoBaH;#} or {%Lalitav.:%} {#manaHsaMvaro DarmalokamuKamaBiGA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tavyApAdamiTyAdfzwiprahARAya saMvartate#}. <sup>3</sup> Warding off, removal;
<div n="lb">e. g. in {%Gauḍapāda'%}s comm. on the {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#ADiBO-#}
<div n="lb">{#tikasya#} (scil. {#duHKasya#}) {#rakzAdinABiGAto dfzwaH#}. <sup>4</sup> (In the
<div n="lb">{%Vājas. Prātisākhya.%}) The vehemence or physical excite-
<div n="lb">ment which accompanies the recital of mantras at the
<div n="lb">evening oblation ({#tftIyasavana#}), when the voice is loudest,
<div n="lb">it being low at the morning oblation ({#prAtaHsavana#}) and louder
<div n="lb">in the noon-oblation ({#mADyandinasavana#}). Compare besides
<div n="lb">the terms {#AyAma, mArdava, viSramBa, Akzepa#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-tam#}) A harsh pronunciation (e. g. when putting
<div n="lb">a question), produced by the neglect of Sandhi rules, more
<div n="lb">esp. by combining a preceding soft {%aspirate%} sound ({#Ga, Ja,#}
<div n="lb">{#Qa, Da, Ba#}) with a following unaspirate sound (either {#ka, ca,#}
<div n="lb">{#wa, ta, pa#} or {#ga, ja, qa, da, Ba#}), or a hard aspirate sound
<div n="lb">({#Ka, Ca, Wa, Ta, Pa#}) with a following hard unaspirate sound
<div n="lb">({#ka, ca, wa, ta, pa#}), or a soft unaspirate sound ({#ga, ja, qa,#}
<div n="lb">{#da, ba#}) with a following hard aspirate sound ({#Ka, Ca, Wa,#}
<div n="lb">{#Ta, Pa#}). ({%Keralagrantha,%} as quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}) Also {#aBI-#}
<div n="lb">{#GAta#}. E. {#han#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#} and {#n#} changed to {#t#}.
<LEND>

<L>5953<pc>239-b<k1>aBicakzaRa<k2>aBicakzaRa
{#aBicakzaRa#}¦ Tatpur. I. n. ({#-Ram#}) (ved.) (Probably.) A magic

<div n="lb">pointing out, making clear; {%Atharvav.:%} {#yAvatIrdiSaH pradiSo#}

<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#yuc#}. (This would be the E. according to
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 149., when the word must form a fem. in {#A,#}
<div n="lb">and be udātta on the last syllable; but if the present ed.
<div n="lb">of the {%Atharv.%} is correct, there is an irregularity in the ac-
<div n="lb">centuation, for the word is udātta on the third syllable,
<div n="lb">i. e. it is accentuated like the neuter, formed with {#lyuw,#}
<div n="lb">although the fem. is not in {#I;#} but perhaps the aff. is {#lyu#}.)
<LEND>

<L>5959<pc>239-b<k1>aBicaritavE<k2>aBicaritavE
{#aBicaritavE#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) <sup>1</sup> To enchant for a malevo-
<div n="lb">lent purpose. <sup>2</sup> To be enchanted for such a purpose; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Kāśikā:%} {#tasmAtpitA nABicaritavE;#} or {%Swaramanj.:%} {#agni-#}
<div n="lb">{#cinnABicaritavE#}. (The word has two accents: the udātta
<div n="lb">on the second and on the last syllable.) E. {#car#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#tavEH#} (i. e. an obsolete dative of an obsolete base
<div n="lb">{#aBicaritu;#} comp. the following).
<LEND>
[Page240-a+ 56]

<L>5960<pc>240-a<k1>aBicaritos<k2>aBicaritos
{#aBicaritos#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) To enchant for a malevo-
<div n="lb">lent purpose (= {#aBicaritum#}); e. g. {%Kāśikā:%} {#ISvaro'Bi-#}
<div n="lb">{#caritoH#}. E. {#car#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tosun;#} (i. e. the
<div n="lb">genitive of an obsolete base {#aBicaritu#} with the udātta on
<div n="lb">the second syllable; comp. the preceding).
<LEND>

<L>5961<pc>240-a<k1>aBicAra<k2>aBicAra
{#aBicAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) Incantation, employment of charms
<div n="lb">or spells for a malevolent purpose.--The {%Shaḍvinśa-Brā-%}
<div n="lb">{%hmaṇa%} names as such purposes: killing an enemy and de-
<div n="lb">priving him of his cattle or property; it gives an account
<div n="lb">of four sacrifices which are performed for the attainment
<div n="lb">of these objects, (see {#Syena, trivfdagnizwoma, saMdaMSa#} and {#vajra#})
<div n="lb">and describes the manner in which the mantras are to be
<div n="lb">recited at these sacrifices; (see {#vizwuti#}).--The {%Tantrasāra%}
<div n="lb">(as quoted by {%Rādhākāntad.%}) names six purposes of incan-
<div n="lb">tation, viz. causing death ({#mAraRa#}), mental aberration ({#mo-#}
<div n="lb">{#hana#}), stoppage of the bodily functions ({#stamBana#}), hatred ({#vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvezaRa#}), ruin ({#uccAwana#}) and submission ({#vaSIkaraRa#}). [Comp.
<div n="lb">e. g. also the following passage from the {%Skanda-Purāṇa:%}
<div n="lb">{#kuSErvA dUrvayA devi Asane SuBrakambale . upaviSya tato devi#}
<div n="lb">{#japedekAgramAnasaH#} (scil. {#gurugItAm#}) {#. SuklAsane vE SAntyarTe#}
<div n="lb">{#'vaSye raktAsanaM priye . aBicAre kfzRavarRaM pItavarRaM DanAgame .#}
<div n="lb">{#uttare SAntijApyasyAvaSye pUrvamuKoditam . dakziRe mAraRaM#}
<div n="lb">{#proktaM stamBane paScime muKam . mohanaM sarvaBUtAnAM banDamokzakaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#param . devaBUpapriyakaraM rAjAnaM vaSamAnayet#} &c.]--{%Suśruta%}
<div n="lb">speaks of a variety of fever caused by incantation (see {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#BicArajvara#} and comp. {#aBizaNgajvara#}), the symptoms of
<div n="lb">which are, according to the {%Nighaṇṭa Prakāśa,%} thirst,
<div n="lb">mental aberration, abscesses, delirium, fainting, anguish,
<div n="lb">excessive heat &c.--{%Manu%} (likewise Viṣṇu &c.) when
<div n="lb">speaking of incantations (9. 290.) makes a distinction between
<div n="lb">{#aBicAra, mUlakarman#} and various {#kftyA;#} the former com-
<div n="lb">prises, according to {%Medhātithi%} and {%Kullūka%} as well incan-
<div n="lb">tations founded on vaidik writings ({#vEdika#} or {#SAstrIya,#}
<div n="lb">such as the Śyena &c.), as those founded on vulgar super-
<div n="lb">stition ({#lOkika,#} such as taking the dust of the feet, digging
<div n="lb">in needles--{#sUcIniKanana#} in the E. I. H. Mss. of {%Medh.%} being
<div n="lb">apparently a better reading than {#mUlaniKanana#} in the present edd.
<div n="lb">of {%Kull.%}--&c.) for the purpose of {%causing death;%} {#mUlakarman#} is,
<div n="lb">according to both comm., {%subduing%} a person by means of
<div n="lb">mantras, drugs &c. ({%Kull.:%} {#mantrOzaDAdinA;#} {%Medh.:%} {#mantrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dikriyayA#}); the {#kftyA#} are, according to {%Kullūka,%} incantations
<div n="lb">for the sake of {%causing ruin, making sick%} &c., according to
<div n="lb">{%Medh.,%} for the sake of {%causing ruin, animosity between friends%}
<div n="lb">{%or relatives, working wonders%} &c. ({#uccAwanasuhfdbanDukalahavici-#}
<div n="lb">{#trIkaraRAdihetavaH#}).--{%Manu%} fines a person who employs
<div n="lb">charms two hundred Paṇas (9. 290.), classes in another pas-
<div n="lb">sage {#aBicAra#} and {#mUlakarman#} amongst the Upapātaka (11. 63.)
<div n="lb">and makes the expiation of an {#aBicAra#} depend on the per-
<div n="lb">formance, thrice repeated, of the penance called Kṛchchhra
<div n="lb">(11. 197.). But as these clauses would jar apparently with
<div n="lb">the vaidik texts which impliedly sanction the employment
<div n="lb">of charms by regulating the sacrifices Śyena &c. performed
<div n="lb">for incantatory purposes, {%Kullūka%} qualifies the definition of
<div n="lb">Manu 11. 63. by commenting that {#aBicAra#} is an {#upapAtaka,#} if
<div n="lb">it causes the death of an {%innocent%} or {%unoffending%} person ({#SyenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#diyajYenAnaparADasya mAraRam#}), while {%Medhātithi%} seems merely
[Page240-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">to lay stress on the fact of {%death%} itself (although the death
<div n="lb">be that of an enemy) and perhaps too on the condition of
<div n="lb">death being caused by a {%vaidik%} kind of incantation ({%Medh.%}
<div n="lb">to 11. 63.: {#aBicAro vEdikena SApAdinA mantraprayogeRa Sye-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAdiyAgena vA SatrumAraRam,#} or to 11. 197.: {#vEdikena japaho-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAdinA SatrormAraRamaBicAraH#}); for the same reason, pro-
<div n="lb">bably, both comm. agree in giving to the penalty clause
<div n="lb">(9. 290) the additional sense: ‘if the incantation does {%not%}
<div n="lb">{%cause death%}’, and qualify, in the clause 11. 197., the incan-
<div n="lb">tation as one ‘directed against a person who ought not to have
<div n="lb">been brought under the spell (i. e. an innocent or unoffending
<div n="lb">person)’; some however, as results from {%Medh.'%}s discussion
<div n="lb">on the latter verse, give it a different bearing, for they supply
<div n="lb">the preceding word {#yAjana#} at {#aBicAra#} and subject thus to the
<div n="lb">penance Kṛchchhra, not the {#yajamAna#} or the person who
<div n="lb">institutes an incantatory sacrifice, but the {#ftvij#} or the
<div n="lb">priest who performs for him such a sacrifice. But in spite
<div n="lb">of these efforts of the commentators to establish a harmony
<div n="lb">between Manu and the Veda, it will seem that another
<div n="lb">possibility alluded to by {%Medhātithi%} is more plausible, viz.
<div n="lb">that Manu did not attach any scriptural authority to such
<div n="lb">voluntary rites, as the incantatory sacrifices, and, there-
<div n="lb">fore, did not consider himself at variance with the Veda,
<div n="lb">when he interdicted incantations in an unqualified manner;
<div n="lb">({%Medhātithi:%} {#nanu ca kAmyAnyapi nizidDAni . kAmAtmatA na praSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#steti . yattasya vizayaH . sa tatrEva vyAKyAtaH#}). E. {#car#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">Kalpas of this Veda. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#kalpa#}.

<L>5964<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArajvara<k2>aBicArajvara

<div n="lb">tations; see s. v. {#aBicAra#}. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#jvara#}.
<LEND>

<L>5965<pc>240-b<k1>aBicAraRIya<k2>aBicAraRIya
{#aBicAraRIya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) To be enchanted,
<div n="lb">deserving or allowed to be brought under a spell; e. g. {%Kul-%}
<div n="lb">{%lūka:%} {#aBicAro'naBicAraRIyasya;#} or {%Medhātithi:%} {#aBicA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRIyABicAro'pyanujYAmnAtaH#}. E. {#car#} in the caus., with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar#}.
<LEND>

<L>5966<pc>240-b<k1>aBicAramantra<k2>aBicAramantra
{#aBicAramantra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ntraH#}) A formula or hymn for working
<div n="lb">a charm or incantation; e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#sPuwamidamaBicA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ramantra eva prati yuvateraBiDAnamaNganAnAm#}. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#mantra#}.
<LEND>

<L>5967<pc>240-b<k1>aBicArayajYa<k2>aBicArayajYa
{#aBicArayajYa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jYaH#}) A sacrifice for the purpose
<div n="lb">of incantations, a sacrifice with magic powers, viz. either
<div n="lb">of the sacrifices called {#Syena, trivfdagnizwoma, saMdaMSa, vajra#}
<div n="lb">qq. vv. See {#aBicAra#}. E. {#aBicAra#} and {#yajYa#}.

<div n="lb">cording to the Dhātupār.).

<>EXTENDED AND IMPROVED FROM THE SECOND EDITION OF THE DICTIONARY
<>OF
<>PROFESSOR H. H. WILSON,
<>WITH HIS SANCTION AND CONCURRENCE;
<>TOGETHER WITH
<>A SUPPLEMENT, GRAMMATICAL APPENDICES AND AN INDEX,
<>SERVING AS
<>AN ENGLISH-SANSKRIT VOCABULARY.
<>BY
<>THEODOR GOLDSTÜCKER,
<>PH. D., PROFESSOR OF THE SANSKRIT LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE IN
<>UNIVERSITY COLLEGE, LONDON.

<L>5973<pc>241-a<k1>aBija<k2>aBija
{#aBija#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Grown round or every-
<div n="lb">where; comp. {#aBijAta;#} e. g. {#aBijAH keSAH#}. E. {#jan#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa#}.
<LEND>

<L>5974<pc>241-a<k1>aBijagmivas<k2>aBijagmivas
{#aBijagmivas#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gmivAn-gmuzI-gmivat#}) Hav-
<div n="lb">ing arrived. E. {#gam#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvasu#}.
<LEND>

<L>5975<pc>241-a<k1>aBijana<k2>aBijana
{#aBijana#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) <sup>1</sup> Native country; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
<div n="lb">{#tataH pragaditA vAkyaM miTilABijanA nfpam#}. <sup>2</sup> The country
<div n="lb">of the ancestors; (this is the sense given to the word by
<div n="lb">{%Patanjali%} to {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 3. 90. in distinction from {#nivAsa,#} IV.
<div n="lb">3. 89., which would mean according to him the country where
<div n="lb">one lives oneself: {#aTa nivAsABijanayoH ko viSezaH . ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAso nAma yatra saMpratyuzyate . aBijano nAma yatra pUrvEruzitam#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> The ancestors; (according to {%Kaiyyaṭa%}--hence {%Kāśikā%}
<div n="lb">and {%Vardhamāna%}--on the preceding quotation: {#aBijana-#}
<div n="lb">{#Sabdena pUrve bAnDavA ucyante#} &c.). <sup>4</sup> Race, family in general;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Lāṭyāyana:%} {#ya ezAmaDyayane'BikrAntitamaH syAdaBijanena#}
<div n="lb">{#vA#} ({%Agnisvāmin:%} {#aBijanaH kulam#}). <sup>5</sup> The head or ornament
<div n="lb">of a family. <sup>6</sup> Fame, notoriety. E. {#jan#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#GaY#} (according to the commentators of the {%Amarak.;%}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ac,#} according to {%Bharatas.%} on the {%Bhaṭṭik.%}).
<LEND>

<L>5976<pc>241-a<k1>aBijanavat<k2>aBijanavat
{#aBijanavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) Of family, of a noble
<div n="lb">family. (In the verse of the {%Rāmāy.%} {#tacCutvA Barato vAkyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#DarmABijanavAYCuciH . papAta#} &c. the word {#DarmABijanavAn#}
<div n="lb">is not to be rendered as equivalent to {#DarmavAnaBijanavAMSca,#}
<div n="lb">‘virtuous and of noble family’, but ‘of a virtuous family’;
<div n="lb">{%Maheśvaratīrtha:%} = {#Darmayukto'Bijano'nvayo yasyAstIti#}
<div n="lb">{#taTA;#} {%another:%} = {#DarmayuktavaMSavAn#}.) E. {#aBijana,#} taddh. aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>5977<pc>241-a<k1>aBijanitos<k2>aBijanitos
{#aBijanitos#}¦ Tatpur. ind. (ved.) To produce. E. {#jan#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tosun#} (i. e. the genitive of an obsolete base
<div n="lb">in {#-tu;#} with the udātta on the second syllable, used like
<div n="lb">the classical infin. in {#-tum#}).
