<div n="lb">Having the characteristic property of {#aBimAna#} 1. q. v.; as
<div n="lb">{#ahaMkAra#} q. v.; e. g. {%Vijnānāch.%} (on the {%Sāṅkhya S.%} {#caramo#}
<div n="lb">{#'haMkAraH#}): {#yaH so haM karotItyahaMkAro'BimAnavfttikaH;#} or
<div n="lb">(on the {%Sāṅkhya S.%} {#ahaMkAro kartA na puruzaH#}): {#aBimAnavf-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttikamantaHkaraRamahaMkAraH;#} comp. also the quotation s. v. {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#BimAna#} 1. and {#aBimAnAtmaka#}. E. {#aBimAna#} and {#vftti,#} sa-
<div n="lb">māsānta aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6236<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnita<k2>aBimAnita

<div n="lb">course. E. (probably) {#aBi#} and {#mAnita#}.
<div n="P">II. f. ({#-tA#}) The same as {#aBimAnitva#} q. v.; comp. the
<div n="lb">quotation s. v. {#aBimantf#}. E. {#aBimAnin,#} taddh. aff. {#tal#}.

<L>6237<pc>258-a<k1>aBimAnitva<k2>aBimAnitva
{#aBimAnitva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philosophy.) The condition of
<div n="lb">one who conceives objects with the notion that they refer
<div n="lb">exclusively to one's own self. <sup>2</sup> Personification, persona-
<div n="lb">tion; e. g. {%Jaiminīyanyāy.:%} {#pfTivI hotetyAdiko mantraScaturhI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA . tasminmantre yajYANgAnAM caturRAM SrutatvAt . aTavA tasya ma-#}
[Page258-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#ntrasyABimAnitvenAtmaBUtaH kaScitpuruzaH prajApatinA caturvAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAmantritaH pratyuttaramuvAceti sa puruzaScaturhUtaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Pride, ar-
<div n="lb">rogance. Also {#aBimAnitA#}. E. {#aBimAnin,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6238<pc>258-b<k1>aBimAnin<k2>aBimAnin
{#aBimAnin#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-nI-ninI-ni#}) <sup>1</sup> (In Philo-
<div n="lb">sophy.) Conceiving objects with the notion that they refer
<div n="lb">exclusively to one's own self; esp., however, with the im-
<div n="lb">plied sense that such conception is erroneous; (comp. {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAna#} 1.); e. g. (in the {%Vedānta,%} the inferior degrees of the
<div n="lb">absolute Spirit, each of which conceives the world as re-
<div n="lb">ferring exclusively to itself) {%Ved. Sāra:%} {#etatsamazwyupahitaM cE-#}
<div n="lb">{#tanyaM vESvAnaro virAqiti cocyate sarvanarABimAnitvAdviviDaM#}
<div n="lb">{#rAjamAnatvAcca#} ‘he is called Vaiśvānara, because he conceives
<div n="lb">the whole of mankind as referring to him exclusively &c.’
<div n="lb">(where the affix {#tva#} belongs to the whole compound {#sarvanara-#}
<div n="lb">{#aBimAnin#}). <sup>2</sup> Conceiving (in general), but esp. with the
<div n="lb">implied sense: conceiving erroneously, fancying, imagining;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Udyogap. Mahābh.:%} {#prajYABimAnI pratikUlavAdI tyAjyaH#}
<div n="lb">{#sa tAdfktvarayEva BftyaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Personifying, personating; e. g. {%Śan-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara%} in his comm. on the {%Chhānd. Up.:%} {#…te sarve'rcizam#}
<div n="lb">(i. e.) {#arciraBimAninIM devatAmaBiniviSanti#} (i. e. {#pratipadya-#}
<div n="lb">{#nte#}) &c. {#…. te DUmaM#} (i. e.) {#DUmABimAninIM devatAmABimu-#}
<div n="lb">{#Kyena saMBavanti#} &c. {#…. nEte karmiRaH prakftAH saMvatsaraM#} (i. e.)
<div n="lb">{#saMvatsarABimAninIM devatAmaBiprApnuvanti;#} or {%Mahīdh.%} in the
<div n="lb">comm. on the {%Vājas.:%} {#SAKAdInAmacetanatve'pi tadaBimAni-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAM devatAnAM sattvAddevatAtvam . aBimAnivyapadeSastviti vyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sasUtrokteH;#} or {#saMvatsarABimAnI prajApatiH stUyate;#} or {%Sāy.:%} {#yadya-#}
<div n="lb">{#pi tisra eva devatA ityuktatvAtkzityAdyaBimAninyo devatAstisra#}
<div n="lb">{#eva#} &c.; or {%Prabodhach.:%} {#maDumatyA ca BUmimApannaH sTAnABimA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ninIBirdevatABirupacCandyate#} ‘…by the deities who personated
<div n="lb">the place’, i. e. who created in Purusha's mind the illusion that
<div n="lb">it was mount Meru; or {%Vedānta-Sūtra:%} {#aBimAnivyapadeSastu#}
<div n="lb">{#viSezAnugatiByAm#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#na Kalu mfdabravIdityevaMjAtIya-#}
<div n="lb">{#kayA SrutyA BUtendriyARAM cetanatvamASaNkanIyam . yato'Bi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnivyapadeSa ezaH . mfdAdyaBimAninyo vAgAdyaBimAninyaSca ce-#}
<div n="lb">{#tanAdevatA vadanasaMvadanAdizu cetanocitezu vyavahArezu vyapadi-#}
<div n="lb">{#Syante na BUtendriyamAtram#}); or {%Daśakumārach.:%} {#kaScinnarendrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BimAnI mAM nivarRya#} &c. ‘somebody personating a doctor &c.’.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Proud, not bearing a slight, haughty; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAninamudBrAntamAtmasaMBAvitaM SaWam .…Gnanti vEriRaH;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Gītagov.:%} {#hariraBimAnI rajaniridAnImiyamapi yAti virA-#}
<div n="lb">{#mam . kuru mama vacanaM#} &c. (comm. {#laGutvaM na sahate#}). <sup>5</sup> Wishing,
<div n="lb">desiring; e. g. {%Vijnānāch.%} on a {%Sāṅkhya S.:%} {#…ahaMkAra#}
<div n="lb">{#indriyAdihetuH . loke BogABimAninEva rAgadvArA Bogopaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRanirmARadarSanAt#} (v. 1. {#BogopakaraRakaraRadarSanAt#}). <sup>6</sup> Do-
<div n="lb">ing injury, hostile, an enemy; e. g. {%Sāyaṇa%} (in the comm. on
<div n="lb">{#aBimAti#}): {#aBimAtIraBimAninaH karmaviGnakAriRaH SacUn#}.
<div n="P"> 2. m. ({#-nI#}) <sup>1</sup> A name of Agni as the eldest born of
<div n="lb">Brahman (masc.); according to the {%Viṣṇu Purāṇa.%} <sup>2</sup> The
<div n="lb">name of a son of the Manu Bhautya who presides over the
<div n="lb">fourteenth Manwantara. (There is probably an allegorical
<div n="lb">connexion between the name of these personages and the
<div n="lb">Sāṅkhya doctrine which makes {#ahaMkAra#} originate in the prin-
<div n="lb">ciple of intellect.) E. {#man#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini;#} 1. 4.
<div n="lb">perhaps not a Tatpur., but {#aBimAna,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>6242<pc>259-a<k1>aBimuKa<k2>aBimuKa
{#aBimuKa#}¦ I. Bahuvr. or Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-KaH-KA#} or {#-KI;#}
<div n="lb">see {%N. B.;%} {#-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> With the face directed towards, facing,
<div n="lb">fronting; e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#SArdUlo'BimuKo'Byeti;#} or in the
<div n="lb">locat. used adverbially, {%Rāmāy.:%} {#kftAYjaliruvAcedaM SvaSrUma-#}
<div n="lb">{#BimuKe sTitAm#}. <sup>2</sup> Near, approaching; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#yu-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoja pAkABimuKErBftyAnvijYApanAPalEH;#} comp. also {#aBimu-#}
<div n="lb">{#KIkaraRa, aBimuKIBUta#}. <sup>3</sup> Disposed towards, engaged in,
<div n="lb">ready for; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#prAtaH prayARABimuKAya…tasmE#}
<div n="lb">{#vfzwiM SaSaMsuH;#} or {#svasAramAdAya vidarBarAjaH purapraveSABimu-#}
<div n="lb">{#Ko baBUva#}. <sup>4</sup> Kindly disposed, favourable, propitious; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#na nAstikenABimuKo buDaH syAt;#} or {%Lalitav.:%} {#ye#}
<div n="lb">(scil. {#boDisattvAH#}) {#tuzitavaraBavanasTAH sarve caramaBavABimu-#}
<div n="lb">{#KAH#} &c. <sup>5</sup> With the face upwards; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#ABugnI#}
<div n="lb">{#'BimuKaH Sete garBI garBASaye striyAH . sa yoniM SirasA yAti#}
<div n="lb">{#svaBAvAtprasavaM prati;#} comp. also the {%comm.%} of the {%Nalodaya%}
<div n="lb">on the word {#anavAk,#} viz.: {#avAk . aDomuKaH . na avAk .#}
<div n="lb">{#anavAk . aBimuKaH#}. [N. B. According to a {%Kārikā%} on
<div n="lb">{%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 54. the fem. of this word must end in {#I (NIz),#}
<div n="lb">if it is applied to a {%living being,%} otherwise in {#A;#} thus e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#rAjAnamevABimuKI kEkeyI vAkyamabravIt;#} or {#prayAtu#}
<div n="lb">{#caturaNgiRI . ayoDyABimuKI senA;#} or {%Śaṅk.%} on {%Chh. Upan.%}
<div n="lb">4. 6. 1.: {#tAH SanEScarantya AcAryakulABimuKyaH prasTitAH;#} but {%Kā-%}
<div n="lb">{%śikā:%} {#aBimuKA SAlA;#} comp. e. g. {#candramuKI#} and similar
<div n="lb">compounds (said of a woman) but {#SlakzRamuKA SAlA#}.]
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-KI#}) One of ten earths stepped upon by Buddha,
<div n="lb">in Buddhistic mythology; (in the classical Sanskṛt this fem.
<div n="lb">in {#I#} instead of in {#A#} would be doubly wrong; comp. the
<div n="lb">foregoing remark and {%Pāṇ.%} IV. 1. 58.).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-Kam#}) <sup>1</sup> With the face towards, in the
<div n="lb">direction towards; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#AsyatAmiti coktaH sannA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sItABimuKaM guroH;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#vyaktoditasmitamayUKaviBA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sitozWastizWanmuneraBimuKaM sa vikIrRaDAmnaH;#} or {%Ṛtusaṃh.:%} {#cU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tavfkzAn . aBimuKamaBivIkzya;#} or in the {%dramas:%} {#nepaTyABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#muKamavalokya#}. <sup>2</sup> Near; e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#svagfhABimuKaM prayAtaH;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBimuKapatitErguRaprakarzAdavarjitam#} &c.; or {%Me-%}
<div n="lb">{%ghad.:%} {#arcistuNgAnaBimuKagatAnprAzya ratnapradIpAn#}. [{#aBimuKa#}
<div n="lb">is udātta on the last syllable; this accent follows for the
<div n="lb">{%Avyayībh.%} from {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 223., for the {%Tatpur.%} from VI.
<div n="lb">2. 185., and for the {%Bahuvr.%} from the same Sūtra, since the
<div n="lb">rule VI. 2. 177. (exception to VI. 2. 168.) concerns only such
<div n="lb">Bahuvr. ending in {#muKa,#} as express a {%permanent%} condition
<div n="lb">of the face (comp. {#pramuKa#}), not a {%transitory%} one like ‘facing’,
<div n="lb">and applies moreover only to the {%literal%} meaning of {#muKa,#}
<div n="lb">not to the figur. sense it has e. g. in {#aBimuKA#} as epithet
<div n="lb">of {#SAlA;#} (but VI. 2. 177. applies probably also to {#aBimuKa#} I.
<div n="lb">1. 5.); {%Kāśikā:%} {#bahuvrIhirayam . prAdisamAso vA . avyayI-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAve tu samAsAntodAttatvenEva sidDam . upasargAtsvANgamiti#}
<div n="lb">{#sidDe vacanamabahuvrIhyarTam . aDruvArTam . asvANgArTaM ca;#} comp.
<div n="lb">the quotation from {%Patanj.%} s. v. {#apamuKa#}.] E. {#aBi#} and {#muKa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6250<pc>259-b<k1>aBimlAta<k2>aBimlAta

<L>6253<pc>259-b<k1>aBiyA<k2>aBiyA
{#aBiyA#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. ({#-yAH-yAH#}) Coming near, approaching,
<div n="lb">esp. with a hostile intention; attacking, assailing; e. g. in
<div n="lb">the following {#mahAyamaka#} of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBiyAtA varaM tuNgaM#}
<div n="lb">{#BUBftaM ruciraM puraH . karkaSaM praTitaM DAma sasattvaM puzkarekzaRam ..#}
<div n="lb">{#aBiyAtAvaraM#} (or {#aBiyAtA varaM#}) {#tuNgaM BUBftaM ruciraM puraH .#}
<div n="lb">{#karkaSaM praTitaM DAma sasattvaM puzkare kzaRam;#} where {#aBiyAtA-#}
<div n="lb">{#varam#} in the second Śloka is analyzed by the commentators
<div n="lb">either {#aBiyA#} (instrum. sing. of {#aBiyA#} or of {#aBI#} ‘fear-
<div n="lb">less’, scil. {#hanUmatA#}) and {#atAvaram#} ({#ata#} ‘wind, sun &c.’
<div n="lb">and {#Avaram#}) or {#aBiyAtA#} (instrum. sing. of {#aBiyAt#})
<div n="lb">and {#varam#}. E. {#yA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>6254<pc>259-b<k1>aBiyAcanA<k2>aBiyAcanA

<L>6257<pc>259-b<k1>aBiyAt<k2>aBiyAt

<div n="lb">assailing; comp. {#aBiyA#}.

<L>6259<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyAti<k2>aBiyAti

<div n="lb">following and {#aBiyAt#}. (Perhaps the abstract femin. in
<div n="lb">the sense ‘aggression’ personified as a masc., like in {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BUti#} &c.) E. {#yA#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6260<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyAtin<k2>aBiyAtin

<div n="lb">(according to {%Rāyamuk., Bharata%} &c. on the {%Amarak.%}). E.
<div n="lb">(according to {%Rāyam.%}) {#yat#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini;#} but
<div n="lb">it seems plausible to connect the E. of this word with that
<div n="lb">of {#aBiyAti#} and to derive it from {#yA#} with {#aBi#} by an
<div n="lb">aff. {#tin;#} comp. {#aBimAtin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6264<pc>260-a<k1>aBiyukta<k2>aBiyukta
{#aBiyukta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) <sup>1</sup> Diligent, intent,
<div n="lb">studiously engaged in; e. g. {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} {#svakarmaRyaBiyukto#}
<div n="lb">{#yaH saNgadvezavivarjitaH . pUjitastadviDErnityamApto jYeyaH sa tAdfSaH;#}
<div n="lb">also applied to {%religious meditation,%} i. e. engaged in medi-
<div n="lb">tation; e. g. {%Bhagavadg.:%} {#ananyAScintayanto mAM ye janAH#}
<div n="lb">{#paryupAsate . tezAM nityABiyuktAnAM yogakzemaM vahAmyaham#} ({#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyAº:#} {%Arjunam.:%} = {#sarvadA madekanizWAnAm;#} {%Śaṅkara:%} = {#sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#tatABiyoginAm;#} {%Sadānanda%} in his metrical gloss: = {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#dareRa sadA DyAne vyApftAnAm#} &c.). <sup>2</sup> Versed in, instructed;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Kumārila's Mīm. Vārtt.:%} {#SAstrArTezvaBiyuktAnAM puruzARAM#}
<div n="lb">{#hi sarvadA . stokenApyanyaTAtvena SAstrArTo nizPalo Bavet;#}
<div n="lb">also used absolutely in the sense of {%learned, a scholar,%} e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Kumārila:%} {#aBiyuktAnaBiyuktajYAnayoScABiyuktajYAnaM balavadi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tarasya sulaBApavAdatvAt . ataH SAstrABiyuktatvAdAryAvartani-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAsinAm . yA matiH sEva DarmANgaSabdArTatvapramA matA .. ete-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAryAvartanivAsimaDye'pi .. aBiyuktatarA ye ye bahuSAstrArTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vedinaH . te te yatra prayuYjIransa so'rTastattvato Bavet;#} or {%Rā-%}
<div n="lb">{%matīrtha%} on the {%Vedānta S.:%} {#taduktamaBiyuktEH . muKyaM tu sapta-#}
<div n="lb">{#daSakaM praTitaM hi liNgamiti#}. Comp. also {#aBiyoga#}. <sup>3</sup> At-
<div n="lb">tacked, assaulted, assailed; e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBiyuktaM tvayE-#}
<div n="lb">{#naM te gantArastvAmato'pare#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#aBiyuktam . aBiyAtam#});
<div n="lb">or {%Hitop.:%} {#aBiyukto yadA paSyenna kiMcidDitamAtmanaH . yuDya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAnastadA prAjYo mriyate ripuRA saha;#} or {#balIyasABiyuktastu#}
<div n="lb">{#nfpo'nanyapratikriyaH . ApannaH saMDimanvicCetkurvARaH kAlayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#panam;#} or {%Bharatas.%} on the words {#mfzA te mayi duHsTabudDiH#}
<div n="lb">of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#mayyasmadvizaye duHsTo'yamariBiraBiyukto'ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti te tava budDirmfzA miTyA#}. <sup>4</sup> Blamed, rebuked ({%Wilson%}).
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> (In Law.) Charged, prosecuted, defendant; e. g. {%Yājnav.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBiyogamanistIrya nEnaM pratyaBiyojayet . aBiyuktaM ca nAnyena#}
<div n="lb">&c.; or {%Nārada:%} {#aBiyuktastaTAnyena rAjakarmodyatastaTA#} (v. 1.
<div n="lb">{#rAjakAryoºº#}) {#.…vizamasTASca nAseDyA na cEtAnnAhvaye-#}
<div n="lb">{#nnfpaH;#} or {%Vyavahārat.%} on {%Vṛhasp.:%} {#atrABiyuktena SapaTaH karta-#}
<div n="lb">{#vya ityutsargaH#}. Comp. {#aBiyoga#}. E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6270<pc>260-b<k1>aBiyoga<k2>aBiyoga
{#aBiyoga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Connexion, application; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Chaurapanch.:%} {#adyApi tatkanakakuRqalaGfzwagaRqamAsyaM smarAmi#}
<div n="lb">{#viparItaratABiyoge#} ({%Gaṇapati:%} {#aBiyogaH saMbanDaH#}). <sup>2</sup> Ener-
<div n="lb">getic effort, exertion; ({%Hemach.%} = {#udyama#}); e. g. {%Jayamang.%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kftamAraRABiyogA rAtricarI#}. <sup>3</sup> Instructed-
<div n="lb">ness, learning, scholarship; e. g. {%Śabara:%} {#anaBiyogaSca Sa-#}
<div n="lb">{#bdArTezvaSizwAnAm . aBiyogaScetarezAm;#} or {%Mīm. Sūtra:%} {#tatra#}
<div n="lb">{#tattvamaBiyogaviSezAtsyAt#} ({%Śabara:%} {#kaTaM punastatra tattvaM SakyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vijYAtum . SakyamityAha . arTino hyaBiyuktA Bavanti dfSyate#}
<div n="lb">{#cABiyuktAnAM guRavatAmavismaraRamupapannam;#} {%Kumārila:%} {#kaH pu-#}
<div n="lb">{#naraBiyogaH ko vA tadviSezaH kaTaM vA tena vAcakatvanirUpaRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti . taducyate . lakzaRaSravaRAByAsAdaBiyogaH pravartate#} &c.).
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Imputing, ascribing; e. g. {%Nyāya S.:%} {#anigrahasTAne nigra-#}
<div n="lb">{#hasTAnABiyogo niranuyojyAnuyogaH#}. <sup>5</sup> Attack, onset, battle;
<div n="lb">(the same as {#aBigraha#} 1. q. v. and see there the explanation
<div n="lb">of {%Rāyam.%} &c.); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#narABiyogaM nfBfjAM praDAna#}
<div n="lb">{#mantronmuKaH kiM nayase gurutvam;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#aBiyoga imA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nmahIBujo BavatA tasya kftaH kftAvaDeH praviGAwayitA#}. <sup>6</sup> Chal-
<div n="lb">lenge; (the same as {#aBigraha#} <sup>2</sup> q. v. and see there the ex-
<div n="lb">planation of {%Nīlak.%} &c.). <sup>7</sup> Defeat, destruction (?); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#yadA na PeluH kzaRadAcArARAM manoraTA rAmabalA-#}
[Page261-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#Biyoge#} ({%Bharatas.:%} = {#rAmabalasya hanane#}); see the closing remark.
<div n="lb"><sup>8</sup> Curse, reproof (? see the closing remark). <sup>9</sup> (In Law.) An
<div n="lb">offence as subject of an accusation, a charge; e. g. {%Mitākṣara%}
<div n="lb">on {%Yājnav.:%} {#aBiyujyata ityaBiyogo'parADaH;#} or {#kaTamaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#yogasya nihnave'Biyuktena kfte yadyaBiyoktA sAkzyAdiBirBA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vito'BiyuktastadA tatsamaM…dadyAt;#} or {%Nārada:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#yukto'Biyogasya yadi kuryAdapahnavam#} &c.; or {%Yājnav.:%} {#tulA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gnyApo vizaM kozo divyAnIha viSudDaye . mahABiyogezvetAni#}
<div n="lb">{#SIrzakasTe'Biyoktari…kuryAt#} ({%Raghunand.:%} {#mahABiyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gezu mahApAtakAdigurutarABiyogezu#}).--An {#aBiyoga#} is, ac-
<div n="lb">cording to {%Nārada,%} either a {#SaNkABiyoga,#} a charge on sus-
<div n="lb">picion, or {#tattvABiyoga,#} a charge founded on positive in-
<div n="lb">dications of guilt ({#dvyaBiyogastu vijYeyaH#}--scil. {#vyavahAraH--#}
<div n="lb">{#SaNkAtattvABiyogataH . SaNkAsatAM tu saMsargAttattvaM hoqABidarSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAt#}); and the latter may be again, according to {%Vijnāne-%}
<div n="lb">{%śvara,%} either of a negative kind ({#pratizeDAtmaka#}), as when a
<div n="lb">person is accused not to have restored property received
<div n="lb">by him, or of a positive kind ({#viDyAtmaka#}), as when a
<div n="lb">person is charged with a robbery. The objects or topics
<div n="lb">of a charge are arraigned by {%Manu%} &c. under eighteen
<div n="lb">heads, which are subdivided again by {%Nārada%} so as to
<div n="lb">comprise 108, and by {%Kātyāyana%} so as to comprise 1008
<div n="lb">cases; see {#vyavahArapada#} and for the judicial procedure {#vyava-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAra#}. [N. B. The meaning {%‘curse, reproof’%} is given on the
<div n="lb">authority of a quotation by {%Mallinātha%} to {%Kirātārj.%} 2. 46.
<div n="lb">from the {%Viśvaprak.,%} and this quotation would seem also
<div n="lb">to countenance the meaning {%‘destruction’%} given by {%Bharatas.,%}
<div n="lb">viz. {#aBiyogastu SapaTe syAdAhavaparABavAviti viSvaH;#} the
<div n="lb">Mss. of this Kosha, however, in the library of the E. I. H.
<div n="lb">and of the R. S., do not contain an explanation of the word
<div n="lb">{#aBiyoga,#} but have the following: {#aBizaNgo'Ta SapaTe syA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dAkroSe parABave;#} comp. also {%Hemach.:%} {#…aBizaNgaH parA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bave . AkroSe SapaTe ca,#} the latter omitting equally a com-
<div n="lb">ment on {#aBiyoga#}.] E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6275<pc>261-a<k1>aBiyojayitf<k2>aBiyojayitf

<L>6276<pc>261-a<k1>aBiyojya<k2>aBiyojya
{#aBiyojya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jyaH-jyA-jyam#}) <sup>1</sup> To be attacked,
<div n="lb">assailable; e. g. {%Hitop.%} (ed. {%Johnson,%} &c.): {#saMtyajyate prakfti-#}
<div n="lb">{#BirviraktaprakftiryuDi . suKABiyojyo Bavati vizayezvatisakti-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAn#} (ed. {%Schlegel-Lassen:%} {#suKABiyogyo…#} which seems
<div n="lb">less correct). <sup>2</sup> To be prosecuted, indictable; e. g. {%Vyava-%}
[Page261-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%hārat.:%} {#atrABiyoktuH SirovartitvokteraBiyojyasya divyakartftvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pratIyate#}. E. {#yuj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.

<L>6286<pc>261-b<k1>aBirAja<k2>aBirAja
{#aBirAja#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-jaH#}) The proper name of a Burmese
<div n="lb">king; he is, according to the legend, the founder of one of
<div n="lb">the oldest dynasties and belongs to the family of the Śākyas
<div n="lb">in Kapilavastu; he emigrated from the latter city after its
<div n="lb">destruction by a king of Kośala and, having reached the
<div n="lb">banks of the Irawaddy, built the city of Tagoung. E. {#aBi#}
<div n="lb">and {#rAjan,#} samās. aff. {#wac;#} literally: reigning everywhere.

<L>6295<pc>262-a<k1>aBirUpa<k2>aBirUpa

<div n="lb">ing, agreeable, beautiful; ({%Mathureśa, Bhānudīkṣita%} &c.:

<div n="lb">stract noun comp. {#ABirUpaka#} and {#ABirUpya#}.]
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> A name or epithet of: <sup>a.</sup> Kāma, <sup>b.</sup> Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb"><sup>c.</sup> Śiva. <sup>2</sup> The moon. [{%Śabdaratnāv.:%} {#aBirUpo buDe ramye#}

<div n="lb">Viṣṇu in the Mahābhārata this name does not occur, nor
<div n="lb">amongst the same amount of names of Śiva in the Padma-
<div n="lb">purāṇa.] E. {#aBi#} and {#rUpa#}.

<L>6307<pc>263-a<k1>aBilApa<k2>aBilApa
{#aBilApa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) Speech, expression; e. g. {%Sā-%}
<div n="lb">{%hityad.:%} {#(rasaH) aBilApasaMsargayogyatvavirahAnna…savikalpa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasaMvedyaH#} (comm. {#savikalpakajYAnasaMvedyAnAM hi vacanaprayogayo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gyatA na tu rasasya#}); or {%Ved. Sūtras:%} {#na ca smArtamatadDarmABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#lApaH#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#…yadyapyadfzwatvAdivyapadeSaH praDAnasya saMBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vati taTApi na drazwftvAdivyapadeSaH saMBavati…adfzwo drazwA#}
<div n="lb">{#aSrutaH SrotA amato mantA avijYAto vijYAtA iti hi vA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kyaSeza iha Bavati#}); or {#saMskAraparAmarSAttadaBAvABilApAcca#}
<div n="lb">({%Anūpanār.:%} {#…na saMskAro na vratAni SUdrasyeti tadaBAvo-#}
<div n="lb">{#kteSca na SUdre'DikAraH#}); or {#anyADizWite pUrvavadaBilApAt#}
<div n="lb">({%Śaṅkara:%} {#…ko'BilApasya tadvadBAvaH . karmavyApAramantareRa#}
<div n="lb">{#saMkIrtanam#}); or {%Prakramādhikaraṇa%} (as quoted by {%Rādhā-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāntad.%}): {#kAmyABilApasahitaH kuSatilajalatyAgarUpaH saMkalpaH#}
<div n="lb">{#SAstrArTaH#} ‘the intention (of performing a vow) implies the
<div n="lb">{%enunciation%} of the voluntary rite (to be performed); it con-
<div n="lb">sists in such oblations as those of kuśa, oil and water, and
<div n="lb">is founded on the sacred precepts’ (comp. {%Mādh. Jaiminī-%}
<div n="lb">{%yanyāyam.:%} {#saMkalpo'trAnuzWeyavratatvena viDIyate#}). See {#aBIlApa#}
<div n="lb">and comp. {#aBivyAhAra#}. E. {#lap#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6308<pc>263-a<k1>aBilAva<k2>aBilAva
{#aBilAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Cutting, destroying; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
<div n="lb">(Sugrīva speaks to Hanūmat and his monkeys:) {#yAta yUyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#…vanABilAvAnkurvantaH svecCayA cAruvikramAH#} ({%Jayam.:%}
<div n="lb">{#vanABilAvAn = vanaviDvaMsAn,#} {%Bharatas.:%} = {#araRyaviDvaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAn#}). <sup>2</sup> Mowing ({%Rāyam., Bharatam.%} &c. on the {%Amarak.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#DAnyAdiCedana#}). E. {#lU#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6309<pc>263-a<k1>aBilAza<k2>aBilAza
{#aBilAza#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zaH#}) Desire, craving, covetousness;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Vijnāneśvara%} on {%Manu%} ({#kAmAddaSaguRaM,#} scil. {#daRqyaH#} &c.):
<div n="lb">{#kAmaH strIvyatikarABilAzaH;#} or {%Kirātārj.:%} {#yastyaktavAnvaH sa#}
<div n="lb">{#vfTA balAdvA mohaM viDatte vizayABilAzaH;#} or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#pre-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyAhArAByAsakftAtstanyABilAzAt;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#yaTA#}
<div n="lb">{#duHKAddUzeH puruzasya na taTA suKAdaBilAzaH;#} or {%Daśakumārach.:%}
<div n="lb">{#nftyotTitA ca sA sidDilABaSoDinI kiM vilAsAtkimaBilA-#}
<div n="lb">{#zAtkimakasmAdeva na jAne#} &c.; or an {%Aśvaśāstra:%} {#aSvavAha-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAdyaBilAzEH SvetASvaH sarvakAmadaH#}.--Amongst the works on
<div n="lb">poetry which distinguish in their definition of Love (see
<div n="lb">{#SfNgAra#}), Love under difficulties (see {#vipralamBa#}) and Love the
<div n="lb">course of which runs smooth (see {#saMBoga#}), the {%Kāvyapra-%}
<div n="lb">{%kāsa%} mentions {#aBilAza#} or {%longing%} as one (the first in the
<div n="lb">given enumeration) of the {%five%} erotic conditions of the first
<div n="lb">kind; the {%Sāhityadarp.%} which subdivides ‘Love under dif-
<div n="lb">ficulties’ into four categories, names {%longing%} ({#aBilAzaH#}
<div n="lb">{#spfhA#}) as one (the first in the given enumeration) of the {%ten%}
<div n="lb">erotic conditions of the {#pUrvarAga#} or ‘affection arising from
<div n="lb">hearing or sight before the lovers meet’, which is the first
<div n="lb">of those subdivisions; either work quoting as an instance
<div n="lb">the verse of the {%Mālatīm.,%} ed. Calc. p. 76, line 4 &c. Similarly
<div n="lb">the {%Saṅgītadāmodara. Bharata%} as quoted by {%Śaṅkara%} on the
<div n="lb">{%Śākuntala,%} calls ‘longing’ the commencement of love ({#praTame#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaBilAzaH syAt,#} and in the same words the {%Saṅgītad.%}) when
<div n="lb">{%Śāk.%} v. 22. (ed. {%Boehtlingk%}) or v. 24. (ed. {%Williams%}) would
<div n="lb">be an instance. An example, however, of {#aBilAza#} as be-
<div n="lb">longing to the other description of the Erotic (the {#saMBoga#}),
<div n="lb">is in the verse of the {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#AliNgitAyAH sahasA trapA-#}
[Page263-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#vAMstrAsABilAzAnugato ratAdO viSvAsitAyA ramaRena baDvA#}
<div n="lb">{#vimardaramyo madano baBUva#}.--[An objectionable reading is
<div n="lb">{#aBilAsa,#} for the word is given in the form {#aBilAza#}
<div n="lb">not only in the commentaries on the {%Dhātupāthas%} s. r.
<div n="lb">{#laz#} (not s. r. {#las#}), but as an {#antyamUrDanya#} in the chapter
<div n="lb">on orthography of the {%Viśvapr.%} and amongst the words
<div n="lb">that contain a {#z#} only in a similar treatise by {%Purushottama.%}]
<div n="lb">E. {#laz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6336<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAdaka<k2>aBivAdaka
{#aBivAdaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) <sup>1</sup> One who
<div n="lb">salutes or makes the {#aBivAdana#} q. v.; e. g. {%Kullūka%} on
<div n="lb">{%Manu:%} {#aBivAdako viprAdirAyuzmAnBava sOmyeti vAcyaH#}.
<div n="lb">[Like other nouns formed with the kṛt aff. {#Rvul#} it may
<div n="lb">have the same sense as the infin. of the corresponding verb
<div n="lb">(i. e. = {#aBivAditum#}), if it is logically connected with an-
<div n="lb">other verb; e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#Agato'smItyuvAcEnaM BavantamaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdakaH#} ‘…to salute thee’.] <sup>2</sup> One who has the habit of
<div n="lb">making salutations, civil, polite ({%comm.%} on the {%Amarak.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#aBivAdanaSIla#}). E. {#vad#} (in the caus.) with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#Rvul#}.
<LEND>

<L>6337<pc>264-a<k1>aBivAdana<k2>aBivAdana
{#aBivAdana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) Respectful salutation of a superior
<div n="lb">or elder, especially of a Guru, by a junior or inferior for the
<div n="lb">sake of obtaining his blessing; ({%Vīramitr. Āchāraprak.:%} {#a-#}
<div n="lb">{#BivAdananAma vaworAtmAnamaBi gurorASIrvacanAnukUlo vyApA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raH#}). It consists of three acts, viz. 1. the {#pratyutTAna#} or rising
<div n="lb">from the seat, 2. the {#upasaMgrahaRa#} or {#pAdopasaMgrahaRa,#} the peculiar
[Page264-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">mode of Hindu obeisance, and 3. the {#aBivAda#} or the ut-
<div n="lb">tering of the formula of salutation.
<div n="P"><sup>a.</sup> The first act is indispensable on the part of the person
<div n="lb">whose duty it is to make the salutation, whatever be the
<div n="lb">quality of the person saluted ({%Āpastamba:%} {#sarvatra tu pratyutTA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yABivAdanam#}); but the two other acts undergo various
<div n="lb">modifications according to the rank or quality of the person
<div n="lb">saluted and the person saluting.
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> With regard to the {#upasaMgrahaRa#} or the obeisance, the
<div n="lb">general rule is, according to {%Manu,%} that the saluter should
<div n="lb">with crossed hands ({%comm.:%} the right hand being placed
<div n="lb">over the left) clasp the feet of his {%Guru,%} touching the left
<div n="lb">foot with his left, and the right foot with his right, hand;
<div n="lb">({%Manu:%} {#vyastapARinA kAryamupasaMgrahaRaM guroH . savyena savyaH#}
<div n="lb">{#sprazwavyo dakziRena ca dakziRaH#}); the same injunction is given
<div n="lb">by {%Āśvalāyana%} and {%Baudhāyana%} with the addition that he
<div n="lb">should first touch, with composure of mind, his own left
<div n="lb">ear with his left and his right ear with his right, hand,
<div n="lb">and then make his bow, in the indicated manner, by
<div n="lb">touching his Guru from the knees to the feet; ({%Āśvalāy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#vAmaM vAmena saMspfSya dakziRena tu dakziRam . hastena karRaM hastAByAM#}
<div n="lb">{#gurURAmaBivAdanam . vAmopari karaM kftvA dakziRaM nAma co-#}
<div n="lb">{#ccaret . jAnupraBfti pAdAntamAraBya pAdayornamet;#} {%Baudhāy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#Srotre saMspfSya manaH samADAyADastAjjAnvorA padByAmityupasaMgra-#}
<div n="lb">{#haRam#}); according to some, his hands must be made
<div n="lb">hollow, when he touches the feet of the Guru and he
<div n="lb">is forbidden, under the threat of loosing the benefit of all
<div n="lb">his pious actions, to perform this act only with one hand
<div n="lb">({%Paīṭhīnasi:%} {#uttAnAByAM pARiByAM dakziRena dakziRaM savyena savyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pAdamaBivAdayet;#} {%Viṣṇu:%} {#ajAkarRena viduzAM mUrKARAmekapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RinA;#} {%Vīramitr.%} on the latter: {#SrotrasamO karO kftvA punara-#}
<div n="lb">{#jAkarRavatsaMpuwitena karadvayenetyarTaH;#} {%Viṣṇu:%} {#janmapraBfti yatkiM-#}
<div n="lb">{#ciccetasA DarmamAcaret . sarvaM tannizPalaM yAti ekahastABivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#danAt#}); {%Āpastamba%} enjoins, on his part, that a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">when saluting should raise his right arm as far as his ears,
<div n="lb">a Kshatriya as far as his breast (or according to a v. 1. as
<div n="lb">far as his shoulder), a Vaiśya as far as his navel and that
<div n="lb">a Sūdra making his obeisance should hold it down ({%Āpast.:%}
<div n="lb">{#svaM dakziRaM bAhuM SrotrasamaM prasArya brAhmaRo'BivAdayetoraHsamaM#}
<div n="lb">{#rAjanyo maDyasamaM vESyo nIcEH SUdraH prAYjaliH;#} {%Vīram.%} on the
<div n="lb">latter: {#aMsasamaM rAjanya ityapi pAWaH . maDyaM nABiH;#} {%Atri,%} how-
<div n="lb">ever, seems to reserve this mode of salutatioin for a learned
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa in general, while he enjoins the touching of the
<div n="lb">feet, if the person saluted is a Guru; {#dakziRaM pARimudDftya#}
<div n="lb">{#prakAmamaBivAdayet . Srotriye tvaYjaliH kAryaH pAdopagrahaRaM gu-#}
<div n="lb">{#roriti#}). If the person to be saluted is a woman, the
<div n="lb">politeness of touching her from the knees to the feet is sub-
<div n="lb">ject to some restrictions: if she is the wife of the {%Guru,%}
<div n="lb">but not of the same class as her husband, {%Manu%} and other
<div n="lb">legislators dispense with it altogether; if she is of the same
<div n="lb">class and the student is young, he must pay her that re-
<div n="lb">spect only when he returns from a journey, on other oc-
<div n="lb">casions he prostrates himself before her at his daily salu-
<div n="lb">tation, ({%Vīram.%} on {%Manu%} 2. 217. and {%Gautama:%} {#viprozyeti va-#}
<div n="lb">{#canAnna pratyahamiti gamyate#}); but if she is young and the young
<div n="lb">man knows already to distinguish right from wrong which
[Page265-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">is the case when he has completed his twentieth year (ac-
<div n="lb">cording to {%Manu;%} or his sixteenth year, according to the
<div n="lb">{%Vīram.%} on {%Gautama%}) he must never touch her feet but al-
<div n="lb">ways prostrate himself before her; {%Manu%} enjoins further
<div n="lb">that the sister of his mother, the wife of his maternal
<div n="lb">uncle, his own wife's mother and the sister of his father
<div n="lb">must be treated by him like the wife of his Guru, equally
<div n="lb">so the wife of his brother ({%comm.:%} the eldest wife, of the
<div n="lb">same class), and that the sister of his father and of his
<div n="lb">mother as well as his own elder sister must be saluted in
<div n="lb">the same manner as his mother, but that his paternal and
<div n="lb">maternal kinswomen are to be greeted by touching their
<div n="lb">feet only on his return from a journey. {%Gautama'%}s rule
<div n="lb">that the wives of a brother and one's own wife's mother
<div n="lb">are never to be touched in this manner is restricted by the
<div n="lb">{%Vīramitrodaya%} to the wives of the same class ({%Gaut.:%} {#nopa-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMgrahaRaM BrAtfBAryARAM SvaSrvASca;#} {%Viram.:%} {#yannopaºº iti gOta-#}
<div n="lb">{#mavAkyaM tadasavarRAvizayam#}), and when the same legislator
<div n="lb">enjoins that with the exception of a mother, the wife of a
<div n="lb">paternal uncle and a sister, no woman must be touched
<div n="lb">by her feet in being greeted except on the return from a
<div n="lb">journey, the same commentator infers that this ceremony
<div n="lb">is obligatory on the latter occasion ({%Gautama:%} {#nAviprozya#}
<div n="lb">{#strIRAmamAtfpitfvyaBAryABAginInAm;#} {%Vīram.:%} {#aviprozyeti#}
<div n="lb">{#vacanAdviprozya tu pAdopasaMgrahaRaM kartavyameva#}).
<div n="P"><sup>c.</sup> The formula of salutation consists in general, if the
<div n="lb">person greeted is a man, of the word {#aBivAdaye#} ‘I greet’,
<div n="lb">followed by the declaration of the saluter's own name and
<div n="lb">ending with the reverential word {#BoH#} ({%Manu:%} {#aBivAdAtparaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vipro jyAyAMsamaBivAdayan . asO nAmAhamasmIti svaM nAma#}
<div n="lb">{#parikIrtayet .…BoHSabdaM kIrtayedante svasya nAmno'Bi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdane . nAmnAM svarUpaBAvo hi BoBAva fziBiH smftaH#}); e. g.
<div n="lb">{#aBivAdaye devadatto'haM BoH,#} or {#aBivAdaya indravarmAhaM BoH,#}
<div n="lb">or {#aBivAdaya indrapAlito'haM BoH,#} or (if a woman greets) e. g.
<div n="lb">{#aBivAdaye gArgyahaM BoH;#} according to the {%Vīram.,%} some com-
<div n="lb">bine with the declaration of the name also that of the family
<div n="lb">and the descendants when the word {#aBivAdaye#} is placed
<div n="lb">at the end of the salutation, e. g. {#amukapravaro'mukagotro'muka-#}
<div n="lb">{#SarmAhaM Bo BivAdaye#} ‘father of such and such a son, descendant
<div n="lb">of such and such a family, I, such and such a…sarman,
<div n="lb">(e. g. {#kfzRaSarman#}) Sir, greet (thee)’; if husband and wife salute
<div n="lb">there is no other restriction ({%Gaut.:%} {#strIpuMyoge'BivAdato#}
<div n="lb">{#'niyamameke#}), but the formula becomes shortened in this way:
<div n="lb">{#aBivAdaye gArgyahaM gArgaSarmAhaM BoH#}. If the person saluted is a
<div n="lb">woman or a Śūdra or a man who either does not understand
<div n="lb">the Sanskṛt meaning of the proper name or does not know
<div n="lb">the proper manner of protracting the final vowel of the
<div n="lb">name in the return of the salutation or is otherwise igno-
<div n="lb">rant of the proper manner of returning it (see g.), the formula
<div n="lb">of the saluter is simply thus: {#‘aBivAdaye'ham’#} ‘I greet’,
<div n="lb">such an address being not considered an {#aBivAdana;#} ({%Vī-%}
<div n="lb">{%ram.%} on {%Manu.%} 2. 123. and 126.: {#nAmaDeyasyABivAdanikasyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BivAdamaBivAdanavAkyArTatvaM ye na jAnate tAnstrIM ca pratyaha-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti lOkikaM nAma coccaretprAjYo na pUrvoktamaBivAdanavAkyam .#}
<div n="lb">{#yadvA nAmaDeyasyABivAdakanAmno'nte'BivAdaM plutAkArArikaM#}
<div n="lb">{#na jAnate tAnpratIti dveDA meDAtiTirvyAcaKyO;#} {%Medhātithi%} re-
[Page265-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">ferring to the Śūtra and Vārttikas of {%Pāṇini%} VIII. 2. 83.).
<div n="lb">[{%Medhātithi%} and {%Govindarāja%} take the word {#nAma#} in the
<div n="lb">passage of Manu quoted above in its literal sense and give
<div n="lb">the formula; e. g. {%Medhāt.:%} {#aBivAdaye devadattanAmAhaM BoH,#}
<div n="lb">but this mode of salutation is not approved of by other
<div n="lb">authorities; e. g. {%Kullūka%} in reference to this use of {#nAman:#}
<div n="lb">{#meDAtiTigovindarAjayoraBiDAnamapramARam#}.]
<div n="P"><sup>d.</sup> The general rule that prevails at a salutation is that
<div n="lb">the person who receives it must be an ‘elder’ or what is
<div n="lb">technically termed a {%Guru%} and that the person who pays
<div n="lb">it must be a ‘youth’ or an inferior; such a salutation
<div n="lb">may be of course occasional, but it is a duty of a youth
<div n="lb">to salute his ‘elders’ or ‘Gurus’ every morning after
<div n="lb">he has managed the consecrated fire ({%Yājnav.:%} {#agnikAryaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tataH kuryAtsaMDyayoruBayorapi .. tato'BivAdayedvfdDAnasAvahami-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti bruvan;#} {%Yama:%} {#tato'BivAdayedvfdDAnagnikAryAdanantaram;#}
<div n="lb">{%Gautama:%} {#guroH pAdopasaMgrahaRaM prAtaH#}).--For the persons
<div n="lb">comprised under the name {#guru#} and their relative superiority
<div n="lb">or inferiority see s. v., it may suffice here to give the de-
<div n="lb">finition of {%Devala%} who enumerates as male Gurus: the
<div n="lb">teacher (see {#upADyAya#}), the father, the eldest brother, the
<div n="lb">king, the maternal and paternal uncle, the father-in-law,
<div n="lb">an initiated householder, the maternal and paternal grand-
<div n="lb">father, and the eldest of the same class; as female Gurus:
<div n="lb">the mother, the maternal and paternal grandmother, the
<div n="lb">sisters of father and mother, the mother-in-law, and the
<div n="lb">old nurse; and to add from the definition of others the
<div n="lb">priest (see {#ftvij#}) and the spiritual teacher (see {#AcArya#}).
<div n="lb">If there are several persons present who have a claim to a
<div n="lb">salutation, the teacher who has given instruction either on
<div n="lb">worldly or ritual or spiritual matters, has precedence be-
<div n="lb">fore all others, according to {%Manu%} ({#lOkikaM vEdikaM cApi#}
<div n="lb">{#taTADyAtmikameva ca . AdadIta yato jYAnaM taM pUrvamaBivAdayet#}),
<div n="lb">and, in general, every superior Guru has precedence before
<div n="lb">the one next to him in degree. [In the passage of {%Gautama:%}
<div n="lb">{#pAdopasaMgrahaRaM gurusamavAye'nvaham . aBigamya tu viprozya mA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tfpitftadbanDUnAM#} (i. e. mother, father, maternal uncle and aunt,
<div n="lb">paternal uncle and aunt &c.) {#pUrvajAnAM#} (i. e. elder brothers
<div n="lb">&c.) {#vidyAgurURAM#} (i. e. the Upādhyāya, Āchārya &c.) {#tatta-#}
<div n="lb">{#dgurURAM ca#} (i. e. their maternal or paternal grandfathers &c.)
<div n="lb">{#saMnipAte parasya,#} the last word ({#parasya#}) does not imply that
<div n="lb">each {%following%} precedes in rank each preceding, but means
<div n="lb">each {%superior; Vīram.:%} {#mAtrAdInAM purA yatsaMnipAte samAgame#}
<div n="lb">{#parasyotkfzwasya praTamamupasaMgrahaRaM kartavyam#}.] The term ‘youth’
<div n="lb">mentioned above is not to be taken in its literal, but in its
<div n="lb">metaphorical sense; for {%Manu%} rules that fellow citizens are
<div n="lb">equal (as to age) for ten years, dancers and singers for five,
<div n="lb">learned theologians for three, but persons related by blood
<div n="lb">for a very short time; again, that one must consider a
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa though but ten years old, as if he were the father
<div n="lb">of a Kshatriya though aged a hundred years; therefore a
<div n="lb">friend, e. g., is not to be addressed with the words {#BoH#} or
<div n="lb">{#Bavat,#} unless he be older than ten years, and a Brāhmaṇa
<div n="lb">must never salute first a Kshatriya or a man of a lower
<div n="lb">class, however distinguished he be ({%Vīram.:%} {#daSavarzADikakaH#}
<div n="lb">{#saKA BoBavacCabdAByAM saMboDyaH;#} {%Śātātapa:%} {#nABivAdyAstu vi-#}
[Page266-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#preRa kzatriyAdyAH kaTaMcana . jYAnakarmaguRopetA yadyapyete bahuSru-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAH#}); for if he does so, he incurs severe spiritual penalties.
<div n="P"><sup>e.</sup> Persons not to be saluted are, according to {%Manu, Gau-%}
<div n="lb">{%tama, Baudhāyana:%} a priest ({%Ṛtvij%}), a wife's father, a maternal
<div n="lb">and paternal uncle, learned and pious persons, {%if they are%}
<div n="lb">{%younger;%} they are merely to be addressed with the words ‘I, so
<div n="lb">and so, am here’ {#asAvaham,#} and to be honoured by rising from
<div n="lb">the seat; this ceremony does not constitute, therefore, an
<div n="lb">{#aBivAdana#}. [In {%Manu%} 2. 130. the word {#gurUn#} is to be taken
<div n="lb">in the sense of ‘an elder by learning and piousness’; it
<div n="lb">does not occur in the corresponding passages of {%Gautama%}
<div n="lb">and {%Baudh.;%} the former: {#ftvikSvaSurapitfvyamAtulAnAM tu ya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vIyasAM pratyutTAnamanaBivAdyAH;#} the latter with the same words
<div n="lb">except for the last, {#pratyutTAyABiBAzaRam#}.] In law courts, in
<div n="lb">houses of penance and palaces where Brāhmaṇas are assem-
<div n="lb">bled, the latter are not to be saluted individually, but the words
<div n="lb">{#sarveByo namaH#} ‘respect to all’ are to be addressed to the whole
<div n="lb">assembly; this mode of address is called the {#namaskAra#} which
<div n="lb">is different therefore from the {#aBivAdana;#} ({%Viṣṇu:%} {#saBAsu#}
<div n="lb">{#cEva sarvAsu yajYarAjagfhezu ca namaskAraM na kurvIta brAhmaRaM nA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BivAdayet;#} {%Vīram.%} on those words: {#sarvAsu DarmavyavahAraprA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yaScittAdinirRayasaBAsu namaskAraM na kuryAt . pratyekamiti Se-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaH . kiM tu sarveByo nama ityeva vaktavyam;#} {%Vṛhadviṣṇu:%} {#saBAM#}
<div n="lb">{#nABivAdayet#}); {%Āpastamba%} forbids to salute a man who
<div n="lb">carries fuel, flowers, kuśa grass, fire, water and rice in
<div n="lb">his hands and one who performs the Japahoma; {%Kātyāyana:%}
<div n="lb">a wicked man, a cripple, a stranger, one who has enemies
<div n="lb">after him, a diseased person, a Yogin, one bent upon do-
<div n="lb">ing penance and a youngster (similarly {%Vṛhaspati%}); {%Śatā-%}
<div n="lb">{%tapa:%} a heretic, an outcaste ({#patita#}), a Vrātya (q. v.), a
<div n="lb">person while his head is oiled, while eating, yawning,
<div n="lb">cleansing his teeth, performing his natural functions &c.;
<div n="lb">the {%Vṛhadnāradīya:%} an atheist, a libertine ({#BinnamaryAda#}), an
<div n="lb">impious man, a thief and a cheat, a man fond of litigation,
<div n="lb">a drunken man, one who vomits or stands in water, one
<div n="lb">who carries rice given to him as alms or one who is in a
<div n="lb">lying position, one who performs a Śrāddha, a vow or a
<div n="lb">sacrifice; amongst {%women Śātātapa%} forbids to greet: one in
<div n="lb">her courses, one recently delivered, one who has killed her
<div n="lb">husband and one who has miscarried.
<div n="P"><sup>f.</sup> A man must not salute, according to {%Āpastamba,%} while
<div n="lb">he has his shoes on, while his head is covered ({#vezwitaSi-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAH#}) and while his hands are stretched out; according to
<div n="lb">{%Śaṅkha,%} while he carries water in his hands, while he is
<div n="lb">unclean, performs funeral rites or is in a lying position
<div n="lb">…, according to {%Baudhāyana,%} while he carries fuel, a
<div n="lb">water-jug, flowers or rice.
<div n="P"><sup>g.</sup> The return of the salutation or the {#pratyaBivAdana#} con-
<div n="lb">sists, generally, in uttering first the words {#AyuzmAnBava#}
<div n="lb">{#sOmya#} ‘long mayst thou live, friend’ or similar words to
<div n="lb">the same effect; ({%Manu:%} {#AyuzmAnBava sOmyeti vAcyo vipro#}
<div n="lb">{#'BivAdane,#} where the word {#iti#} indicates, according to {%Me-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhātithi%} and the {%Vīramitrodaya,%} that the preceding words are
<div n="lb">merely an illustration of the phrase to be used; thus the
<div n="lb">address may be worded also in this manner: {#AyuzmAneDi#} or
<div n="lb">{#dIrGAyurBUyAH#} or {#ciraM jIva#} &c.); these words are followed
[Page266-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">by the name of the person who has greeted first and, if
<div n="lb">the latter is a Brāhmaṇa, the last vowel of his name, which
<div n="lb">at the same time is the last vowel of the whole phrase, be-
<div n="lb">comes protracted (according to the general rules on making
<div n="lb">vowels {#pluta#} q. v.); some require moreover, that the name
<div n="lb">should always receive the addition of the word {#Sarman,#} others,
<div n="lb">however, consider this addition unnecessary ({%Manu:%} {#akA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raScAsya nAmno'nte vAcyaH pUrvAkzaraH plutaH;#} {%Vīram.:%} {#tatra nAmE-#}
<div n="lb">{#veti kecit . SarmAntamityapare#}); the return of the salute to
<div n="lb">a Brāhmaṇa would therefore run on the following pattern:
<div n="lb">{#AyuzmAnBava sOmya devadattA3,#} or {#AyuzmAnBava sOmya devada-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttaSarmA 3 n,#} or {#AyuzmAnBava piRAkapARA 3 i (= piRAka-#}
<div n="lb">{#pARe),#} or {#…vizRA 3 u (= vizRo),#} or {#AyuzmAneDi#}
<div n="lb">{#…#} &c.; (the omission of the word {#Sarman#} when it originally
<div n="lb">belongs to the name, or the omission of the name altogether
<div n="lb">are rebuked by {%Kullūka%}). If the person thus addressed is
<div n="lb">a Kshatriya or Vaiśya or if the word {#BoH#} is added after
<div n="lb">the name (which seems permitted according to {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">on {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 2. 83., although {%Patanjali%} observes that other
<div n="lb">authorities do not approve of the combination of the name
<div n="lb">{%and%} {#BoH,#} but allow only the enunciation of the one or the
<div n="lb">other), the protraction of the vowel is optional; e. g. in
<div n="lb">returning the salute to a Kshatriya: {#AyuzmAneDIndravarmA 3 n#}
<div n="lb">or {#…ºvarman,#} to a Vaiśya: {#AyuzmAneDIndrapAlitA 3#} or
<div n="lb">{#…ºpAlita;#} or with {#BoH, AyuzmAneDi devadatta BoH 3#} or
<div n="lb">{#…BoH#} (but the latter phrase should be, according to the
<div n="lb">above mentioned observation, either {#AyuzmAneDi BoH 3#} or
<div n="lb">{#…devadattA 3#}); if the person addressed is a woman or a
<div n="lb">Śūdra or spoken to in contempt or derision, no protraction
<div n="lb">of the vowel takes place, e. g. a woman: {#AyuzmatI Bava#}
<div n="lb">{#gArgi;#} a Śūdra: {#AyuzmAneDi tuzajaka;#} or in contempt: {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#yuzmAneDi sTAlin#} ({%Patanjali:%} {#asUyakastvamasi jAlma . na tvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pratyaBivAdanamarhasi . Bidyasva vfzala sTAlin;#} {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#asU-#}
<div n="lb">{#yakaH pratyAcazwe . pratyaBivAdavAkyAntasTasya nAmno gotrasya ca#}
<div n="lb">{#pluta izyate nAnyasyeti yOgikasya pluto na viDeyaH . tatra pratya-#}
<div n="lb">{#BivAdayitrA sTAliSabdaM saMjYAM matvA pluto vihitaH . yadA tU-#}
<div n="lb">{#pahAsArTamasUyakastamAkzipati tadAsO pratyaBivAdaM nArhatyASI-#}
<div n="lb">{#rvacanaM hi pratyaBivAdo gfhyate . pratisaMBAzaRamAtraM tu pratyaBivAdaM#}
<div n="lb">{#matvA vArttikakftAsUyake pratizeDa uktaH;#} in phrases such as
<div n="lb">{#devadatta kuSalyasi, devadatta AyuzmAneDi#} which are not word-
<div n="lb">ed in the proper manner in which the return of a salutation
<div n="lb">should be made, since the name does not stand at the end
<div n="lb">of the sentence, the protraction of the vowel is equally
<div n="lb">prohibited).--If the person to whom the salutation is to
<div n="lb">be returned, has performed the preparatory observances of
<div n="lb">a sacrifice, his name should not be enounced but in its
<div n="lb">place the reverential word {#BoH;#} and to the wife of another
<div n="lb">or to any woman not related by blood the epithet of address
<div n="lb">should be {#Bavati#} or {#suBage#} or {#Bagini#} (according to {%Manu%}).
<div n="lb">After the person has returned the greeting, he may put
<div n="lb">the usual polite questions, after the saluter's health &c.;
<div n="lb">(it is not therefore the latter who asks after the health &c.
<div n="lb">of the person who returns the salute, for {%Govindarāja%} who
<div n="lb">expresses that opinion, is rebuked for it by {%Kullūka%}); the
<div n="lb">model, however, laid down by {%Manu%} and {%Āpastamba,%} that
<div n="lb">a Brāhmaṇa must be asked whether he prospers, a Ksha-
[Page267-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">triya whether he is quite well, a Vaiśya whether he is
<div n="lb">happy, and a Śūdra whether he is free from disease ({%Manu:%}
<div n="lb">{#brAhmaRaM kuSalaM pfcCetkzatrabanDumanAmayam . vESyaM kzemaM samAgamya#}
<div n="lb">{#SUdramArogyameva ca;#} {%Āpastamba:%} {#kuSalamavaravayasaM samAnavayasaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vA vipraM pfcCet . anAmayaM kzatriyaM kzemaM vESyamArogyaM SUdram#})
<div n="lb">is not to be taken in its literal sense, as the commentators
<div n="lb">observe and as may be inferred from instances in the epic
<div n="lb">and dramatic literature; thus in the {%Sabhāparvan%} of the {%Ma-%}
<div n="lb">{%hābhārata, Nārada%} after having returned the salute of {%Yu-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhishthira%} does not content himself with the question whether
<div n="lb">the king is quite well, but overwhelmes him with an inter-
<div n="lb">rogatory of 110 Slokas (v. 151-260) which is perhaps the
<div n="lb">completest of its kind, though probably an overdone illus-
<div n="lb">tration of this part of a Hindu greeting.
<div n="P"><sup>b.</sup> The object of the {#pratyaBivAdana#} being a blessing ({%Viṣṇu:%}
<div n="lb">{#SizyARAmASizaM dadyAtpAdopagrahaRo guruH#} and compare the
<div n="lb">commencement of this article), a person who omits to re-
<div n="lb">turn the salutation is threatened by {%Yama%} to become guilty
<div n="lb">of all the sins of the person he ought to have greeted
<div n="lb">({#aBivAde tu yaH pUrvamASizaM na prayacCati . yadduzkftaM Bavettasya#}
<div n="lb">{#tasmAdBAgaM prapadyate#}), by {%Angiras%} to fall into hell and by
<div n="lb">the {%Bhavishya-Purāṇa%} moreover, if the person thus slighted
<div n="lb">is a Brāhmaṇa, to be reborn in a future life as a tree on a
<div n="lb">cemetery which will be inhabitated by vultures and crows;
<div n="lb">({%Bhav.-Pur.:%} {#aBivAde kfte yastu na karotyaBivAdanam . ASizaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vA na kurvIta sa yAti narakaM Druvam . aBivAde kfte yastu taM vipraM#}
<div n="lb">{#nABivAdayet . SmaSAne jAyate vfkzo gfDrakAkanizevitaH#}).--
<div n="P"><sup>i.</sup> As a reward for performing properly and habitually the
<div n="lb">ceremony of a salutation {%Manu%} promises an increase of
<div n="lb">life, wisdom, fame and strength ({#aBivAdanaSIlasya nityaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vfdDopasevinaH . catvAri saMpravarDanta AyurvidyA yaSo balam#})
<div n="lb">and the Buddhistic work {%Dhammapāda%} which has modified
<div n="lb">the quoted verse, an increase of life, beauty, happiness and
<div n="lb">strength ({#aBivAdanaSIlassa niccaM vadDApacAyino . cattAro#}
<div n="lb">{#DammA vaqQanti Ayu vaRRo suKaM balaM#}). Comp. {#aBivandana#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#vad#} in the caus., with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6347<pc>267-b<k1>aBivAnyA<k2>aBivAnyA
{#aBivAnyA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-nyA#}) (ved.) A cow who (has lost
<div n="lb">her own calf and) suckles another; comp. {#aBivAnyavatsA#}).
<div n="lb">The word occurs in the {%Mānava Kalpa Sūtras%} where it is
<div n="lb">rendered by {%Kumārila%} {#vivatsA,#} and twice in a quotation of
<div n="lb">{%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaiminīyanyāyam.%} from a passage referring to
<div n="lb">the Mahāpitṛyajna: {#mahApitfyajYa evaM SrUyate . pitfByo'gni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvAtteByo'BivAnyAyE dugDe manTamiti;#} when {%Mādhava%} says
<div n="lb">on one occasion: {#atra vatsarahitAyA aBivAnyASabdABiDe-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAyA DenvA dugDe#} &c. and on another: {#mftavatsA DenuraBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnyA#} &c.; but while all the Mss. of this work within my
<div n="lb">reach coincide in reading {#aBiºº,#} the corresponding pas-
<div n="lb">sage in {%Weber'%}s ed. of {%Śatap.%} II. 6. 1. 6. runs: {#aTa pitfByo'gni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvAtteByaH . nivAnyAyE dugDe sakfdupamaTita ekaSalAkayA manTo#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavati,#} and the E. I. H. Ms. 657 of {%Sāyaṇa'%}s ({%Mādhava'%}s)
<div n="lb">comm. of the {%Śatap.%} has also the reading {#nivAnyA#} without
<div n="lb">any further remark. It is probable, however, that the
<div n="lb">quotation of the {%Jaiminīyanyāyam.%} belongs to a school of
<div n="lb">the {%black Yajurveda%} and that {#aBivAnyA#} and the reading of
<div n="lb">the {%Śatapathabr.%} {#nivAnyA#} are synonymous terms. Comp.
<div n="lb">{#aBivAnyavatsA#}. E. doubtful, perhaps {#aBivA#} and {#anya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6348<pc>267-b<k1>aBivAnyavatsA<k2>aBivAnyavatsA
{#aBivAnyavatsA#}¦ Bahuvr. f. ({#-tsA#}) (ved.) A cow who (has
<div n="lb">lost her own calf and) suckles another; {%Aitareya Br.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAnyavatsAyAH payasA juhuyAdanyadivEtatpayo yadaBivAnyavatsA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yA anyadivEtadagnihotraM yatpretasya#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#vA gatiganDayo-#}
<div n="lb">{#riti DAtoraBipUrvasyABivA iti rUpam . anyaScAsO vatsaScA-#}

<div n="lb">{#pozaRAdiprakAreRopasTitetyarTaH#}). Comp. {#aBivAnyA#}. A less
<div n="lb">correct reading is {#apivAnyavatsA#}. E. doubtful; acc. to {%Sā-%}

<L>6354<pc>268-a<k1>aBiviDi<k2>aBiviDi

<div n="lb">{#ryAdA#} of its meaning ‘until ({%exclusively%})’; thus {%Kaiyy.%} on a
<div n="lb">{%Kār.%} to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#AN maryAdABiviDyoriti samAsaviDO Ni-#}

<div n="lb">{%clusively%}); or {%Kumārila%} on the words {#A caturTAtkarmaRaH#}

<div n="lb">{#yAguRAByAM kArtsnyena saMbanDaH#} (i. e. when completeness of act
<div n="lb">and properties are implied); or {%Kāś.%} (on {%Pāṇ.%} {#aBiviDO#}

<L>6355<pc>268-a<k1>aBivinIta<k2>aBivinIta

<L>6356<pc>268-a<k1>aBivimAna<k2>aBivimAna
{#aBivimAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-naH#}) The same as {#aBimAna#} 1. q. v.
<div n="lb">and therefore used in the {%Chhāndogya Upanishad%} as an epi-
<div n="lb">thet of {%Vaiśvānara%} or the worldly form of the Supreme
<div n="lb">Soul, since he conceives the whole of mankind as referring
<div n="lb">to him exclusively (viz. ‘I am Brahman’); {%Chh. Up.:%} {#yastve-#}
<div n="lb">{#tamevaM prAdeSamAtramaBivimAnamAtmAnaM vESvAnaramupAste sa sarvezu#}
<div n="lb">{#lokezu sarvezu BUtezu sarvezvAtmasvannamatti#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#pratyagAtmata-#}
<div n="lb">{#yABivimIyate'hamiti jYAyata ityaBivimAnaH#} ‘because it is
<div n="lb">conceived as Supreme Soul under the notion of I, it is called
<div n="lb">Abhivimāna’; and comp. the passage of the {%Vedānta Sāra%}
<div n="lb">where Vaiśvānara is defined as the Supreme Soul conceived
[Page268-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">as wordly Totatily: {#etatsamazwyupahitaM cEtanyaM vESvAnaro virA-#}
<div n="lb">{#qiti cocyate sarvanarABimAnitvAt,#} this passage and esp.
<div n="lb">the latter word being founded on the quoted words of the
<div n="lb">{%Chh. Upan.;%} as Vaiśvānara is the Supreme Soul in its re-
<div n="lb">ference to the world there is a tendency to equivocation in
<div n="lb">the Upan., for {#prAdeSa#} which means there ‘space’ in general,
<div n="lb">might convey the notion of limitedness--in its sense ‘span’
<div n="lb">--and {#aBivimAna#} remind of {#vimAna#} ‘absence of measure’;
<div n="lb">or {#aBivimAna#} might be taken in the sense ‘creator’, scil.
<div n="lb">of the universe; these possibilities are alluded to by {%Śan-%}
<div n="lb">{%kara%} in his commentary on the {%Vedānta Sūtras,%} but the
<div n="lb">first explanation is clearly that adopted in preference by
<div n="lb">him and the Vedāntists; comp. {%Śaṅk.%} on the {%Vedānta Sūtra%}
<div n="lb">(I. 2. 24.): {#vESvAnaraH sADAraRaSabdaviSezAt#} where the given
<div n="lb">passage is alleged, and on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#Amananti cEna-#}
<div n="lb">{#masmin#} (I. 2. 32.) where he observes: {#aBivimAnaSrutiH pratya-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAtmatABiprAyA . pratyagAtmatayA sarvEH prARiBiraBivimIyata#}
<div n="lb">{#ityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 1. {%as above%}) {#. aBigato vAyaM pratyagAtma-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAdvimAnaSca mAnaviyogAdityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 2. {%‘resorted to,%}
<div n="lb">{%because he has the nature of the Supreme Soul, and illimited, be-%}
<div n="lb">{%cause he is devoid of measure’%}) {#. aBivimimIte vA sarvaM jagatkA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRatvAdityaBivimAnaH#} (i. e. 3. {%‘creator’%}) {#. tasmAtparameSvaro vE-#}
<div n="lb">{#SvAnara iti sidDam;#} {%Govindānanda:%} {#ABimuKyenAhaM brahmeti vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mimIyate jYAyata ityaBivimAnaH pratyagAtmA#} (i. e. 1.) {#. aBigata-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScAsO vimAnaH sarvasvarUpatve satyAnantyAt . mAnamatra parimARam#}
<div n="lb">(i. e. 2.) {#. aBivimimIta iti nirmimIte#} (i. e. 3.) {#. tasmAdvE-#}
<div n="lb">{#SvAnaravAkyamupAsye brahmaRi samanvitamiti sidDam#}. E. 1. (and
<div n="lb">3.) {#mA#} with {#vi#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw;#} (2. {#aBi#} and {#vimAna#}).
<LEND>

<L>6363<pc>268-b<k1>aBivfzwa<k2>aBivfzwa
{#aBivfzwa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) Rained upon,
<div n="lb">sprinkled with rain; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#maRqUko yadaBivfzwaH kani-#}
<div n="lb">{#zkan#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBivfzwaH parjanyenABiziktaH#}); or {%Mahābh.:%}

<div n="lb">{#BivfzwAni SfNgARyaTa DarABftAm#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-zwam#}) The same as {#aBivarzaRa;#} e. g. {%Śabara%} (on
<div n="lb">the {%Mīm. S.%} quoted s. v. {#aBivarzaRa#}): {#taTABivfzwasya . unda-#}

<L>6370<pc>269-b<k1>aBivyAdAna<k2>aBivyAdAna
{#aBivyAdAna#}¦ Bahuvr. n. ({#-nam#}) (In vaidik Grammar.) A sup-
<div n="lb">pressed sound; viz. such a long vowel {#A,#} separated from
<div n="lb">a preceding {#A#} by a hiatus, as becomes {%wrongly%} absorbed
<div n="lb">by the protracting beyond the legitimate measure of such a
<div n="lb">preceding {#A;#} as if in the pronunciation of {#tA ApaH, avasA#}
<div n="lb">{#A, yA ApaH, tA A#} (in verses of the Ṛgveda), the
<div n="lb">speaker commits the fault of allowing the final {#A#} of {#tA,#}
<div n="lb">{#avasA, yA#} to absorb, by unduly protracting it, the be-
<div n="lb">ginning {#A#} of {#ApaH#} and {#A#}. [In the {%Ṛk-Prātiś.-Sūtra%}
<div n="lb">{#aBivyAdAnaM ca vivfttipUrve kaRWye tA Apo'vasA eti#}
<div n="lb">{#dIrGe#} it would seem more natural to look upon {#aBivyAdAna#}
<div n="lb">as a Tatpur. and render it ‘absorption’; but as {#vyAdAna#}
<div n="lb">means ‘enouncing, pronouncing’ and as a negative value
<div n="lb">of {#aBi#} is but seldom admissible in a {%Tatpur.,%} it appears
<div n="lb">better to adopt {%Uvaṭa'%}s comment which represents the
<div n="lb">word as a {%Bahuvr.%} and supplies {#akzara,#} viz.: {#AdAnamAramBaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#viviDaM vipulaM viSAlaM vAdAnamaTavAdAnameva vyAdAnam . kena-#}
<div n="lb">{#cidaBivyAptamaBiBUtaM vA vyAdAnaM tasya tadidamaBivyAdAnaM Bava-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyakzaram;#} and since the condition of {%this%} defect of pronun-
<div n="lb">ciation is the meeting of {%two%} {#A,#} there seems equally no
<div n="lb">choice left but to adopt the elliptical interpretation of this
<div n="lb">comm., as regards {#vivfttipUrve kaRWye dIrGe,#} which words he
<div n="lb">renders as neuters in the dual accus., for in giving them
<div n="lb">the apparently more natural value of a locat. sing. the rule
<div n="lb">would not necessarily imply the meeting of {%two%} long vowels
<div n="lb">{#A#}.] E. {#aBi#} and {#vyAdAna,#} scil. {#akzara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6388<pc>270-b<k1>aBiSapta<k2>aBiSapta

<L>6391<pc>270-b<k1>aBiSasta<k2>aBiSasta
{#aBiSasta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Insulted, blamed,
<div n="lb">accused, whether rightly or wrongly, but esp. wrongly;
<div n="lb">hence, calumniated; e. g. {%Baudhāyana:%} {#pAtakABiSaMsane kf-#}
<div n="lb">{#cCrastadarDamaBiSastasya;#} or {%Manu:%} {#vatsasya hyaBiSastasya puro#}
<div n="lb">{#BrAtrA yavIyasA . nAgnirdadAha romApi satyena jagataH spfSaH;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#indrasTAne'BiSastAnAM mahApAtakinAM nfRAm .#}
<div n="lb">{#nfpadrohe pravfttAnAM rAjadvAre prayojayet;#} or {%Yājnav.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#Sasto mfzA kfcCraM caredAgneyameva vA#} &c.; compare also the
<div n="lb">quotation s. v. {#aBiSapta#}.--According to {%Yājnavalkya%}
<div n="lb">3. 285 ff. a man exonerates himself from a false accusation
<div n="lb">by undergoing the penance Kṛchchhra, or by sacrificing
<div n="lb">to Agni the Puroḍāśa, or to Vāyu a sacrificial animal
<div n="lb">(compare the legend in {%Manu%} 8. 116. and in the {%Hariv.%}
<div n="lb">6428 &c.; {%Vijnāneśvara%} holds that the term {#apANktya,#} when
<div n="lb">used by {%Manu%} 11. 200., comprises the {#aBiSasta#}); whoever
<div n="lb">makes a false accusation becomes twice as guilty as if he
<div n="lb">had divulged the real blemish of a person, and assumes,
<div n="lb">moreover, all the other evils that may arise to the slan-
<div n="lb">dered person; he undergoes, besides, the penalty of fasting
<div n="lb">during a whole month, muttering the Śuddhavatī prayers
<div n="lb">and abstaining from sensual enjoyments. The civil liabi-
<div n="lb">lities for an insult or slander are regulated according to
<div n="lb">the nature of the offence and relative caste, sex &c. of the
[Page271-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">parties; comp. {%Manu%} 8. 267-270.; {%Yājnav.%} 2. 204-211. and the
<div n="lb">synopsis of the various law authorities as given by the
<div n="lb">{%Mitākṣara%} on the named verses of {%Yājnav.,%} by the {%Vīra-%}
<div n="lb">{%mitrod.%} p. 148 a ff., the {%Vivādachint.%} p. 69 &c. &c.--<sup>2</sup> Ill-
<div n="lb">famed, defamed, of doubtful character; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#pApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rogyaBiSastaSca dAmBiko rasavikrayI#} (scil. {#varjyAH#}) ({%Medhāt.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBiSastaH pAtakayoH karteti loke prasidDaH . asatyakartfkatvani-#}
<div n="lb">{#Scaye;#} {%Kull.:%} {#anirRote'pi tasminmahApAtakAdO jAtABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SApaH#}); or {#niyamya prayato vAcamaBiSastAMstu varjayet#} ({%Medh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aº = kftapAtakatve prasidDAnadfzwapAtakAnapi#}); or the {%Mit.%} when
<div n="lb">it explains in a verse of {%Kātyāy.%} the word {#saMdigDaH = aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SastaH#}. Several commentators on the {%Amarak.%} restrict the
<div n="lb">sense of the word to the meaning ‘a married man or wo-
<div n="lb">man slandered on the score of chastity’, others however
<div n="lb">take it in the general sense of the first meaning: {%Rāyam.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Bharatam., Padārthak., Nīlak., Bhanūjid,%} &c. {#mETunaM prati#}
<div n="lb">{#miTyAdUzitayoH parastrIparapuruzayoH,#} or {#miTyAmETunaparivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dayukte,#} but also: {#parastriyAM parapuruze vA miTyAdUzite mETunaM#}
<div n="lb">{#prati AhUta iti kecit . upapannapAtaka iti kecit . miTyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dUzitamAtra iti kecit#} ({%Bharatam.%}); thus {%Sārasund.%} = {#mi-#}
<div n="lb">{#TyAvAkyadUzitaH,#} {%Kṣīrasv.%} {#alIkotpannapAtakavyapadeSaH#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#SaMs#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Hurt, struck, inflicted; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#devi kenABiSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#stAsi kena vAsi vimAnitA;#} or {%Manu:%} {#AturAmaBiSastAM#}
<div n="lb">{#vA cOravyAGrAdiBirBayEH . patitAM paNkalagnAM vA sarvopAyErvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mocayet#} ({%Kull.:%} = {#vyADitAM cOravyAGrAdiBayahetuBiH;#} but,
<div n="lb">besides {#sarvaprARErvimocayet#} instead of the latter words, there
<div n="lb">is a {%v. l.%} {#aBizaktAm#} in the place of {#aBiSastAm,#} which is
<div n="lb">also adopted by {%Medhātith.:%} {#aBizaktAM = gfhItAm#}); or {%Nā-%}
<div n="lb">{%rada:%} {#baDAdfte brAhmaRasya na baDaM brAhmaRo'rhati . Siraso#}
<div n="lb">{#muRqanaM daRqastasya nirvAsanaM purAt . lalAwe vABiSastANkaH#} (a
<div n="lb">mark of infamy stamped on his forehead) {#prayARaM gardaBeRa#}
<div n="lb">{#ca#}. E. {#Sas#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6392<pc>271-a<k1>aBiSastaka<k2>aBiSastaka

<L>6393<pc>271-a<k1>aBiSasti<k2>aBiSasti
{#aBiSasti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-stiH#}) I. <sup>1</sup> Abuse, calumny, scandal,
<div n="lb">defamation ({%Med., Hemach., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Ajayap.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Śabdaratnāv.,%} &c. = {#apavAda#} or {#lokApavAda#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#uruzyA Ro aBiSasteH soma#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSasteraBiSaMsanAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#BiSAparUpAnnindanAt#}); or {%Vājas., Atharv.:%} {#amutra BUyAdaDa#}
<div n="lb">(v. 1. {#ºDi#}) {#yadyamasya bfhaspate'BiSasteramuYcaH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SasteH . aBiSApAdapi lokApavAdAdapi#}); hence personified:
<div n="lb">(ved.) a {%slanderer,%} an {%enemy;%} e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#jahI Bikitvo#}
<div n="lb">{#aBiSastimetAm#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#enamaBiSaMsakam#}); or {#tvaM devAM~ aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SasteramuYcaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBiSaMsakAcCatroH#}); in the verse of the
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#yuvaM sinDUM~raBiSasteravadyAdagnIzomAvamuYcataM gfBItAn#}
<div n="lb">it is probably more correct to take {#avadyAt#} as an appo-
<div n="lb">sition to {#aBiSasteH#} than to consider {#aBiSasteH#} as a masc.
[Page271-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">or as an adject. referring to {#avadyAt#} i. e. ‘you have liberated
<div n="lb">the rivers from that crime, the slander’, (but {%Sāy.%} from
<div n="lb">‘that notorious crime’: {#aBiSasteraBiSasyamAnAdaBitaH praka-#}
<div n="lb">{#witAdavadyAttasmAtpApAdamuYcatam#}). <sup>2</sup> Asking, begging; (ac-
<div n="lb">cording to the various Koshas mentioned above; some
<div n="lb">comm. of the {%Amarak.%} however restrict its sense to the
<div n="lb">‘religious begging’; thus {%Rāyam., Ramān., Nīlak.,%} &c.:
<div n="lb">{#BikzAmAtre,#} {%Bharatam.:%} {#vrataBikzAyAm#}). E. {#SaMs#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<div n="P">II. Injury, destruction (ved.); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#naBo na rUpaM#}
<div n="lb">{#jarimA minAti purA tasyA aBiSasteraDIhi#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SasterhiMsAhetoH#}); or {#somyAsaH…titikzante aBiSastiM janA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAm#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aBiSastiM = hiMsAm;#} but {%Mahīdh.%} takes the
<div n="lb">word in the latter instance, when it occurs in the corre-
<div n="lb">sponding verse of the {%Vājas.,%} in the sense and etym. of I. 1.
<div n="lb">viz. = {#durvacanam#}); or {%Vajas.:%} {#samidasi sUryastvA purastAtpAtu#}
<div n="lb">{#kasyAScidaBiSastyE#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#hiMsAyAH#}); also personified
<div n="lb">in this sense: {%an enemy;%} when {%Sāyaṇa%} however, and pro-
<div n="lb">bably wrongly, analyzes it as a Bahuvr. m.; comp. {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SastipA, aBiSastipAvan#} and the following. E. {#Sas#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6402<pc>272-a<k1>aBiSApa<k2>aBiSApa
{#aBiSApa#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-paH#}) <sup>1</sup> Charge, accusation; more esp.
<div n="lb">a heavy charge, and one from which the accused is able to
<div n="lb">exonerate himself; hence a false imputation, a calumny;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#nfpArTezvaBiSApe ca vaheyuH SucayaH sadA#} ({%Mit.:%}
<div n="lb">{#nfpadrohezu mahApAtakABiyoge ca#}); or {#sAhasasteyapAruzyago'Bi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SApAtyaye striyAm . vivAdayetsadya eva kAlo'nyatrecCayA#}
<div n="lb">{#smftaH#} ({%Mit.:%} {#aBiSApaH pAtakABiyogaH#}); or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SApe samuttIrRe prAyaScitte kfte buDEH . viSudDipatrakaM deyam#} &c.;
<div n="lb">or the same {#uttamezu samastezu aBiSApe samAgate . vfttAnuvAda-#}
<div n="lb">{#leKyaM yattajjYeyaM saMDipatrakam;#} or {%Vyāsa:%} {#BAgABiSApasaMdigDe#}
<div n="lb">{#yaH samyagvijayI Bavet . tasmE rAjYA pradAtavyaM jayapatraM suni-#}
<div n="lb">{#Scitam#}. <sup>2</sup> A curse, an imprecation (esp. uttered by a
<div n="lb">Brāhmaṇa, a Guru, an old man and a magician; {%Vijaya-%}
<div n="lb">{%rakshita%} as quoted by {%Rādhākaṇtad.:%} = {#brAhmaRaguruvfdDasidDA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmanizwABiSaMsanam;#} {%Chakrapāṇidatta%} in his comm. {%Bhānu-%}
<div n="lb">{%matī%} on {%Suśruta:%} {#aBiSApo guruvfdDasidDAcAryAdiBiraBiSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#panam#}); e. g. {%Nalop.:%} {#yasyABiSApAdduHKArto duHKaM vindati#}
<div n="lb">{#nEzaDaH . tasya BUtasya no duHKAdduHKamapyaDikaM Bavet#}. According
<div n="lb">to the medical superstition, a kind of fever is produced by
<div n="lb">the imprecation of a Brāhmaṇa &c. the symptoms of which
<div n="lb">are delirium and thirst and otherwise like those of the fever
<div n="lb">produced by incantation (comp. {#aBicArajvara#}); e. g. {%Su-%}
<div n="lb">{%śruta:%} {#aBicArABiSApAByAM…jvaro pravartate;#} and {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#cArABiSApAByAM mohastfzRABijAyate#}.--Also {#aBISApa#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#Sap#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#DaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6404<pc>272-a<k1>aBiSIta<k2>aBiSIta
{#aBiSIta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Cold; e. g. {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SIto vAyuH#}. [This form is given by the {%Kāśikā%} on {%Pāṇ.%}
<div n="lb">VI. 1. 26., besides {#aBiSyAta;#} but neither form occurs in the
<div n="lb">{%Siddhk.%} or in the commentaries on the Dhātus by {%Mādhava,%}
<div n="lb">{%Hemach.,%} &c.; nor is there a Vārtt. or a Bhāṣya on the
<div n="lb">named Sūtra, to countenance these past partic. of {#SyE#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} ending in {#ta#}.] E. {#SyE#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta,#} with
<div n="lb">samprasār. of the semivowel.
<LEND>

<div n="lb">{%Kāśikā:%} {#aBiSInaM Gftam#}. Also {#aBiSyAna#}. E. {#SyE#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#kta#} with samprasār. of the semivowel and final {#na#}
<div n="lb">instead of {#ta#}.

<div n="lb">word is udātta on the third syllable; a derivation with kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#yuc#} according to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 150. and a meaning ‘one
<div n="lb">who causes pain’ is therefore not admissible.)

<L>6416<pc>272-b<k1>aBiSrI<k2>aBiSrI
{#aBiSrI#}¦ (ved.) I. Tatpur. m. f. ({#-SrIH-SrIH#}) <sup>1</sup> Approaching,
<div n="lb">having recourse to; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#evA ta indro suBvaM supeSasaM#}
<div n="lb">{#rasaM tuYjanti praTamA aBiSriyaH#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#praTamA muKyA grA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vARo'Dvaryavo vA . aBiSriyaH . aBiSrayantaH santaH#}); or
<div n="lb">{#asaScataH . SataDArA aBiSriyo hariM navante'va tA udanyuvaH#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSrayaH . aBitaH somaM SrayantyaH#}); or {%Ṛgv.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#A sute siYcata SriyaM rodasyoraBiSriyam .#}
<div n="lb">{#rasA daDIta vfzaBam#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBiSriyamaBiSrayantam;#} but
<div n="lb">comp. II.). <sup>2</sup> To be had recourse to, to be respected or
<div n="lb">venerated everywhere; e. g. {%Ṛgv., Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#GftavatI#}
<div n="lb">{#BuvanAnAmaBiSriyorvI pfTvI maDuduDe supeSasA#} ({%Sāyaṇa%} and

<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#vESvAnarasya sumatO syAma rAjA hi kaM BuvanAnAmaBi-#}

[Page273-a+ 56]

<div n="lb">{#'BiSrIH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#enI ta ete bfhatI aBiSriyA hiraRyayI#}

<div n="lb">where; e. g. in the verse {#A sute#} &c. quoted above (p. 272,

<div n="lb">{#ete#} quoted above (line 2) where {%Sāyaṇa%} says that the word
<div n="lb">might mean also {#prAptESvarye#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#SrI#}.

<L>6421<pc>273-a<k1>aBizakta<k2>aBizakta

<L>6422<pc>273-a<k1>aBizaNga<k2>aBizaNga
{#aBizaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Contact, union, connexion, at-
<div n="lb">tachment; e. g. {%Māghak.:%} {#muhuriti vanaviBramABizaNgAdatami#}
<div n="lb">{#tadA nitarAM nitambinIBiH#} ({%Mallin.:%} {#vanaº = vanaBramaRasaNgAt#});
<div n="lb">also figur., e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#sAtvikAstu#} (scil. {#guRAH#}) {#Anf-#}
<div n="lb">{#SaMsyaM…smftirDftiranaBizaNgaH#} (i. e. want of attachment).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Embracing, copulation; ({%Halāyudha:%} {#saMsargABiBavAkroSe-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvaBizaNgaH prakIrtitaH#}). <sup>3</sup> Possession by evil spirits or pas-
<div n="lb">sions; {%Chakrapāṇidatta%} on the {%Sūtrasth.%} of {%Suśruta:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaNgo devAdInAM viparyAyAnupraveSaH;#} {%a modern medical comm.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#BUtAnAM kAmAdInAM ca SarIre manasi vA saMbanDaH;#} e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Suśruta'%}s {%Uttarat.:%} {#kecidBUtABizaNgotTaM bruvate vizamajvaram;#}
<div n="lb">or {#BUtABizaNgAdudvegahAsyakampanarodanam#}. See also {#aBizaNga-#}
<div n="lb">{#jvara#}. <sup>4</sup> An oath (= {#SapaTa#} {%Trik., Hem., Viśvapr., Med.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Śabdaratnāv.%} of {%Mathureśa, Bhūripr.;%} = {#SApa#} {%Ajayap.%} and
<div n="lb">{%comm.%} on the {%Amarak.%}). <sup>5</sup> Curse, imprecation (= {#AkroSa#}
<div n="lb">{%Amarak., Hem., Viśvapr.,%} &c.); e. g. {%Mahābh. Śāntip.:%} {#kzepAya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mARamaBizaNgavyalIkaM nigfhRAti jvalitaM yaSca manyum . aduzwacetA#}
<div n="lb">{#mudito'nasUyuH sa Adatte sukftaM vE parezAm#}. <sup>6</sup> False accusation,
<div n="lb">calumny; ({%Mathureśa%} on the {%Amarak.:%} = {#SApe siTyABiSaMsane#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>7</sup> Defeat, misfortune, calamity (= {#parABava#} {%Amarak., Hem.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Viśvapr., Śabdar.,%} &c.; = {#aBiBava#} {%Halāy., Ajayap.%}); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Sāhityad.:%} {#tIvrABizaNnapraBaveRa vfttiM mohena saMstamBayatendriyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAm . ajYAtaBartfvyasanA muhUrtaM kftopakAreva ratirbaBUva;#} or
[Page273-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%Raghuv.:%} {#tato'BizaNgAnilavipravidDA…DaratrIM lateva sI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA sahasA jagAma;#} or {#…gururASramASritaH . aBizaNgajaqa#}
<div n="lb">{#vijajYivAn#} (comm.: = {#aBizaNgeRa duHKena jaqam#}). Also
<div n="lb">{#aBIzaNga#} and in the three first meanings probably also {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvaNga#} or {#aBIzvaNga#} ({%Sārasund.%} on the {%Amarak.%} 3. 3. 6. reads
<div n="lb">{#aBizvaNga,#} and {%Bharatam.:%} {#dve SApe . aBerito dIrGaH . zatvam .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBIzaNgaH . aBizaNgaSca . dvayamapi nirvakAraH#}). E. {#saYj#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6423<pc>273-b<k1>aBizaNgajvara<k2>aBizaNgajvara
{#aBizaNgajvara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) (In Medicine.) A kind of
<div n="lb">fever supposed to be produced by evil spirits; its symptoms
<div n="lb">are, according to {%Suśruta,%} alternate agitation, trembling,
<div n="lb">laughing and crying, and, according to others, moreover,
<div n="lb">loss of bashfulness, of consciousness and of sleep; this kind
<div n="lb">of fever belongs to the class of the ‘accidental fevers’ (see
<div n="lb">{#Agantu#}) and is called also {#BUtAveSajvara#}. E. {#aBizaNga#} and {#jvara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6424<pc>273-b<k1>aBizaYjana<k2>aBizaYjana
{#aBizaYjana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The same as {#aBizaNga#} (of which
<div n="lb">it occurs as an explanation). E. {#saYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6425<pc>273-b<k1>aBizava<k2>aBizava
{#aBizava#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-vaH#}) <sup>1</sup> The religious act of pressing
<div n="lb">out the juice of the Soma plant or Asclepias acida (see
<div n="lb">also {#somABizava#}), or in default of this plant, of its substi-
<div n="lb">tute, the Pūtīkā or Cæsalpinia bonducella (see also {#pUtI-#}
<div n="lb">{#kABizava#}); it constitutes an essential ceremony of the
<div n="lb">Soma sacrifices (see {#jyotizwoma#}), and is performed the day
<div n="lb">after the sacrificial acts called {#upasad#} (q. v.), by means
<div n="lb">of stones ({#grAvan#}) which press on two boards (called
<div n="lb">{#aDizavaRa#}); the act takes place in the southern part of a
<div n="lb">building erected in the western part of the Uttaravedi near
<div n="lb">a cart which is placed there and bears, like the building,
<div n="lb">the name {#havirDAna#}. (Comp. e. g. {%Mādhava vv. ll.:%} {#yadi#}
<div n="lb">{#somaM na vindeta pUtIkAnaBizuRuyAditi SrUyate;--dIkzAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasAdUrDvaM somABizavadivasAtpUrvaM kartavyA homA upasadaH;#}--
<div n="lb">{%Mahīdhara:%} {#aDvaryuBiH sutA aBizavaDarmeRa grAvaBiH dravIBA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vamApAditAH;#} {%Mādhava:%} {#somABizavADArayoraDizavaRaPala-#}
<div n="lb">{#kayoH saMtardanaM kAryam;--uttaravedyAH pratIcIne maRqape'Bi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zavaH;--havirDAne grAvaBiraBizutyAhavanIye hutvA sadasi#}
<div n="lb">{#Bakzayanti;--jyotizwome SrUyate . uta yatsunvanti sAmiDenI-#}
<div n="lb">{#stadanvAhuriti . havirDAnamaRqapagatayordakziRottaraBAgayora-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasTitayorhavirDAnanAmakayoH SakawayormaDye dakziRaM Sakawamatra#}
<div n="lb">{#yattacCabdAByAmaBiDIyate . tatra samIpe somasyABizavaH#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2a.</sup> Religions bathing, ablution preparatory to religious rites;
<div n="lb"><sup>b.</sup> Drinking the juice of the Soma plant. [Some of the
<div n="lb">comm. on the {%Amarak.%} 2. 7. 46. give only the first meaning
<div n="lb">(2. a.), others both meanings; {%Rāyam., Tarkavāgīśa, Ramān.,%}
<div n="lb">&c. = {#yajYasnAne;#} {%Bharatam., Sārasund., Nīlak.:%} {#yajYasnAne#}
<div n="lb">{#somalatApAne ca#}.] <sup>3</sup> Sacrifice in general ({%Med., Śabdar.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Bhūripr., Viśvapr.%} = {#yajYa;#} {%Hem.%} = {#kratu;#} {%Trik.%} = {#yAga#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Bathing in general ({%Med., Trik., Hem.,%} &c., &c.). <sup>5</sup> Ferment,
<div n="lb">yeast, any substance producing vinous fermentation ({%Ama-%}
<div n="lb">{%rak.%} = {#saMDAna;#} {%Rāyam.%} on this word: = {#madyakalke;#} {%Ramān.%} =
<div n="lb">{#madyasajjIkaraRe;#} {%Bhānud.%} = {#AmrAdisaMDAne;#} {%Śabdamuktām.%} =
<div n="lb">{#vaMSANkurAmraPalAdijanitacirasTApitamadyotpAdakadravyaviSeze;#}
<div n="lb">{%Ajayap.%} = {#madyasaMhatO;#} {%Śabdar.%} = {#madyasaMDAne;#} {%Bhūripr., Jaṭādh.%}
<div n="lb">= {#SIDusaMDAne;#} a meaning ‘distillation’ given to this word
<div n="lb">elsewhere is therefore erroneous).
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-vam#}) Sour gruel; comp. {#aBizuta;#} ({%Halāy., Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%nigh.%} = {#kAYjika#}). E. {#su (zuY)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>
[Page274-a+ 56]

<L>6426<pc>274-a<k1>aBizavaRa<k2>aBizavaRa
{#aBizavaRa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. n. ({#-Ram#}) The same as {#aBizava#} 1. q. v.;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Nirukta:%} {#aBivahanastutimaBizavaRapravAdAM stutiM manyante#}.
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-RI#}) (ved.) Probably; the juice of the Soma
<div n="lb">plant pressed out for sacrificial purposes (comp. {#aBizava#}
<div n="lb">1. 1.); {%Atharv.%} (where it occurs among sacrificial implements
<div n="lb">besides {#fjIza,#} the stale Soma or the remains of the
<div n="lb">plant, after its juice has been extracted): {#SUrpaM pavitraM tuzA#}
<div n="lb">{#fjIzABizavaRIrApaH#}. E. {#su (zuY)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6427<pc>274-a<k1>aBizavaRIya<k2>aBizavaRIya
{#aBizavaRIya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Fit for a Soma
<div n="lb">sacrifice, (said of the juice of the Soma plant). E. {#su (zuY)#}
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar#}.
<LEND>

<L>6434<pc>274-a<k1>aBizAvakIy<k2>aBizAvakIy
{#aBizAvakIy#}¦ denom. parasm. ({#-yati#}) To have a desire for one
<div n="lb">who presses out the juice of the Soma plant. [This denom. is
<div n="lb">an example to the {%Vārtt.%} {#na vAnupasargatvAt#} to {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 65;
<div n="lb">the latter Sūtra enjoins that {#s#} of the rad. {#su (zuY)#} when pre-
<div n="lb">ceded by certain prefixes, e. g. by the upasarga {#aBi,#} becomes
<div n="lb">{#z;#} e. g. {#aBizuRoti;#} thereupon a {%Vārtt.%} ({#nAmaDAtostu pratize-#}
<div n="lb">{#DaH#}) observes that if a denomin. is formed of a deriv. of {#su#}
<div n="lb">(e. g. {#sAvakIy#} of {#sAvaka#}) and such a denom. is preceded by a
<div n="lb">prefix like {#aBi,#} the change of {#s#} into {#z#} does {%not%} take place;
<div n="lb">thus {#sAvakIy#} when prefixed with {#aBi,#} remains, for in-
<div n="lb">stance, {#aBi sAvakIyati;#} the mentioned {%Vārtt.%} {#na vAº#} then
<div n="lb">limits the generality of this restriction by adding that {#s#} re-
<div n="lb">mains unchanged, only if e. g. {#aBi#} is not {#upasarga#} to {#su;#} for {#aBi#}
<div n="lb">being upasarga to {#su#} in the derivat. {#aBizAvaka, s#} becomes
<div n="lb">{#z#} not only in the latter, but also in its denom. {#aBizAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#kIy;#} the case being different from that of {#aBi sAvakI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yati#} where {#aBi#} is not upasarga to {#su#} but to {#sAvakIy;#}
<div n="lb">forms like {#aBisAvakIy#} or {#parisAvakIy#} are therefore {%not%}
<div n="lb">simple denom., but must, like other radicals with upasar-
<div n="lb">gas prefixed, be looked for under the simple form, i. e. under
<div n="lb">{#sAvakIy#}. {%Patanj.:%} {#nAmaDAtostu pratizeDo vaktavyaH . sAvaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#micCati . aBi sAvakIyati . pari sAvakIyati ..#} ({%Vārtt.:%}
<div n="lb">{#na vAnupasargatvAt#}) {#. na vA vaktavyaH . kiM kAraRam . anupasarga-#}
[Page274-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#tvAt . yatkriyAyuktAstaM prati gatyupasargasaMjYe BavataH . na cAtra#}
<div n="lb">{#sunotiM prati kriyAyogaH . kiM tarhi sAvakIyatiM prati;#} {%Kaīyy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#na veti . aBiH kyajarTasyecCAyA viSezaRatvAdupasargo na sunoteH .#}
<div n="lb">{#sunotyupasargatve tvaBizAvakamicCati . aBizAvakIyati . Bavatyeva#}
<div n="lb">{#zatvaM nAsAvevamiti#}.] E. {#aBizAvaka,#} denom. aff. {#kyac#}.
<LEND>

<L>6445<pc>274-b<k1>aBizeka<k2>aBizeka
{#aBizeka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) {%Sprinkling over;%} hence 1. Sprinkling
<div n="lb">consecrated liquid over a sacrificer, {%inaugurating%} or {%conse-%}
<div n="lb">{%crating%} him; e. g. (in reference to the sacrifice {#aBizecanIya#}
<div n="lb">q. v.) {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#zawpurastAdaBizekasya juhoti;#} or {%Mādh.%}
