<div n="lb">consists of river and sea-water is consecrated by chanting
<div n="lb">hymns from the Atharvaveda, Sāmaveda and other sacred
<div n="lb">works; ({#saritsamudrasalilakumBEH pUrRavimADavEH#} ({%sic%}) {#. aTarva-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAmagItESca cAnyEScAgamamantrakEH#}); the king marks his fore-
<div n="lb">head with the sign Tripuṇḍra (q. v.: {#paScAttu homanizWAM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#darBaM dattvA tripuRqrakam . lalAwasAraRaM kuryAdBUpatistu yaTAvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#Di#}), anoints his body with sandal and saffron, and the
<div n="lb">{%Sthapati%} purifies him with the compound called {%Pancha-%}
<div n="lb">{%gavya%} (see above page 282{%b,%} line 45); them the family-priest
<div n="lb">places on his head the tiara, and this toilet being com-
<div n="lb">pleted, the {%Sthapati%} and the {%Sthāpaka%} invite the king to
<div n="lb">take place, with his queen, on the throne when the sacred
<div n="lb">liquid is sprinkled on his forehead while he bears the
<div n="lb">jewelled tiara ({#ratnasaMtuzwamukuwamUrDvaM rAjopaDArayet#}). This
<div n="lb">ceremony having been performed under ‘benedictions and
<div n="lb">all manner of auspicious noises’ ({#sarvamaNgalaGozESca svastivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#canapUrvavat#}) the king mounts on an elephant and, under the
<div n="lb">sounds of a similar music, rides round his city, keeping
<div n="lb">his right side towards it, and distributes gifts amongst the
<div n="lb">spectators ({#kuryAdArohaRaM paScAdrAjA tvErAvatopari . nagarI-#}
<div n="lb">{#pradakziRaM kuryAtsarvamaNgalaGozakEH#}). These gifts which consist
<div n="lb">in corn and the like, cow's and other milk, weapons, and
<div n="lb">generally in any thing whether auspicious or not, the king
<div n="lb">should throw before himself and touch with his own hand,
<div n="lb">for in doing so he will not merely acquire strength, victory
<div n="lb">and glory but abundance of food &c. [A modern treatise on
<div n="lb">the royal inauguration, called {%Rājyābhiṣekapaddhati,%}--with-
<div n="lb">out either date or name of the author--is very prolix in the
<div n="lb">enumeration of the mantras; it quotes the {%Śatapathabr.%} and,
<div n="lb">among the Purāṇas, chiefly the {%Agni-P.;%} but it is rather
<div n="lb">an uncritical compilation from various books, than an au-
<div n="lb">thoritative source of information.]
<div n="P">The {%time of the inauguration%} must be an auspicious one.
<div n="lb">{%Rāma%} was inaugurated when the moon entered the asterism
<div n="lb">{%Pushya,%} in the hour {%Abhijit;%} ({%Yuddhak.:%} {#tataH praBAte vimale#}
<div n="lb">{#muhUrte'Bijiti praBuH . vasizWaH puzyayogena brAhmaREH parivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ritaH . rAmaM ratnamaye pIWe…upaveSya#} &c.).--The {%Agni-P.%}
<div n="lb">merely forbids the inauguration to take place at night
[Page285-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">time, but makes no further restriction ({#sAMvatsaro nfpaM kAle#}
<div n="lb">{#sasaMBAro'Bizecanam . kuryAdfte rAtrikAlaM kAlasya niyamaH#}
<div n="lb">{#smftaH#}).--According to the astrological work {%Jyotishara-%}
<div n="lb">{%tnamālā,%} the inauguration of a king may take place when
<div n="lb">the moon enters either of the following asterisms: {%Anu-%}
<div n="lb">{%rādhā%} (17<sup>th</sup> ), {%Hasta%} (13<sup>th</sup> ), {%Pushya%} (8<sup>th</sup> ), {%Rohiṇi%} (4<sup>th</sup> ), {%Śra-%}
<div n="lb">{%vaṇa%} (23<sup>d</sup> ) and the three next to it (viz. {%Dhaniṣṭhā, Śata-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhiṣā, Pūrvabhādrapadā%}), {%Revatī%} (28<sup>th</sup> ), {%Mṛgaśiras%} (5<sup>th</sup> )
<div n="lb">or {%Aśvinī%} (1<sup>st</sup> ); ({#mEtraSAkrakarapuzyarohiRIvEzRavezu tisfzUttarAsu#}
<div n="lb">{#ca . revatImfgaSiro'SvinIzvapi kzmABujAM samaBizeka izyate#}).--
<div n="lb">Another astrological work, the {%Muhūrtachintāmaṇī,%} lays
<div n="lb">down the following rules: ‘the inauguration of a king is
<div n="lb">auspicious, if it takes place at the period of the sun's pro-
<div n="lb">gress to the north of the equator, when Jupiter, the Moon
<div n="lb">and Venus have risen or those powerful planets: Mars, the
<div n="lb">Sun, the predominant or the minor planet which rule the
<div n="lb">(king's) nativity; but {%not%} on the fourth, ninth or fourteenth
<div n="lb">day of the month Chaitra, on a Tuesday, during the night
<div n="lb">or in an intercalary month. If it is performed at the
<div n="lb">conjunction of ill-omened planets with the first asterism
<div n="lb">(reckoned from that under which the king is born) their
<div n="lb">influence brings him illness; with the eighth, death; with
<div n="lb">the fifth, affliction of his sons; with the twelfth, poverty;
<div n="lb">with the tenth, it deprives him of energy; with the seventh
<div n="lb">or fourth, it destroys his sovereign power. All is au-
<div n="lb">spicious, however, if an auspicious planet enters into the
<div n="lb">circle. If Jupiter enters into conjunction with the ninth
<div n="lb">or fifth asterism (reckoned from that under which the king
<div n="lb">is born) or Mars with the sixth, or Venus with the tenth,
<div n="lb">the king will always enjoy royal happiness; if Saturn
<div n="lb">enters into conjunction with the third, the Sun with the
<div n="lb">eleventh or Jupiter with the tenth or fourth asterism (and
<div n="lb">the inauguration then takes place), his empire will remain
<div n="lb">firm’; [{#rAjABizekaH SuBa uttarAyaRe gurvinduSukrEruditErbalA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nvitEH . BOmArkalagneSadaSeSajanmapErno cEtrariktAraniSAmalimlu-#}
<div n="lb">{#cEH .. 9 .. pApEstanO rugniDane mftiH sute putrArttirarTavyayagErda-#}
<div n="lb">{#ridratA . syAtKe'laso Brazwapado dyunAmbugEH sarvaM SuBaM kendragatEH#}
<div n="lb">{#SuBagrahEH .. 2 .. gururlagnakoRe kujo'rO sitaH Ke sa rAjA#}
<div n="lb">{#modate rAjalakzmyA . tftIyAyagO sOrisUryO KabamDvorguruScedDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ritrI sTirA syAnnfpasya .. 3 .. iti rAjABizekaprakaraRam ..;#}
<div n="lb">the technical terms are rendered, in the given translation,
<div n="lb">according to the comment of the author, {%Daivajnarāma%}].
<div n="P">{%B.%} INAUGURATION OF A MILITARY COMMANDER. This
<div n="lb">ceremony, the object of which is to ensure to the chief of
<div n="lb">an army victory over his enemies, does not appear to have
<div n="lb">been performed before the period of the {%Mahābhārata,%}
<div n="lb">where the inauguration of {%Kārtikeya%} as commander of the
<div n="lb">divine hosts is mentioned as the type of such a rite; comp.
<div n="lb">e. g. the words addressed by {%Duryodhana%} to {%Śalya,%} the king
<div n="lb">of Madra, when he chose him for his military chief: {#sEnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#patyena varaye tvAmahaM mAtulAtulam . so'smAnpAhi yuDAM SrezWa#}
<div n="lb">{#skando devAnihAhave . aBizicyasva rAjendra devAnAmiva pA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vakiH . jahi SatrUnraRe vIra mahendro dAnavAniva#}.--The pro-
<div n="lb">ceedings at such an inauguration are not fully detailed in
<div n="lb">the description given in the {%Śalyaparvan%} of the {%Mahābh.%}
<div n="lb">(ch. 46), of the inauguration of {%Kārtikeya;%} but from the
[Page285-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">rites which are mentioned, it may be inferred, that they
<div n="lb">were substantially the same as those which took place
<div n="lb">at the inauguration of a king; (comp. e. g.: {#tato'Bizeka-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMBArAnsarvAnsaMBftya SAstrataH . vfhaspatiH samidDe'gnO juhAvAgniM#}
<div n="lb">{#yaTAviDi . tato himavatA datte maRiprabaraSoBite . divyara-#}
<div n="lb">{#tnAcite puRye nizaRRaM paramAsane . sarvamaNgalasaMBArErviDimantrapura-#}
<div n="lb">{#skftam . ABizecanikaM dravyaM gfhItvA devatAgaRAH#} &c. {#….#}
<div n="lb">{#bahulatvAcca noktA ye viviDA devatAgaRAH . te kumArABize-#}
<div n="lb">{#kArTaM samAjagmustatastataH . jagfhuste tadA rAjansarva eva divO-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasaH . ABizecanikaM BARqaM maNgalAni ca sarvaSaH . divyasaMBA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rasaMyuktEH kalasEH kAYcanErnfpa . sarasvatIBiH puRyABirdivyatoyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bireva tu . aByaziYcankumAraM vE saMprahfzwA divOkasaH . senApatiM#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAtmAnamasurARAM BayaMkaram . purA yaTA mahArAja varuRaM vE#}
<div n="lb">{#jaleSvaram . taTAByaziYcadBagavAnbrahmA lokapitAmahaH#} &c.); the
<div n="lb">text (as results from the last quotation) professes at least
<div n="lb">that they are analogous to those at the inauguration
<div n="lb">of {%Varuṇa%} as king of the waters, and at the latter cere-
<div n="lb">mony (mentioned {%Śalyap.%} chap. 48) reference is made to the
<div n="lb">inauguration of {%Indra,%} which is the type of a royal inau-
<div n="lb">guration; ({#varuRaM devatAH sarvAH sametyedamaTAbruvan . yaTAsmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nsurarAwSakro BayeByaH pAti sarvadA . taTA tvamapi sarvAsAM#}
<div n="lb">{#saritAM vE patirBava .…aBiziktastato devErvaruRo'pi#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAyaSAH . saritaH sAgarAMScEva nadAMScApi sarAMsi ca . pAla-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAmAsa viDinA yaTA devAYCatakratuH .#}). There seems to
<div n="lb">have been that difference, however, that the military com-
<div n="lb">mander, his installation having been performed, did not
<div n="lb">give but receive presents, for the {%Mahābh.%} exhibits a long
<div n="lb">list of presents that were offered to {%Kārtikeya%} by the gods
<div n="lb">who assisted at his consecration.--The time deemed au-
<div n="lb">spicious or inauspicious is the same for the inauguration
<div n="lb">of a military chief as for that of a king, except that {%Tuesday%}
<div n="lb">is considered also amongst the lucky days of the former,
<div n="lb">Mars being himself a military chief; (according to {%Daiva-%}
<div n="lb">{%jnarāma%} in his comm. on the quoted first verse of the
<div n="lb">{%Muhūrtachintāmaṇi:%} {#kutracidBOmavAro'pyuktaH . sa senApatya-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bizekaparo jYeyaH . BOmasya senApatitvAt#}).
<div n="P">2. The water or liquid used at the ceremony of inau-
<div n="lb">guration; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#kaRquyanyABizekeRa prali-#}
<div n="lb">{#mpate#} ({%Śrīdeva:%} {#aBizekeRa = aBizekodakena#}); or {%Ādip. Ma-%}
<div n="lb">{%hābh.:%} {#karRo'BizekArdraSirAH SirasA samavandata#}. 3. The
<div n="lb">name of the sacrificial building where the inauguration of
<div n="lb">a king takes place; ({%Mānasāra:%} {#sarvAlaMkArasaMyuktamaBizekA-#}
<div n="lb">{#KyamaRqapam#} &c.). 4. Bathing, washing; e. g. {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%}
<div n="lb">{#duHKAduHKaM jalABizekavanna jAqyavimokzaH#} ({%Vijnānāch.:%} {#yaTA#}
<div n="lb">{#jAqyArttasya jalABizekAdduHKAnivfttireva Bavati na tu jAqya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vimokza ityarTaH#}); esp. for religious purposes, ablution; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Śatātapa:%} {#surApaH…SarkarAyAstulA sapta dadyAtpApaviSu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDaye . japitvA tu mahArudraM daSAMSaM juhuyAttilEH . tato'BizekaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kartavyo mantrErvaruRadevatEH#} &c.; or {%Vanap. Mahābh.:%} {#plakzA devI#}
<div n="lb">{#smftA rAjanpuRyA devI sarasvatI . tatrABizekaM kurvIta valmI-#}
<div n="lb">{#kAnniHsfte jale . arcayitvA pitFndevAnaSvameDaPalaM laBet;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Anuśāsanap. Mahābh.:%} {#skanda uvAca . mamApyanumato DarmastaM#}
<div n="lb">{#SfRuDvaM samAhitAH . nIlazaRqasya SfNgAByAM gfhItvA mfttikAM tu#}
<div n="lb">{#yaH . aBizekaM tryahaM kuryAttasya DarmaM niboData#} &c.
<div n="P">5. Washing the image of a divinity, purifying it with
<div n="lb">ablutions. This ceremony takes place either at a festival
[Page286-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">held in honour of a divinity or at the installation of an
<div n="lb">idol as a domestic and tutelary divinity; it consists in
<div n="lb">rubbing it over with ointments and washing it with liquids
<div n="lb">prepared of different substances under the recital of appro-
<div n="lb">priate mantras. (According to the given quotation from
<div n="lb">the {%Agni-Pur.,%} the invocations mentioned in the latter, are
<div n="lb">the same for the consecration of an idol as for that of a
<div n="lb">king.) At the {%Dola%} festival held in honour of the juvenile
<div n="lb">{%Kṛṣṇa%} the following materiels are used, according to the
<div n="lb">{%Utkalakhaṇḍa%} (as quoted by {%Rādhākāntadeva%}): cold water,
<div n="lb">cow-dung, cow's urine, cow's milk, curds, clarified butter
<div n="lb">(i. e. the five substances of the Panchagavya), infusions of
<div n="lb">Kuśa-grass ({#kuSodakam#}), of Śaṅkha (a perfume, apparently
<div n="lb">a dried shell-fish; {#SaNKodakam#}), of sandal ({#candanodakam#}),
<div n="lb">of saffron ({#kuNkumodakam#}), of fruits and flowers ({#Paloda-#}
<div n="lb">{#kam#} and {#puzpodakam#}), an unguent prepared of the powder
<div n="lb">of sandal wood and of emblic myrobalan ({#candanapizwAma-#}
<div n="lb">{#lakyudvartanam#}); scented water ({#suganDijalam#}) with which the
<div n="lb">idol is washed eight times, milk, clarified butter and honey
<div n="lb">being added severally at the second, seventh and eighth
<div n="lb">ablution; an infusion of perfumes ({#ganDodakam#}) with which
<div n="lb">five ablutions are made; water taken from places of pil-
<div n="lb">grimage ({#tIrTajalam#}), Ganges-water, water proceeding from
<div n="lb">an ant-hill, infusion of small annuals ({#sarvOzaDijalam#}),
<div n="lb">Sahasradhārā-water ({#sahasraDArAjalam#}), various kinds of
<div n="lb">water in jars (according to some, in 108 jars).--At the
<div n="lb">{%Durgā%} festival, according to the {%Vṛhannandikeśvara-Purāṇa%}
<div n="lb">(also quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}) the image of the goddess is rubbed
<div n="lb">over before a looking glass ({#darpaRapratibimbe#}) with an oint-
<div n="lb">ment prepared of turmeric and powder of emblic myro-
<div n="lb">balan and then washed with the following things one after
<div n="lb">the other, under the recital of mantras, with: pure water,
<div n="lb">an infusion of Śaṅkha, Ganges-water, an infusion of per-
<div n="lb">fumes, each article of the Panchagavya (successively, as
<div n="lb">mentioned before), an infusion of Kuśa-grass, Pañchāmṛta
<div n="lb">(a mixture of milk, curds, sugar, clarified butter and honey),
<div n="lb">ice-water, honey, an infusion of flowers, sea-water mixed
<div n="lb">with the juice of the sugar-cane ({#ikzurasasAgarodake#}), an
<div n="lb">infusion of small and large annuals mixed together ({#sarvO-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaDimahOzaDijalam#}), water containing five kinds of extracts
<div n="lb">({#paYcakazAyodakam#}), eight sorts of earth ({#azwamfttikAH?#} pro-
<div n="lb">bably {#azwO mfº#}), infusion of fruits, hot water, Sahasra-
<div n="lb">dhārā-water, various kinds of water in eight jars, viz.
<div n="lb">atmospheric water in one jar ({#vyomagaNgAmbupUrRAdyakalasaH#}),
<div n="lb">cloud-water in a second ({#meGatoyapUrRaº#}), water of the Sara-
<div n="lb">svatī in a third ({#sArasvatatoyapUrRaº#}), sea-water in a fourth
<div n="lb">({#sAgarodakapUrRaº#}), water mixed with lotus-pollen ({#padmareRu-#}
<div n="lb">{#miSritajalapUrRaº#}) in a fifth, cascade-water in a sixth ({#nirjJa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rodakapUrRaº#}), water from various places of pilgrimage in a
<div n="lb">seventh ({#sarvatIrTAmbupUrRaº#}) and pure water in an eighth jar
<div n="lb">{#SudDajalapUrRAzwamakalasaH#}). Besides these substances, other ri-
<div n="lb">tual works mention: river-water, infusions of cocoa-nuts and
<div n="lb">of (pounded) pearls, rain-water, infusions of camphor and
<div n="lb">of sandal, aloe, gold, silver, {%Gorochanā,%} saffron, {%Śrīphala,%}
<div n="lb">corn, Dūb-grass, sugar, lake-water, Ganges-and sea-water
<div n="lb">mixed together, an infusion of five kinds of grain ({#paYca-#}
[Page286-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#Sasyajalam#}), of sesamum, tank-, lotus-pond-, and well-
<div n="lb">water, infusions of fruits and roots, Arghya (q. v.) -water,
<div n="lb">other kinds of water in four jars, and cold water; sesamum-
<div n="lb">oil and fragrant-oil; earth from river-banks, earth stirred
<div n="lb">up by the teeth of a boar ({#varAhadantamfttikA#}), earth from
<div n="lb">the door of a brothel ({#veSyAdvAramfttikA#}), from the gate of
<div n="lb">a palace ({#rAjadvAramfttikA#}), earth stirred up by the horns
<div n="lb">of a bull, earth from an ant-hill, from a quadrivium, from
<div n="lb">the near and opposite banks of a stream ({#pArAvAramfttikA#}),
<div n="lb">from the door of a temple and from the Ganges; and accord-
<div n="lb">ing to some, earth stirred up by the teeth of an elephant,
<div n="lb">earth from a river, from its two banks, from a town-gate
<div n="lb">({#nAgaramfttikA#}), from a cowpen and a trivium; others
<div n="lb">name infusions of the five acticles of Pañchāmṛta severally,
<div n="lb">of the small and the large annuals severally ({#savOzaDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#mahOzaDI pfTak#}), of the five kinds of extracts severally, or
<div n="lb">infusions only of two articles of the Pañchāmṛta (viz.
<div n="lb">honey, butter and milk excepted); again some name an
<div n="lb">ointment made of turmeric only, some one prepared of
<div n="lb">sesamum-oil and turmeric, and others add an aromatic
<div n="lb">powder and one made of five kinds of grain. In the ritual
<div n="lb">works founded on the {%Kālī-%} and {%Devī-Purāṇas%} there are men-
<div n="lb">tioned, besides, infusions of (pounded) corals, emeralds, ru-
<div n="lb">bies, pearls, lapis lazuli, several varieties of lotusses ({#padma,#}
<div n="lb">{#kahlAra, kumuda#}), of sugar-cane, lac ({#alaktaka#}), red sandal,
<div n="lb">turmeric, flour, rice and white mustard, as well as pool-
<div n="lb">water and water from various places of pilgrimage; earth
<div n="lb">from five such places; oil made of the Viṣṇu plant, an
<div n="lb">ointment made of emblic myrobalan together with sesamum-
<div n="lb">oil and turmeric.--The ritual works founded on the
<div n="lb">{%Purāṇas%} mention moreover eight melodies which are se-
<div n="lb">verally played when the idol is washed with the eight kinds
<div n="lb">of water in the eight jars (see above col. {%a,%} line 43), as
<div n="lb">well as the instruments with which they are played. At
<div n="lb">the washing with the atmospheric water the melody is (acc.
<div n="lb">to the ritual of the {%Vṛhannandikeśvara-Pur.%}) {%Mālasī,%} played
<div n="lb">with the instrument {%Mangalotsava,%} or (acc. to the ritual of
<div n="lb">the {%Devī-Pur.%}) {%Vārāḍī,%} played with the instrument {%Indra-%}
<div n="lb">{%vijaya,%} or (acc. to the ritual of the {%Kālī-Pur.%}) {%Mālava,%}
<div n="lb">played with the instrument {%Vijaya;%} at the washing with
<div n="lb">the cloud-water, the m. is {%Devakīrī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Bhu-%}
<div n="lb">{%vanavijaya (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Mālavagauḍa,%} p. w. the instr.
<div n="lb">{%Mangalavijaya (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Lalitā,%} played with the large
<div n="lb">kettle drum {%Dundubhī (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the
<div n="lb">water of the Sarasvatī, the m. is {%Vārāḍī,%} p. w. the instr.
<div n="lb">{%Vijaya (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Mālava,%} p. w. the instr. {%Devotsava%}
<div n="lb">{%(D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vibhāṣā,%} p. w. the drum {%Dundubhi (K.-Pur.);%}
<div n="lb">at the washing with the sea-water, the m. is {%Deśāla,%} p. w.
<div n="lb">the instr. {%Rājābhiṣeka (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Deśāla,%} p. w. the
<div n="lb">instr. {%Ghanatāla (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Bhairavī,%} p. w. the flute
<div n="lb">{%Vanśī (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the lotus pollen-water,
<div n="lb">the m. is {%Dhānuṣī,%} p. the instr. {%Madhurī (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or
<div n="lb">{%Mālavī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Madhukara (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Koḍā,%}
<div n="lb">p. w. the instr. {%Indrābhiṣeka (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing
<div n="lb">with the cascade-water, the m. is {%Bhairavī,%} p. w. the cymbal
<div n="lb">{%Karatāla (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Bhairavī;%} p. w. the double drum
[Page287-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%Ḍhakkā (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vārāḍī,%} p. w. the conch {%Śaṅkha%}
<div n="lb">{%(K.-P.);%} at the washing with the Tīrtha-water, the m. is
<div n="lb">{%Gujjarī,%} p. w. the flute {%Vanśī (Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Vasanta,%}
<div n="lb">p. w. the conch {%Śaṅkha (D.-Pur.),%} or {%Vasanta,%} p. w. the
<div n="lb">instr. {%Pañchaśabda (K.-Pur.);%} at the washing with the pure
<div n="lb">water the melody is {%Vasanta,%} p. w. the instr. {%Pañchaśabda%}
<div n="lb">{%(Vṛh.-Pur.),%} or {%Koḍā,%} p. w. the drum {%Mṛdaṅga (D.-Pur.),%}
<div n="lb">or {%Dhānuṣī,%} p. w. the instr. {%Vijaya (K.-Pur.).%} See {%Rādhāk.%}
<div n="lb">s. v. {#aBizeka#}.--At the installation of a domestic idol
<div n="lb">({#devapratizWA#}) the following articles are recommended for
<div n="lb">the ablution by the {%Devapratiṣṭhatattva%} (as quoted by
<div n="lb">{%Rādhāk.%}): river-, torrent-, sea-, cascade- and cloud-water,
<div n="lb">a mixture of milk, curds, sugar, clarified butter and honey,
<div n="lb">{%Panchagavya%} mixed with an infusion of Kuśa-grass; earth
<div n="lb">stirred up by the hoofs of a horse and the teeth of an ele-
<div n="lb">phant, earth from a mountain, from Kuśa-grass and an
<div n="lb">ant-hill, sesamum-oil, clarified butter, an infusion of five
<div n="lb">extracts ({#paYcakazAyodakam#}), flowers of the mango-tree, of
<div n="lb">the {%Champaka%} (Michelia champaca), of the Acacia suma,
<div n="lb">lotusses and Oleander; leaves of holy basil, jasmin and
<div n="lb">{%Śṛphala%} (Ægle marmelos.), a cleansing powder prepared
<div n="lb">either of the refuse of Sesamum ({#tilakalka#}), or of rice
<div n="lb">({#SAlitaRqula#}), or of {%Vilwa%} (Ægle marmelos.) -leaves, or of
<div n="lb">emblic myrobalan ({#Amalaka#}); hot water, water from places
<div n="lb">of pilgrimage. To prepare the liquid either a hundred and
<div n="lb">eight, or fifty four, or twenty jars are required, or one
<div n="lb">jar may suffice; the water is taken in the proportion of
<div n="lb">a hundred and eight Pala-weight--such is the vaidik (!)
<div n="lb">quantity--or, commonly, in the proportion of three
<div n="lb">hundred and sixty Tola-weight, and the substances named
<div n="lb">are mixed and shaken with it in each jar separately.--
<div n="lb">If a person, however, cannot afford to provide all these
<div n="lb">articles, he may take merely earth from an ant-hill, new
<div n="lb">cowdung, dry cowdung, some water mixed with ashes and
<div n="lb">scented water. (Comp. {%Rādhāk., Śabdak.%} s. v.).--E. {#sic#}
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. Comp. also {#aBizecanIya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6446<pc>287-a<k1>aBizekaBUmi<k2>aBizekaBUmi
{#aBizekaBUmi#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-miH#}) (In Buddhistic doctrine.)
<div n="lb">(Perhaps.) The place of ablution or purification, one of
<div n="lb">the 108 {#DarmAlokamuKa#} q. v.; {%Lalitav.:%} {#aBizekaBUmiDarmAlo-#}
<div n="lb">{#kamuKamavakramaRajanmABinizkramaRaduzkaracaryAboDimaRqalopasaMkra-#}
<div n="lb">{#maRamAraDvaMsanaboDiviboDanaDarmacakrapravartanamahAparinirvARasaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#darSanatAyE saMvartate#}. E. {#aBizeka#} and {#BUsi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6447<pc>287-a<k1>aBizektf<k2>aBizektf

<div n="lb">crates by means of the rite {#aBizeka#} q. v.; e. g. {%Śatapath.:%}
<div n="lb">{#kzatriyo vAva kzatriyasyABizektA;#} or {%Aitar. Br.:%} {#so'Bizi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kto'Bizektre brAhmaRAya hiraRyaM dadyAtsahasram#}. E. {#sic#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#tfc#}.
<LEND>

<L>6450<pc>287-a<k1>aBizecana<k2>aBizecana
{#aBizecana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The same as {#aBizeka#} q. v.;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%(bathing for religious purposes), Kaṇāda Sūtr.:%} {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zecanopavAsabrahmacaryagurukulavAsavAnaprasTayajYadAnaprokzaRA diNna-#}
[Page287-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#kzatrakAlaniyamAScAdfzwAya#} ({%Upaskāra:%} {#aBizecanaM snAnaM gaNgA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAm#}); or {%(inauguration, consecration) Mahābh. Sāntip.:%}
<div n="lb">{#rAzwrasyEtatkftyatamaM rAjYa evABizecanam;#} or {%Harivanśa:%} {#na cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DikAro devAnAM rAjendrasyABizecane;#} or {%Rāmāy.:%} {#rAjamArgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kftaH SrImAnpOrE rAmABizecane#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>6451<pc>287-b<k1>aBizecanIya<k2>aBizecanIya
{#aBizecanIya#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) To be bathed
<div n="lb">or consecrated, worthy of being bathed or consecrated (see
<div n="lb">{#aBizeka#}); e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#ye vA etasyodfcaM gamizyanti rAzwraM#}
<div n="lb">{#te Bavizyanti rAjAno BavizyantyaBizecanIyAH…viSo#}
<div n="lb">{#'naBizecanIyAH#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar#}.
<div n="P">II. 1. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) Fit for, or serving for,
<div n="lb">the ceremony of consecration (see {#aBizecana#} and {#aBizeka#});
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#aBizecanIyAni pAtrARi Bavanti yatrEtA#}
<div n="lb">{#Apo'BizecanIyA Bavanti#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-yaH#}) The name of a Soma sacrifice: the second
<div n="lb">of the seven Soma sacrifices which form part of the {%Rāja-%}
<div n="lb">{%sūya%} (q. v.; and see {#pavitra#} or {#aByArohaRIya, daSapeya, keSava-#}
<div n="lb">{#panIya, vyuzwidvirAtra#} consisting of two sacrifices, and {#kzatra-#}
<div n="lb">{#DftiH;#} {%Sāyaṇa%} in conformity with {%Kātyāyana:%} {#tatra#}--i. e.
<div n="lb">in the {%Rājasūya%}--{#pavitrABizecanIyadaSapeyakeSavapanIyavyuzwi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvirAtrakzatraDftisaMjYakAH sapta somayAgAH;#} the {%Vyākhyā%} of the
<div n="lb">{%Maśaka Sūtr.:%} {#rAjA rAjasUyena yajeta tasya sapta sutyA aByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rohaRIyaH . aBizecanIyaH . daSapeyaH . keSavapanIyaH . vyuzwi-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvirAtraH . kzatrasya Dftiriti#}). It is performed a year after
<div n="lb">the {#pavitra#} or {#aByArohaRIya#} has taken place ({%Sāyaṇa%} on the
<div n="lb">{%Śatap.:%} {#evaM pavitrAKyAtpraTamasomayAgAdanantaraBAvInyAnuma-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAdInIzwidarvihomAtmakAni saMvatsaraparyantamanuzWeyAni karmARya-#}
<div n="lb">{#nukrAntAni . aTa dvitIyasyABizecanIyAKyasya somayAgasya pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yogo'BiDAsyate;#} the {%Vyākhyā%} on {%Maśaka:%} {#aByArIhaRI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yenezwvA saMvatsarAdUrDvamaBizecanIyena yajeta#}), and commences,
<div n="lb">according to {%Harisvāmin,%} on the first day of the second
<div n="lb">or dark fortnight; acc. to the {%Sāmaveda-school,%} on the first
<div n="lb">day of the first or light fortnight of the month Phālguna
<div n="lb">(February-March); it consists of several ceremonies which
<div n="lb">last five days, the first or {#dIkzA#} occupying one day, the
<div n="lb">{#upasad#} offerings three days and the {#sutyA#} one day. The
<div n="lb">officiating priest who performs the initiatory rites and
<div n="lb">chants the Sāmav.-hymns specified in {%Maśaka'%}s {%Kalpasūtras,%}
<div n="lb">must be a Brāhmaṇa of the family of {%Bhṛgu.%} The principal
<div n="lb">ceremonies of this sacrifice (in which seem to have originated
<div n="lb">those of the {#aBizeka#} q. v.) are the following: after the
<div n="lb">initiatory rites have been performed and the {%Adhwaryu%}
<div n="lb">priest has summoned the king who performs the Rājasūya
<div n="lb">sacrifice, in proclaiming his name, the name of his father
<div n="lb">and mother and that of his kingdom, he takes seventeen
<div n="lb">kinds of liquid with vessels made of {%Udumbara%} (Ficus glo-
<div n="lb">merata) wood, viz. he takes 1. water of the river Sarasvatī,
<div n="lb">which he places in a well screened place; 2. having pro-
<div n="lb">vided himself with as much clarified butter as is sufficient
<div n="lb">for a full libation and gone into a pond, and having sent
<div n="lb">there a man or a beast, he pours into the first wave which
<div n="lb">is roused by either of them in an eastern direction, the
<div n="lb">clarified butter and then takes the water of that wave; 3. he
<div n="lb">repeats the same process with the second wave which is
<div n="lb">roused in a western direction; 4. he then takes river-water
[Page288-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">in the direction with the stream and 5. against the stream,
<div n="lb">6. river-water which has broke out and formed a separate
<div n="lb">stream, 7. sea-water, 8. water from a whirlpool, 9. water from
<div n="lb">a deep lake, 10. water proceding from rain during sunshine,
<div n="lb">before it has fallen down, 11. water from small tanks, 12. well-
<div n="lb">water, 13. ice- or dew-water; ({%Śrīdeva%} observes that it must
<div n="lb">be collected in places where there is much dry grass,
<div n="lb">by throwing a clean garment over it and afterwards by
<div n="lb">wringing it out in a cup); 14. honey, 15. water proceeding
<div n="lb">from the membranes investing the fœtus of a cow which
<div n="lb">has calved, 16. milk, 17. clarified butter; ({%Śrīdeva%} observes
<div n="lb">that the water of the Sarasvatī and all water which is not
<div n="lb">at hand as well as the water which can only be had con-
<div n="lb">ditionally, e. g. that of 10. 13 15., must be first procured and
<div n="lb">then the other kinds). He then catches, at it were, sun beams
<div n="lb">with the hollow of his hand and joins them with each of the
<div n="lb">seventeen liquids while repeating severally the hymns he
<div n="lb">has recited before, when collecting each water. Then, he
<div n="lb">pours these liquids into one vase made of {%Udumbara-%}
<div n="lb">wood, arranges four vases made severally of {%Palāśa%}-(Butea
<div n="lb">frondosa), {%Udumbara-,%} the pendant branch of the {%Ficus%}
<div n="lb">{%Indica-,%} and {%Aśvattha-%} (Ficus religiosa) wood, spreads
<div n="lb">out before them a tiger-skin and distributes the water col-
<div n="lb">lected in the one vase, into the four sacrificial vases. Next
<div n="lb">follows the toilet of the king who takes off the garments
<div n="lb">he wore at the preparation for the sacrifice, and now is
<div n="lb">clad by the Adhwaryu in a silk under garment and over
<div n="lb">it in a red and white cloak; on his head the priest places
<div n="lb">the royal turban ({%uṣṇīṣa%}), fastening both its ends to his
<div n="lb">waist; and in his hands the bow, which he strings, and
<div n="lb">three arrows. Then he throws copper into the face of a
<div n="lb">long-haired eunuch who sits in the midst of the assembly and
<div n="lb">represents the various kinds of death. These rites having been
<div n="lb">performed, the Adhwaryu invites the king to step on the
<div n="lb">tiger-skin, placing under his feet a golden circle and another
<div n="lb">golden circle perforated with nine or a hundred holes on his
<div n="lb">head; then he lifts up the arms of the king, and while the
<div n="lb">latter is thus standing with his face towards the east, either he
<div n="lb">or the royal family priest drops the contents of the Palāśa
<div n="lb">vase over him; then the king's brother drops over him the
<div n="lb">water contained in the Udumbara vase; then a Kshatriya
<div n="lb">friend the water in the third vase, and lastly a Vaiśya
<div n="lb">the water in the Aśvattha vase. The Hotṛ then having
<div n="lb">recited the legend of Śunaḥśepa, the king gives to the
<div n="lb">Adhwaryu and to him severally a hundred or a thousand
<div n="lb">cows as well as gold, food and cloth; he then rubs the
<div n="lb">consecrated water which remains on his body, over himself
<div n="lb">with a black-horn-brush, makes three steps on the tiger-
<div n="lb">skin at the hand of the Adhwaryu, and having poured the
<div n="lb">remainder of the consecrated liquid into the Palāśa vase
<div n="lb">hands it to his favourite son. After a libation of clarified
<div n="lb">butter the Adhwaryu then proclaims the name of the king
<div n="lb">coupling with it, however, this time the name of the son
<div n="lb">(by saying e. g. ‘here is Daśaratha, the father of Rāma’).
<div n="lb">The subsequent ceremonies refer to the preparation of a
<div n="lb">carriage, the putting to it of a team of horses &c., the
[Page288-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">giving of cows to the king's brother, the king's mounting
<div n="lb">the car, tying on his feet a pair of shoes made of boar's
<div n="lb">skin, giving to his bow-bearer the bow with the three ar-
<div n="lb">rows and after various other rites, playing a game of shells,
<div n="lb">five shells having been handed to him by the Adhwaryu,
<div n="lb">with his brother, his charioteer ({%sūta%}) or his architect ({%stha-%}
<div n="lb">{%pati%}) and his military chief, the shells being either made
<div n="lb">of gold, or the fruits of Beleric myrobalan serving as such
<div n="lb">({%Sāyaṇa%} on the {%Śatap.:%} {#akzA nAma kapardakAH suvarRanirmitAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#viBItakaPalAni sOvarRA vetyeke#}) and the game representing
<div n="lb">the victory of the Kali age over the other ages; the cere-
<div n="lb">mony closes with libations in the fire. (The Mīmānsists
<div n="lb">do not consider the recital of the legend of Śunaḥśepa and
<div n="lb">the game of shells as special parts of the Abhiṣechanīya,
<div n="lb">but as rites belonging in general to the whole Rājasūya
<div n="lb">sacrifice. For the full detail of the ceremony and the
<div n="lb">hymns to be recited at the various rites see {%Śatapathabr.%}
<div n="lb">V. 3. 3. 1.--4. 4. 25. and {%Kātyāyana'%}s {%Śrautas.%} book 15,
<div n="lb">4-7.). E. {#aBizecana,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} (II. 2. scil. {#somayAga#});
<div n="lb">({%Mādhava,%} however, who uses also the term {#aBizecya#} as
<div n="lb">the name of the ceremony, seems to consider the word as
<div n="lb">a Tatpur. like {#aBizecanIya#} I.).
<LEND>

<L>6452<pc>288-b<k1>aBizecya<k2>aBizecya
{#aBizecya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-cyaH-cyA-cyam#}) <sup>1</sup> To be bathed.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> To be consecrated, to be inaugurated (see {#aBizeka#}); e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#tatra tvamaBizecyaSca manastvarayatIva mAm . SvastvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#hamaBizektAsmi yOvarAjye paraMtapa#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-cyaH#}) The same as {#aBizecanIya#} II. 2.; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mādhava'%}s {%Jaim. nyāyam.:%} {#rAjasUyakaTaMBAvAnuvftteH sarvaSeza-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA . kalpyAkANkzABizecyasya prakriyA prabalA tataH;#} or {#ekasyE-#}
<div n="lb">{#vABizecyasya tadaNgaM niKilasya vA . rAjasUyasyApakarzAdAdyaH#}
<div n="lb">{#prakriyayottaraH;#} or {#aBizecyaprAkftANgasamAptO devanAdayaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#maDye vA pUrvavatsarvasamAptO devanAdayaH;#} the word being ex-
<div n="lb">plained by Mādhava in these instances as synonymous with
<div n="lb">the Soma sacrifice {#‘aziBecanIya’#}. E. {#sic#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛtya aff. {#yat#}.
<LEND>

<L>6456<pc>288-b<k1>aBizeRi<k2>aBizeRi

<div n="lb">if reduplication takes place; e. g. desider. {#aBizizeRayizati,#}

<div n="lb">{#avyutpannaH senASabdaH . aTavA sahenena senA . sahasya saH saMjYA-#}

<div n="lb">no inflected verb of a base {#aBizeRi#}).

<L>6460<pc>289-a<k1>aBizwi<k2>aBizwi
{#aBizwi#}¦ Tatpur. (ved.) I. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Approaching, moving
<div n="lb">towards, access; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBImavanvantsvaBizwimUtayo'nta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rikzaprAM tavizIBirAvftam . indram#} &c. ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#SoBanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByezaRavantaM SoBanABigamanamityarTaH#} i. e. with graceful motion);
<div n="lb">or {#sa vetasuM daSamAyaM daSoRiM tUtujimindraH svaBizwisumnaH#} &c.
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#suzwvaByezaRIyAnyaBigamyAni sumnAni suKAni yena de-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAni#} i. e. who bestows happiness that is easy of access);
<div n="lb">comp. also {#aBizwidyumna;#} or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#vanemA te aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwiBiH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#mArgEH,#} but comp. II. 1.). <sup>2</sup> Approaching
<div n="lb">in order to assist, assistance, help, protection; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#(indra) pAhi no dUrAdArAdaBizwiBiH sadA pAhyaBizwiBiH#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#aByAgamanEH#} or {#aBita ezaREH#}); or {#yABiH kaRvama-#}
<div n="lb">{#BizwiBiH prAvataM yuvamaSvinA . tABiH#} &c. ({%Sāy.:%} = {#apekzi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tABI rakzABiH#}). <sup>3</sup> The object to be approached or aimed
<div n="lb">at, wish, desire; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#UtIryuvoraha citra aBIke#}
<div n="lb">{#aBavannaBizwayaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#sarvEH prARiBiraByezaRIyA aBavan#});
<div n="lb">or {#SatenA no aBizwiBirniyutvAM~ indrasAraTiH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBita#}
<div n="lb">{#ezaRIyEH kAmEH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra sadyaScittamaBizwaye karo#}
<div n="lb">{#vaSaSca vAjinam#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBimataprAptaye,#} but see also II. 1.);
<div n="lb">or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#yo nUnaM mitrAvaruRAvaBizwaya Acakre#} ({%Mahīdh.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#aBimatalABAya#}); or {#devaM devaM vo'vase devaM devamaBizwaye#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBilazitaprAptyarTam;#} {%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBilazitaPalAptaye,#}
<div n="lb">the sense of ‘attainment’ in the latter instances being rather
<div n="lb">implied by the fourth case than by the base of the word);
<div n="lb">or {#SaM no devIraBizwaya ApaH#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBIzwAya;#} but
<div n="lb">comp. II. 1.); comp. also {#aBizwikft#}.
<div n="P">2. m. f. ({#-zwiH#}) <sup>1</sup> One who goes towards; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#A yaM pfRanti divi sadmabarhizaH samudraM na suBvaH svA aBizwayaH#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#ABimuKyena gamanavatyaH#}). <sup>2</sup> One who approaches with
<div n="lb">a hostile purpose, attacking, conquering; an enemy; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv., Sāmav., Vājas.:%} {#(indra) mahAM~ aBizwirojasA#} ({%Sāy.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#aBigantA#} i. e. {#SatrURAmaBiBavitA,#} but see also II. 2.); or
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra svarzA janayannahAni jigAyoSigBiH pftanA aBizwiH#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBigantA#} i. e. {#aBiBAvukaH san#}); comp. also {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwipA#}. <sup>3</sup> One who approaches for the sake of a desire, desirous
<div n="lb">of; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#Urjo napAdaBizwaye#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBIcCate mahyamannaM#}
<div n="lb">{#prayacCeti SezaH#}). E. According to {%Sāyaṇa,%} {#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#ktin,#} when {#aBizwi#} would stand in the room of {#aBIzwi,#}
<div n="lb">analogously to {#SakanDu, halIzA#} &c. for {#SakAnDu, halezA#} &c.;
<div n="lb">a more plausible E., however, seems to be {#sTA#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt or uṇ. aff. {#ki,#} when {#aBizwi#} would stand instead of
[Page289-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#aBizWi,#} analogously to {#suzwu, duzwu, pulasti#} (explained by
<div n="lb">{%Mahīdh.%} to {%Vāj.%} 16. 43.: {#paro'gre tizWati pulastiH . yasya tatvaM#}
<div n="lb">{#CAndasaM rasya latvaM ca#}) &c.; an E. {#as#} ‘to be’ with {#aBi#}.
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#ktin,#} which is countenanced, too, by another
<div n="lb">explanation offered by {%Mahīdhara%} on {#pulasti,#} might apply to
<div n="lb">the meaning ‘attacking, conquering’, but would be scarcely
<div n="lb">reconcilable with the meanings implying {%‘approach’%} and
<div n="lb">{%‘assistance’.%}
<div n="P">II. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) Sacrificing towards, in presence of or
<div n="lb">completely, a complete sacrifice; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#indra sadyaScitta-#}
<div n="lb">{#maBizwaye#} &c. (see above 1. 1. 3.; the word being explained by
<div n="lb">{%Sāy.%} also {#ABimuKyena yAgAya#}); or {#vanemA te aBizwiBiH#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#havirBiH;#} comp. also I. 1. 1. and III. 1.); or {#SaM no#}
<div n="lb">{#devIraBizwaya ApaH#} (see above 1. 1. 3.; {%Sāy.:%} = {#yajYAya#}); or
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#dEvIM DiyaM manAmahe sumfqIkamaBizwaye#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#aBi#}
<div n="lb">{#samantAdyajanamaBizwiH…aBimuKatvena prAptasya yajYasya si-#}
<div n="lb">{#dDyarTam#}); comp. also {#aBizwikft#}.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwiH#}) One to be worshipped by a sacrifice; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#mahAM~ aBizwirojasA#} (see above I. 2. 2.; {%Sāy.%} in the cor-
<div n="lb">responding {%Sāmaveda-%} verse: = {#ABimuKyena yazwavyaH,#} besides
<div n="lb">{#aByezaRaSIlo vA SatrURAm#}); or {%Vājas.:%} {#Iqito devErhari-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAM~ 2 .. aBizwirAjuhvAno havizA SarDamAnaH#} (where the word
<div n="lb">has the same sense and need not be explained as a Bahuvr., as
<div n="lb">{%Mahīdh.%} does: {#aBi samantAdizwiryAgo yasya;#} comp. also III. 2.).
<div n="lb">E. {#yaj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ktin;#} comp. the remark under E. I.
<div n="P">III. 1. f. ({#-zwiH#}) Praise, an encomiastic hymn; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#vanemA te aBizwiBiH#} (see 1. 1. 1. and II. 1.; {%Sāyaṇa%}
<div n="lb">giving besides the quoted explanation also the sense {#stotrEH#}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwiH#}) One who is praised; e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#Iqito#}
<div n="lb">{#devErhariSAM~ 2 .. aBizwiH#} (see II. 2.; {%Mahīdh.%} giving besides
<div n="lb">the quoted explanation also the following: {#aBizwUyata itya-#}
<div n="lb">{#BizwiH#}). E. {#stu#} with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#qi#} ({%accord. to Mahī-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhara%}). [The meanings s. II. and III. and the correspond-
<div n="lb">ing EE. do not appear required by the context in the pas-
<div n="lb">sages where the word occurs; and the commentators them-
<div n="lb">selves either disagree or give the option of the meanings
<div n="lb">s. I. The {%Ṛgv. Prātisākhya%} observes that if {#aBizwi#} pre-
<div n="lb">cedes as first part of a compound another word beginning
<div n="lb">with a {#s,#} this {#s#} does not become {#z;#} e. g. {#svaBizwisumna,#}
<div n="lb">not {#svaBizwizumRa#}.]

<L>6470<pc>290-a<k1>aBizyanda<k2>aBizyanda
{#aBizyanda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ndaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Oozing, flowing. <sup>2</sup> Great increase,
<div n="lb">excess; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#(maTurA) svargABizyandavamanaM kftvevopa-#}
<div n="lb">{#niveSitA#} ‘founded as it were by throwing off the excess
<div n="lb">of population in the paradise’. <sup>3</sup> (In Medicine.) {%Ophthalmīa%}
<div n="lb">which, if neglected, produces the severe kind called {%Adhi-%}
<div n="lb">{%mantha;%} it may be produced, according to {%Suśruta,%} by de-
<div n="lb">rangement in the air, bile, phlegm or blood; if the disease
<div n="lb">is produced by derangement in the air, the patient ‘has a
<div n="lb">sensation of throbbing, rigidity, horripilation, of sand in
<div n="lb">the eye and harshness, he suffers from headache, dryness
<div n="lb">and his tears are cold’ (comp. {#vAtABizyanda#}); if by de-
<div n="lb">rangement in the bile, ‘he suffers from burning pains, discharge
<div n="lb">of pus, has a liking for cold applications, a sensation of
<div n="lb">smoke in the eye, his tears are warm and his eye is yel-
<div n="lb">low’ (see {#pittABizyanda#}); if by derangement in the phlegm,
<div n="lb">‘he likes hot applications, the eye feels heavy, is swollen,
<div n="lb">itches, is greasy, white, very cold and has a thick discharge’
<div n="lb">(see {#kaPABizyanda#}); if by derangement in the blood, ‘his tears
<div n="lb">are copper coloured, the eye is red and its small vessels very
<div n="lb">red; moreover the symptoms of bile are present’ (see {#raktA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bizyand#}). Comp. {#aBisyanda#}. E. {#syand#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6471<pc>290-a<k1>aBizyandin<k2>aBizyandin
{#aBizyandin#}¦ (In Medicine.) I. Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ndI-ndinI#}
<div n="lb">{#-ndi#}) 1. Oozing, trickling, fluid; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#daDi tu#}
<div n="lb">{#maDuramamlamatyamlamiti…. mahABizyandi maDuraM kaPamedo-#}
<div n="lb">{#vivarjanam…. rase pAke ca maDuramatyaBizyandi dozalam#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#syand#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<div n="P">2. Causing defluxions or serous effusion ({#yadeva dravyaM SarI-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAByantare kledaM janayati…. aBizyandidravyARi daDimatsyadu-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwodakapraBftIni#}); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#vidAhiguruvizwamBirukzABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zyandiBojanEH…. hikkA SvAsaSca nfRAM samupajAyate;#} or
<div n="lb">{#divA svapnamaBizyandi guru cAnnaM vivarjayet#}. Comp. {#aBisya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ndin#}. E. {#syand,#} in the caus. with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
[Page290-b+ 56]
<div n="P">II. m. f. n. ({#-ndI-ndinI-ndi#}) Affected with ophthalmia
<div n="lb">(see {#aBizyanda#}) ({%Wilson%}). E. {#aBizyanda,#} taddh. aff. {#ini#}.
<LEND>

<L>6472<pc>290-b<k1>aBizyandiramaRa<k2>aBizyandiramaRa

<L>6473<pc>290-b<k1>aBizvaNga<k2>aBizvaNga
{#aBizvaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) Strong attachment, love, devotion
<div n="lb">(‘the feeling happy or unhappy according to whether an-
<div n="lb">other is happy or unhappy, the wishing to live or to die,
<div n="lb">according to whether another lives or dies’); a stronger
<div n="lb">term therefore than {#sakti#} which merely implies the pleasur-
<div n="lb">able feeling derived from the connexion with an object, e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Bhagavadg.:%} {#asaktiranaBizvaNgaH putradAragfhAdizu…eta-#}
<div n="lb">{#jjYAnamiti proktam…#} ‘not deriving pleasure from the
<div n="lb">connexion with any object, absence of love for son, wife,
<div n="lb">house &c…that is called wisdom’ ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#asaktiH .#}
<div n="lb">{#saktiH saNganimittezu vizayezu prItimAtraM tadaBAvo'saktiH .#}
<div n="lb">{#anaBizvaNgo'BizvaNgABAvo'BizvaNgo nAma saktiviSeza evA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyAtmaBAvanAlakzaRo yaTAnyasminsuKini duHKini vAhameva suKI#}
<div n="lb">{#duHKI ca . jIvati mfte vAhameva jIvAmi marizyAmi ceti;#}
<div n="lb">{%Sadānanda:%} {#saktirmamedamityeva prItimAtramudIritA . aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zvaNgastu putrAdO tAdAtmyADyAsalakzaRaH anyasminputraBAryAdO#}
<div n="lb">{#suKaduHKAnvite sati . ahameva suKI duHKItyAdirUpo durA-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaH . varjyO tO saktyaBizvaNgO putradAragfhAdizu#}). Compare
<div n="lb">{#aBizaNga#}. E. {#svaYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6479<pc>290-b<k1>aBisaMskAra<k2>aBisaMskAra

<L>6496<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDA<k2>aBisanDA

<L>6497<pc>291-b<k1>aBisanDAna<k2>aBisanDAna
{#aBisanDAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Speaking, saying, declaring
<div n="lb">(with the implied sense of {%deliberateness%}); e. g. {%Kṛṣnatark.%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Dāyabh.:%} {#SAstrIyadAnapadasya svatvABisaMDAnapUrvakatyAge#}
<div n="lb">{#lakzaRA;#} comp. also the inst. s. v. {#aBisanDi#}. <sup>2</sup> Promise,
<div n="lb">agreement; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#sA hi satyABisaMDAnA taTAnanyA#}
<div n="lb">{#ca Bartari#}. <sup>3</sup> Aim, intention, purpose, interest in an object;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#jEhyaM kOwilyam . anyABisaMDAnenAnyavAditva-#}
<div n="lb">{#manyakartftvaM ca;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Pravach.:%} {#svaBAvAccezwitamanaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMDAnAdBftyavat#} ({%Vijnānabh.:%} {#yaTA prakfzwaBftyasya svaBAvAtsaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#skArAdeva pratiniyatAvaSyakI ca svAmisevA pravartate na tu sva-#}
<div n="lb">{#BogABiprAyeRa taTEva prakfteScezwitaM saMskArAdevetyarTaH#}). <sup>4</sup> Im-
<div n="lb">posing, cheating, deceiving; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#parABisaMDAnaparaM#}
[Page292-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#yadyapyasya vicezwitam#} &c. (comm.: {#yadyapi SatruvaYcanapraDAnaM#} &c.).
<div n="lb"><sup>5</sup> Making peace or alliance ({%Wilson%}). E. {#DA#} with {#sam#} and
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6498<pc>292-a<k1>aBisanDi<k2>aBisanDi
{#aBisanDi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-nDiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Speaking, saying, declaring
<div n="lb">(with the implied sense of {%deliberateness%}); e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} (on
<div n="lb">the passage of the {%Chh. Up.%} quoted s. v. {#aBisanDA#}) {#…sa#}
<div n="lb">{#dahyate'Ta hanyate rAjapuruzEH svakftenAnftABisaMDidozeRa….#}
<div n="lb">{#yadAtmABisanDyanaBisaMDikfte mokzabanDane#} (liberation or bondage
<div n="lb">caused by a--righteous--or by a false declaration)
<div n="lb">{#…tatsatyaM sa AtmA#} &c.; or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#aBivalamaBisaMDi-#}
<div n="lb">{#SCalena yaH#}. <sup>2</sup> Intent, purpose, aim, interest in an object;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Śaṅkara%} (on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#adfzwAniyamAt#}): {#…aha-#}
<div n="lb">{#midaM PalaM prApnavAnIdaM pariharARi . itTaM prayate . itTaM karavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#RItyevaMviDA aBisaMDyAdayaH pratyAtmaM pravartamAnA adfzwasyAtmanAM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca svasvAmiBAvaM niyaMsyantIti . netyAha ..#} ({%Sūtra:%}) {#aBisaM-#}
<div n="lb">{#DyAdizvapi cEvam;#} or {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#na ca kArye pratipattyaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMnDiH#} ({%Anūpanar. Śirom.:%} {#prajApateH saBAM veSma prapadye . iti#}
<div n="lb">{#pratipattyaBisaMDiH prAptisaMkalpaH#}); or {%Gautama:%} {#aBisaMDimA-#}
<div n="lb">{#trAtputriketyekezAm#} ‘some say that a {#putrikA#} (q. v.) may be
<div n="lb">appointed merely by intention’ (another category being the
<div n="lb">{#putrikA#} appointed by an express declaration; comp. {%Kul-%}
<div n="lb">{%lūka:%} {#aBisaMDimAtrakftA . vAgvyavahAreRa na kftA#}); or {%Śāntip.%}
<div n="lb">{%Mahābh.:%} {#yaH karotyanaBisaMDipUrvakaM#} (unintentional) {#tacca nirRu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dati yatpurA kftam . nApriyaM taduBayaM kutaH priyaM tasya tajjana-#}
<div n="lb">{#yatIha kurvataH;#} or {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#nanu kAmakfte prAyaScittABAvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tkaTaM vyavahAryatvaM tadaBAvaScAnaBisaDikfte'parADe prAyaScitta-#}
<div n="lb">{#miti vasizWavacanAt#}. Comp. also the inst. s. v. {#aBisaMhita#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Implied sense, bearing (of a sentence &c.); used thus
<div n="lb">frequently by commentators, e. g. {%Mītākṣ.%} (on {%Yājnav.%} 2.
<div n="lb">27. or 61. or 96.) or the {%Dattakamīm.%} (p. 17. 27. 29. on pas-
<div n="lb">sages in law-books): {#ayamaBisanDiH#} ‘such is the sense of
<div n="lb">the passage’. <sup>4</sup> Belief, opinion (with the implied sense of
<div n="lb">{%erroneousness%}); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#dadaMSa tAmrAmburuhABisaMDistf-#}
<div n="lb">{#zRAturaH pARitale'pi DfzRuH#} ‘the impudent bee parched
<div n="lb">with thirst bit her in the palm of her hand, believing it to
<div n="lb">be a red lotus’ ({%Jayam.:%} {#raktapadmametadityaBisaMDiraBiprAyo#}
<div n="lb">{#yasya BfNgasya sa#}). [<sup>5</sup> Joint junction. <sup>6</sup> Making peace or
<div n="lb">alliance. <sup>7</sup> Cheating, deceiving ({%Wilson%}).] E. {#DA#} with {#sam#}
<div n="lb">and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ki#}.
<LEND>

<L>6518<pc>293-a<k1>aBisAra<k2>aBisAra
{#aBisAra#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> An assignation, a lover's
<div n="lb">appointment; e. g. {%Gītagov.:%} {#ratasuKasAre gatamaBisAre mada-#}
<div n="lb">{#namanoharaveSam . na kuru nitambini gamanavilambamanusara taM#}
<div n="lb">{#hfdayeSam;#} or in the following verse (which exemplifies an
<div n="lb">alliteration called {#mahAcakra#} or {#kulAlacakra#} q. v.): {#rADA SrutA-#}
<div n="lb">{#livacanA virasABisArA rAsABisArasamaye vivftApakArA .#}
<div n="lb">{#rAkA patAvftaparApyapayAtamArA rAmAtayA paramadurgalitASru-#}
<div n="lb">{#DArA;#} or {%Vivādachint.:%} {#striyaM puruzaM vABisAraM prati saMcAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#yati yaSca tayoraBisArasTAnaM dadAti tO pAradArikavaddaRqyO#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> An army. <sup>3</sup> An attack; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#pravfttistErihAKyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA Svo'BisAraH purasya naH#} ({%Dharaṇik.:%} = {#yudDa;#} battle, war).
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> A follower. <sup>5</sup> A purificatory ceremony; (viz. lustration
<div n="lb">of arms). [In the explanation of the {%Dharaṇik.:%} {#aBisAro#}
<div n="lb">{#bale yudDe sahAye sADane'pi ca,#} the meaning {#bala#} and {#sADana#}
<div n="lb">are clearly founded on the compound words {#sarvABisAra#}
<div n="lb">and {#lohABisAra,#} the former meaning the making a whole
<div n="lb">army ready for attack or battle, and the latter a ceremony
<div n="lb">observed by princes before opening a campaign; the mean-
<div n="lb">ing {#bala#} in the {%Dharaṇik.%} should therefore not be rendered
<div n="lb">‘strength’, not the meaning {#sADana#} ‘instrument’.] <sup>6</sup> A
<div n="lb">fish; (according to the {%Nighaṇtaprakāśa%}).
<div n="P">2. m. pl. ({#-rAH#}) The name of a country, in the south-
<div n="lb">west of Kashmir, the modern {%Hazār;%} usually mentioned
<div n="lb">together with the Dārva (e. g. {%Bhīṣmap. Mahābh.:%} {#dArvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BisArA dAradAH puRqrAScEva sahasraSaH;#} or {%Rājatar.:%} {#SIte#}
<div n="lb">{#dArvABisArAdO zaRmAsAnpArTivo'vasat#}); the {%Abisares%} of
<div n="lb">{%Arrian;%} (comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%Arr. Antiq.%} p. 190; {%Troyer'%}s {%Rājatar.%}
<div n="lb">11. cc. s. v.; {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alterth.%} II. pp. 138. 144. 146. 154 ff.
<div n="lb">235. 467. 669. 887. &c.).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-rI#}) The name of a town; probably the capital
<div n="lb">of the country Abhisāra; {%Sabhāp. Mahābh.:%} {#aBisArIM tato#}
[Page293-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#ramyAM vijigye kurunandanaH#}. E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} the
<div n="lb">fem. in {#I#} is irregular. Comp. also the two following articles.
<LEND>

<L>6519<pc>293-b<k1>aBisArasTAna<k2>aBisArasTAna
{#aBisArasTAna#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) A locality adapted for as-
<div n="lb">signations. [The {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} recommends the following
<div n="lb">eight places for lovers to meet: a field, a garden, temple-
<div n="lb">ruins, the house of a procuress, a forest, a place of
<div n="lb">pilgrimage, a cemetery, the bank of rivers (&c.); but
<div n="lb">thinks that occasionally any dark place will do: {#kzetraM vAwI#}
<div n="lb">{#BagnadevAlayo dUtIgfhaM vanam . mAlayaM ca SmaSAnaM ca nadyAdInAM#}
<div n="lb">{#tawI taTA . evaM kftABisArARAM puMScalInAM vinodane . sTAnA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyazwO taTA DvAntacCannezu kvacidASrayaH#}. The rhetorico-musical
<div n="lb">work {%Saṅgītadāmodara%} improves the enumeration in men-
<div n="lb">tioning: ‘a bower, a grove, a park, a ditch (without water),
<div n="lb">a place where water is distributed, an attic, a hemp-field,
<div n="lb">the bank of a river, a thorny spot, a building ground, a
<div n="lb">house in the neighbourhood of a town, the ruins of a col-
<div n="lb">lege and so on’, these having been the places where the
<div n="lb">cowherdesses made their appointments with Kṛṣṇa: {#ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#kubjakAnanodyAnanirambupariKAprapAH . awwAlikASaRakzetraDunI-#}
<div n="lb">{#roDAH#} (Ms. Paris. B. 155; Ms. E. I. H. 1486: {#awwAlikA#}
<div n="lb">{#gavAkzaSca#}--‘a window’--{#DunIroDaH#}) {#sakaRwakAH . vAwI-#}
<div n="lb">{#parisarAgArapaScAdBagnamaWAdayaH . ete pradeSAH saMketasTAnAni#}
<div n="lb">{#muravidvizaH . yatrA-#} (Ms. E. I. H. {#atrA-#}) {#BisAraM kurvanti devyA#}
<div n="lb">{#vallavavallaBAH#}. Compare e. g. the third story of the {%Vetala-%}
<div n="lb">{%pañchavinśati.%}--Also called {#saMketasTAna#}.] Comp. also the
<div n="lb">following article. E. {#aBisAra#} and {#sTAna#}.
<LEND>

<L>6520<pc>293-b<k1>aBisArikA<k2>aBisArikA
{#aBisArikA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-kA#}) A woman who meets her lover
<div n="lb">by assignation ({%Amarak.:%} {#kAntArTinI tu yA yAti saMketaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sABisArikA;#} {%Hemach.:%} {#yAti yA priyaM sABisArikA;#} {%Śabda-%}
<div n="lb">{%ratnāv.:%} {#kAntamuddiSya saMketaM yAti yA sABisArikA#}); {%Bharata%}
<div n="lb">defines this character which is of frequent occurrence in
<div n="lb">poetry and affords an insight into the amorous customs
<div n="lb">of the ancient Hindus, as ‘a woman who, having lost all
<div n="lb">modesty and fear, under the influence of love or passion
<div n="lb">invites her paramour to come to her (as quoted by {%He-%}
<div n="lb">{%mach.'%}s {%comm.:%} {#hitvA lajjABaye SlizwA madanena madena vA#}--
<div n="lb">by {%Vallabhagaṇi:%} {#madena ca--. aBisArayate#}--{%Vallabh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBisArayedyA--kAntaM sA BavedaBisArikA#}); or as ‘one
<div n="lb">who cannot even wait for the arrival of the messenger she
<div n="lb">has sent out, but suffers unbearable pains of thirst after
<div n="lb">the water of love, desirous as she is to drink the lips of her
<div n="lb">absent friend’ ({%Vetalapanch.:%} {#yA dUtikAgamanakAlamapArayantI#}
<div n="lb">{#sA duHsahasmarajalArtipipAsiteva . niryAtavallaBajanADarapAnalo-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAtsA kaTyate munivarEraBisAriketi#}); similarly the {%Rasi-%}
<div n="lb">{%kasarvaswa%} which defines her as ‘one who having lost all
<div n="lb">modesty, attracted by her lover's youth and by love invites
<div n="lb">him to meet her’ ({#lajjAM hitvA samAkfzwA yOvanena madena ca .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBisArayate kAntaM kIrtitA sABisArikA#}); but if we follow
<div n="lb">other works on Hindu rhetoric, this definition would only
<div n="lb">apply to the second or the last of the three categories of the
<div n="lb">{#aBisArikA,#} as mentioned e. g. by the {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} and the
<div n="lb">{%Saṅgītadāmodara;%} the former of which works, after having
<div n="lb">prefaced the definition that ‘wise men call {%abhisārikā%} a woman
<div n="lb">who under the dominion of love either invites her lover to
<div n="lb">come to her or goes herself to him’ ({#aBisArayate kAntaM yA#}
<div n="lb">{#manmaTavaSaMvadA . svayaM vABisaratyezA DIrEruktABisArikA#}) dis-
[Page294-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">tinguishes between gentle-women who go to meet their lovers,
<div n="lb">courtesans and servant girls; ‘the gentle-woman will make
<div n="lb">herself on such occasions as small as possible, deafen the
<div n="lb">noise of her ornaments and wrap herself up in a veil; the
<div n="lb">courtesan will make a display of gay apparel, her ankle-
<div n="lb">ornaments will merrily tinkle and her face smile with joy;
<div n="lb">if a servant girl goes to meet her lover, her speech will
<div n="lb">stammer with delight, her eyes stare wide open with flurry,
<div n="lb">and her gait will be awkwardly bewildered’ ({%Sāhityad.:%}
<div n="lb">{#saMlInA svezu gAtrezu mUkIkftaviBUzaRA . avaguRWanasaMvItA ku-#}
<div n="lb">{#lajABisaredyadi .. vicitrojjvalaveSA tu valannUpuranisvanA .#}
<div n="lb">{#pramodasmeravadanA syAdveSyABisaredyadi .. madasKalitasaMlApA vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BramotPullalocanA . AvidDagatisaMcArA syAtprezyABisaredyadi ..#}).
<div n="lb">But the rhetorico-musical work {%Saṅgītadāmodara%} is appa-
<div n="lb">rently more in keeping with the general division of amorous
<div n="lb">ladies (see {#nAyikA#}) into such as are their own mis-
<div n="lb">tresses, or such as belong to another (as a married
<div n="lb">woman and a maiden) and such as belong to every body
<div n="lb">(comp. {#svastrI, anyastrI#} and {#sADAraRastrI#}), when it sub-
<div n="lb">stitutes for the servant girl the second category; for its
<div n="lb">story runs thus: ‘the gentle-woman goes to the lover's
<div n="lb">house wrapped up, afraid, bashful, concealing her emotions,
<div n="lb">confused (?), with downcast looks; a married woman will
<div n="lb">go to him her speech somewhat stammering, her eye glaring
<div n="lb">wide open with flurry, her gait awkwardly bewildered,
<div n="lb">with slow steps, and no one will see her; but a courtesan
<div n="lb">walks up to her lover in the company of a friend, full
<div n="lb">of passion, her eyes trembling, fearless, decorated with
<div n="lb">all kind of ornaments, surrounded by people, with tinkling
<div n="lb">anklets: (in short) just as she pleases’. This work tells
<div n="lb">us besides that some of these ladies prefer assignations
<div n="lb">during the light half of a month, i. e. from new to full
<div n="lb">moon,--hence called {#SuklABisArikAH#} or dames of the
<div n="lb">light fortnight--and others during the dark half, when
<div n="lb">the moon is in the wane--hence called {#kfzRABisArikAH#}
<div n="lb">or dames of the dark fortnight; the former wear garlands
<div n="lb">of Arabian jasmine, are anointed all over with Sandal
<div n="lb">preparations and dressed in silk, but do not make their
<div n="lb">appearance by moon-light; the latter are anointed with
<div n="lb">black aloe unguents, are fond of dark colours, and are
<div n="lb">also afraid of the moon-rise; ({#kulajAnyANganA veSyA triDA#}
<div n="lb">{#syAdaBisArikA .. kulajA saMvftA trastA savrIqA tadgfhaM vrajet .#}
<div n="lb">{#saMlInA svezu BAvezu srastA vikzepitAnanA .. mandasKalitasaMlApA#}
<div n="lb">{#viBramotPullalocanA . AvidDagatisaMcArA SanErgamanakAriRI .#}
<div n="lb">{#nAyakaM paranArI tu vrajennAnyena vIkzitA .. saKIyuktA madAvizwA#}
<div n="lb">{#sPAritAkzI tvaSaNkitA . nAnABaraRacitrAQyA taTA parijanAvf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA . sanUpurA yaTAkAmaM veSyA sarati nAyakam .. Suklapakze kfzRapakze#}
<div n="lb">{#dviDA syAdaBisArikA . mallikAmAlyaDAriRyaH sarvANgenArdraca-#}
<div n="lb">{#ndanAH#}--Ms. E. I. H.; Ms. Paris. {#sarvANgInArdracandanAH--.#}
<div n="lb">{#kzOmavatyo na lakzyante jyotsrAyAmaBisArikAH . kAlAguruvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#liptANgI nIlarAgavadaMvadA . candrodayaparitrastA kfzRapakzABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#sArikA#}).--[A specimen of the gentle-woman is doubt-
<div n="lb">less {%Urvaśī%}--in the drama {%Vikramorv.%} act 2, scene 2--,
<div n="lb">when she comes to meet {%Purūravas%} in a purple dress with
<div n="lb">pearl ornaments (cf. {%Wilson's Hindu theatre%} I. p. 230 note:
<div n="lb">{#aBisArikAveSA;#} {%Bollensen:%} {#kftABisaraRaveSA;#} ‘{%Urvaśi:%}
[Page294-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">I feel my strength desert me; bring him quickly--or
<div n="lb">quickly lead me to his royal palace’; or {%Rādhā%} in the
<div n="lb">{%Gītagov.;%} comp. e. g. the words of her friend, ed. {%Lassen%} V. 19:
<div n="lb">{#saBayacakitaM vinyasyantIM dfSO timire paTi . pratitaru muhuH#}
<div n="lb">{#sTitvA mandaM padAni vitanvantIm . kaTamapi rahaH prAptAmaNgera-#}
<div n="lb">{#naNgataraNgiBiH . sumuKi suBagaH paSyansa tvAmupEtu kftArTatAm#});
<div n="lb">a specimen of the married woman may be found in the
<div n="lb">daughter of alderman Samudradatta, in the third story of
<div n="lb">the {%Vetālapañchavinśati.%} Instances of the courtesan are e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mithyādṛṣṭi%} (Heresy) in the drama {%Prabodhach.%} (comp.
<div n="lb">e. g. act 2, scene 9: {#…nIlendIvaradAmadIrGatarayA dfzwyA#}
<div n="lb">{#DayantI mano dolAndolanalolakaNkaRaraRatkArottaraM sarpati#});
<div n="lb">or {%Amaruśat.%} v. 28 and 69. A servant girl who makes love in
<div n="lb">the manner described, is exhibited in the {%Sāhityadarpaṇa:%} her
<div n="lb">betel-stained teeth she always displays; with horselaughter
<div n="lb">she laughs, but no one knows why; from place to place
<div n="lb">she sets, to please, her staggering steps, and dancing high
<div n="lb">her hips, she slily stops before young men’.] The best
<div n="lb">time for {%abhisārikās%} to meet their lovers is, according to
<div n="lb">the {%Saṅgītad.,%} ‘during a dense fog, a winter-night, com-
<div n="lb">plete darkness, at noon of a summer-day, while a whirl-
<div n="lb">wind rages, during an uproar, at moon-rise, during a re-
<div n="lb">volution, when the king is ill, or the town is on fire, during
<div n="lb">a great festival, and in the evening’, for it seems ‘that on
<div n="lb">such occasions the cowkeeper girls as well as the dames of
<div n="lb">the dark as those of the light fortnight had their amatory
<div n="lb">sport with Kṛṣṇa’; (but their meeting at moon-rise is
<div n="lb">apparently at variance with the preceding definition; {#sPA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rikujJawihemantarajanIDvAntasaMcayAH . grIzmamaDyAhgavAtAlI-#}
<div n="lb">{#kolAhalaviDUdayAH . rAzwraBaNganfpAtaNkapuradAhamahotsavAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#pradozASceti kaTitA dvAdaSAnehasaH kramAt#} (Ms. E. I. H.; Ms.
<div n="lb">Paris. {#dvAdaSAnekaSaH kramAt#}) {#. gokulasTAH purEtezu kaMsArA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tiriraMsayA . suveSAstarasA yAnti kfzRaSuklABisArikAH#}).
<div n="lb">The {%Rasamañjarī%} (as quoted by {%Rādhākāntadeva%}) distin-
<div n="lb">guishes in general between {%abhisārikās%} who meet their para-
<div n="lb">mours in day-time, by moon-shine and in the dark (see
<div n="lb">{#divABisArikA, jyotsnABisArikA, anDakArABisArikA#});
<div n="lb">comp. e. g. {%Ṛtusanhāra:%} {#sutIkzRamuccE rasatAM payomucAM GanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nDakArAvftaSarvarIzvapi . taqitpraBAdarSitamArgaBUmayaH prayAnti#}
<div n="lb">{#rAgAdaBisArikAH striyaH;#} or {%Kumārasambh.:%} {#yatrOzaDipra-#}
<div n="lb">{#kASena naktaM darSitasaMcarAH . anaBijYAstamisrARAM durdinezva-#}
<div n="lb">{#BisArikAH#}. For the places of assignation see {#aBisAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#sTAna#}. E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rvul,#} fem. aff. {#wAp#}.
<LEND>

<L>6521<pc>294-b<k1>aBisArin<k2>aBisArin
{#aBisArin#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-rI-riRI-ri#}) <sup>1</sup> The same
<div n="lb">as {#aBisarat#}. <sup>2</sup> Coming back to its herd, after having
<div n="lb">broken away from it; e. g. (a cow) {%Uśanas:%} {#adaRqyA mfta-#}
<div n="lb">{#vatsA ca saMjYArogavatI kfSA . adaRqyAH kARakUwASca vfzASca#}
<div n="lb">{#kftalakzaRAH#} (v. 1. {#adaRqyO kARakubjO ca ye SaSvatkftalakza-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAH#}) {#. adaRqyAgantukA gOSca sUtikA cABisAriRI#} ({%Mitra-%}
<div n="lb">{%miśra:%} {#aBisAriRI svayUTAtpracyutA punaH svayUTagAminI#}).
<div n="P">2. f. ({#-riRI#}) The name of a vaidik metre which consists
<div n="lb">of two {%pādas%} of the class {%Virāj%} (i. e. of ten syllables) and
<div n="lb">of two {%pādas%} of the class {%Jagati%} (i. e. of twelve syllables);
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv. Prātis.:%} {#vErAjajAgatO pAdO yo vAcetyaBisAriRI#} (the
<div n="lb">quoted instance being the {%Ṛgv.%}-verse: {#yo vAcA vivAco#}
<div n="lb">{#mfDravAcaH purU sahasrASivA jaGAna . tattadidasya pOMsyaM gfRI-#}
[Page295-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#masi piteva yastavizIM vAvfDe SavaH#} (with a {#vyUha#} q. v. in the
<div n="lb">third {%pāda%}). E. {#sf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Rini#}.
<LEND>

<L>6525<pc>295-a<k1>aBisusUz<k2>aBisusUz
{#aBisusUz#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-sUH-sUH-sUH#}) <sup>1</sup> One who desires to
<div n="lb">press out the juice of the Soma plant. <sup>2</sup> One who desires to
<div n="lb">sprinkle upon or to bathe. (This word and {#nisusUz#} are the
<div n="lb">object of the rule of {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 117., as regards the effect of
<div n="lb">the redupl. caused by the affix {#san#} not followed by another
<div n="lb">affix on the {#s#} of {#su (zuY),#} for an {%inflected%} form {#susUzati,#} with
<div n="lb">the radical {#s#} unchanged, {%without%} a prefix, would follow already
<div n="lb">from VIII. 3. 61. and a similar form {%with%} a prefix ending in
<div n="lb">{#i#} or {#u,#} e. g. {#aBisusUzati#} or {#ºte#} from VIII. 3. 64.; {%Patanj.:%}
<div n="lb">{#sani kimudAharaRam . susUzati . nEtadasti prayojanam . stOti-#}
<div n="lb">{#syoreva zaRyaByAsAdityetasmAnniyamAnna Bavizyati . idaM tarhi .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBisusUzate . etadapi nAsti prayojanam . sTAdizvaByAsena cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByAsasyetyasmAnniyamAnna Bavizyati . idaM tarhi prayojanam .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBisusUzaterapratyayaH . aBisusUH . nisusUH;#} comp. {#aBisozyat#}.)
<div n="lb">E. {#su (zuY)#} in the desider., with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip#}.
<LEND>

<L>6528<pc>295-a<k1>aBisozyat<k2>aBisozyat
{#aBisozyat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) <sup>1</sup> One who will
<div n="lb">press out the juice of the Soma plant. <sup>2</sup> One who will

<div n="lb">in the rule of {%Pān.%} VIII. 3. 117.; comp. {#aBisusUz#}.) E. {#su#}
<div n="lb">{#(zuY)#} in the future, with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.

<L>6533<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyanda<k2>aBisyanda
{#aBisyanda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-ndaH#}) The same as {#aBizyanda;#} the
<div n="lb">change of {#s#} to {#z#} in this deriv. of {#syand,#} pref. {#aBi,#} being
<div n="lb">optional, if it applies to {%inanimate%} objects; e. g. {%Suśruta:%}
<div n="lb">{#samaYjizWAni maDunA pizwAnIkzurasena vA . raktABisyandaSAntyarTa-#}

<L>6534<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandin<k2>aBisyandin
{#aBisyandin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ndI-ndinI-ndi#}) The same
<div n="lb">as {#aBizyandin;#} the change of {#s#} to {#z#} in this deriv. of
<div n="lb">{#syand,#} pref. {#aBi,#} being optional, if it applies to {%inanimate%}
<div n="lb">{%objects;%} if it is used, however, of {%living%} beings the form
<div n="lb">should be only {#aBisyandin#} ({%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 3. 72.). Comp.
<div n="lb">the following. E. see s. {#aBizyandin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6535<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandiramaRa<k2>aBisyandiramaRa
{#aBisyandiramaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) A suburb, a smaller town
<div n="lb">appended to the royal capital; {%Jaṭādh.:%} {#tatrABisyandiramaRaM#}
<div n="lb">{#SAKAnagaramapyuBe;#} {%Śabdaratn.:%} {#tadaBisyandinagaraM SAKAnaga-#}
<div n="lb">{#rameva ca;#} similarly {%Trikāṇdaśeṣa.%} (The comm. of the {%Ama-%}
<div n="lb">{%rak.%} on the synon. {#SAKAnagara#} restrict the term to the
<div n="lb">suburb of a {%royal capital;%} e. g. {%Mathureśa:%} {#mUlanagarAttu yada-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyatpuraM tacCAKAnagaram . ekaM rAjaDAnIsamIpe nagarAntarasya#}--
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘{%one%} term for another town in the neighbourhood of a
<div n="lb">royal capital’--{#. aBisyandiramaRaSabdo'pyatra;#} or {%Rāmā-%}
<div n="lb">{%śrama:%} {#mUlanagaraM rAjaDAnI tato'nyadyatpuraM tacCAKeva nagaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#SAKAnagaram#}. The word implies literally ‘a pleasure ground
<div n="lb">where people flock together’ and the writing {#aBizyaº#} is
<div n="lb">therefore incorrect, since {#syand,#} pref. {#aBi,#} applies in this
<div n="lb">compound to {%living beings;%} comp. the preceding; {%Rāyam.%}
<div n="lb">(on {#SAKAnagara#}): {#mUlanagare'saMmitajanOGasyAvasTAnArTaM mUla-#}
<div n="lb">{#nagarasya saMniDO yadanyatpuraM nagarAntaraM kriyate#} &c.; {%Bharatam.:%}
<div n="lb">{#mUlanagare'saMmitasya janOGasya sTAnAya mUlanagarasya samIpe'Nke#}
<div n="lb">{#vA yadanyatpuraM nagarAntaraM tacCAKAnagaram#}). A word {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#syandIvana#} in the same sense which occurs in a Ms. of the
<div n="lb">{%Bhūriprayoga,%} belonging to the E. I. H., is probably a mis-
<div n="lb">reading for the given word. E. {#aBisyandin#} and {#ramaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6536<pc>295-b<k1>aBisyandIvana<k2>aBisyandIvana
{#aBisyandIvana#}.¦ See the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>6537<pc>295-b<k1>aBisvayamAtfRRam<k2>aBisvayamAtfRRam
{#aBisvayamAtfRRam#}¦ Avyayībh. (ved.) Over the sacrificial brick
<div n="lb">called {#svayamAtfRRA#} or ‘full of holes by itself’ (in analogy
<div n="lb">to the small volcanic stones which bear the same name);
<div n="lb">{%Śatapath.:%} {#aBisvayamAtfRRamanyA izwakA upaDIyante#}. E. {#aBi#}

<L>6538<pc>295-b<k1>aBisvar<k2>aBisvar
{#aBisvar#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-svaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Praising, a hymn, an
<div n="lb">economiastic song; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBisvarA nizadA gA ava-#}
<div n="lb">{#syava indre hinvAnA draviRAnyASata#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBisvarA .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBitaH svaraH svaraRaM SabdanaM yasya tena stotreRa#}); or {%Sāmav.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#nemiM namanti cakzasA mezaM viprA aBisvare#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBisvare aBisvaraRAya stotrAya;#} {%Ṛgv. v. l.:%} {#aBisvarA#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Invocation, the calling near, the urging to one's presence;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Ṛgv., Sāmav.:%} {#sTAtA raTasya haryoraBisvara indro dfhLA#}
<div n="lb">{#cidArujaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#haryoraSvayoraBisvare'smadABimuKyena preraRe#}
<div n="lb">{#nimittaBUte sati#} i. e. the calling his horses towards us being
<div n="lb">the motive of Indra's mounting his chariot, or ‘he mounts
<div n="lb">his chariot for the purpose ({%dative%}) of urging the horses to
<div n="lb">our presence’). [The {%Ṛgv. Prātiś.%} notices the unchanged
<div n="lb">condition of {#s#} in this compound.] E. {#svf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
[Page296-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">aff. {#vic#}. (The first explanation of {%Sāyaṇa%} which appa-
<div n="lb">rently represents the word as a {%Bahuvr. n.%} of {#aBi#} and
<div n="lb">{#svar#} can be scarcely correct, since {#aBisvar#} is udātta on the
<div n="lb">last syllable; his subsequent gloss is therefore preferable;
<div n="lb">the dative {#aBisvare#} is udātta on the last syllable according
<div n="lb">to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 168. and need not be referred, therefore, to
<div n="lb">a base {#aBisvara#} for which there is no authority.)
<LEND>

<div n="lb">gether, intermixture; e. g. {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%} (things may be
<div n="lb">imperceptible) {#…sOkzmyAdvyavaDAnAdaBiBavAtsamAnABihA-#}

<L>6552<pc>296-b<k1>aBihita<k2>aBihita<h>1
I. {#aBihita#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Said, spoken,
<div n="lb">declared, called, named; e. g. {%Śāntip. Mahābh.:%} {#BaradvAja#}
<div n="lb">{#uvAca . yadetadBavatABihitaM suKAnAM paramA sTitiriti na ta-#}
<div n="lb">{#dupagfhRImaH;#} or {%Gauḍap.%} on the {%Sāṅkhyak.:%} {#yamA niyamASca#}
<div n="lb">{#pAtaYjale'BihitAH;#} or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#vijYAtasya parizadA tri-#}
<div n="lb">{#raBihitasyApyapratyuccAraRamananuBAzaRam;#} or {%Vṛhasp.:%} {#arTinA-#}
[Page297-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#Bihito yo'rTaH pratyarTo yadi taM taTA . prapadya pAraRaM brUyAtpra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyavaskandanaM hi tat;#} or {%Suśr.:%} {#sirAvyaDaviDO pUrvaM narA ye ca#}
<div n="lb">{#vivarjitAH . na tezAM nIlikAM viDyedanyatrABihitAdBizak;#} or
<div n="lb">{#iti yatprAgaBihitaM vistarastasya vakzyate;#} or {%spoken to, addressed:%}
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#vipAko'yaM daSagrIva saMdfzwo'nAgato mayA .#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaM tenABihitaH paTyaM kiM kopaM na niyacCasi;#} or {%Daśakum.:%}
<div n="lb">{#mayA tu smayamAnenABihitam . sOmya#} &c.; see {%Kaiyyaṭa'%}s ex-
<div n="lb">planation at the end of {#aBihita#} II. <sup>2</sup> Determined, con-
<div n="lb">veyed, explicit or clear (as the sense); e. g. {%Pāṇini%} inscribes
<div n="lb">the chapter treating on the use of the oblique cases: {#anaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hite#} i. e. when the sense of the case requires an expla-
<div n="lb">nation; the sense of the {%base%} is naturally conveyed by the
<div n="lb">first case or nominative ({%Patanj.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} II. 3. 1.: {#anaBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hitastu viBaktyarTastasmAdanaBihitavacanam . kaH punarviBaktyarTaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#ekatvAdayo viBaktyarTAH . tezvanaBihitezu karmAdayo'BihitA#}
<div n="lb">{#viBaktInAmutpattO nimittatvAya mA BUvanniti tasmAdanaBihi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tavacanam . tasmAdanaBihitADikAraH kriyate .;#} comp. II. 3. 46.
<div n="lb">and {%Vārtt.:%} {#aBihite praTamA#}); or {%Nyāya S.:%} {#aviSezABi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hite'rTe vakturaBiprAyAdarTAntarakalpanA vAkcCalam#}. See {%Kaiyy.%}
<div n="lb">at the end of II. <sup>3</sup> Placed upon, fastened upon; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mānava-Kalpa-S.:%} {#aBihitatamaM dakziRaM kuryAt#} (scil. {#pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#Dim#}) i. e. placed nearest the Āhavanīya fire; or {#upaBfdDruva-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoH sakASAdaBihitatarA#} i. e. the {#juhU#} is placed nearer the
<div n="lb">Āhavanīya than the {#upaBft#} and {#DruvA#} ({%Kumārila'%}s {%Bhāṣya:%}
<div n="lb">{#upaBftaH sakASAjjuhUrAhavanIyasaMnikfzwatarA#}). See {%Kaiyy.%} at
<div n="lb">the end of {#aBihita#} II.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-taH#}) The proper name of a Gotra-or family-
<div n="lb">chief; his descendants are called {#aBihitAH#} or {#ABihitayaH;#}
<div n="lb">another reading of the word is {#anaBihita#} q. v. ({%Vardha-%}
<div n="lb">{%māna,%} the author of the {%Gaṇaratnamahodadhi:%} {#aBipUrvasya#}
<div n="lb">{#hinoterdaDAtervA kte naYi ca . anaBihitastasyAnaBihitAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#AnaBihitayaH . kecidaBihiteti naYA vinA paWanti . tatrA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BihitAH . ABihitayaH#}).
<div n="P">3. n. ({#-tam#}) A word; e. g. {%Kāvyaprak.:%} {#sAmAnyarUpARAM#}
<div n="lb">{#padArTAnAmAkANkzAsaMniDiyogyatAvaSAtparasparasaMsargo yatrApa-#}
<div n="lb">{#dArTo'pi viSezarUpo vAkyArTastatrABihitAnvayavAde kA vArtA#}
<div n="lb">{#vyaNgyasyABiDeyatAyAM ye'pyAhuH#} &c.; or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#tA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tparyArTastadboDakaM ca vAkyamityaBihitAnvayavAdinAM matam#} (i. e.
<div n="lb">the opinion of those who contend that the purport of a
<div n="lb">sentence arises from the logical connexion between the
<div n="lb">words of the sentence); or {%comm.%} on the {%Sāh.:%} {#aBihitA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmaBiDayA lakzaRayA vA padopasTApitAnvayaboDavAdinAM prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#cInanEyAyikAnAmityarTaH#} (the latter maintaining that the
<div n="lb">‘purport’ of a sentence follows from the original or ellip-
<div n="lb">tical sense of the words themselves).
<div n="P">4. f. ({#-tA#}) The name of a plant (Commelina salici-
<div n="lb">folia); see {#jalapippalI#} ({%Nigh. Prak.%}). E. {#DA#} with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#kta#} (2. also referred to II. {#aBihita#}).
<LEND>

<L>6553<pc>297-a<k1>aBihita<k2>aBihita<h>2
II. {#aBihita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Gone. <sup>2</sup> In-
<div n="lb">creased. E. {#hi,#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}. [The latter word
<div n="lb">and its meanings on the authority of {%Kaiyyaṭa%} who has the
<div n="lb">following remark on {#aBihita#} I. and II.: {#aBipUrvastAvadda-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAtirbanDanoccAraRapratipAdanezu vartate . aSvABiDAnImAdatta#}
<div n="lb">{#ityatra banDanavfttiH . aBihitaH Sloka ityuccAraRavfttiH . aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#hito'rTa iti pratipAdanavfttiH .. hinoterapi gativfdDyarTasyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bihitamiti Bavati#}. Comp. also the Etym. of I. 2.]
<LEND>
[Page297-b+ 56]

<L>6554<pc>297-b<k1>aBihitatva<k2>aBihitatva

<L>6559<pc>297-b<k1>aBihrut<k2>aBihrut

<L>6561<pc>297-b<k1>aBihvAra<k2>aBihvAra

<div n="lb">seems less correct.) E. {#hvf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.

<L>6562<pc>297-b<k1>aBI<k2>aBI<h>1

<div n="lb">as the first part of several Tatpur. See the following ar-
<div n="lb">ticles and the Preface.
