<L>6563<pc>297-b<k1>aBI<k2>aBI<h>2
II. {#aBI#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-BIH-BIH-Bi#}) Fearless; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#niSvasantaM yaTA nAgaM rAvaRaM vAnarottamaH . sahasA#}
<div n="lb">{#paramodvignaH sopAsarpadaBIstataH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#aBiyAtAvaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#tuNgaM BUBftaM ruciraM puraH#} where the comm. analyze {#aBiyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tAvaraM#} either {#aBiyAtA#} (fut.) and {#varam,#} or {#aBiyA#} (instr.
[Page298-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">of {#aBiyA#} q. v.) and {#atAvaram (= atasya Avaram#}), or
<div n="lb">{#aBiyAtA#} (instr. of {#aBiyAt#}) and {#varam,#} or {#aBiyA#} (instr.
<div n="lb">of {#aBI#}) and {#atA#} (instr. of {#at:#} ‘going’) and {#Avaram;#}
<div n="lb">see also {#aBIBABiBUBABU#}. Comp. III. {#aBIka#}. E. {#a#} priv. and {#BI#}.
<LEND>

<L>6564<pc>298-a<k1>aBIka<k2>aBIka<h>1
I. {#aBIka#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) Lustful, libidinous; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#dadfSe parRaSAlAyAM rAkzasyABIkayATa saH#} (comm. =
<div n="lb">{#kAmukyA#}); the same as {#aBika#}. E. See s. v. {#aBika;#} with
<div n="lb">the protraction of the second syllable. [The {%Śabdaratnāvalī%}
<div n="lb">which has only the form {#aBIka#} gives the meanings: <sup>1</sup> Lustful
<div n="lb">({#kAmuka#}). <sup>2</sup> Anxious ({#utsuka#}); the former perhaps in re-
<div n="lb">ference to the E. {#kam#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa;#} the latter in
<div n="lb">reference to the E. {#aBi,#} taddh. aff. {#kan#}.]
<LEND>

<L>6565<pc>298-a<k1>aBIka<k2>aBIka<h>2
II. {#aBIka#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-kaH#}) (ved.) [occurs especially in the
<div n="lb">locative {#aBIke#}] <sup>1</sup> Neighbourhood, vicinity ({#aBIke#} near;
<div n="lb">perhaps also in reference to time: {%soon; Nirukta:%} = {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#sanna#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#ko vAM mahaScittyajaso aBIka uruzyantaM#}
<div n="lb">{#mADvI dasrA na UtI#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#AsannapradeSe#}); or {#sadyo#}
<div n="lb">{#dasyUnpra mfRa kutsyena pra sUraSca{??} vfhatAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpe#}
<div n="lb">or {#saMgrAme,#} see the following); or {#pari vAmaSvA vapuzaH pataNgA#}
<div n="lb">{#vayo vahantvaruzA aBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#gfhasamIpe#}); or {#svarvatIrita#}
<div n="lb">{#UtIryuvoraha citrA aBIke aBavannaBizwayaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpe#});
<div n="lb">or {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#A yadize nfpatiM teja AnawSuci reto#}
<div n="lb">{#niziktaM dyOraBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#AsannakAle#} {%soon, Māhidh.:%} = {#samIpe,#}
<div n="lb">{%Sāy.%} considering {#dyOH#} as an epithet ‘luminous’ of Agni;
<div n="lb">{%Mahīdh.%} as a {%genitive%}--not {%ablat.%}--depending on {#aBIke#});
<div n="lb">or {%Ṛgv.:%} {#mahaScidagna enaso aBIka UrvAddevAnAmuta martyAnAm#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#antike,#} with {#devAnAm#} and {#martyAnAm#} depending
<div n="lb">on it). <sup>2</sup> Battle, combat ({%Nigh.:%} = {#saMgrAma#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#Asno vfkasya vartikAmaBIke yuvaM narA nAsatyAmumuktam#} ({%Sāy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#saMgrAme#} i. e. in the battle between the wolf and the quail;
<div n="lb">the abl. {#AsnaH#} depending not on {#aBIke,#} but on {#amumu-#}
<div n="lb">{#ktam#}); or {#atriM na mahastamaso mumuktaM tUrvataM narA duritAdaBIke#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} = {#saMgrAme,#} the abl. {#duritAt#} depending on {#tUrvatam,#}
<div n="lb">not on {#aBIke#}); or {#tvaM no asyA indra durhaRAyAH pAhi vajri-#}
<div n="lb">{#bo duritAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#samIpavartini saMgrAme,#} the abl.
<div n="lb">{#duritAt#} depending on {#pAhi,#} not on {#aBIke#}); or {#ahannindro#}
<div n="lb">{#adahadagnirindo purA dasyUnmaDyandinAdaBIke#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#saMgrAme#}).
<div n="lb">[These two meanings of the word answer perfectly the
<div n="lb">sense of all the ved. passages where it occurs; other mean-
<div n="lb">ings leant to this word, are neither required nor founded
<div n="lb">on authority.] E. {#ac#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac;#} (the for-
<div n="lb">mation being analogous to {#pratIka, samIka, anUka;#} {%Sāyaṇa%}
<div n="lb">who gives this E. and assimilates it in this derivation to
<div n="lb">the words of the {%Gaṇa%} {#pacAdi,#} on account of the affix,
<div n="lb">and to those of the {%Gaṇa%} {#pfzodara,#} on acc. of the irregu-
<div n="lb">larity in the composition, proposes also an E. {#i (iR)#}
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#kak;#} but the former is preferable; the
<div n="lb">literal sense of the word is therefore ‘approaching’; comp.
<div n="lb">{#aBigamana, aBiyAna#} and similar compounds.
<LEND>

<L>6566<pc>298-a<k1>aBIka<k2>aBIka<h>3
III. {#aBIka#}¦ Bahuvr. 1. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kA-kam#}) <sup>1</sup> Fearless;
<div n="lb">see the inst. s. v. {#arDaBramaka#} ({%Trik., Med., Śabdar., Ajayap.%}
<div n="lb">&c.). <sup>2</sup> Cruel ({%Med., Śabdar.%}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-kaH#}) <sup>1</sup> A poet ({%Med.:%} = {#kavi#}). <sup>2</sup> A master
<div n="lb">({%Halāy.:%} = {#svAmin#}). E. {#a#} priv. and {#BI,#} samās. aff. {#kap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6567<pc>298-a<k1>aBIkzRam<k2>aBIkzRam
{#aBIkzRam#}¦ Avyayībh. <sup>1</sup> Repeatedly, frequently ({%Amarak.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Hemach., Ajayap., Śabdar.%} &c.); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#mUtre niku-#}
[Page298-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#mBArDapalaM vipAcya pibedaBIkzRaM kuqavArDamAtram;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
<div n="lb">{#icCantyaBIkzRaM kzayamAtmano'pi na jYAtayastulyakulasya lakzmIm;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Sāhityad.:%} {#vinayati sudfSo dfSoH parAgaM praRayini kOsu-#}
<div n="lb">{#mamAnanAnilena . tadahitayuvateraBIkzRamakzRordvayamapi rozara-#}
<div n="lb">{#joBirApupUre;#} or {%Kṣīrasv.%} and {%Vardhamāna%} (the author
<div n="lb">of the {%Gaṇaratnam.%}): {#aBIkzRamAsPAlayatIva kumBam;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aBIkzRAvagAhakapiSAYjawilAnkuwilAlakAn .#}
<div n="lb">{#AtmAnaM cogratapasA biBratI cIriRaM kfSam#}. <sup>2</sup> Constantly,
<div n="lb">always ({%Amarak.%} &c.); e. g. {%Kṣīrasv.:%} {#aBIkzRaM vakti#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Much, exceedingly, eminently ({%Trik., Med., Śabdar.%} &c.);
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Kenopan.:%} {#aTADyAtmaM yadetadgacCatIva ca mano'nena cEta-#}
<div n="lb">{#dupasmaratyaBIkzRaM saMkalpaH#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} = {#BfSam#}). <sup>4</sup> Quickly;
<div n="lb">({%Hem., Med., Śabdar.%}). [The word is said by some comm.
<div n="lb">on the {%Amarak.%} to be used also in the three genders; but
<div n="lb">this assertion appears to be founded only on the circum-
<div n="lb">stance that it occurs in other {%Koshas%} also amongst the in-
<div n="lb">flected words; its form, however, is always there {#aBIkzRam#}
<div n="lb">which might apply as well to an adj. as to an indecl.; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāsrama:%} {#ajayastvaBIkzRaSabdamanavyayamapyAha . anavyayapra-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRapAWAt#}). E. That given by {%Rāmāśr., Bhanūjid.%} &c.:
<div n="lb">{#kzRu#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qam,#} and {#Bi#} being protracted be-
<div n="lb">cause the form belongs to the {#pfzodarAdi,#} is not very
<div n="lb">plausible; {%Yāska%} explains the word as a contraction of
<div n="lb">{#aBikzaRam;#} but as the protraction of the final vowel of
<div n="lb">{#aBi#} {%in compounds%} points either to a kṛt deriv. with {#GaY#} or
<div n="lb">{#kvip#} or to the loss of a following {#a#} (comp. {#aBIka#} II. and
<div n="lb">{#aBIpat#}), the word is better considered as an Avyayībh.
<div n="lb">of {#aBi#} and {#akzRa#}. (It belongs to the {%Gaṇas%} {#svarAdi#} {%Pāṇ.%}
<div n="lb">I. 1. 37. and {#brAhmaRAdi#} V. 1. 124.)
<LEND>

<L>6576<pc>299-a<k1>aBItvara<k2>aBItvara
{#aBItvara#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rI-ram#}) (ved.) Approaching
<div n="lb">with hostile intent, ready for assault; e. g. {%Vājas.:%} {#yA senA#}
<div n="lb">{#aBItvarIrAvyADinIrugaRA uta#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} {#aBItvarIraBItvaryaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBiyAyinyaH#}); or {%Aitar. Br.:%} {#etadDa sma vE tadvidvAnAha jana-#}
<div n="lb">{#mejayaH pArikzita evaMvidaM hi vE mAmevaMvido yAjayanti tasmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dahaM jayAmyaBItvarIM senAM jayAmyaBItvaryA senayA#} &c. ({%Sāy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBItvarIm = aBito yudDArTamudyuktAm#}). E. {#i (iR)#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvarap,#} āgama {#tuk#}.

<L>6578<pc>299-a<k1>aBIpat<k2>aBIpat

<div n="lb">between both meanings is proposed by {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBI-#}

<div n="lb">seems more congenial with the context. E. probably {#ap#}
<div n="lb">(an obsolete rad.; comp. {#Ap#}) with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.

<L>6583<pc>299-a<k1>aBIBABiBUBABU<k2>aBIBABiBUBABU

<div n="lb">passing a fearless elephant.’ (This monstrous compound

<L>6584<pc>299-a<k1>aBIma<k2>aBIma

<div n="lb">prets the two names {#SaraBo BImaH#} either {#SaraBa#} and {#BIma,#}
<div n="lb">or {#SaraBa#} and {#aBIma,#} and comments upon {#BIma#} and {#aBIma#}
[Page299-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">as follows: {#(vikzetyataH sarvajano) Biyo magvikalpaHtaH zuNga#}
<div n="lb">(compare {%Uṇṇādi-S.%} 1. 147.) {#taTA ca BImaH . BayaMkaro vApya-#}
<div n="lb">{#BayaMkaro hi satAM tvaBImaH…#} (the following words of
<div n="lb">this verse and the next verse refer to another name of
<div n="lb">Viṣṇu in the text) {#. oM BImAya aBImAya vA namaH .#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#BIma#}.

<L>6586<pc>299-b<k1>aBImoda<k2>aBImoda
{#aBImoda#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) Excessive happiness or joy; e. g.

<div n="lb">{#prAviSan#} (where {#aBImodamudaH#} is either Dwandwa ‘ex-
<div n="lb">cessive joy and pleasure’ or perhaps an irregular intensitive
<div n="lb">formation with the reduplication of the whole radical in-
<div n="lb">stead of its first syllable (similar in some degree to the ved.
<div n="lb">{#badbaD#} the intens. of {#banD#}); the masc. of the relative, {#ye,#}

<L>6587<pc>299-b<k1>aBIra<k2>aBIra
{#aBIra#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. ({#-raH#}) A cowherd. ‘According to
<div n="lb">Manu (X. 15.) the {%Abhīra%} is of mixed origin, the offspring
<div n="lb">of a Brāhmaṇa father and a mother of the Ambashtha or
<div n="lb">medical caste; but the {%Abhīras%} were a people, a pastoral
<div n="lb">tribe, settled about the beginning of the Christian era, on
<div n="lb">or near the lower course of the Indus on a tract known to
<div n="lb">classical geographers, as the {%Abiria%} of Ptolemy, lying north
<div n="lb">of the Sahyadri mountain and of Syrastrene. The {%Abhīras%}
<div n="lb">of Saurāṣtra are mentioned in the Mahābhārata. From
<div n="lb">their pastoral habits the name came to be generally applied
<div n="lb">to the cowherds of Hindustan. In the spoken dialects of
<div n="lb">upper India the word is corrupted to Ahīr, Uheer; in Ben-
<div n="lb">gālī and Marāṭhī it is unchanged, occurring as Abhīr.’
<div n="lb">({%Wilson'%}s {%Glossary of Indian Terms.%}) See {%Lassen'%}s {%Ind. Alt.%}
<div n="lb">vol. 1. pp. 106. 396. 539. 546. 705. 798. 799. 823; II. pp. 385.
<div n="lb">547. 553. 592. 792. 855. 953. 956. &c.--The word as a
<div n="lb">name of a people occurs in the Purāṇas ‘always conjoined
<div n="lb">with the {%Śūdras,%} as if conterminous’ ({%Wilson'%}s {%Viṣṇu-P.%}
<div n="lb">p. 195 n. 154).--The {%Sāhityadarpaṇa%} mentions the {%Abhīras%}
<div n="lb">as assistants appointed in, or belonging to, the harem
<div n="lb">(together with dwarfs, eunuchs, Kirātas or mountaineers,
<div n="lb">Mlechchhas or barbarians, the mock-brother-in-law of a
<div n="lb">king, i. e. the brother of his concubine, hump-backs, mutes
<div n="lb">&c.: {#vAmanazaRqakirAtamlecCABIrAH SakArakubjAdyAH#}). The
<div n="lb">same work, in defining the purposes for which Sanskṛt
<div n="lb">and the Prākṛt-dialects are used in the dramatic dialogue,
<div n="lb">appropriates the dialect of the Abhīras (which therefore is
<div n="lb">not considered by the {%Sāh.%} as an Apabhranśa-dialect) to
<div n="lb">cowherds and woodcutters; comp. {#ABIrI#} s. v. {#ABIra;#}
<div n="lb">{#(ABIrezu taTABIrI…. ABIrI SAvarI cApi kAzWa-#}
<div n="lb">{#pattropajIvizu);#} others hold the Abhīra-dialect as belonging
<div n="lb">to the Apabhranśa, when it would be excluded from dra-
<div n="lb">matic use. See {#apaBraMSa#} and {%Lassen'%}s {%Institutiones Linguae%}
<div n="lb">{%Pracriticae.%}--(The word occurs usually in the form
<div n="lb">{#ABIra;#} the dialect spoken by the Abhīras is {%always%} called
<div n="lb">{#ABIrI,#} not {#aBIrI#}.)
<div n="P">2. n. (? {#-ram#}) The name of a {%Mātrāvṛtta%} or Prākṛt
[Page300-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">metre, regulated by quantity; it consists of a stanza of
<div n="lb">four lines with eleven {%mātrās%} in each line (the value of a
<div n="lb">mātrā being a short syllable, and a long syllable equal to
<div n="lb">two short), viz. each line being composed either of seven
<div n="lb">mātrās and a Scolius ({??}), or of a Dactylus ({??}),
<div n="lb">a Iambus ({??}) and a Scolius, or of a Scolius, a Tri-
<div n="lb">brachys ({??}) and a Scolius. E. {#Ir#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff.
<div n="lb">{#ac#} (according to several comm. of the {%Amarak.%}); but the
<div n="lb">word is probably not of Sanskṛ4tic origin.
<LEND>

<L>6590<pc>300-a<k1>aBIrAjI<k2>aBIrAjI

<L>6591<pc>300-a<k1>aBIru<k2>aBIru
{#aBIru#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ruH-ruH#} or {#rUH-ru#}) Fearless,
<div n="lb">undaunted; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#te vASImanta izmiRo aBIravo#}
<div n="lb">{#vidre priyasya mArutasya DAmnaH;#} or {%Manu:%} {#gulmAMSca sTApayedA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ptAnkftasaMjYAnsamantataH . sTAne yudDe ca kuSalAnaBIrUnavikA-#}
<div n="lb">{#riRaH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#ahaM svapnakprasAdena tava vandAruBiH saha .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBIruravasaM strIBirBAsvarABiriheSvara;#} or in the following
<div n="lb">specimen of alliteration: {#BUriBirBAriBirBIrErBUBArEraBire-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bire . BerIreBiBiraBrABEraBIruBiriBEriBAH#} ‘elephants con-
<div n="lb">tended with elephants that were numerous, heavy, terrible,
<div n="lb">immense, roaring, cloud-like and fearless’ ({%Yates, Essay%}
<div n="lb">{%on alliteration%}).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-ruH#}) A (euphemistic) name of Bhairava or
<div n="lb">Śiva; e. g. {#aBIrurBEravo BIrurBUtapo yoginIpatiH#} ({%Vaṭuka-%}
<div n="lb">{%bhairavastava,%} as quoted by {%Rādhāk.%}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-ruH#} or {#rUH#}) The name of a plant (Asparagus
<div n="lb">racemosus); according to some, a large variety of it. (So
<div n="lb">called, because its leaves are firm on account of its nu-
<div n="lb">merous roots, or on account of their containing always
<div n="lb">juice; {%Bhanūj.:%} {#sTirapatratvAt;#} {%Rāyam.:%} {#dUralambitabahumUla-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvAt . sadArasAlayatvena sTirapatratvAditi tu svAmI;#} comp.
<div n="lb">{#aBIrupatrI#}); e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#aBIrUmisisinDUtTavatsakoSIra-#}
<div n="lb">{#padmakEH…datto vastiH suSItalaH#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BIru#}.
<LEND>

<L>6599<pc>300-b<k1>aBIvarta<k2>aBIvarta
{#aBIvarta#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-rtaH#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Being everywhere; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBi tvA viSvaBUtAnyaBIvarto yaTAsasi#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aBitaH#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvatra vartamAno Bavasi#}). <sup>2</sup> Approaching, esp. with hostile
<div n="lb">intent; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBIvartena havizA yenendro aBivAvfte .#}
<div n="lb">{#tenAsmAnbrahmaRaspate'Bi rAzwrAya vartaya#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBIvartena =#}
<div n="lb">{#aBigacCatA#}); or {%Atharv.:%} {#aBIvartena maRinA yenendro aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAvfDe . tenAºº#}. Hence the word has become the epithet or
<div n="lb">name of several vaidik verses or hymns which are recited
<div n="lb">for obtaining victory; {%Benfey,%} in his valuable Index to the
<div n="lb">{%Sāmaveda,%} mentions the following {%Sāma-verses%} which, in
<div n="lb">the Gānas bear this name: 1. 242 (= 1. 3. 1. 5. 10), 2. 25. 26
<div n="lb">(= II. 1. 1. 9), or only 2. 25b. 26a (= II. 1. 1. 9. 1b. 2a), 2. 35. 36
<div n="lb">(= II. 1. 1. 13), 2. 117 (= II. 1. 2. 20. 1), 2. 161. 162 (= II. 2. 1. 13),
<div n="lb">2. 206 (= 2. 2. 9. 1), 2. 214-216 (= II. 2. 2. 12), 2. 272 b. 273 a (= II.
<div n="lb">3. 1. 11. 1 b. 2 a), 2. 283. 284 (= II. 3. 1. 15), 2 347 b. 348 a (= II. 3.
<div n="lb">2. 12. 1 b. 2 a), 2. 429 a. 430 b (= II. 4. 1. 12. 1b. 2a), 2. 710-713 (= II.
<div n="lb">6. 1. 5 and 6), 2. 741-743 (= II. 6. 2. 5), 2. 761. 762 (= II. 6. 2. 12),
<div n="lb">2. 771. 772 (= II. 6. 2. 16), 2. 929. 930 (= II. 7. 3. 3), 2. 987. 988
<div n="lb">(= II. 8. 1. 8); moreover {#indrasyABIvartaH#} or {#prajApateraBIvartaH#} or
<div n="lb">{#aBIvartasyANgirasasya BAgam#} 1. 236 (= 1. 3. 1. 5. 4); {#jamadagnera-#}
<div n="lb">{#BIvartaH#} 1. 239 (= I. 3. 1. 5. 7) and 2. 771. 772 (see above);
<div n="lb">{#vfzasya jYAnasyABIvartaH#} 1. 523 (= I. 6. 1. 4. 1); e. g. {%Maśaka-%}
<div n="lb">{%Kalpa-Sūtr.%} (in the chapter on the {%Abhijit%}): {#pra soma deva-#}
<div n="lb">{#vItaya ityaBIvartaH#} (i. e. {%Sāmav.%} 2. 117); or {#punAnaH soma DA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rayetyaBIvartaH#} (i. e. 2. 25); also called {%Brahmasāman;%} e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#gavAmayane brahmasAma vihitam . aBI-#}
<div n="lb">{#varto brahmasAma Bavati#}.--It is the name, too, of {%Ṛgv.%} 10.
<div n="lb">174.--In {%Vājas.%} 14. 23. the name is applied to a {%sacrificial%}
<div n="lb">{%brick%} ({#izwakA#}), when {%Mahīdhara%} explains {#aBIvarta#} as meaning
<div n="lb">literally either ‘repetition’ or ‘approaching’, the former
<div n="lb">assuming the sense {%stoma,%} since the Sāmaverses are re-
<div n="lb">peated in a hymn of that description, and the latter the
<div n="lb">meaning ‘year’, since the year (i. e. time) approaches all created
<div n="lb">beings; he holds therefore that the brick is likened in this
<div n="lb">passage to a hymn or to a year. (The {%vaidik glossary%} of
<div n="lb">{%Someśvara%} explains the word in this manner: {#aBIvarto#}
<div n="lb">{#BUtaBedayAtAyAtanirUpaRe . nAnAsaMsftisaMsTAnasvarUpAmnAya-#}
<div n="lb">{#varRane . divyezwikAtmanicayacayane'pi prakIrtitaH#}). E. {#vft#}
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY;#} the second vowel being protracted;
<div n="lb">(this protraction is mentioned in the {%Prātiśākhyas%}).
<LEND>
[Page301-a+ 56]

<L>6600<pc>301-a<k1>aBIvft<k2>aBIvft
{#aBIvft#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-t-t-t#}) (ved.) Going or being,
<div n="lb">everywhere; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#aBIvftaM kfSanErviSvarUpaM hiraRyaSamyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#yajato bfhantam . AsTAdraTaM savitA…#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} = {#aBito#}
<div n="lb">{#vartamAnam#}). E. {#vft#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kvip,#} with the
<div n="lb">second syllable protracted; comp. the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>6601<pc>301-a<k1>aBIvfta<k2>aBIvfta
{#aBIvfta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> Surrounded,
<div n="lb">accompanied. <sup>2</sup> Covered, obscured.--In the {%Ṛgv.%}-verse
<div n="lb">I. 164. 29.: {#ayaM sa SiNkte yena gOraBIvftA mimAti mAyuM Dvasa-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAvaDi SritA,#} {%Sāyaṇa%} who supplies to {#ayaM#} the word {#vatsaH#}
<div n="lb">and takes the latter as a metaphorical expression for the
<div n="lb">world desiring rain, and {%‘the cow’%} as the cloud, renders
<div n="lb">the beginning words: {#yena vatsena gOrmAtABIvftA . AgatyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bito vezwitA Bavati;#} {%Durga%} on {%Yāska%} 2. 9. supplies to
<div n="lb">{#ayaM#} the word {#meGa#} and renders {#gOH#} ‘voice, speech’: {#ayaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sa meGaH SabdAyate Sabdamiva karoti . na ca tAvadasO SabdaM#}
<div n="lb">{#karoti . aTa ca tAvanmADyamikAyAM vAci tatsTAyAM SabdaM#}
<div n="lb">{#kurvatyAM tatsAhacaryAdvijYAyate sa eva SabdaM karotIti . yena#}
<div n="lb">{#meGena kiM kftamiti . yena gOraBIvftA . yena mADyamikA vA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gaBipracCAditA satI mimAti mAyuM nirmimIte nirvartayati#}
<div n="lb">{#mAyuM SabdaM karotItyarTaH;#} in {%Roth'%}s ed. of the {%Nirukta%} (2. 9.)
<div n="lb">{#aBipravfttA#} must therefore be corrected to {#aBipravftA,#}
<div n="lb">the former being contrary to the sense and unsupported by
<div n="lb">the gloss of {%Durga.%} E. {#vf#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta,#} with
<div n="lb">the second syllable protracted (as noticed by the {%Ṛgv.%}
<div n="lb">{%Prātiś.%}).
<LEND>

<L>6603<pc>301-a<k1>aBISu<k2>aBISu
{#aBISu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-SuH#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Finger ({%Nighantu:%} = {#aNgu-#}
<div n="lb">{#li#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#sTirA vaH santu nemayo raTA aSvAsa#}
<div n="lb">{#ezAm . susaMskftA aBISavaH#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aNgulayaH#}); or {#daSA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BISuByo arcatajareByo daSa Duro daSa yuktA vahadByaH#} ({%Durga%} to
<div n="lb">{%Yāska:%} {#‘aByaSnuvate karmARi’, aBISavo'pyaNgulaya eva tA#}
<div n="lb">{#aByaSnuvate karmARi vyApnuvantItyarTaH . anekErnAmaBiraNgulaya evo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ktAH#}). <sup>2</sup> (ved.) Arm ({%Nigh.:%} = {#bAhu#}). <sup>3</sup> (ved.) A ray of
<div n="lb">light ({%Nigh.:%} = {#raSmi#}); see {%Durga%} at the end. <sup>4</sup> A rein
<div n="lb">({%Nigh.:%} = {#raSmi#}); e. g. {%Ṛgv., Vājas.:%} {#raTe tizWannayati vA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jinaH puro yatrayatra kAmayate suzAraTiH . aBISUnAM mahimAnaM#}
<div n="lb">{#panAyata manaH paScAdanu yacCanti raSmayaH#} ({%Sāy., Mahīdh.:%} =
<div n="lb">{#raSmInAm#}); or {%Vājas.:%} {#suzAraTiraSvAniva yanmanuzyAnnenI-#}
<div n="lb">{#yate'BISuBirvAjina iva#} ({%Mahīdh.:%} = {#pragrahEH#}); or {%Ṛgv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#anaSvo jAto anaBISurarvA#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#AlambanADArapragraha-#}
<div n="lb">{#sTAnIyaraSmirahitaH#}). Comp. {#aBIzu#}. E. ({%Yāska, Sāyaṇa,%}
<div n="lb">&c.) {#aS#} with {#aBi,#} uṇ. aff. {#uR,#} with an irregular con-
<div n="lb">traction in the second syllable (compare e. g. {#aBIkzRa#});
<div n="lb">‘finger’ and ‘arm’ because they perform work; or perhaps
<div n="lb">because they move quickly, ‘finger’ being derived in several
<div n="lb">synonymes from radicals implying motion, comp. {#aNguli,#}
<div n="lb">{#agrU, aTari#} &c.; ‘rays of light’ metaph. as fingers of the
<div n="lb">sun; or perhaps because they ‘pervade; ‘rein’ esp. of the
<div n="lb">horses of the sun, metaph. as the rays; but acc. to {%Durga%}
<div n="lb">the two latter meanings would seem to refer to another E.,
<div n="lb">viz. a rad. implying checking, restraining, ‘for the rays
<div n="lb">check the water and the reins horses’; perhaps {#IS#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#u;#} {%Durga%} to {%Yāska%} on {%Nigh.%} 1. 5. {#(raSmirya-#}
<div n="lb">{#manAttezAmAditaH sADAraRAni paYcASvaraSmiBiH): Aditya-#}
[Page301-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#saMbanDenEva raSminAmAnyuttarARi paYcadaSa . raSmiryamanAduda-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasya . aSvAnAM vA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6605<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzAh<k2>aBIzAh

<L>6606<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzu<k2>aBIzu
{#aBIzu#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-zuH#}) <sup>1</sup> A ray of light. <sup>2</sup> A rein. <sup>3</sup> Desire.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Attachment, love. (The two first meanings in {%Amarak.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Hem., Viśvapr.,%} &c. for the two latter comp. {%Śabdaratnāv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aBIzu pragrahe raSmO puMsi kAmAnurAgayoH#}. {%Bharata%} and
<div n="lb">{%Mathureśa%} on the {%Amarak.%} admit the form {#aBISu#} only for
<div n="lb">the meaning ‘ray’ (in the classical dialect); {%Mallin.%} on the
<div n="lb">{%Śiśupālab.%} 16. 51. however observes that all the words which
<div n="lb">are given by the Koshas as ending in {#z,#} occur in the vaidic
<div n="lb">and in the classical language with a final {#S: viSvaprakA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SAdayaH sarve'pyaBiDAnikA mUrDanyAntezu ye lokavedayostAla-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyAntA dfSyante#}. Comp. {#aBISu#}.) E. see {#aBISu,#} with {#z#} for
<div n="lb">{#S;#} but the comm. on the {%Amarak.%} derive the word from
<div n="lb">{#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#u;#} or {#aBi (= aBigata)#} and {#izu;#}
<div n="lb">this E. is without any probability.
<LEND>

<L>6607<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzumat<k2>aBIzumat

<L>6608<pc>301-b<k1>aBIzwa<k2>aBIzwa
{#aBIzwa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-zwaH-zwA-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> Longed for, dear,
<div n="lb">beloved; ({%Rāyam.%} on the {%Amarak.:%} {#aBi punaH . punarizwama-#}
<div n="lb">{#BIzwam#}); e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#prARA yaTAtmano'BIzwA BUtAnAmapi#}
<div n="lb">{#te taTA . AtmOpamyena BUtezu dayAM kurvanti sADavaH;#} or {%Pancha-%}
<div n="lb">{%tantra:%} {#Aha ca . Bo mitra tvaM vaDAya mayA samAnIto BAryA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAkyena viSvAsya . tatsmaryatAmaBIzwadevatA#}. <sup>2</sup> Wished, desired
<div n="lb">(in general); e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#samAranta mamABIzwAH saMkalpA-#}
<div n="lb">{#stvayyupAgate;#} or {#utkArezu ca DAnyAnAmanaBIzwaparigrahAH#} (scil.
<div n="lb">{#yUyaM yAta#}). <sup>3</sup> Optional, arbitrary, any one or any one
<div n="lb">thing of several; e. g. {%Lilāvatī:%} {#[dviDA BavedrUpaviBAga evaM]#}
<div n="lb">{#sTAnEH pfTagvA guRitaH sametaH . izwonayuktena guRena niGno'BI-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwaGnaguRyAnvitavarjito vA#} ({%Colebrooke:%} [These (the preceding)
<div n="lb">are two methods of subdivision by form.] Or multiply se-
<div n="lb">parately by the places of figures and add the products to-
<div n="lb">gether. Or multiply by the multiplicator diminished or
<div n="lb">increased by a quantity {%arbitrarily%} assumed; adding or
<div n="lb">subtracting the product of the multiplicand taken into the
<div n="lb">assumed quantity); or {%Vījagaṇita:%} {#fRAtmikA cetkaraRI#}
<div n="lb">{#kftO syAdDanAtmikAM tAM parikalpya sADye . mUle karaRyAvanayora-#}
<div n="lb">{#BIzwA kzayAtmikEkA suDiyAvagamyA#} ({%Colebrooke:%} if there be a
<div n="lb">negative surd-root in the square, treating that irrational
<div n="lb">quantity as an affirmative one, let the two surds in the
<div n="lb">root be found, and one of them, as selected by the intel-
<div n="lb">ligent calculator, must be deemed negative).
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-zwaH#}) A beloved person, a sweatheart; said
<div n="lb">esp. of a man; e. g. {%Śiśupālab.:%} {#aBIzwamAsAdya cirAya kAle#}
[Page302-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#samudDftASaM kamanI cakASe . yozinmanojanmasuKodayezu samudDftA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SaNkamanIcakASe;#} or (superl.) {%Sāhityad.:%} {#smitaSuzkaruditaha-#}
<div n="lb">{#sitatrAsakroDaSramAdInAm . sANkaryaM kilakiYcitamaBIzwatamasaMga-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAdijAdDarzAt;#} but also used in a general sense of {%either%}
<div n="lb">{%sex;%} e. g. {%Sāhityad.:%} {#tatra tu ratiH prakfzwA nABIzwamupEti vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#pralamBo'sO#} ({%comm.:%} {#aBIzwaM nAyakaM nAyikAM vA#}).
<div n="P">3. f. ({#-zwA#}) <sup>1</sup> A beloved woman, a mistress. <sup>2</sup> Betel
<div n="lb">(Piper betel); see {#tAmbUlI#}. [{%Wilson'%}s {%first ed.%} and {%Rādhāk.'%}s
<div n="lb">{%Śabdakalpadr.%} give the meaning {%‘perfume’%} and refer for
<div n="lb">its being a synonyme of {#reRukA#} to the authority of the
<div n="lb">{%Śabdachandrikā;%} but this reference contains an error, caused
<div n="lb">perhaps by an omission of a copyist of the {%Śabdachandrikā.%}
<div n="lb">The latter vocabulary has been composed by {%Chakrapāṇi-%}
<div n="lb">{%datta%} with a view of being a supplement to the {%Amarak.;%}
<div n="lb">it does not contain as much matter as this vocabulary nor
<div n="lb">does it follow {%throughout%} its order; but in certain portions it
<div n="lb">{%has%} the same order and it gives always literally the text of
<div n="lb">the {%Amarak.,%} whereever additional synonymes have been
<div n="lb">intended by the author, these synonymes being either im-
<div n="lb">mediately annexed by him to the words of the {%Amarak.%}
<div n="lb">in a subsequent verse or pointed out through the repetition
<div n="lb">of the word to be enlarged upon, which then is put in the
<div n="lb">locative. The end of the enumeration is marked by the
<div n="lb">repetition of the word synonymized, between two full stops.
<div n="lb">Thus the Śloka of the {%Amarak.%} II. 4. 4. 8. which contains,
<div n="lb">up to {#nAgavallI,#} synonymes of ‘piper betel’, and afterwards
<div n="lb">those of the perfume {#reRukA#} (viz. {#tAmbUlavallI tAmbUlI nAga-#}
<div n="lb">{#vallyapyaTa dvijA . hareRU reRukA kOntI kapilA BasmaganDinI#})
<div n="lb">runs thus in the {%Bodleian%} copy of the {%Śabdach.,%} of Professor
<div n="lb">{%Wilson'%}s collection: {#tAmbUlavallI tAmbUlI nAgavallyapyaTA dvijA .#}
<div n="lb">{#hareRU reRukA kOntI kapilA BasmaganDinI . tAmbUlyAM kawukABIzwA#}
<div n="lb">{#devABIzwA gfhASayA#} (these four words mean therefore {%Betel%}) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#reRukAyAM BavejjyotsnI kftAntA KaranAdinI . varAvaramuKI#}
<div n="lb">{#pucCArSoGnI SyAmA varatkarI#} (and these eight words the per-
<div n="lb">fume {%Reṇukā%}) {#.. reRukAKye ganDadravye ..#}. The mentioned Ms.
<div n="lb">omits, as may be observed, (contrary to its practice, and
<div n="lb">merely from carelesness of the copyist,) the ending word,
<div n="lb">{#.. tAmbUlI ..,#} before {#reRukAyAM,#} and as it has served both,
<div n="lb">Professor {%Wilson%} and {%Rādhākaṇtadeva,%} the oversight be-
<div n="lb">comes thus explainable.]
<div n="P">4. n. ({#-zwam#}) <sup>1</sup> A desired object, desire; e. g. {%Sāhityad.:%}
<div n="lb">{#jYAnABIzwAgamAdyEstu saMpUrRaspfhatA DftiH;#} or {%Bhaṭṭik.:%} {#kva ca#}
<div n="lb">{#KyAto raGorvaMSaH kva tvaM paragfhozitA . anyasmE hfdayaM dehi#}
<div n="lb">{#nAnaBIzwe GawAmahe#} ({%Jayam.:%} = {#anaBimate vizaye;#} {%Bharatas.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#anucite vastuni#}). <sup>2</sup> The name of a plant; see {#tilaka;#}
<div n="lb">(according to the {%Nigh. Prak.;%} but as the gender is not
<div n="lb">given in this work, it is doubtful whether the word is in
<div n="lb">this sense a {%m.%} or a {%n.%}). E. {#iz#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta;#}
<div n="lb">in the first meaning perhaps better {#aBi#} and {#izwa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6609<pc>302-a<k1>aBIzwatA<k2>aBIzwatA

<L>6618<pc>302-b<k1>aBU<k2>aBU
{#aBU#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-BUH#}) Unborn; a name or epithet of Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb">the 437<sup>th</sup> among the thousand names which occur in the
<div n="lb">{%Anuśasanap.%} of the {%Mahābh.;%} (according to {%Gaṅgādhara%}
<div n="lb">who admits in the verse {#anirvirRRaH sTavizWo BUrDarmayUpo#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAmaKaH#} the option between the reading {#sTavizWo BUH#} and
<div n="lb">{#sTavizWo'BUH,#} and interprets accordingly: {#BUrhi satAM Bava-#}

<div n="lb">{#oM Buve'Buve vA namaH#}). E. {#a#} neg. and {#BU#}.

<L>6619<pc>302-b<k1>aBUta<k2>aBUta
{#aBUta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Non-existent, what is
<div n="lb">not or has not been; e. g. {%Kaṇāda Sūtras:%} {#viroDyaBUtamaBU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tasya ..#} ({%Śaṅk. Upask.:%} {#aBUtaM varzaM BUtasya vAyvaBrasaMyogasya#}
<div n="lb">{#liNgam . evaM sPowAderviroDI mantrapAWaH . taTA cABUtamanutpannaM#}
<div n="lb">{#sPowAdiBUtasya mantrapAWasya liNgam . viroDiliNgasyodAhara-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAntaramAha#}) {#.. BUtamaBUtasya ..#} ({%Śaṅk. Upask.:%} {#BUtaM sPowAdi-#}
<div n="lb">{#kamaBUtasya mantrapAWasya liNgam . evaM BUto vAyvaBrasaMyogo'BU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tasya varzasya liNgam . evaM BUto dAho'BUtasya manyAdisamava-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnasya liNgam#} &c.); or {%Yāska:%} {#kastadveda yadaBUtamidamapItara-#}
<div n="lb">{#dadButam#}. Comp. the following articles. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BUta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6620<pc>302-b<k1>aBUtatadBAva<k2>aBUtatadBAva
{#aBUtatadBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) The becoming of, the being
<div n="lb">transformed or changed of a substance to, what it has not
<div n="lb">been before; {%Kaiyyaṭa:%} on {%Patanj.%} on the {%Vārtt.%} {#aBUtatadBAva#}
<div n="lb">{#iti vaktavyam#} to {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 50.: {#yena rUpeRa prAgaBUtaM kAraRaM#}
<div n="lb">{#tena rUpeRa tasya BAvo'BUtatadBAvaH;#} {%Kāśikā%} on the same
<div n="lb">{%Vārtt.:%} {#kAraRasya vikArarUpeRABUtasya tadAtmanA BAvo'BUta-#}
<div n="lb">{#tadBAvaH;#} or {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 1. 12.: {#BfSAdizvaBUtatadBAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaRaM kartavyam#}. [The notion implied by this term is ex-
<div n="lb">pressed by the affixes called in {%Pāṇini'%}s system {#cvi#} and
<div n="lb">{#sAti,#} and in some denominatives by the affix {#kyaN;#} see
<div n="lb">the Sūtras quoted, and V. 4. 51-55.--The Calcutta Paṇḍits
<div n="lb">who have compiled a comm. on {%Pāṇ.%} have misapplied this
[Page303-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">word in using it in the sense of ‘the {%being%} or taking place
<div n="lb">of what has not been before’, when they comment on the
<div n="lb">word {#AScarya#} ‘wonderful’, VI. 1. 174.; neither {%Patanjali%} and
<div n="lb">his comm., nor the {%Kāś.%} or the {%Siddhk.%} make use of the
<div n="lb">word at this occasion.] E. {#aBUta#} and {#tadBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6621<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtapUrva<k2>aBUtapUrva
{#aBUtapUrva#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rvaH-rvA-rvam#}) Not having existed
<div n="lb">before, unprecedented; e. g. {%Rāmāy. Yuddhak.:%} {#aBUtapUrvo#}
<div n="lb">{#rAmeRa seturbadDaSca sAgare#}. E. {#aBUta#} and {#pUrva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6622<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtaprAdurBAva<k2>aBUtaprAdurBAva
{#aBUtaprAdurBAva#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-vaH#}) Manifestation of what has
<div n="lb">not existed before; e. g. {%Kāś.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} {#(‘itTaMBUtena kftamiti#}
<div n="lb">{#ca’) kftamiti kriyAsAmAnye karotirvartate . nABUtaprAdurBAva eva#}
<div n="lb">‘the verb ‘to do’ of which ‘done’ is the past part. means
<div n="lb">in this Sūtra action in general, not (that special action
<div n="lb">which implies) manifestation of what has not existed be-
<div n="lb">fore’ i. e. {#kftam#} is there not to be taken literally, but as
<div n="lb">the general notion of verbal action. E. {#aBUta#} and {#prAdurBAva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6623<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtarajas<k2>aBUtarajas
{#aBUtarajas#}¦ Bahuvr. m. pl. ({#-saH#}) The name of a class of
<div n="lb">divinities in the fifth Manwantara; e. g. {%Hariv.:%} {#devAScABU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tarajasastaTA prakftayo'pare#} &c.; or {%Brāhma Pur.:%} {#devAScABU-#}
<div n="lb">{#tarajasastaTA prakftayaH smftAH;#} comp. {%Wilson'%}s {%Vishnup.%} p. 262.
<div n="lb">n. 15. E. {#aBUta#} and {#rajas#} lit. ‘in whom the condition of
<div n="lb">of Rajas or passionateness is non-existent’.
<LEND>

<L>6624<pc>303-a<k1>aBUtAharaRa<k2>aBUtAharaRa
{#aBUtAharaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) A covert or metaphorical ex-
<div n="lb">pression; {%Sāhityad.:%} {#…vyAjASrayaM vAkyamaBUtAharaRaM matam;#}
<div n="lb">as in the following instance where the death of Aśvatthā-
<div n="lb">man is reported under the metaphor of a prostrate elephant:
<div n="lb">{#aSvatTAmA hata iti pfTAsUnunA spazwamuktvA svEraM Seze gaja iti#}
<div n="lb">{#kila vyAhftaM satyavAcA#}. E. {#aBUta#} and {#AharaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6625<pc>303-a<k1>aBUti<k2>aBUti
{#aBUti#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-tiH#}) <sup>1</sup> Non-existence, non-entity; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Vājas.:%} {#aBUtyE svapanam#} (in the Purushamedha the priest
<div n="lb">consecrates a drowsy man as a symbol of Sleep to Non-
<div n="lb">existence). <sup>2</sup> The not being, the not becoming of; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Śatap.%} or {%Bṛhadār.:%} {#tadDEtatpaSyannfzirvAmadevaH pratipede . ahaM#}
<div n="lb">{#manuraBavaM sUryaSceti tadidamapyetarhi ya evaM vedAhaM brahmAsmIti sa#}
<div n="lb">{#idaM sarvaM Bavati tasya ha na devAScanABUtyA ISata#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#devA#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAvIryASca na api aBUtyE aBavanAya brahmasarvaBAvasya neSate#}
<div n="lb">{#na paryAptAH;#} {%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBUtyE sarvAtmakabrahmaBAvasyABavanAya na#}
<div n="lb">{#paryAptAH#} ‘they are not able to prevent him to become
<div n="lb">Brahma’). E. {#a#} neg. and {#BUti#}.
<LEND>

<L>6626<pc>303-a<k1>aBUmi<k2>aBUmi
{#aBUmi#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-miH#}) <sup>1</sup> Anything but earth, anything but
<div n="lb">a solid ground; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#SUlaM cABUmO#} ({%Yā-%}
<div n="lb">{%jnikad.:%} {#aDvaryustadDfdayaSUlaM na pfTivyAM nApsu nikzipet,#} he is
<div n="lb">not to put it down anywhere, i. e. he is to hold it up).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> No object for; e. g. {%Śākunt.:%} {#sa Kalu manoraTAnAmaBUmirvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#sarjanAvasarasatkAraH#} (comm. {#aBUmiH = avizayaH#}) ‘the honour
<div n="lb">(Indra conferred on me) at the occasion of dimissing me,
<div n="lb">was indeed no object for (i. e. beyond) my wishes’; or
<div n="lb">{%Śiśupālabadha:%} {#aBUdaBUmiH pratipakzajanmanAM BiyAm#} (comm.
<div n="lb">{#aBUmiravizayaH#}) ‘he was no object for fear from enemies’,
<div n="lb">i. e. he was fearless. [<sup>3</sup> A bad or unsuitable ground.] E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. or deter. and {#BUmi#}.
<LEND>

<L>6627<pc>303-a<k1>aBUmija<k2>aBUmija
{#aBUmija#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jaH-jA-jam#}) Not grown in (arable)
<div n="lb">lands, grown in marsh-lands; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#anArtavaM vyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DihatamaparyAgatameva ca . aBUmijaM navaM cApi na DAnyaM guRava-#}
<div n="lb">{#tsmftam . navaM DAnyamaBisyandi laGu saMvatsarozitam#} &c. [For
<div n="lb">the culture of rice in India in dry arable lands and in
[Page303-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">marsh-lands (the flooded rice) comp. {%Crawfurd'%}s {%Indian%}
<div n="lb">{%Archip.%} I. p. 357 ff.; and for the medicinal effect of either,
<div n="lb">{%Ainslie'%}s {%Materia Indica%} I. 341. ‘the produce of the {%caar%}
<div n="lb">crop (the flooded rice) which is reapt in October, he (Aga-
<div n="lb">stya) considers as of a different quality; this he says {%“will%}
<div n="lb">{%bring on indigestion, flatulency, eruptions on the skin, and%}
<div n="lb">{%other evils;”%} he finishes by saying, that {%“a person had%}
<div n="lb">{%better beg his bread, than eat the rice of the caar crop”.%}] E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#BUmija,#} or {#aBUmi -ja#}.
<LEND>

<L>6635<pc>303-b<k1>aBeda<k2>aBeda
{#aBeda#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-daH#}) <sup>1</sup> Undividedness, close union; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Hitop.:%} {#aBedena ca yuDyeyU rakzeyuSca parasparam;#} or {%Bhartṛh.%}
<div n="lb">{%Śriṅgāraś.:%} {#adarSane darSanamAtrakAmA dfzwA parizvaNgarasEkalo-#}
<div n="lb">{#lA . AliNgitAyAM punarAyatAkzyAmASAsmahe vigrahayoraBedam#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Sameness, identity; e. g. {%Kaiyy.%} (on {%Patanj.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} I.
<div n="lb">1. 9.): {#spfzwatAdyaBedAdvivArAdiBede'pi yaTA Bavati taTA spf-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwatAdiBede'pi vivArAdyaBedAtprApnotIti praSnaH;#} or {%Bharatas.%}
<div n="lb">on {%Bhaṭṭik.%} 1. 21.: {#kzatriyatvaM brAhmaRatvaM cAnyonyaprayojanakaM jA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tivyaktyoraBedopacArAt#}.--The term is of frequent occur-
<div n="lb">rence in {%philosophical%} works; e. g. {%Viśvan.%} on a {%Nyāya S.:%}
[Page304-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#guRaguRinoraBedo na;#} or {%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#AYjasyAdaBedato#}
<div n="lb">{#vA guRasAmAnyAdestatsidDiH praDAnavyapadeSAdvA;#} or {%Sāṅkhya%}
<div n="lb">{%Tattwak.:%} {#aDyavasAyo budDiH . kriyAkriyAvatoraBedavivakza-#}
<div n="lb">{#yA…budDeH yo'DyavasAyo budDerasADAraRavyApArastadaBedA#}
<div n="lb">{#budDiH#}. In the {%Vedānta%} {#aBeda#} is especially applied to {%the%}
<div n="lb">{%identity of the universal and individual soul%} or of the {%Deity%}
<div n="lb">and the {%world;%} e. g. {%Vedāntasāra:%} {#anayorvyazwisamazwyorvanavfkza-#}
<div n="lb">{#yoriva jalASayajalayoriva cABedaH . etadupahitayorISvara-#}
<div n="lb">{#prAjYayorapi vanavfkzAvacCinnAkASayoriva jalASayajalagataprati-#}
<div n="lb">{#bimbAkASayoriva cABedaH#}. This view of identity is refuted
<div n="lb">by the {%Nyāya-Vaiś.;%} e. g. in this passage of the {%Siddhānta-%}
<div n="lb">{%mukt.:%} {#satyaM jYAnamiti brahmaparaM jIvezu nopayujyate jYAnAjYA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nasuKitvaduHKitvAdiBirjIvAnAM BedasidDO sutarAmISvaraBedaH#}
<div n="lb">(ed. Calc. 1827; the reading {#ºSvarABedaH#} in Dr. {%Röer'%}s ed.
<div n="lb">seems a misprint) {#. anyaTA banDamokzAnupapatteH . yo'pISva-#}
<div n="lb">{#raBedaboDako vedaH so'pi tadaBedena tadIyatvaM pratipAdayanstO-#}
<div n="lb">{#ti . aBedaBAvane ca yatitavyamiti vadati . ata eva sarva eva#}
<div n="lb">{#Atmani samarpitAH SrUyante . mokzadaSAyAmajYAnanivfttAvaBedo#}
<div n="lb">{#jAyata ityapi na . Bedasya nityatvena nASAyogAt . BedanASe#}
<div n="lb">{#'pi vyaktidvayaM sTAsyatyeva#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Beda#}.
<div n="P">II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-daH-dA-dam#}) <sup>1</sup> Undivided, closely
<div n="lb">joined; e. g. {%Siddhāntamukt.:%} {#karmaDArayasTale tu nIlotpalami-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyAdAvaBedasaMbanDena nIlapadArTa utpalapadArTe prakAraH . na ca#}
<div n="lb">{#tatra lakzaRA#}. [<sup>2</sup> Identical.] E. {#a#} priv. and {#Beda#}.
<LEND>

<L>6636<pc>304-a<k1>aBedaka<k2>aBedaka
{#aBedaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-dakaH-dikA-dakam#}) Not dividing,
<div n="lb">not separating, not producing a difference; e. g. {%Patanjali%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Kātyāy. Vārtt.%} {#BedakatvAdguRasyeti vaktavyam#} (to {%Pāṇ.%} I.

<L>6637<pc>304-a<k1>aBedya<k2>aBedya

<div n="lb">penetrable; e. g. {%Sāyaṇa%} on {%Ṛgv.%} (VI. 28. 2.): {#aBinne =#}
<div n="lb">{#SatruBiraBedye (sTale) nidaDAti;#} also in a moral sense: {%in-%}
<div n="lb">{%corruptible, indestructible;%} e. g. {%Kull.%} on {%Manu%} (7. 64.):
<div n="lb">({#SuciH#} i. e.) {#arTastrISOcayuktaH . tena DanastrIdAnAdinABedyaH,#}

<div n="lb">{%not to be differenced,%} e. g. {%Mahābh.:%} {#mAnaso nAma pUrvo'pi#}

<L>6639<pc>304-a<k1>aBoktf<k2>aBoktf
{#aBoktf#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktA-ktrI-ktf#}) Not enjoying, not using,
<div n="lb">(not keeping; comp. {#aBuj#}). Comp. the following. E. {#a#}
<div n="lb">neg. and {#Boktf#}.
<LEND>

<L>6640<pc>304-a<k1>aBoktftva<k2>aBoktftva
{#aBoktftva#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-tvam#}) The condition of one who does
<div n="lb">not enjoy; in the {%Sāṅkhya phil.%} the condition of {%Prakṛti%}
<div n="lb">or Matter in contradistinction from that of {%Purusha%} or Soul,
<div n="lb">for whose benefit or enjoyment the former is created; e. g.
[Page304-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%Sāṅkhya Prav.:%} {#praDAnasfzwiH parArTaM svato'pyaBoktftvAduzwra-#}
<div n="lb">{#kuNkumavahanavat#} ‘Matter is created on account of some one
<div n="lb">other; for though its creation is spontaneous, it cannot
<div n="lb">enjoy (being unintelligent), like as a camel carries saffron
<div n="lb">(for some one else, i. e. for its master)’. E. {#a#} neg. and
<div n="lb">{#Boktftva#}.
<LEND>

<L>6641<pc>304-b<k1>aBogin<k2>aBogin
{#aBogin#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gI-ginI-gi#}) Not enjoying,
<div n="lb">abstemious; e. g. {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aBogino'yaM tava vipra#}
<div n="lb">{#dehaH pIvA yatastadvada naH kzamaM cet#}. E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bogin#}.
<LEND>

<L>6642<pc>304-b<k1>aBogGan<k2>aBogGan
{#aBogGan#}¦ Tatpur. m. pl. ({#-GanaH#}) (ved.) Destroying those
<div n="lb">who do not sacrifice, killing the impious; an epithet of the
<div n="lb">Maruts; {%Ṛgv.:%} {#yuvAno rudrA ajarA aBogGano vavakzuraDri-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAvaH parvatA iva#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#ye devAnhavirBirna Bojayanti tezAM#}
<div n="lb">{#hantAraH#}). E. {#aBoj#} and {#han#}.
<LEND>

<L>6643<pc>304-b<k1>aBogya<k2>aBogya
{#aBogya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-gyaH-gyA-gyam#}) What cannot be
<div n="lb">enjoyed or used; e. g. {%Meghad.:%} {#snehA nAhuH kimapi viraha-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyApadaste hyaBogyA dfzwe vastunyupacitarasAH premarASIBavanti#}
<div n="lb">({%Wilson:%} ‘true love, no time nor distance can destroy; and
<div n="lb">independent of all present joy, it grows in absence, as re-
<div n="lb">newed delight, some dear memorials, some loved lines ex-
<div n="lb">cite’). Comp. the difference between this word and {#aBojya#}.
<div n="lb">E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bogya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6644<pc>304-b<k1>aBoj<k2>aBoj
{#aBoj#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-k#}) (ved.) Not giving (the gods) the
<div n="lb">enjoyment (of a sacrifice), impious; {%Sāy.%} (in his gloss. on
<div n="lb">{#aBogGan#} q. v.); {#BojayantIti BojaH . na Bojo'BojaH#}. E.
<div n="lb">{#a#} neg. and {#Boj#}.
<LEND>

<L>6645<pc>304-b<k1>aBojana<k2>aBojana
{#aBojana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not eating, as {%a symptom of%}
<div n="lb">{%disease,%} caused by want of appetite &c.); e. g. {%Shādvinśabr.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aTa yadAsya prajayA paSuzu SarIre vArizwAni prAdurBavanti vyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Dayo vA anekaviDA atisvapnamasvapnamatiBojanamaBojanamAlasyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vraRamajIrRanidrARyevamAdIni tAnyetAni sarvARi yamadevatyAnya-#}
<div n="lb">{#dButAni prAyaScittAni Bavanti .#} ({%Sāyaṇa:%} {#aBIjanamarucyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dinA#}). <sup>2</sup> Abstinence, fasting, as {%a religious act;%} e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Kātyāy. Śrautas.:%} {#aBojanaM tasyocCvAsAt;#} or as {%a penance%}
<div n="lb">(see {#prAyaScitta#}) for the expiation of sin; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#vedo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ditAnAM nityAnAM karmaRAM samatikrame . snAtakavratalope ca prAya-#}
<div n="lb">{#ScittamaBojanam;#} or {%Bharadvāja:%} {#nirAcArasya viprasya ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zidDAcaraRasya ca . annaM BuktvA dvijaH kuryAddinamekamaBojanam;#}
<div n="lb">(for the various modes of fasting, as practised in under-
<div n="lb">going the penances {#prAjApatya, sAntapana, mahAsAntapana, ati-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAntapana, kfcCraM, atikfcCra, taptakfcCra, pAdakfcCra, parAka,#}
<div n="lb">{#cAndrAyaRa#} &c. see s. vv. and s. v. {#prAyaScitta#}). In the verse
<div n="lb">of {%Manu%} 8. 49. which describes the five different means by
<div n="lb">which a creditor may obtain payment of a debt ({#DarmeRa#}
<div n="lb">{#vyavahAreRa cCalenAcaritena ca . prayuktaM sADayedarTaM paYcamena balena#}
<div n="lb">{#ca#}) {%Kullūka%} interprets the term {#Acarita#} ({%Sir W. Jones%} and
<div n="lb">and {%Colebr. Dig.%} I. 339. ‘distress’) according to {%Vrihaspati:%}
<div n="lb">{#dAraputrapaSUnhftvA kftvA dvAropaveSanam . yatrArTI dApyate'rTaM#}
<div n="lb">{#svaM tadAcaritamucyate;#} {%Medhātithi%} however qualifies the ‘sitting
<div n="lb">at the debtor's door’ by adding {#aBojana#} (viz. {#aBojanagfhI-#}
<div n="lb">{#tadvAropaveSanam#}) and {%Vijnāneśvara%} when quoting this verse
<div n="lb">of {%Manu%} in the {%Mit.%} on {%Yājnav.%} (2. 40.) renders {#Acaritena#}
<div n="lb">(misprinted in the 4<sup>to</sup> ed. {#acaritena#}) simply with {#aBojanena#}.
<div n="lb">(For this practice of fasting at the door of debtors which
<div n="lb">is familiar under the name of ‘sitting in Dherna’; comp.
<div n="lb">{%As. Res.%} IV. p. 332.) E. {#a#} neg. and {#Bojana#}.
<LEND>
[Page305-a+ 56]

<L>6648<pc>305-a<k1>aBojya<k2>aBojya
{#aBojya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-jyaH-jyA-jyam#}) <sup>1</sup> Not to be con-
<div n="lb">sumed by eating or drinking, unfit for food, prohibited
<div n="lb">as food; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#aBojyamannaM nAttavyamAtmanaH SudDimicCa-#}
<div n="lb">{#tA;#} or {%Mahābh. Śāntip.:%} {#cikitsakasya yaccAnnamaBojyaM rakzi-#}
<div n="lb">{#RastaTA . gaRagrAmABiSastAnAM raNgastrIjIvinAM taTA;#} (unfit
<div n="lb">for {%drinking%} e. g.) {%Vṛhat-Śātātapa:%} {#pItaSezaM tu yatkiMci-#}
<div n="lb">{#dBojane muKaniHsftam . aBojyaM taddvijasyAhurBuktvA cAndrAyaRaM#}
<div n="lb">{#caret;#} sometimes {%contrasted%} with ‘what is unfit to be {%drunk%}’
<div n="lb">and then used in the same sense as {#aBakzya;#} e. g. {%Śāntip.:%}
<div n="lb">{#pretAnnaM sUtikAnnaM ca yacca kiMcidanirdaSam . aBojyaM cApyapeyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca DenordugDamanirdaSam;#} but in general (though not always)
<div n="lb">the use of {#aBakzya#} is restricted to solid food while {#aBojya#}
<div n="lb">is said of eating and drinking; (comp. also the criticism of
<div n="lb">{%Kātyāy.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 3. 69. where the latter renders {#Bojya#}
<div n="lb">with {#Bakzya#} while he ought to have rendered it, according to
<div n="lb">{%Kātyāy.,%} {#aByavahArya#} q. v.; for {#BojyaH sUpaH#} and {#BojyA yavAgUH#}
<div n="lb">are, as {%Patanjali%} instances, as good expressions as others
<div n="lb">where {#Bojya#} is combined with articles of solid food; {%Patan-%}
<div n="lb">{%jali,%} it is true, defends at the same time {%Pāṇini%} by ob-
<div n="lb">serving that the derivatives of {#Bakz#} are sometimes used,
<div n="lb">too, in connexion with liquids or food in general, e. g. in
<div n="lb">{#abBakza#} or {#vAyuBakza;#} but {%in general%} the distinction, pointed
<div n="lb">out in the {%Vārttika%} of {%Kātyāy.%} is correct; {%Patanj.:%} {#kiM punaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kAraRaM na siDyati . BakzirayaM KaraviSade vartate . tena drave na#}
<div n="lb">{#prApnoti . nAvaSyaM BakziH KaraviSade vartate . kiM tarhi . anya-#}
<div n="lb">{#trApi vartate . tadyaTA . abBakzo vAyuBakza iti#}). For prohi-
<div n="lb">bited articles of food and the penances on eating such
<div n="lb">food see the quotation s. v. {#aBakzya#}. <sup>2</sup> One whose food
<div n="lb">must not be eaten; see the following; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#aBo-#}
<div n="lb">{#jyAnAM tu BuktvAnnaM strISUdrocCizwameva ca . jagDvA mAMsamaBakzyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca saptarAtraM yavAnpibet#} ({%Kull.:%} {#aº = aBojyAnnAnAm;#} {%Me-%}
<div n="lb">{%dhāt.:%} {#yezAmannaM na Bujyate te'BojyAH puruzAH#}). E. {#a#} neg.
<div n="lb">and {#Bojya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6649<pc>305-a<k1>aBojyAnna<k2>aBojyAnna
{#aBojyAnna#}¦ Bahuvr. m. f. n. ({#-nnaH-nnA-nnam#}) One whose food
<div n="lb">must not be eaten (because eating it makes impure or brings
<div n="lb">misfortune); e. g. {%Manu:%} {#ya ete#} (those mentioned in the
<div n="lb">preceding verses) {#'nye tvaBojyAnnAH kramaSaH parikIrtitAH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tezAM tvagasTiromARi vadantyannaM manIziRaH#} ‘…their food, the
<div n="lb">wise say, is (like) skin, bones and hair’. Such persons
<div n="lb">are, for instance, an insane man, a wrathful person, a
<div n="lb">thief, a public singer, a carpenter, a eunuch, a woman in
<div n="lb">her courses or in childbed, a backbiter, a tailor, a black-
<div n="lb">smith, a physician, a libidinous woman, a usurer &c.; see
<div n="lb">{%Manu%} 4. 205-221.; {%Yājnav.%} 1. 160-168.--One who has un-
<div n="lb">knowingly eaten the food of such persons must fast during
<div n="lb">three days; but, having eaten it knowingly he must per-
<div n="lb">form the penance called {%Kṛṣchhra,%} as if he had tasted
<div n="lb">seminal impurity, ordure or urine; according to {%Manu%} 4. 222.
<div n="lb">In another verse, however, {%Manu%} (11. 152.) is satisfied, if
<div n="lb">such a sinner drinks barleygruel for seven days and nights
[Page305-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(see the quot. s. v. {#aBojya#}). Comp. {%Raghunand.%} I. p. 317 ff.
<div n="lb">E. {#aBojya#} and {#anna#}.
<LEND>

<L>6650<pc>305-b<k1>aBOtika<k2>aBOtika
{#aBOtika#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-kaH-kI-kam#}) Not produced by
<div n="lb">the coarse or visible elements, intellectual.--In the
<div n="lb">{%Sāṅkhya philosophy%} {#aBOtikasarga#} is one of the creations or
<div n="lb">evolutions of {%Prakṛti%} or Matter, comprising the evolutions
<div n="lb">called {#liNgasarga#} ‘evolution of mind’ and {#BAvasarga#} ‘evolution
<div n="lb">of mental affections’, the other evolution of {%Prakṛti%} being
<div n="lb">{#BOtikasarga#} or {#BUtasarga,#} produced by the coarse elements and
<div n="lb">comprising eight classes of celestial beings (see {#brAhma, prA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jApatya, sOmya, Endra, gAnDarva, yAkza, rAkzasa, pESAca#})--in
<div n="lb">whom prevails the quality {#sattva#}--, five species of brute
<div n="lb">creation (tame animals, wild animals, birds, reptiles and
<div n="lb">immovable substances)--in whom prevails the quality
<div n="lb">{#tamas#}--, and the species man, with the predominant quality
<div n="lb">{#rajas;#} ‘both, the {#aBOtika#}--and the {#BOtika#}--evolutions,
<div n="lb">comprise therefore sixteen evolutions of Matter’. [This is, in
<div n="lb">my opinion, the bearing of {%Gaudapāda'%}s concluding remark
<div n="lb">on the {%Sāṅkhya-Kār.%} v. 54: {#evamaBOtikaH sargo liNgasargo BA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vasargo#}--cfr. v. 52--{#BUtasargo dEvamAnuzatEryagyona#}--cfr. v. 53--
<div n="lb">{#ityeza praDAnakftaH zoqaSasargaH#}]. E. {#a#} neg. and {#BOtika#}.
<LEND>

<L>6651<pc>305-b<k1>aByakta<k2>aByakta
{#aByakta#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-ktaH-ktA-ktam#}) I. Oiled, anointed,
<div n="lb">greased; e. g. {%Manu:%} {#nAYjayantIM svake netre na cAByaktAmanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vftAm . na paSyetprasavantIM ca tejaskAmo dvijottamaH;#} or {%Yājnav.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aputrA gurvanujYAto devaraH putrakAmyayA . sapiRqo vA sagotro#}
<div n="lb">{#vA GftAByakta ftAviyAt;#} or {%Kātyāy.:%} {#aByaktaSirasaM cEva#}
<div n="lb">{#nABivAdyetkaTaMcana;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#snehAByakte yaTA tvakze cakraM#}
<div n="lb">{#sADu pravartate . saMDayaH sADu vartante saMSlizwAH SlezmaRA taTA;#} or
<div n="lb">{#GftAByaktAgranetraM (vastiM) GftAktagudAya prayacCet;#} in the {%Atharv.%}
<div n="lb">verse (10. 1. 25.)--{#aByaktAktA svaraMkftA sarvaM BarantI duritaM#}
<div n="lb">{#parehi#}--the first word {#aByakta#} seems to represent the {%neuter%}
<div n="lb">in the sense of {#Gfta, aByaktAktA#} then being equivalent to
<div n="lb">{#GftAktA#}. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<div n="P">II. Approached, arrived, near; used by {%Yāska%} to ex-
<div n="lb">plain etymologically the word {#aBIka (aBIke'Byakte)#} and
<div n="lb">similarly by {%Sāyaṇa%} e. g. to {%Ṛgv.%} I. 71. 8.: {#aBIke'Byakte#}
<div n="lb">{#'Bigate'BiprApte#}. E. {#ac#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.

<L>6654<pc>305-b<k1>aByaNka<k2>aByaNka

<L>6655<pc>306-a<k1>aByaNga<k2>aByaNga
{#aByaNga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-NgaH#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, in general; e. g. {%Jai-%}
<div n="lb">{%minīyanyāyam.:%} {#jyotizwome SrUyate dIkzArTAByaNge…. tatra#}
<div n="lb">{#barhizi samUlacCedasyAByaNge navanItasya puroqASe yaTocitapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasya ca viDeyatayA sarvamavaSizwaM stAvakam#}. See also {#aByaYjana#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Rubbing the body with unctuous substances, smearing
<div n="lb">the body with oil, inunction; e. g. {%Suśr.:%} {#snAnAByaNgadivA-#}
<div n="lb">{#svapnaSItavyAyAmayozitaH . na Bajeta svarotsfzwo yAvanno balavA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nBavet#}.--{%Raghunandana%} quotes in the {%Śuddhitattva%} (II.
<div n="lb">p. 132) the following definition ({#AyurvedoktapAriBAzikaM#}) of
<div n="lb">the word: {#mUrDni dattaM yadA tElaM BavetsarvANgasaMgatam . sroto-#}
<div n="lb">{#BistarpayedbAhU aByaNgaH sa udAhftaH . tElamalpaM yadaNgezu na ca#}
<div n="lb">{#syAdvAhutarpaRam . sA mArzwiH pfTagaByaNgo mastakAdO prakIrtitaH#}
<div n="lb">‘when oil is applied to the head, goes over the whole
<div n="lb">body and delights with its flood the arms, this is called
<div n="lb">{%Abhyanga;%} but when little oil comes on the body and the
<div n="lb">arms are not much wetted, such partial inunction of the
<div n="lb">head &c. is called {%Mārṣṭi%}’. The medicinal effect of this
<div n="lb">practice is thus briefly described in the {%Rājanigh.:%} {#aByaNgo#}
<div n="lb">{#mArdavakaraH kaPavAtavinASanaH . DAtUnAM puzwijananaH sutvamvarRa-#}
<div n="lb">{#valapradaH . pAdAByaNgo'Ta nidrAkfccakzuzaH pAdarogahA . cakzuzi#}
<div n="lb">{#pratibadDe dve Sire pAdagate nfRAm . ataScakzuHprasAdArTaM pAdA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByaNgaM samAcaret#} (comp. also {%Wise, Hindu syst. of Med.%} p. 93).
<div n="lb">A religious student, an anchorete and a widow are for-
<div n="lb">bidden to anoint themselves; {%Manu:%} {#(brahmacArI varjayet)#}
<div n="lb">{#aByaNgamaYjanaM cAkzRorupAnacCatraDAraRam#}); {%Prachetas%} (as quoted
<div n="lb">by {%Raghunand.%}): {#tAmbUlAByaYjanaM cEva kAMsyapAtre ca Bojanam .#}
<div n="lb">{#yatiSca brahmacArI ca viDavA ca vivarjayet#}). <sup>3</sup> Unguent, lini-
<div n="lb">ment; e. g. {%Suśr.:%} {#sPowajanmarujAsrAvatvakpAkaH svedanaM jvaraH .#}
<div n="lb">{#daraRaM cApi mAMsAnAmaByaNge vizasaMyute#}. [<sup>4</sup> Applying colly-
<div n="lb">rium to the eyes. <sup>5</sup> Sediment of oil, oilcake ({%Wilson%})].
<div n="lb">See the following. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6656<pc>306-a<k1>aByaYjana<k2>aByaYjana
{#aByaYjana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) <sup>1</sup> Anointing, greasing, in general;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.:%} {#aByaYjanapraBfti karoti#} (scil. {#yUpA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAm#}); or {%Hitop.:%} {#durjanaH prakftiM yAti sevyamAno'pi ni-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyaSaH . svedanAByaYjanopAyEH SvapucCamiva nAmitam#}. <sup>2</sup> Making
<div n="lb">clear or bright, manifesting; (see the meaning 4.). <sup>3</sup> The
<div n="lb">same as {#aByaNga#} 2.; e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.:%} {#evaM pratiprasTAtA#}
<div n="lb">{#patnImaByaYjanAdi tUzRIm;#} or {%Manu:%} {#BojanAByaYjanAddAnAdya-#}
<div n="lb">{#danyatkurute tilEH . kfmiBUtaH SvavizWAyAM pitfBiH saha majjati#}.
<div n="lb">Sometimes used together and contrasted with a word
<div n="lb">meaning a partial inunction of the body such as appli-
<div n="lb">cation of collyrium to the eyes; e. g. {%Bhāgav. Pur.:%} {#aYja-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAByaYjanonmardastryavaleKAmizaM maDu . sragganDalepAlaMkArAMstyaje-#}
<div n="lb">{#yurye DftavratAH#}.--One of the great sacrifices (see {#sattra#}) which
<div n="lb">lasts 49 days, is called, on account of the daily anointments
<div n="lb">which form part of its ceremonial,--according to {%Śabara%}
<div n="lb">on the {%Jaiminīsūtras%} and some Mss. of the {%Jaim. nyāyamālāv.%}
<div n="lb">--{#aYjanAByaYjana#} (e. g. {%Śab.:%} {#astyaYjanAByaYjananAmakonapaYcA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SadrAtraH#} &c.; {%Jaim.nyāy.:%} {#astyaYjanAByaYjanasaMjYaka ekonapaYcA-#}
<div n="lb">{#SadrAtraH sattraviSezaH . tatra SrUyate . gOggulavena prAtaHsavane#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByaYjanaM pEludAraveRa mADyandine savane sOganDikena tftIyasavana#}
<div n="lb">{#iti#}), according to the {%Āśvalāyana-%} and {%Kātyāy. Śrauta S.%}
<div n="lb">{#AYjanAByaYjanIya#} q. v.; e. g. {%Kātyāy.:%} {#AYjanAByaYjanIye#}
<div n="lb">{#'BiplavAHzaw ..…yaTAsavanaM tEH#} (i. e. with butter pre-
<div n="lb">pared with {#guggulu, suganDitejana#} and {#pIludAru#}) {#savanezvAYja-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAByaYjane kurvIrannAgnIDre'harahaH;#} {%Yājnikad.:%} {#AYjanamakzRoH#}
[Page306-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">(Ms. E. I. H. 1362. on book 24. 3. 13.: {#aYjanamakzRoH#}) {#. aBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#YjanaM SarIrasyeti karkaH;#} on another occasion ({%Kātyāy.%} 21. 4. 26.)
<div n="lb">the term {#aByaYjana#} is, in the same combination with {#AYjana,#}
<div n="lb">said by the {%Saṅkṣiptasāra%} (as ‘extracted’ by {%Weber%}) to de-
<div n="lb">note merely the {%‘anointment of the feet’:%} {#AYjanamakzRoraYjanaM#}
<div n="lb">{#kajjalAdinA . aByaYjanaM ca pAdayostElAYjanam#}. <sup>4</sup> An unctuous
<div n="lb">substance, esp. oil or butter; e. g. {%Ṛgv.:%} {#AtmA pitusta-#}
<div n="lb">{#nUrvAsa ojodA aByaYjanam#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#aByaYjanamaByaYjanasADanaM Gf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tatElAdikam;#} but he proposes also to take {#aByaº#} as an
<div n="lb">accus., with an adv. sense, determining {#ojodA,#} viz. {#aBi-#}
<div n="lb">{#vyaktaM yaTA Bavati taTojodA,#} i. e. ‘imparting strength mani-
<div n="lb">festly’); or {%Śatap.:%} {#teBya AgateBya AYjanAByaYjane prayacCanti;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Mānava Kalpa S.:%} {#hastenAYjanAByaYjanalepaM nimArzwi#} ({%Kumā-%}
<div n="lb">{%rila:%} {#aByaYjanaM tElam;#} on a subsequent {%Sūtra:%} {#aYjanAByaYjana-#}
<div n="lb">{#pAtre tarhi drazwavye#}); or {%Suśr.:%} {#(cikitset…mftyuvaSaprayAtaM)#}
<div n="lb">{#tIkzRAYjanAByaYjanaDUmayogEH#} &c.; or {#tElamaByaYjane#} (in the butter)
<div n="lb">{#kAryaM kuzWe sarjarase'pi vA#} (at the treatment of the children-
<div n="lb">disease {#revatI#}); or {#nasyAByaYjanasekezu vidaDyAdyogatattvavit .#}
<div n="lb">{#KarASvASvatarolUkakaraBaSvaSfgAlajam#}. <sup>5</sup> A collyrium or appli-
<div n="lb">cation to the eye-lashes; see {#aYjana;#} e. g. {%Ṛgv., Atharv.:%}
<div n="lb">{#cittirA upabarhaRaM cakzurA aByaYjanam . dyOrBUmiH koSa AsI-#}
<div n="lb">{#dyadayAtsUryA patim;#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#cakzurevAYjanamAsIt#}). This last
<div n="lb">sense of the word is probably restricted to the vaidik pe-
<div n="lb">riod. E. {#aYj#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.

<L>6657<pc>306-b<k1>aByaDika<k2>aByaDika

<div n="lb">cellent, excessive, very much; e. g. {%Mahābh. Anuśās.:%} {#stri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAstvaByaDikaH sneho na taTA puruzasya vE;#} or {%Bharata:%} {#alaM-#}

<L>6664<pc>307-a<k1>aByantara<k2>aByantara
{#aByantara#}¦ I. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-raH-rA-ram#}) The reverse of
<div n="lb">{#vAhya#} and comp. {#antara#}. <sup>1</sup> Interior, being in the middle or
<div n="lb">between, included in; e. g. {%Manu:%} (the following are not to be
<div n="lb">invited at a Śrāddha) {#…brahmaviwparivittiSca gaRAByantara eva#}
<div n="lb">{#ca#} (one being in, i. e. belonging to, a college &c.); or
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#UcustadAgataM rAmamidamaByantarAH striyaH#} (the women
<div n="lb">who lived in the town); or {%Sāṅkhya Pravach.:%} {#na vAhyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByantarayoruparaYjyoparaYjakaBAvo'pi deSavyavaDAnAtsruGnapAwa-#}
[Page307-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#liputrasTayoriva;#} or a {%Kār.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} (IV. 1. 78.): {#SabdAntara-#}
<div n="lb">{#midaM vidyAdfzwamaByantaraM trizu#} ({%Kaiyyaṭa:%} {#tripraBftizu yadaByanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#ram#}); or {%Patanj.%} in the introd. on {%Pāṇ.:%} {#aByantaraSca samudAye#}
<div n="lb">{#'vayavaH;#} or {%the same:%} {#nanu BavAnapyaByantaro loke . aByantaro#}
<div n="lb">{#'haM loke na tvahaM lokaH;#} or the same on {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 135. v. 8:
<div n="lb">{#yastvasO DAtUpasargayoraBisaMbanDaH . tamaByantaraM kftvA DAtuH#}
<div n="lb">{#sADanena yujyate;#} or {%Śaṅkara%} (on the {%Ved. Sūtra:%} {#antara#}
<div n="lb">{#upapatteH#}): {#parameSvara evAkzaRyaByantaraH puruza;#} or {%the same%}
<div n="lb">(on the {%Sūtra%} {#adfzwAniyamAt#}): {#bahuzvAtmasu sarvagatezu prati-#}
<div n="lb">{#SarIraM vAhyAByantarAviSezeRa saMnihitezu manovAkkAyErDarmADarma-#}
<div n="lb">{#lakzaRamadfzwamupArjyate#}.--‘The {%Sautrāntika%} and {%Vaibhāṣika%}
<div n="lb">sects (of the Buddhists) admitting external ({#vAhya#}) and in-
<div n="lb">ternal ({#aByantara#}) objects, distinguish, under the first head,
<div n="lb">elements ({#BUta#}) and that which appertains thereto ({#BOtika#}),
<div n="lb">namely organs and sensible qualities; and under the second
<div n="lb">head, intelligence ({#citta#}) and that which unto it belongs
<div n="lb">({#cetta#})’. {%Colebroke'%}s {%Ess.%} I. p. 392; comp. {%Burnouf Introd.%} I.
<div n="lb">p. 448 ff.; {%Kœppen, Die Religion des Buddha%} I. p. 600 and
<div n="lb">the references given there. <sup>2</sup> Initiated in, familiar with,
<div n="lb">interested in; with a noun in the locative; e. g. {%Kātyāy.%}
<div n="lb">(on the admissibility of witnesses): {#aByantarastu niHkzepe sA-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzyameko'pi dApayet#} (v. 1. in the {%Vīramitr.:%} {#vAcayet#}) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#arTinA prahitaH sAkzI Bavedeko'pi yAcite;#} or {%Raghunand.:%}
<div n="lb">{#kAryezvaByantaro yaH syAdarTinA prahitaSca yaH . kulyAkulavivAdezu#}
<div n="lb">{#Baveyuste'pi sAkziRaH#}. <sup>3</sup> Near, intimate; e. g. {%Panchat.:%}
<div n="lb">{#tyaktAScAByantarA yena vAhyAByantarIkftAH . sa eva mftyumApnoti#}
<div n="lb">{#yaTA rAjA kakudrumaH#}. [It is doubtful, however, whether
<div n="lb">the correct form of the word is not in the {%latter sense%} {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#Byantara,#} when, by its taddhita-derivation, it would cor-
<div n="lb">respond in value with the compound {#aByantarIkfta;#} comp.
<div n="lb">e. g. the following verse of the {%Mahābh. Śāntip.%} 4787: {#A-#}
<div n="lb">{#Byantare prakupite vAhye copanipIqite . kzIRe koze Srute mantre#}
<div n="lb">{#kiM kAryamavaSizyate#}. See also the remark s. v. {#aByantarakaraRa#}.]
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ram#}) Interior, middle, the space within, lit. and
<div n="lb">fig.; e. g. {%Suśruta:%} {#yaH SyAvadantOzWanaKo'lpasaMjYaSCardyardito#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByantarayAtanetraH#} &c.; or {#sirABiraBisaMprApya viguRo'Byantare#}
<div n="lb">{#BfSam#} &c.; or {%Yājnav.:%} {#kfcCrAtikfcCro'sfkpAte kfcCro#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByantaraSoRite#} ‘…the penance Kṛchchhrātikṛchchhra
<div n="lb">(is the penalty) when the blood (of a Brahman) is {%shed,%} the
<div n="lb">penance Kṛ. when his blood still remains in his body (i. e.
<div n="lb">when he is beaten black and blue)’; or {%Ratnāvalī:%} {#devi#}
<div n="lb">{#taduttizWAvaH . AvAsAByantarameva praviSAvaH;#} or {%Meghad.:%}
<div n="lb">{#…nirvinDyAyAH paTi Bava rasAByantaraM saMnipatya strIRAmAdyaM#}
<div n="lb">{#praRayavacanaM viBramo hi priyezu;#} or {%Hitop.:%} {#ato'haM zaRmA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAByantare#} (within six months) {#tava putrAnnItiSAstrABijYAnka-#}
<div n="lb">{#rizyAmi#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#antara#} ({%Rāyam., Bhānud.%} &c. =
<div n="lb">{#aBigatamantaram#}).
<div n="P">II. Avyayībh. ({#-ram#}) Towards the interior, inwards;
<div n="lb">see the quotation s. v. {#aByantarAyAma#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#antara#}.
<LEND>

<L>6665<pc>307-b<k1>aByantarakaraRa<k2>aByantarakaraRa
{#aByantarakaraRa#}¦ Karmadh. ({#-Ram#}) The same as {#antaHkaraRam;#}
<div n="lb">and the reverse of {#vAhyakaraRa#}. This form of the word oc-
<div n="lb">curs in some Mss., but the more correct form is {#AByantara-#}
<div n="lb">{#karaRa#} q. v.; and the compound {#vAhyAByantarakaraRa#} which is
<div n="lb">of frequent occurrence in {%Vedānta-, Sāṅkhya-%} and {%Yoga%}
<div n="lb">writings, is to be analyzed therefore: {#vAhya-AByaº-kaº#}.
<div n="lb">E. see {#AByantarakaraRa#}.
<LEND>
[Page308-a+ 56]

<L>6666<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarakalA<k2>aByantarakalA
{#aByantarakalA#}¦ Karmadh. f. ({#-lA#}) Literally, interior art, i. e.
<div n="lb">art of wantonness. (It is mentioned in the second chapter
<div n="lb">of the {%Daśakumārach.%} as one in a long list of arts, a mother
<div n="lb">is to afford her daughter instruction in, if she wants to
<div n="lb">bring her up as a courtezan; this fine description of mater-
<div n="lb">nal duties is termed there {#gaRikAmAturaDikAraH,#} and com-
<div n="lb">prises amongst others:) {#sajIvanirjIvAsu ca dyUtakalAsvaByanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rIkaraRaM#} (initiation in the art of gambling with live and
<div n="lb">dumb objects) {#aByantarakalAsu vESvAsikajanAtprayatnena prayoga-#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaRam#} ‘making her learn from confidential friends how to
<div n="lb">become an arrant coquette’ &c. E. {#aByantara#} and {#kalA#}.
<LEND>

<L>6667<pc>308-a<k1>aByantaratas<k2>aByantaratas

<div n="lb">{#kAzWAni;#} or {%Suśr.:%} {#dfzwirvirUpA SvasanopasfzwA saMkucyate'Byanta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rataSca yAti#}. [In a word like {#vAhyAByantaratas,#} e. g. {%Sāhi-%}

<L>6668<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarAyAma<k2>aByantarAyAma
{#aByantarAyAma#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) (In Medicine.) A curvature
<div n="lb">of the spine, considered as one of the diseases produced
<div n="lb">by the derangement of the temperamental element {%air%} (see
<div n="lb">{#vAtavyADi#}) and thus described by {%Suśruta:%} {#aNgulIgulPaja-#}
<div n="lb">{#WarahfdvakzogalasaMSritaH . snAyupratAnamanilo yadi kzipati vega-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAn . vizwabDAkzaH stabDahanurBagnapArSvaH kaPaM vaman . aByantaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#Danuriva yadi namati mAnavaH . tadA so'ByantarAyAmaM kurute#}
<div n="lb">{#mAruto balI ..#} ‘When deranged {%air%} pervading fingers,
<div n="lb">ankles, belly, heart, chest and neck, contracts the muscles
<div n="lb">(of these parts), when the eyes and jaws of the patient
<div n="lb">become fixed and his sides (at it were) broken, when he
<div n="lb">vomits phlegm and his body is {%bent inwards%} (i. e. for-
<div n="lb">wards), such deranged {%air%} produces the disease {%Abhyantarā-%}
<div n="lb">{%yāma%}’. Comp. {#vAhyAyAma#}. E. {#aByantara#} (Avyayībh.) and {#AyAma#}.
<LEND>

<L>6669<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarIkaraRa<k2>aByantarIkaraRa

<div n="lb">familiar with; see the inst. s. v. {#aByantarakalA#}. [<sup>2</sup> Making
<div n="lb">a near friend (of a person); comp. the following.] E.
<div n="lb">{#aByantara,#} taddh. aff. {#cvi,#} and {#karaRa#}.
<LEND>

<L>6670<pc>308-a<k1>aByantarIkfta<k2>aByantarIkfta

<L>6671<pc>308-a<k1>aByamana<k2>aByamana

<L>6672<pc>308-a<k1>aByamanavat<k2>aByamanavat
{#aByamanavat#}¦ m. f. n. ({#-vAn-vatI-vat#}) With diseases; {%Yāska%}
<div n="lb">(on the word {#amavAn#} of {%Ṛgv.%} 4. 4. 1.: {#kfRuzva pAjaH prasitiM#}
<div n="lb">{#na pfTvIM yAhi rAjevAmavAM~iBena#}): {#yAhi rAjevAmAtyavAna-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByamanavAnsvavAnvA#} &c. ‘come like a king’, {#amavAn#} i. e.
<div n="lb">‘with ministers’ (viz. to obtain victory) or ‘with diseases’
<div n="lb">(to terrify thy enemies) or ‘with riches’ (viz. with a well
<div n="lb">supported army, and therefore to obtain victory); {%Durga%}
<div n="lb">on {%Yāska:%} {#yAhi rAjeva yaTA rAjA yAyAdamAtyavAnAvi-#}
[Page308-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#yukto (?) vijayAya taTA tvaM yAhi . aTavA yaTAByamanavAn .#}
<div n="lb">{#rogaBUtaH pareByo BayadAtA yAyAttaTA yAhi . aTavA yaTA#}
<div n="lb">{#svavAn . vittavAn . suBftasEnyo yAyAdvijayAya taTA yAhi#}
<div n="lb">(comp. also {%Sāy.%} on the same verse). E. {#aByamana,#} taddh.
<div n="lb">aff. {#matup#}.
<LEND>

<L>6673<pc>308-b<k1>aByamita<k2>aByamita
{#aByamita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) Also {#aByAnta#} q. v.
<div n="lb"><sup>1</sup> Sick, diseased. <sup>2</sup> Arrived, come, taken place; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Bhaṭtik.:%} {#tezAM nihanyamAnAnAM saMGuzwEH karRaBediBiH . aBUdaBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#mitatrAsamAsvAntASezadigjagat#} ({%Jayam.:%} {#aByaº = aBigata-#}
<div n="lb">{#trAsam;#} {%Bhar.:%} = {#prAptaBayam#}). <sup>3</sup> Uninjured; {%Durga%} (on
<div n="lb">{%Yāska'%}s explanation of {#amatra#} 6. 23.: {#amatro'mAtro mahAnBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vati . aByamito vA#}): {#aByamito vA syAt . anaBihiMsitaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kenacit#}--[The first meaning, for which no corroborative
<div n="lb">passage in the literature has come under my observation,
<div n="lb">rests on the authority of the {%Koshas%} of {%Amara, Hemach.,%}
<div n="lb">the {%Rājanigh.%} and the comm.--{%Kāśikā%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 2. 28.
<div n="lb">gives the instances {#aByamita#} and {#aByAnta#} (while the {%Siddhk.%}
<div n="lb">only has the simple forms {#amita#} and {#Anta,#} and {%Kātyāy.%}
<div n="lb">and {%Patanjali%} offer no remark at all), but without stating
<div n="lb">their meaning. {%Mādhava%} quotes in the {%Dhātuvṛ.%} the alleged
<div n="lb">{%Sūtra%} and the simple forms {#amita#} and {#Anta,#} but under
<div n="lb">{#am#} ‘to go, to honour, to sound’, not under {#am#} ‘to be
<div n="lb">sick’; and, what is more remarkable, {%Hemach.,%} too, quotes
<div n="lb">in the {%Dhātūparāyaṇa%} {#aByamita#} and {#aByAnta#} under {#am#} ‘to
<div n="lb">sound, to honour’ to which he refers {#am#} ‘to go’, but
<div n="lb">not under {#am#} ‘to be sick’. It will seem therefore, that
<div n="lb">the meaning ‘diseased’ of these participles is a doubtful
<div n="lb">one.--Unless {%Durga'%}s meaning ‘uninjured’ is merely con-
<div n="lb">structive or explanatory of a (possible) meaning ‘attacking’
<div n="lb">(viz. successfully attacking), the E. he has derived it from,
<div n="lb">is unknown to me.] E. {#am#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#} and
<div n="lb">āgama {#iw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6689<pc>309-a<k1>aByarTanA<k2>aByarTanA

<div n="lb">{#mama . nAnayAByarTanAyuktamuktapUrvaM smarAmyaham;#} or (a quotation
<div n="lb">in {%Rādhākāntad.'%}s {%Śabdak.%} s. v. {#alaMkAra#}): {#dozasyAByarTanA-#}

<div n="lb">by {%Vijnānabh.%} on {%Sāṅkhyapr.%} 6. 6.): {#aByarTanABaNgaBayena sA-#}
<div n="lb">{#DurmADyasTyamizwe'pyavalambate'rTe#}.--The neuter form {#aByarTana#}
<div n="lb">{#(-m)#} is objectionable (comp. {#arTanA, prArTanA#} and {%Pāṇ.%} III.
<div n="lb">3. 107.), although it occurs e. g. in a verse of the {%Śāntis.%} of
<div n="lb">{%Hœberlin'%}s {%Chr.,%} where the necessity of metre seems to have
[Page309-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">led to the grammatical inaccuracy: {#DanEryAcYAlabDErna na pari-#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavo'ByarTanaPalaM…nikAro'gre paScAdDanamahaha BostadDi#}
<div n="lb">{#niDanam#}. E. {#arT#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#yuc#}.

<L>6690<pc>309-b<k1>aByarTanIya<k2>aByarTanIya

<L>6691<pc>309-b<k1>aByarTayamAna<k2>aByarTayamAna
{#aByarTayamAna#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-naH-nA-nam#}) One who requests
<div n="lb">or solicits; e. g. {%Mitākṣ.%} (on {%Āpastamba%}): {#tatrApravfttasya#}
<div n="lb">{#pravartakaH prayojakaH . sa ca triprakAraH . AjYApayitAByarTayamAna#}
<div n="lb">{#upadezweti ca .…aByarTayamAnastu yaH svayamasamarTaH prArTanA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dinA macCatruM vyApAdayeti samarTaM pravartayati so'BiDIyate…#}
<div n="lb">In a {%legal%} sense the {#aByaº#} is therefore the instigator of a
<div n="lb">crime, who has not the power of doing the criminal act
<div n="lb">himself but {%requests%} another who has the power, to do it
<div n="lb">for him; while the {#AjYApayitf#} is the person who {%orders%} his
<div n="lb">subordinate to accomplish the criminal act, and the {#upadezwf#}
<div n="lb">the person who {%instructs%} others how to do it; all three be-
<div n="lb">longing to the category {#prayojaka#}. E. {#arT#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#SAnac#} and āgama {#muk#}.
<LEND>

<L>6696<pc>309-b<k1>aByarDa<k2>aByarDa
{#aByarDa#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-rDaH-rDA-rDam#}) (ved.) <sup>1</sup> The same as
<div n="lb">{#aByarRRa;#} e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#sa vA aByarDa ivetarABya AhutiByo#}
<div n="lb">{#juhoti#} ({%Sāy.:%} {#itarAByaH praDAnAhutiByaH sakASAdaByarDa iti#}
<div n="lb">{#saMnihitapradeSa eva na tAsAM sTAne#}); or {#ukTaM hi purorugfgGi#}
<div n="lb">{#purorugfgGyukTaM sAma graho'Ta yadanyajjapati tadyajustA hEtA#}
<div n="lb">{#aByarDa evAgna fgBya AsuraByarDo yajurByo'ByarDaH sAmaByaH#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Increasing, making prosperous. See the following. E.
<div n="lb">1. Probably {#arD#} (in the sense of {#ard#} to go), 2. {#fD,#} with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#ac#}.
<LEND>

<L>6697<pc>309-b<k1>aByarDayajvan<k2>aByarDayajvan

<div n="lb">the sacrificers, an epithet of Pūṣan; {%Ṛgv.:%} {#mimyakza yezu#}
<div n="lb">{#rodasI nu devI sizakti pUzA aByarDayajvA#} ({%Yāska:%} = {#aByarDa-#}
<div n="lb">{#yanyajati,#} explained by {%Durga:%} {#aByarDayannaBivarDayanyAjayati#}
<div n="lb">i. e. ‘he urges to make sacrifices, in making prosperous
<div n="lb">the sacrificer’; according to which gloss the word would
<div n="lb">be a {%Karmadh.; Sāyaṇa%} however: = {#stotFnaByarDayansamfdDA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nkurvan . yo yajati Danena pUjayati#}). E. {#aByarDa#} and {#yajvan#}.

<L>6702<pc>310-a<k1>aByarhitatva<k2>aByarhitatva

<L>6706<pc>310-a<k1>aByavadAnya<k2>aByavadAnya
{#aByavadAnya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-nyaH-nyA-nyam#}) (ved.) Not liberal,
<div n="lb">mean, miserly; {%Śatap. (= Bṛhadār.):%} {#mA no BavAnbaho-#}
<div n="lb">{#ranantasyAparyantasyAByavadAnyo'BUditi#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#mA BUnno#}
<div n="lb">{#'smAnaBi asmAneva kevalAnprati BavAnsarvatra vadAnyo BUtvA#}
<div n="lb">{#avadAnyo mA BUtkadaryo mA BUdityarTaH;#} {%Anandag.:%} {#vadAnyo#}
<div n="lb">{#dAnaSIlo viBave satyadAtA kadarya iti BedaH;#} {%Dwivedag.:%}
<div n="lb">{#anyasminnarTijane vadAnyo dAnaSIlo BUtvA no'smAnevABi#}
<div n="lb">{#aBilakzyAsmAnprati avadAnyaH kadaryo viBave satyadAtA mA#}
<div n="lb">{#BUdBavAn#}). E. According to the quoted commentators it
<div n="lb">would seem as if they looked upon {#aByavadAnya#} not as a
<div n="lb">compound but as representing two distinct words {#aBi#} and
[Page310-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#a#} (neg.)--{#vadAnya,#} since the negative {#a#} could otherwise
<div n="lb">not have been recognized by them, in conformity with
<div n="lb">grammar, between {#aBi#} and {#vadAnya#}. Whether this division
<div n="lb">of the word has taken place in the {%Bṛhadār.,%} it is pro-
<div n="lb">bably not possible to say; in the {%Śatap.,%} however, the ac-
<div n="lb">cent shows that {#aByavadAnya#} is {%one%} compound base. But as
<div n="lb">{#aBi#} imparts sometimes a negative sense (‘away’) to the
<div n="lb">latter part of a compound of which it is a former part
<div n="lb">(comp. {#aByaya, aBiharaRa#} &c.), it is more plausible per-
<div n="lb">haps to take {#avadAnya#} as another form of, and equivalent
<div n="lb">in meaning to the shorter and probably older {#vadAnya#} (from
<div n="lb">{#vadAna = avadAna#}), and to analyze therefore: {#aBi#} and
<div n="lb">{#avadAnya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6709<pc>310-b<k1>aByavaharaRa<k2>aByavaharaRa
