<L>6710<pc>310-b<k1>aByavahAra<k2>aByavahAra
{#aByavahAra#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) <sup>1</sup> Taking food, eating or drinking;
<div n="lb">comp. the preceding; ({%Hemach.%} = {#aSana;#} {%Bhūripr., Rājanigh.%}
<div n="lb">= {#Bojana#}) e. g. {%Manu:%} {#alpAnnAByavahAreRa rahaHsTAnAsanena#}
<div n="lb">{#ca . hriyamARAni vizayErindriyARi nivartayet;#} or {%Patanj.%}
<div n="lb">(in his {%introd.%} to {%Pāṇ.%}): {#vede Kalvapi payovrato brAhmaRaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#yavAgUvrato rAjanyaH . AmikzAvrato vESya ityucyate . vrataM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#nAmAByavahArArTamupAdIyate#}. The {%Kāśikā%} explains the meaning
<div n="lb">of {#Buj#} and the words {#nigaraRa#} and {#pratyavasAna#} with {#aByava-#}
<div n="lb">{#hAra#}. <sup>2</sup> Food; e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#so'hamaByavahArArTI tO dfzwvA#}
<div n="lb">{#kftaniScayaH#} &c.; or {%Kāśikā%} (on {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 125.): {#jamBaSabdo#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByavahAravAcI dantaviSezavAcI vA . SoBano jamBo'sya su-#}
<div n="lb">{#jamBo devadattaH . SoBanAByavahAraH SoBanadanto vA;#} comp.
<div n="lb">{%Siddhk.:%} {#jamBo Bakzye dante ca#}). E. {#hf#} with {#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6711<pc>310-b<k1>aByavahArya<k2>aByavahArya
{#aByavahArya#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-ryaH-ryA-ryam#}) Fit to be taken
<div n="lb">as food (solid or liquid); e. g. {%Vārtt.%} 1. to {%Pāṇ.%} VII. 3. 69.:
<div n="lb">{#BojyamaByavahAryamiti vaktavyam,#} with which words {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">criticizes {%Pāṇini%} for having either restricted the sense of
<div n="lb">{#Bojya#} to that of {#Bakzya#} (‘fit to serve as solid food’) or used
<div n="lb">{#Bakzya#} in the general acceptation of {#aByavahArya#}. {%Patanjali,%} it
[Page311-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">is true, defends {%Pāṇini%} (as he frequently sides with {%Pāṇini%}
<div n="lb">against the hypercriticisms of {%Kātyāyana%}) also on this oc-
<div n="lb">casion by alleging {#abBakza#} and {#vAyuBakza#} in evidence that {#Bakz#}
<div n="lb">(and, impliedly, that {#Bakzya#}) are used in a general sense;
<div n="lb">but on another occasion when he shows that there are
<div n="lb">words the bearing of which in the classical language can
<div n="lb">merely be established from the context in which they occur
<div n="lb">in the vaidik literature, and not be made out otherwise (see
<div n="lb">{#ekapada#}), he gives these very instances as a proof of his
<div n="lb">latter assertion, and admitting therefore that they belong to
<div n="lb">this exceptional category, corroborates thus involuntarily
<div n="lb">the view of {%Kātyāy.%} that {#Bakz#} cannot be applied to the word
<div n="lb">{#ap#} in a {%general sense,%} and much less to any other word
<div n="lb">having the sense of a liquid substance ({%Patanj. Introd.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aTavA santyekapadAnyapyavaDAraRAni tadyaTA . abBakzo vAyuBakza#}
<div n="lb">{#iti . apa eva Bakzayati vAyumeva BakzayatIti gamyate . evami-#}
<div n="lb">{#hApi sidDa eva na sADya iti;#} {%Kaiyy.:%} {#evaSabdaprayoge dvipada-#}
<div n="lb">{#mavaDAraRam . dyotakatvena evaSabdasyApekzaRAt . yadA tu dyota-#}
<div n="lb">{#kamantareRa sAmarTyAdavaDAraRaM gamyate tadA tadekapadamityucyate#}
<div n="lb">{#tatra sarva evApo BakzayantItyabBakzaSrutiH sAmarTyAnniyamamavagama-#}
<div n="lb">{#yati . apa eveti . ihApi nityAnityavyatirekeRa rASyantarA-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAvAtsidDaSabdopAdAnAnniyamo'vagamyate#}). But as {#Bakz#} {%is%}
<div n="lb">applied to {#ap,#} in the vaidik language, and as it seems
<div n="lb">strange that {%Pāṇini%} should have erred in the use of so
<div n="lb">common words as {#Bojya#} or {#Bakzya,#} it is possible also to ob-
<div n="lb">tain another result from this discussion of {%Patanjali,%} which
<div n="lb">would reconcile the observations he makes in his Introd.,
<div n="lb">with those he has appended to the quoted Sūtra, a result
<div n="lb">supported by many {%Sūtras%} of {%Pāṇini,%} viz. that {%Kātyāyana,%}
<div n="lb">far from being a contemporary of {%Pāṇini,%} as is stated in
<div n="lb">one of the ghost stories of the {%Kathāsaritsāgara,%} has lived,
<div n="lb">on the contrary, at another period, and that many {%Vārttikas%}
<div n="lb">of his must not be looked upon {%by us%} as impugning the ac-
<div n="lb">curacy of {%Pāṇini'%}s rules at the time when this grammarian
<div n="lb">wrote, but as commenting upon, extending and restricting
<div n="lb">the validity of these rules at a probably much later period
<div n="lb">of the Sanskṛt literature. See my Preface to the {%Mānava-%}
<div n="lb">{%Kalpa-Sūtras.%}
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-ryam#}) Food (in general); e. g. {%Rāmāy.:%} {#SucI-#}
<div n="lb">{#nyaByavahAryARi mUlAni ca PalAni ca;#} or {%Kāśikā:%} {#satfRamaBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vaharati . na kiMcidaByavahAryaM tyajatItyarTaH;#} or {#KaraviSadamaBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vahAryaM BakzaSabdenocyate#}. E. {#hf#} with {#ava#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#Ryat#}.
<LEND>

<L>6712<pc>311-a<k1>aByavahAryatva<k2>aByavahAryatva
{#aByavahAryatva#}¦ n. ({#-tvam#}) The condition of food; e. g. {%Nago-%}
<div n="lb">{%jibh.%} (on {%Kaiyy.:%} {#paya eva vratayati#}): {#vratayatIti . aByavahArya-#}
<div n="lb">{#tvenopAdatta ityarTaH#}. E. {#aByavahArya,#} taddh. aff. {#tva#}.

<L>6717<pc>311-b<k1>aByasat<k2>aByasat
{#aByasat#}¦ (?) Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) Frequently em-
<div n="lb">ploying. The correctness of this form, instead of {#aByasyat#}
<div n="lb">(see s. v. {#as#} cl. 4 with {#aBi#}), seems doubtful; it occurs
<div n="lb">in the given sense in {%Suśr.%} II. p. 470, 1. 7: {#(kroDaSokaBayA#}
<div n="lb">{#…uzRAtividAhinaH) nityamaByasato duzwo rasaH pittaM ca#}
<div n="lb">{#kopayet#}. (Comp. {#aByaset#} in {%Kull.%} on {%Manu%} 7. 43.) E. {#as#}
<div n="lb">(cl. 1 instead of cl. 4) with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>6718<pc>311-b<k1>aByasana<k2>aByasana
{#aByasana#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-nam#}) The same as (the more usual)
<div n="lb">{#aByAsa#} q. v.; e. g. {%Bhagavadg.:%} {#anudvegakaraM vAkyaM satyaM pri-#}
<div n="lb">{#yahitaM ca yat . svADyAyAByasanaM cEva vANmayaM tapa ucyate#}
<div n="lb">({%Śaṅk.:%} {#…yaTA SAnto Bava vatsa svADyAyaM yogaM cAnutizWa#}
<div n="lb">{#taTA te Sreyo BavizyatIti;#} {%Sadānanda:%} {#…yaTA Bo vatsa#}
<div n="lb">{#SAntastvaM Bava svADyAyamAcara . yogaM taTAnutizWa tvaM niHSreyaste#}
<div n="lb">{#Bavizyati . yaTAviDyAgamAByAso vANmayaM tapa ucyate;#} {%Arju-%}
<div n="lb">{%nam.:%} {#svAº = vedAByAsa;#} (comp. {#vyasana#} in the same sense,
<div n="lb">e. g. in this verse of the {%Hitop.:%} {#vipadi DEryamaTAByudaye kzamA#}
<div n="lb">{#sadasi vAkpawutA yuDi vikramaH . yaSasi cABirucirvyasanaM#}
<div n="lb">{#SrutO prakftisidDamidaM hi mahAtmanAm#}); or {%Raghuv.:%} (‘recon-
<div n="lb">cile to thee the cow by being constantly after her like
<div n="lb">as’…) {#vidyAmaByasaneneva prasAdayitumarhasi#}. E. {#as#} (cl. 4)
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6719<pc>311-b<k1>aByasanIya<k2>aByasanIya
{#aByasanIya#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yaH-yA-yam#}) The same as the
<div n="lb">following; e. g. {%Kumārila%} on a {%Mānava Kalpa S.:%} {#tarhyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dAnAdyAsAdanAntaM guRakARqamekEkatrAByasanIyam#}. E. {#as#} (cl. 4)
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar#}.
<LEND>

<L>6720<pc>311-b<k1>aByasitavya<k2>aByasitavya

<div n="lb">(&c., see {#as#} cl. 4 with {#aBi#}); e. g. {%Jaiminīyanyāy.:%} {#tataH#}
<div n="lb">{#pratipaSu sakfttvamaBiDAtumekaDetyayaM mantro'ByasitavyaH#}. E. {#as#}
<div n="lb">(cl. 4) with {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#tavya#}.
<LEND>

<L>6721<pc>311-b<k1>aByasUyaka<k2>aByasUyaka
{#aByasUyaka#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-yakaH-yikA-yakam#}) <sup>1</sup> In the habit
<div n="lb">of detracting or calumniating, detractor, calumniator; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Bhagavadg.:%} {#mAmAtmaparadehezu pradvizanto'ByasUyakAH . tAnahaM#}
<div n="lb">{#…kzipAmyajasramaSuBAnAsurIzveva yonizu#} ({%Arjunam.:%} =
<div n="lb">{#sanmArgavartinAM guRezu dozAropakAH;#} {%Sadānanda:%} {#nanu gurvAdayaH#}
<div n="lb">{#SizwAH kaTaM tAnnAnuSAsati . ityatrAhAByasUyante (ºyAM te?)#}
<div n="lb">{#kurvantaH sajjanezvapi . vedamArge sTitAnAM te kAruRyAdiguRezva-#}
<div n="lb">{#pi . pratAraRAdidozARAmAropaRasvaBAvakAH#} ‘…intimating
<div n="lb">that their kindness &c. is merely deceit &c.’). <sup>2</sup> Envious,
<div n="lb">spiteful; ({%Śaṅk.%} on the word {#aByaº#} in the quoted verse:
<div n="lb">{#sanmArgasTAnAM guRezvasahamAnAH#})--Comp. {#asUyaka#} and the
<div n="lb">following.--E. {#asU (N)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#vuY#} (im-
<div n="lb">plying here habit or disposition).
<LEND>

<L>6722<pc>311-b<k1>aByasUyA<k2>aByasUyA
{#aByasUyA#}¦ Tatpur. f. ({#-yA#}) <sup>1</sup> Detraction, calumny; e. g. {%Bhaṭṭik.:%}
<div n="lb">{#anirvftaM BUtizu gUQavEraM satkArakAle'pi kftAByasUyam . vi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BinnakarmASayavAkkule no mA jYAticelaM Buvi kasyacidBUt#} ({%Bha-%}
<div n="lb">{%ratam.:%} {#kftAByasUyaM kftAmarzaM guRe'pi dozAvizkaraRamasUyA#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Envy, spite; e. g. {%Raghuv.:%} {#jagmuH… . BojyAM prati vyarTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#manoraTatvAdrUpezu veSezu ca sAByasUyAH#} ({%comm.:%} {#IrzyAsahitAH#});
[Page312-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">or {#…dilIpaH . atizWadekonaSatakratutve SakrAByasUyAvini-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfttaye yaH#} ({%comm.:%} {#indrasyerzyAnirAkaraRArTam#}). [The learned
<div n="lb">Paṇḍits who partly complied and partly composed the
<div n="lb">comm. on the present edition of {%Pāṇini%} seem to have
<div n="lb">employed {#aByasUyA#} in the sense of ‘abuse, reproof’, or:
<div n="lb">‘derision’, when they observe on {%Pāṇ.%} VIII. 2. 94.: {#adya#}
<div n="lb">{#amAvasyA#} (the opinion of the person which, as the inter-
<div n="lb">locutor has shown, is wrong) {#ityevaM vAdI yuktyA svamatAtpra-#}
<div n="lb">{#cyAvya sAByasUyamanuyoktrEvamanuyujyate,#} for there is neither {%ca-%}
<div n="lb">{%lumny%} nor {%envy%} in what the {%anuyoktṛ%} says, but only {%reproof%}
<div n="lb">or perhaps {%derision;%} on what authority they have used the
<div n="lb">word in this sense is unknown to me, for there is no com-
<div n="lb">ment on the Sūtra by {%Kāty.%} and {%Patanj.%} &c., and the {%Kāś.%}
<div n="lb">and {%Siddhk.%} write: {#adyAmAvAsyetyevaM vAdinaM yuktyA pracyAvya#}
<div n="lb">{#svamatAdevamanuyujyate#}.]--The same as {#asUyA;#} {%Śabdārnava:%}
<div n="lb">{#asUyA tvaByasUyA ca;#} as quoted also by {%Bhānud.,%} &c. on the
<div n="lb">{%Amarak.;%} the latter work, however, and its comment., as
<div n="lb">well as other {%old%} authorities do not allow {#asUyA#} to be a
<div n="lb">synonyme of {#Irzya#} ‘envy’, but restrict its sense to the first
<div n="lb">meaning. See s. v. {#asUyA#}.--E. {#asU (N)#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#a#}.
<LEND>

<L>6723<pc>312-a<k1>aByasta<k2>aByasta
{#aByasta#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-staH-stA-stam#}) <sup>1</sup> Accumulated by
<div n="lb">repeated practice; e. g. {%Suśr.%} (of {%food%}): {#viSuzkamannamaByastaM#}
<div n="lb">{#na pAkaM sADu gacCati;#} or {%the same%} (of {%qualities which are re-%}
<div n="lb">{%born in a future life%}): {#karmaRA codito yena tadApnoti punarBave .#}
<div n="lb">{#aByastAH pUrvadehe ye tAneva Bajate guRAn#}. <sup>2</sup> Repeatedly done,
<div n="lb">repeated, frequently practised; e. g. {%Mitākṣ.:%} {#yadA tvetadeva#}
<div n="lb">{#vimiSritaM paYcagavyaM trirAtramaByasyate tadA yatisAntapanasaMjYA#}
<div n="lb">{#laBate . etadeva tryahAByastaM yatisAntapanaM smftam;#} or {%Amaruśat.:%}
<div n="lb">{#BrUBedo racitaSciraM nayanayoraByastamAmIlanam#} &c.; or {%Mṛchchh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#kAlasyAlpatayA ca cIvarakftaH skanDe na jAtaH kiRaH . nAByastA ca#}
<div n="lb">{#kazAyavastraracanA#} &c. Comp. also s. v. {#AkUpAra#}. <sup>3</sup> Mentally re-
<div n="lb">peated, learnt by heart, studied; e. g. {%Bhartṛh.:%} {#nAByastA Buvi#}
<div n="lb">{#vAdivfndadamanI vidyA vinItocitA…SUnyAlaye dIpavat;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Nagojibh.%} (in the introd. on {%Patanj.%}): {#bahUnAmapi samAnapfzWoda-#}
<div n="lb">{#rapARipAdAnAmaDyayanamaDIyAnAnAmekaH kaScitpaSyannapi svaBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#stADyayano'pi tIkzRabudDirapi sanna paSyati . arTAnaBijYatvAt;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Mallin.%} (on {%Kiratārj.:%} {#sukftaH pariSudDa AgamaH kurute dIpa#}
<div n="lb">{#ivArTadarSanam#}) {#sukftaH svaByastaH#}. <sup>4</sup> (In {%Arithmetic.%}) Multi-
<div n="lb">plied; e. g. {%Yāska:%} {#viMSatidvidaSataH SataM daSadaSataH sahasraM#}
<div n="lb">{#sahasvadayutaM niyutaM prayutaM tattadaByastam#} &c. ({%Durga:%} {#sahasraM daSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#kftvo'ByastamayutaM…ayutamapi daSakftvo'ByastaM niyutami-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyucyate#} &c.); or {%Sūryasiddh.:%} {#trijyAByastaM BujaPalaM calakarRavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#BAjitam;#} or {#…tena#} (scil. {#BUpariDinA#}) {#deSAntarAByastA#}
<div n="lb">{#grahaBuktirviBAjitA#}. [In pure-arithmetical works this term
<div n="lb">is of less frequent occurrence than {#guRita, saMguRita, hata,#}
<div n="lb">{#Ahata, nihata#}.] <sup>5</sup> (In {%Grammar.%}) Reduplicated (but see
<div n="lb">{#aByasta#} {%neuter%}); e. g. {%Yāska:%} {#erira itIrtirupasfzwo'ByastaH;#}
<div n="lb">or {#rarivAn . rAtiraByastaH#}.--{%Yāska%} in using {#aByasta#} as a
<div n="lb">{%masc.%} and therefore, with the ellipsis of {#DAtu#} (q. v.) differs
<div n="lb">from {%Pāṇini%} who uses the word merely as a {%neuter;%} and
<div n="lb">in applying it to a radical like {#Ir,#} differs from {%Kātyāyana%}
<div n="lb">and {%Patanjali,%} probably also from {%Pāṇini;%} see the following.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-stam#}) (In {%Pāṇini%}); scil. {#aNga#} q. v. The {%redupli-%}
<div n="lb">{%cated base%} of a radical, in general, in the preterite ({#liw#}),
<div n="lb">the aorist ({#caN#}), the desider. ({#san#}) and the intens. ({#yaN#})
[Page312-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">--comp. VI. 1. 8. 9. 11.--, moreover the reduplicated base
<div n="lb">of a radical of the third class ({#hu#} &c. VI. 1. 10.) and the
<div n="lb">{%base%} (being in reality a reduplicated one) of {#jakz, jAgf,#}
<div n="lb">{#daridrA, cakAs, dIDI, vevI#} and {#SAs#} (to which {%Kātyāy.%}
<div n="lb">adds, though not with the consent of {%Patanj.%} and {%Kaiyy.:%}
<div n="lb">{#sas#} and {#vaS#} VI. 1. 6 and vv.), before a {#sArvaDAtuka,#} as well
<div n="lb">as the {%reduplicated base%} of a radical of the named categories
<div n="lb">in the participles (included in the foregoing terms) and in
<div n="lb">such derivatives as {#baBru, yayu, cakra, ciklida#} &c. (VI. 1. 12 vv).
<div n="lb">The term {#aByasta#} {%n.%} comprises therefore, in {%Pāṇini,%} the
<div n="lb">radical syllable {%and%} the syllable of reduplication (which
<div n="lb">latter is called by him {#aByAsa;#} VI. 1. 5.: {#uBe aByastam;#}
<div n="lb">VI. 1. 4.: {#pUrvo'ByAsaH#}); e. g. {#dadA#}--, and {#nenij#}--of
<div n="lb">{#dadAti#} and {#nenijati#} are {#aByastam#} ({#da#}--and {#ne#}--being
<div n="lb">in these words the {#aByAsa#}). {%Kātyāyana%} and {%Patanjali%} con-
<div n="lb">clude from this definition of {%Pāṇini%} that the term can only
<div n="lb">be used where there are {%two%} syllables representing the re-
<div n="lb">duplication and that it is not applicable to the first syllable
<div n="lb">in instances like {#Irtsanti#} (the desid. of {#fD#}) or {#Ipsanti#}
<div n="lb">(the desid. of {#Ap#}) ({%Kāty.:%} {#uBegrahaRaM saMjYinirdeSArTam;#}
<div n="lb">{%Pat.:%} {#antareRApyuBegrahaRaM prakftaH saMjYinirdeSaH . kaTaM dve iti#}
<div n="lb">{#vartate . idaM tarhi prayojanam;#} {%Kāty.:%} {#yatroBe SabdasvarUpe SrUyete#}
<div n="lb">{#tatrAByastasaMjYA yaTA syAt;#} {%Pat.:%} {#iha mA BUt . Irtsanti Ipsa-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntIti . Irtsan . Ipsan . Ertsan . Epsan#}). [The learned
<div n="lb">Paṇḍits who partly complied and partly composed the
<div n="lb">comm. of the present ed. of {%Pāṇ.%} have been mistaken, con-
<div n="lb">sequently, when they supply at the term {#aByasta#} the word
<div n="lb">{#DAtu,#} instead of {#aNga,#} in their gloss on VI. 1. 189. (‘{#aByasta-#}
<div n="lb">{#saMjYakAnAM DAtUnAm#} &c.’ instead of {#…aNgAnAm#}); for
<div n="lb">such an ellipsis would unduly restrict the bearing of the
<div n="lb">rule and be at variance not merely with the process of re-
<div n="lb">duplication as conceived by {%Pāṇini%} (I. 1. 59.), but with the
<div n="lb">neuter gender of the term. {%Pāṇini,%} it is true, calls the
<div n="lb">seven quoted radicals {#jakz#} &c. {#‘aByasta’#} (whence {%Patanjali%}
<div n="lb">speaks of {#sapta jakzityAdayo'ByastasaMjYakAH#}--scil. {#DAtavaH#}--,
<div n="lb">and the {%Kāś.%} comments {#jakza ityayaM DAturityAdayaScAnye zaq#}
<div n="lb">{#DAtavo'ByastasaMjYakA Bavanti,#} which is a much clearer para-
<div n="lb">phrase of the {%Vārtt.%} and {%Bhāṣya,%} than the modern gloss
<div n="lb">which renders {#zaz#} of the Sūtra simply with {#saptan#}), but,
<div n="lb">not to speak of the exceptional nature of these radicals
<div n="lb">which are not of a primitive kind, is is obvious that {%Pā-%}
<div n="lb">{%ṇini,%} in connecting the {%neuter%} {#aByastam#} (of the preceding
<div n="lb">Sūtra) with the word {#jakzityAdayaH#} (of the following), did
<div n="lb">not mean the {#DAtu,#} but the {#aNga#} of these radicals, espe-
<div n="lb">cially as he treats of the rules concerning the {#aByasta,#} in
<div n="lb">the chapter on {#aNga#} (VI. 4. 1. to the end of the seventh
<div n="lb">book). The same inaccuracy of supplying the word {#DAtu,#}
<div n="lb">instead of {#aNga,#} has been frequently committed by the same
<div n="lb">Paṇḍits in the last named chapter (e. g. VII. 4. 69. 73. 84. 85.
<div n="lb">86. 87. 88. 89. 90. 91. 92. 96. 97. &c. &c. where the {%Kāśikā%} either
<div n="lb">omits the word supplied or has {#aNga#}), but even {%Jayāditya%}
<div n="lb">himself has nodded, though rarely.--{%One%} Sūtra may, in-
<div n="lb">deed, lead to the assumption that {%Pāṇini,%} too, speaks of
<div n="lb">a {#DAtu#} which is {#aByasta,#} but merely apparently; VI. 1. 32. he
<div n="lb">rules {#hvaH saMprasAraRam#} ‘there is {%samprasāraṇa%} of the radical
<div n="lb">{#hve#}’; and VI. 1. 33. he adds {#‘aByastasya’;#} this latter word,
[Page313-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">however, does not mean ‘when {#hve#} is {#aByasta#}’, but, acc. to
<div n="lb">{%Kāty.%} and {%Pat.,%} when there is a reason for making ‘a re-
<div n="lb">duplicated base’ of {#hve#} (viz. in the desid., intens. &c.); for
<div n="lb">it is not this base (of two syllables) that suffers {%sampra-%}
<div n="lb">{%sāraṇa,%} but the radical when it is {%not yet%} a reduplicated
<div n="lb">base; properly speaking {#aByastanimitte#} would have been
<div n="lb">therefore a better Sūtra than {#aByastasya;#} and, continues
<div n="lb">{%Kātyāy.,%} if {%Pāṇini%} meant to rule that a reduplicated base
<div n="lb">({#aByasta#}) suffers {%sampr.,%} a prohibition was at least required
<div n="lb">for the syllable of reduplication ({#aByAsa#}) &c.: {%Patanj.:%} {#hvo#}
<div n="lb">{#'Byastasyetyucyate . na cEtad hvo'Byastam . kasya tarhi hvAyayateH .#}
<div n="lb">{#hva etadaByastam . kaTam . ekAco dve praTamasyeti#} (VI. 1. 1.) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#evaM tarhi hvayateraByastasyetyucyate . na cAtra hvayatiraByastam .#}
<div n="lb">{#kastarhi . hvAyayatiH . hvayatirevAtrAByastam . kaTam . ekAco#}
<div n="lb">{#dve praTamasyetyevamapi; ..#} {%K. Vārtt.:%} {#aByastanimitte'naByastasaMpra-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAraRArTam ..;#} {%Pat.:%} {#aByastanimitta iti vaktavyam . kiM prayoja-#}
<div n="lb">{#nam . anaByastasya saMprasAraRArTam . anaByastasya saMprasAraRaM yaTA#}
<div n="lb">{#syAt . juhUzati . johUyate ..;#} {%K. Vārtt.:%} {#aByastasya prasAraRe#}
<div n="lb">{#hyaByAsaprasAraRAprAptiH ..;#} {%Pat.:%} {#aByastaprasAraRe hi aByAsa-#}
<div n="lb">{#prasAraRasyAprAptiH syAt#} &c.--In the {%Vārtt.%} 1. to VI. 1.
<div n="lb">186. {#aByastasic#} is a Dwandwa, before it becomes com-
<div n="lb">pounded with the following {#arTa#}. E. {#as#} (cl. 4) with {#aBi,#}
<div n="lb">kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6724<pc>313-a<k1>aByastamaya<k2>aByastamaya
{#aByastamaya#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-yaH#}) (ved.) The setting of the sun
<div n="lb">with regard to (some act, i. e. while some act is taking
<div n="lb">place); e. g. {%Kātyāy. Śr. S.:%} {#anudDftAByastamaye#} (q. v.) {#kuSabadDe#}
<div n="lb">{#hiraRye paScAdDriyamARa iDmenodDaredArzeyo brAhmaRaH;#} or {%Yājni-%}
<div n="lb">{%kad.%} (on {%Kāty. Śr.-S.:%} {#AdityAByaye'hutAyAmapi#}): {#vapA-#}
<div n="lb">{#homAtpUrvamAdityAByastamaye#} &c. Comp. the following. E. {#aBi#}
<div n="lb">and {#astamaya#} (not {#aByastam#} and {#aya#}).
<LEND>

<L>6725<pc>313-a<k1>aByastamita<k2>aByastamita
{#aByastamita#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) One towards whom
<div n="lb">the sun has set (scil. while he is asleep), asleep at sunset;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Gotama:%} {#sUryAByudito brahmacArI tizWedaharaBuYjano'Bya-#}
<div n="lb">{#stamitaSca rAtriM japansAvitrIm#} (where the ellipsis ‘when
<div n="lb">asleep’ follows from the word {#svapna#} in the preceeding pas-
<div n="lb">sage: {#retaskandane Baye roge svapne'gnInDanaBEkzacaraRAni sapta-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAtraM kftvAjyahomaH sABisanDervA retasyAByAm#}).--This is the
<div n="lb">reading acc. to both Calc. edd. of {%Kullūka%} to {%Manu%} 2. 220;
<div n="lb">the Calc. ed. of {%Gotama'%}s {%Sanh.%} (made by {%Bhavanīcharana-%}
<div n="lb">{%vandya,%} as he says, {#bahuprayatnataH#}) has, however, {#sUryAByudite#}
<div n="lb">{#…(a)Byastamite ca…,#} when it would be necessary to
<div n="lb">take {#sUº#} as equivalent to {#sUryAByudaya#} and {#aByaº#} as expressing
<div n="lb">the sense of {#aByastamaya,#} both words being then locatives
<div n="lb">of a neuter {#ºtam#}. But {%Kullūka'%}s reading seems better as
<div n="lb">being countenanced by analogous expressions in {%Manu%} 2. 221.
<div n="lb">Comp. {#aBinirmukta#} and {#aByudita#}. E. {#aBi#} and {#astamita#} (not
<div n="lb">{#aByastam#} and {#ita,#} for {#aBi#} refers to the person or act con-
<div n="lb">cerned by the sunset; similarly in ved. passages which
<div n="lb">contain the combination {#aByastamagAt#} or {#aByastamiyAt,#} the
<div n="lb">rad. {#gA#} or {#i#} are combined first with {#astam#} and then with
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} not with {#aByastam#}); see also the preceding.
<LEND>

<L>6726<pc>313-a<k1>aByastasvara<k2>aByastasvara
{#aByastasvara#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-raH#}) The accent of reduplicated bases
<div n="lb">(see {#aByasta#} 2.), i. e. the udātta on the first syllable; e. g.
<div n="lb">a {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} VI. 1. 188.: {#svapAdInAM vA vacanAdastasvaro#}
<div n="lb">{#vipratizeDena;#} or {%Pat.%} on a {%Vārtt.%} to VI. 1. 192.: {#aByastasvaro#}
<div n="lb">{#'tra bADako Bavizyati#}. E. {#aByasta#} and {#svara#}.
<LEND>
[Page313-b+ 56]

<L>6727<pc>313-b<k1>aByasyat<k2>aByasyat
{#aByasyat#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-n-ntI-t#}) See the meanings of
<div n="lb">{#as#} cl. 4, with {#aBi;#} e. g. {%(shooting) Mahābh. Ādip.:%} {#SI-#}
<div n="lb">{#GramaByasyato vARAnsaMdaDAnasya cAniSam . nAntaraM dadfSe kiM-#}
<div n="lb">{#citkOnteyasya yaSasvinaH;#} or {%(doing frequently) Mṛchchh.:%}
<div n="lb">{#vEdeSyena kfto Bavenmama gfhe vyApAramaByasyatA#} &c. Comp. {#aBya-#}
<div n="lb">{#sat#}. E. {#as#} (cl. 4) with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#Satf#}.
<LEND>

<L>6733<pc>313-b<k1>aByAgata<k2>aByAgata
{#aByAgata#}¦ Tatpur. m. f. n. ({#-taH-tA-tam#}) <sup>1</sup> Come, arrived; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Rāmāy.:%} {#aTa te mantrinaH sUtaM sumantraM sapurohitAH . Ucura-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByAgatAnasmAmrAjYe tvAvedayeti vE;#} frequently with the im-
<div n="lb">plied sense, ‘as a {%visitor%}’ and then also used absolutely as
<div n="lb">a {%masc. ‘visitor’;%} e. g. {%Hitop.:%} {#vAlo vA yadi vA vfdDo yuvA#}
<div n="lb">{#vA gfhamAgataH . tasya pUjA viDAtavyA sarvatrAByAgato guruH;#} or
<div n="lb">{#gururagnirdvijAtInAM varRAnAM brAhmaRo guruH . patireko guruH#}
<div n="lb">{#strIRAM sarvasyAByAgato guruH;#} or {%Mahābh. Udyogap.:%} {#ye cA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pyanye saMSritA DArtarAzwrAnnAnAdigByo'ByAgatAH sUtaputra . dfzwvA#}
<div n="lb">{#tAMScEvArhataScApi sarvAnsaMpfcCeTAH kuSalaM cAvyayaM ca . evaM sarvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAgatAByAgatAMSca rAjYo dUtAnsarvadigByo'ByupetAn . pfzwvA#}
<div n="lb">{#sarvAnkuSalaM tAMSca sUta paScAdahaM kuSalI tezu vAcyaH#} (comp. s. v.
<div n="lb">{#aBivAdana#}), in which passage {#AgatAByAgata#} might seem
<div n="lb">to be merely a poetical redundance to denote the great
<div n="lb">number of the arrived envoys, but the comm. of {%Chaturbhu-%}
<div n="lb">{%jam.%} is probably correct in distinguishing between the {#Agata#}
<div n="lb">or the {%guest%} (who makes a stay) and the {#aByAgata#} or the
[Page314-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">{%visitor%} (who soon leaves): {#AgatAn . tatrevAgatya sTitAn .#}
<div n="lb">{#aByAgatAn AgatAgatAnapi gamizyataH;#} for a similar dis-
<div n="lb">tinction is made between {#atiTi#} and {#aByAgata#} e. g. in this
<div n="lb">verse of the {%Bhāg.-Pur.:%} {#yastviha vA atiTInaByAgatAnvA#}
<div n="lb">{#gfhapatirasakfdupagatamanyurdiDakzuriva pApena cakzuzA nirIkzate#}
<div n="lb">{#tasya#} &c.; {%Hemach.,%} however, treats {#atiTi#} and {#aByAgata#}
<div n="lb">as convertible terms, the distinction being probably dropped
<div n="lb">in common language. <sup>2</sup> (In {%Law.%}) Come down by inheri-
<div n="lb">tance (as property); e. g. {%Yājnav.:%} {#kramAdaByAgataM dravyaM hfta-#}
<div n="lb">{#maByudDarettu yaH . dAyAdeByo na taddadyAdvidyayA labDameva ca;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Nārada:%} {#kramAdaByAgataM prAptaM putrEryannarRamudDftam . dadyuH pEtAmahaM#}
<div n="lb">{#pOtrAstaccaturTAnnivartate#}. E. {#gam#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6734<pc>314-a<k1>aByAgama<k2>aByAgama
{#aByAgama#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-maH#}) <sup>1</sup> Arrival (with friendly intent),
<div n="lb">visit ({%Hemach., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Med., Śabdar.:%} = {#aByu-#}
<div n="lb">{#dgama#}). <sup>2</sup> Neighbourhood ({%Hem.%} &c.: = {#antika;#} or {#nikawa#}).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Hostile encounter, war, battle ({%Amarak., Hem., Bhūripr.,%}
<div n="lb">{%Śabdar., Viśvapr.:%} = {#yudDa, samara, Aji#} &c.). <sup>4</sup> Enmity,
<div n="lb">hostility ({%Hem.:%} = {#roDa;#} {%Med., Viśvapr., Bhūripr., Trik.:%}
<div n="lb">= {#viroDa;#} {%Śabdar.:%} = {#vEra#}). <sup>5</sup> Striking, hurting ({%Med.:%} =
<div n="lb">{#aBiGAta;#} {%Hem., Viśvapr., Śabdar.:%} = {#GAta#}). <sup>6</sup> Result,
<div n="lb">fruition, enjoyment; e. g. {%Nyāya Sūtra:%} {#yaToktahetutvAtpAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#tantryAtsvakftAByAgamAcca na manasaH#} ‘(desire &c.) are not qua-
<div n="lb">lities of {%Manas,%} because they are caused by what has been
<div n="lb">explained before, because they depend on other (existences),
<div n="lb">and because enjoyment arises only from one's own doings’
<div n="lb">({%Viśvan.:%} {#aByAgamo BogaH . sa manaso yatnAdisattve na syAt#}
<div n="lb">&c.). [{%Rādhāk.%} quotes s. v. a meaning {#aByutTAna#} ‘rising
<div n="lb">from a seat at the arrival of a guest’ as founded on the
<div n="lb">{%Viśvapr.,%} but none of the {%Mss.%} of this Kosha at my dis-
<div n="lb">posal give this explanation; they read: {#aByAgamo'ntike#}
<div n="lb">{#GAte viroDAByudgamAjizu#}.] E. {#gam#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#ap#}.
<LEND>

<L>6753<pc>315-a<k1>aByArUQa<k2>aByArUQa

<div n="lb"><sup>2</sup> Surpassed; e. g. {%Atharvav.:%} {#devAnAmetatparizUtamanaByArUQaM#}
<div n="lb">{#carati rocamAnam . tasmAjjAtaM brAhmaRam#} &c.; or {%Śatap.:%}
<div n="lb">{#tenEva kzatramanaByArUQam#} ({%Sāy. Ms. E. I. H.:%} {#tenEva vElakzaRyena#}
<div n="lb">{#viSA kzatramanaByArUQam . kzatriyajAtira(na)ByArUQA Bavati#});
<div n="lb">and comp. the quotation s. v. {#aByAroha#}. E. {#ruh#} with {#A#}
<div n="lb">and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#kta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6754<pc>315-a<k1>aByAroha<k2>aByAroha
{#aByAroha#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-haH#}) <sup>1</sup> (ved.?) Ascending, mounting;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Śatap.%} (III. 3. 4. 9.): {#udDate prOgye Palake BavataH . tada-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntareRa tizWantsubrahmaRyaH prAjati SreyAnvA ezo'ByArohAdBavati#}
<div n="lb">({%Sāy. Ms. E. I. H.:%} {#prayugasaMDiPalake udDate prayugAdapyunnate#}
<div n="lb">{#cuvukapramARe BavataH . ata eva sUtrakArastasminneva pradeSe Palaka-#}
<div n="lb">{#yorOdDatyaM sUtrayAmAsa prayugAccodDate ca Palake Bavata iti .#}
<div n="lb">{#tattayoH PalakayorantareRa maDye subrahmaRyaH prAjati . prerayatyana-#}
<div n="lb">{#qvAhO . aDaHsTitiM praSaMsati SreyAnveti . karituragAdyArUQasya#}
<div n="lb">{#praSastatvaM lokasidDam . atastadaByArohAtsomaH SreyAnBavati .#}
<div n="lb">{#atastadaDizWitaSca kawamAroQumarhati#} (Ms. {#ºmarhamiti#}) {#. BUyizWa#}
<div n="lb">{#eva satprAjati#} (Ms. {#satprajAti#}). <sup>1</sup> (ved.) Transition from or
<div n="lb">by one to another in an ascending direction, progressive
<div n="lb">movement, progress (contrasted with {#nivAha#} the transition
<div n="lb">in a descending direction, retrogressive movement) (ved.);
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Śatapath.:%} {#aTa vA ato'hnAmaByArohaH . prAyaRIyenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tirAtreRodayanIyamatirAtramaByArohanti caturviMSena mahAvratama-#}
<div n="lb">{#Biplavena paramaBiplavaM pfzWyena paraM pfzWyamaBijitA viSvajitaM svara-#}
<div n="lb">{#sAmaBiH parAntsvarasAmno'TEtadaharanaByArUQaM yadvEzuvatamaBi ha#}
<div n="lb">{#vE SreyAMsaM rohati nEnaM pApIyAnaByArohanti ya evametadveda ..#}
<div n="lb">{#aTa vA ato'hnAM nivAhaH . prAyaRIyo'tirAtraScaturviMSA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAhne nivahati caturviMSamaharaBiplavAyABiplavaH pfzWyAya pfzWyo#}
<div n="lb">{#'Bijite'BijitsvarasAmaByaH svarasAmAno vizuvate vizuvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ntsvarasAmaByaH svarasAmAno viSvajite viSvatitpfzWyAya pfzWyo#}
<div n="lb">{#'BiplavAyABiplavo go'AyurByAM go'AyuzI daSarAtrAya daSa-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAtro mahAvratAya mahAvratamudayanIyAyAtirAtrAyodayanIyo#}
<div n="lb">{#'tirAtraH svargAya lokAya pratizWAyA annAdyAya#}. <sup>3</sup> (ved.)
<div n="lb">Praying, devotion, (lit. ‘raising one's self to a divine state
<div n="lb">by muttering prayers’; then, the act of praying itself);
<div n="lb">{%Śatap.%} or {%Bṛhadār.:%} {#aTAtaH pavamAnAnAmevAByArohaH . sa#}
<div n="lb">{#vE Kalu prastotA sAma prastOti sa yatra prastuyAttadetAni japeda-#}
<div n="lb">{#sato mA sadgamaya tamaso mA jyotirgamaya mftyormAmftaM gamayeti#}
<div n="lb">({%Śaṅkara:%} {#aTAnantaraM yasmAccEva viduzA prayujyamAnaM devaBAvA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yAByArohaPalaM japakarma . atastasmAttadviDIyate .…asya ca#}
<div n="lb">{#japakarmaRa AKyAByArohaH#} [{%Dwivedag.:%} {#asya ca japakarmaRo#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByAroha ityAKyA#}] {#. ABimuKyenArohayatyanena#} (ed. {%Röer:%} {#ºha-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyanena#}) {#japakarmaRA evaMviddevaBAvamAtmAnamityaByArohaH#}). E. {#ruh#}
<div n="lb">with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>
[Page315-b+ 56]

<L>6755<pc>315-b<k1>aByArohaRa<k2>aByArohaRa
{#aByArohaRa#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-Ram#}) The same as the preceding;
<div n="lb">(the base of the following word). E. {#ruh#} with {#A#} and
<div n="lb">{#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#lyuw#}.
<LEND>

<L>6756<pc>315-b<k1>aByArohaRIya<k2>aByArohaRIya
{#aByArohaRIya#}¦ m. ({#-yaH#}) The name of a Soma sacrifice:
<div n="lb">the first of the seven Soma sacrifices of the {%Rājasūya%}
<div n="lb">which is performed by a king (see {#rAjasUya#} and the quo-
<div n="lb">tations s. v. {#aBizecanIya#}); it is called so in the {%Śrauta%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtras%} of {%Āśvalāyana%} and of the {%Sāmaveda-schools,%} but for
<div n="lb">shortness sake {#pavitra#} in the {%Śrauta S.%} of {%Kātyāyana;%} ({%Āśval.:%}
<div n="lb">{#aTa rAjasUyaH . purastAtPAlgunyAH pOrRamAsyAH pavitreRAgni-#}
<div n="lb">{#zwomenAByArohaRIyena yajeta pOrRamAsyAM cAturmAsyAni prayuNkte#}
<div n="lb">{#nityAni parvARi cakrAByAM tu parvAntarezu carantyaharviparyayaM pakza-#}
<div n="lb">{#viparyayaM vA;#} {%Yājnikadeva%}--Ms. E. I. H. 1362--on {%Kāty.%}
<div n="lb">{%Śr. S.%} XV. 1. 4. and 5.: {#SAKAntare'sya#} (i. e. {#pavitrasya#}) {#aByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rohaRIya iti saMjYA . PAlgunIpakzasya praTamAyAM dIkzetAByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rohaRIyA yajYasyEkA dIkzA dvAdaSaM SataM dakziRA iti cCando-#}
<div n="lb">{#gasUtre . ASvalAyano'pi purastAººº prayuNkta iti#} [--the first
<div n="lb">quotation being taken from {%Lātyāy. Śr. S.%} IX. 1. where,
<div n="lb">however, the Ms. E. I. H. 1652 and the Ms. R. L. Berlin
<div n="lb">Chamb. 89 (p. 64 {%a%}) and {%Agnisw.%} comm. Chamb. 436 (p. 244{%b%})
<div n="lb">have the more correct reading {#ºByArohaRIyAya jyotizwo-#}
<div n="lb">{#mAya tasyEkA dIºº--#}] {#. pavitra iti saMjYAsaMvyavahArArTA#}).
<div n="lb">Neither {%Āśval.,%} nor {%Lāṭyāy.,%} nor {%Maśaka%} give a detailed
<div n="lb">description of this sacrifice, since it shares chiefly in the rites
<div n="lb">of the {%Agniṣṭoma,%} and {%Kātyāyana,%} too, who founds his rules
<div n="lb">({%Śr. Sūtr.%} XV. 1. 4.--3. 46.) on the text of the {%Śatapathabr.%}
<div n="lb">(V. 2. 3. 1.--3. 2. 8.) and, among the Sūtra-authors, gives
<div n="lb">the fullest information, only mentions what is peculiar to
<div n="lb">this sacrifice and not what it has in common with the Agni-
<div n="lb">ṣṭoma; {%Maśaka%} Ms. Chamb. Berl. 100 (p. 42 {%b%}): {#kxpto'ByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rohaRIyaH;#} {%Vyākhyā%} E. I. H.: {#kxº iti . jyotizwoma ityanu-#}
<div n="lb">{#vartate sa cAgnizwomasaMsTaH . agnizwomamaByAharatIti SruteH;#}
<div n="lb">{%Yājnik.%} on {%Kāty.:%} {#avacane'gnizwoma iti vakzyamARatvAt#});
<div n="lb">the {%Śatap.%} itself, however, begins its description only with
<div n="lb">the proceedings connected with but following the {%Abhyāroh.,%}
<div n="lb">viz. with the {%Pūrṇāhuti%} &c.; ({%Sāy.:%} {#tatra#}--i. e. {#rAjasUye--#}
<div n="lb">{#pavitranAmake praTamasomayAge pravfttisamAnatvena vaktavyABAvAttaM#}
<div n="lb">{#parityajya tadavasAne kartavyaM tatra pUrRAhutipraBfti vESezikamuttara-#}
<div n="lb">{#tantramaBiDIyate#}).--The {%Abhyārohanīya%} (or {%Pavitra%}) com-
<div n="lb">mences on the first day of the first or light fortnight of the
<div n="lb">month Phālguna (February-March) and lasts eight days, the
<div n="lb">{%four%} first of which are occupied by the {%Dīkṣā%} or initiatory
<div n="lb">rites, the {%three%} following by the {%Upasad%}-offerings (q. v.)
<div n="lb">and the {%eighth%} by the {%Sutyā%} (q. v.; {%Yājnik. Paddh.:%} {#caturdI-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzastryupasatka ekasutyaH pavitrasaMjYakaH somayAgo'gnizwomasaMsTaH#});
<div n="lb">the presents given to the priests are a thousand cows; in the
<div n="lb">choice of the priests, the buying of the Soma &c. it con-
<div n="lb">forms itself, as is said before, to the rules of the Agni-
<div n="lb">ṣṭoma.--The rites connected with this sacrifice and
<div n="lb">following it, are: on the {%ninth%} day the {%Pūrṇāhuti%} or a liba-
<div n="lb">tion of a ladle-full of butter, in the house of the sacrificer,
<div n="lb">if he wishes it;--the present he makes on this occasion,
<div n="lb">being left to his own liberality. ({%Harisvāmin%} adds the
<div n="lb">following details, which may serve as an instance: the
<div n="lb">Adhwaryu takes first the Āhavanīya fire out; four seats
<div n="lb">are prepared; the choice of the Brahman is made silently;
[Page316-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">the Adhw. sits silently down at the right side of the Brahman
<div n="lb">and the sacrificer, prepares the clarified butter, cleans the
<div n="lb">ladles {%Sruch%} and {%Sruva%} and takes with the {%Sruva%} as much
<div n="lb">butter as is necessary to fill the {%Sruch;%} then he proceeds
<div n="lb">with fuel and the {%Sruch%} to the fire, sits down, puts the
<div n="lb">fuel on and in saying svāhā! sacrifices the butter with the
<div n="lb">words: ‘this to Agni, this to Prajāpati’; then the sacri-
<div n="lb">ficer gives the present to the Adhwaryu.) The principal
<div n="lb">ceremonies after this libation are: on the following or {%tenth%}
<div n="lb">day the burnt sacrifice of a Puroḍāśa fried in eight bowls,
<div n="lb">under the recital of {%Vājas.%} 9. 35., to Anumati (q. v.), when
<div n="lb">the present to the priest is a garment; on the {%eleventh%} day
<div n="lb">the sacrifice of a Puroḍāśa fried in eleven bowls, to Agni
<div n="lb">and Viṣṇu, the present being gold; on the {%twelfth%} day, of
<div n="lb">a Puroḍāśa, also fried in eleven bowls, to Agni and Soma,
<div n="lb">the present: a cow which has been several times liberated,
<div n="lb">(liberation being the object to be effectuated by this gift);
<div n="lb">on the {%thirteenth%} day, of a Puroḍāśa fried in twelve bowls,
<div n="lb">when the priest receives a bull; on the {%fourteenth%} day, an
<div n="lb">{%Āgrayaṇeṣṭi%} (q. v.) accompanied with the gift of a cow.--
<div n="lb">The next four sacrifices are those which constitute the
<div n="lb">{%Chāturmāsya%} ceremonies, viz. the {%Vaiśvadeva, Varuṇapra-%}
<div n="lb">{%ghāsa, Sākamedha%} and {%Śunasīrya%} (qq. vv.); they are per-
<div n="lb">formed during four successive months but so that the com-
<div n="lb">mencement of the {%Śunasīrya%} falls on the same day on which
<div n="lb">the Dīkṣā of the Abhyārohanīya had begun in the pre-
<div n="lb">ceding year. The rite on the {%first%} day of the Śunasīrya is
<div n="lb">the {%Pañchavatīya%} (q. v.), viz. a libation of butter under
<div n="lb">special injunctions and accompanied by the muttering of
<div n="lb">the verses {%Vāj.%} 9. 35. and 37., (performed esp. when the king
<div n="lb">suffers from a painful disease, since it will give him relief);
<div n="lb">the present is a cart with three horses. There follows on the
<div n="lb">{%second%} day the {%Indraturīya%} which consists of four libations,
<div n="lb">viz. a libation of {%Havis%} fried in eight bowls, to Agni,--
<div n="lb">of {%Charu%} made of barley, to Varuṇa,--of Charu made
<div n="lb">of gavedhuka-rice, to Rudra,--of curds proceeding from
<div n="lb">the milk of a cart-cow, to Indra; and this cow is then
<div n="lb">offered to the priest as a present. The sacrifice on the
<div n="lb">then following, or {%third,%} day is the {%Apāmārgahoma,%} which
<div n="lb">serves also to break the spell of incantatory rites performed
<div n="lb">by an enemy and to turn them against himself, and the
<div n="lb">peculiarities of which are therefore described with some
<div n="lb">detail by {%Kāty.%} and the commentator; it seems to be barren
<div n="lb">for the Adhwaryu, for no present is mentioned. The next
<div n="lb">in order are the {%Trishamyukta%}-libations in three divisions:
<div n="lb">first, Puroḍāśa fried in eleven bowls, to Agni and Viṣṇu,
<div n="lb">Charu to Indra and Viṣṇu, and Charu or Puroḍāśa fried
<div n="lb">in three bowls to Viṣṇu;--the present is a short bull or
<div n="lb">cow; secondly on the following day, Puroḍāśa fried in
<div n="lb">eleven bowls, to Agni and Pūṣan, Charu to Indra and
<div n="lb">Pūṣan, and Charu to Pūṣan, the present: a black bull
<div n="lb">or cow; thirdly on the following day, Puroḍāśa fried in
<div n="lb">eleven bowls, to Agni and Soma, Charu to Indra and
<div n="lb">Soma, and Charu to Soma, the present: a tawny bull or
<div n="lb">cow; on the next day Puroḍāśa fried in twelve bowls is
<div n="lb">offered to Viśvānara, and Charu made of barley to Va-
[Page316-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">ruṇa, or the latter libation is spared for a separate, the
<div n="lb">following day; in such a case the present given to the
<div n="lb">priest for the libation to Viśvānara is a bull, and for that
<div n="lb">to Varuṇa, a black garment, or if such a garment cannot
<div n="lb">be had, one that is not black. [The Śunasīrya and the
<div n="lb">other ceremonies would therefore comprise seven, or if the
<div n="lb">two last are performed on one day, six days; and the cere-
<div n="lb">mony to be mentioned presently, the {%Ratnahavis,%} would be-
<div n="lb">gin on the eighth or seventh day after the Śunasīrya. Such
<div n="lb">is the rule of the {%Kāṇva%} school, but {%Harisvāmin%} despatches
<div n="lb">the {%Indraturīya, Apāmārgahoma%} and the three {%Trishamyukta%}
<div n="lb">on the day after the Śunasīrya, and puts the Viśvānara-
<div n="lb">and Varuṇa-libations on the third, or the Viśvānara-lib.
<div n="lb">on the third and the Varuṇa-lib. on the fourth day, with
<div n="lb">the further remark that, according to the option in the per-
<div n="lb">forming of the latter rites, the beginning of the next fol-
<div n="lb">lowing, the {%Ratnahavis,%} would come to fall either on the
<div n="lb">third or on the fourth day. This difference between the
<div n="lb">two schools, as regards the time of the performance of these
<div n="lb">rites, continues therefore in what follows.] The rites next
<div n="lb">in order are twelve libations called {%Ratnahavis%} (q. v.) which
<div n="lb">are performed on twelve successive days in twelve different
<div n="lb">houses, whereto the sacrificer repairs for this purpose on
<div n="lb">each following day, with the {%Gārhapatya%} and {%Āhavanīya%}
<div n="lb">fire placed on the two {%Araṇis;%} viz. a libation of 1. Puroḍāśa
<div n="lb">fried in eight bowls, to Agni Anīkavat, in the house of
<div n="lb">the {%Senānī%} or commander in chief; 2. Charu to Bṛhaspati,
<div n="lb">in the house of the {%Purohita%} or family priest; 3. Puroḍāśa
<div n="lb">fried in eleven bowls to Indra, in the house of the {%Yaja-%}
<div n="lb">{%māna%} or the king for whom all these proceedings take
<div n="lb">place; 4. Charu to Aditi, in the h. of the {%Mahiṣī%} or his
<div n="lb">first and principal wife; 5. Charu (made of barley) to Va-
<div n="lb">ruṇa in the h. of the {%Sūta%} or the master of the horse
<div n="lb">({%Yājnik.:%} = {#aSvasAraTiH;#} {%Hariśv.:%} = {#aSvapozaka#}); 6. Puro-
<div n="lb">ḍāśa fried in eight bowls, to the Maruts, in the h. of the
<div n="lb">{%Grāmaṇī%} or mayor ({%Yājnik.:%} = {#grAmanetA vESyAnAM mahattaraH#});
<div n="lb">7. Puroḍāśa fried in twelve or eight bowls, to Savitṛ, in
<div n="lb">the h. of the {%Kṣattṛ%} or goldstick-in-waiting (at the same
<div n="lb">time the overseer of the harem and confidential messenger;
<div n="lb">({%Sāy.:%} {#kzattA nAma yazwihasto'ntaHpurADyakzaH sarvezAM niyantA#}
<div n="lb">{#pratihArAparaparyAyaH#}); 8. Puroḍāśa fried in two bowls, to
<div n="lb">the Aśvins, in the h. of the {%Saṅgrahītṛ%} or the driver (who
<div n="lb">stands on the left side of the king in his carriage); 9. Charu
<div n="lb">to {%Pūṣan,%} in the h. of the {%Bhāgadugha%} or minister of the
<div n="lb">revenue ({%Sāy.:%} {#rAjYaH prAptaM zazWaM BAgaM prajAByo gfhItvA rAjYe#}
<div n="lb">{#dogDi prayacCatIti BAgaduGaH#}); 10. Charu made of Gave-
<div n="lb">dhukas which have been fetched from the houses of the
<div n="lb">overseer of the gambling halls ({%akṣavāpa%}) and of the {%govi-%}
<div n="lb">{%kartṛ%} or (master of the) huntsmen (or acc. to others of a
<div n="lb">ploughman), to Rudra, in the h. of the {%Yajamāna%} or sacri-
<div n="lb">ficer; 11. Ājya or clarified butter taken four times, to Road
<div n="lb">(personified as a divinity), in addressing it with the words
<div n="lb">‘may Road liking the clarified butter partake of it ({%Śatap.%}
<div n="lb">V. 3. 1. 11.)’, in the h. of the {%Dūta%} or messenger; 12. a
<div n="lb">Darvihoma of Charu made of black rice which has been
<div n="lb">unhusked with the finger-nails, under the recital of the
[Page317-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">words {#eza--svAhA#} ({%Vājas.%} 9. 35.), or a simple Charu pre-
<div n="lb">pared in the same manner under the recital of the same
<div n="lb">words and a {%Vaṣaṭkāra,%} to Nirṛti, in the h. of a wife of
<div n="lb">the king who has been left by him for want of having
<div n="lb">borne him a son. The presents to the priests in the pre-
<div n="lb">ceding twelve acts are severally (and in the given order):
<div n="lb">1. gold, 2. a cow with a black back (or acc. to others with
<div n="lb">a white back; see {#SitipfzWa#}), 3. a bull, 4. a milch-cow, 5. a
<div n="lb">horse, 6. a spotted cow, 7. a red (or acc. to others, a white;
<div n="lb">see {#Syeta#}) cart-ox, 8. two twin-cows or, if they cannot be
<div n="lb">had, two cows, which are born one after the other, 9. a
<div n="lb">cow with white and black hairs, 10. three presents (for the
<div n="lb">lib. to Rudra), viz. a. either a cow with white thighs (acc.
<div n="lb">to some, with black thighs) or one with a white tail (acc.
<div n="lb">to some, with a black tail; see {#SitibAhu#} and {#Siti-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAla#}), b. a dagger-sword, sharp and its point unbent,
<div n="lb">(without a sheath), c. a vessel where gambling-dice are
<div n="lb">thrown in, tied round with a cord made of hairs; 11. three
<div n="lb">presents (for the lib. to Road), viz. a. a bow covered with
<div n="lb">{%pyukṣṇas%} [which word is rendered by {%Sāy.:%} tendon, by
<div n="lb">{%Yājnik.%} in reference to others: tail of a peacock, or skin
<div n="lb">of a boa constrictor; the E. I. H. Ms. of the comm. to
<div n="lb">{%Śatap.%} V. 3. 1. 11. and {%Weber'%}s ed. read {#ukzRaº#} for {#pyukzRa#}
<div n="lb">which seems doubtful, though {#ukzRa#} is explained {#ukzavikAra#}],
<div n="lb">b. a leather quiver with arrows, and c. a red turban; 12. a
<div n="lb">black, old diseased cow.--Then the king tells his bar-
<div n="lb">ren wife to go forth and out of his power, and she re-
<div n="lb">pairs to the house of a Brāhmaṇa where the king has no
<div n="lb">more any control over her.--After the {%Ratnahavis%} have
<div n="lb">been completed, the (royal) sacrificer goes to his palace
<div n="lb">and makes (apparently on the day of the twelfth Ratna-
<div n="lb">havis) a libation of Charu which has been prepared in the
<div n="lb">milk of a white cow which has had a white calf, to Soma
<div n="lb">and Rudra; and the present he makes to the priest, is this
<div n="lb">white cow; (this rite is performed esp. if the king suffers
<div n="lb">from scabs or vitiligo). On the following day he makes a
<div n="lb">libation of Charu to Mitra and Bṛhaspati, and makes to
<div n="lb">the priest the gift of a cow. This libation which is also
<div n="lb">the subject of special injunctions, closes the rites which are
<div n="lb">connected with the Abhyārohaṇīya and are immediately
<div n="lb">followed by those of the {%Abhiṣechanīya.%} [The {%Sāmaveda%}
<div n="lb">school must have rejected the performance of the Śunāsīrya
<div n="lb">and of all the following rites, since they place with distinct
<div n="lb">words the beginning of the {%Abhiṣechanīya (v. s. v.)%} on the
<div n="lb">same day of the following year on which, in the previous
<div n="lb">year, the initiatory rite of the Abhyār. commenced, viz. on
<div n="lb">the first day of the light fortnight of the month Phālguna,
<div n="lb">i. e. on the same day when acc. to the {%Yajurveda%} school,
<div n="lb">the Śunāsīrya would have to begin (e. g. {%Lātyāy. Śr. S.:%}
<div n="lb">{#saMvatsarAdUrDvamaBizecanIyena yajeta tasminneva kAle;#} {%Agnisw.:%}
<div n="lb">{#izwvAByArohaRIyena saMvatsaramAsitvA tato'BizecanIyena yajeta .#}
<div n="lb">{#aBizecanIya iti saMjYA . tasminneva kAle . yasminkAle'ByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#rohaRIyenezwam . PAlgunIpakzasya praTamAyAmiti#}); {%Harisvāmin%}
<div n="lb">who seems to assign only a fortnight to the performance
<div n="lb">of the rites from the Śunāsīrya to the last Charu-libation,
<div n="lb">puts the Abhish. (as mentioned s. v.) on the first day of
[Page317-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">the {%dark%} fortnight of the month Phālguna ({%Harisw.:%} {#PAlguna-#}
<div n="lb">{#kfzRapratipadyaBizecanIyasya dIkzeta#}) in reading the {%Śrauta S.%}
<div n="lb">XV. 3. 49. of {%Kātyāy.:%} {#PAlgunIyajanIye dIkzate;#} but the
<div n="lb">{%Kāṇva%} school which is followed by {%Yājnikadeva,%} the com-
<div n="lb">mentator of {%Kātyāy.,%} assigns a much longer duration to
<div n="lb">these rites and places therefore the beginning of the {%Abhish.%}
<div n="lb">(which circumstance I omitted to mention under {#aBizeca-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIya#}) on the first day of the light fortnight of the month
<div n="lb">Chaitra (March-April), in reading the named Sūtra {#PAlgu-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIpakzayajanIye'BizecanIyaM dIkzate#} and supplying at {#PAlgu-#}
<div n="lb">{#nIpakza#} the word {#atIta;#} they forbid moreover altogether
<div n="lb">any religious act to be performed during the dark fortnight
<div n="lb">of Phālguna ({%Yājnik.:%} {#PAlgunyAM nityaM SunAsIrIyaM prAtarnityaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vESvadevaM parva . PAlgunakfzRapakze kimapi karma na Bavati#})]. E.
<div n="lb">{#aByArohaRa,#} taddh. aff. {#Ca#} (or perhaps a Tatpur., {#ruh#} with
<div n="lb">{#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya aff. {#anIyar;#} comp. the E. of {#aBize-#}
<div n="lb">{#canIya#}); scil. {#somayAga#}.
<LEND>

<L>6757<pc>317-b<k1>aByArohya<k2>aByArohya

<div n="lb">to be reached; e. g. {%Śatapathabr.:%} {#yajYena vE devAH . imAM#}
<div n="lb">{#jitiM jigyuryEzAmiyaM jitiste hocuH kaTaM na idaM manuzyErana-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByArohyaM syAditi#}. E. {#ruh#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛtya
<div n="lb">aff. {#Ryat#}.
<LEND>

<L>6758<pc>317-b<k1>aByAvartam<k2>aByAvartam
{#aByAvartam#}¦ Tatpur. ind. By repeatedly coming; by being re-
<div n="lb">peated; e. g. {%Śatap.:%} {#tena retasA siktenemAH prajAH punaraByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#vartaM prajAyante#} ({%Sāy.:%} = {#aByAvftyAByAvftya#}); or (said of the
<div n="lb">verses in a {#stotra#}) {%Śatap.:%} {#yadUrDvA stomA anuyanti . yajYama-#}
<div n="lb">{#ByAvartaM sAmaBiH kalpamAnAH;#} or {#upAvartaDvamiti vA anyAni#}
<div n="lb">{#stotrARi . aByAvartaM DuryE stuvata imA vE prajA etAni sto-#}
<div n="lb">{#trARyaByupAvfttAstasmAdimAH prajAH punaraByAvartaM prajAyante;#} or
<div n="lb">{#caturviMSAH pavamAnAH . trivfdaByAvartaM catuScatvAriMSAH pavamAnA#}
<div n="lb">{#ekaviMSamaByAvartam#} &c. (where {#aByAvartam#} is not to be taken
<div n="lb">as a neuter in the sense of {#Avfttistotra;#} for in the gloss
<div n="lb">of {%Harisvāmin%}--Ms. E. I. H.--: {#‘paYcaBiretABiH kalpAntaraM#}
<div n="lb">{#prapaYcyate . tatra praTame yAvadahani trayo'pi pavamAnA yASca-#}
<div n="lb">{#turviMSAyAnu (?) aByAvartayanti . aByAvartaM DuryE stuvate tattrivft#}
<div n="lb">(Ms. {#natfvft#} sic) {#. pavamAnavyatiriktAnyAvfttistotrARi tri-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfnti BavantItyarTaH#}’, the word {#Avfttistotra#} explains the
<div n="lb">{%‘sense’%} but not the grammatical quality of {#aByAvartam#}. It
<div n="lb">should be observed that in this and similar passages {#trivft,#}
<div n="lb">{#ekaviMSa, trayastriMSa, ekaviMSa#} &c. are names of {%Stomas%} which
<div n="lb">qualifiy the {%Stotra:%} the former expressing how often the
<div n="lb">verses of a Stotra are to be repeated, while the {%Viṣṭuti%}
<div n="lb">explains the {%order%} in which such a repetition takes place;
<div n="lb">comp. e. g. {%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#tezu trizu tfcezUrDvagAnena tri-#}
<div n="lb">{#vftstomo Bavati . na tvatra paYcadaSasaptadaSastomAdInAmivAvftta-#}
<div n="lb">{#gAnamasti;#} or {#atra#} (I. 4. 3.) {#trizvapi vAkyezu trivftpaYcadaSasapta-#}
<div n="lb">{#daSaSabdA guRaviDAyakatvena saMmatAH .…tasmAdvahizpavamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nAdiSabdAH stotranAmaDeyAni .--tErnAmaBiH karmARyanUdya tri-#}
<div n="lb">{#vfdAdiguRA viDIyante#}). E. {#vft#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#Ramul#} (with the udātta on the penultimate, which ac-
<div n="lb">cent the word would not have, if it were a regular accus.
<div n="lb">of a deriv. with {#GaY#}).
<LEND>

<L>6762<pc>318-a<k1>aByASa<k2>aByASa
{#aByASa#}¦ Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-SaH-SA-Sam#}) Near, proximate;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Kumāras.:%} {#tayA vyAhftasaMdeSA sA baBO niBftA priye .#}
<div n="lb">{#cUtayazwirivAByASe maDO#} (in the approaching spring) {#paraBf-#}
<div n="lb">{#tonmuKI;#} or {%Patanj.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} V. 4. 50 v. 3: {#samIpIBavati .#}
<div n="lb">{#aByASIBavati . antikIBavati#} &c.; comp. {#samaByASIkaraRa;#}
<div n="lb">a noun depending on it stands in the gen. or abl.; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Kāś.%} on {%Pāṇ.%} II. 3. 34.: {#aByASaM grAmasya#} or {#grAmAt#}.
<div n="P">2. n. ({#-Sam#}) Neighbourhood, vicinity; e. g. {%Mahābh.%}
<div n="lb">{%Draupadīhar.:%} {#Danuzo'ByASamAgatya tasTO giririvAcalaH;#}
<div n="lb">or {%Nalop.:%} {#sahasAByAgatAM BEmImaByASaparivartinIm . jagrAhA-#}
<div n="lb">{#jagaraH#} &c.--It retains its abl. ending when compounded
<div n="lb">with a past partic. in {#kta;#} e. g. {%Kāś.:%} {#aByASAdAgataH#}. [The
<div n="lb">{%Amarak.%} and {%Hem.%} give the word as having three genders;
<div n="lb">the {%Med.%} and {%Trikāṇḍaś.%} have the form {#aByAsa#} as a masc.
<div n="lb">in the sense of {%vicinity;%} on the latter form see the remark
<div n="lb">at the end. A masc. nom. {#aByASaH#} in the sense ‘neigh-
<div n="lb">bourhood’, has not come under my observation; the cases
<div n="lb">{#ºSasya, ºSam#} &c. are better referred to a neuter.]
<div n="P">3. m. ({#-SaH#}) Result, consequence; e. g. {%Chhānd. Up.:%}
<div n="lb">{#sa ya etadevaM vidvAnsADu sAmetyupAste'ByASo ha yadenaM sADavo#}
<div n="lb">{#DarmA A ca gacCeyurupa ca nameyuH#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#sADuguRavadvidvAMsta-#}
<div n="lb">{#syEtatPalamaByASaH#} &c.); or {#tadya iha ramaRIyacaraRA aByASo#}
<div n="lb">{#ha yatte ramaRIyAM yonimApadyeran#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#tenAnuSayena puRyena#}
<div n="lb">{#karmaRA candramaRqale BuktaSezeRAByASo ha#} &c. (In other pas-
<div n="lb">sages of {%Dr. Röer'%}s ed. of the {%Chh. Up.%} the word is written,
<div n="lb">when implying the same sense, {#aByAsa,#} e. g. {#kAmaM DyAya-#}
<div n="lb">{#nnapramatto'ByAso ha yadasmE sa kAmaH samfDyeta;#} or {#sa ya etamevaM#}
<div n="lb">{#vidvAnAdityaM brahmetyupAste'ByAso ha yadenaM sADavo GozA A#}
<div n="lb">{#ca gacCeyuH#} &c.) E. {#aS#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. [The
<div n="lb">comm. to the {%Amarak.%} who give only the sense ‘near’,
<div n="lb">allow the word to be written {#aByASa#} or {#aByAsa,#} equally
<div n="lb">so {%Vallabhag.%} on {%Hem.--Rāyamukuṭa%} is even at hand
<div n="lb">with an E. {#sad#} with {#A#} and {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#qa,#} which he
<div n="lb">founds on the {%Vārtt.%} to {%Pāṇ.%} III. 2. 101.; or {#as#} (cl. 4)
<div n="lb">with {#aBi,#} kṛt aff. {#GaY#}. But though the confusion be-
<div n="lb">tween the two forms is undeniable, it is certain that the
<div n="lb">best Mss., and among them the grammatical ones, write
<div n="lb">always {#aByASa#} in the sense of ‘near’; and it seems to me,
<div n="lb">too, that the meaning ‘result’ is better referred to {#aByASa,#}
<div n="lb">than to {#aByAsa,#} because it follows more naturally, like
<div n="lb">that of ‘near’, from a radical expressing quickness, per-
<div n="lb">vasion, than from the radical {#as,#} ‘to throw’. An ana-
<div n="lb">logy for both meanings is afforded by {#aByAgama#} q. v.]
<LEND>

<L>6763<pc>318-a<k1>aByASAdAgata<k2>aByASAdAgata

<div n="lb">{#rake'tiprasaNgaH;#} {%Pat.:%} {#…dUrAdAgataH#} (as instance) {#. sa#}

<L>6766<pc>318-b<k1>aByAsa<k2>aByAsa
{#aByAsa#}¦ I. Tatpur. m. ({#-saH#}) <sup>1</sup> Repetition, repeated occurence;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Manu:%} {#te'ByAsAtkarmaRAM tezAM pApAnAmalpabudDayaH . saM-#}
<div n="lb">{#prApnuvanti duHKAni#} &c.; or {%Kātyāy. Śr. S.:%} {#aBiplavAByAse-#}
<div n="lb">{#nABipUraRam;#} or {%Kumārila%} on a {%Mānava-Kalpa-S.:%} {#triri-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyaByAso'nuvAdaH;#} or the {%Mit.%} on {%Yājnav.%} (2. 81.): {#etacca#}
<div n="lb">{#…anaByAse ca drazwavyam . loBAdikAraRaviSezaparijYAne#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByAse ca manunoktam;#} or the {%same%} on {%Yājn.%} (3. 255.): {#ajYA-#}
<div n="lb">{#nato'ByAse tu vasizWenoktam .…jYAnato'ByAse tu SaNKo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ktam .…atyantAByAse harItoktam;#} or {%Raghun. Prāya-%}
<div n="lb">{%śchittat.%} (a quotation): {#goGnavadvihitaH kalpaScAndrAyaRamaTApi#}
<div n="lb">{#vA . aByAse tu tayorBUyastataH SudDimavApnuyAt;#} or {%Jaimini-%}
<div n="lb">{%Sūtras:%} {#AgneyastUktahetutvAdaByAsena pratIyeta;#} or {#yAvajjIviko#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByAsaH karmaDarmaH;#} or {#aByAso vA vikArAtsyAt . paSustvevaM#}
<div n="lb">{#praDAnaM syAdaByAsasya tannimittatvAtsamAsaSabdaH syAt;#} or {#arTa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAMstu nEkatvAdaByAsaH syAt…;#} or {#vediprokzaRe mantrAByAsaH#}
<div n="lb">{#karmaRaH punaHprayogAt#} &c. &c.; or {%Ved. Sūtr.:%} {#Anandamayo#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByAsAt;#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#paramAtmAnandamayo Bavitumarhati . kutaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#aByAsAt . parasminneva hyAtmanyAnandaSabdo bahukftvo'Byasyate#});
<div n="lb">or {%Nyāya-S.:%} {#nAnuvAdapunaruktayorviSezaH SabdAByAsopapatteH ..#}
<div n="lb">{#SIGrataragamanopadeSavadaByAsAdviSezaH;#} or {#aByAsAt#} (sound
<div n="lb">is permanent on account of its frequent occurrence) {#.. anyatve#}
<div n="lb">{#'pyaByAsasyopacArAt;#} or {%Mādh. Jaiminīyany.:%} {#…sUktaM tri-#}
<div n="lb">{#rAvartanIyam . tatra praTamAvfttO praTamAyA fcastriraByAsaH;#} or
<div n="lb">{#aByAsAdanyakarmatvaM darSezwO dviH prayujyatAm#} &c. &.; or {%Mādh.%}
<div n="lb">{%Sarvadarś. (Pāṇinid.):%} {#yaTA svADyAyaH sakftpaWyamAno nAva-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAryate . aByAsena tu sPuwAvasAyaH#} &c.; or {%Mādhāva%} observes
<div n="lb">in his comm. on the {%Aitareyabr.%} at the end of several chap-
<div n="lb">ters, that the last word is to be repeated to indicate the
<div n="lb">close of the chapter, e. g. the word {#Bavati#} at the end of
<div n="lb">the first Adhyāya is to be repeated: {#BavatiSabdasyAByAso#}
<div n="lb">{#'DyAyasamAptyarTaH;#} or at the end of the fifth Adhy. or the
<div n="lb">first Pañchikā: {#aByAso'DyAyasamAptyarTaH,#} similarly at the
<div n="lb">end of the seventh, ninth, tenth &c. &c. Adhyāyas. See
<div n="lb">also s. v. {#AkUpAra#}. <sup>2</sup> Repeated practice, repeated use of
<div n="lb">a thing, habit; e. g. {%Pāṇini:%} {#miTyopapadAtkfYo'ByAse;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Yājnav.:%} {#tatrAtmA hi svayaM kiMcitkarma kiMcitsvaBAvataH .#}
<div n="lb">{#karoti kiMcidaByAsAdDarmADarmoBayAtmakam;#} or {%Mit.%} on {%Yājn.%}
<div n="lb">(3. 253.): {#aByAse tu surAyA iti vAsizWe#} &c.; or {%Medhāt.%} on
<div n="lb">{%Manu:%} {#(vyasanasya ca mftyoSca vyasanaM kazwamucyate) vyasanaSabdenA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tyantAByAsaH . etadvargavizaya ucyate#} (i. e. in the sense of ‘bad
<div n="lb">habit, vice’); or {%Nyāya-S.%} (soul is eternal): {#pretyAhArAByA-#}
<div n="lb">{#sakftAtstanyABilAzAt;#} or (knowledge of the absolute truth
<div n="lb">increases) {#samADiviSezAByAsAt ..…araRyaguhApulinA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dizu yogAByAsopadeSAt;#} or {%Suśruta:%} {#ASayyAByAsayogena#}
<div n="lb">{#karotyASayasaMBavam;#} or {%Rājatar.:%} {#darSanAByAsasaMvfdDacacUrAgaH#}
<div n="lb">{#kzamApatiH#} (comp. also the inst. s. v. {#anvaya#} p. 151{%b,%} 1. 45);
[Page319-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">or {%Sāhityad.%} (v. 49): {#SikzAByAsAdimAtreRa rAGavAdeH svarU-#}
<div n="lb">{#patAm . darSayannartako nEva rasasyAsvAdako Bavet#} (where {#Si-#}
<div n="lb">{#kzAByAsa#} seems rather to be a Tatpur., than a Dwandwa).
<div n="lb"><sup>3</sup> Repeated mental practise, study; e. g. {%Viśvan.%} on a {%Nyāya-%}
<div n="lb">{%S.%} (3. 113. where it is mentioned as one of the twenty-
<div n="lb">seven means to awaken memory): {#aByAsaH saMskArabAhulyam#}
<div n="lb">({%abhyāsa%} means the multiplicity of mental impressions) {#.#}
<div n="lb">{#etasya yadyapi nodboDakatvaM taTApi tAdfSe SIGramudvoDakasamava-#}
<div n="lb">{#DAnaM syAdityASayena tadupanyAsaH . aByAso dfQatarasaMskAraH#}
<div n="lb">(i. e. it means a mental impression which has become very
<div n="lb">strong); or {%Sāṅkhya-Prav.:%} {#tattvAByAsAnneti netIti tyAgA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dvivekasidDiH#} ‘discriminative knowledge becomes accom-
<div n="lb">plished through the study of the twenty-five principles and
<div n="lb">the avoiding of what is negatived in scriptural texts with
<div n="lb">the words: “it is not…it is not…”’; or {%Sāṅkhyakār.:%}
<div n="lb">{#evaM tattvAByAsAnnAsti na me nAhamityapariSezam . aviparyayA-#}
<div n="lb">{#dviSudDaM kevalamutpadyate jYAnam;#} or {%Manu:%} {#vedAByAso hi viprasya#}
<div n="lb">{#tapaH paramihocyate;#} or {%Yājnav.:%} {#yaTA viDAnena paWansAmagA-#}
<div n="lb">{#yamavicyutam . sAvaDAnastadaByAsAtparaM brahmADigacCati;#} or
<div n="lb">{%Bhartṛh. Vākyapadīya:%} {#aByAsapratiBAhetuH sarvaH SabdaH parEH#}
<div n="lb">{#smftaH .…anAgamaSca so'ByAsaH samayaH kEScidizyate#}.
<div n="lb"><sup>4</sup> Reading; e. g. {%Ṛgv. Prātiś.:%} {#aByAsArTe drutAM vfttiM prayo-#}
<div n="lb">{#gArTe tu maDyamAm . SizyARAmupadeSArTe kuryAdvfttiM vilambitAm#}
<div n="lb">‘let the quick way (i. e. quick time) be used at the reading
<div n="lb">(of sacred texts), the middle in common discourse, the
<div n="lb">slow in instructing pupils’. <sup>5</sup> Constant veneration; e. g.
<div n="lb">{%Mahābh. Anuśāsanap.:%} {#aByAse nityaM devAnAM saptarzIRAM Druvasya#}
<div n="lb">{#ca . mokzaRaM sarvakfcCrARAM mocayatyaSuBAtsadA#}. <sup>6</sup> (In {%Philo-%}
<div n="lb">{%sophy%} and such passages of non-philosophical works as
<div n="lb">refer to the philosophical doctrines, this word has been used
<div n="lb">in the following manner: in the {%Mīmānsā%} and {%Nyāya%} it is
<div n="lb">used only in the three first meanings as illustrated by some
<div n="lb">instances from their Sūtras; in the {%Vedānta Sūtras%} equally
<div n="lb">so, but in the {%later Vedānta%} it assumes also the sense)
<div n="lb"><sup>a.</sup> {%inculcation of a truth conveyed in sacred writings by means%}
<div n="lb">{%of repeating the same word or the same passage;%} it is one of
<div n="lb">the six characteristics of the {#SravaRa#} or ascertaining the pur-
<div n="lb">port of the Vedānta (see the enumeration of the other terms
<div n="lb">s. v. {#apUrvatA#}): {%Ved. Sāra:%} {#prakaraRapratipAdyasya vastunastanmaDye#}
<div n="lb">{#pOnaHpunyena pratipAdanamaByAsaH;#} by such repetitions are meant,
<div n="lb">according to the {%Ved. Sāra,%} e. g. that of the words {#tattvamasi#}
<div n="lb">which occur nine times in the sixth Prapāth. of the {%Chhānd.%}
<div n="lb">{%Upan.;%} or, acc. to {%Rāmakṛṣṇat.%} that of {#sa eza neti neti#}
<div n="lb">of the {%Bṛhadār.,%} or of the passage {#sa yaScAyam#} in the
<div n="lb">{%Taitt. Up.,%} or of the passages {#yenAkzaraM puruzaM veda satyam,#}
<div n="lb">{#tadetadakzaraM brahma, tamevEkaM vijAnITa AtmAnam#} (?) in the
<div n="lb">{%Muṇḍaka Up.,%} &c. (In the {%Sāṅkhya Prav.%} it has also the
<div n="lb">sense as illustrated before by instances from these Sūtras,
<div n="lb">but in the {%Sūtra%} 6. 29. and the {%Yoga%} it means) <sup>b.</sup> {%the effort%}
<div n="lb">{%of the mind to remain in its unmodified condition of purity%}
<div n="lb">{%(sattwa) or that condition which is free from the affections of%}
<div n="lb">{%passion (rajas) and sin (tamas): Yoga S.%} 1. 13.: {#tatra sTitO#}
<div n="lb">{#yatno'ByAsaH#} ({%Patanjali'%}s {%comm.:%} {#cittasyAvfttikasya praSAnta-#}
<div n="lb">{#vAhitA sTitiH#}--comp. 3. 10.--{#tadarTaprayatnI vIryamutsAhaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tatsaMpipAdayizayA tatsADanAnuzWAnamaByAsaH;#} {%Vāchaspatim.%} on
<div n="lb">these words: {#cittasyAvfttikasya rAjasatAmasavfttirahitasya#}
[Page319-b+ 56]
<div n="lb">{#praSAntavAhitA vimalatA sAttvikavfttivAhitEkAgratA sTitiH#}
<div n="lb">&c.; {%Bhojad. Rājamārt.:%} {#vfttirahitasya cittasya svarUpanizWA-#}
<div n="lb">{#pariRAmaH sTitiH#}); {%this effort becomes consolidated or firm if%}
<div n="lb">{%it is persevered in during a long time, unremittingly and%}
<div n="lb">{%through the accomplishments (of penance, chastity, wisdom and%}
<div n="lb">{%faith): Yoga S.%} 1. 14.: {#sa tu dIrGakAlanErantaryasatkArAsevito#}
<div n="lb">{#dfQaBUmiH#} ({%Patanj.'%}s {%comm.:%} {#dIrGakAlAsevitaH . nirantarAse-#}
<div n="lb">{#vitaH . tapasA brahmacaryeRa vidyayA SradDayA ca saMpAditaH satkA-#}
<div n="lb">{#ravAndfQaBUmirBavati . vyutTAnasaMskAreRa drAgityevAnaBiBUtavi-#}
<div n="lb">{#zaya ityarTaH;#} according to the {%Rājamārtaṇḍa ‘through the%}
<div n="lb">{%accomplishment of great respect’:%} {#bahukAlaM nErantaryeRAdarA-#}
<div n="lb">{#tiSayena ca sevyamAno dfQaBUmiH sTiro Bavati dArQyAya pra-#}
<div n="lb">{#BavatItyarTaH#}); it is together with {#vErAgya#} (q. v.) the means
<div n="lb">to hinder the modifications of the mind which are called
<div n="lb">{#pramARa, viparyaya, vikalpa, nidrA#} and {#smfti#} qq. vv.; {%Yoga S.%}
<div n="lb">1. 12.: {#aByAsavErAgyAByAM tanniroDaH;#} (comp. also the {%Sūtra%}
<div n="lb">1. 18.: {#virAmapratyayAByAsapUrvasaMskAraSezo'nyaH#}); the word is
<div n="lb">used in the stated sense in the {%S. Prav. Sūtra:%} {#DyAnaDAra-#}
<div n="lb">{#RAByAsavErAgyAdiBistanniroDaH#} ({%Vijnānabh.:%} {#samADidvArA#}
<div n="lb">{#DyAnaM yogasya kAraRaM DyAnasya ca kAraRaM DAraRA tasyASca kA-#}
<div n="lb">{#raRamaByAsaScittasTEryasADanAnuzWAnamaByAsasyApi kAraRaM vizaya-#}
<div n="lb">{#vErAgyam#} &c.); {#aByAsa#} has this {%technical%} Yoga-sense also,
<div n="lb">for instance, in these verses: {%Bhagavadgītā%} (6. 35.): {#asaMSayaM#}
<div n="lb">{#mahAbAho mano durnirgrahaM calam . aByAsena tu kOnteya vErA-#}
<div n="lb">{#gyeRa ca gfhyate#} ({%Śaṅkara:%} {#aByAso nAma cittaBUmO kasyAMci-#}
<div n="lb">{#tsamAnapratyayA vfttiH…gfhyate niruDyata ityarTaH;#} {%Sadānanda:%}
<div n="lb">{#aByAsena viSudDena vErAgyeRa nigfhyate . aByAso nAma kasyAM-#}
<div n="lb">{#ciccittaBUmO nirantaram . samAnapratyayA vfttiScittasyADiviyo-#}
<div n="lb">{#ginaH#}); or (12. 9.) {#aTa cittaM samADAtuM na Saknozi mayi sTiram .#}
<div n="lb">{#aByAsayogena tato mAmicCAptuM DanaYjaya ..#} ({%Śaṅk.:%} {#cittasyE-#}
<div n="lb">{#kasminnAlambane sarvataH samAhftya punaH punaH sTApanamaByAsaH .#}
<div n="lb">{#tatpUrvako yogaH samADAnalakzaRastenAByAsayogena#} &c.; {%Sadān.:%}
<div n="lb">{#cetasaH sTApanaM BUyo BUyo'ByAsaH sa ucyate . tatpUrvakasamA-#}
<div n="lb">{#Diryastena mAM prAptumISvaram#}) {#aByAse'pyasamarTo'si matkarmapara-#}
<div n="lb">{#mo Bava .…Sreyo hi jYAnamaByAsAjjYAnAdDyAnaM viSizyate .#}
<div n="lb">{#DyAnAtkarmaPalatyAgastyAgAcCAntiranantaram;#} or {%Mahābh. Śān-%}
<div n="lb">{%tip.:%} {#taTEtadantaraM vidyAtsattvakzetrajYayorbuDaH . aByAsAtsa taTA#}
<div n="lb">{#yukto na gacCetprakftiM punaH#} ({%Arjunam.:%} {#taTA nErmalyena yukto#}
<div n="lb">{#yadi tadA na prakftisaNgaM gacCet#} which explanation {#‘nErmalyena’#}
<div n="lb">will become intelligible when compared with the definition
<div n="lb">of the term, as applying to the condition of {#sattva#}); comp.
<div n="lb">also {%Mādhava'%}s {%Sarvadarś.:%} {#tatra maDumatI nAmAByAsavErAgyA-#}
<div n="lb">{#divaSAdapAstarajastamoleSasuKaprakASamayasattvaBAvanayAnavadyavE-#}
<div n="lb">{#SAradyavidyotanarUpa ftamBaraprajYAKyA samADisidDiH#}. <sup>7</sup> (In
<div n="lb">{%Grammar.%}) <sup>a.</sup> Reduplication (in general); e. g. {%Nirukta%} (on
<div n="lb">the word {#babDAm#}): {#AdinAByAsenopahitenopaDAmAdatte baBa-#}
<div n="lb">{#stirattakarmA#}. <sup>b.</sup> (In {%Pāṇini.%}) The first syllable of the re-
<div n="lb">duplicated base; {%Pāṇ.:%} {#pUrvo'ByAsaH#}. See the explanation
<div n="lb">s. v. {#aByasta#} 2. (In this sense, and not in the general sense
<div n="lb">{%reduplication,%} the term is also understood in the {%Vārttikas%}
<div n="lb">and the other commentaries on {%Pāṇ.;%} e. g. VI. 1. 12. v. 9;
<div n="lb">16. v. 3; 17. v. 1; 30. v. 1; 135. v. 5; VII. 4. 58. v. 1; 67. v. 1;
<div n="lb">82. v. 3; VIII. 2. 3. v. 7; 6. v. 11;--or I. 1. 65. paribh. 1;
<div n="lb">VII. 4. 83. paribh. 1. 2.)--<sup>8</sup> (In {%Poetry.%}) The repetition
<div n="lb">of a word or verse in a stanza, or of the stanza itself;
<div n="lb">e. g. {%Lāṭyāy. Śr. Sūtr.:%} {#aByAso gUrdasya#} (the stanza {%Sāmav.%}
[Page320-a+ 56]
<div n="lb">2. 457-459.) {#. aByAsAdiruttarezAM trayARAm#} ({%Agnisvāmin:%} {#dvi-#}
<div n="lb">{#tIyapAde yanmaDyamaM caturakzaramaByasyate sa pratihAraH#} &c.).--
<div n="lb">In the late artificial poetry there are four kinds of such
<div n="lb">repetitions which bear the name {#aByAsa,#} viz. {#pAdAByAsa,#}
<div n="lb">{#arDAByAsa, sarvAByAsa#} and {#SlokAByAsa#} qq. vv.; the general
<div n="lb">name, however, for repetitions of syllables, words or verses
<div n="lb">is {#yamaka#} q. v. (where all the names of the subdivisions will
<div n="lb">be found). <sup>9</sup> (In {%Arithmetic.%}) <sup>a.</sup> Multiplication; (more
<div n="lb">usual terms, however, are {#aBihati, Ahati, guRana#}). <sup>b.</sup> Pro-
<div n="lb">duct of multiplication; e. g. (for both meanings) {%Vījagaṇ.:%}
<div n="lb">{#vajrAByAsO jyezWalaGvostadEkyaM hrasvaM laGvorAhatiSca prakftyA . kzuRRA#}
<div n="lb">{#jyezWAByAsayugjyezWamUlaM tatrAByAsaH kzepayoH kzepakaH syAt;#} ‘the
<div n="lb">greatest and least roots are to be reciprocally multiplied
<div n="lb">crosswise; and the sum of the products to be taken for a
<div n="lb">least root. The product of the two (original) ‘least’ roots
<div n="lb">being multiplied by the given coefficient and the product
<div n="lb">of the ‘greatest’ roots being added thereto, the sum is the
<div n="lb">corresponding greatest root; and the product of the addi-
<div n="lb">tives will be the (new) additive’; {%Colebrooke'%}s {%Alg.%} p. 171.
<div n="lb"><sup>10</sup> (In {%military terminology.%}) Archery; (as such the word is
<div n="lb">named in several {%Koshas: Hem., Trik., Bhūripr.;%} while
<div n="lb">{%Hemach.%} e. g. sometimes adds the word for {%bow%} or {%arrow%}
<div n="lb">which is supplied; thus, {%nānārth.%} 3. 730.: {#AkarzaH pASake#}
<div n="lb">{#DanvAByAsANge dyUta indriye;#} or 4. 163.: {#upAsanamAsane . SuSrU-#}
<div n="lb">{#zAyAM SarAByAse#} &c.; elsewhere it has, with this sense and
<div n="lb">without the addition of {#Sara#} or {#Danu,#} not come under my ob-
<div n="lb">servation, except, where its elliptical sense may be easily
<div n="lb">supplied, in the) {%Dhanurveda:%} {#…kumBakena sTiraM kftvA huMkA-#}
<div n="lb">{#reRa visarjayet . ityaByAsakriyA kAryA DanvinA sidDimicCatA#}.
<div n="P">[II. Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. ({#-saH-sA-sam#}) The same as
<div n="lb">{#aByASa#} which is the more correct form.
<div n="P">2. m. ({#-saH#}) <sup>1</sup> Result, consequence; e. g. {%Chhānd. Up.:%}
<div n="lb">{#sa ya etamevaM vidvAnAdityaM brahmetyupAste'ByAso ha yadenaM sADa-#}
<div n="lb">{#vo GozA A ca gacCeyurupa ca nimreqerannimreqeran#} (ed. {%Röer%}
<div n="lb">p. 232); or {#AtmAnamantata upasftya stuvIta kAmaM DyAyannapramatto#}
<div n="lb">{#'ByAso ha yadasmE sa kAmaH samfDyeta#} &c. (ed. {%Röer%} p. 49).--
<div n="lb">See {#aByASa#} 3. <sup>2</sup> Neighbourhood, vicinity; e. g. {%Mahābh.%}
<div n="lb">{%Ādip.:%} {#rorUyamARasyAByAse BfSaM viprasya pARqavaH#} &c.; or
<div n="lb">{%Vanap.:%} {#tatrAByAsasTo'pi kaScinnApaSyat;#} or {%Rāmāy.:%} {#aByetya#}
<div n="lb">{#tvaramARaSca raTAByAsaM manIziRaH#} &c.; or {%Daśakum.:%} {#adarSaM#}
<div n="lb">{#ca mArgAByAsavartinaH kasyApi kzapaRavihArasya#} &c.--In both
<div n="lb">meanings the writing {#aByASa#} which occurs, too, in some
<div n="lb">Mss. of the passages quoted, is more correct. See the
<div n="lb">remark under the latter word, also as regards the masc.
<div n="lb">gender of the second meaning.] E. {#as#} with {#aBi,#} kṛt
<div n="lb">aff. {#GaY#}.
<LEND>

<L>6767<pc>320-a<k1>aByAsanimitta<k2>aByAsanimitta
{#aByAsanimitta#}¦ Tatpur. n. ({#-ttam#}) (In comm. on {%Pāṇini.%}) The
<div n="lb">cause of the reduplication-syllable; e. g. a {%Vārtt.%} in the
<div n="lb">{%Kāś.%} (not in the {%Bhāṣya%}) to {%Pāṇ.:%} {#svAperRyantasyAByAsanimi-#}
<div n="lb">{#ttena pratyayenAnantarye sati saMprasAraRamizyate#}. E. {#aByAsa#} and
<div n="lb">{#nimitta#}.
<LEND>

<L>6768<pc>320-a<k1>aByAsayoga<k2>aByAsayoga
{#aByAsayoga#}¦ Tatpur. m. ({#-gaH#}) Deep meditation preceded by
<div n="lb">the effort to keep the mind in its unmodified condition or
<div n="lb">in that of goodness. See {#aByAsa#} 6. b. and the instance
<div n="lb">p. 319{%b,%} 1. 30. Comp. {#aDyAsayoga#}. E. {#aByAsa#} and {#yoga#}.
<LEND>
